111111112112211211111222.content:
The white marble eyes of the lady moved around in the socket as she scanned Daniel’s expression. The skin on her face appeared as if it could peel off any moment, as she walked towards Daniel, such was the looseness and paleness of her skin. Her walk had an air of menace about it, those crouching jerky motions quite synced with the thoughts going on in her rotten mind; in some way it was quite like the walk of a leopard, who walks knowing that the prey won’t get away no matter how much the leopard dawdles. With every jerky step which the lady took, Daniel’s heartbeat wnet up a notch. His eyes went towards the lady’s feet to find the cause of such awkward walk – what he saw he couldn’t believe and he felt the hair on the back of his neck rise. Although the darkness in the room didn’t allow him to anything much but he was sure that he saw her feet were turned around with the ball of the heels facing Daniel. It was as if her body, waist down onwards, was of somebody else who was standing with his face in the opposite direction. She looked at Daniel’s face and flashed a smile at him, looked at her legs and said –
“That happened on an exorcism night, Daniel. That was a bad bad day,” she added in a hushed tone.

There was something about the way in which she said it that made Daniel even more comfortable than he was. That nasal voice of hers could pierce through glass and right now, it was piercing through the bravado and courage of Daniel. She was now standing at an arm’s distance from Daniel, whose lungs were tiring from filtering breathable air from the most putrid of environments.

Daniel knew he had to solve this mystery before it went further into his head and stressed him even more. He gathered courage to look into those sickening eyes which were piercing his soul and asked –
“Who are you?”
Daniel’s room reverberated with the sound of the lady’s laugh which seemed more and more sinister as it went on.
“I am Haddiva from beyond the living realm.”

Daniel was not overtly surprised about it since he somehow felt that the soul standing in front of him wasn’t from the realm of the breathing ones. He asked –
“And why are you here, Haddiva?”

“To serve my master,” she said with a smile which curved her lips but didn’t reach her eyes, ”and that would be you, Daniel.”
Daniel had heard this before and he wanted the “why” of it.

“You are from the dead, Haddiva, and you belong to that place. Who called you here?”
Daniel noticed that Haddiva’s face contorted when he said those words to her – it was if someone had pricked a needle in her heart –but she was now regaining normalcy.
“Nobody calls me, Daniel,” her voice shivered with suppressed anger as she said those words, “but I come to those who belong to me.”
“Belong to you? Why do you think I belong to you, Haddiva?” Daniel was peeling off the layers one by one in order to reach to pit the truth.
Haddiva’s eyebrows curved upwards as if surprised by Daniel’s comments –
“How could you not remember it, Daniel? You sacrificed your own mother for me,” she smiled again, slightly opening her mouth which very looked like the hell in which Daniel’s brain was getting sucked into. Daniel’s head was spinning like a whirlpool in the middle of a wild river. Leave alone him, but how could anyone sacrifice their own mother, the one guardian angel we are blessed with! He held his head and crashed to his bed.
Daniel was raised by his grandmother alone in a village far beyond the Stark Realm. Ever since he remembered, he hadn’t seen her mother or even father for that matter. Grandma said that Father went through the Re-Re forest once, to collect food he told them but never returned back. And his mother – well he knew nothing about his mother. Every time he had asked to get the facts straight with Grandma, she had avoided it like plague, as if something rotten was behind it. Grandma not only shooed the topic away but did it with such force and thrust that he felt below dignity to raise it again with her. As if something more was there to it than what met the eye. Those images from his conversations with Grandma were now flashing in his mind. He could see in them how pained Granny looked every time that topic was brought up. And then, an image hijacked his mind which gave him a bolt of sorts; it was the image of his grandmother trying to say something to him. He remembered now that she had started to tell him about his mother dying while giving birth to him. She was now opening up about his father who had left for the forest to never come back and that is when she started to choke, as if somebody was pulling her breaths away from her. She was sick, and on some really cold and foggy days she did have problems while talking, but this felt something different as if some invisible force was strangling her, not wanting to let her talk any further about it. He remembered her waving her arms around as someone who is choked would and then falling silent all of a sudden. Tears ran down his eyes as he relived those heart wrenching images in his heart. He cursed himself that he didn’t push her Granny more for it back then because as what now seemed pretty certain was that there was something evil behind it all and he knew nothing about it till today.
Haddiva was looking at him all this while, as he murmured and cursed himself. She knew what he was going through but just to be sure she decided to ask her –

“You don’t know that your mother was killed as she gave birth to you?” her voice was dull, monotonus and had no trace of earnestness in it; all what it had was malice.
Daniel flung his stare to her, as it could cut her to pieces – “But, I didn’t kill her,” he said, gnashing his teeth.
“Maybe you didn’t but your birth did, Daniel and there is no denying – “
“What could a child do if the mother dies while giving birth. What is there which a child could do, Haddiva?”
She thought for a while, as if considering before revealing some secret, and then said, “But maybe, your father could have.”

“Father!” a look of angst and surprise came on his face, “Father was away in the forest, Haddiva. He had gone missing some months before my birth.” Daniel wasn’t even sure of whether Haddiva was saying the truth but it didn’t stop him from feeling awful about it, as his mind made him relive those old wounds again.
Haddiva had the coldest of smile on her face as she spoke – “But did you ever question your mother why your father went away, Daniel?”

“I did – that is what I told you. That is what I know!” Daniel was now screaming at the top of his lungs.

“How gullible little kid are you, Daniel?” she sniggered, “she tells you that father was lost in the forest and you take that? I pity you,” she smiled some more.

Daniel moved threateningly towards Haddiva and muttered under his breath – “One more word about me or my family, Haddiva and I would – “
“You would what? Kill me? Kill the darkest of spirits which inhabit the land of the living, Daniel?” she laughed on his face, “Poor gullible little kid,” she tut-tutted.

Daniel had had enough of her; his tightened hand landed with such force on Haddiva’s cheeks that it made a thudding sound so loud that the birds sitting on the tree flew away. Haddiva was violently pushed to a side by another shove from Daniel who was now walking towards the window of the room. He stood there looking outside for some time, taking deep breaths to take his mind away from what all he had heard till then.

“Was this all true? Was he the reason behind the death of his mother? Was there something else behind the disappearance of his father?” many more questions such as these bulleted in his mind as he considered the possibilities of the story which Haddiva was trying to say.

Just then, he heard her whisper - “Like father, like son,” and she whispered it just loudly enough for it to reach Daniel’s ears. He turned to look at Haddiva who still had that sickening smile on her pale, dead face.
He walked towards her with urgent steps and said –

“What do you want from me, Haddiva?”

“I have told you before too, Daniel. I want to fulfill your wishes – especially the darkest of them.”
“Tell me about my father, will you” Daniel said, with tears burning his eyes, without even listening to what Haddiva offered to him.
“Or you could ask for the ultimate power in the darkest of realms?” Haddiva teased her, not thinking twice about her tears. Daniel didn’t answer but his red eyes did which were baying for her blood.

“I know you want to, Daniel – just like your father,” she said with that manic smile again, ”you were a blessing from Satan which was got after sacrificing your mother for it. Poor Mother, little did she knew that her husband didn’t go to the forest to just bring the woods but he also went there to raise the dead from the morgue. He was a necromancer, Daniel, he was a NECROMANCER!” Haddiva’s thunderbolt hit Daniel with quite some force and he plopped to his bed.

Queen Hannah slipped off her mare and it ran away back into the woods. The three hags approached her, seeming to float on the air like ghosts. They smelled like moss left out in the sun or brambles under the roses. They each had different color hair; one had silver gray hair that streamed behind her like a lace curtain, another had hair a fierily red with green stripes, short and curly, the last was bald, shaven to the deep mahogany skin. Or what she thought was skin. It had a pattern on it that resembled tree bark and not the smooth skin of most human types

Queen Hannah was not afraid. These three looked like her book club old ladies before discussing Fifty Shades of Gray, a book some had thrown against a wall and others had put through a blender half way through reading it. She, herself, had torn the pages out and used it for paper on the bottom of the royal parrot's cage. Inner goddess, indeed, thought Hannah. More like an inner prepubescent.

The hags waved their arms at her, all pointy fingernails, black with something, wailing away, coming closer.

Queen Hannah planted her tiny feet on the ground and crossed her arms. "Oh, go away and bother someone else. I have many things to do today. That sword looks like you got it out of the five and dime store or a high school musical. And whoever that was you gave it to is obviously the village simpleton. I don't know what you want but hurry about your way, I am Queen Hannah and too important for the likes of you. Plus, you stink. Sorry, I know it's not politically correct to call a homeless old person a stinky person, but you three could use a good hot bath at the YMCA. Plus, they have cots you can sleep on and some clean clothes to wear. The ones you have on are all tattery and torn. How do I know about the YMCA, you may ask yourself, or selves, being a Queen and all. Well, my Uncle Jasper liked a little too much of the gin bottle and smoked a little too many bunches of gangee to have a straight head. He lost his job and ended up at the YMCA for about a year or so. Best thing that ever happened to him. He fell down the stairs and broke his leg and.."

The hags were getting agitated. they weren't use to humans not running away from them and screaming. It ruined their act. They menaced closer. The red haired hag stuffed moss in her ears to try and drown out the whiney, sing song voice of Hannah the Queen.

"..and then he ended up in the hospital and met the cutest little nurse's aide who took pity on him and got him on the straight and narrow. He owns a furniture story now and sells those chairs you lay in, you know, a Lazy Boy chair? Oh, look, you three need a manicure. Your nails have brown and green fungus all over them! I know a great manicurist in East Hedgerow over in the North Kingdom. If you don't mind a dwarf doing your nails, they do a wonderful job, much better than the pixies who tend to get more of the nail color all over themselves and the floor rather than your nails. So let me just pull Chez Beauty's card out of my sleeve (that's where I keep all my cards, you know, better than a purse, although sometimes they fall out into my soup).." the Queen chattered on.

The hags had had enough. The silver haired hag reached out with bony hands and grabbed the Queen's long, slender neck. She startled. The hag's fingers went right through the air, as though the Queen wasn't there at all.

"Ha, ha, you old witches with a b! You think I got to be Queen by being a fool? I am a first class ventriloquist, and a second class mirage maker. The great Houdini taught me all he knew before he got sucker punched. You will never find me! I was sure and researched all I could about these parts before I came over. Don't you know there is a Fodor's guide to the kingdom? Of course, I don't use that one. Too conservative for me. I prefer to use the Lonely Planet's Guide to the GOT Kingdom, version 2.12. In English, although I heard the elfin version had.." the Queen prattled on and on and on.

The hags passed their one eyeball around to each other and stared. They tried to strangle the image of Queen Hannah again, but is was like trying to squeeze a mist. The red haired hag kicked a horny foot onto the mirage Queen's buttocks. That really made the queen laugh.

She laughed so hard, she fell over, feet over kimble, Her tall crown fell off her head and she lost another crown jewel (really they were the faux jewels, the king didn't let the real one out of the vault. Queen Hannah was forever losing things or getting into battles. He tried to explain to her that a crown was not a disc to be hurled, and her staph was not a sword, but Queen Hannah would use whatever was handy.)

"That's not fair," growled the silver haired hag. "You aren't playing by the fantasy rules. You're supposed to be a helpless female who needs a strong knight to come save her. We even polished up our eye to scare you better with. Don't you know who we are? We are the three witchy hags of the forest! We eat gross things and moan and groan. We strangle small children."

"Well, shame on you, then,"scolded the mirage Queen. "You should know better than that. Small children make good pets, sometimes. Why waste them? I have a whole prison full of scumbags you are all welcome to so I don't have to keep feeding them and entertaining them. Did you know they gave me a list of commands? The nerve of them! Well ladies, it was nice to chat, but I have things to do and people to be royal to. If you would like my card, here, let me look up my sleeve.."

The hags vanished in a poof of air. They knew they wouldn't get anywhere with this crazy queen. They felt bad for the king, though. They promised themselves they would send him a big fruit basket next Yule tides

After the hags were gone, Queen Hannah removed the invisibility cloak she had borrowed from a brat of a boy named Harry, and lifted her not so delicate nose in the air.

Yep, they are gone, thought the Queen. The air smelled like pine and poppies again. Speaking of poppies, the Queen felt her stomach rumble. She pulled out a long loaf of Frenchified bread, a pat of European butter (made by elves of course) and a knife to spread from her sleeve. A couple of cards were stuck in the butter, so she pulled them out after licking the delicious creamy yellow butter off them.

Oh, well, they weren't readable anymore, she thought. I can get more. But this bread is divine!

While the Queen was devouring her bread and in plain sight in the opening, without her invisibility cloak on, a creature started to creep up on her. It was attracted to the heavenly smell of fresh baked bread and oozy warm butter. The creature..

Ask.

The geese disappeared in the mist, but were guided by an inner directional sense. They flew south by southwest for a few hours, before finding themselves near the BeastMaster’s home. Spying the telltale signs of the BeastMaster. They knew they were close when predators and prey were seen roaming fields side by side. Normally aggressive predators acted as meek as sheep, yet none appeared hungry. Surely some magic beside the BeastMasters ability to control the beasts was at work!

         Finally they spied a small wood cabin that they innately knew belonged to the BeastMaster. As they landed, he emerged from inside and looked at them with a smile on his face.

         “I’ve been expecting you my friends. What causes you to visit me in such a rush?”

         “BeastMaster, we beseech thee, please kind sir! As geese, the wise ones of the land will not listen to our advice. We are cut off before we can complete a sentence, mocked to our faces. If only we can be wise like you, or human even. We have heard you know magic, by chance is there a spell you can cast that will allow us to be listened to?”

         “My friends, come inside, let’s sit and talk a little, and decide exactly what it is you wish.”

         The BeastMaster led them inside his spacious cabin. It had looked so small from the air, and while talking outside, but once inside it was a veritable castle! Once they were all seated comfortably, the BeastMaster asked, “Now, exactly what would you like of me? Yes, I can do many things to help you, and will do so gladly.”

         BeastMaster couldn’t help but smile as the geese talked among themselves. Finally, the elder shushed the rest and turned to him and said, “Sire, if it’s not asking too much, we’d like to be wise beyond years, and human.”

         “Well, I have his number still. At least I think I do. It’s somewhere here in my notebook.”

         Saying that, Yore pulled his notebook from his desk and scanned through the pages. “Ah, here it is! Right next to my name. I remember now telling myself that if I put his name someplace I knew well, I’d always find it.”

         He gave the notebook to Electra, then handed her the phone. She looked at it curiously as he punched the number in on the keypad.          Yore grabbed the phone from Electra and put it to his ear. Finally a voice on the other end answered, “Who’s calling me at this time of the evening?”

         “Uh sir, it is I, Yore, I’m sorry to disturb you. But there are seven women here who were arrested for shoplifting. They say the only person they know is you. Knowing my past and all, you know I still have your number. Just in case… uh , just in case I want to return, you know, right?”

         “Yore! You’re not going back, get that thought out of your mind! What’s going on with these women? Let me speak to one of them!”

         Yore handed to phone to Electra. She had watched closely as Yore spoke with the BeastMaster, and confidently took it from him. She placed it next to her ear, upside down. “BeastMaster, we need help! You didn’t tell us about shopping, that things need to be paid for! What shall we do now?”

         “Which one of you is this? I don’t quite have your voices down yet, but I will.”

         “Ah yes, now I remember. You’re the only one who managed to walk out of my house without waddling. Let me speak to Yore for a moment, we’ll have this taken care of.”

         Electra handed the phone back to Yore and said, “He wants to tell you what to do with us.”

         Yore took the phone and listened intently. The only thing the girls heard was an occasional “Uh huh”, “Yes Sir”, and “No Sir”. When the call was finished, he turned to the girls and said, “He’s on his way. BeastMaster is not an easy man to cross, so don’t get on his wrong side.          “Are you sure you can handle this old Yore? Are you sure you want an anchor like this?”

         BeastMaster looked at the sisters and said, “I know Yore has told you what I’m going to do. However, I am only going to change 6 of you back. Yore has needed a mate since his changing…” There was quite a commotion at this announcement, and quite a few questions about Yore’s changing. Finally getting the sisters quieted, BeastMaster said, “Yes, at one time, Yore was like you, and underwent the changing process. He’s done well, and has served me well. It’s time to reward him. Like I said, I only need six of you, and he likes Electra the most. I know, I know. But I don’t have 6 more donkeys acting as human around here, so I can’t find mates for all of you! Besides, I already have seven swans a swimming. Maybe the rest of you six sisters can lay eggs and raise some young. And, if we do happen to find any suitors, I will change you back just like I did this time. Now, lay down and sleep, for tomorrow you regain your former beauty.”

         With that, the BeastMaster walked out of the jail, leaving the sister still having a fit, and Yore with a silly grin on his face…

111121112211.title: Hannah and Spender set off on their journey

1111211122111.content:
As the two young people ride along the deserted forest road in the moonlight, the stark outlines of the shadows of the trees slash the ground ahead. The hot breath of the cantering horses steams from their nostrils and mingles with a gathering ethereal mist which rises from the damp evening ground.

Anya’s mind floods with memories of other headlong rides through the night. She had fled from King’s Landing disguised as a boy to escape Joffrey’s Guard, just after her father had been murdered. Her sister had not been so lucky. As far as Anya knew, she was still a virtual prisoner in the Capital. The following months had been a constant, vital battle to keep her identity hidden from the others in the party. Eventually, she had come to regard some of them as trusted companions.

Two years had not noticeably dimmed the feeling of being hounded that had dogged her on that fateful journey. Many times she and her companions had faced discovery and death. They had endured privations and hardship, had been at her side throughout, and had become a loyal band, looking out for each other as they fled from the capital. Some had not survived. She wondered what had become of those who had. Rumours were rife in these troubled times.

She was younger then, a mere child, really, but her will had been strong, and it was, subsequently, to be tempered in the fire of danger. Her present steely resolve was the result. As her recollections of that trying time fill her thoughts, this resolve hardens. ‘King Joffrey will pay for all the pain he has caused to my family and friends.’ She tightens her hold on the reins and increases her speed to catch up with Spender, who has raced in front.

Anya’s thoughts snap back to the present as she realises that Spender has reined in his horse up ahead of her. She eases back on the speed of her horse, Midnight, and trots to her cousin’s side. He is standing up in his stirrups, listening. Off in the distance there is the thunder of hooves. It seems as if many riders are on the road, approaching from the opposite direction.

“We don’t want to be seen here!” Both horses are snorting and tossing their heads. “We must get off the road and hide until they pass.” His voice echoes in the stillness as he turns his mount towards the trees. Anya follows him deep into the undergrowth where they dismount. They have barely had a chance to conceal themselves, and settle the horses, before the first rider appears.

Anya gasps and sinks further down as the imposing figure heaves into view. He is wreathed in a swirling white mist which leaks sideways into the forest, and he sits astride a magnificent, pure, white charger, which has a flowing silver mane and tail streaming out behind it, in the back current of the forward motion. Every part of the leather saddle and harness are studded with burnished silver.

A silver helmet in the form of an eagle’s head sits on top of the rider’s head, glinting in the moonlight, and a flowing plume surmounts its brow. A thick fur cape is fastened around his neck. His face is shrouded in shadows, but his eyes glow with a piercing blue light.

“A White Walker! So far south!” Anya’s horrified gasp is quickly stifled as the rider draws nearer.
Behind him ride a horde of insubstantial figures who seem to be part of the mist. As the horde approach, the White Walker pauses and the tumult of the hooves subsides leaving behind a sibilant whispering.

Anya feels a chill creep over her as the mist seems to surge out towards her from the deathly form on the white charger. An aroma of death and decay fill her nostrils. Seconds elongate, as time seems to stretch. The two cousins press themselves closer to the ground and pray to the Old Gods to keep them hidden. It seems that the old Gods are listening. The mist flows around them before it ebbs back towards the forest edge once more.

With a flourish of his reins, the White Walker surges forward once more, with the swathes of ghostly horsemen following in his wake. The ground trembles as they pass. As the tumult subsides, muffled by the trees as the riders disappear down the way that Anya and Spender had come, the icy white mist lingers at the margins of the forest and filters through the trees.

Anya and Spender stay where they are for a while, not quite believing that they have escaped the scrutiny of the the White Walker and his horde. Gradually, they begin to shift from their uncomfortable positions and with many glances down the road that the host had disappeared along, they emerge from the undergrowth and squat down under an old oak tree to gather their strength.

“I didn’t think the White Walkers had come this far south.” Anya’s voice shakes with emotion. “Surely the Wall has not been breached?” She drops her head in despair at this turn of events.

“There was talk in the tavern, but I didn’t give it much credence.” Spender brushes at the leaves clinging to his coat in distraction. “This means things are much more dangerous for the whole of the Kingdom, not just for us.” The sound of the horses cropping the nearby grass fills the ensuing silence as the two young people sit deep in thought for several minutes.

“No matter!” Anya gets to her feet and dusts off some clinging ivy tendrils. “We still need to deal with the events in hand and get to the crossroads.” Spender gathers up the reins of the horses as she speaks and passes those belonging to Midnight to her. “We must be vigilant on the rest of the journey.”

“It will be slower but safer if we stay off the main road and travel through the trees for a while.” Spender mounts his horse and turns its head in a westerly direction, through the trees, and away from the road.

“You are right, as usual.” Anya mounts Midnight and follows his lead. They move off in single file, as fast as the trees and undergrowth will allow. It was going to be a long night.

Anya and Spender pick their way through the darkness of forest. The passage they follow is long and arduous but the Old Gods are watching over them and they encounter no more obstacles to reaching their destination. The sky lightens to the east and they venture out on to the open road once more.

Here, they make better time without the undergrowth and trees to hamper their progress. They pass several small parties of other travellers, some going in the opposite direction, others in the same direction. They pass, without incident. One or two small parties are camped at the edge of the road. A few others have made camp a little way off the beaten track. None of them give more than a cursory look at the two travellers on the road.

The area around it is packed with other travellers, many readying themselves to leave. A number of soldiers dressed in the livery of King Joffrey are either lounging about or patrolling the assembly with watchful eyes.

Anya and Spender dismount and lead their horses to the back of the Inn, their heads lowered to avoid being seen by the soldiers. They pay the stable hand and he takes the horses inside the stable to rub them down, feed, and water them.

The two figures blend into the general melee. No one seems to be paying them much attention. They move about the area for a time, their eyes taking in all, then, make their way back to the Inn. There is no sign of the Lannister spy so far. They take up a vantage point at a table at one of the windows, order some food and drink, and settle down to watch the road outside for his arrival. They know he has to come here and meet with his contact before noon the next day.

The barmaid brings their food and they eat it in silence, each one deep in their own thoughts. They must be vigilant and prepared to act at a moment’s notice. All through that day they watch and wait, taking turns to stretch their legs. They know that this meeting must be stopped at all costs.

They don't know how they will manage it but both feel confident that when the time comes, they will find a way to complete their mission.

Talen fumed but he responded rightly this time. "I seek your priestess."

The dwarf laughed in his face, much to his annoyance. "Kyra will not like the company of a outland visitor, she is more tempered than me, I'm afraid."

The Dragon's Spleen Inn was a haunt of the roughest and toughest citizens of the land. There was not a night that went by when at least one of her patrons would be rushed to a medical centre or a mortuary. Nobody dared to enter the place sober and nobody dared to refuse a drink when offered, which was why the spy had been so intoxicated upon his return.

The Inn had been surprisingly empty when the spy had entered. There had been a couple of men, a few forest-dwellers, two firewraiths, and a couple of necromancers. Despite the fact that they were all from different walks of life and from different lands, they were all huddled around one large table in the far corner.

Although their voices were hushed, the spy was able to tell that the group was arguing. The men were waving their arms about and the firewraiths were glowing a dangerous shade of blue. The necromancers were the only people at the table who seemed to be relaxed.

The spy took a seat at a table close enough to the group of conspirators so that he could eavesdrop, yet far enough away so that he would not appear too obvious or be taken for a threat. He summoned the barman and began drinking.

Most of the conversation he overheard was mundane and filled with the usual centuries-old mistrust that existed between the great races. Although this group seemed to tolerate each other, the only two races who really got along were the necromancers and the firewraiths; that was only because they both drew on the ancient dark magics that man had long forgotten about, and they both shared a common ancestral bloodline.

After drinking three or four glasses of mandrake wine, the spy was well away with the faeries. However, it was only then that the conversation he was listening in on took a decidedly dark turn. There was a legend as old as time about The End of Days, and how it would ride in on the backs of four demons - the demons of earth, air, fire and water. The End of Days would herald in an age of evil the like of which no man could imagine, and the necromancers had already summoned the demon of earth.

The spy knew he had to report back to his master, and quickly.

11131.content:
The spy snoozed in a corner chair, dreaming mandrake wine dreams. The wild tales of a drunken informant wouldn't normally raise alarm, but this fellow was usually a fairly reliable source. Still, if it had been just this fellow, it might be chalked up to the wine, or the mad imaginings of fire wraiths and necromancers overheard.

But it was not just one wild eyed report. His whisperers had all been whispering similar tales of nebulous fright. Nothing that could be named, nothing that could be taken in hand, nothing, but the whispers had all risen in chorusing unanimity, cacophonous as it was alarming.

What to do. He was of three minds. What should he do for his own personal safety and continuance? What might he do in service of the Realm, as it had always been in this way that his own best interest had been served, at least to this point? How might he discover the source of this threat and so avoid what must be disasterous?

It all came down to information. He'd had an ear full of the stuff, too much, but none of it clear. There was no way to know what would help him survive if he didn't know what was coming. Exasperated, he settled on a course with his usual decisiveness.

I must not appear to be as ignorant as I am. In service of the Keeper of the Realm such was invitation to punishment from above or undermining and replacement by his peers. Neither would serve. He drew from his desk his favorite tools of the trade, slipping them into hidden pockets and strapping them to his person. Weapons for stealthy killing, impliments for the foiling of locks, and small magics to aid in remaining free to do as he pleased. These were his stock and trade when he'd been like the fellow who snoozed in the chair, just an informant. I must see what is wrong with my own eyes, he thought. All these hints are confused by fear. I must see for myself.

But he was not just that simple sneak-thief of secrets, he had expanded his skills in the areas of the mind. What he most needed, beyond seeing the state of the realm for himself, was the opinion of a man he trusted who's skills were as great as his own if in other areas. Enalphose, his old comrade and true friend. If anyone would have the sense of this dark storm that was rising, he would.

He shrugged into his old grey cloak, nearly black, like true shadow, and comfortable. He stepped through the door to his receiving room and spoke to his assistant, Miss Jones. "Jones? Do give Enalphose word that I will seek him at the usual place in three days time. There is foul doings afoot. I would have his thoughts on what comes our way."

Secure in Jones' competence he slips out into the Realm.

Od came face to face with the serving page’s hundred and ninety seven year old great grandmother. “Callest me hag, wouldst thou?”
Od was shocked at being addressed so, but not as shocked as the page. “Great-granna, please ware thy tongue. Know who it is thou speak against?”
“Aye. ‘Tis the man who as babe I changed his diapers.” Od now recognised the face of the woman who had been his wet-nurse; the woman he had been raised to respect as much as his own kith and kin.
“The boy tells that you knowest about the End of Days. That is was summoned in your younger time.”
The White One turned to her grandson and cuffed him harshly about the ear. “The boy’s tongue wags more than is good for it! Now runneth along home Kaden, and tarry not in the markets.”
Kaden excused himself from the presence of the two adults, and did as he was bade.
“Speak, please,” Od said.
“Very well. I shall speaketh of the terror of my childhood.”

It began in the foretime, in the days of the previous Keeper of the Realm. He was a strong true man in his youth, but by the time these events took place he had become quick to judge and was rash in his decisions. It was that rashness that not only caused the summoning of the End of Days, but also paved the way for our current powerful and benevolent Keeper, the Great GotWitch, to assume guardianship of the realm. May Her Extreme Greatness preserve the Realm for all time.
There was a plague of firepixies destroying the realm, and there was but one person who knew of the magics to defeat them. The granna of the Keeper was the most magical of the White Ones and was the last of our line to know that magic, but she had been departed for near twelve seasons.
Gilgamesh, the Supreme Necromancer of the time, offered to summon the deceased so that her magic could save the realm. The Keeper agreed without hesitation, as to deny the necromancer’s offer would have meant death for the realm. His granna was summoned, and within two sunrises the firepixies were banished back to their realm. However, instead of returning the summoned back from whence she had come, Gilgamesh used her in the darkest and foulest of rituals just to glimpse the future.
The Keeper found out, and Gilgamesh was banished to the wastelands, but not before he swore vengeance would be his. It took him near three seasons, but he finally collected all of the Five Substances.
As commanded in the ritual, he had then endured the Austerities for three years. He had gone without clothing since finding the last substance (leaving him blistered and burnt from the harsh suns that beat down), he had denied himself water on five separate occasions for fifteen sunrises (leaving him blind and near madness), and he had fasted once each year for fifty sunrises (leaving him horribly emaciated). None who clapped eyes upon him, would recognise the once great Gilgamesh.
With his dying breath and dying magic, he did the unpardonable. He summoned the Elemental Demons and the End of Days.
The demon of earth was the first to come. He laid waste unto the lands and the harvests. The grounds shook with such ferocity that the gods would have felt it and people feared the sky wouldst surely fall.
The demon of water came on a great tsunami. He flooded the lands and drowned hundreds of citizens of our fair realm.
The demon of air summoned sandstorms and great whirling dervishes. Houses were uprooted and deposited hundreds of leagues away. The rich and the poor alike were left homeless. Even the great castle of the Keeper was destroyed.
The demon of fire scorched the land in preparation for The Coming. Great seas of magma were called from the bowels of the realm. It brought yet more suffering, as it ushered in The End of Days.
The sun was blotted out by the chariots of the Unseelie Court who rode day and night bringing misery to all they came into contact with. The rivers ran with the screams of the tormented. "I trust you have news for me, William."

"Yes, my Lord." The spy stood where he had , shuddering ever so slightly at the cold. "I was down at the Inn."

"Sit." The lord gestured at the seat opposite him. "What did you hear?"

"The usual ramblings of the magic men - the wraiths and the faeries. Now however I fear their mad musings have merit. I -" He hesitated. "I heard them speaking of the demons. Of the End of Days."

For a moment there was silence, then Hawthorne burst out laughing. "You young and your wild fantasising. There are no such things as demons, William. Not anymore. They were rid of the Earth some three hundred years ago."

"No, my Lord," William pressed. "The necromancers. They -"

"They couldn't summon a spirit worth a dime, even if I laid a knife to their own necks."

"But my Lord-"

"Enough, William." Lord Hawthorne was losing his patience. "Do not make a fool of me, boy. Go now and find something of import or I shall I leave you to rot in the dungeons for all the good it would do me."

The spy, William, left his lord's tower the next morning. He'd made up his mind to forget about the End of days, certainly Hawthorne was right. There were no demons. He would know, the story had been drilled into him - into them all - during his childhood.

"Black smoke." His caregiver had told him in an ominous tone. He had been nothing but a child of five when he'd heard the stories but he remembered them as though it were yesterday. "Black smoke with talons sharp enough to slice air itself. They had eyes but they had fire and they spewed brimstone from their mouths. They wielded magic, magic of the earth and magic of blood. To feed their magic, they lusted on the soul. The souls of men and that of their own, as well.

The reigned supreme over all the beings on the planet, even the dragons. Everyone feared the dark ones - the shadow walkers, they called them. Then arose the Great War. The benign beings of this realm objected to their vile, dark ways and rose up against the demons - only one thing could purge the earth of their bloodlusting existence and it was a sacrifice. A hundred warlocks sacrificed themselves - they did not die rather they were promised to the service of the realm. They called them the mal'akh and they wielded the only weapons that could destroy the demons. In one colossal battle the reign of the demons ended and the earth was purged of every one of them. The peace would last for a long time, it was promised, yet none knew how long it would last."

How promising, William thought as he headed into a forest grove. He wanted to get away from the city tonight. Tomorrow he would ride down to the neighbouring village and listen to more rumours. William sighed as he lead his horse to a stream. What had his life come to? He was reduced to being the ears of a noble man. Since when had he started being a hired rumour monger?

He remembered, of course. It had started the day his father died, he thought bitterly.

No. William thought, strongly. I refuse to go down that road again.

After his horse had drunk enough f the water, William threw down his saddle and decided to stay near the stream for a while. He loved getting lost in the woods and hearing the whisperings of leaves for a change. They were good company - they certainly didn't talk of sinister things like the end of the world, for starters.

The water rippled by softly and William took off his riding boots. He perched himself on a rock and let his toes touch the water beneath him. It felt cool and relieved his worries instantly. He sat there for a long time until the sun was overhead. It calmed him down, listening to the forest sounds - this wood had ferns, soft grasses and evergreen trees the towered over him and extended well into the sky. Occasionally, a bird would chirp in the constant hum of the grasshoppers. He sat there until the smell of fresh earth and wild grass filled his lungs and cleared his mind.

Slwoly reality set back in and he decided that he would have to head back soon, else ride in the forest at night - as comforting as the forest was during the day, the second option terrified him and rightly. The Wildswood still had it's wildness, only the beasts came to play after dusk.

He was just about to get up when he heard it. A telltale rustle of leaves, the kind that signalled the approach of a person. But it was so soft he wondered if it was a child or perhaps one of the birds flying down. William didn't stand up though, he merely looked around, his eyes sharp, his ears shaper still.

There - behind the tree.

William slowly got to his feet, careful not to make any noises.

He didn't bother with his boots, treading lightly to the tree, his dagger in his hand. Once he was close, he moved fast, quickly moving to the other side of the tree to see -

The most beautiful creature he'd ever laid eyes on.

The nymph held his gaze, her hazel eyes searching his face curiously. There considered good luck, the wood nymphs or dryads. It was very rare to see them in their work, while they weaved their forest magic. She didn't bother running away or vanishing, as they usually did. Instead she held his gaze for a long time.

William couldn't shake it off. The nymph was so beautiful. Her slender form was swathed in dark silks, her hair as red as a flame, her doe eyes deep and curious. Her tanned skin adorned gold flecks - sigils of sorts. She looked like a dream, so much so that William reached out to her without even realising it.

I climbed the stone steps until I reached the top of the turret. As I stood staring out at the realm I felt my anger slowly ebb from my body. There, in the east, the banner of the House Stark fluttered in the wind. A sudden fear gripped me.
"Surely not them," I mumbled. "They are my most loyal subjects. They are industrious, hard working, and most important, they fear me."
I turned my face to the south and frowned. There, across the verdant field lay the remains of the House of Martell followers.
"Lazy, good for nothing buggers," I said. I knew the Martell house members to be the worst of my subjects. They dealt in money games, they drank heavily, they participated in games of chance, and worst of all I knew their intentions, their secret, diabolical intentions.
Shaking my fist at their flags that lay flaccid, I shouted, "Never! You will never wrest the throne from my benevolent grasp." My words were gobbled up by the soft breeze blowing over my shoulders.
I needed a plan. Something simple I told myself. Something no one would suspect. I had to call on my most trusted ally. I walked to the guard standing watch at the head of the stairs.
"You, guard," I said. "Do you know the maestro?
The guard lifted the metal grill protecting the lower portion of his face. "Yes, of course, my queen. Everyone knows him." As he spoke I couldn't help noticing that his beady eyes traveled over my beautiful body. I felt myself warm inside. Stop it! I told myself.
"Go and fetch him," I commanded. "Bring him to me."
I could hear the guard's suit of armor creak as he walked down the stairs, and I vowed to purchase a case of 3-in-1 oil and maybe some WD-40. Maintenance of the guard's protective equipment would be useful when I hatched my plan. I returned to the rampart to wait for the maestro.
As I gazed upon my realm I could hear the sound of metal scraping against metal, and soon the guard stepped from the darkness. He stooped and placed his hands on his knees and he tried to catch his breath. He spoke a moment later, his breathing still a bit labored.
"I'm getting too old for this s--"
"Enough of that kind of talk," I said. How many times had I instructed my commander of the guard to make sure these men stayed in shape? I would see to that later.
"Well," I said. "Did you find the maestro?" Again his eyes traveled over me, and the metal grill covering his face did little to hide the gleam of his blue eyes. Attractive eyes, I told myself. In fact, the way he filled out his chain mail shirt made my skin warm again. But the sound of footsteps on the stone steps pulled me from the beginnings of a rather heated fantasy.
"You called, your highness?" The maestro stood before me. He was not tall, but his broad shoulders spoke of strength. His waist was trim, his thighs powerful, his chest bulged with finely honed muscle. He kept his baton inside the waist band of his tights, its length revealed against his thigh, I sighed at the sight of the the instrument he used to make beautiful music. I had to force my eyes away from him. I turned and spoke to him without looking at him.
"I have come up with a plan that involves music," I said calmly. "And that means you are an integral piece of that plan."
"I am here to serve you, my queen." His words were like a song, soft, sensual, song-like.
I turned to him, and said, "Have you ever heard of this new kind of music?" My eyes rose to the sky as if I would find the right words there. "It's called Rap. Sometimes it's referred to as Hip Hop."
The maestro hesitated, his eyes closed as if he was in deep thought. His hand went to his chin as if in great contemplation. "Yes, my queen, I believe I have heard a trio of musicians in the court yard playing it. There is a strong rhyme factor to it. But the words can sometimes be quite offensive."
"Exactly," I said and turned to him. "I want you to seek out these musicians." I turned my gaze back out to where the House of Martell members staggered in a drunken stupor. I clucked my tongue and shook my head. "What am I going to do with that lot," I asked no one in particular, my words drifting on the breeze.
"With whom, my queen?"
"Nothing, nothing at all, maestro." I turned to him and said. "Bring these rap people to me. Tell them there is something important they can do for their queen."
"Can I give them some small piece of information about what you will require of them?" the maestro asked.
I slowly let my gaze drift back to the south and frowned. "No, maestro. Just tell them I command their presence. Tell them that their music will assist me in keeping my throne."
"As you wish," maestro said as he bowed and slowly stepped back.
I was alone except for the guard whose eyes seemed to follow my every move. I had the remainder of the day with nothing to do. I needed a distraction to fill my time. I turned and admired the guard's physique. Stepping in front of the guard, I spoke slowly.
"What time do you get off word, my protector?"

My brothers and I bowed in front of the man in a strange jacket and tight jeans. The wizard had a lean, rugged face with the dark waves of oily hair hanging just a little too long on his forehead. It wasn’t what he looked like, but the way he stood: no ambling, no sauntering, just looking confident and standing straight in the middle of a whole hive of bees buzzing around him.

I would be sure of myself, too, if I had bees hovering about me as bodyguards, I thought. The wizard lifted his amulet at me, with his free hand that didn’t grasp the wand.

“You can never achiever such heights, Young Man,” he said, reading my thoughts. “It takes great learning to have bees protect one.”

“The evil, Sir,” I stammered. “The evil is spreading and we don’t know what it is or how to fight it. It seems to be able to eradicate the mankind, in the long run. Please, Sir, we do need your help.”

“You the offspring of one who challenged me and then found his end now asking me for help? I am flattered,” he said mockingly.

“Sir, if I may, how can you blame the grandchildren of one who crossed you?”

“I can’t and I don’t. I just found it amusing. But it seems to me you people are blaming yourselves. That is good for the soul, that luxury in self-reproach. Now that you feel the blame, you think no one else has a right to blame you. Right?”

“If you say so,” said my brother, feeling off put. “If good men like you do nothing, evil will triumph. Is that what you want.”

“My, my, young man,” chuckled the wizard. “A bit of the grandpa in you, I see.”

“Please, Sir,” I said, trying to make up for my brother’s ineptitude, “Please help us, I implore. We don’t want evil to win. We want it stopped. But if we don’t know what kind it is and what its dimensions are, how can we fight it? You are the only one who…”

With the wave of a hand he interrupted my words. “If only it were all so simple…Evil may seem invincible, but its only end is to make you fall for it. This evil has gained a face because of the evil people insidiously committing evil deeds. You can’t find and destroy them, because good and evil lies in everyone’s core. It is this stupidity that propels people and makes evil an entity, you must fight against. Find the stupidity first, and fight that. Evil will go away.”

“How can be find it?” my brother asked.

“First, by not asking me stupid questions. Second go into the town and cities and find all the violent deeds. Inside their center lies the stupidity. That you must fight against. This is all I can tell you, for I have to go have my starlight tea.”

Saying that the wizard turned his back and sauntered into the large tree that was his headquarters.

"Welcome", The wizard said as we entered, "Thank you for answering my call." His voice was low and steady. I nodded to him and walked a few paces towards him, my brother Kallem at my side. Kallem's hand hovered at his sword, although it was not necessary - the old mage evidently meant us no harm - and even if he had, a long sword would be no match against his great powers.

"Please," He continued, "Take a seat - would you like some tea? Some wine?" He gestured to a small mole - like creature who began to fuss at a low, wooden table with jugs, cups and sugar bowls.

"Thank you, " I said, helping myself to a drink, more out of politeness than because I was thirsty - although once I brought the cup to my lips I realized my throat had been more parched than I had imagined. "What brings you to Little Pekan? It has been some time since you were last here," I continued, carefully. The wizard nodded slowly.

"You have heard by now that there are evil forces coming to the fore?"

"Yes. I heard the rumors. And......I spoke with Lark."

"The goblin?" The wizard seemed surprised at this fact.

"Yes, he's still locked in the palace dungeons.....although........" I hesitated and glanced at Kallem. The old wizard waited patiently for me to continue, "although, I think he may be of use. He may be able to help us, with his knowledge."

The wizard was silent for a while. He stared into the middle distance as though he was viewing something which only he could see - which may well have been the case. After some time he returned his gaze to mine.

"Warrior, you are the keeper of this realm and I will stand beside you to ensure that peace reigns here, as throughout the whole kingdom. I am not the most powerful wizard in the land, and evil will do its best to triumph, but we must join forces to ensure that this does not happen. I want only peace and justice for this realm. Here, take this locket. This is your way of connecting with me, wherever I am - look inside and you will see my face. You will be able to speak with me. Now, return to your village and take whatever action you deem necessary - remember, I will be here to help you when I can, but you must also help yourselves."

As his speech ended, there was a sharp, cracking sound accompanied by a purple flash of light. Kallem and I blinked. We were back in the forest clearing. The tree, mole, table and wizard had all vanished, yet when I looked down at my palm there lay there a small, golden locket on a chain.......

My brother and I sat at his wrinkly feet, hanging on his every word. His voice was deep, not thin and reedy as you would expect such an old man's voice to be. His beard, thick and full, hung in a silvery curtain with a floor-brushing hem. His lips were invisible beneath the hair, but the few teeth he had remaining were visible as he spoke.
"My young ones," he said, "listen well and you were learn of many things. Things that will serve you well as you walk through this world."
My skin goose pimpled in anticipation. What wondrous pearls of wisdom were about to fall from those nonexistent lips? My brother, biting his lip, eyes wide open, leaned forward and...

The deepest, loudest rumble shook the oak tree, sending us tumbling to the entrance. We poked our heads' out, stacked one of top of the other. The Wizard's beard hung over my face, and when I parted that curtain, I was stunned by what I saw.

An enormous dragon, resplendent and sinuous, stood before our astonished eyes. It roared again, shaking the tree until we all fell out in a heap, our teeth rattling in our heads.

We untangled ourselves slowly, so as to break the fragile bones of the Wizard, under the watchful eye of the burgundy and gold dragon. The Wizard was the first to speak.
He knelt on creaky knees. "Greetings, old one. It has been too long." The dragon yawned, emitting puffs of curling smoke that rose into the sky.
"Yes, Wizard. I wish I were here with glad tidings." His golden eyes held unfathomable depths of sorrow, and I shivered involuntarily as he continued his tale of woe.

Lulla mooes again. Maribelle throws a hoof her way, challenging her, my old feisty darling that she is. Lulla moves close to me almost touching me.

But another change is coming over Maribelle, too. Is this love?

No, this can’t be love, because now she looks scary. Her mere hoofs have turned into cloven hoofs. In her mouth, fangs appear. No, a cow cannot have fangs. Her chest heaves and splits open, to be immediately covered with more scales, ugly muddy, greenish scales…

Her eyes are no longer black, but more like the dulled moon while it sets and sickly. She is chaos itself, threatening the very fabric of the world. I have no defense. Lulla has no defense. No one has any defense against the edict of evil. Not anymore.

Lillian, that's me, there's been a mistake.

The River Lyle formed a border between the kingdoms of the North and our kingdom, Lyola. It had never been a problem before; the spring thaw always refilled the water to the banks of the river. But now, with rumors abounding of a coming drought, all kingdoms bordering the River Lyle wanted to secure their rights.

Now all of this happened before the mind of evil crept into the land. "I wasn't a human then, I was a young steer madly in love with you."

"Then why did you stop using our secret tunnel to come visit me?"

"You were getting so involved with the teachings of your teacher, Maribelle, that I thought you wanted to become a nun. I didn't fit into the picture any more. My presence was only a distraction to you."

"It's true, I was headed in that direction before, Lu-Lu-" I couldn't say the name. "Before a newcomer arrived and started telling lies to Maribelle. She told her that Pom and Fen, and Chester were eavesdroppers and that I was a traitor because of my association with you, I mean with Herbert."

I was getting confused.

"My poor darling," He started to pace. "I had no idea. Is that the reason the four of you came all this way? Because you had all been accused by Lulla?"

"You know her name?"

"Yes, she came here once. She tried to work her charms on my father, but he was too wise. When he refused her, she had him accused of being a traitor too. Our whole family was condemned to the slaughter house. We were being trailered in when another cow in the trailer told us about the transformation process."

My ears perked up and I raised my head. "What transformation?"

"I can't explain it. All I can say is that when we agreed the whole family became human. You should have seen the look on the faces of the
workers when they opened the tailgate to let us out and there were no cattle. They shooed us away and sent out a search party to find the treacherous cattle." He laughed. "Of course they never did."

"If what you say is true, then why did you send my friends, Pom, and Fen, and Chester to the Slaughter house?"

"No, you misunderstood. They are going to an outer pen for rest and relaxation. I kept you here so I could explain. I still love you Lillian. Of course, it's a ludicrous term in our present physical states. One of us has to change."

"I'd feel better if I could talk with my friends," I said. "Frankly Herbert, what you're telling me sounds insane."

"I suppose it does, it takes getting used to. I'll have you delivered and pick you up in the morning."

Chapter 11 -Chester Gives his advice.

Herbert was right - no cow-pen in sight. I had been dropped off in a lovely green pasture with it's own pond for bathing and a water trough for drinking. There were several lean-tos where cattle could escape a broiling sun or excessive wind, rain hail or snow. After all, we were in the Northern Kingdom.

Since today was mild and clear without a cloud in the sky, none of them were necessary. Pom. Fen and Chester were were already mingling in the open with other cattle. I hoped they hadn't told them where we came from or how we traveled to the Northern Kingdom. I knew Chester would remain mum. Pom and Fen could be real chatterboxes.

Seeing me they all galloped over. "Lillian," Pom mooed, "We were so worried about you. With that rope about your neck, we thought they were going to hang you."

"I thought so too," I sympathized. "Actually the human who stayed behind is someone I had met before. He remembered me and wondered what I was doing here."

They looked at me strangely. I had to think fast. "Do you remember when my father was on the inter-kingdom water rights council that met here several years ago and Hank and I came with him?" Chester remembered. "Well I met him then, we all did, I mean my whole family-did." I was rambling.

Chester became suspicious. "Do you mean that's the one who gave you the combination to the tunnel lock at this end, the one you call Herbert?"

"No, I mean, yes. Oh Chester, I've got to talk to you alone. Do you think Pom and Fen would mind?"

"Let's ask. Would you women like to go back and graze with your new friends?" They left in a flash.

Chester and I found a shady spot under a tree to talk. "What's going on?" he asked. I can tell that something is bothering you. Are you afraid your friend, the human, will betray us?"

"No, he won't do that. Oh Chester, how can I tell you? I know what you'll think because I thought the same thing. You'll think I'm insane."

"Try me," he said. "Court jesters are very adaptable. I've seen and heard just about everything. What is it Lillian?"

"The human says that he is the same Herbert we met at the council. But when I knew him he was a young steer. He says he and his whole family have been transformed into humans."

"That's insane."

"I told you so."

"Why would they do something so stupid?"

"Like us they had been accused of being traitors to their country. King Rupert of Flinchland had sent spies to see if the Northern Kingdom was harboring Flinchland rebels. The very same Lulla who convinced Maribelle to accuse us, accused Herbert's father, Lord Flanders, of being a traitor.
They didn't want to be humans but it was a matter of going through the transformation process or going to the slaughterhouse. Now Herbert wants me to go through transformation also."

Chester backed up in shock, as though he were about to be contaminated. "You're not, surely you're not."

"I told Herbert I wanted to talk to you first. I couldn't do something like that without telling you and Pom and Fen first."

"Never mind Pom and Fen," he said. "They mean no harm but they like to chatter. It will have to be our secret."

"Then you approve?"

"I didn't say that. Lord almighty, what would your poor father say if he knew? I can't give you advice on this Lillian. I've never heard of such a thing.
I've never even dreamed about it.

"Ask yourself this question, child. Who are you? Where do you come from? Are you a member of your family and your herd and your species?
Or are you a free spirit that can flit from all these to another? Could you truly leave everything that you've always been behind? I know I couldn't."

"You're not in love," I said simply.

"Aaah, so that's it. I should have known. Well then, in that case, this is something you and Herbert must decide between you. I only ask this much of you, child. If you decide to do it, don't tell me. I don't want to know."

When Herbert arrived the next morning for my answer, he brought devastating news. "News of the arrival of you and your friends, and why you had to leave Loyola has leaked out," he said. "I can't imagine how, but it has."

Pom and Fen, It was the first thought to enter my mind. In their excitement they told their new friends in the pasture. I could only hope they didn't reveal our secret underground passageway. "Do they know how we arrived ?" I asked.

"I don't think so. Nothing has been said about that yet. You'll have to transform right away. What about your friends, will they be interested? "

"I only told Chester,he is totally against it. The two lady cows don't know. I didn't dare tell them because they are such chatterboxes."

"Maybe that's where the news leaked out."

"I thought of that too. Let's talk to Chester and see what he thinks."

Chester listened in horror. "If we remain in our present form we will surely be killed."

"That's right, Herbert said. "Do you want to be a martyr or a human?"

"They are both forms of martyrdom, Sir," Chester said ungraciously.

"What about the other two? Are they staying or coming with us?"

"If they go with you then I'll have to come too. They are far too, shall I say "limited in mental capacity," to adapt to a new identity on their own."

"Well then, go ask them. We'll wait ten minutes before leaving. I will not risk Lillian's safety by waiting any longer."

Chester galloped away. Nine minutes later he returned with Pom and Fen trailing behind, mooing at their loudest.

"Be still, do you want to attract attention and get us all killed?" Chester scolded

Herbert led us to a covered trailer.


If you're wondering how the transformation took place, you are going to be disappointed. Chester and I were sworn to absolute secrecy and
Pom and Fen were given strong sedatives. We remained isolated in the barn for a month to get used to our new bodies.

I turned out rather pretty, but not a breath taking beauty. Herbert was very satisfied with my latin look and created a back story to go with it. "We will tell people you were an orphaned princess discovered by me on the streets of the Southern Kingdom. Immediately recognizing you as a person of royal blood and and great potential, I arranged for you to return with me and live as one of our family proteges. During this time I fell in love with you; now we are engaged to be married. How's that?"

"It's wonderful but what will the rest of your family say to such a lie?"

"You forget, we were once transformed ourselves. We know the danger of a wagging tongue."

"And the others?"

"Pom and Fen can be ladies in waiting in another household. They remember nothing, but it is best not to have them living with us in case they ever do."

"And what about me?" asked Chester while he practised reading a book while sitting in a chair? "Where shall I be farmed out?

"We'll say you were once Lillian's tutor in the Southern Kingdom and when we discovered it, we sent for you."

Obviously pleased, Chester enquired about his name. "Chester the Jester is to recognizable."

"Absolutely," Herbert agreed. "You will all need new names. Lillian can be Lillith and you can be Socrates."

"Do you like the name, Socrates?" I asked.

"I'm honored," Chester said. "What do you think of Pamela and Francis for the two ladies? I rather like the ring of them."

"Then so be it," Herbert and I agreed.

"Good that's done," Herbert said. "I will go to find a household for Pamela and Francis to work as ladies madis. You, Socrates,may set up to begin your tutoring of Lilith in the arts and sciences. And find her a riding instructor. She must learn how to ride horses, now that she is a lady of substance."

"Anything but polo," I laughed. "It would ruin my shins."

"No polo," Herbert grinned.

Chapter 16

When it became clear they had gleaned all they could from a distance, Herbert agreed to ride into camp. Lulla couldn't possibly recognize him as the young bull calf sentenced to the slaughterhouse with the rest of his family because his father rejected her advances. While his two friends stood guard from their hiding place, Herbert mounted his black steed, Storm, and rode down to meet her.

How strange it was to know he could draw his sword and cut off her head if he wanted to. He didn't. What Herbert wanted more than revenge was
the name of her director, the Nexus of the Flinchland operation. Was it King Rupert? That seemed unlikely. Rupert couldn't even maintain the
windmills in his country, or the cisterns, when drought was their biggest threat. How could he control and direct an invasion of any kind.

No, much as he would like to show Lulla how he and his family had survived, he had to keep it to himself.

At their last meeting they each had four hooves, a tail for swishing flies, and he had the very beginning of horns. Now here they were, two humans. Or at least he was. He had agreed to transformation and lived in a world where there was no going back.

Lulla, on the other hand was a shapeshifter who could assume any form, possibly at any moment. The only thing that remained the same was her desire to control, at any expense. He had seen it in action many years ago. Now he only sensed.it glowing in her eyes and projected from her vibes. He must not surrender to the glittering aura that she spread to pull him in.

Looking away he turned his attention to the camp. "You are not alone," he said.

"Did you want to be alone with me?"

"I wondered who was here, and why? People from the North seldom camp so close to the border."

"We are strangers in a strange land," she said with her teeth glittering. "Will you not welcome us into your homes?"

"Is that what the others doing? Insinuating themselves into our homes?"

"What a suspicious man you are. Come, dismount and let us sit together by the fire."

He pulled on the reins to back up Storm. "I came to find out you sent you."

The hint of a scowl passed over her face. "I am sent by he who one day will rule. That is all you need to know."

She dismissed him then, walking dangerously close to the freshly turned earth. He did not want her to know they'd been looking for the weapons.

"Look there," he said pointing to a bird cruising overhead. "Perhaps it is an omen of things to come."

"Foolish man," she said. "I'm not into omens, I'm into power. She raised a bow and arrow laying close by, pointed it at the bird and let the arrow fly.

Herbert willed the bird to fly faster. Lulla's harmless arrow fell to the ground.

"You have gained nothing little man," she said, walking away from the suspected cache of buried weapons.

Thunder stayed on watch while the other two slept. This time the Flinchlanders returning to camp for food and rest did not return to the forest. They pulled back from the fire like howling wolves, then started to break up camp. One of the men picked up a shovel to dig where the Northeners suspected their weapons were buried.

With a bellow loud enough to wake the dead, let alone Bold and Herbert, Thunder crashed into the camp. His huge long horns tossed men this way and that. Bold soon followed. Herbert lept onto the the bare back of his stallion, Storm, and charged into the camp with Bold.

The frightened men, thinking it must be the great god, Thor, scattered in all directions. Four got away, Bold cornered one at the edge of the fire pit and and Herbert lassoued two. Where was the other one? They counted again and realized two were missing, Lula and one of the men. "How could they get away?" Bold asked.

"She's a witch," Herbert said with no proof. "They probably flew off on her broomstick."

The three prisoners started to chatter among themselves. Bold tightened the ropes that bound them and gagged them.

Herbert picked up one of the shovels left behind. Thunder and Bold pitched in with their hooves. Soon they came to what looked like a huge casket.
The prisoners howled behind their gags. Thunder opened the lock with one of his horns expecting to find sharp spears, swords, cross bows and maybe some of those new fangled firing sticks. Instead a bundle of bones fell out of the casket and a gaggle of spirits flew away dripping blood behind them.

The horrified prisoners screamed so loud they popped off their gags. "The avengers, the avengers," they cried.

Chapter 18

In the art museum that Chester took Lillith to, she saw many paintings of naked men and women. She inspected them closely wondering how they mated and when their mating season started. The tradition in the herd had been for one steer to mate with several cows in order to replenish the crop of young calves each year. Lillith had not conceived her first calf when she led Pom. Nel, and Chester the Jester into the underground smugglers tunnel to escape Llula's unfounded charges of espionage.

At the time the fleeing suspects had expected two choices: be assimilated into the crowds of the North, or be extradited back to Loyola for trial as spies. How could she have known that her true love, Herbert, had been transformed into a male human, and that she and her friends would choose the same fate? Their's had been a bitter choice; extradition or humanity.

Only Lillith's rekindled love for Herbert drove her to the second choice. Lillith and Chester had not yet entered the big house. They remained in the barn, which Herbert had fixed up with comfortable living quarters for the two of them while they adjusted to their new life. Chester had gone to town several times on his own, but this trip to the museum was Lillith's first sight of street bustling with people. .

The simple brown and white smock and brown sandals that Herbert had provided never bothered Lillith before. In fact, she appreciated that he brought her smocks the same color has her previous cow skin. But in comparison to the fancy, colorful dresses and shoes worn by other ladies in town, Lillith now felt downright dowdy.

"People are staring at me," she said. "They think I'm odd. Maybe they know the truth."

In an effort to put her at ease Chester said, "They are only staring at your great beauty. Hold your head high and step out smart."
Once they entered the museum Lillith felt better because people were staring at the paintings, not her.

"Do you think Herbert is home yet?" she asked on their way back to the barn."

"I should think so, " Chester said, secretly determining to speak to Herbert about Lillith's clothes when they had a minute alone.



Herbert was fast losing patience with the slow pace of the prisoners stumbling along behind his horse, Storm. He wished he had Thunder with him but the strong back of the huge bull had been needed to carry the casket of bones back to the herd. He could at least have brought Bold. Maybe he should back track and get Bold. Herbert tried to approximate the difference in miles between going back to the camp or going forward to his home. Then he added the distance from the camp to the herd that the two steers would have covered by now. The choice was obvious, they had to keep going forward.

Strange noises and strange sights worried him. What if the four escaped Flinchlanders were lying in wait to attack him? Would they free their
three comrades and kill Herbert, or maybe take him prisoner? The idea of it made him shudder. He could cut lose the rope tied to the trailing men and spur Storm ahead at a gallop. The others on foot would never catch him then.

Save his own skin and leave these men loose in the Northern Kingdom? No, it was a cowardly thought. Just then a cloud of dust appeared to the right. Men riding in? Who could they be? The escaped Flinchlader s, or his own captain of the guards from Wooster? He squinted his eyes looking for clues. The prisoners were also searching. "Can you tell who it is?" he asked, momentarily forgetting he had gagged them. Seeing the rags stuffed in their mouths,he jumped from his saddle, gave each a long drink of water, and asked the question again.

"The Avengers," one of them said. "They are the spirits of the avengers . They are wondering in search of their bones. Until they reconnect they are lost spirits roaming the earth looking for the casket that holds their bones. Without them they have no body to support them. They are not born from flesh and blood like the rest of us, they are born from the Spirit of Revenge. that lies dormant in their bones."

"Why are they coming here? What will they do?" Herbert asked.

"What can they do? Choke us to death with their whirling dust storms, I fear. We best lie down and cover our heads. Play dead."

"It was a trick," Herbert thought, "The prisoners are tricking me to lie down in a dust storm so they can run away. I should keep going."

But already whirling wind and flying bits of dirt and dust were filling his eyes, and his ears, and his mouth. Storm was snorting and coughing. The prisoners were lying face down with their hollow walking sticks held up as a breathing tube. "They will live and I will not," Herbert thought.

The swirling wind felt like it lasted for hours but probably was much less than that. When all of them stopped moving the avenging wind swept away in search of more victims. The event had altered the dynamics between captor and captives. Herbert shared out the rest of his water among the captives and his horse. He removed their lasso and wound his rope on his saddle. "We might as well die as friends," he said.



Another cloud of dust appeared on the horizon, only this time men on horseback were easy to distinguish. They carried the Wooster flag.

"They are my men," Herbert said. The prisoners groaned.

"Lord Herbert," the captain of the guard greeted him when they drew near. "Your mother was worried. She asked us to look for you. Who are these?" he asked, pointing to the three men on foot.

"We'll put them up in the old barn, sir," Captain Brawn said to Herbert when they entered the courtyard to Wooster.

Captain Brawn watched his master springing to the old barn. What was going on? Why restore the place when they already had a new barn? He made a mental note to ask the downstairs maid next time he saw her.

A couple of hours later one of the prisoners signalled to a guard outside the guest house. "We need to see Lord Herbert right away. It's an emergency."

"You can give me the message."

"Tell him we want to make a deal but there's not much time."

"What's the emergency?" Herbert asked when the message had been delivered.

"We want to tell you why we were sent across the border, the spokesman for the prisoners said. And---"

"And what?"

"And we want to work for you. You been square with us. We don't trust that Brawn guy. We want to be your personal guards"

Herbert laughed. "Brawn's fine. But if you really want to work for me I'll find you some sort of a job - provided you tell me the truth about why you were sent across the border."

The talky one continued, "Rufus has plans to take over the Realm, one kingdom at a time . He spent spies in all directions to scope out weak spots. When he heard the king of the North never goes out among the people, he decided the the king must be dying. . We were sent to find out if the king is already dead. If he is, Rufus plans to take over. Then he called for Lulla the witch, and her gaggle of
spirit avengers to start spreading rumors in the population that their king was either going to abdicate or die and Rufus would be there new king.

"Those who escaped when you captured us are still working on the plan. We want to warn your king of the North that he should be seen in public and he should appear strong."

"Well," Herbert said. "What do you want me to do?"

"Show us the way to your king. Go with us. Tell him what you saw at the border, all of it. Tell him about eight of us setting up camp, and Lulla, the
witch and her gaggle of spirits that rise from the bones in casket whenever it is opened. Tell him we saved your lives on the way here, and how we are on your side now. If you do all these things he might believe us."

Herbert wished his father was still alive for him to consult "There's someone I want you to meet." he said, thinking of Chester. He used to be a Court Jester for the herd. He's very wise."

"For the herd?" The man raised his eyebrows.

"Only a matter of expression. It's a Northern expression for group." Whew! Herbert almost blew it that time. He would have to be more careful.
