Chester to you."





When the three prisoners and Lord Herbert left in a horse drawn coach for the palace of the king , a small crowd of well wishers gathered to see them off. Among the crowd Captain Brawn noticed a beautiful young woman he had not seen before. "Who is she?" he asked a man next to him.

The man shrugged his shoulders, "Never seen her before. "Not bad looking."

"If you like the type." Brawn hid his interest until the coach pulled away and the crowd thinned. He noticed an elderly man, perhaps her father, walking with the girl. His interest soared when they entered the door to the old barn.

Who was she, why was Herbert keeping her hidden?"/i} He considered it his job to find out and report to Lady Wooster.

Lillith had seen the well muscled captain staring at her in the courtyard, and she had squirmed under his glance. She opened the half door on the barn to make sure he was gone. Instead she found him strolling back and forth directly in front of her view.

"What are you looking at?" Chester came up behind her.

"Only the sky," she said. "See what a bright blue it is tonight, it almost sparkles."

"Are you happy?" Chester asked.

"I am. But already I miss my Herbert. It seems people are always calling him away."

"He is an important person. He has many responsibilities. You must get used to it."

"I know," she sighed. "I hope super comes soon, I'm famished."

Brawn noticed the kitchen maid headed in the direction of the old barn carrying a large tray of food. "Let me help you carry that," he said whisking the tray out of her hands."

"Thank you sir," she said, blushing.

"Think nothing of it." Brawn knocked on the half door of the barn where he had seen the unfamiliar girl looking out.

"That's not the right knock," Chester noted.. "Don't open it."

But Lillith, who was hungry, did not want to wait. She opened the door and stared straight into Brawn's nordic blue eyes.

He held out the tray of food. "Who are you?" he asked as she held out her arms to accept the fooc.





The guards a the King's palace allowed the coach to pass when they recognized Lord Herbert sitting inside. "What are your names?" he said to his companions. "I've only known you as prisoners, and ex-prisoners."

"We are brothers," the talky one said. "Rip and Tip, and Snip."

Herbert stifled a laugh. "That's good, I think I can remember those. Which one are you?"

"I'm Snip, sir."

"Well then, Snip, when we are presented you may walk behind me and the other two may walk behind you. Do not sit down in the presence of the king. Stand at all times and when it is time to leave we must all back out. So Rip and Tip will back out first.

"Why sir?"

"There is no why. It's the way it is done. Do you understand."

"Yes, sir, they said in chorus.

They were ushered into a waiting room filled with other people waiting. "Why are we all waiting?" Snip asked. "Who's inside.?"

"No one," Herbert said. "That's the problem. "No-one can find the king. Don't look so surprised. You yourself said he needs to make himself more available to the people. Well, that includes the people of the court. He's not a snob. He's a recluse."

1132.content:
Figures ghost through the darkness. There is no peace, no silence, but quiet that sets the nerves on edge with the soft falls of carefully set feet. It is the ghost dance, the manuever that leads to blood in the night. I know it well, I have danced this dance and know that a dancer will step and step, secret and silent, but then the next step will bring the battle's noise and the silence that hides the coming battle will be shattered irreparably.

There are two armies, maybe more. Who can say what forces are arrayed in the darkness, not even the armies themselves may know their own force. Could there have been defections? Who can say? Might error or cowardice have thinned their forces in that dark field? It must be said that it is possible. But in the moonless night a fighter and his foe must meet.

The heavy tread of the thick necked battlers, anger burning through torpor. These are quick to anger and fierce in their pride. There heads are crowned with death and their feet are hard enough to break another's bones. Oh, they are fierce and like to charge a friend as to kill an enemy, but who can stand against such as he? It is death to face his thick muscled body, trampling to stand against him to his face. There is a scent upon the air that makes the battlers rage. A scent that calls their blood to fight, they move, swinging sharp tipped weapons side to side as they seek what they may kill or failing that to vent their rage upon their own kind if that is what they find to do.

Within the darkest shadows moves a pack of darker shadows. If light betrayed there might be gleam of sharpened tooth, but these drift near the earth. Weapons for the ravaging of those who come to grief in the night of the stealth hunters. These know the meaning of the scents, the heady scents of fearful fighters, food if they should flee. It is their way to hound their prey, to fight a skirmish, and perhaps to run away only to turn back to tear their foe to pieces.

Hunger is their goad, they seek the meat of the slain, not like the carrion crow, not like the raven that will feast upon the fallen in the light, no, these are not patient for their food. They will make a kill and feed upon the dying while its blood is hot.

And then the clouds are torn away. The wind upon the fields falls with the light of moon and stars above the clouds that wind has torn to gibbious threads that glow and their the battle down below. A bellow and a growl as two armies set to. Two armies that will fight until the feathered black birds that love the battles leavings will descend. This is war, and this is death. The death of bulls and wolves and too, the death of silence as the thunk of horn and ripping sound of fang are but the least of sounds that shatter all quietness that once held sway upon this field.

And the decision seems to be to jolt them out of their senses, to reveal them how puny they are when standing shoulder to shoulder with the nature’s very own fury and to crush their egos which are powerful than their athletic muscles. The Dragon raises his head a little, opened his mouth to reveal the wildly uneven, hundreds of sharp, stained red and yellow teeth – nah daggers – which would have devoured hundreds of humans at once just by merely placing its toothy jaw on them. The froth building in his mouth signaled to the warrior of what the Dragon thought of him – a nice, juicy piece of lump; nothing more, nothing less. As the man-creature looked at the dark abyss revealed by the agape mouth of the dragon, the warrior wondered for a while about remnants of how many villages, how many of his countrymen could be found beyond that abyss. The gleaming teeth of the dragon, gnashed together as the dragon let out a noise from its nostril which sounded something like neighing of hundreds of wild horses together. Good thing that the man-creature had a headgear which shielded his pale face, death seeing eyes and the quivering lip from the furious, preying eyes of the Dragon; Dragons prey on the fear of the feeble, detest it; They devour the carrier of weak willed soul and see it as their duty to wipe out the land of such limp creatures.

The man-creature tried to firm his grip on his war-skythe but his strong wrists had lost their power as the Dragon’s sweltering breath grazed his neck. Dragon’s breath smelled of all those things which the warrior didn’t want to think of at this point – it smelled of blood, not of one but of an army battalion of thousands of stronger warriors; it smelled of the razing fire in its belly which would turned hundreds of villages to ashes in a matter of two deep breaths. The warrior considered whether the being standing in front of him had the pride, the ego which said to the other species that see I am the most majestic, most powerful creature in the whole multiverse. The warrior wasn’t sure but the thought that the Dragon drew back a little, as haughtily as it could, one step at a time total five steps in all. It gave its wing a slight flutter, as if brushing off the tainted weak breaths of the warrior it must have gathered from standing so close to him and looked away towards the group of warriors standing nearby.

“Am I not good enough for him?” the warrior wondered. He got his answer, not in the way he expected.

A roar, as if hundreds of simultaneous thunderclaps, echoed through the land where they stood. It was a if a minor earthquake had hit the land; after all, it was the Dragon, the most savage beast in the history speaking –

There was a slight rustle and clicking of the panoplies as the suited warriors looked around to search for what the Dragon asked for. Nobody knew what they were looking yet as their master, if alive, was a thousand miles away in the valley of Sminvalia. Yet they were hoping for an answer from someone; someone who was brave enough to proclaim himself as their master for now.

Dragon dragged its fiery claw into the muddy ground below. He was sensing it was worthless to talk to the bunch of pushovers encircling him. Perhaps they would be of more use in the empty chambers of his belly. His eyes twinkled. He craned his neck a little, fluttered his majestic wings and then raised his monster paw to turn the flimsy mob into a pulp.

"It's simple enough, Jaren." Aris stared up at the older man, eyes fixed and unwavering. "We can stay here, scratching a living in this forest whilst everyone else carves slices off the kingdom for themselves, or we can go back and fight. Maybe get a tasty bit for ourselves."

"Oh yeah, you impudent little shit. Fight with what. All you got here is a few score farmers armed with sticks. First army you come across will chew you up and spit you out." Specks of spittle hit Aris in the face under the onslaught. He blinked, and slowly wiped it off, making a point of flicking it away.

"You forget our secret weapon, old man. Your breath."

Jaren stood frozen for a moment and suddenly burst our laughing, clasping Aris on the shoulder. "Took yer a score of years, but you finally found yer balls 'eh. Alright, alright. I suppose you have some grand plan then?"

Aris smiled inwardly. The decision was made, it was just about the details now.

"As you well know, we are more than just farmers with sticks. Last count had us at just shy of 120 men, over three score with army experience. Add to that a score of hunters mean with a bow and we aren't just a flea to be flicked away. If we're smart, there's opportunities. Did you speak to Whiston about stores?"

"Food supplies are solid. These trees have fed us well. We got more bows than we have archers to fire them. What we're strugglin' with is arms and armour. For some of the lads, a stick isn't far from what they have."

"Don't underestimate a good quarterstaff, but agreed it is a problem." Aris put a hand to his chin, thinking. "Castle Winebrook is only three days away."

"Old Lord Kefnir's place?"

"That's the one. His armoury will be well stocked, if he could just be... ...persuaded to part with it."

Jaren grinned. "I can be mighty persuadin' when I wants to be."

"It'd be risky though. Decrepit as the place is, it's still a castle. Won't just be a stroll inside. There's some sense in just heading south. Heard rumours The Fireguard are roaming about there. If we join up with them they'd need to arm us, and a wage wouldn't hurt."

Jared spat on the ground. "Merc's. Pah, I don't want to be takin' no orders from some jumped up merc Captain."

"Wouldn't need to be for long and would see us right for a bit. But yeah, not too keen on it myself. We could always do some mercinary work ourselves. I could be your jumped up merc Captain. Head up to the coast, find some work around the docks of Stalhaven."

"Like yer said. We got options."

"Ya got that right, but what if, we appear to be more. We convince them to leave their sanctuary for fear of a siege and starvation."

Jaren took the stick from Aris, and with his foot erased the symbols Aris had been drawing.

"This be the Castle Winebrook." He drew a square in the dirt. "Thirty men on all sides."

"Thirty will not give the look of strength we need. We need solidarity, a united front."

"Hush, boyo and learn from a master. Now, we march our men amongst the trees on three fronts - north, south and west."

"But the easiest escape is to the east."

"Aye, where thirty of our men lie waiting in ambush. We take the castle and the stores of those who flee. They wilst not leave gold and food behind."

"Still, thirty men..."

"Aye, thirty times thirty."

"Jaren, I fear that last knock on the head has played with your senses. How are thirty men to become thirty times thirty?"

"Illusion." Jaren laughed. "Illusion and stamina. On three sides our men will march in amongst the trees in clear view, but out of reach."

"Surely, that will reveal our numbers."

"Aye, but not if they march in view, run behind the trees out of sight, and return on the same march." Jared drew his plan. "Each man, appears to be thirty with an unending stream of troops, or so it shall appear."

"I see, at that distance they will not be able to see the details, just the movement, and we give them two options: vacate in safety or face our wrath."

"Indeed, and we take the spoils in the castle - "

"Old Lord Kefrir's rumored to be a bit unstable. Will he fight or will he flee?"

"You have not met the old reprobate. He is nothing more than a coward. He will flee if outnumbered. Like the rat he is, he will flee."

Being one of their best with a bow it made sense for him to head this group, but it made him anxious not knowing how the rest of the plan was going, and having to rely on Jaren so much. It was Jaren's own plan though, and Aris wasn't so proud yet as to be unwilling to admit it was a good one.

The woodlands curled around the old keep like a horseshoe. Finding a good location on each side to set up the illusion march was easily done. Aris had adapted the plan slightly and took five men from each group to bolster his own force. The remaining twenty five on each side would have to run a little harder to maintain the illusion but it was his group that would actually be engaging the enemy. Aris felt better with a wall of twenty five arms-men between him and his archers should the Lord have a larger retinue than expected. It was no coincidence they were some of the better armed and armoured too.

A growing spiral of smoke was rising up in the distance. He was trying to take it as a good sign, but the bigger it grew the harder it was to convince himself something hadn't gone wrong. The plan was to stay put, but what if Jaren was in trouble?

His men were growing as alarmed as he was, but Aris motioned for quiet and to remain in place. I don't know what's going on over there, but it doesn't change the need for a blocking force. The whole idea is to make Kefnir run and I've got to think this is likely to do it.

Then, out of the shadowing woods, a small group of men came hurrying. Four of them were strugged under the weight of a great chest. Six wore armor and strode with steel bared and behind them old lord Kefnir struggled to keep up with his money, his face as red as his doublet. Every few steps the old man glanced back over his shoulder and this seemed to help him keep pace. There were a few more men, men at arms perhaps, that straggled behind the lock-box and the knights with their lord, these seemed as nervous as their lord, glancing backward like Kefnir, but also looking around them trying to penetrate the shadows of the forest.

Aris stepped out of concealment and shouted, "Hold there lord Kefnir!"

A few of his men moved out with him, drawing their bows with arrows noched. Kefnir squeeled in fright and then screamed, "Shoot them."

The men behind the lord revealed that they carried bows, drawing at the command, but Aris's men were already firing and they fell or fled. Kefnir shrieked his displeasure and howled for his knights to "strike them down." But there were only six against thirty and they dumped their swords in the dirt and stood with hands raised in surrender. "Cowards!" shouted Kefnir, but the knights glanced at their lord with distain and ignored him.

Suddenly there were many more men in the woods. But before he could order his men to defense Aris saw that Jaren was at their head. "I don't believe this is the whole of the garrison, but I believe we've smoked out the treasury," said Aris to his lieutenant.

"You'd rob an old man on the highway, you're no better than brigands," spit the erstwhile lord of Winebrook.

"Smoked out, that's a good word for it. We set campfires for an army when it got dark, but it seems that a few, well, all of them got away from us." Jaren looked slightly embarassed, "Looks like the smoke and fire sent the rats to scuttling."

As Aris's men approached the lock-box, the bearers and the knights stepped away. Lord Kefnir clung to his riches, "Its mine, you're common thieves I tell you. . ." but he merely slumped on the ground cursing when they lifted it and carried it away.

Aris looked over the scene. What do I want with the old ruin of a castle? A base? Perhaps, and there was reason to want to see what they could find in the castle's armory and larder, but it surely was not worth the lives of my men to take it from the garrison, reduced as it was by a dozen or so men. Jaren's trick had netted them a rich treasure, they could avoid any losses and just take what they had, but maybe there was an even better outcome. What should he do?

Leadership, he knew, was about making decisions, sometimes the quickest was better than the best, but sometimes it was the best.

The longer he waited the more his unease grew. His men were restless, edging backwards. The fortress was just that. Four walls of solid grey brick that reached up high into the early morning sky. Yet as Aris stared at it, he knew there were chinks in the armour. Here and there the greying stone was crumbling, a sad weathering of beautiful fortress. One of the windows on the lower floors was wide enough to squeeze a small man through should they need and the gate barring their entry was resting on rusted hinges. Yes, if this plan didn't work there would be others.

"Higlon," he called to his fastest man. Higlon appeared from under the darkness of leaves, his long hair dark, hanging down to his chest.

"Yes, Aris?"

"See that smoke over there?" He nodded his head towards the rising plume of smoke. It was still faint in the morning but still not a part of their plan. Perhaps old Jaren was signalling him. Perhaps there had been a change.

"Yes, sir."

"Go find out what is going on."

Without another word, Higlon took off into the woods, skirting around the outside of the fortress, his figure becoming a mere shadow in amongst the trees.

"What do you think it is?" another man asked, a quiver audible in his voice.

"I'm sure it's naught to worry about. But we must wait here for Jaren's signal."

The man simply nodded.

It seemed that they waited there in the darkness and shadow, eyes peeking between the trees and staring at the fortress and the smoke beyond it. Finally, Higlon returned, out of breath.

121123.content:
The Forest People!

Who had seen them and lived to tell the tale? None knew for sure what powers those being had - reason enough not to venture deep into the Eastern Edge, where they were reputed to stay.

Some said they were actually the spirits of those who were unable to cross over into the Hallowed Hall Above. Others whispered beings from another realm, who came down/out/up (the version varied from person to person, whether they inhabited an Underworld, an Other World, or the Above World) when they were bored/angry/frolicsome (again versions varied according to the natural propensities of the teller).

Aris was no more pusillanimous than anyone, but he could not help a chill shiver beginning running up his spine.

"Nonsense, man! Why would they come out of their lair?"

"It must be all this skirmishing that has been going on, someone must have disturbed them!"

"So, that one fool would not be returning home, why would they be marching upon us, stop being a coward! What exactly did you see?"

"I saw a flicker of flame, and masses of green leaves being propelled forward, as though the forest itself was walking. Was that not enough?"

Aris smiled.

Alas for being surrounded by fools!

"That only means that the Sohum is coming to our aid!"

"Who is that?"

"He is my cousin from over the hill, a master of disguise. He must have used leaves and branches to disguise his band. And the fire would be a flaming arrow or two he had loosed at any following enemy."

"And would a following enemy not come here behind him?"

"He would not retreat if there were many, this must be what remained of the fellows we ourselves did not finish off. Let him approach. We shall hear from his own mouth."

1211233.content:
As if on cue, the trees around them began to move and shake, the leaves rustling as something big pushed through them. Higlon's eyes widened and he stepped back.

"Do not be a coward, man!" Aris yelled. He saw Higlon swallow but he stood his ground, awaiting whatever was coming.

Then a green mass of leaves and twigs came crashing through the underbrush followed by more and more. It was indeed his cousin, Sohum, just as he thought. He was surrounded by men, including Jaren.

Aris rushed forward at the sight. "What is this? What news?"

Jaren shook his head. "They knew. They were waiting." He panted and dropped his gaze to the floor.

Aris frowned. "How could they have known?"

Jaren merely shrugged but Sohum growled. "They have a witch."

A gasp came from behind as Higlon took another step back as if afeared that the very woman was with them now.

"Are any of you hurt?" Aris asked looking between Jaren and his cousin.

"We lost many. There is only me left." Jaren spoke, sorrow tinging his voice.

Then Sohum spoke. "We managed to save Jaren but I have other men badly injured." He pointed. Beneath the disguises, Aris made out wounds as they seeped blood. One man was missing a hand.

"What now?" Aris asked. Everything had gone wrong. Everything he wished for had been stopped at this first engagement of the castle all thanks to a witch and now he was lost.

"We must flee. We must recover." Jaren hurried forth his opinion.

"Flee? We are men not cowards!"

"There is nobody left."

Aris looked to his cousin. He could trust Sohum with his life and his men. "Sohum?"

"Jaren is right. Now is the time to mend, to regroup. We must plan."

Aris nodded bruskly. He did not want to retreat and leave this behind but knowing that a witch was on board the castle meant they had to rethink their plan. They needed magic on their side. "Where?"

"We can go back to our camp. Come on."

Aris signalled and his men followed Sohum as they trooped back through the woods and up towards the perilous mountain beyond. None but the most hardy of folk ever travelled there. He himself had never visited that desolate place and yet here he was marching towards it with more confidence than he ever thought possible, though what they would meet there, he did not know.

12122.content:
It was not an easy journey, for they could travel only just before light or just after evenfall. Their horses had their hooves muffled with squares of cloth tied on, this made them fidget and cavort more than usual when ridden. All the bits and buckles were also padded here and there to prevent clinking. As for the horses neighing, they had chosen the oldest and best trained, these would not neigh unless they saw grave and immediate danger.

They rested in thickets and caves by day, when they might run into patrols on business, they ate cold food, for they could not allow a wisp even of smoke. It made for a laborious and slow progress and Jaren's muttering and grumbling was wearing down Aris' patience. Yet, he needed the other man for the plan to be brought to fruition.

"Aris, why do we dodge and hide even now, we have seen nary another soul in these three days. We could have made the journey thus far in one day!

"We have seen none, and more important, none have seen us, because we have taken precautions. Had we been on the road later, or earlier, we might not have had that luxury."

"Ho, the only ones to use these trails are farmers and villagers, let those dolts see us."

"It's not even the chance met patrol I fear, but these very dolts you dismiss. They are liable to pass on the information of two loaded horses and strangers passing this way. Then, be sure, the patrols will converge upon our trail."

"You shy from ghosts and look for shadows from which to cower! Ha! Is this the brave Aris who fought on the fields of Irame?"

"I fought there, and hope to live to fight these cursed barons and their like. Which is not likely to happen if you are in charge of our journey."

"I am more than capable of finding Sramius on my own, You need not think yourself so clever, Sir Know-it-all!"

"Scramius may not reveal himself to you, alone. Be careful, do not go off alone, there's suspicion all around these days, even from allies."

"I still think you are being ox-headed."

Aris just grunted, there was no point in going on with the useless debate. He looked around, wondering if that was a twig crackling underfoot, that snap he had just heard.. He raised his right hand and shushed Jaren's attempt to continue his tirade.

He quickened the horse's gait with a twitch of the reins, if it was a man on foot, he'd soon be left behind.

"Ah, good, now you are making good time."

"Jaren, there's danger here. Be careful, I hear rustling and clinking around us!"

Jaren heard it too, his face paled, silent now, he too urged his horse to better speed.

He had just gone past Aris, who was slowing for some inexplicable reason, when he heard a groan. He swung in the saddle to see ...

Aris had been struck by an arrow, but it must have been a flesh wound only, because he pulled it out and threw it away.

"A child's toy? It was a mere six inches long, and barely as thick as a quill!" Yet, he shortened the reins and motioned Jaren to keep going.

"Fly man, for we know not what more they have in check!"

The two horses needed no urging, they sensed the tension and made ate up the road with their long strides.

It must have been four or five miles later that Aris signalled a halt.

"Stop! I can ... go on ... no more. I feel ..."

Aris swayed in the saddle and fell to the ground.

Jaren jumped off his mount and stopped to the still figure. He tried to support him, but Aris just slipped back, his jacket opening to show the bloodstained shirt underneath. He pulled that cloth out of the waistband, there was a tiny puncture wound, but the flesh was purple and green for inches around.

Poison. The arrow was meant not to injure but to deliver the poison.

Jaren starred at his companion's limp form.

Now I have to tend to him, but know neither the poison nor its remedy. I have to find Sramius. He will be able to tell me how to tackle this. I pray he will.

One tear trickled down his his weather-beaten cheek, he let it roll into the corner of his mouth, salt and bitter.

"My friend, for you are that. I swear I shall keep you alive and well and help you find the answers you seek."

He lifted the dead-weight of his friend, staggering under the load as he arranged it over the saddle of the patient steed.

Onward, we ride to Scramius' lair.

Aronn of High-hill was determined to get his chance to take power. He had waited for this chance all his life. The old King had ruled for too long and, now departed, gave this thin slice of a chance for Aronn and his men.

Aronn had been borne with great poverty. His mother was clever and gained a position with the High-hill servers. As Aronn grew up, he befriended the boy Earl - Targon of High-hill. The two were inseparable as boys, and soon Aronn's mother became Targon's high maid. This meant the boys had as much time as they wished to play together and learn to fight. They soon realised that together they could be strong enough to replace the old King, or perhaps die trying.

Targon decreed that Aronn was his brother. It was made law in High-hill, and from then on they were an unbeatable force in the hills. They slowly gained land and became known to the old King afar. The King sent troops to the edge of the hills to try and capture the brothers - they were never caught. It was true that the old King feared the brothers but he did not voice his concerns to anyone.

So, Aronn of High-hill and his troops, gathered outside of the town's wall. He blackmailed some servants to let them into the King's land and slowly made his way to the court.

Targon, meanwhile, remained at High-hill, fearful of retribution. Even if Aronn was successful, Targon had no intention of letting the hill land fall. With the King's land and High-hill, the brothers would be a force that would be hard beaten.

After a long conversation that also became loud at times, Jared relented, and he and Aris set off to meet the Fireguard. Jared still grumbled a bit about orders. The journey started out though.
The silence of the woods lengthened as they rode on. The clacking of their horses' hooves was the only thing that broke the oppressive stillness during the long days and nights. They kept south making camp along the trail that would lead them to the Fireguard. They longed for real shelter, but the prospect of steady wage kept then moving.
On a particularly dark night Jared and Aris were awakened by a blood curdling shriek that ripped through the dark. They jumped to their feet and grabbed the swords that hung from their saddles. The horses were snorting nervously and the men hung tightly to the reins in case the animals bolted in fright.
A large, dark shape flew over head. The moon was blotted out as it swept past. Both Jared and Aris screamed. The shape took another pass. The horses screamed and both men lost hold of the reins. The horses bolted and ran into the woods. The men barely noticed as they watched the sky for the figures. The trees swayed as an unnaturally strong wind blew through the forest. The men could not see the shapes. The night was empty. The wind was the only noise.
"Owl. That is all it was. Come. We have to find the horses,"Jared said.
"That was no owl," said Aris hysterically.
Jared snorted and turned in the direction the horses ran. The color drained from his face. Aris turned to look.
Three Others stood looking at the men. Their deep blue eyes stared at them eagerly.

“What is that sound?” wondered Jared. A terrible sound surrounded them. It was as if thousands of venomous snakes with their heads recoiled, hissed at them; maybe preparing to strike at the same time, anytime. With the corner of the eyes he scanned the vast expanses of nothingness surrounding them. Not even a plant, leave alone an animal, was anywhere in sight. He wanted to survey more of a land around them but he soon sensed that sound was coming from something in front of them. It soon dawned upon him -

“It’s them? It IS them!” Jared eyebrows went up in acknowledgement of the fact it was the breathing of The Others which was causing this ghastly wheezing, hissing sound! The hair on the back of his neck stood up as he realized the fact although The Others stood some ten feet away from where AJred waxs but he could still hear each and every breath so clearly.
W-w-w-h-h-hh-hhh-e-e-e-e-z-z-z-z . H-i-s-s-s-s-s-s-s.

It sounded so death like. Jared was stunned but not afraid by any stretch of imagination. He looked straight into the Other’s eyes – those cold blue pupils, cracked at the ends and red veins zigzagging in them, as if ready to burst - but didn’t bat an eyelid and instead stared even harder. His fists were clenched and head upright. His muscular strong trunk like legs were tightened - not stiff just ready - to jump into the action if need arose. The gentle, cold breeze flowing under the blue, starry sky played with Jared’s mane and it flowed in the air, giving him a distinctive Samson appearance. He was ready for any mischief The Others may cause – well, almost ready – and all he needed was his thirsty Sword. He didn’t care about himself but he knew that he wasn’t alone in it. He had a responsibility of a partner who was possibly cursing him because it was he, Jared, who dragged Aris onto this adventure for which Aris was possibly not prepared to cope with.

“Ahh, my friend Aris,” - a mighty lump formed in his throat.

Jared turned his neck slightly – not much lest he might miss a view of The Others who looked posed for an attack -to look at Aris who was standing to his left. Aris’ pale eyes told the story of all the fears, all the brutality and all the savageness he was imagining at this point. His panic stricken yellow face shone even more under the moonlight and it went whiter with every passing moment. His lips shivered worse than a dry leaf in the autumn wind and his knees seemed like a mirage which could dissolve in the desert underneath them, without warning anytime now. It was if the shrillness from The Others’ eyes was impaling his soul, devouring it and ripping it out, one strand at a time – it is more painful that way.

Jared knew that he had to do something or the other else the anxiety of Aris would take over. As The others stood staring Jared and Aris, possibly trying to ascertain whom should they devour first, Jared parted his lips to say something. But The Others didn’t let him do it. The one in the middle said to them,

“Waskulyn Astrysda Ondro, va?”

Jared carefully moved his neck away from the frozen Other’s nail. He relaxed a moment, confused by the sudden cessation. The Other at his neck suddenly bent and kneeled. The two holding Aris knelt as well, dropping an equally confused Aris.
“Beravas, li torea bram cek manda tyresa,” the voice echoed through the woods again.
The Other in front of Jared snapped his (her?-- Jared wasn’t aware of the process of determining an Other’s gender) head up and whined. It was a loud, high-pitched squeal followed by a low, angry, guttural groaning.
“Warg ytotre le wetgu delaste reys abaratistals?” the voice echoed, this time threatening and challenging.
The Other bowed his/her head again. “Megrabe vy, fey abara.”
Jared mouthed a silent “What is happening?” to Aris, who shook his head and shrugged. Slowly, Jared began to back away from the Others. Aris, catching onto his lead, did the same.
Jared’s Other snapped his/her head up again. “My friends! Wait!”
Jared froze, as did Aris. “Why?”
The Other rose, as did the other two. “The gods have commanded we honor you by speaking your language, and take you into our village.”
“Gods? What gods? Vishnu and Hidra?”
The Others snorted, chuckling. “The piece of driftwood and our former latrine rock? No, friend. Our gods are much more powerful, and very real.”
This time it was Aris who snorted. “As if. If Vishnu and Hidra do not exist, then it is not reasonable for other gods to exist.”
“Maybe not gods, but perhaps something else,” a new voice cut in. The three Others dropped to their knees again, and this time Jared heard the clop clop clop and snort of a horse. He spun around to face the new intruder. His hand was at his scabbard, but his shock caused him to freeze and gape. Aris couldn’t even hold back a cry of surprise. “By the gods!”
Out of the woods came clopping a horse. But this horse not just a regular sorrel stallion, as was common among the knightry, but a lightning blue mare, with a golden mane, tail, and hooves. White feathery wings sprouted from the horse’s shoulder, an unheard of feature not even wild enough to appear in myth.
What really stole the show, however, was the winged horse’s rider. She was little, probably around five feet. But she was dressed in a full suit of armor, with the blue-ruffed helmet peeking out of her saddlebag. Her skin was tan and wrinkled, and her hair was long and white, portraying a woman in the age of carriages and sedan chairs. But Jared suspected from her garb that she was not the sedan chair type.
“Fey araba,” the Others spoke as one.
The woman smiled. “Rise, my chosen ones. You have done well.”
The Others rose from their knees to a squatting position.
“What are you doing?” the woman demanded
“It is disrespectful to raise one’s head higher than a goddess’s.”
"Oh, poppycock! You're eight feet tall! That's how tall I made you, and I want you to use all eight feet of that height at all times!"
"As you wish, fey abara."
The woman smiled as the Others rose back to their feet. She then turned to Jared and Aris.
"My name is Dame Melrose Marinafeather. I am one of the nine knights of the beyond, the queen of the Mars, or as you know them, the Others. Please, come with me, that I may help you with your quest."

Once upon a day rising Emma of the House of Martell left the world. She just didn’t get up one morning as the others went with their daily rites. They didn’t even notice her absence at first. After all, what is one less vieing for attention?
When they finally missed her, they went to her chamber and found her sleeping. Try as they might they couldn’t rouse her. She simply went on sleeping, oblivious to their call.

So began she first adventure of Emma to Otherworld.

When she awoke, she was in a strange yet familiar surroundings. No comfort in the familiarity, for it was dark and dank and her nerves were tingling. Yes, she knew the place now. It was the world of her reveries, when , at times, she’d just stare off in some distraction. Usually, it was a fair place but recent ones were ominous like this hall of darkness. Once it was a place where you were meant to face your own fears, your fearful self. Now it was menaced by a horrid beast set on turning those entering into his minions, using their dark selves permanently.

She shuddered as she remembered something impressed upon her in the last contact before the darkening images began:
“We are in serious danger. Without our visits to the Hall of Dark, where we face new levels of understanding, wisdom and strength, our society will stagnate and die or worse. Should we give in to the Morbidane, we become evil and turn in on ourselves, becoming a threat to others, even your world, eventually.

We have always served as peacemakers of spheres, constantly shifting to preserve a balance, as we have for all time, as directed by the Master. We serve to keep others at bay. The dark force too, is ever present. Greater it grows. Now it even enters our domain. A test, perhaps.

You are a rare one to have been able to delve into our world and we welcome peaceful intrusion. Now, it seems, in our hour of greatest need, you may be of service. In fact, he has already crept into you as well, so that you have stopped fighting in your own world. Little does he realize he may have played into our hands. Yes , the Great One makes use of evil to turn it to good.”

As she stood silent in the hall, she had so many questions battling for expression. How did she get here? What was she to do? Oh, she didn’t understand this. She just wanted to rest! Now she was to be a worse battle and had no clue. Worse still, it was not just for herself anymore, but would effect these gentle beings fo her reveries. Where would she be without them?
She made herself quiet and concentrated, to make contact.

“Yes , Emma , I hear you. Cannot help, I’m afraid. On ly to say that you have all you need to face this foe. We will support you and pray for alone we cannot defeat this evil. You have been chosen, so believe….”

“Wait!” Emma panicked. “Don’t go! Don’t leave me alone here!” she cried as the voice faded. A gentle echo reminded her: You are never alone , dear one.”

Emma leaned against the smooth rocky interior of the cave-like hall and took a deep breath, wondering what her next move should be. Should she wait for whatever was to happen or go in search of it? She was not eager to find it but wanted it to be done. She was about to decide when she heard the most raucous nerve tingling voice she’d ever heard.

“Welcome , young Emma. See how easy it was to just give up fighting and come to me? Fatigue is an easy tool to manipulate, don’t you agree? He laughed.

“I do not willing come to you, whoever you are! I am merely resting and you are totally imaginary!” she responded with all the courage she could muster on being confronted by this eery being.

The Morbidane roared with laughter, tossing his gigantic head back. “oh, no! I am quite real, though not know well in this form. And you, you are one of many falling, or rather coming to our ranks.”

“Never! Why me , anyway?”

“Why not? The higher they are , the more power I gain whrn they fall. It happens sooner or later, my dear. So face it?”

“Yes , we all make mistaken choices but there is always a way back. You may think you have me, but I will not stay! You cannot make me, If I will against you.” Emma retorted.

Morbidane merely grinned at the challenge. “Not easy, ma petite. I have several of these sickening peace creatures in my clutches, already primed and now, with you too, I’ll soon take over this domain. It is much too restful for my taste.”

“I will not help you. The others you tricked were not expecting subterfuge. I know you. I have forewarning. I will , but the Maker’s grace, not stay here.” Emma firmly stated as she stood, arms crossed, head held high in defiance.

Morbidane squinted at her steady clear eyes and rubbed one grubby had across his chin. “We’ll see,” he said , as he turned away. “You have yet to face the secrets of this hall.”

“That you have tampered with, no doubt. You are not in charge of me, do you hear?” Emma yelled after him. “You do nothing but take orders and hurt innocent beings, ignorant uninformed people. You have none of your own power. Only use theirs, you parasite.!”

Emma was quite angry at his confidence and a trifle afraid as well. She was not used to anger. Was she drawing on his? She didn’t know what to expect. The unknown was always a frightening concept, and for all her bravado, she didn’t know if she was strong enough to withstand the great tempting to come. In little things she even failed. Yet she learned from them and grew stronger. Now so much depended on her. Oh , she wanted to go home and cry in a corner at her fate. But somehow, with her anger turned to potency she knew she wouldn’t give in.

As she turned to begin her trek down the corridor, she saw a flash of light reflected off of a mica stone wall. Instantly she recalled Camil’s words, “You are never alone.” That’s right, she thought. She looked around for a dry spot and knelt to pray. She knew , in all humility, the only way through this was with the Maker’s help. She could not manage it alone but knew, if she asked in faith, He’s give her strength. It was a magic the Morbidane could not fathom.

“Oh Great Maker, I kneel before you, seeking, in my little faith, your help. Help my weakness in this grave time, for your peacemakers and for your greater peace. Let not this evil one win the day with his pride and arrogance. Surround us with love and strength, here in this darkness. Thank you." She ended in a whisper. As she signed the blessing she heard the faint echo of "unbowed, unbent, unbroken" the chant of the Martell Sunspears as they headed to battle, and with a lighter heart , she rose and began the trek into the Hall of Darkness.

She wondered, as she heard it just then, if it was happening back in her own time.

122311.content:
She walked into the great hall and was surprised to see the snowfall coming down all around her.

"Winter is coming, my dear," a strange voice said. Emma looked toward the center of the room and could barely make out the shape of a human form located there, deep within the snows. "The time of House Martell has come to a close. Winter is coming and those who are prepared shall endure."

Emma raised her chin. "The sun will melt the snows." Her voice was strong and defiant, belying the tremor she felt through her body.

"The sun may try." The scratchy voice laughed and Emma felt an odd familiarity. She knew that voice. She knew this soul. "Grandmother?" She stepped a little closer to the center of the room.

"Yes, my dear," her grandmother said. "But you can come no closer to me. I cannot offer you physical help here. It is forbidden. But you must beware the snow. It covers lightly, gently, until you realize that your path is blocked and you are no longer able to move."

Emma looked around at the snowflakes that fell into her golden locks and onto her thin night shift. She gave an involuntary shiver at the cold she had expected, but there was none. The Martell sun must be keeping me warm, she thought.

"The cold is not always felt on the skin," Grandmother warned. "The cold we must fight against most is within the heart. He will try to corrupt your heart. He will attempt to make you believe things that you know are not true. If you believe, your heart will freeze and all will be lost."

Emma worried her lower lip with her teeth. It was a habit that she thought she had broke as a young child. And, like a child, she longed to rush into her grandmother's arms to find comfort. Grandmother had been a Stark and had traveled from Winterfell to House Martell when she married Grandfather. "It makes sense that you would be in here with the snow," Emma said. "You always did miss it. I still think of your stories."

Grandmother chuckled softly. "I never could get used to the heat that you all seem to thrive within. But you must be prepared, my granddaughter. Winter snows can cover even the warmest of hearts."

Emma nodded. "Yes, Grandmother," she said solemnly. "But, can you tell me, why am I here?"

Grandmother sighed. "You were chosen," she said. "None but the Maker know the reason why. But He has faith in you. And I do as well. You must defeat this best. You must refuse him. For if you do not, the Martells will perish along with the rest of the realm."

Emma felt a weight, like that of a fifty pound feed sack, press down on her shoulders. She was barely fifteen, so how could she be expected to take on this task and save the kingdom. Wasn't that a job for knights and squires? Maidens like herself were expected to embroider and run households.

She fell to her knees in the deep snows. The white powder covered them and crept up her thighs. She considered lying there and allowing the snow to cover her body. What cannot be seen cannot be hunted, she thought.

"You must not give up before you begin," her grandmother's voice traveled toward her ears and she found she could not shut out the words as she longed to do. "You are chosen and you must fulfill your destiny."

"I don't want it." Emma said simply.

"Then we are all surely lost." Grandmother's voice was sad and disappointed. The words felt like a dagger slicing her thin skin and Emma felt the coldness of the snowdrift in which she sat.

"It's so cold," she remarked. "I feel as if it is sucking all of the warmth from my body." She lifted her hand from the snow to stare at the reddened skin.

"When you give up the warmth, you allow the cold to seep in." Grandmother said.

"What can I do?"

"You must continue your destiny, child. You must defeat the Morbidane."

"And if I cannot?" Emma's voice trembled, though she wasn't sure if it was from fear or the cold. She stood, eager to leave the snow's icy grip.

"You must!" Grandmother's words were harsh and firm, like the winters she often spoke of in Winterfell.

Emma nodded, her eyes brimming with tears. "I'm afraid."

"We all are afraid when our destiny comes to call." Grandmother's voice softened and Emma took solace in the warmth there.

"What do I do?" She steeled herself. Fear was for children. She was a woman and would do what was needed to save her family.

"You must face your fears and let them not change you."

Emma let out a ragged breath. "Okay, I am ready."

"You have passed the first fear." Grandmother said. "You did not allow the cold to freeze you. You found your warmth. The others, I'm afraid, won't be so simple. But you must continue. We all depend on you. Be well, child. And remember, winter is coming."

A new day has dawned, but my mind is always a whirl of jumbled thoughts. Today I drift into the future into my early days on Writing.Com. I was but a wee calf of a writer back then.

Once upon a time, way before Game of Thrones, I went to join Stories.Com, which later became Writing.Com.

The year was 2000.

When I first joined this site, I came with a group. The site was about 9 days old and the only writing we could do was in Interactive Stories like this one. My group came from a website that wrote fan fiction about a movie. When we came to write in the Interactive we did not have to go through an editor because we could post our work instantly.

I had no idea who ran the site when I first joined. I just jumped in, created a portfolio so I could write in the Interactive Story called Sam and Josie, I believe and wrote and wrote and wrote. I wrote literally 100's of pages. I had so much fun and so did my friends. We eventually quit going to the other site because we would have to wait months after we submitted our work for the person in charge to post it. In looking back, I think she was quite mean to some of us, especially the younger writers.

At some point I saw that the Interactive Story briefcase was "Cool". This is the equivalent of what is now being promoted to preferred. I seem to remember some sort of dark glasses on the briefcase. I wanted to have that and when we could add items to our portfolio (not to long after joining - maybe a couple of months) it was not long before I was cool,

I had no idea who Moderators were or what they did because I never interacted with anyone outside my group until I decided to make a forum for myself. That was a mistake because soon after I made that forum someone came into it and told me my writing wasn't good and it was all the same thing over and over.

A Moderator called The Milkman came in and defended me and so did SMs and SM. They were very nice to me. So, I got over it and branched out and started to read other things besides my groups story.

I made up my mind then that I would write more than just Fan Fiction about the movie, Never Been Kissed, but I continued to write stories and my popularity grew until I was pretty far up the most viewed list. I started reading and reviewing more outside of my group and I had a great time doing that. I tried this thing called The Writing Assignment that was run by NL* and I was a co-winner of the first gift point giving contest on the site.

My handle back then was CAROLINELOVESTHEBUS. I wrote some really racy stuff back in my youth - we called it red ball then, but today it is known as XGC or something like that. I blush thinking of some of the stuff I wrote in my stories, but it got readers to come to me.

Things went along alright and I didn't pay much attention to site politics until one day in June 2001 when I was promoted to Moderator. I had no clue, so I wanted to see what was what with that. Let's just say my feelings were hurt by people who said I couldn't write. A lot of people, like SMs, NL* and others defended me, but a lot (who later admitted they hadn't read my stuff because they hated fan fiction) thought my writing was cow pies.

I overreacted, lets just say that. I overreacted and was a bit of an ass my own self in my overreacting youthful (compared to now) rage.

I declined the promotion and wrote some angry rants. I never named people, but I went off on their behavior in a way that I shouldn't have done. Sometimes, even a bull like me allows my temper to rule the day.

I also found out that some of my friends in my group were not really my friends. Oh, they pretended they were, but I saw enough things around then to know that my friends were now allied with the people who wrote terrible things about my writing and about me as a person.

Jealousy is a revealing thing. When I moved up that list of "Most Viewed" the long knives came out for me and some came out in writers who were here because I told them about this site. Some of them no longer wanted to know me when I was hurt and at my lowest point. But, the feeling there was mutual. Later when they tried to butter me up, I had none of it.

Some figured out that I was back as 4provinces, but I kept my identity to myself for a while. I wanted to prove that I could write and so that is what I did. I wrote and I wrote and I read everything I could find to read. A forum called, "You Should Be Reading This," was hosted by Yemassee, the number #1 Most Viewed author for a time. It was a great place to recommend fine reading and to find great reading. Yem would feature those of us who frequented our forums and personally recommend us. A recommendation from him meant a lot.

Yem was one of the first people here who encouraged me. He had no idea who I was, but he read my writing and endorsed me. That means so much to me, even today. I am in his debt forever for that. He had quite a sense of humor and sent me pictures of cuts of meats once I became the hooves personal as a secondary account. But, I get ahead of myself in my story.

Yem was a good friend.

I know fair weather friends and allies when I see them. I know the duplicitious evil that envy engenders.

So, that was a hot summer, that summer of 2001. In August I folded my tent and said adios, until I returned to write again in September as 4Ps.

That was the beginning of the modern era for me.........

He has ties to everything in Hollywood, a silent era Kevin Bacon of sorts.

Charlie Chaplin had an absentee father and his mother was in and out of the nuthouse in London. When she went "away", Charlie had to go to the orphanage with his brother. Think about how bleak that must have been for the little guy. He was the first to write, Direct, produce and act in and write music for his own films. They take liberties with the facts, but the biographical film of him starring Robert Downey Jr is quite something. I really enjoyed that film and it made me want to learn more about him.

Another cool fact about Chaplin is that he stood up to Hitler. Hitler had a Charlie Chaplin moustache, not the opposite. So, when Chaplin ridiculed Hitler in the Great Dictator (around 1940) Hitler put Chaplin on his "kill" list. If Germany had won the war, Chaplin would have been toast.

The frenzied rhythm of the music pulsed faster, and the steps of the dancers grew wilder with each twist, turn, and downbeat. Their voices rose as one, exuberant and exultant. The atmosphere was festive, though tinged ever so slightly with fear. The man in the red silk paid no heed to the music riveting the other celebrants. His eyes were downcast, focused on the grave. He danced to his own time signature, and muttered words no other could hear, even if they had been attuned to them. If his words failed, their fate was sealed. He carried on, bare feet stomping and arms swaying, out of sync with the rest of the revelers.

The blonde haired woman in the silver gown rejoined him at last. Her dancing mirrored his own, and like a reflection in a mirror, neither image touched the other. The heat from the bon fire glistened on their skin, shining under the cool beams emanating from the enormous blue-white moon. Together, they twirled faster and faster, as if something wicked nipped at their heels.

The night wore on, and the triumphant dancers faded away, exhausted by the frivolity. All but the man in red silk and the woman in the silver gown. The pair danced on, until the last little star had left the indigo sky. Only then did their dance cease. Only then did they realize, it was all in vain.

The sun, which had just begun to rise to its glorious, pink-tinged heights, disappeared in a boom of thunder that shook the gravestones. Night fell again, without the benefit of light from neither moon nor star. Darkness, like the depths of the ocean, enveloped the village. From the stone beneath their feet, a ghastly grey mist swirled, coalescing into a familiar shape. Their hearts sank.

There came something across the meadow, howling at the moon. Oh yes, it is the direwolf leading me to wind my story back to the country of my origin, the place where Game of Thrones (part of it anyway) is filmed. That would be Ireland.

One day I returned to my native land. This was after I was transported forward in time to the year 2005. It was December. I flew in a giant Aer Lingus plane from Boston to Shannon, Ireland. The hillsides were alive with grazing sheep and cattle as I landed in the early morning hours.

I carried with me a heavy mantle of grief and pain that is always with me through the centuries. When one loses ones loved ones as I have done, you feel the loneliness quite keenly. This is all the more painful for me around Christmastime as I lost both my parents close to Christmas.

My travels this time took me to Westport, Galway, the Dingle Peninsula and then to Adare. In Adare I went walking one winter's day. All the leaves were brown. And the sky was gray. It was foggy and the village streets were clouded with a heavy mist. I knew somehow I would find my brethren as I walked, and so I did. I turned a corner, as if drawn to them by a siren's song. There they were, a fine bovine herd grazing in the earling morning.

I heard a lot of fine music on that trip, in pubs and in the streets of Westport. There was no more welcome sound than those early morning moos. An old man I passed on the street, called me, "english". He appeared to be suffering from some sort of confused anxiety or dementia. I am no more English then he was. Maybe, he felt that I was different and as a time traveling bovine, so I am. I am very different. As we passed one another, I deliberately passed gas. I confess this because I feel a certain triumphant guilt about it. Things happen. I forgive myself. He deserved it.

While I work hard for my herd and for my team, I am me, first, last and always. I am not perfect. In fact, I have a jealous streak and I am quite competitive when the mood strikes me. I will carry my mantle and do what is right no matter what comes my way. I can fight any bull in the pasture, but it must be on my terms. I lower my horns and charge and pray for the best that is to come.

Many a noble steed has met their ending in the Game of Thrones. Whether it was on a Belfast filming set or somewhere in the fictitious Westeros, there have been some awful deaths. Don't get me started on the Dothracki and their antics. Daernys and those dragons are cool, but Kal Drogo was pretty shocking to me. I know I will survive to live, graze and even dance another day. How do I know this? I am an old soul, who has survived for centuries, traveling through the shrouded mists of time.

If you look in any film that features bulls, you will see the eyes of hooves. In Hemingway's writing, I'm always there, nodding to the great man. No boundary can keep me in. I fly on the wings of the raven and I charge into the fray. Aligned with the Stark family, I know that right and goodness are with me. These traits will carry us through to tomorrow and beyond.

When I travel, I need no credit card. My credit is in the wink of an eye and the low melifluous moo of my calling. I bring peace to the countryside in my open face and steadfast ways. You might think, at times, that I am a reviewing machine. This is what I was meant to do, to write, to communicate with others via this modern day invention called a computer. My hooves type like the wind as I convey my heart's deepest fears and wildest hopes and fantasies. I will carry you with me to Ireland, to Westeros, to Broadway.

I am show tunes. I am music and I write the songs. Barry Manilow stole that from me.

Oh yes. I am a one bull show.

Bravo.

Do not go gentle into that good night for I will find you and I will force you to do what is right and fair. I see you with your pride that goes before the fall. Do you know what that means? I would not wave your banner so high and mighty in the face of adversity that comes from the hunger and pain of a noble family. This is not Downton Abbey. There is no Lady Sybil to campaign for what is right and fair. There is only us, the lowly rabble to contend with. We do everything we can to emerge victorious.

I am Lady Sybil. I am Spartacus. I am probably trying to combine every movie and Television show I've ever seen into this Interactive story, but it is my feverish imagination and it is original and it is fine. I am Seinfeld. How about that? I am George Costanza, with his secret weapon of wishing for the opposite of what he truly wants. My deductive powers are beyond imagining.

I babble on in my feverish rantings, but the end is near. I can feel the yoke of centuries being lifted from my haunches. Things will work out for the Starks, or they won't. The fairies heard that the great Hooves would be coming into the woods in the evening to the annual Dance without Pants in the moonlight Event. They were so excited and a little nervous. Most of the creatures that attended were bigger than they were and the heifer had wonderful if big hooves. He was light on his feet but they would need to make sure that little ones watched where they tread.

Teena and Tona had met Hooves in the pasture one day while dusting the flowers and clover. They knew right away that he was no ordinary cow and had as sort of magic and imagination beyond others of his kind. Fairies like all creatures and can get along with most and it was no different with Hooves.

They talked of many interesting things and shared concern over what was happening with the battles between the great castles and the destruction of pasture and woodlands. Humans tend not to think ahead in their press for glory and riches, or to protect what is theirs. Fairies like when everyone can play fair and all win. Fun and uniqueness is the name of the game.

One day, when they met, Piper came along and played his flute. It was then the meadow came alive and they saw Hooves make his moves, dancing in the field. It was wonderful, the clopping this way and that in a line dance and then leaping like a ballerina and he did not even need tights! Teena and Tona flitted and flirted around him until they all fell laughing on to the green clover bed. A few passing onlookers from the fairy and animal clans clapped in delight. They had heard Piper's music and cam down to enjoy the show.

That was awhile ago before the Great Houses went to war and the Starks swooped up the bovines and home and headed for safer place. So when the word got round that Hooves was coming back (from travels to somewhere called Broadway} everyone was excited.

Preparations were being made for the dance already, but now they shifted the venue to a flatter piece of green , just outside the woods. The main buffet and sitting area was still in the woods, so if folks noticed anything and came to investigate, they could hide. and all they would see was Hooves, a grazing cow. They wanted Hooves to have lots of room to maneooover with the other creatures who would be dancing too.

Piper and the crickets, grasshoppers and owls were getting in tune. Tree sprites had coaxed the fireflies into the fairy lanterns to hang in the trees. All of the animals brought a selection of foods as they liked and the rule was no one could eat each other. They had to get Bear and Moose to carry the bale of hay for Hooves' meal. Though he could graze all he wanted, they wanted Hooves to feel like a part of the family and a guest at the same time.

The sun was setting and all was in readiness as the first creatures began to arrive. As the stars rose, they could see a shadow sauntering forward from the horizon. Could it be Hooves? He was still a ways off but it definitely had his silhouette.

As the full moon rose, Piper began to play and fairies twirled around in the air. Rabbit and coyote paired up for a Catch as Can dance, not wearing pants. Bear rubbed a tree as he did the Jive. The deer and moose jerked their horns and heads in unison from side to side to the beat, getting ready for the chorus line Hooves would lead. Porcupines paired each other as no one else would and spun in the Quill and Spill dance they had created. Raccoon did the Slide by himself, keeping on eye on the treats, ready to sneak some if he slid too far. Skunk and his partner kept a distance from the others in case he had an accident. They enjoyed the Dance of the Two- toned Tails while the ground hogs did the Boss A NOOOva . Ravens, crows and other bird friends went Hop Hop Bopping along while the Owl hooted with the fairy and cricket band.

The dance was in full swing when Hooves made it to the clearing. He was already moving his tail as he heard the music from afar. Teena and Tona went to greet him and each sat on one ear, giggling.

The music came to an end and everyone looked at Hooves with welcoming hiya's. They all stepped out to make a circle around the dance field and Hooves took his place with the Moose and deer to begin the chorus line. Piper began a rousing tune and everyone began to sway and kick and flit and had a ball, even when feet kicked this way instead of that and tripping became a trick. Laughter, hoots, caws, grrs, gaffaws, were the order of the night. They were glad they had moved the dance area away from the trees and food or injuries might have occurred.

When the music stopped, they sat and watched their guest Hooves perform his renowned minuette with the fairies. Hooves happily danced without pants to his heart's content and when it ended, everyone applauded and wanted to join Hooves in another foot stomping hoe down song. Everyone got in the swing, except Raccoon, who could simply not wait any longer and snuck away for a bite.

Soon, everyone followed suit and as the sun began to rise, the party broke up and everyone drifted off to their homes. The fairies stayed the night with Hooves in the pasture, and they all thought it was the best Dance Without Pants in the Moonlight Event ever!

"CAWWWWW!" Raven of Martell screeched as he was squeezed through the tunnel that some sneaky Stark mage tricked him into. Blast his weakness for shiny things and chocolate! he thought.

He struggled out to the other end and ... "CAAAWWWW! Where the heck was he?" he pondered as he looked around this strange place. He was in a park so he recognized trees and grass and....sky...and that was about it. Humans he saw but what weird looking outfits and ...well..really is that blue hair? There must be wizards here." he thought.

He ruffled his feathers and hopped around on the grass to uncrease his body and being. He caught a bug while he was at it. Might as well eat as he pondered what to do.

He hopped over to a seat made of metal and noticed a man, grubby as a soldier laying on it. A large scroll like paper was placed over his head. Raven hopped up on the arm of the seat and peered at the scroll. A date caught his eye.

2015!! The future! That stark creature has sent me ahead in time.? No wonder...

He leapt from the seat and flew over to another stone statue--perhaps it was a gravestone. Interesting . It was a man on a horse in some sort of outfit. maybe a futuristic battle outfit. From there he could see even more outlandish things on wheels travelling faster than horses. and structures that were taller than any castle and blocked the sun.He flew up to investigate. He looked right in and whammed right into an invisible glass. It took him a minute to recover midair! CAAAAAWWWWW.! What magic is this? He landed with a little thud on a very hard surface and was almost stepped on by a woman with spikes on her shoes. He had to keep hopping around as people pushed by each other so fast and if he went too far over, those speeding machines would run him down for sure. Weren't there any other creatures here?

"Ruff, rufff, grr." oh great! He looked up. What on earth was that? A tiny furry barking....carried by that woman in spikes.

" A dog" a caw came out of nowhere. Raven looked up on the tent over a doorway to see a Crow watching him with a smirk. He flew up and joined him. "Oh, really. not like any dog I have ever seen. More like a cat." he said.

"mmm, new to these parts, are ya?" Crow asked, giving him the once over and grinning again.

"well, yes, actually , just today. What is this place? Do you live here?"

"Yep, for years. It is called Broadway."

"It does not look broad to me. Narrow walks and buildings together. and too many people squished in."

" oh it is the name of the town, not the space. You get used to it and it is a great place for us to get good eats and you should see how it shines at night. All the twinkles we crows are fond of. Don't even need to steal them. They are there every night."

"Really." Raven perked up. He did like shining things. "how..?"

"Well, they say the stars come out on Broadway. But they are not white like our stars. And You would not even know it was night sometimes with all the light."

"is it magic? Does a wizard make it happen?"

"Wouldn't know about such things! You are a strange one, you are.Where did you say you were from?" Crow looked at him once more. "The country probably, a hick no doubt. So I suppose what you see here might be called magic." He did not want to think about that too much as Crows have long memories, and he recalled.

"er..well..you might say that." Raven considered his answer. "I'd sure like to see the shiny things."

"Just hang around with me then. I am for a meal so watch and learn." Crow flew down and picked up a piece of food from a large tin can. "See. Easy." Raven was intrigued and went over and peeked in. Wow. It was certainly a variety of treats. He snatched a piece of burger. "mmm! That will fill me up for a week. " he cawed with delight.

"Now what?"
"We wait for night fall and you'll see. Let's rest in that tree for now. You can watch it all from there, safely." Crow suggested.
Raven sat and thought while Crow went silent. What was he doing? he should be figuring out a way back--to his time. Martell house needed him. There must be a way.

"Must you think so loudly?" Crow interrupted his thoughts. "I knew there was something odd, yet familiar about you. From the past, eh? Some wizard trick, I imagine. "

"What? you knew....? "Raven was confused.

"Not at first. Just thought you were a country bumpkin. I meet alot of them. Not much brain. But you seemed different and then when you mentioned a wizard...mmm.. not much talk of that any more. So I thought I would just listen."

"You were feigning sleep?"

"Smart one aren't you? You would have known it too had you not been so busy being distracted here. It is how you lose who you are and forget....which is what that sneaky wizard would want to happen. so you never find your way back."

"There is a way back?"

"on yes, and lucky for you, I am here to show the way. I have been waiting a long time, stuck here in this world. er..well I have enjoyed it. But we had more power and brilliance back then...in your time."

"you...you are from my time?" Raven was amazed.

"Well, likely before your time. I too was transported by such a wizard . One other was with me. I watched as he lost his way and became ordinary. We parted ways. I was lucky to find the way back, but then had a dream. About you. And knew my calling was to remain and wait--for you are vital to the battle and must return. I believe all our times depend upon it." he stressed.

"But...well, they tell a story of such a one as you but we thought it just a tale." Raven said. "So you will help me get home."

"Yes and we begin now. See it is sunset and the twinkles are coming on. We must fly down to one of the play houses and watch a show."

"What? You mean like one of those travelling minstrel shows that come to the castle? Here?"

"Not exactly, but close enough. They do plays on stage and there is one show that has what we need.
We will have to hurry and fly in when the door opens before that guard attendant shoos us. I will tell you what you must do in case we get separated."

"You mean these shows have guards as castles do? What are they protecting?" Raven was intrigued.

"It is not really like that. People pay to get in and they don't let creatures in or people who want to bother the performers, who are famous."

"Oh, the riff raff! I get it." Raven said, happy to finally understand something about this world. "but , wait,
what will happen to you? Will you return with me?"

" I doubt I can now, and would not want to. Life is harder there and I am aged. Still, we will see what fate has for us. A prophet rarely sees his own. You know that."

"Indeed," Raven mused. Was he not the one to "see" what others could not, yet in he walked to a trap!

"Look!" Crow motioned with his wing.

Raven's eyes widened to take in the spectacular display of lights of all coloured signs that lit up the buildings. BROADWAY in neon flashes. "Wow, it is so magical!" I will always remember" Raven murmurred. "but I am ready to go home."

Crow nodded and said. "Then let's go!" and flew down to the theatre now opening its doors---the back doors were the easiest. It stood ajar and the doorman was smoking a cigarette a foot away from it. it was just enough of a space for the two birds to hop up the step and into the hall.

"whew! This way." said Crow , flying up to the rafters above the stage. Raven followed and they both sat there watching the performers get ready.

"This is it. You know what to do. Near the end of the show, when they sing their last number, ....I will tell you when...I have seen this so many times and never taken the risk...."

"Will you come this time..? You must feel so alone here..."Raven left off, seeing Crow shake his head. "I have done what I came to do , if you get home. yet, maybe.." Crow could feel Raven's pull toward home, the home he knew, but the home Crow tried to forget. It would be gone now anyway. Still he felt a call to somewhere.

"Now" Crow cued. "Good luck my friend." Raven nodded. "same to you."
He flew down to the stage and saw Crow do the same, just as the chorus sang the refrain of the age old song, full of the magic that would send him home....

"Bye, Bye Birdie"

With the last chorus, people in the audience could have sworn they saw too black birds shoot low and disappear in to the lights.

That night the Princess fell asleep without peace. The dark veil of unconsciousness evaded her for several hours before it fell over her weary mind. She had no idea of the hour this happened but one thing was certain - she'd wiled every waking minute thinking of the Raven and the orbs.

So it was apt that after however long, when she finally fell asleep she dreamt of the raven and his magic.

The darkness of her mind turned into wings of midnight black which slowly drew away. With a jolt she realised she was the raven itself. She could feel her wings arching at her sides, the pull and thrust of every movement as she flew. This oddly felt too real to be dream, she thought as she soared into the sky, feeling the hot sun on her black feathers.

Then the dream morphed again as she flew into an old mansion. The place was deserted like everyone had left there in a hurry. Everything seemed to be old to her eyes, everything with just a little hint of magic. It was her fascination perhaps that drew her further into the house. Silk draped the walls and thick woollen carpets adorned the floors. She could see chandeliers hindering her flight at every turn - huge crystal monoliths that sparkled fresh at every new turn.

So as she flew through a set of carved oak doors, she expected the rooms to be empty as well. But again her dreams morphed and there was an abundance of people in the once empty room.

Among them, lying on the king sized bed of white draperies lay her grandmother like she'd last seen her. She'd been ill then, though now in real life Aqua knew she was prosperous. She didn't think she'd be noticed, but her grandmother sussed everyone else and bade them to leave her way.

Hesitantly she reached her side, perched by her bed. She lifted her beautiful eyes up to her and said,

"Find that which has been lost, leave no stone unturned. For every magic is treasure and every treasure can be unlocked."

With that the princess felt herself fading away. She tried desperately to hold on but she couldn't. She felt herself sinking into the darkness again but she could've sworn she saw those violet orbs in her grandmother's eyes before she faded away from her.

With that the princess spent the rest of the night in the dark solace and awoke that morning with a new puzzle in her hands.
