Hooves was pacing and the ship was rocking.

Troubled by events that had happened in the past three weeks, hooves could not shut off his thinking. Being a good sailor should have made for an enjoyable voyage, but hooves was troubled.

There were many positives. Hooves had enjoyed some great reading, met some awesome people and gotten reacquainted with some others who were some of the nicest people going.

That had to be said. The "game" forced hooves out of his comfort zone and into the mix. All good things. All positive things.

Last year, when hooves cheered for another team, he was welcomed with open arms, hugs and lots of encouragement.

This year, being a player on a team, the welcome mat was not there for almost three weeks.

It was as if he was expected to know what to do and how to do it. The leader of the team was very positive, but it was the other members who at times gave hooves the cold shoulders. If the truth were told, that had been the case since whenever, not just June. Now that hooves had proved he was a worker bee, there was some luke warm respect, and even one intrepid interactive sweetie pie, but very little else.

Since the team prided itself in helping and nurturing newbies, hooves wondered a little about this. Do you remain insular when dealing with them? He wondered about it some more. But talk is cheap. Show and tell takes time and experience.

The reason for this doubt was that hooves was a newbie to the team this year. Oh, yes he was.

But it is okay to not feel welcome or even wanted at times.

That can be a motivational factor that works to the good.

Negative reinforcement does not work on hooves. It might work on the people on survivor, but hooves is not on survivor. Maybe people have watched too much reality TV and they think you have to berate to motivate. Breaking old hooves down to nothing, tell him he's a loser and motivate him to prove he isn't? Sorry, doesn't work. Hooves knows who he is. He is a kind heart, who tries to do the right thing, but gets overwhelmed by temper tantrums when he is tired.

Positive reinforcement is the best teaching method there is. If you encourage and nurture, you see positive results.

People talk a lot about a lot of things.

Actions really do speak louder than words.

hooves decided to turn the experience into something enjoyable by just being himself. Sometimes, if that is not enough, then it is okay, too. Hooves is fine with being himself and just trying to use the experience to....well.. maybe in some way pay it forward.

This may take inventive thinking and ingenuity, but hooves has something to prove and it isn't to those who would kick him when he is down. He has to prove that despite hearing he is behind all the time, he will not quit. He will finish and there will be things he takes from the experience that are positive, whether or not he is liked or even wanted. He has outgrown the need to be accepted by anyone. That really doesn't matter

At the end of the day, what does matter is how we treat each other. hooves may have whined at times, but he always tried to express the truth about what was happening. No game strategy, just plain truth, hooves truth.

With the current struggles, she needed to be home to assist her fellows in combat, yet within minutes of arriving, she would feel herself lifted back out again. When she came to, she found herself in the forest. The scents told her she was home, but for how long? Would she be able to find her Queen, her band? Would she finally be able to help? Or was this just another tease, a promise unfilled? She rose, brushed herself off, and decided she would do what she could - as much or as little as her captor would allow.

Myst drew her sword. The hairs on her nape stood on end. She heard nothing, saw nothing, even smelled nothing, but she knew there was something out there, something with a heartbeat - something, friend or foe. 1223233113.content:
Unlike the slow moving, plodding bovines, Baron was fleet of foot, and sharp witted. He knew a nice, fat, juicy hare lived nearby under the hedges. He had seen its floppy ears and quivering nose poke out of a hole near the black berry bush. Baron had shed his human master long ago, back when he was a wee pup and knew he was destined for greater things. He didn't even think they missed him, way back six seasons ago. Now he was in his canine prime of life.

A twitch from the bushes and a cautious June hare hopped forward. Baron didn't move a whisker. He didn't want to spook the quick creature. He knew he was down wind, and chose a spot in the field where he could blend in with the fallen woods and bracken. The clouds were covering the sun and a cold breeze made it feel more like November.

Baron's stomach growled. He had been living on field mice and what his friend Kinney called 'leftovers' in the village and really was looking forward to sinking his teeth into the warm flesh of a hare.

The clouds parted and the sun streamed down for a minute, before a shadow blotted out the sun again. The hare, startled, bolted back into the bushes and Baron snorted a sound of disgust.

Baron stood up and shook the dirt from his body and gave one good last scratch. The clouds were back,and whatever caused the big black shadow was no where to be seen. In fact, there was no longer any bird sound at all.

Baron's fur stiffened and the thick protective cuff of fur around his neck raised. A sharp smell reached his sensitive nose. It wasn't man or beast, at least it wasn't anything he had detected before.

It smelled like blood left out in the rain, like mashed mushroom under the porch rotting, like Kinney after a good rut with the local bitches. It was an interesting smell, complex, multilayered, but not anything he could pinpoint, and Baron had the best nose in the land.

He trotted forward, a sleek twenty pound mass of canine muscle and steel determination. Nothing was going to ruin his potential dinner. But nothing was to be seen or heard in the field. He scanned the air, still no birds, No shadows, no rustling grasses, just the bouquet of blood.

Then he spied a subtle movement on a low hanging branch of the sycamore tree. A blending of greens, grays and browns were hiding a being made of grays and browns, a being not familiar to Baron, and one that put the fear of Odin in his heart.

The creature was watching the same berry bushes Baron had been watching. It had two arm like appendages, with something between fur and feathers in an intricate pattern between them. Baron thought he could see two gray eyes with something else behind a bush of tangled brown rasta braided hair. Was it human? Bird? Tiger? Baron couldn’t tell. Maybe it was a species of carrion bird he wasn’t familiar with, except it didn’t have the perfume of one of the clean up crew. With one of the creatures long nail like endings of the appendages, the creature pressed something on a leash like item on its wrist.

A shot of light flew from the creature and lit up the bush below. The hare bolted and the creature turned its device towards it and lit up the hair.

Baron froze in place. All that was left of his potential dinner were burnt bones and melted led from where a careless hunter had shot the hare a year ago. Nothing else. Baron heard a rumbling from overhead, similar to the noise humans called laughter.

The creature touched a red spot on its gray face and a human like voice spoke.

“You must be what the earth crawlers call a dog. Well, dog, I cooked your supper for you, maybe I went a bit to far. Sorry, buddy. If you don’t want the same fate as the hopping thing, you better come with me. I heard from the other dogs you have the best nose on this planet. Come, oh black nosed one and join with me. My name is 7n89hiphkjkp, but you can call me 7. I need you to find a certain fungus for my shipmate. 8 has turned green around the gills from eating a short red haired human last night. If I land on the ground, here, in front of you, you have my permission to ride my back while we circle the lands looking for the fungus. Well?” the creature growled.

Baron was shocked. He could understand the creature as well as he could one of his canine friends. It spoke dog fluently, but what was it? Baron was a smart dog, and knew he better play along with the creature until he could figure out a way out of the area. He thought he would at first test the mettle of the creature to see if it was bluffing. Baron was brave like that.

“I am not a truffle dog,” he spat. “I am a pure bred schipperke, destined to do great things and rule the fields and oceans. I am no one’s bitch (well I am male, so I guess I am not) and do no human’s bidding. No one is my master.”

The creature did the laughing sound again. “I don’t want a slave, I want a partner. I am always on the look out for a quick thinker, a loner, someone who knows what they want and doesn’t accept their place in this world. How do you think I landed here on your blue planet with nothing but my trusty friend 8 and a tin can?”

Baron came closer the creature, now landed on the ground in front of him. The ground was steaming and the grasses near the creature turned brown. But the smell from the creature was what he had noticed earlier and it was like heaven to a dog.

131122.title: A hunter who happened to go the same way

13113.content:
Sabrina tried to ignore the pain in her foot, so she began to sing. It was an old song her grandmother had taught her when she was very little.

Climb high
Creep low
Watch for shadows
wherever you go

Keep watch
Follow the light
Never, ever,
go out at night.

She glanced up at the cloudy sky, not sure where the sun was, and hoping it would not get dark soon. Sabrina's grandmother had warned her many times about the dark. And it had worked because Sabrina was afraid of the night, especially after she and her dog Bo had gone into the woods years ago.

Thank the stars, her fairy mother Celine had protected her dog from being pounced upon and shredded up for stew. But now her mother was dead. The wolf had killed her, so she heard. How does one kill a fairy? Besides, there was no proof. But Sabrina was determined to find out for herself.

She wished Bo was still alive. He'd been an old dog when she was little and died shortly after the incident in the woods. Her father promised she could have another dog, but he never followed through. She loved animals so much. And she still thought about the wolf in the woods and wondered if he could be tamed. Perhaps he'd been cursed by an evil witch and there was an antidote to remedy it.

Sabrina's father said she would never amount to anything because she was too kind and giving and always found the good in people and animals. He had told her the world was full of evil people who would just take advantage of her. But though she tried (and not for long,) she could not change who she was.

The woods loomed before her, uninviting and dangerous.

Climb high
Creep low
Watch for shadows
wherever you go

Keep watch
Follow the light
Never, ever,
go out at night.

The first thing she did when she entered the dark forest, was find a sturdy stick to help her walk. Her foot was throbbing with pain, worse than before. So she kept on singing.

Climb high
Creep low
Watch for shadows
wherever you go

Keep watch
Follow the light
Never, ever,
go out at night.

How far did she dare walk? It wasn't getting any easier and it surely was not getting any lighter.

A twig snapped behind her. She turned and forced a smile at the growling wolf.

13113.title: Sabrina finds herself in a bad situation

131131.content:
"Shush, Koal," a tiny figure demanded of the wolf. "Halt!"

"Mother?" Sabrina stepped closer, though warily. "Is that really you?"

Celine glowed with delight and flew toward her daughter. "It's been too long," she cried, hovering in front of Sabrina's face. "I've missed you dearly, my love."

"Father forbid me to come to the forest, especially after the last time, which was so long ago. Mother," Sabrina said, desperately choking back her sobs, "I thought you were dead. There were rumors going around, many years ago, that the... this... wolf had killed you."

"Ah, Sabrina. Don't believe everything you hear. It's very difficult to kill a fairy. And Koal protects me, warns me, as we've become quite attached to each other. We... We have no one else, you see. I've been a prisoner of the forest for too many years, thanks to Arwad, the evil sorcerer. And Koal has no friend because everyone is terrified of his size and they misunderstand his fear with ferociousness. But he and I... we understand each other. How is that father of yours, by the way?"

Sabrina leaned on her stick and frowned, staring down at her feet. She shrugged, then let out a breath. "Not well," she told her mother. "He's grumpier than ever. No one speaks to him much, unless they have to. And he still won't let me have a dog to replace Bo."

"Bo has passed then?" the fairy said sadly. "I didn't know."

"He was old, Mother," Sabrina said. "It was shortly after I saw you last, when you saved his life."

"Did your father promise you another dog then?"

"Yes, he did. But he always comes up with some excuse to make me wait longer. I'll never get a pup as long as I live with him."

Celine flew back to Koal and stood on his back. "You could always come and live here, with me," she said. "And Koal. He could be your wolf-dog, you know."

Sabrina had never considered leaving her father before now. And certainly not to live in the dangerous woods! And with a wolf for her pet? What was her mother thinking?

"Father would be furious," she finally said. "He would be all alone, too. He's already so unhappy."

"Perhaps if you left, Sabrina, he would be free to marry again. You are a constant reminder of me, you know."

"But the two of you are still married," Sabrina reminded her mother.

"Till death do us part," Celina said, winking. "Does he not believe the rumors?"

"He does," said Sabrina. "And he hates hearing them, too. He loved you very much, Mother."

"I know, my love. If only we could find a cure for this curse. I could return to him."

"Is there something I could do to help?" Sabrina offered, but suddenly fell to the ground in pain.

"Oh, what is it, Sabrina?" The fairy hurried over to her daughter.

"I sprained my foot I'm afraid. It's taken a turn for the worse."

131131.title: Celine Lives

1311311.content:
Celine gathered nearby herbs along with other live resources and packed them on her daughter's foot.

"You'll feel a difference momentarily," the fairy said. "In the meanwhile, you need to make some decisions. You cannot worry your father for long. He will be beside himself if you're gone for more than a few hours, I suspect." Celine closed her eyes for a brief moment and smiled. She missed her husband. She missed being the size of a human. Missed raising her daughter. Missed poor old Bo, too, and life outside the woods.

"How can we figure out what the antidote for your curse is, Mother? " asked Sabrina, standing now, without pain.

"I've been through every inch of this forest," Celine answered. "There's nothing here to indicate a remedy for this curse. My guess would be the cure is somewhere out there." She nodded toward the path that ended at the edge of the forest, into the light. "And of course, there is no way I can search for this remedy outside my prison among the trees."

"Then I must do it for you," Sabrina announced. "If you could only give me clues as to where to look, I will begin immediately."

"Not before you speak with your father about it," said Celine firmly. "I think it's time you are honest with him, tell him everything, including that I am alive and well... and missing him dearly."

"But Mother, he won't believe me!" exclaimed Sabrina. "He never believes me. I don't even think he likes me much, as he rarely speaks to me other than Stay away from the woods, girl."

Celine pulled the worn, pink ribbon from her hair, allowing her wavy blonde hair to tumble about her shoulders and back. "Give your father this," she said, but not before pulling several strands of her long hair out and tying the pink ribbon around them. "He will believe you once he sees the ribbon and my hair. The ribbon was a gift the day you were born, Sabrina; a token of our first girl child. He was so moved by you, my love. And he does like you... It may be hard for you to understand, but you remind him of me. And that's painful. He still loves me very much, I can feel it."

Sabrina wiped the tears from her cheeks. "I suppose you are right, Mother. I guess I never thought about it that way." She took a deep breath and smiled. "So. I'm off to find a remedy for your curse, which you've given me no clues as to where to look, but first I will speak with Father."

"I'm so proud of you," said Celine. "Your father might know where you can start to look, too. And tell him..." she paused. "Please tell him I'm looking forward to the day we can be together again." It was the fairy's turn to wipe tears from her cheeks.

Sabrina hugged her mother, nodded to the wolf who was napping, and headed down the path that would lead her back to her father, and hopefully a remedy for her mother's curse.

1311311.title: Sabrina's Decision

13113111.content:
It was dark, even outside of Silver Forest. But at least it wasn't as scary. Sabrina could see lights from the village, probably torches to keep evil beasts and spirits away. Her father would be worried. Probably angry. Would he punish her? She hoped at least he would take the time to listen to what she had to say.

Their torch had not been lit. Sabrina tried to open the door, but it was stuck. Father rarely bolted the entrance door if she was not home. He must be very angry, she thought, anxiety rising throughout her entire being. She knocked. Her father must be sleeping. Or passed out from too much drink, which had not been a rare occasion of late.

"Who's there?" a voice whispered loud enough for Sabrina to hear.

A woman's voice? Sabrina's heart sank. Had her father crossed the line? Had he finally believed his wife was dead and now taken in a whore?

"Sabrina," she answered. "I live here with my father," she added.

Someone unbolted the door and pulled it open. There stood an older lady, plump with gray hair and a wart on her right cheek. She smiled, showing off a gap where one of her teeth were missing. "Hurry!" she whispered, pulling the girl inside.

"Where's Father?" Sabrina asked, glancing around. "And who are you?"

"There's a problem," the woman began, still whispering. "Your father was at the tavern this afternoon, and I'd served him his last drink when a stranger sat next to him, at the same table. 'May I get you a drink, sir?' I asked him, but he shook his head. When I asked him if he'd like supper, he stared hard at me till his eyes glowed and I hurried away as fast as I could."

"Where is Father?" Sabrina asked again, hoping this wasn't going where she guessed it might.

The woman held out her hand. "I'm Bonnie, by the way. I knew your mother before she was... well, I knew her, anyway. Nice lady."

Sabrina let go of Bonnie's hand and asked a third time, "Where is my father? Tell me, please!"

"When the stranger left, your father told me to go to his home where you would be, and bolt the door. And not let anyone in," Bonnie continued. "He also told me to give you his love and he was sorry for not being kinder to you since your mother... disappeared. He never said where he was going, but I just bet it had something to do with that man with the glowing eyes."

"I wonder..." said Sabrina. "Have you heard of Arwod the Sorcerer?"

Bonnie jumped back, eyes bulging like saucers. "Shush, child. You musn't say his name too loudly. It's bad luck! Of course I heard of him. He's got spies, that one."

"Could the stranger in the tavern been a spy, do you suppose?" Sabrina asked.

"Now that you mention it, yes. He looked evil enough to me."

"Bonnie, how long ago did my father send you here?"

"Going on ten minutes or so. Not long. Hey, where are you going, lass? You father said to keep you locked in here!"

But Sabrina was gone, her mother's pink ribbon and strands of hair with her. If her father was still at the tavern, they could talk and she would give him her proof her mother was alive. If he wasn't there, she would ask questions and then search for her father the best she could.

13113111.title: The First Lead: Missing

131131112.content:
"Father!" Sabrina cried as she caught up with him. He'd just stepped out from the tavern door, appearing ragged and in need of sleep, but he looked up.

"S-Sabrina...love... y-you shouldn't be here," he stammered, eyes glazing. "Go back home, b-before it's too late."

"Father, we need to talk," Sabrina told him, taking his arm and leading him to a nearby bench.

"Not here," he said in a low voice. "Follow me. Quickly." With renewed strength, he led his daughter down an alley way then pulled her into a vacated room smelling of must and filth. An old mattress lay on the floor with a single blanket, threads barely keeping it together, and with holes worn through. The scent of urine lingered in the air from the pot in the corner.

"Father... do you... stay here?" Sabrina managed, trying very hard to breathe with shallow breaths.

He nodded. "At times, yes, daughter," he said. "It's a hide-a-way, you might say. But no matter. It's safe enough to talk now. Speak quickly. Time runs out."

Sabrina handed her father the pink ribbon and strands of her mother's hair. "Mother said to show this to you and you would believe me... that I've seen her. Today, Father. I've seen Mother today in the woods..."

He held his hand up for her to stop talking, while swiping a tear from his cheek with the other. He pressed the ribbon and hair strands to his heart. "Can it be so? Celine lives? Your mother is truly alive, not dead by the monster wolf?"

"Yes, it's true," Sabrina told him. "And she rides the wolf, Father. They are friends, she and Koal. He's kind, unlike the rumors, and only attacks those who attack him or are a threat to Mother."

"Is she still cursed?" he asked, though he knew the answer because she was not there.

"Yes, but she sends a message to you," Sabrina told him gently. "She loves you very much and says one day you'll both be together again, once we find a cure to the curse, of course. And that's why I'm here, Father. To find a remedy to the curse. Do you have any clues, or do you know where Arwod the..."

"SHUSH!" he shouted, though regretted it right away. "Do not say his name in case his spies linger near. They would jump at the chance to take you away to the evil sorcerer. Apparently, one has noticed you entering the woods, and has threatened to take you once he finds you. Bonnie was supposed to keep you bolted in, safe from harm. I see she has failed my request."

"It's my fault, not hers," Sabrina admitted. "She tried very hard to keep me there, but I have a mission to accomplish. I want my mother back and I want my parents to be happy and together again. Is that too much to ask?"

"No, of course not, child," her father said, though he should not have called her child. She had grown lovely and delicate, graceful and beautiful, just like her mother. It was painful to look upon her at times, reminding him of his loss.

"Then what shall we do?" Sabrina asked sweetly.

"We must not act hastily," he warned. "In fact, we must not act at all, till just before dawn. The spies should be asleep by then, tired of watching for you to escape, and we will slip away. I know of a cave, well hidden, where we can spend tomorrow deciding our next move." He lifted the ribbon and hair. "There is magic in this, Sabrina. Did you know that?"

She shook her head. "No. Mother said nothing about magic."

"Perhaps not magic in the woods, but the hair from a fairy holds special powers, though I'm not sure what they are. We will find out soon enough, daughter. Now we must rest."

Sabrina glanced down at the filthy mattress. "I..."

"Of course not," he said, reading her thoughts. He opened a closet door and pulled out another blanket, along with a pillow. "Here," he said. "The floor is hard, but these are clean at least."

131131112.title: Just in Time

1311311122.content:
A few hours before dawn, Sabrina and her father headed out. The streets were quiet except for an occasional dog barking or cat screeching. No words were spoken between the two travelers as they headed for rocky hills.

At last, Sabrina felt they could speak, at least at a whisper. "How much further?" she asked.

"Don't tell me you're tired, Daughter. We've a ways yet. I'm surprised..."

"Father," Sabrina interrupted. "I'm not tired, I'm hungry. I haven't eaten since breakfast yesterday, and only a wee bit of cheese and stale bread."

"Here," her father reached in his pack and pulled out a very bruised and shriveling up apple.

Sabrina decided not to complain. She buffed it up the best she could to make it look more inviting, though it hadn't helped much. Food was food, at this point. At least there were no worm holes.

"What was that?" she whispered even lower than before and crouched down along with her father.

He glanced around, but saw nothing. "We'd best keep low," he said. "We'll pick our way through the larger rocks till we reach the passageway. The cave is just past there, high and overlooking a valley no one inhabits."

"Why not, Father?" Sabrina was curious.

"Many say it's evil. But we need to pass through it. Keep your fingers crossed."

Keeping low to the ground, father and daughter at last made it to the passageway, where they stood up and stretched, feeling safe.

"The cave's over there." Her father pointed to a hidden crevice.

"But Father, look!" Out from the cave came a giant wolf. It stared their way, frozen.

"I have nothing to fight a wolf with," he told his daughter.

"The fairy hair, Father! Use the fairy hair tied up in Mother's ribbon!"

He held up the small bundle and the wolf stood, and slowly approached.

"It's not working," he said, backing up.

"But it is working," said Sabrina, smiling. "It's Mother's wolf, Koal! He's come to help us!"

1311311122.title: The Magic of Fairy Hair

13113111221.content:
Koal nuzzled Sabrina's hand, to her father's surprise.

"Did Mother... I mean, Celine send you?" she asked, gently stroking his back.

Koal's eyes were closed, enjoying the physical attention. He'd had to be careful to get to this point. And he only came because Celine insisted. He liked her daughter, but he'd been unsure about her husband at first.

"He's tired," Father said. "We are most fortunate it was him and not another wolf."

"Is something wrong?" Sabrina asked, noticing her father's eyes water.

"I'm... I was... wrong. I should have listened to you years ago," he said. "I'm much too set in my ways. I have not listened to you as a father should listen to his daughter."

"It doesn't matter now, Father," said Sabrina. "We are here now, together. On the same mission. And having Koal her makes it even better."

Koal opened his eyes, only for a moment, hearing his name.

"Once he rests," said Sabrina, "I'm sure he will take us where we need to be. Koal loves her as much as we do. And..." she added... "if it all works out, perhaps he could me my new dog you promised me after Bo died."

"The people of the village would be much to afraid of him, Daughter."

"They will accept him, especially after he helps us find Mother. You will see."

Koal opened his eyes once again, ready.

"Let's go," Sabrina said, her hand on his back. "Lead us, Koal, and we will follow."

131132.content:
But the wolf did not smile back. Instead, he seemed to be changing shape. He stretched his neck like a pipe and howled. Immediately two big horns appeared on his head. Then he stretched his paws and his nails started growing until they were ten inches long. Then he opened his mouth and growled, as his fangs grew the size of a grown-man’s arms.

“Oh,” Sabrina said, knowing she had no escape, but her only way out was to use her head. “Oh, how wonderful! Just how did you do that?” Hadn’t her fairy of a mother told her in a dream that even the wildest of beasts could be tamed by a loving and gentle hand?

The wolf seemed to be taken aback. He stared at her with--what seemed to Sabrina as- love-starved eyes. As Sabrina looked back into the beast’s eyes faking bravery, her mother’s relentless, demanding voice whispered in her ear. “Remember your fairy blood.”

Fairy blood? Now what was that? She drew in a ragged breath as her flesh prickled cold and damp with perspiration.

“I am Sabrina, Sir,” she said in gentle voice, but without letting her eyes hold any deference in the least. “The daughter of Celine, the fairy.”

The wolf’s eyes’ lofty arrogance in their intense yellow brightness paled then, and he sat on his haunches, still staring at Sabrina.

“Celine,” he moaned. “Oh, that Celine! She broke my heart.”

“I heard my mother was wasted here in the woods,” Sabrina continued. Surely, she didn’t want to say ‘you’d eaten her.’ That would give the beast new ideas.

“A fairy is never wasted or eaten, little Halfling,” the wolf said. “Fact is, she had had it enough with her mother-in-law and the man she called husband, in fact, the entire humankind who neither respected nor understood her.”

Now, Sabrina was truly surprised. Had her grandmother and father not told her the truth? “She is still…”

“Yes, she still is here living in the woods in the fairyland with her kind, but as much as I’ve chased her, and I am using the word chase metaphorically, she wouldn’t even look at me. My stalking her annoyed the queen of the fairies, so she gave me this shape. Anytime I approach someone I like, I turn into a beast.”

“Shucks,” said Sabrina, taking a deep breath, “That means you like me. I like you, too. In fact, I like all animals and all life. It’s not fair what has been done to you. Just because you liked someone…”

“Oh to be so naïve! I had sensed that about you, little Halfling. But life is never about fairness.”

“I wish it were,” said Sabrina. “After all your mistake was loving someone. As far as the reality of justice is concerned…”

“Beings like us make their own reality, little Halfling. We love for reasons even unknown to our own selves.”

“Well, whatever the reason, still it is not fair. I am still young but I always think of love to be the hardest thing to find and keep. Love can make the worst things, the most unimaginable things, tolerable. I think it is even better than hope.”

“Hope, yes,” intoned the beast. “Now looking at you, I am finding the hope. The hope for this curse to be lifted of me.”

“So there is a possibility, you say, as hope means possibility,” said Sabrina. “Can you tell me what you hope for? Maybe I can help.”

“Yes, you can, but I don’t want to tell you what, because if I ask for the cure from anyone, it undoing of the curse won’t happen.”

“You mean, I have to figure it out for myself.”

“Yeah, exactly. And yah! Spells are fought with other spells.” The beast smiled now, baring sharpened fangs that looked fatal to Sabrina, and she wondered if the beast was eager to sink them into her. “Your fairy blood,” the invisible Celine whispered in her ear.

“Your smile hides your pain and tears, and what your outward appearance now shows to the world is only a cover that conceals what’s inside. I respect that.”

“I am lined with scars and wounds that go all the way to the foundation of my existence,” sighed the beast. “But no one sees the real me.”

“Oh, but I do, and I think you are a wonderful…entity. Very lovable, in fact. If you would only let me…”

The beast’s eyes suddenly shone as if stars from the night sky had fallen into them. “I would let you do anything you wish, anything you’d like to do.”

“May I, then,” Sabrina swallowed her next breath…”stroke your fur and hug you?”

The beast nodded his eyes tearing up. He is such an emotional beast! Maybe all beasts are really very emotional, and we don’t understand them, thought Sabrina. She believed now that she was in no danger. This beast could, would not, harm her.

Laura stumbled momentarily toward the beast, losing her stride, but regained her balance almost immediately, approaching him with unobtrusive steps. With a modest smile, she reached to his powerful neck and put her arms around it. The beast growled, but Sabrina kept her arms tight around the beast. Then she bent her head and put her lips on the smelly, rust colored fur.

The beast let out a first rasping, then a bubbling sound. His body quavered and his eyes rolled in their sockets. The horns on his head, his claws and fangs retracted, and his size grew smaller. Now he was a small wolf, not the ferocious one Sabrina had first encountered, and definitely not a beast.

The wolf turned and licked Sabrina’s face, just like Bo used to do. “Thank you, Little Halfling friend of mine,” he yapped. “You are a brave one. And you broke the curse. I will be in your debt, forever.”

“How did I do that? I don’t understand…” Sabrina was amazed at the change in the beast, but more shocking was the fact that she was the one who had caused it.

“You loved the unlovable,” the wolf said. “But come to think of it, I think you are a glutton for punishment. This could go either way, you know.”

“I trusted you, Sir,” Sabrina said. “And even in your beastly state, I loved you, truly loved you, as you have something gentle about you like my Bo had once.”

“Now, my Halfling Friend,” said the wolf. “Let’s cut through the chase. First, please stop calling me sir. Lofty titles are difficult on one’s shoulders. Give me a name, so you can call me with it or just call me Friend.”

Sabrina thought she should name her wolf as….

131132.title: A Cure for the Curse

1311321.content:
Sabrina thought she should name her wolf as Adolfo. Of course. This one was a noble wolf, and he could only be an Adolfo, since that is what Adolfo meant, the noble wolf.

“I think Adolfo would fit you perfectly, if you don’t mind it,” she said, still stroking the wolf’s fur, as she had never stopped stroking it even through the change in him.

“I do love it. It is just a word but it came out of your lips in loving kindness. I’m Adolfo, then, from this day on. What a historic moment this is!”

“Yes,” said Sabrina. “Historic it is. I have never seen anything like it. The question is, where do we go from here and is there anything else you need?”

The wolf licked her face again. “I should be the one to ask you that, after everything you did for me. But I think if not the whole good thing you did for me, I can at least pay you back a little bit.”

“You don’t have to pay me back or anything. I didn’t even know what I was doing. I did what I did because I felt like it.”

“That is just the thing, my Friend Sabrina. You, of all creation, sensed how the fate of the curse worked. There was no changing of it. You didn’t know it consciously, true, but the inner you did. And that made all the difference.”

“Tell me, Adolfo,” Sabrina said, “Why should a friend feel indebted to his friend just because of a little favor? You really shouldn’t feel this way.”

“These words just show how gracious you are, Sabrina. You chose love, the dignified kind of love; knowingly or not knowingly, it doesn’t matter. As there is also the fake kind of love that ruins and destroys.”

“I can only feel one kind of love,“ Sabrina said.

“That is good and mighty in itself, but not all beings respect that. You have much to learn, my friend.” The wolf stood up on all fours. “I have much to teach you. Let me show you the art of the fight. I know it better than anyone.”

“But I don’t like fighting,” Sabrina said. “I don’t like wars. I don’t like hurting.”

“True. Wars do not make one great. But at least you should learn about keeping your distance from the frightful stuff. Besides, knowing how to fight doesn’t mean you actually have to fight. It is important for those who want to hurt you to know that you can fight. “

“That makes a bit of sense, but starting down that shady path may not be a solution for me,” Sabrina said.

“Don’t use the might, ever, if you don’t want to, but having the enemy know you have strength gives you an edge.”

“You may have a point, there, Adolfo.” Sabrina finally settled into an accepting state of mind. “I may just learn what you can show me if not for fighting but for anticipating the next move of the other person.”

“That, too,” the wolf said. So let’s go together to that clearing over there where I can show you the first few moves.”

131212.content:
The howling came from the distance, but with the storm raging, Redalf couldn't determine its exact location. He gathered the children around him and knelt in front of them.
"The storm will only get worse, young ones." The three children's eyes widened with terror. Redalf reached out and rubbed each small head in turn. "Worry not, children," he said. "I will protect you."
All around Redalf and the three children the wind blew. Trees bent, flying leaves filled the air, and the rain fell sideways. The children shivered and huddled together.
"Come, we must try to get back to my cave before the storm worsens," Redalf shouted to be heard over the screaming storm. "Hold hands," he said and watched as each child grasped the hand of the child next to him. "That's it, now hold tight."
Redalf stood and his gaze scanned the area. The track he had taken to get here had nearly been hidden by the falling leaves and debris. Just then a patch of sky opened above him and he could see the golden rays of sunshine and then he knew.
He took the hand of one of the children and turned. Pointing, he shouted, "That way. Hold tight to each other and we shall be safe."
As Redalf led the children into the forest, he heard the shriek of terror. "That's a wolf," he mumbled, but the wind took his words away before the children could hear them. "Hurry, children," he said as he picked up the pace.
Redalf held his open hand above his eyes so that he could better see where he was going. It wasn't too far to the cave where he had left Sabrina asleep, safe in her bed. Before the thought left him, another piercing howl filled him with fear. But a new fear now weighed heavily in his stomach as if he had swallowed a rock.
Suddenly, Redalf stopped and cocked his ear in the direction of his cave. "Helllllp!" The word carried on the wind and set Redalf on edge.
"That's Sabrina, children," he shouted. "We must hurry, my Sabrina is in danger."
The children senses Redalf's fear and began to pull away from him.
"No, no," he shouted. "You must remain with me, or surely you will perish." He knelt and gazed into the blue eyes of a young girl. He had to try to calm the children, Sabrina's life might depend on it.
"What is your name, little beauty?" he asked.
"I'm Daisy," the little girl said shyly.
"Okay, Daisy, I need your help." Redalf let his gaze scan the other children's eyes. "Do you think you can help me?"
"I'll try," Daisy said, as she placed her thumb into her mouth. "What should I do?"
"Hold my hand tightly, Daisy," Redalf said. The small soft hand slid into his palm and it felt like a bird's wing instead of a young girl's. "That's right Daisy," he said. "Now take the hand of the boy behind you and then tell him to take the hand of the boy behind him."
Redalf watched as each child regained the hand of the child in front of him. He understood that his plan had worked. Seeing Daisy's courage to move forward gave the boys courage also.
"Okay, we much hurry."
The small line of children followed Redalf as he made his way toward his cave as quickly as he dared.

The storm seemed to slow, as Redalf and his young charges reached the edge of the mountain where Redalf's cave sat hidden by layers of branches. For a moment there was complete silence.
I'm too late, he told himself as fear ripped through him. But suddenly he saw movement inside the cave. It wasn't more than a shadow, but it told Redalf that someone, or something inside the cave was alive.
"Sabrina!" he shouted. When there was no response, he shouted again, "Sabrina!"
Unbeknownst to Redalf, Sabrina could not answer him because she was locked in battle with the biggest wolf she had ever seen.

Sabrina picked up a rock lying at her feet and threw it at the beast's head. Her eyes widened when she watched it bounce from the wolf's head with no harm done. The wolf shrugged and a sinister smile widened on his face. His mouth opened revealing two rows of large sharp teeth. A dark, viscous liquid dripped from the wolf's black lips.
The wolf growled, it's foul smelling breath billowing over Sabrina, knocking her to the ground.
As the wolf approached Sabrina, she saw the glint of metal on the other side of the cave. But the wolf snatched her by the hair and lifted her off the ground. Holding her up to his eyes, his slimy tongue slid along his lips, a hungry look etched itself into his glistening eyes.
Sabrina tried to pull away, but the wolf's hold was too strong. She watched in terror as the wolf's mouth began to open. Slowly, ever so slowly, more and more teeth were revealed as the wolf prepared to eat Sabrina. Just as she felt herself being move to his mouth, in fact the point of one tooth had begun to penetrate her skin, she felt the wolf shudder. His eyes glazed over and his grip loosened.
Sabrina wasted no time in scurrying into a dark corner and watched the wolf. He seemed to be injured. But how? she asked herself. She hadn't been able to hurt him. She had no weapon. She had been resigned to be eaten.
Suddenly a shadow passed over her. Sabrina looked to the cave entrance and saw a large body silhouetted against the grey sky outside the cave.
"Sabrina!"
Sabrina recognized the voice. She was saved.
"Redalf?" She shouted. "Is that you Redalf?"
"Where are you, Sabrina," Redalf shouted. "I can't see you."

choices: Redalf hears the wolf running away.

1312121.content:
Redalf stepped into the cave and stopped so his eyes would become accustomed to the darkness inside the cave. But the wolf must have realized what Redalf was doing, because he quietly rose to his feet and slowly, quietly, made his way to where Redalf stood. The wolf's head still stung from where the big rock that Redalf had thrown hit him. Bright spots circled inside his vision, and there was a distinct ringing in his ears.
"Sabrina?" Redalf called.
Sabrina heard her name being called, but she was still in shock, and the word sounded filtered, as if it was coming from far away instead of just a few feet from where she stood. She tried to clear her head, she wanted to find out who was calling out to her. It might be some of the children calling her, and she definitely didn't want the wolf to get anywhere near the children.
Sabrina felt a presence move past her. She couldn't see it, but she felt it, and she could smell it. The memories of the last two days flowed through her, and she tried to place the odor that now filled the air around her. Suddenly her eyes grew wider.
"The wolf," she said. Even in her dazed state of mind she knew the wolf was nearby, she could feel him, she could smell him.
Sabrina placed her palms flat on the ground and pushed herself into a sitting position. She looked around and in the darkness she could see the dark shape of the wolf as he slowly made his way to the cave entrance.
You have to stop him, she told herself. But how? She used her hand to search the darkness around her. A rock, a tree limb, a heavy tool, surely there was something she could use to protect herself and Redalf. She sighed when she found nothing.
In the dim light coming from the cave entrance, Sabrina could just make out Redalf as he stood. He wobbled and had to use his hands against the cave walls to steady himself. With the wolf only a few feet away, the last thing Redalf needed was to fall down.
"Redalf," Sabrina called out. "Can you hear me, Redalf?" Sabrina gazed around the darkness of the cave but saw nothing.
"I'm here, Sabrina," Redalf finally called back. "Are you alright?"
Sabrina felt her emotions soar when Redalf's friendly voice found her. She hoped it was not premature, but her fear began to slip away from her. Renewed by Redalf's presence, Sabrina also found new strength. She stood, holding the wall with one hand to steady herself, and peered through the darkness.
Tentatively, Sabrina took two strides in the direction of the cave entrance, but suddenly there was a dark form blocking the way.
"Who's that?" Sabrina said, worry once more edging its way back into her voice.
It happened in an instant. Sabrina didn't notice the quick movement, but the breeze created by the wolf's quick movement blew some strands of hair off Sabrina's face.
The moving air cooled her, but when she realized she was now blocked from reaching the cave's entrance, fear again gripped Sabrina.
"Redalf?" Sabrina paused, waiting for Redalf to reply. When he didn't, she called him again. "Redalf... Redalf? Are you alright?" As Sabrina turned the corner of the cave, she could see that the wolf had blocked Redalf. Sabrina's heart sank like a stone in water when she realized she was now doomed.

Before Sabrina could retreat, Redalf used his hand to indicate that she should back away. It appeared to Sabrina that there was about to be a horrendous fight, and she didn't need to be in the middle of it.
The two massive beasts circled each other like two crazed animals. The wolf grunted, a viscous fluid dripped from his teeth, and a bright light shone in his eyes. The wolf's pointy, sharp claws glistened in the dim light of the cave.
Across from him, Redalf circled in the opposite direction. It was as if the two antagonists were dancing. but it would be a dance to the death. As Redalf moved into a shadowed corner of the cave, he disappeared. When the darkness spit him out, he stood in the dim light and Sabrina saw the large sword in his hand. The wolf saw it too.
"Hold on a minute here," the wolf said. Confusion had extinguished the angry light that had been in his eyes. "A sword?" he asked Redalf. "And where di you get that?"
Redalf chuckled, his laughter menacing, dry, and hateful. "I had it hidden in my leggings, but it doesn't matter."
"Why doesn't it matter?" the wolf asked. The wolf seemed ready to talk now that he had seen the sword. Where before he was all about hate, hurt, and annihilation, he now sought to quell the anger building in Redalf's eyes.
"Maybe we should take a minute to talk about this," the wolf said. He held his glistening claws up to his eyes, and said, "my claws are no match for that sword in your hands."'
"Too bad," Redalf said.
"Give me a chance, will you?" the wolf was obviously scared now. With each step to the side he now took, he also took a half step back.
"You know," Redalf said. "My mother once told me that God didn't make everyone physically the same." Redalf smiled shyly. "But he did make equalizers." With that Redalf held the sword up high where the sharp metal edge glinted in the dim light of the cave.
"Can't we talk about this, Redalf?" the wolf asked as he backed away from Redalf.
"Talk?" Redalf scoffed. "Talk is for sissy's."
Redalf let out a grunt of surprise, and then stepped forward to where the wolf had stood only a minute before. "Where did he go?" Redalf asked no one in particular. He turned to Sabrina, and said, "Where is he?"
Sabrina looked around the cave. It wasn't a big cave so if the wolf was there he would e easy to see. He would be easy to smell. But Sabrina saw nor smelled anything.
Redalf let the sword fall to his side and he entered deep into the cave. His steps echoed against the wet walls.
"Look here, Sabrina," Redalf said, the excitement now returned to his voice.
"What is it, Redalf," Sabrina asked as she reached where Redalf stood.
Redalf pointed with his sword. "Look, a trap door."
Sabrina followed the sword to its tip and then saw the crease in the rock. "Is that what that is?"
"Yes, and it's well hidden too." Redalf smiled. "I guess the wolf didn't want a fight afterall."
From some place far back in the cave, the voice of the wolf echoed and moved forward. The words stiffened Redalf's back with resolve.
"I will live to fight another day!" The wolf's words riled Redalf. But he knew he could do nothing about it. The wolf had managed to escape again. "Drats!" Redalf said. "Now the children are in danger again."
Redalf tossed the sword aside and turned to Sabrina.
"It's time we left this place.There is nothing for us here. The wolf is loose again, and we must protect the children."
Just then the sun rose high enough that its rays flooded the cave with yellow light. Sabrina followed Redalf to the cave entrance and squinted when she stepped into the sunlight.

Many thought the wolf’s powers faded. Many were foolish. The years slipped by, as did Sabrina’s fear of the forest. In that while, the wolf had spent his time in the sanctuary of darkness. Over time, his wounds healed from the defeats at the hands of the fairy Celine.

The wolf would venture forth as strength allowed only to engage in the hunt. Yet, he always avoided the canopy where the fairies resided. The fairies were fortified by the light of the sun and only drifted down the lower regions to heal the forest and the foliage that were not exposed to the healing rays of the sun.

It had been many years since Sabrina dreamt of the fairy princess Celine. Sabrina could not question papa about the dreams. His tears were too much for her gentle heart. She could not tell him that the dreams took on an quality of foretelling and that she was being summoned to the woods. She must take her rightful place as the seer for the village. She must retrieve the emblems of her rank from the hallowed ground in the middle of the forest.

13122.title: Faded Powers

131221.content:
For many days, Sabrina had the same dream, she would be standing in a dark place in front of a stone chimney. In the early morning hours, the sun would slowly awaken the life in the forest. As the sun made it’s slow arc across the sky, the rays would pierce the denseness of the woods and strike the face of the chimney and burn geometric shapes into the stone surfaces.
As Sabrina turned her face to the sun, she would be wide awake standing in the gardens of her home staring at the forest. It was time. The whispers of the forest would lead her to the hallowed ground. Sabrina breathed in the dank and heady scents of the forest. She honed her senses to the musty scents of the untamed, and listened carefully for the soft rustle of the forest creatures who were either her guide or her enemy.
The fox with the golden eyes blocked her path. She allowed the fox to circle her and take in her scent. The sly one pranced to a point several steps in front of Sabrina, stretched the forward paw in front and the other bent as if to bow his loyalty to Sabrina.
“Thank you, faithful one. I command you to lead me to the hallowed ground.”
“It is my honor to obey.” The fox wheeled and darted into the center of the forest. Sabrina labored to keep up. The rivulets of perspiration soon saturated her garment, causing her tunic to cling to her body slow her footsteps.
The fox leaped as high as he could, catching the shelving of the stone wall and using it to launch himself over the stones. Sabrina ran to the other side, but the fox had disappeared. She collapsed against the coolness of the boulders, resisting the desire to allow fatigue and sleep to overtake her. She whispered into the darkness that surrounded her, “Keeper of the Hallowed Ground, I am here to claim the powers that are to be entrusted to me.”
The moonlight took that moment to brighten to reveal the enchantment of this place. The smallest of creatures one by one presented their gifts to Seer Sabrina. As each paw touched the hem of her tunic, her strength, knowledge and joy increased.
Morning broke, allowing the jeweled pattern of the chimney surface to reveal itself. Sabrina recognized the pattern. During the night, Sabrina was aware that the wolf of her youth had been circling. She could feel it’s hot breath near her neck. “Wolf, bow to your master!”
“Never!”
“Cease!”
While the wolf remained frozen in mid-attack, Sabrina, pressed the jeweled stones in the order presented in her dreams.

The earth calmed. The stones in the chimney transformed to reveal a cache of magical items that would serve Sabrina in her office as Village Seer.
She released the scrolls from their protective covering. Each revealed the secrets of the ages that gave her insights into the coming troubles that would present in ensuing days. She feared them not. It would only be short-lived. Sabrina released the gold netting and bound her hair into a soft cushion that fell just below her shoulders. Her hair would be the source of her foresight and would need to be protected from those seeking to harm her. She next released the bands that would be placed at her wrists and ankles. With these she would manipulate time and objects. The scrolls warned of the misuse of the powers. She would not know what that punishment would be, only that it would be her worst nightmare.
Sabrina pulled the final object from the chimney. A morsel of food for the wolf. Sabrina only intended to push the wolf sideways so that he would fall prostate on the hearth. Instead it removed the magic and he was now circling again with fangs bared. Sabrina tossed the morsel to the wolf who snapped it as if he had not eaten in several days.
The wolf stopped his pacing and did his four-point bow. “Master.”
Sabrina touched the soft spot between his eyes. “You will obey my commands to your last breath.”
“Understood.”
“Quickly, now. We must establish a sanctuary in the village. The fairies must be protected and that cannot happen if the alter remains here.”
“The aerie of the Thunderbird is close. They will bring the Gristalka with them.”
“Those are demon creatures!”
“No. They are not. Their appearance may give that impression. They use their horns for carrying large objects. They use their hands for hunting and gathering. They use their hooves for rapid movement. They are well muscled and large body for battles and the hunt. They do not seek to cause harm, but they will protect themselves.”
“In other words I need the Thunderbirds because I cannot find the Gristalka without them.”
“You are wise, Seer Sabrina.”
“Not yet. I just know that time is short and this must be completed quickly. Call the Thunderbirds.”
The fox stepped forward with some hesitancy. “The Thunderbirds will feast on the fairies.”
Sabrina snapped her face to the wolf to allow him to refute the accusation.
“Yes, Seer, they will have to be bound by your commands. The fairies must hibernate while the Thunderbirds are active.”
“You are to keep no secrets from me. What shall I call thee?”
“Ronan.”
Sabrina looked at her fox. “What be thy name, fox?”
“Fareed.”
Sabrina eyed the fox and knew he did not speak truth.
“Fareed is the name my mother gave me. Others use a different name for me. Please do not address me with those names. They are displeasing to me.”
“Fareed, send a message to the fairies to cover themselves until the Thunderbird and Gristalka have completed their duty. Ronan, go to the land of the Thunderbirds and summon them to this place. Go, now to complete that which you have been tasked to do.”
Sabrina lowered herself on the hearth and arranged her skirts around her.
In time each of the woodland creatures brought a gift of nourishment for Sabrina. She accepted offerings of berries, herbs and acorn cups of water. She did not need these, but acceptance of the offerings would form the bonds needed in the coming days when her leadership would be tested quite consistently.

Sabrina had fallen asleep with her head resting uncomfortably against the stones. She was chilled and ached from sitting in the same position for an extended period. The only thing that brought her to sleepy wakefulness was the chatter of the squirrels flying and scampering above her, and the hail of acorns being pelted at her. She scratched her head where the netting was fastened to her tresses. The scrolls were correct. When she touched her hair, she could see future events. In this case, it was a huntsman approaching rapidly.
Sabrina clicked the gold bands at her ankles. She noted the highest branch that would support her weight and within a moment had transgressed several feet and ten feet off the ground. The woodland creatures were seeking cover in the various hidey holes and brush that they could find.
Sabrina wrinkled her nose. How could one person give off such a stench? As surreptitiously as possible, she moved a cloth over her nose to block the foulness emanating from the huntsman.
The huntsman dropped his crossbow as he approached the stone structure. He recalled it as a chimney, now it looked more like a sacred cache. His band would be sorely disappointed that they were not the first to discover the trove of valued items. He turned in a complete circle and caught the scent of woman wafting on the breeze. Whoever she was, she was close.
He examined the stonework more closely. Running his finger over the mantle, his fingers drifted over a strand of long dark hair. As he held it up to the sunrays he could see it curl and reflect the light of the sun. He could also tell where the maiden had secreted herself and the valued treasures she had close to her person. He would not be able to win an honest battle against this one, but fairness was not his strong suit.
He took his pouch from his leather waistband into which he deposited the newest treasure for safekeeping. His brethren would be pleased that he knew the identity of the new Seer. They would have to be a little more careful in capturing this Seer.

The cave was dank, humid, and it stunk. The irregular ground was covered in wolf scat, making an already slippery surface even more slippery.
No one knew how many wolves lived in the cave. But cave was a misnomer. Lair was the word that better described where the wolves lived.
But then Sabrina pranced out of the lair, her dark eyes shone like black marbles as the sun reflected from them. Her paws, small but hiding powerful claws, grasped the wet, dank rock as sure footed as any animal that ever lived.
As her dark gaze scanned her surroundings, Sabrina hunted for the fairy princess Celine. But Sabrina knew that the princess of fairies lived high in the canopy. Turning her gaze skyward, Sabrina tried to locate Celine. She would befriend Celine, given the chance, but only to serve her own purposes.
Sabrina shook of last night's dew and took a few tentative steps out into the verdant field. She looked around at all the surrounding beauty. There were the beautiful and mighty oak trees. Their roots spread twice as far as their widest branches, she had been told. And then there were the streams, brooks, babbling and non-babbling, as well as the rivers with their swirling, twirling waters. Sabrina loved it all. But she most loved that so many other wolves were at her back and call.
Yes, she told herself, there were definite benefits to being the queen of the lair. Isn't it wonderful, she asked herself, that because she was queen she could get a hairstyle without waiting in line. And wasn't it wonderful that she didn't need dinner reservations at any of the popular restaurants. All she had to do was show up and she would be shown to the best table in the restaurant. Yes, she told herself, being queen had its advantages.
"Life is good," Sabrina shouted and listened to her words echo across the glen. "Yes," she mumbled to no one in particular, "Being queen was definitely more beneficial than being one of the worker wolves, the ones who got their paws dirty hunting for fresh gazelle, hyena, or the occasional elephant.
Sabrina yawned with a feminine groan. "I should prepare myself for my morning nap."
"But you just woke up, Princess Sabrina," Maurine said. "The canopy fairies are going to think you're lazy."
Sabrina gaze a short wave of her hand. "Let them think what they will," Sabrina said. "I don't have to answer to any of them."
"That's true, Sabrina," Maurine said. "But you know, appearances are important."
"Appearances?" Sabrina said, shocked. "I don't have any appearances."
Maurine shook her head, and said, "Maybe you should go lie down, after all."
"Yes, I think you're right," Sabrina said and headed back inside the wolf lair.

131223.content:
The canopy hung high in the sunshine, the dappled shade below it cooling, but humid. High above the canopy the sun shone in it's relentless pursuit to turn everything hot. Ray of sunshine bore down on the thin, and not so thin, prickly leaves covering the tree tops. But it was that very warmth that kept life in the canopy in operation, and operating at its best.
Some people thought the jungle was too hot, and for animals and insects that were indigenous to the colder climates like Antarctica, the north pole, Alaska, and some parts of northern Canada, life is the canopy would be difficult, if not down right deadly. But the creatures living in the canopy were not from Antarctica, the north pole, and nor were they from northern Canada. They were from right there in the canopy.
Lizards, spindly creatures, some crawling, some spinning a web to hang from, others slithering along the leafy growth.
But all of the life in the canopy came to a stop when a giant shadow dimmed the sun. Every insect, every animal, every living creature, no matter where they hailed from, knew not to be noticed by the princess of fairies, Celine.
Celine was not a dangerous ruler of the canopy, no, she loved the world up high where she could see for leagues in every direction. She liked that she could look off to the west in the early mornings and watch the mountains be silhouetted by the rising sun behind them. She would watch as steam rose from the verdant mountainsides as the sun's warmth turned the early morning dew into vapors.
Celine liked looking towards the south as well. She could make out the outline of the canopy as the sun rose and revealed the natural beauty of the canopy. But Celine also loved the view to the east, where the ocean waves slipped ashore with a whisper, before washing back out to sea, leaving a lattice work of foam in its wake. But it was the view to the north that Celine loved the most.
"Everything wonderful and beautiful can be found in the north," Celine would tell anyone willing to listen. "From the north comes the very things that keep the canopy rich and vibrant," she said to her assistant fairy this morning. "Look, don't you see it?" Celine pointed her dainty finger in the direction of the tall trees dripping with life.
"But I fear the cold, princess Celine," her assistant Maurine said. "And the cold can harm us."
"Not if we are prepared, Maurine," Celine said. "Gloves, hats, heavy, fur lined boots and ear muffs," Celine said as if reading from a shopping list. "those are the things that protect us from the cold."
"But we have no means of warming our dwellings, princess Celine," Maurine said.
"Must I think of everything?" Celine said, annoyance edging her voice.
"But," Maurine said and smiled. "Didn't you say that handling all of the canopy's problems is why you were paid," her smile widened, "The big bucks?"
Princess Celine smirked. "Don't make me mad this early in the morning." She turned and looked north. "You wouldn't want me to spend the day with ruffled wings, now, would you?"
"Oh, of course not, dear princess Celine."
"I remember once," Celine said, "When I had to spend the entire day wearing wrinkled fairy wings. OMG, it was terrible. The prince, you know how he is, well, he was so upset."
"What did the great prince do to the great princess?" Maurine asked.
"Don't you think that question is a little personal?" Celine asked princess Maurine.
Maurine gazed at Celine for a long second before answering. As she waited for the right words, Maurine wondered how this ditsy blond had become a princess. Maurine knew of so many fairies that would gladly take Celine's place at the throne. Fairies that were pretty, well coiffed, and would love to show the prince a good time. And some of those pretty fairies would make wrinkled fairy wings the last thing the prince saw when they stepped into his presence.

1313221.content:
Sabrina stared up at the tree. It hadn't been that difficult to get down, just slow, but going up might be a different matter. Well, no matter how difficult it was going to be, she would have to try it. There was no way she could knock on the front door. Her father probably wouldn't even open it since he wouldn't be expecting visitors and visitors never came at this time of night.

And anyway, how would she explain her sudden appearance outside when he'd left her snuggled up in her bed!

Sabrina's imagination flew off into many types of punishment she might receive for her disobedience, and that made her all the more determined that she had to climb the tree. Her nocturnal, external journey had to remain a secret.

She glanced over her shoulder briefly, turned back when she spotted the glow by the wood. The fairy was watching her. Bet she doesn't think I can do it, she thought glancing back up the tree.

And with that tiny bit of a challenge, Sabrina walked around the tree eyeing the bark and the nodules where limbs had been severed years and years ago. The biggest issue would actually be having the height or wingspan to grab hand-holds above her head.

Well, she got down, didn't she? Didn't break any limbs or rip her pyjamas in the descent.

Sabrina heard a soft bark from Bo but didn't try to talk to him; that would only encourage him to be louder and having her dad find her half up a tree wouldn't be good. She sucked in a breath, walked around the old trunk once more and decided on where to start. Fortunately, and with great serendipity, the light spilling out her bedroom window lit the branches from above, making them quite easy for Sabrina to see and to consider which to take hold of and which to ignore.

The tree was pretty ancient; it had stood longer than the house had. It had always looked strong and barely suffered any damage when the storms came but sometimes rotten branches did fall. And always they were the ones that had seemed solid. Sabrina closed her eyes a second, heart fluttering at the thought of finding one of those branches.

Any normal child might have thought to just take whatever punishment would be meted out, but Sabrina had always been courageous, determined and precocious. Her disobedience would remain a secret, and that was just how it was going to go.

After another breath, Sabrina got herself together. She knew the tree well, having talked to it often from her window, had always been nice to it and she didn't think it would let her down now. She reached for the next nodule, a split in the bark that she could wedge her fingers into and pull on.

Inch by inch, the six-year-old child climbed the tree. She didn't look over her shoulder again to see if she was being watched (she was, but not by the fairy), kept all her concentration on the climb, on carefully selecting branches to hang onto and branches to stand upon. The higher she rose through the tree, the more branches she had to choose from and the effort to climb became a lot more easy. Sabrina still climbed with great concentration though; it was a bumpy ride down if she should lose her grip.

She could hear Bo growling above her, probably thinking there was an intruder so she got out in a loud whisper, 'Sssh, Bo, it's just me!'

That broke a growl in half and cause a bark to sound. To Sabrina it sounded a little like 'Sabrina, you're alive, yay.' If she wasn't already flushed from the exertion, she might have flushed at how silly she felt thinking that. Then again, Bo hadn't wanted her to leave the bedroom, that much had been clear.

Bo continue to give happy barks, but softly so Sabrina didn't think her father would hear and investigate what was going on.

As she reached level with the bedroom window, Bo hanging over the sill, Sabrina let herself relax. Her legs and arms were trembling and her fingers and toes stung. She probably had dozens of splinters but she still had a couple of fee to go, out on a sturdy limb - before she could really worry about what scrapes she had.

Sabrina had sat out on the limb before - it was plenty large for a child - but this time she inched across it so slowly she wasn't sure she was even moving. She was so close to safety and to secrecy that fear had her move like a turtle to ensure she didn't make a hash of things.

Bo strained over the sill, tongue hanging out. She ordered him to get back, fearing he'd become excited and knock her off as she was climbing over the sill. He obeyed like the wonderful animal he was and Sabrina clenched both hands to the sill, using the strength in her arms to pull her lower over over and into her room.

With a gasping cry she hit the floor and lay still, trembling. Tears of relief, of late fear, of all sorts of things filled her eyes, and then a long raspy tongue slobbered over her face.

Sabrina flung her arms around Bo and hugged him close.

Sabrina considered the tree. Surely she could climb it? But as she walked around it once, looking for hand and footholds, she found that the trunk was quite smooth at her level. There was no way she could leap for a branch.She thought for a second on how she'd gotten down the tree. Couldn't she go back up the same way?

Not an option. She'd managed to scramble down through the branches but near the bottom she'd had to take a bit of a gamble that she wouldn't break any bones by leaping the rest of the way.

Sabrina bit her lip. There was nothing for it but to knock on the front door and suffer the consequences for being out of bed and out of the house after the express warnings not to do so.

She moved around the tree, back to the front path and up to the door. Solid pine, at least two inches thick with brass bands crisscrossing the face, and a big iron door handle with knocker. The door was made to keep things out. A shiver raced up and down Sabrina's spine and she glanced over her shoulder. There was no light any more from the fairy but that didn't mean she wasn't still there watching; that's usually what a shiver meant - someone was watching you. Sabrina swallowed. She wasn't in danger here, she wasn't in danger here....

Sabrina all but leaped onto the stone threshold and banged the knocker with all the strength her six-year-old arms could manage. Not a great deal, since they were sore from climbing down the tree and not a little bit numb from the chill air. But the crashing sound was echoing through the house and she was sure her father would come.

Or maybe he wouldn't. He wouldn't be expecting anyone at this time of night. Maybe he wouldn't even come to the door to see what was going on?

Sabrina edged right up to the handle and called through the lock, 'Papa, it's me.'

She doubted her father would think it was someone else making her voice, but... what if he wasn't within earshot of the door? Sometimes, when you were at the back of the house, or even upstairs, the sound didn't reach that far. Sabrina crashed the knocker against is iron plate again, and this time when she called for her father it came out as rather more a shriek.

'Sabrina?' she heard faintly from within the house.

'Let me in, papa,' Sabrina called. 'I'm stuck out here.'

'What are you doing outside, child?'

'I... I fell out of the window.' Sabrina winced, that was a stupid reason!

But maybe it wasn't; she heard footsteps hastening and next thing the latch across the small barred window scraped out. 'I can't see you,' came her father's muffled voice.

Instead of insisting she was who she said she was, Sabrina took two steps back so she could be seen and so her father could see her.

She heard what sounded a lot like a curse and then the latched scraped shut. Momentarily Sabrina panicked that that was it, but then she heard the big bolts being pulled. Then the door unlatched and swung in half a foot. Sabrina's father peered around it, looked over her shoulder, and then made "hurry up" motions with his hand.

Sabrina darted forward, yelping when the hand grabbed her shoulder and yanked her through the gap. The bolts all shunted home to make an impregnable barrier once again, and then Sabrina felt the weight of her father's stare.

'For someone who fell out of a window, Sabrina, you don't look very hurt, or very dirty.'

She knew her father didn't believe a word of what she'd said; this was his way of telling her to come clean before she was made too.

'The fairy made me,' she blurted before she could stop herself.

'The what?' her father asked.

Sabrina swallowed. 'The fairy.'

Meanwhile, back at home, James Tanner stood in front of the fire place staring at the small painting of his late wife. Dead two years now, taken by who knew what. Rumour abounded that it was the beast in the forest but James wasn't so sure. They'd found no trace of his wife, of a struggle or anything that might indicate the wolf.

And deep down in his heart, where he went in his greatest need for peace, he was sure the wolf wasn't involved in Morgana's death. A vicious death hung around, like a sliver in a heart that couldn't heal. James didn't feel that; he just felt a void as if his wife had simply vanished.

They said she was dead because she'd never been found but James was sure he'd still feel something even in her death. There was nothing inside to connect him now, just the sense of her being missing. Sabrina was always going on about fairies and how her mother had been turned into one. James always pooh-poohed that nonsense, for Sabrina's sake. Other folk already looked at her slightly askew - they had before Morgana's death and they hadn't stopped.

It wasn't because James was raising her on his own, it was because Sabrina would happily tell her friends about her fairy mother or how she saw a fairy yesterday or two fairies the day before. Some of the townsfolk thought she wasn't quite right in the head, but - for god's sake - she was only a child. Children believed in fairies.

Sabrina believed in them more than most, which was the problem.

And James... well, behind his daughter's back he had a little bit of belief too. Maybe not quite to the point of believing Morgana was now a fairy, but he was aware of magical auras and a few charms and spells. For example, the brass bands criss-crossing the stiff wooden door carried an old charm that prevented witches from crossing the threshold. Witches hadn't been seen in years but the charm held strong (at least, he expected it did.)

And the black ring he wore on a leather thong around his neck kept him abreast of when anyone was nearing the house - magic or otherwise. The door knocker heralded visitors remarkably well but the ring would start to vibrate faintly whenever any one passed the fence boundary.

James sighed at the portrait. Sabrina carried her mother's beautiful features and dark hair, was going to be an absolute beauty when she hit her teens. As long as she'd stopped talking so much about fairies by then, she would probably make a wonderful love match with someone. He ran a finger over Morgana's hair as if he could run a finger through it like he used to. 'If you are out there, Morgana,' he whispered, 'please keep watch over her.'

A log collapsed in the fire, sending out a rush of heat and shower of sparks and ash. James' heart leapt and for a split second he saw that as a sign from his lost wife. Then he chuckled to himself, got down on his knees and sorted the fire out. The log had burned through and collapsed of its own accord.

When James straightened, he moved to the front door to double check the bolts were in place. The lock held no key but that hung safely on the hook just under the window latch. He didn't lock the door at night because the bolts were better strength in keeping the door closed. As he did most nights before he headed up to bed, he bent down and peered through the lock, down the path to the picket fence.

It glowed abnormally in the dark, until James realised that the glow came from an upper window and there was only one window on that side of the house.

She's probably reading still, James thought, and shook his head.

Sabrina read everything she could get her hands on, which James was very proud of, but not tonight. Sabrina had a big day dawning tomorrow and if she didn't get enough sleep tonight, tomorrow was going to be a disaster!
