1313231.content:
James trod the quiet stairs, proud of the fact that for over stairs over one hundred years old they did not creak or squeak or groan. Sometimes their quietness was an issue; Sabrina had a tendency to be able to sneak downstairs pretty easily on those occasions that she'd been grounded to her room!

Outside her door, he gave a half knock and was startled by a muffled WOOF and scratching. Bo knew his tread and normally didn't react in any manner to his arrival - whether Sabrina was awake or asleep.

James rushed into the bedroom and stopped dead. The bed sheets were thrown back to reveal a smooth white under sheet and no daughter. He glanced around but she wasn't sitting at her little princess desk, nor on the floor by the toy cabinet. The Labrador barked and nudged James knee, and he crouched down for a second, gripping the dog's head. 'Where's she gone, Bo?'

The dog held still just a second, then broke free and moved to the window, and that's when James realised it was wide open. He knew the curtain had been back, because that's how he'd known the light was still on; it had been shining on the fence. He strode to the window, leaned on the sill and gazed out. The ancient tree blocked a lot of his view out over the field to the forest.

Beside him Bo set his paws on the sill and gave another bark as if to say 'she went that way'.

James drew in a breath. Lord, had Sabrina climbed down the tree? She'd been known to sit on the big branch that reached the window sill but he hadn't ever seen her get into the tree with the intention of climbing down it. She was just six. Precocious, certainly, and determined to do a lot of the things that the boys her age did but this tree was a challenge.

James muffled a curse against a hand and straightened up. If she'd climbed out, then something was up. She'd been restless, he remembered, when he'd said good night to her early. Something about fairies again. Not her mother this time, but a guardian or something-or-other. Damn, child, not tonight!

A new year of school was starting tomorrow and a half-asleep child wasn't going to make a good impression!

James hauled the sash window down and latched it.

Then he moved back down the stairs, gathered up his knife and shoved a smaller on inside his boot once he'd laced them up. Bo had followed him and he stood for a moment regarding the dog. Not much of a defence animal, but he'd be able to find Sabrina easily. That meant James could get away without taking a torch (sometimes it was best to be wandering about in the dark truly in the dark!).

Decision made, James pulled on his heavy oil-proof jacket and attached Bo to his leash. 'Come on, Bo, we've got a wayward child to find.'

James took the key from the hook, and drew back the bolts on the door. It swung quietly open on well-oiled hinges and latched with a click behind them. The key turned in the lock and then found a temporary home in a pocket of the jacket.

Sabrina's father took a moment to ensure his jacket was done up entirely, even though the night was not yet freezing, and then started up the path. He was going to have to ground Sabrina for a month for this; the child had to learn obedience. She was a good student, but if she spent nights in disobedience she wasn't going to be very attentive during the day and would end up either falling asleep in class or making silly little mistakes that could see her dropped from the school. He could not afford to send her to school if she didn't make an effort.

And that puzzled James because Sabrina liked going to school. Or had. Perhaps the month off over the first spring month had changed her? James grimaced; he and Sabrina were going to have to have a long chat.

For now, he needed to find her, and he had the ever growing suspicion that he had little time to do so. Bo was pulling at the leash and only wanted to go in one direction - toward the wood. She'd been told so many times to stay clear of the wood as much as possible but something always pulled her that way.

James broke into a trot, would have had to even if he'd not chosen it himself, because of Bo. He wanted to yell out but night was silent apart from his steps and Bo's puffing.

The moon, though just a sickle, put out enough light in the cloudless sky to reveal the woods. Well, to reveal a huge black shape that stretched for miles and seemed oddly high in any case. James couldn't make out individual trees in the blackness.

And that universal darkness, like he was staring at an absolute nothingness, allowed his eyes to pick up the tiny flicker of green a hundred yards off. He stopped still, causing a half yap from Bo, getting out a low 'sshhh,' in response. He settled a hand onto Bo's collar and the dog fell silent. But he wiggled beneath James' hand, signifying he'd seen the light too.

James strained his hearing but nothing came to him in terms of voices.

The green light was moving about. James might have thought it was just a firefly or other some such creature that emitted a phosphorus glow from the moon's light, if it hadn't been for the type of green. A bright green that looked ill. In other words, poison green. Whatever was making that colour wasn't good. And my daughter's out here! James thought.

The element of surprise was his, he thought, so he started moving closer, keeping his hand on Bo's collar so the dog knew to stay at heel and stay quiet.

All of a sudden he heard 'I'm not afraid of you' delivered in a belligerent voice. A childish voice.

'Sabrina?' he called, unable to stop himself, hurrying forward.

'Daddy?' came the return cry. 'Daddy!'

Truly, in the darkness they probably would have run passed each other, if Bo hadn't been present. He yanked out of James' gripped and took off into the darkness with a bark. James didn't even get out the dog's name before he heard a squeal of delight and muffled barking.

James came across his daughter and dog in a tumble on the ground, and for a moment thought to join in. Then he was sure he saw the flash of green again - not close, but whatever it was was obviously still around. 'Alright, young lady,' he said, grabbing his daughter's arm. 'Time to get you home and into bed. You have school tomorrow.'

He hoped his words and tone and Sabrina's resultant 'oh, do I have to?' would put the green thing off, think that it remained unnoticed.

James noticed how Sabrina didn't try to disengage him, nor pull back, but moved with quick step. The dog stayed right by her side, ears alert as if he kept on guard.

They headed for the house in silence and James refrained from speaking even when they came into the patch of light made by Sabrina's window and he noticed she was just in pyjamas, with bare feet. Grounded... the only option, after a stern talking to!

Inside the house, with the massive bolts drawn and this time the key turned in the lock, James sat his young daughter in the rocking chair in front of the fire and frowned down at her.

'I've so many things to say,' he said, 'that I don't know where to begin!'

'I'm sorry, daddy.' Sabrina looked at her lap.

James swung loose the blanket from over the back of the rocker and fitting it around Sabrina. 'If I go and make a hot chocolate, will you promise not to move?'

Sabrina nodded, tucking her feet up under the blanket.

James waited just a second before heading to the kitchen, reflecting that Sabrina hadn't seem scared at any time on the walk or even now. Surprised, first, and then a bit relieved but not really scared. A fact that he was both proud of and worried about. Children were fearless because they didn't think there was anything to fear. That made them incredibly (and occasionally) bold and liable to get into a whole world of trouble.

But perhaps the green thing hadn't been bad? James felt a prickle down his spine, for a second wondered if it had been Morgana. No, he shook his head. The poison green was a give-away. Nothing good carried that colour. And his wife sure as heck wouldn't!

With a hot chocolate made for both of them James returned to the lounge room and handed a mug over. Sabrina mumbled a small thank you and buried her face in the cup, as if she might think that'd get her out of answering questions. James shook his head.

'Sabrina, why did you climb out the window? Why did you disobey me?'

'I didn't mean to,' Sabrina said quietly. 'But I was curious, and it was insistent.'

'The fairy,' Sabrina answered, looking up.

'The green thing?'

Sabrina's brows rose, her lips parting in surprise. Her dad saw... But didn't he always say fairies were just tales?

James crouched in front of the chair. He pulled the black ring from down his shirt and let it dangle. Sabrina had seen it several times, had always just thought it was something from her mother.

'This tells me whenever someone has passed through the front gate,' he said quietly. 'It heats up.'

Sabrina watched the ring twist slowly on the leather thong. 'Daddy,' she whispered, 'you do believe...'

'Yes,' James said.

13132311.title: James finds Sabrina.

131323111.content:
Sabrina stared at her father. He'd told her so many times to stop talking so much about fairies, to stop telling people her mother was one; she'd been sure he had no belief in these things at all, even about the beast in the woods. She'd always thought it was just a ploy parents used to make their kids behave. Now, he dangled a ring in front of her and told her it was magic. And - way more important - he'd just said he'd see Charie (well, 'the green thing') and that he believed.

She opened her mouth and he said, 'Sabrina, this is still my question time.'

Oh right, trouble first!

'What do you mean, the fairy insisted?' her father asked. 'That you follow it out of your room?'

Sabrina nodded. 'It said that Celine was in trouble, that only I could help her.'

'Who is Celine?'

'Another fairy,' Sabrina whispered to her hands. Then looked up. 'My guardian angel. She saved me from the beast once, when I was in the forest.'

Her father's brows rose one at a time and she knew he was trying to think of a time when she'd been in the woods with his knowledge. Not many, but far more without his knowledge. Eventually he said, 'you've been disobeying me quite some time, I gather.'

'Yes, father,' she admitted quietly.

'Why?'

'I was curious,' Sabrina said.

'There's a time and place for curiosity and inquisitiveness, Sabrina,' her father said, 'but it does not involve that forest at any time.'

'Is the beast real, then?' Sabrina asked, even though she'd seen it briefly with her own eyes. She remembered it as a giant wolf but sometimes wondered if that was something Celine had 'made' her see so that she could cope.

Her father rose, flexed a knee, then turned to the fire for a moment. But he wasn't looking at the flames, instead his gaze was on the painting of her mother. He was silent so long she prompted him with, 'daddy?'

He started, as if he'd forgotten about her, and turned back. 'Sabrina, when I tell you not to do something, there is always a reason behind it. Why would I tell you to stay out of the woods if there was nothing dangerous in there?'

Sabrina remained quiet. Her father nodded as if that answered his question. 'So tonight,' he continued, after a short moment, 'a fairy told you that your angel fairy was in trouble and that you had to help.'

Not a question, but Sabrina nodded anyway.

'And you didn't stop to think that other fairies would have been more helpful than a human child?'

Sabrina opened her mouth to say something about 'other fairies' (he hadn't sounded like he was having a laugh) and then realised the latter part of the question was quite sound. She hadn't thought of this at all. She shook her head but said, 'why would a fairy lie about that sort of thing?'

'Fairies are not all good, Sabrina,' her father said. 'And nothing that shade of green is good - fairy, food or otherwise!'

Sabrina coloured. 'I was afraid for Celine,' she said. 'She helped me; all I thought about was helping her. Charie said she might die.'

'Charie?'

'The green fairy,' Sabrina said. 'And she didn't always show that green. I noticed it mostly out by the forest, that's when I started to think... well, started to believe her.'

'She wanted you to go into the woods?'

'Yes, and she said as long as I was with her I'd be safe, but if I didn't go then who knew what would happen.'

'I heard you say you weren't afraid of her,' her father murmured.

'Well, I wasn't,' Sabrina said, puffing up a bit. 'I was bigger than her, and I wasn't in the woods. I didn't think anything could get me, and I could see my window.' Now that she said all that out loud, she realised she might just have been lucky about all this. If the fairy could cross out of the woods, then maybe other things could have too. Sabrina kept her spine straight.

Her father shook his head just a tiny bit.

'Mother would have done the same,' Sabrina said, indicating the portrait with a finger.

Her father didn't turn, just gazed at her, let out a silent sigh. She apologised for worrying him. When he raised a brow, she added an apology for disobedience.

'You're grounded for a month, kiddo,' he said. 'I'll take you to school, and I'll pick you up, and every moment outside of that you'll be here in the house.'

Sabrina held her tongue. Arguing would be silly right now, she understood. She changed the subject just a little. 'I thought mum gave you that ring.' It rested on the outside of her father's jacket, occasionally catching the fire light.

He picked it up, ran his thumb around the edge. 'She did,' he responded in a thick voice.

'Did she... she knew what it does, didn't she?' Sabrina pushed herself forward in the chair to peer more closely at the ring.

'Yes, she did,' her father admitted.

'And she gave it to you before she... disappeared,' she ended. She'd been going to say 'became a fairy' but wasn't sure she should.

Her father gazed at her. 'What makes you say that?'

'Because you didn't need it when she was around,' Sabrina said. 'Did you? There was always both of you here, looking after me. But then just you... Daddy, she knew she was going away, didn't she?'

Her father seemed stunned at the thought but also sort of relieved. Sabrina had never thought her mother was dead but tried not to bring that up much because she knew it upset her dad. But know that she'd spoken, the more she thought she'd spoken true. Her mum had meant to go, or at least had known something was going to happen and had made sure her husband was prepared. Tears pricked Sabrina's eyes. 'She's not dead, daddy.'

'I know,' he whispered and gathered his daughter in his arms. 'That doesn't mean I think she's a fairy,' he added after a moment, 'but she is not dead. Of that I'm certain.'

131323112.content:
Sabrina stared at her father with curiosity and hurt, and he knew why.

'Honey, the world that you believe in is nothing compared to the truth,' James said. 'How could I reveal that to you? You're just six years old.'

'I'm not a baby,' was her first response and then she grimaced. She'd just sounded like one! 'Daddy, mum gave you the ring, didn't she?'

James nodded. 'Not long before she... left.'

'She isn't dead,' Sabrina whispered. 'Not really dead, anyway.' She waited but this time her father didn't speak. She hugged her mug to her chest, then took a drink before speaking again. 'You don't think she is either, do you?'

James spent a long time looking at the black ring as it flickered in the fire light. How could he tell his child what he thought? She seemed very open to these ideas but thus far everything she 'knew' was just made up. Could he really reveal what was going on in the world, or in the woods? He looked up. Sabrina was gazing at him with a direct look, and James felt a tiny smile twist onto his features. His daughter had often acted beyond her years!!

He took a gulp from his own mug and then rose, set it on the mantle next to Morgana's picture. Even at six, Sabrina resembled her closely. He blew out a breath, waited, but his wife gave no sign about whether he should continue or not, so he made the decision himself. Turning he said, 'Sabrina, your mother isn't dead, not in the sense that she has been buried. I would feel that. Or - I would feel nothing at all, like something has been cut from me. I don't know where she is, or even how she is, but she's still here somehow.'

Sabrina sucked on her lips, somehow managed to not say that she was a fairy. To be honest she suddenly wasn't so sure about that anyway! Not with her dad suddenly being so serious.

'I don't believe she is a fairy,' her father said. 'I know that's what you'd like, but I'm sure I'd sense that. And I don't.'

'Did you sense Charie?'

'Charie?'

'The fairy,' Sabrina said. 'The one I followed.'

James shook his head. 'No, I didn't, but even out there by the woods I just saw green, Sabrina, barely any shape.'

Sabrina's mouth turned into an O.

'By the way,' James said and let his voice tighten, 'let's get the punishment sorted before we go too far.'

Sabrina pulled a face; had been hoping somehow her father might have forgotten about that.

James hid a smile in the shake of his head. 'You are grounded for two months. I'll take you to school and I'l pick you up. Outside of school you'll be here in the house. And I will cut that limb so that you cannot climb down the tree.'

Sabrina clutched her mug, so many arguments trying to escape. But her father didn't really use this tone with her much; she knew he was truly angry and scared. 'Sorry, daddy.'

'I'm glad to hear it, Sabrina,' he said gruffly. 'That was a silly, silly thing you did tonight. Your curiosity could have got you seriously in trouble. It could have gotten you killed!'

'But I wasn't in the forest, daddy,' Sabrina felt the need to say. 'I stayed outside.'

'Sabrina, the beast can leave the forest,' James said. 'There's nothing to stop it, but an old wives' tale.'

For a second, Sabrina felt rather miffed but it wasn't her dad's fault so she smiled timidly at him. He arched a brow and shook his head. 'Why didn't you go into the forest?'

'Because I didn't like how she pushed me,' Sabrina said, and straightened in her seat. 'She was bossy and I didn't like that.'

James tried hard not to smile.

'And she said I'd be safe if I stayed with her, but not if I didn't. I didn't think that sounded right.'

'I wish you'd thought that at the beginning, Sabrina,' James said with a sigh.

'She said Celine was in danger,' Sabrina said. 'I had to go.'

'And who is Celine?'

Sabrina stopped a moment and thought how to respond. Her father seemed to be taking things reasonably well right now. Would talking about a Guardian Fairy change that? She bit her lip.

'Sabrina.'

'Guardian Fairy,' Sabrina blurted.

'Right,' she thought she heard her father mumble. Then he looked at her. 'Explain, child.'

So Sabrina told him what Charie had said, why she felt she had to go with her, what Celine had done for her. Her father remained silent the entire time, which made her a little nervous. He might have some strong beliefs but fairies seemed to be down his list. When she fell silent, her father remained so.

'I had to go, daddy,' Sabrina insisted.

'Yes, I'm sure you felt you did,' James responded softly. 'Sabrina, did the colour of the fairy not shout a warning to you?'

'The colour?'

'Poison green,' he said. 'Nothing that shade of green is good. Nothing!'

'Well, she wasn't always that colour,' Sabrina said. 'Not until at the end, when I said I wouldn't go with her.' Sabrina tried to remember other colours Charie had been but couldn't, but she was sure on the green.

'How many times have you been in the forest?'

Sabrina winced. The interrogation was set to be a long one, and she wanted to know what her father believed! 'Not many,' she said, hoping that would satisfy him.

Which told James that she'd been in there a decent number of times. He sighed and shook his head. Then he changed tack a little. 'The best is real, Sabrina,' he said. 'Did you see it the day you claim Celine saved you?'

'I saw a wolf,' Sabrina said quietly. 'He wasn't so big.'

When her father asked for a description she gave it, and judged by his expression that what she had seen wasn't what everyone else knew about. 'Celine still saved me,' she pouted.

'Yes,' James said.

'It wasn't the beast, was i?' she ventured.

Her father only shook his head.

'Daddy, why don't you believe in fairies?'

'I never said I didn't, Sabrina,' was his response.

She waited but he was regarding the ring again.

13132312.content:
James headed for the woods because, unfortunately, that seemed the logical place to find his daughter. If she was disobeying him tonight, then she'd be going all out - and entering the woods was the biggest no-no rule he had.

That's because it carried the biggest danger, and yet no matter what he told Sabrina she seemed to think it was all just part of a great fairy tale. Well, that had some truth but she'd think again, he was sure, if she saw the scars down his back. He'd always been very careful to never let her see them, even on those piping hot summer days when he worked in the garden. Never shirtless.

James growled to himself. Perhaps he should have shown her! Shown her that the fairy tale had claws, revealed the stories around her mother's disappearance. Morgana wasn't the only person to have simply disappeared, presumed dead. If it happened (at least twice a year!) and young children were involved then the townsfolk followed a plan. A parent (or sibling) was dead but it had nothing to do with the woods or the beast within. Sabrina had been just four. Though she'd been extra in touch with fairies and magical things even then, James knew her thoughts about Morgana being a fairy now herself related to her own feelings, not because she'd heard anything around town.

James ensured no one fed her hocus pocus.

Now, he regretted it somewhat. Children were too bold by half, not afraid of anything, and especially not of stories. If he'd shown her the scars and related their arrival maybe he wouldn't now be out on a barely moon-lit light trying to find her.

His fault, as usual! And he muttered to himself, because his daughter's inquisitiveness and stubborness weren't his fault. That's just how she was, and he was sure that even Morgana wouldn't have been able to curb it! As earlier, James made a silent wish for Morgana to be watching over their child.

No log crashing in the fire answered him this time. It was just he and Bo moving towards a wall of blackness, even blacker than the night sky and that was barely light at all. The moon was a sickle but he couldn't see any stars.

The nights had been like that for a couple of weeks now, and everyone was unsettled. It meant something but no one knew what, and none of the annals in the town's tiny library revealed any past occurrences. Rumour abounded though, that the beast was stirring - more so that usual because that rumour was often used to keep children in line.

Wish it worked for mine.

James slowed his steps as he got nearer the woods. He couldn't make out outlines of trees; indeed the mass of the forest seemed to have coalesced into a solid wall and it gave off an intense air of foreboding. His grip tightened on his knife, other hand clenching around the leash. Though the dog might not be a great defence animal, James was thankful he'd brought him. Bo would find Sabrina no matter how dark it was.

At the moment though, while Bo was continuing to strain forward he seemed more out for a run rather than a 'seek' trip. He occasionally sniffed the ground but didn't seem, to James anyway, to pick up anything that made him more alert. But, nor was he acting as if something was terribly amiss. He had, in the past.

James momentarily wondered if that was because Sabrina hadn't come this way at all. Damn, he should have walked around the house first. Made sure, even, that she wasn't in the tree! Though, surely she'd have spoken out then. James stopped; did he go back and check? He glanced over his shoulder, saw the patch of light from the window half shuttered by the tree. He couldn't make out the shape of anyone lingering in the bare foliage.

James crouched, hugged Bo to him. 'Do we continue on?' he asked the dog in a whisper. 'I only have a knife, no torch.' He glanced at the deepness that rose above him like a sudden mountain range. The beast didn't have the forest to itself; there was more than one thing in here that could make his night very nasty. 'Shit,' he said. He was under prepared, but then again he hadn't expected not to find Sabrina out here somewhere. It could only have been a half hour at most between telling her to go to bed and now. How far could she have gone?

He tried not to think of the fact that once Sabrina had got to this point, something else might have helped her along. Except, it was very rare that anything actually left the veil of trees. If you stayed outside the line, you kept a decent amount of safety. James had to work hard to convince himself that his daughter had some intelligence in her. Believe the stories or not, surely she wouldn't have gone into the wood - not in the middle of the night!!

James stared ahead of him, straining to see the outline of anything. But it was just blackness; truly like a void, like nothing was there at all. Maybe that's what it was at night? A void.

The soft chuckle startled him before he realised it was his own. God, he was starting to imagine things! He dug his fingers into Bo's soft fur for a reality check, and received a slobber over his face. 'Okay, old boy,' James said. 'Do we go in, or do we check outside?'

13132312.title: James doesn't find Sabrina.

131323121.content:
Knowing Sabrina she would have just marched straight on into the darkness. The child was fearless, terrifyingly so!

And disobedient.

James shook his head. His daughter had always been wayward, seemed more so now that Morgana wasn't around. But what could he do to rein her in, bar chaining her to the house! Which he'd never do because he appreciated Sabrina's free spirit. He just wished, sometimes, she wasn't so free with it.

The scars across his back seemed to tighten. Tonight of all nights! There was barely a moon in the sky and certainly no stars. It felt thick out here, this darkness. As if there was more to it than usual. But that was probably James himself making it so.

He hadn't been into the woods in a number of years and he had done his darndest to keep Sabrina away. He sighed; he should have been open with her, told her what he knew, what he believed. Told her about the scars across his back.

Hindsight....

Well, that wouldn't find his daughter! 'Right, Bo,' James said with more nerve than he felt. 'Let's get ourselves in here and find Sabrina.'

At her name, Bo gave a bark and started sniffing the ground, as if he knew he needed to play a role here. James was grateful he'd brought the dog. Not big on defence, but his hearing and sense of smell would be very helpful once they'd stepped over the threshold.

James glanced over his shoulder briefly, back at the house and the light shining from his daughter's bedroom. Perhaps he should go and get better weapons? Perhaps he should contact his neighbours.

No, any delay now could be disastrous. Might already be, but he tried not to think of that.

Bo tugged at the leash. James drew in a tight breath and let the dog move him forward, across the invisible line and into the forest.

Weirdly, the night was even more silent within the forest and it hadn't exactly been noisy outside! There should have been night creatures moving about - voles, mice, lizards even, owls. But James heard nothing that sounded like life outside of himself and Bo, not even a breeze moving the bushes. And the darkness was complete; he couldn't see his hand in front of his face.

He felt Bo press against him and he murmured a soft encouragement. He had to keep thinking encouraging thoughts too, since in reality he might have entered the woods in a totally different place from his daughter. Damn, he should have brought a light! How on earth did he expect to be able to find his way let alone his daughter in this darkness?

If danger lurked (probably no 'if') he wouldn't see it before it found him.

James' breath was a little on the short side, and his nerves weren't helped by the fact the scars were starting to sting, as if by some weirdness they were raw again. Don't be stupid, he thought, that can't happen!

His spare hand fumbled for the black ring Morgana had given him just before she left. Keep this with you, always, my love, she'd said, and he had never taken it from around his neck. He clutched the ring now, cool under his touch but seeming to grow warmer. Just my hand, he thought.

And then he'd have sworn he heard his name spoken, and he stopped dead, ears straining. Bo leaned against him but didn't appear to be reacting at all.

James.

James went rigid, as still and as silent as the forest.

James!

'Who's there?' he rasped out.

'Oh blast, I forgot. Your human eyes can't see me.'

James nearly choked on the shock of hearing the voice out loud, and not too far away. He looked down and had to reach out to reassure himself that Bo was still with him. The dog was, and yet he wasn't growling or making any sound.

A scratching sound came from the right and then a faint blue glow appeared. James struggled to withdraw his knife, held it out in front of him.

'Put that away, James,' came the voice. Female? He wasn't sure. 'I'm not here to hurt you.'

'Who are you?'

'My name is Celine.'

'Who are you?'

'I am your daughter's Guardian,' the voice said. It seemed to come from the blue light which hadn't yet attained a shape.

'Sabrina? Where is she? What have you done with her?' James edged closer to the light, scars pulling at his back making him feel stiff. Why did the name sound familiar?

'James,' Celine said calmly, 'do not worry, she is fine. I have her in a safe place now. She thought you might find she was gone from her room, and worried you'd come looking.'

'Of course I'd come looking,' James cried. 'She's my daughter!'

The blue flared brighter, making James shade his eyes, and when it faded a young woman stood there. James' jaw dropped. 'Morgana?' he croaked out.

The woman shook her head. 'I am not your wife, James.'

'But...' James staggered, nearly fell to his knees. Bo snuffled at him.

'I appear to people differently,' she said softly, calmly. 'You miss your wife, and though you don't believe your daughter with her tales about Morgana being a fairy, you still wish it were so.'

James rubbed his face and when he looked up this time, the young woman was certainly not his wife. He let out a sound that might have been a sob. 'Take me to Sabrina, p-please.'

'Of course,' Celine said. 'Come this way, stay close.'

'Why is she out here?'

'She followed Charie,' and the tone was anger.

'Who?'

'A fairy intent on nefarious things,' Celine said, 'but do not worry, James, Sabrina is safe.'

'Sabrina is a sensible child,' James heard himself say. And intelligent; surely she wouldn't just follow...

'You can get the story from her,' Celine said. 'I'm sure she has quite the tale to tell. Resourceful child.'

That last came out softly and James was certain he heard pride. He shook his head; resourceful or not, his child was going to be grounded until she turned eighteen!

'Do those scars bother you much?'

James jerked. 'What?' And then, 'how do you know?' His grip tightened on the knife again.

'I'm a guardian,' Celine said. 'It's my job to know.'

James didn't care for the cryptic answer, but before he could speak, Celine added, 'I can see you are in pain, and I can sense the mark of the beast upon you.'

James didn't really have a comeback for that. He got out stiffly, 'they feel like they are fresh.'

'The forest does that,' Celine said softly. 'I have some salve you can use that will prevent the pain.'

James wasn't sure he wanted anything from the fairy apart from his daughter, but he didn't say so.

131323122.content:
Bo gave a bark, which James interpreted as 'check outside' . He nodded as if in agreement and turned left. He kept Bo's leash short, and kept the dog on his right - next to the forest. Bo would see and hear things moving there before he could, even if his eyesight was adjusting to the deep dark.

Bo put his nose to the ground and sniffed, let out a little yelp.

'Do you sense Sabrina?' James asked, hopeful.

Bo usually did have a good sense of where his daughter might be or had been, but out here he could have found the trail of a mouse as easily as his daughter. The dog didn't look up, but kept snuffling the grass. James jiggled the leash and took a step, the Labrador following as if the grass hadn't been so fascinating two seconds ago.

James sucked in his lips, and broke into a trot. He had two sides of a forest to check and he didn't want to take all night. The air was chilled and the lack of stars was distinctly uncomfortable. He found his spare hand snuck into his jacket and curved around the black ring. It wouldn't do anything here but he felt just a little bit closer to Morgana. He hoped that wherever she might be, she was looking out for their daughter.

I can't lose her too.

James picked up his pace again, into a jog. No point in doing this slowly; he'd be here all night and the need to fight his way-ward daughter was getting stronger by the minute.

James yelled our Sabrina's name, hearing it echo over the wide expanse of field. From the forest came no response at all, no growling from animals, cackling from birds, not even any sounds within the trees themselves. Yet it wasn't a still night, a soft breeze lifted James' hair and ruffled Bo's coat. The forest was its own living form, or in some cases 'dead' form.

The forest was silent, and so was the field in front of him. No response from his daughter.

As he ran along, James started to hear his name. He shoved his hand over his ear a second, then released it. No, he still heard it. James stopped still, holding his breath. Beside him, Bo pricked his ears forward - not toward the forest as James feared but further out into the field. And then the dog started growling low in its throat.

James held still, trying the locate the name caller. He sounded familiar but sound travelled oddly out here sometimes. No, wait... wasn't that...

'James, James, is that you?'

'Richard?' James got out in the direction of the voice, sure he could now see an outline against the faint lights of the next house.

'Oh, it is you, thank the heavens.'

Within a few minutes Richard came to a stop in front of James. 'What are you doing out here? I just tried to reach you at your house.'

'What?' James said surprised. 'Why?'

'You haven't heard?' Richard got out. 'The beast, James. It's been seen out of the forest.'

'What?' James cried. 'When? Where? My daughter's out here somewhere!'

'Sabrina? What? No, James, she's at my house,' Richard said.

James couldn't even respond verbally this time. Richard looked at him, concerned. 'You didn't know?'

James slowly shook his head. 'Seems she climbed out the window.'

'Heh,' Richard said. 'I caught my Lara doing the same thing. Said she was off to meet Sabrina. I gathered your daughter up as soon as she showed up. I came to tell you that too.'

'I better come and get her,' James said.

'And stay for a while,' Richard said. 'We're holding a meeting. If the beast is leaving the forest, we need to have a plan.'

James agreed.

The truth of the wolf

long he'd been misunderstood
this sentinel of the moonlight,
in historic lore and fantasy
given wiles of ill repute
hunted and abused so long
that story turned from myth
to real and even wolves forgot
their logic, speech and wisdom
once respected on the earth
but man had wrought such changes
that wolves now had to run
protect, defend their own
from power they knew not
from honoured teacher
to beast without true home

Yet long he did remember
days when men would walk
and treat every creature
with respect as equal, talk
in hidden language
known to all the earth
and he did not forget
the burden of that knowing
was difficult to bear
as one of a kind he lived
alone, the sentinel of the moon.

Josette, youngest of five children, has awakened just before dawn as she hears something she's never heard before behind their small home. "Josie, I'm scared," Bran whined. The noise grated on Josie's nerves and she was almost sorry that she had brought him.

"We're fine, Bran." She swallowed her irritation. Bran was young and he couldn't help being scared. He'd been born sick, in fact, no one believed he would make his first birth day let alone the fifth one he had celebrated last week.

Josette understood. She was certain she did. Some people needed more care and attention than others, and Josette had always been good at getting along on her own. She wasn't jealous of Bran, not really and she had never truly wished any ill upon him. But there were days when she was tired from her never-ending list of chores and starving from the manual labor, and Bran, who had lain in the cool house all day, was still given the best and largest cut of meat. Josette's stomach growled even now at the thought of the fat, juicy pork chops her mother, father, and Bran enjoyed for dinner last evening.

And it wasn't that her parents didn't love her. She was given delicious bread and cheese to feast upon, so she was not deprived. Girls were just less valuable than boys who would carry on the family name and bring honor to the household. Even among the peasant class, marriage was meant for social gain. Josette would be paired with the son of the blacksmith, while her parents would search far and wide for a girl worthy of their Bran, hoping that he lived long enough to produce an heir for their family farm. Josette would move to town and assist with the Blacksmith business while Bran gain the entire family home.

It was the way of life and there was little use in harping. Instead, Josette sought adventure where she could find it, and today, these woods held a great adventure for her and her young brother.

"How much further?" Bran wheezed. His lungs not nearly as strong as they should be.

Josette reached into her sack and handed him a sprig of mint leaves. Bran chewed obediently, though with a grimace on his face.

"This stuff is terrible!" He complained.

"But, it helps your lungs and you can breathe again," Josette interjected, settling them both into some soft moss near a tree.

"Can't you just tell me what's back in the woods like you used to? I don't think I can make it all the way back." Bran's breathing wasn't improving and Josette's heart raced. What had she done? Had she intentionally brought Bran here knowing what would happen? Couldn't she have just told him about the cub?

The breaking of a branch to their left startled the two and Bran let out a scream. "Shush" Josette said, clamping her hand over his mouth. "We have to get you home," she whispered.

Bran's eyes were wide and Josette could see the fear in them. If they were caught in these woods... Josette shivered in understanding of the terror. She knew. Something was tracking them in here. Josette wasn't sure how she knew, but now that they were silent and listening, she could feel the eyes on her. She realized that those eyes had always been on her. She had put her brother into danger and it was up to her to make it right.

Josette hoisted Bran onto her back, remarking at how light the boy was. She'd carried feed sacks heavier than her current load. Her heart pounded as she situated him and it made her clumsy. Three times she came close to tumbling onto the ground and throwing her passenger. It was only through sheer will that she remained upright and Bran stayed fastened to her back.

Finally, Josette had righted herself and was prepared to slip out of these terrible woods, never to return when she turned and stared up in to the face of her father. She had never seen him that shade of red before and the dread washed over her entire body. Suddenly the beast hidden within these woods didn't seem nearly half so terrifying as the hulking man standing before her.

Without a word, father turned and walked toward the house. Josette hung her head and followed. Bran was silent on her back as well. It was the first time she had ever wished that a walk would go on forever. She had suffered her father's wrath in the past for lesser discretions and was sure that she had just committed the mother of all sins in her father's eyes. She didn't want to know what awaited her at the end of the woods.

Suddenly, a noise in the bush to their right called all three of their attentions. A solid black figure with dark red eyes emerged and lunged for father. Bran screamed into her hear and for a few moments, Josette couldn't hear a sound.

Josette heard the words, but terror would not allow her to move. What would happen to Father? What had she done?

"Josie, run!" Bran urged from her back and it was the wheezing in that noise that gave her feet the courage to leave their post. She took off toward the edge off the woods as fast as her feet would carry her.

One quick glance showed back her that Father had removed his sword from the hilt and he and the beast were locked in a death dance. She hoped that he would return to them. She sent up several prayers under her shaky breath that he would defeat the hideous beast. But she held little hope. Father was an expert swordsman, but that beast was more ferocious than any many within the realm.

Mother awaited them as they emerged from the treeline. "Josette, what on earth!" Mother began, but was stopped by what she saw on her daughter's face. "Where is your father?"

Josette set Bran down onto one of the boulders the children often used as seats and collapsed onto the ground. She was spent.

"Josette!" Mother's voice was shrill from worry. Josette pushed aside her fatigue and stood, head bowed.

"Yes, Mother," she mumbled.

"Where is your father, Josette?" Mother grabbed Josette's shoulders and squeezed, leaving nail prints in the fragile young skin. Josette raised her face to look at Mother. She had never seen her in such a state and guilt gnawed her gut because she knew this was all her fault. She should have never dared venture into the woods. She should have never taken Bran.

"He's..." Josette began, and then like a dam releasing it's hold, something burst within her and tears flooded her cheeks. "I'm so sorry, Mama," she sobbed and hiccuped. "I only wanted to show Bran the cub. I thought he would like the cub. But, he couldn't breath and so we started back and then Father came and then...." Her voice trailed off and her body shook with sobs.

"The beast." Bran whispered from his seat. His voice sounded stronger and the wheezing had ceased. He turned and looked up at them both, his eyes as big as dinner plates. "Father is battling the beast."

Mother covered her mouth with one hand and gasped. With the other hand, she searched for a place to steady herself, settling for the rock where Bran currently sat. She guided herself down onto the other side of the boulder and settled in next to her son. Bran placed his hand on her shoulder in a comforting gesture. Mother smiled at him, but her eyes never left the treeline.

Josette set herself on the ground at Mother's feet, and the three held vigil in this position throughout the day. There would be time later for punishment and guilt. This time was to be spent in wait. As the hours passed, they continued to sit, none daring to even shift positions.

After several hours of waiting, Bran's stomach growled loudly, a reminder to them all that breakfast had been many, many hours ago. Mother wiped her eyes and patted Bran on his knee. "Let's go get you some food," she said and marched toward the house. Her eyes avoided Josette.

Josette felt the weight and the accusation of her mother's actions sure as if the older woman had screamed it into her face. She brought her knees to her chest and rested her head on them. Why couldn't she just be an obedient child? What was wrong with her?

Bran wrapped his arms around Josette and she took some comfort in the embrace, though she knew that she did not deserve the affection. She had just killed the boy's father, so how could he stand to touch her?

Mother set out breads and cheeses for supper, along with a warmed broth soup. She was not focused on the children, instead her eyes fixated on the tiny window. She barely looked at Josette the entire evening and didn't speak to her at all.

Josette nibbled some of the bread, but it felt like rocks inside her stomach. Bran seemed to be the only one of them with any appetite at all. He ate and chattered about how brave Father was and how he would come home at any moment with the nasty beast's head.

The more he chattered, the more guilt Josette felt and the more sullen mother became. At one point, mother simply stood and walked into the bedroom. Josette set to work clearing the leftovers and wrapping them for the next day. She then prepared Bran for bed, all while he chattered away.

While she tucked him into bed, the constant noise from him became too much for her to bear. "Shut up, Bran!" She snapped at him. "He's not coming back. Don't you see that it's dark outside now? Don't you realize Father is dead? I killed him because I disobeyed." Josette laid her head in her hands and wailed. "I should have died, not Father."

Bran laid his hand on the side of her face and Josette looked up at him. His eyes held such love and compassion. "This isn't your fault," he said to her. Words that were wise beyond his five years.

"Mother blames me." Josette said plainly.

"Mother is hurting. We are all hurting. But you will see. He will come back to us."

Josette stretched her lips into a grimace and patted Bran's hand. She stood and walked to her pallette on the floor. She wanted to hope that Bran was right, but she was afraid. What if Father didn't come home. What if the beast had killed him. She needed to know the truth, but she didn't dare enter the woods with the sun vanished from the sky.

She settled in and spent the night in restless slumber with dreams of Father battling the beast and then her battling the beast. The last thing image before she woke was that of the beast. "You will come to me and I will release your father to your family."

The boy had already suffered so much with his affliction; how could he be expected to carry on without his father too.

Josette had always known that Bran was the preferred child. Boys brought value, strength, and the carrying on of family names. They were prized within their small village and the birth of a boy was celebrated town wide.

Girls, however, were seen as burdens to be endured until the day they were married off. Josette's body trembled as she came upon the tall tower in the middle of the glen. This place seemed so very close to her house and yet so far away. It was the first time she had ever been this deep in the woods. She circled the tower searching for the entrance, but had no luck. How could she save Father if she couldn't get to him?

Despondent, she flopped onto the ground and burst into a puddle of tears. 'I'm am a failure,' she thought. 'Bran will grow up without father and Mother will never forgive me for what I have done to our family.' Her stream of self pity flowed until the tears ran out, and then she sat there, red-eyed and dead inside. She had nothing more to give.

"Oy! You!" A hoarse voice called from the trees. "What are you doing out so far in the woods? Don't you know a beast lurks around here?"

Josette nodded and looked up at the stranger as he emerged from the woods. He was rugged and handsome, and his chiseled cheeks reminded her of Jack. She longed for Jack in that moment.

"Can't you talk?" The man's voice softened with concern? "You look ill? Are you ill?"

Josette recoiled. How dare he. Sure she hadn't slept and she had just cried out every drop of water within her body, but one never asked a lady such things. Although, truth be told, she was not a lady. Commoners never were ladies. She lifted her chin and replied, "I can speak. I know of the beast. He took my father. I am here to ask for his release."

For a moment, Josette could have sworn that the handsome stranger's eyes glowed red, but it was gone before she could be totally sure. "And just what do you think you have to barter with that such a mean and vicious beast would want?"

Josette looked down at her hands and began to panic. What did she have? She was simply a lowly girl of sixteen, barely able to keep house to her mother's satisfaction, and more trouble than her father had time to deal with. What could she tell this man?

Then Josette's spine stiffened. Who was this stranger and how dare he question her abilities? She raised her chin and set her lips. "I hardly think that's any of your concern," she scoffed.

The man surprised her by laughing and Josette jerked. "That's the spirit!" he gaffawed. "I was beginning to think that you had no spunk at all. Come, I will take you to the entrance of the foul beast's castle."

"But-" Josette looked up at the tower and back to the man who was now walking away. She looked back to the tower again, afraid to leave this spot. What if the door opened and she could get in? She had to try to save her father.

"He's not in there," the man called over his shoulder. He stopped and turned to face her. "Well, are you coming or not?"

Josette sat still looking between the man and the tower for a moment more. Father wasn't in there. Then where was he? This was the only dwelling she knew of inside these woods and it had always been rumored that the vicious beast lived inside.

"Well?" The man asked impatiently. Josette jumped to her feet and followed obediently behind him. Though she couldn't for the life of her understand why she did so. She didn't know this man. And the flash of red, had that been her imagination? What if he was taking her someplace to kill her? What if she would be sold into slavery? Josette's mind whirled a tornado of thoughts and doubts. This was crazy. She should go home, back to mother and Bran where she could be of some use, not wandering these woods.

"Here we are." The man had stopped in front of a small cave opening that looked barely big enough to fit Josette, let alone the body of a large beast.

"Here we are for what?" Josette asked.

"The entrance to the lair of the beast. If your father is alive, he would be in here. The beast may trade him for you. You are pretty and young and could be quite useful to him." The man brushed a stray hair from Josette's cheek and she flinched back. He laughed and the sound both infuriated and pleased her.

"So I have to go in there?" she whispered, and a shudder ran up her spine.

"I'm afraid so." The man replied.

Josette stood indecisive. She was afraid. It looked dark and small inside that cave. And what if this was to be the last day of her life? What if this was all a trap and Father was already dead. How could she know what to do? She needed his guidance to tell her.

She turned back to the man who stared at her with an odd expression on her face. "I never did catch your name," she said a bit brazenly.

The man winked at her and Josette's heart gave a little flutter in response. "It's Killian," he said giving a grandiose bow. "And you are?"

"Josette," she said, feeling suddenly shy.

The man took her hand and kissed her fingers lightly. Josette's heart went wild with dancing at this and her cheeks flushed red. She had never had her hand kissed as if she were a lady before.

The moment he let her hand go, though, the spell was broken and Josette stood still unsure of what choice to make. "Tell me Killian," she said staring at the opening, "would you go in?"

Killian was quiet for a long time and Josette looked back to make sure that he was still there. He lowered his head. "The beast is my master," he said in a voice so low Josette could hardly hear him.

"Your what??" She screamed. "I knew it. You brought me here to kill me. Where is my father? Is he dead already?"

There is a pause and the great wind ceases. A cloud forms close to the ground and slowly forms itself into a great fist with a pointing finger. "Of course, oh great one," Jalal says. "I thought my statement would show my respect. I wanted the village people to know that you cannot occupy yourself with the trivialities of our every day lives. I meant nothing more than that."
"Okay, then," the thunderous voice lowered its volume. In a conversational voice, it said, "I'll let you off the hook this time." The cloud finger pointed again at Jalal. "But don't piss me off again or it's curtains for you!" Apparently, the great one wanted to emphasize his point and so a great wind blew through the village. Hidden in the trees, the village people gasped.

The cloud slowly drifted until it reached the edge of the jungle and stopped. Slowly, it transformed into a face. A high forehead indicating great intelligence swept above a set of huge, dark eyes with purple iris's. A small nose resembling a ski lift jutted above a wide mouth, it's nostrils flaring and settling, then flaring again. When the face spoke the mouth opened to reveal two rows of large, sharp teeth. In the center of the top rows of teeth, two gold teeth glistened in the sunlight.
"Stand up!" The voice demanded. "Do you dare to fear you God?"
"We're afraid," a small, disembodied voice rose from the jungle. "Your ears are so big."
"All the better to hear my subjects," the voice said.
"But Master," the small voice replied, "Your eyes, they are so big and all seeing."
"Yes, they are," the booming voice said. "All the better to see you my subject."
"Yes, I can see how that works well for you, Master," the small voice replied. "But your mouth, Master," the voice said meekly, "It is your mouth that causes us the most concern."
"As well it should." The cloud face stretched its mouth wide, releasing a foul smelling wind. "But it is so big so that I am able to eat more of my subjects when they defy me."

"You think you can demand of me?" The mouth opened wide, its teeth glistened in the sun.

"Please, don't hurt me," Jalal shouted and crossed his arms protectively over his head. But instead of feeling the God's jaws close around his body, its teeth sinking into Jalal's tender skin, a great sound bellowed.

“I shall do what I can,” the alchemist replied. “But it is a conundrum, as the land is tainted, and any being I bring up can be affected in a negative way. Not the Fire Beast for sure. He recalled the thoughts that had been in his mind then. The contents of this room were fixed in their way, as was the silver forest with its thick shrubbery and dense branches of its tall trees. No change should come in here, and for the better. Any change meant contamination. He had advised the powers that be to have the people who entered the place take off their shoes, wipe their feet, dust their clothes, and wash their faces and hands as thoroughly as they could. Anything to prevent any evil spreading. One never knew what to expect from shadows, especially when those shadows could turn to be a beast.

His eyes grazed the brass andirons that stood as if they were monuments of order and stability.

“Why do you search the place with your eyes?” The Realm Master asked.

“Your Majesty, contamination is more to be feared than the Shadow Beast, as contamination is a forerunner to him. In other words, Shadow Beast goes where contamination is.”

“That would mean the entire realm,” a council member said.

“Exactly,” said the Alchemist. “That is why this room in the tower should be kept meticulously clean of contamination, so at least the governing body can come to right decisions, without the Shadow Beast affecting the minds.” He turned to the council. “Shadow Beast must be afraid of your strength,” he advised. “Strength always can mask what’s brittle.”

Another council member blinked, shaking his head. “Can that beast do that, I mean affect the mind?”

The Alchemist nodded.

The Realm Master looked away in deep thought, focusing on the lights coming from outside, at their glittery allure. When he turned to the Alchemist again, his voice carried great concern. “Tell me: What is the Beast’s purpose in creating such havoc?”

“That I can’t exactly say, Your Majesty, but I can guess it is the same as any other beast: To bring desperation to his environs so he can hide his own desperation.”

Experiencing a ripple in his mind, the Alchemist’s face crumpled; another time, another place, people wasting away, rivers drying, forests burning, beast and man in fierce wars with themselves and one another.

Security, safety. What was that? After that time, he’d never felt safe, not truly, not even while in the dungeon changing copper to gold or training dragons, no matter how strong he had made himself to be or how strong he’s let others think he was.

Was anyone ever strong enough?

He jerked about, coming to his senses, and saw the Realm Master watching him with concern. He bent his head and looked down.

“Tell me,” the Realm Master talked slowly. “What is making you so agitated, so worried?”

Recalling why he was summoned to the tower, he tried a smile, an absent smile without the consent of his soul. He pulled himself together, forcing the noise in his head cease, and faced the shocked silence of the room as the council members who had been murmuring among themselves had quieted totally.

“The experience I had at another time and another realm,” said the Alchemist, ”I recalled that. It was too disjointed, too frightful.”

The Realm Master waved a hand. A servant brought a glass of water to the Alchemist. He gulped it down. He was dripping with perspiration, although he was used to the heat of the dragons and this room was cool in comparison.

“But the realm is not in such danger, or is it?” asked the council member who had first spoken.

“No! No.” The Alchemist shook his large head. “At least not yet. What I had momentarily was the sudden surfacing of an emotional trauma with roots in a distant past. I beg your forgiveness for it, Your Majesty.”

“No need to look so alarmed, Sir,” The Realm Master said. “The council understands. As long as this problem of yours does not interfere with your present operation, disturbing your work.”

Alchemist knew that stress should never be an issue, but to have witnessed such sorrows and not be affected was out of the question. The memories hurt so much…

He relaxed his stance. “I’m only a little jumpy, Sir, informational overload, possibly. Anyhow, I do have an idea.”

“Pray tell.”

The Alchemist thought for a second and pinched at his chin. “Fine,” he said. “This is different from my usual work, but here it is:”

Blood in the air. It does something to people, makes them more desperate, feral, even if they don't recognize the blood for what it is. Warriors become more fearsome adversaries. Merchants haggle cutthroat prices.

And nobles jump for the chance at the throne.

We wait in the throne room, the only room in the old castle large enough to hold all the assembled nobles without smothering them in their unmitigated anticipation. Tables have been arranged against the outer walls, providing refreshments for those who feel peckish and opportunities for political maneuvering for those who possess a different thirst. The throne holds silent court above us all, drawing the desirous gazes of those who for a moment forget that they are supposed to at least pretend they hope the King recovers.

It feels like ages have passed since the news spread throughout the city that the King had been attacked. A midnight assassination attempt, one apparently more successful than most. Now, we wait to hear if the healers at work on the King can save him.

I briefly wonder if I should do something. The assassin escaped -- could he not be in this very room, plotting with the rest of us? And if he was, what could I possibly do about it? I am just a minor noble, the overlooked lord of a small farming hamlet. I'm only here because I was going to beg extra coin from the King's coffers. I certainly wouldn't be able to recognize an assassin if he stared me in the face.

As I head toward one of the refreshment tables to drown my running thoughts of hidden assassins, I hear it. A bell tolling from the castle's belfry, slowly, solemnly.

The nobles stop their chattering and listen, confirming that it is in fact the death knell before becoming more energized. I see a few smiles from nobles who once claimed to be the King's dearest friends. One man begins walking up to the throne, prompting a handful of others to attempt to intercept him. It quickly devolves into a fistfight.

The side doors open, sending a gradual wave of silence across the nobles. A finely-clothed official walks in, carrying a folded black and red silk robe.

He makes his way through the crowd, subtly glowering at those who try to approach him. He stops, not before anyone important, but in front of me. He unfolds the robe and lays it across my shoulders.

I'm too shocked to stop him, but as he pulls away, I grab his hand. "Why me?"

"He named you before he died. He did not have a chance to say why." He pulled his hand out of my grip and stepped back, allowing the others nobles a better view of me while I come to terms with my fate.

I am Tyrl Keravin. I am now the King.

And there's a bloody assassin out there.

“No wait a minute Ser Cleven,” I said putting a stern grip on his arm.

“My Lord?”

“Come with me,” I stepped ahead of him to enter the hall leading to the cells. “Stop! Bring Michael back.”
I stepped back into the Executioner’s Chambers and pulled my sword. The steel sung out. I let the sound pierce the air with no other word. The boots clattered on the broken stones of the Beastmaster’s dungeon, and the clanking of chains and manacles echoed against the ancient stones as the guards returned with the condemned man.

The light in the chamber was ghostly with graying shadows walking across the circular walls. Sinclair, my wise counselor, materialized out of the damp gloom and knelt before me.
“I am glad you have decided to execute justice for the sake of your people my Lord,” Sinclair said, his words falling out on my boots. It was such a soft communication; no one else seemed to hear. “If I may rise King Tyrl, I have something more suitable for this moment.”

“Aye – rise old man – what is this you say?”

The wizard rose and met my gaze with eyes that smoldered, stoked by an inner vow to serve the demons that tormented his soul. His gray beard hung like tangled moss off an old oak. He pressed his crooked body to its full height to stare into my eyes. He huffed as he seemed to find what he was looking for.

“Yes. What I have will be more suitable for swift justice.”

He stepped into the shadows and drug out a sword whose length came to the wizard’s cheek. Its honed steel edges appeared to be on fire as they reflected the dance of flames coming off the torches. Its quillon and pummel sparkled with onyx, emerald and rubies, disclosing the weapon’s royal heritage. Rather than hand the sword to me Sinclair lay it at my feet. Only one other pair of hands had known its killing power. It was more than a gift the old wizard had lowered to the stones in front of me it was a challenge to take the kingdom of the legitimate heirs now dead – all lost except for Lord Kriesmeer’s sword – the dead king’s sword.
Sinclair nodded towards me as though I should know what to do. I stared at the great sword daring my inner strength to come forward to meet this challenge. I knelt down and clasped the handle and tested the weapon’s weight. It felt right. I rose to my feet, my hand directing the sword’s point towards the ceiling as the guard pushed Michael forward. The executioner stepped forward his gaze barely meeting mine. I waited for his eyes to lock on mine.

“You are excused from your duty today, Strok,” I said, bringing the sword to rest by my side. He bowed slightly and stepped to the wall. Sinclair too stepped to the wall as the guards pushed Michael down to rest his head on the oak stump.

I saw Michael’s eyes dart about the room, but he did well at cornering his fear, a warrior accustomed to facing death daily, he became still as I raised the sword above my head. I felt my center giving way at first, and then I was aware I could not focus straight ahead. I took a step back to recover and change my assessment of the sword’s weight. An arrow, from an unseen archer, ripped past where my shoulder had been just a blink of an eye before. As I moved away from the arrow’s path, Michael lashed out at my legs with his chained hands. They caught my boots and footing gave way. I fell into the wall keeping the sword firm in hand and anchored to my front. The next arrow hit the steel blade. It glanced from my sword upward and nicked my right ear. I wanted to clasp my ear with my hand but resisted with all my might every urge to yield to the wound’s demands. I bit back my urge to scream as well. I felt my blood trickle down my neck. At last I saw the archer as his shadow betrayed the swift motion of his setting another arrow. I saw his fingers release the string.

Michael at last found his feet and lunged for my throat. His thick form momentarily blocked my view of the assassin. The arrow struck his heart as it pierced his back. He fell dead at my feet. The guards once too slow to react finally cornered the archer and sliced his throat.

“Here my Lord,” Sinclair said ripping a piece of fabric from one of his inner robes, “let me put this on your ear.” Sir Cleven and Strok helped me to stand.

“Not exactly the moment of justice I had hoped for,” I said grimacing. Pain seared the exposed areas of my wound as the wizard bandaged my ear.

“An archer does not kill a king of his own accord my Lord,” Sinclair said, his eyes so close to mine I could feel the heat in them. “and I doubt that Michael was the leader of this ill-conceived plot to take your life. By that I mean you will have plenty of days to execute justice, my Lord Tyrl, and not just from outside your castle walls.” The wizard pulled away the bloody cloth and pressed it into my hand. “This is the first blood. Your blood. And it is only a trickle because of the sword you now own. And should you wonder to long and too hard, it was the sword that saved your life. It will want for blood soon. Be ye ready?”

While I waited for the noblemen to come to the chamber, I watched a heavily loaded raft, limp up the River Mirsey, against the force of snow melt pushing down stream. A dray horse and an old man latched their lives to the vessel and trudged their way northward towards Bethembly. I wanted to shout at them for employing themselves in such a stupid endeavor, but at the moment my soul was heavily invested in as stupid an endeavor. In reality I should have donned some peasant clothes and yoked myself with them as the sweating trio of fools on the river's path - inch by futile inch.

The noblemen will soon come to tell me that while I am King, I am a vassal. A slave more-or-less, to the house of the Seven. I am a King in name only, and probably this alone by the distinction that my subjects willingly pay all of their taxes to the stronger houses and the nobles have never lifted a finger to intervene. They too feel the sting of the heavy levies placed on us. To which house? It varies. It depends solely on the house that is the strongest at the moment. They become our protector for a while as we feed them beef, venison, mutton and fish with the occasional bounty that comes from our soil.

My simple kingdom of Dimbersmere was never worth conquering, and the "kings" always capitulated and made bargains to keep from being slaughtered. As time went by, many of our citizens grew in their wealth as merchants and craftsmen. While this is a great accomplishment for the people and has won accolades for my hapless predecessor, it has nearly given us a prize status. Too poor we would be left to die - too rich? Could lead to some severe consequences.

The only mystery in the counsel of nobles is what guilds are aligned for autonomy and which ones want to bargain for another alliance. Either way, the price is going to be too high.
Sir Cleven is the first to arrive and I am glad. He comes to the window and chuckles immediately. Ie instantly grasps the significance of the what I see.

"You seem to be back to being your jovial self, my lord," Sir Cleven said.

"It is not every day that one is nearly assassinated while attempting to execute a traitor."

"You did not need to be in harm's way. You could have left Michael in the hands of the executioner."

"That would have been the logical way," I said, leaving the window and taking my seat at the head of the counsel table. "I suppose I had a notion. Foolish I suppose but I wanted to send a message to all traitors in my realm that I would be the one to mete out justice. And I guess by way of defending the realm in this small way I actually felt for a moment like I was king."

"You will have plenty of opportunities for demonstrating your hand of justice. There is a discontent rising between the classes of Dimbersmere. You've heard. You can almost smell it if you can't hear. The poor want a justice that won't come by a sword or any future alliance. Get into the midst of that struggle - that will prove your aptitude to hold the throne."

"Is that your counsel for me today Cleven?"

Cleven only smirked at me and closed his right eye as if to wink, but it was only his quirky way of dealing with his own inability to hold secrets tightly. I knew there was a lot more he was holding back. Not for conspiracy reasons, it was just his way to never tell everything all at once. I would eventually get his full counsel. He would wait until all the nobles had spoken.

The three remaining members of my counsel arrived together. Each of their faces were grey granite, and though never distinguished by fain countenance or handsome features, they were as ugly as death today. I motioned for them to take their seats. All eyes averted meeting other eyes. Throats were cleared as if preparing to speak. Silence.

What I learned at my mother's feet about such moments was that it was a good time to take stock of who was with me. I never pleased her. And tired of constantly scolded me she would instead punish me with long draughts from conversation and a sour face to peer into. This, unfortunately for my mother, whose beauty had faded quickly after I was born, became her method for dealing with everything that perturbed her in life. I found contentment in her grim displays of temperament.

Sir Sladhok at my immediate left hand was most like her. His eyes were red rimmed as though he had been crying for hours. He wore a tunic that bore the colors of his guild of merchants. They were merely butchers, but in a land that doesn't go to war, it gave him a very high rank amongst my other lords. It was the Sladhoks who had discovered Dimbersmere's great gift for growing meat. A burly man who always dressed in black woolen shirt and trousers, felt most at ease when his massive chest and belly were covered by a black leather apron. His gray hair clumped in snake-like coils cascaded down around the ears that formed the most promminate outcrops from this boulder head.

Tome's eyes seemed to focus at last on Sir Nascar Kirwin who seemed oblivious to being the odd man in the bunch. He was the only true nobleman at the table, myself included. His great-grand -father was a Lord in the House Stark. When Dimbersmere became allied with that powerful House, Sir Adele Kirwin was made Lord Protector and First King of Dimbersmere. He was a benevolent king who allowed the Clevens and the Sladhocks to lead their various communities in any direction they pleased. He became a collector and a broker of art and ancient writings. He had recently become a sought after agent for musicians and theater groups.

I let the silence between us grow. I looked hard at each man and Sir Cleven followed my lead. I couldn't help finding a peace in this bit of control I seemed to have over these "lords".

“You have called a counsel Your Majesty, I believe, because the seven houses that have vied for allegiance in the past will once again determine our fate. If you will agree that we are a nation, then I will say those words. They will demand our allegiance once more as a nation.”
Kirwin’s voice was heartier than I could remember, and while taking the long way around to his point, I could bare the weight of his journey. And I did not interrupt.
 

“If you do not disagree, then I will say it more clearly. We are the nation of Dimbersmere. We were formed to live autonomously from all other powers. Our forefathers were hunters and warriors who prepared for the generations to come, a land where we can live in peace and happiness.”
 
Sir Cleven nodded at Tome and Sladhock and they both uttered a sturdy, “aye.” I’m sure my face betrayed by my soul’s appreciation of the comedy that was unfolding before me.
 
“As we know,” Kirwin continued, “Lord Afertyson, has wanted an alliance between his landholdings and our nation. He of course has no more strength against any aggressor than we ourselves possess, however he does have one thing that we do not and that is a powerful alliance with House Lassiter.” Sir Kirwin paused to let this news sink in.
 
The alliance between Lord Afertyson and House Lassiter was well known to me and I’m sure Sladhock, Tome and Cleven had been discussing the worth of such an alliance for some time. But besides holding no love for the other Houses, Lassiter was in no way on common ground with Dimbersmere.
 
As if reading my thoughts Kirwin said, “Lassiter has of course, less favor with the other houses than we do, and they tend to be more accustom to fighting than diplomacy, but they are feared by the other houses because of their violent nature and with some increase in economic fortune they could re-arm themselves and become a powerful protector for both Dimbersmere and Lord Afertyson.”
 
Tome was about to say “aye” when I stood from my chair.
 
“If you are suggesting we try to gain favor with this grissly friend of Lord Afertyson by re-arming them I would bid you consider a different course immediately. They are not a house to be trusted, especially if they are well armed.
 
Tome, his shaggy beard getting grayer by the minute, rolled his saucer eyes and grunted towards the king.

“You needn’t worrby ‘bout does prospects Mi Lord,” he said pushing a cloth against his lips to dry them. “We’ve nuffin Lassiter can use except our food. None of us affordin’ no army now. But they are a feared bunch, I say.”

Sir Kirwin blushed and nodded at Tome. “He is right your Majesty. An able bodied army fully armed is out of our reach…for now.” Naskars eyes widened and seemed to become bluer. What is called for, and is the most important thing I can say to this counsel, is a marriage.”

“A marriage your grace,” Sladhock interrupted, “will help the merchants in every one of the villages. The merchants doing well will help the farmers and hunters and craftsmen to have buyers for their goods.”

As Sir Clemens rose to address me, Sir Kirwin raised a finger and lay it carefully beside his nose. “Pardon me Lord King, for just one moment,” he said, “ Will be right back.”

My hand went involuntarily to my forhead and I rubbed the furrows that were forming without permission from their Lord.

“The proposition is dependent on how badly you want to have a kingdom that will be a legacy for our children,” Sir Cleven began. “You will eventually need a Queen, My Lord or your legacy will die right here and now. Consider a Queen now and all of the possibilities of being in servitude the unholy seven for the next hundred years begin to fade.”
I closed my eyes and took a deep breath. I looked each of my counsel members in the eye. Tome’s black saucers seemed sympathetic and warm. Sladhock’s eyes were steely and gray and narrowed. Cleven’s were smiling and jittery. He blinked several times and I felt the smirk underneath his gaze that challenged mine.

The door burst open and Sir Kirwin led two servants into the counsel chamber carrying a large picture covered with a black curtain. Another servant came in with an easel and the picture was put on display before the counsel.

“This is a gift your Majesty,” Sir Kirwin said, laying a hand on one of the lower corners of the curtain. “Behold – the dutchess of Afertyson.” Naskar’s hand swept the corner of the curtain upward and over the picture frame revealing the newly created painting of Lydia Aftertyson.

For a moment my breathing stopped as my heart pushed upwards past my throat. All the air around me was alive with the heavy sighs of men longing to be young again.
