1411112.title: The Counsel Hears from Sir Nascar Kirwin

14111121.content:
Her eyes locked on mine. A soft violet, the painter had captured within those eyes some tremendous luminous magic that made them sparkle. Her full lips were those of a child. Like rose petals responding to the sun, they parted slightly into a smile, gracious and alluring. Her face was round framed in long dark waves of hair of silk and burgundy wine.
 
I felt drawn to reach out for the image before me. I could have sworn some magic spell had been cast on the picture to entice men from their sanity. I was aware that even Sir Cleven was stunned by what the artist had captured on the canvas, though I had the feeling that he had probably seen it before.
 
Lydia had posed for the painting in a sitting position and her slender arms, delicate and white were bare. Here figure was enhanced by a blue velvet dress that gave the painter inspiration to focus on the flesh of her bosom that pressed upwards into full view above the tight bodice.
In her elegant hands she held a pure white Persian cat that was obviously content to live on Lydia’s lap.

Aware of the long moments of silence, Sir Kirwin broke into my fantasy.

“She has her mother’s beauty and her father’s quiet demeanor. Beautiful isn’t she? The painter, Laoudra, has captured her perfectly, though there is no way he could fully appreciate the Lady’s charm.”
 
“She’s a fine girl,” was all that Sladhock could say.
 
“Makes me wish I were the king,” said Tome.

“There is more your Majesty,” Sir Kirwin said laying a soft hand on the shoulder of one of the servants. “Bring in the next.”
 
Sir Cleven, smiled and turned towards me. His eyes were dancing in a way that I had never seen before and I now knew that he was more invested in this presentation than how he had at first tried to appear.

Sladhock’s paunch pressed hard against the wood table as he strained to see more of the girl in the painting. Lydia. What he was searching for I could not fathom, but the spectacle of a market ruffian being effected by the sight of pure, innocent beauty was amusing.
 
“As you know Sire,” Kirwin continued, “Lord Afertyson’s daughter is an accomplished rider and horse trainer. She is a brilliant manager of her own household though she is only,..”
 
“Fourteen?” I interrupted, remembering all to well the twelve year old Lydia and her ponies.

“I was going to say 16, MiLord. Seventeen in three days actually.”
 
“I think you are mistaken,” I said regaining my composure from my unfortunate outward display of lust and desire,” It was only two years ago that I visited Aftertyson. And she was helping her mother make preparations for the Solstice Celebration.”

“Weren’t you at Aftertyson at that time?” Cleven asked Sir Kirwin.

“Yes I was Sir, and Lydia had turned fourteen that summer. It has been nearly three years and not two and when you see these…Ah yes lads put those pictures there and help me mount the next one,” Kirwin directed the servants.
 
“I think you’ll see King Keravin,” Tome said, “That she is more than a pawn in a scheme of alliance. But truly a prize for the sake of the people of Dimbersmere. She will become a source of goodwill from your throne to your beloved subjects. I don’t know that a king could ask for more than that.”
 
“Perhaps, but that will be little solace when we are overrun by Stark and Baratheon pagans taking their taxes out of our flesh as well as our treasuries.”

“Look!” Tome cried, as the next painting of Lydia was unveiled.

I could not contain my gasp.

“Ummm, uhumm, ummm, uhumm,” Sladhock hummed his jowls loosening up as he took a drink from a jug that appeared from nowhere.
The painting was of the Merlot haired Lydia, straddling a war saddle on a ebony colored charger. The thin mail links of gold glittered from the round tip of her chin over the thin garment that covered her chest. Her healthy woman’s figure was probably exaggerated by the artist, but the obvious power of Lydia’s slight frame was reverberating off the canvas into my soul. Her violet eyes were fierce as she contemplated some enemy of Aftertyson. The short sword in her child like hand was ready to be swung.

I was charmed and amused by the painting that I supposed was to superimpose itself over my doubts of surviving what Stark would consider a “suppression-of-a-Dmbersmere-rebellion.” Why Aftertyson would give his daughter a certain death sentence troubled me. Why my counselors expected me to enter into such a rebellious liaison seemed nearly treasonous. Which one of them would benefit the most from my execution I wondered?

Sir Clevens moved from his position next to me to stand before the painting. “She may not be a true warrior,” he declared, “But look at how she could be the symbol of freedom and liberty for your people. Lydia the Hope of Dimbersmere.”

“Aye,” signified Sladhock, “A vangord for justyce she be like!”

Sir Kirwin clapped his hands and pointed to the next painting. The servants quickly covered “Lydia the Vanguard” and set the next piece in place.

Sir Kirwin’s hand toyed with the edge of the curtain a moment. “Before I remove the cover on this next image of your queen, your Majesty, I just want to prepare you for the exquisite representation of heavenly womanhood that is revealed in it. The paint fades away quickly so watch over your heart with due diligence.”

Before I could attack Kirwin’s disregard for my position, he lifted the curtain up and away from the easel. I blinked back a sudden surge of something moist within my eyes and grasped my chair. I knew my knuckles would be white, but I didn’t care. No one could see me grasping for control.

“O mi sweet mother...,” Sladhock groaned.

I felt Cleven’s eyes on me, burning through my heated face. As I met the pretty girl’s gaze I knew instantly that Cleven dare not look at the goddess immortalized on the canvas.

She was painted into a scene from one of my childhood fantasy picture books where fairies and pixies fluttered about in serene woodlands. In the scene painted before me the fantasy creatures were all around Lydia who sparkled with their own divine light. Lydia’s hair was laced with red and yellow flowers and her eyes carried a sultry message that aroused my desire for her. She had engaged the help of the woodland creatures to prepare for a bath in a mystical pool, shimmering with ethereal light. The forest trees blazed with the cranberry, apricot, and squash colors of autumn.

But it was Lydia’s white - lily white - face, arms, neck and shoulders that grabbed my eyes, as the crimson robe appeared to be slipping away. It was some helpful imps prancing about the hem of her garment who appeared to be her genteel valets. A kiss was forming on her lips and I was suddenly ashamed that I was viewing her in such an intimate setting, especially with the crude louts who were my counselors.

“That’s enough Kirwin. Cover her up!”

Kirwin bowed slightly and motioned for the servants to remove the painting.

14111121.title: I Am Taken With Lydia's Beauty

141111211.content:
My head was bowed to my chest in deep meditation as I cooled the desire that had burned in my chest. But there was no way to erase the image of the young Lady of Aftertyson preparing to disrobe. I wanted to end this meeting. Perhaps all meetings with these Dimbersmere rogues.

“There is one more painting, your grace,” Sir Cleven said. He paused, letting his words sink into my troubled heart. I even heard what sounded to be a dare in his voice.

“There is a song as well,” Kirwin said, and with those words a minstrel walked into the middle of the counsel chamber carrying a lute, a scroll and an unlit candle. He was dressed in black leather pants with a white linen shirt with puffed out sleeves. He wore a flat leather beret with an orange feather two feet long jetting out from one side.

Tome and Sladhock chuckled, but pushed their amusement back when Sir Kirwin cut them a stern look shaking his head. My mood was growing more sullen by the moment and I could not reason why I had tolerated this show thus far.
The minstrel began plucking the strings in a soothing manner as Tome lit the candle. The air was immediately filled with the smell of lilac and roses as the flame touched off bits of scented wax. I closed my eyes and let the melody and fragrances flow over me. I sensed that my demons were making peace within me and in a moment this odd assault on my newly acquired throne would soon become history. I looked forward to going back to my private chambers and contemplate how I could curry the favor of the houses who protected Dimbersmere. And do it all without upsetting our friend Lord Aftertyson.

“It is alright Rodney,” Sir Kirwin said, speaking to the minstrel, “Sing Lydia’s song for the King.”

Rodney rolled open the scroll so that he could read the words.

The minstrel’s voice opened softly. His voice was full, and strong, but kept light with a breathy restraint.

“I am a foundling,
But I am yours, my Lord,
I have prepared myself for you
All my love, all my heart,
All my soul are yours
Please say you will love me too.
Please say that you will love me too.”

I nodded along with the melody, entranced by the words and their message of love.

As Rodney began to repeat Lydia’s beautiful refrain, I slowly opened my eyes. Except for the minstrel I found myself alone with another extraordinary painting of her. My intended. My betrothed.

I could now discern the difference in an artist’s style. An artist’s view. I rose from my throne to get closer to the child’s image, as her song continued to grow in the chamber and in my heart.
Rodney began a verse,

My hope you are
My life will be
Forever yours
Til Eternity
Give me a throne
And love me until
Every ligt is all gone
And our heartbeat is still”

As he began the refrain I knelt before Lydia’s picture and drank in her glorious sensual youth, her peculiar fidelity and her endless vitality. “You are an amazing girl,” I said in a whisper. My soul ached to touch her. Oh how darling and sweet she appeared to be. I wondered about the artist who painted this work. Blumethal was his name and he captured a part of Lydia that drew me to her yet in other ways.

Unlike the other paintings the background on this one was opaque, suggesting people and things were present, but they were in a light that caused everything and everyone to fade away except for her. Eyes closed, her black eyelashes laced her cheeks and seemed to flutter a bit with each strum of the lute. In the curve of her delicate arm was a golden harp that she strummed casually with her slim fingers. Her dainty lips were parted to let the words of her song meld with that of the cardinals and robins gathered around her delicate feet. Her feet were bare and in every possible way they were

I blinked my eyes hard to clear the brine that washed across them. I fought the tears that begged to be released. “You poor child. What…who, could bring you to this sad end? You are too fair and pure to end your brief life in such a grievous way. Lydia, Lydia, Lydia, you speak of love like a romantic babe, as though you know me, but you do not. There are demons within me that would cause your love to soon turn bitter and cold. I could worship you – you probably know that. I could even make you my most prized possession. But you see my poor little dear - you would wither and become a river of scorn before I could ever love you the way you profess to love me.”

“Marriage would only be a curse, sweet Lydia…only a curse.”

The music stopped and the flame of the candle was snuffed out. The scent of roses and lilacs was replaced by that of burnt iron and coal. I heard the scroll roll up. I buried my face in my hands as the minstrel left the room.

I allowed the tears to splash to the rocks and wept for the destiny that was before me. I was afraid to die. Perhaps because I had never really lived. My bravado at being able to take the life of an accused traitor was long gone. I shivered to think that the arrow that was meant for me had imbedded itself in his heart. I unconsciously rubbed the arrow wound on my thigh and brought to full light within my soul what it would mean to die. The end. Even to die for a noble cause. Death was final. No negotiation for more breaths, more sunlight, kisses or love. Death was the end of all things. I was too much of a coward to face death. "To much of a coward to love you my dear sweet child."

I raised my burnt eyes once more to Lydia’s serene face. Pity the child. Pity the father who sells her so cheaply. She would be better spent given to a nobleman of a lesser house than the fool king of Dimbersmere.

choices: My Bride Is Dressed In White
1411112111.content:
“You can be a fool if you wish King Keravin you yourself are no more than a boy child.”
 
I had forgotten I was not in my private chambers. I remained in my bowed position hoping the owner of the voice bouncing off the walls would grow weary of my non-response and go away.
 
“Lydia, has depth of character that you would never comprehend. I do not know if she is afraid of dying, but she certainly is not afraid of life. Perhaps a king could have a wife whose knowledge goes beyond privilege and power and court. You have had just a few days to rule your people. How does it feel? Are you as much a King as Lydia is a Queen?”
Without looking up I knew I was addressing Lord Aftertyson.
 
“So you would give up your daughter even though she will die a martyr’s death?” I raised my eyes to once more look at ….’s painting. I staggered a step on my weakened leg as I stood to my feet. I lowered the black curtain over Lydia’s image. “What has my court promised you in return for making her Queen of Dimbersmere?”
 
My eyes still burned but I turned them on Aftertyson. His head appeared to be that of an ancient tiger. Two scars formed an “x” between his eyebrows. The left eye seemed lazy and that same side of his face was sliding. His mouth drooped a bit as well, giving the aging tiger a place to rest his tongue when he was not speaking.
 
His clothes were laced with gold and silver brocade and accented with gold trim. His boots were polished black leather that reflected what meager light remained in the counsel chambers.
In his left hand was a black walnut walking stick, the knots of which protruded in every direction. No doubt it served double duty as a weapon. It was certainly better than a club and served the purpose of a cane very well.

“In my house, a female of 15 is still a girl. At sixteen she is a woman. At seventeen she is a Lady. Lady Lydia has been running my household since she was fourteen and has hosted most of the wealthy lords of all the houses in this part of the world. I have received eight marriage proposals and one bonafide job offer for her to be made the Dutchess of some independent state far, far away to the south. I’m not exactly sure why, your grace, but she wants only you. Apparently you had some effect on her on your visit to Aftertyson.”
 
“You approve of her choice?” I asked, preparing to hear a deliberate annihilation of my character.
“Perhaps I should second guess my original enthusiasm, but you have just survived an assignation attempt and your counsel was none too subtle in their pushing Lydia on to you, but it was I who commissioned the paintings, chose the scenes, and promised you to my daughter. Perhaps once you have a daughter of your own, you will understand the devotion of a child and the desire to give her everything she wants.”
I knew I was smirking at the poor man. What a fool.
 
“Perhaps you should consider accepting another of those proposals. Dimbersmere, if I follow the brilliant counsel of my learned Lords, will soon be crushed under the hooves of a thousand war horses. I see ruble and destruction ahead. And whatever my court has promised you I assure you it won’t be worth the price.”
 
Aftertyson laughed. It was a roar that came from out of a cavernous place.
 
“All I asked for was that I might be given a home here, preferably over- looking the river. Your Lord Sladhock has in fact given me his villa that is in the shadow of the south end of your castle. I want to be close to my daughter and my grandchildren when they come.”
 
It was obvious Aftertyson was out of his mind.
 
“So my Lord, will you make a marriage? Will your nation be bound to my meager estate and my fortunes? I offer you my most cherished posseion – my daughter and with her a possible peace with your enemies for a hundred years.”
 
I studied Aftertyson. Could madmen be so sincere that one would slip into their fantasy? Why were his words drawing me away from my resolve? I must ignore my counselors and broker a sepearte agreement with the house Lassiter. I knew it in my bones. And yet?
 
“Where is Lydia now Aftertyson?”
 
“She is probably at this moment a day or so away. She is on a barge coming up the river Mirsey. I prefer she have the comforts of home whenever she travels. She loves the river. She will arrive with her entourage tomorrow afternoon.”
 
I could have run him through with my blood thirsty sword for the insolent smirk that was crossing his tiger-face.
 
“So you have presumed that I will meet your Lydia, fall under her spell and marry her. Your presumptions would be enough to say no to your proposals. And no amount of engagement with your fair daughter will change my mind.”
 
Again, Aftertyson roared. His whole body shook. I felt the disdain and pity radiating from every part of his being.
 
“There will be no engagement King Keravin. As I have told your counsel. Your court. There be no engagement formalities. I have given you all I will give. You have the proof you of Lydia’s charm in song and art. Is that not more than enough? As this throne of yours is my witness, what you have of her thus far is all you will know of her before the wedding. If you agree to this alliance you will marry her on the day she sets foot on Dimbersmere soil. If you do not marry her on that day, I will indeed leave you to a fate before your enemies.”
 
“You are insane, Aftetyson!”
 
The tiger face softened and it appeared the old lord was about to burst into tears. He leaned hard on his walking stick and shook his head, as if to fall down dead before me.
 
“Aye - Believe me, I would prefer that she take any of the other proposals. So, yes I am insane. But I will give her what she wants. And because she wants a King in one of the most vulnerable pieces of land in the world, I will find some way to save you so that she does not perish. You have the word of a madman on that score. Just marry the girl. Then I’d say you will have saved your pitiful little nation and no one will ever know what a coward you truly are.”

The words stung deep and I began to forget the notion of being a king. I had not had the throne long enough to appreciate my powers and authority. I was not prone to do anything but yield. Yield to my court, yield to my meager alliances. Announce my pending marriage day after tomorrow and lose my life and yet live it. For that’s what a marriage to a Queen would mean wouldn’t it? Lose my life. Would I not be better served if I were run through with a sword? My subjects would not save me from this fate as most of Dimbersmere did not even know I was their king. Even if they knew, the fools would only rejoice that their monarch had found love. Divine love.

“So. King of Dimbersmere. What will it be?”

I limped back to my throne and eased my self onto the fringed cushions, pushing my weight back hard to suppress more of the ire rising up from my wounded soul. I stared at my adversary considering everything that had occurred in the last hour and put on as noble a countenance as I could conjur up.

“I would prefer to announce my decision with my counsel present as witnesses. As your co-conspirators in this ambush, they should at least be present for my verdict.”
Lord Aftertyson’s usual roar was stifled and came out as a lame chuckle as he rolled his eyes.

“Verdict milord?”

I pointed to the door and waved at him, the fires of rage well stoked to this point melted the last of my patience.

“Go! Go get your accomplices and return with them – and please – take your time. I will announce my decision when you return. Now get out!”

choices: Presenting The King and Queen of Dimbersmere
14111121111.content:
“Lydia is dressed in her wedding gown, your majesty,” Sir Kirwin said.
 
I had been staring at the bride’s barge below for and an hour, wondering what kind of girl she was. Who was the girl I was actually going to make my queen. An artist could have easily falsified her beauty or exaggerated it in any number of ways. Though there had four different artists, so it wouldn’t be likely that they were all hired to deceive me. She was probably just as beautiful as her portraits indicated her to be.
 
“I have your wedding clothes prepared,” Kirwin said, “and your valet will be here in just a few minutes to help you into them. I think you will be pleased at how regal you will look. And this…”
 
I turned to see that Kirwin as holding a new crown. I had several, most of them plated with gold, but I found myself drawn to this one.
 
“The counsel had this one especially made for you,” he said. The light from the southern windows made the large opal, set boldly in the front, shimmer. As I moved to examine it more closely I could see that there were horses etched into and all around the crown. Their slihouettes were formed by hundreds of diamond chips. They glittered and sparkled with a kind of magic that I found pleasing, though I could not imagine why.
 
“The future queen has been given a similar crown as a gift from you,” Sir Kirwin said. “It conveys your love for her in a most practical way, don’t you think?”
 
“Look Sir Kirwin,” I said, “How I feel at this moment is not the business of you or my counsel or the people of Dimbersmere. This a marriage to consummate a dubious alliance and probably put an end to our nation as we know it, so while I will put up with the counsel’s interference to my life’s plan, what I think about gifts, brides, crowns and new clothes will remain my own last secret concerns.”
 
“Where is my sword by the way?”
 
“Your valet’s have it, your grace,” Kirwin said. “And here they are now.”
Sars, my valet entered my chambers leading three other men dressed in the uniform of Dimbersmere royal service. I did not recognize the other three and took it to mean that the counsel had been hiring new staff to accommodate the future queen and her entourage.
Sars carried in my wedding garb, another was assigned my shoes, another my belts and the last carried in my sword.
 
They all bowed before me and waited for Sars to speak.
 
“May we attire you my King?” Sars asked.
 
I nodded my assent and took a seat on the red velvet cushion that topped the cedar chest at the foot of my bed. The valet assigned my boots jumped to my feet and tugged each boot off, laying a towel over the granite floor so that my stockinged feet would be cushioned from the rock.
 
My day to day garb was removed and my new clothes were methodically put on me. I sat for the highly polished boots to be installed on my feet and when I stood, a valet stood on the cedar chest and draped a scarlet cape over my shoulders. Sars jumped up on the other side of the chest and placed the crown on my head.
 
Sir Kirwin clapped his hands and I felt the frown for my face bend part of my jaw.
 
“Your Majesty looks absolutely handsome and regal this special day.” He bowed low then snapped his fingers. Sars and the valets bolted from the room leaving the sword in Kirwin’s hands.
 
“Surely you won’t need this weapon on your wedding day sire. May I put it with the other weapons in the hall?”
 
“No,” I said. I will take it with me to the barge and leave it with one of my guards, but I do not want it far from me today.”
 
Whatever confidence I had given to Sir Kirwin was now gone. I did not want to give him any more fuel for thinking I was coming unglued. But the fact was that there was an entity still at work that wanted my life. My guards, when they were conscious were able to put down any kind of demonstration, but a skilled assassin would be no match for their lethargic methods for keeping me safe. But I didn’t want the overreaction of the counsel that would have sent another hundred guards to surround the wedding party.
 
“May I lead the way then milord? If you are ready.”
 
We walked through the passage ways of my wing of the castle down into the lower court yard. My horse was prepared and I climbed up the ramp to mount so that I could master the long sword, my lack of mobility because of the arrow wound in my left thigh and my lack of enthusiasm. I heard the snickering from some of the stable boys, but at this point I didn’t care. It was four miles down to the river Mirsey and I wasn’t about to walk that distance.
 
At the moored barge of my bride to be, my guards assembled around the entire landing. As I had feared, many more guards had been added to my entourage. I eyed all of them carefully, not at all sure that one of them, might be the one to make the next assassination attempt.
 
The ride had caused my wounded leg to throb and I could see dismounting my horse with no platform was going to be difficult. I handed my sword to one of the guards.
 
“Please take care of that until after the ceremony,” I said.
 
“Yes. Of course your majesty.”
 
I slid off my horse and as my feet touched the ground searing pain sliced through my thigh. I grimaced and shook as tears tried to fill my eyes.
Sir Tome and Sir Cleven were suddenly at my side but waited to touch me.
 
“Are you all right King Keravin?” Tome asked.
 
"Yes, of course I am just fine,” I said, “But please help me when we step aboard the barge.”
 
The place the Aftertyson barge had moored was surrounded by towering maples and sycamore trees aflame with the radiant colors – orange, yellow and reds – of autumn. The evergreens, pine, fir and cedar added a depth of green up and down the river Mirsey from Dimbersmere Landing.
 
An organ played from somewhere deep inside the barge and Lydia’s members of the wedding marched onto a platform that overlooked the river. My party included Cleven and his wife, Sir Sladhock, Lady and Knight Kirwin and Sir Tome and his wife and two older daughters. I followed them up the platform to the arbor that formed the groom’s side of the makeshift chapel.
 
There were few guests. Mostly Aftertyson and family. The people of Dimbersmere would be informed of the marriage later and a possible re-enactment of the solemn ceremony would probably occur later for their benefit.
 
The music grew louder as the doors that contained the sound were thrown open. Lydia floated in on the trumpeted notes, her delicate feet gliding along the deck. She was dressed in a white gown, with a heavy white veil over her face. In her hands was lain was a bouquet made up of six hydrangea blossoms of white, pink and purple. I tried to capture this serene moment in my mind so that if I should become an artist someday, I would be able to recreate the moment on a canvas. Lydia was perfect adorned in her white wedding gown.
 
As the music faded away and I stood shoulder to shoulder with the new love of my life, the official of the wedding began.
 
“Who gives this woman to be married to this man?”

141111211112.content:
A servant bowed low and offered up a red velvet pillow. In the middle of the pillow was a simple gold band. I placed it on Lydia’s finger while her eyes stared at me. In moments the official took us through the contractual agreements of our pledge and vows until with both said our “I do’s”.
 
“I now prounouce you husband and wife,” the official said. “You may kiss the bride.”
 
The kiss. It was all too fast. The vows, the ring, the future the past. A marriage, a queen. What was next cohabitation, children, bondage – forever? But a kiss.
 
Her violet eyes, velvet smoke, softened and seemed to fill with tears. Her lips were parting and she leaned towards me, giving me the sense that her love was mine forever with just one kiss.
 
I placed my arms around her and I could feel for the first time her strength and power. She was not at all as delicate as she had appeared in the paintings. But everything about her was firm and full. My lips finally touched hers and she pressed into me so that I could feel all of her body. The kiss was warm, sweet and inviting. I felt the warrior in me at last surrender.
 
“Members of the wedding,” the official said, “Presenting the King and Queen of Dimbersmere.” The barge rattled with the stomping of feet, applause and a band of fiddlers. Seven flaming arrows went up high over the river and moments later the bells of the Dimbersmere chapel were ringing, clanging out the message that a marriage had taken place. Messengers would soon be every where in the land announcing to the citizens of my kingdom that they were blessed with a new queen. Queen Lydia of Aftertyson would soon be a beloved symbol of peace and tranquility throughout my realm and over night my success as a king would be assured.
 
Lord Aftertyson was the first to come and bow before us.
 
“Your grace,” he said to me turning immediately to his daughter, “your majesty, may your lives together prosper and your reign last a thousand years.”
 
“Thank you father,” Lydia said, and her hand reached out in one of the most regal poses I had ever seen. Aftertyson took her hand and kissed it lightly. He turned to me and pushed me along the ramp to shore, while Lydia struggled with her dress’ train. It appeared to anchor her to the ramp.
 
“Congratulations King Keravin. You have made an excellent marriage. Now if you will excuse me, my lands require my immediate attention.”
 
I looked hard at Aftertyson. He appeared to me more calm, relaxed and at peace than I had ever seen him.
 
“Thank you for your kindness and counsel, Sir Aftertyson,” I said, “but won’t you please stay for the celebration. Your south Dimbersmere villa is all prepared for you and your party. Anything that is lacking I’m sure we can immediately remedy. Do please stay.” Afteryson managed to smile as he blushed and coughed back a bit of a laugh.
 
I felt the tension rise up in Lydia though she was now standing several feet away working with some ladies to free her train from the barges’ ramp. Her hands worked the fabric with such ferocity that I wasn’t sure her anger was because of the dress or something that had been said.
 
“Please don’t misunderstand my urgent need to return to my holdings. It will take me three days by carriage and I am already negligent in overseeing the harvest and making sure my workers are compensated. You and Lydia have a new life together that should not be influenced by my presence, and it would be better for both you and my daughter to have as much time together as possible, especially the next few months.”
 
I offered my hand to my father-in-law and he grasped it firmly. His carriage pulled alongside us and with no further farewell, he was gone.
 
I could hear Lydia’s sigh as the carriage vanished, and watched as she motioned to the guard who was holding my sword. He drew near to his Queen bowing occasionally as he approached her.
 
“Yes your Majesty?” he said.
 
“Give me that thing,” she said pointing to the sword.
 
He handed it to her hilt first and she swooped it up as if it were made of tin. “Stand back,” she ordered the ladies attending her train. As they did she stabbed twice at the cloth imbedding the sword in the planking of the ramp. She pulled her dress onto the razor edge of the sword and slowly turned causing the blade to slice the ivory white satin cloth of her dress. As the train and dress fell away it became clear that underneath she wore a pair of leather riding breeches and black leather boots. Her footwear covered her legs up to her knees and clearly two inches of her height came from the sharp heels of her boots.
 
She strode through the ranks of guards who were still mounted on their horses until she came to an animal that seemed to please her. She turned to me and batted her eyelashes, her pretty face lit up like that of a precocious child.
 
“May I have this one, MiLord?”
 
The guard looked at me dumbfounded by the Queens request.
 
I pointed to him.
 
“Get down off of your Queen’s horse,” I commanded.
 
I thought for a moment the poor man was going to cry as he slid off of his mount. He lingered a moment hugging the animal’s neck. I couldn’t believe it true, but it seemed the poor horse was about to cry as well. He nuzzled a farewell into his former owner’s side.
 
Lydia ignored the tender moment she bounded into the saddle with one leap. As she yanked the horses head to attention she drove her boot heals hard into its flanks. The horse bolted through the crowd of guards and members of the wedding sending men and women sprawling to the turf. The laugh from my bride as the horse flew across the meadow towards the south end of Dimbersmere Castle, sent a chill down my spine.
 
The heartsick guard approached me humbly and in a barely audible voice he said,
“She’s an amazing horsewoman your Majesty. I am glad that mihorse Misty
Is now hers.”
 
I nodded to the poor man. “Never mind all that now. We’ll get you another horse, even better than your Misty. In fact you keep a look out and let Sir Tome know the one you choose and I will make sure that it is yours.”
 
People began to crowd around me their eyes wide with wonder in the wake of my Queen’s unexpected departure. They opened a walk way to the gangplank of the barge. I stiffened my spine and strode to the planks to retrieve my sword. I secretly cursed Lord Aftertyson and contemplated putting an end to the day’s celebrations. My subjects, pitiful in so many ways, needed this celebration. It would be a time to toast the monarchy, as unstable as it was, and a time to find a reason to be proud to be a citizen of such a glorious kingdom as Dimbersmere, even if that was a dream.
 
I turned to go back to my horse only to discover that I was elevated enough to be able to see the entire congregation before me and that I had their complete attention. It seemed and appropriate time to make a proclamation.
 
“Dearest citizens of Dimbersmere, on this grand and glorious day, may I invite you to proceed to the celebration of our new Queen – Queen Lydia Keravin. I am sure she will join in the celebration when she returns from trying the wedding present I have given her. Please eat, drink and have a merry time. I will join you in a few moments.”
 
There were cheers from the wedding party and the crowd of people laughing and smiling ambled towards the tents. During the disbursal Sir Kirwin and Sir Sladhock rushed to my side completely disregarding protocol they were each pressed in close to me to whisper their concerns.
 
“All of our guards along the roadways have not seen her,” Sir Kirwin began. “Everyone has reported in to my messengers.”
 
“Ab yo ideas wher she’d be?” Sladhock hissed.
 
I shook my head no, but of course if she had not been spotted on any of the roads in and out of the Dimbersmere Castle, then there was only one place to the south of here where she could be.

choices: Lydia Becomes The Lady of South Dimbersmere
1411112111123.content:
By the last mile to the Aftertyson villa, the drama that was the last two hours replayed miserably in my head. I heard the cheers as the celebration was announced, the looks of utter disappointment, as I entered the celebration on my own. I plastered a look of happiness on my face and tried to enjoy a dance and then a toast to the King and Queen and then finally an exit, a half hour ordeal perpetuated by well-wishers and panderers.
 
I had not rode my horse more than a mile in over a month, not withstanding the short ride that morning. I felt every movement of my mount below me and though he was pressing to break into a full gallop I was not confident enough to do more than a frantic saunter.
 
At the livery behind the villa, I left my horse with the stable boy who was still working with Lydia’s horse. I limped towards the main house and was greeted at the door by a footman I had never seen before and then a maid, who was a surprise to me as well. They nearly fell to the floor trying to bow sufficiently, obviously not schooled in the fine art of serving royalty.
 
“Are you in service to Queen Lydia?” I asked.
 
“Yes your grace,” answered the maid.
 
“Well it is not necessary to observe the customs afforded royalty while you are in service here. Do your assigned tasks, speak only when spoken too and we will get along famously. Do you understand?”
 
They nodded and bowed only slightly and made their exit.
 
I entered what I thought would be Lord Aftertyson’s parlor to find my bride lounging in front of the massive stone hearth. Her hair shone brightly with a recent brushing and she had changed into a loose fitting green satin gown. She hummed a tune as she gazed into the flames.
 
“You disappointed a lot of people this morning Lydia?” I said. “As the newly anointed Queen of Dimbersmere the members of your court wanted to have a first glimpse, before they share you with your subjects at large.”
 
She did not look my way. Two fingers found a lock of her burgundy colored hair and slowly twisted the strands.
 
“Did I disappoint you too my King?” she asked her voice much deeper and more sensuous than I would have expected. She turned towards me her eyes a violet dance filled with mischief.
 
I bowed my head not wanting to draw near. It seemed that rejection was close at hand and I could not bear to be discover how much I disgusted her.
 
“No my queen. I don’t believe you could ever disappoint me. Perhaps though you could tell me why you are here and not at your celebration.”
 
“Look at you,” Lydia teased, “You are disappointed in me. Well really…umh what should I call you? Tyrl is not a good name for you. Keravin might be too much. You are cute, for a king, maybe we should think of some pet names.”
 
She pouted a bit with a pleasant blush covering her face. The pinky of her right hand traced a portion of her lower lip. I felt seduced and yet sure she had no idea what she was doing. Her eyebrow furrowed. Flexed. She smiled at me at last and went on.
 
“Anyway King Cutie,…oh that is awful, we’ll work on that. You know I love my barge. I’m sure Aftertyson told you, but it was three days of nothing but that barge. I had enough confinement to last a life time. Don’t get me wrong, I know it was rude and ill mannered to take that poor man’s horse, but the thought of being a hostage to a bunch of gawkers was more than I could stand.”
 
And there she was. The beautiful Lydia of the paintings. Soft, endearing, fully woman, enchanting little girl.
 
“I am glad we are married, darling…oh my goodness, that will never do. It’s funny I didn’t think of what to call you the whole time we were engaged. You honestly don’t look like a Tyrl, what was it I called you when you came to visit that time?”
 
I remembered her name for me perfectly, but I hated to remind her. It seemed an ancient moment when I was not charmed by her, but spent my visit at Aftertyson avoiding her. I could feel her eyes on me, but rather than look at her I gazed at the flame behind her letting my disinterest in this conversation be apparent. She lifted her arm from the velvet sofa using her hand to beckon my response.
 
“Prince Rude,” I said.
 
“Oh mercy, yes…” her laugh was warm and invited me to laugh with her. There was a growl rising in my throat instead. She was going to say it and I knew was coming. Not malicious as back then but filled with something I had never seen in a woman before.
 
“That is it. Prince Rudy. And because we couldn’t say it fast enough it was shortened to Prudy. Even Aftertyson thought that was funny, so we kept it up because it made that poor man laugh so much. Prudy, Prudy – why are you so rudy?” The prickles started from my shoulders and went to my legs. I wanted to itch them and yet show my careless concern for her immaturity. Still, hearing her rich contralto sing the song was not unpleasant. But I needed to make her silly game end.
 
“Now are you disappointed in your bride my Lord?”
 
I shook my head and walked to the chair by the hearth. “No of course not Lydia,” I lied. “Why don’t you just call me Ty?”
 
“Ty love? Love – that’s nice isn’t it? It sounds so hopeful. I know you don’t love me now, but I will eventually win your love. I know you are drawn to me like all the men of this world. Even Aftertyson grew to love me after a while. You’ll see. My love will become your love and eventually we’ll have a family. A family of love.”
 
She stood at the foot of the hearth and looked down at me. Without the boots on I now saw that she could not have been more than five three or five four. The gown she wore was loose enough to hide her figure, but I was now fully aware that it was not possible for her to be nearly eighteen. She was still a little girl.
 
“You remember when we found out you could play the piano forte, but you wouldn’t do it for us? That Sir Kirwin who is always hanging around told us that you played beautifully and could read the music we had. But would you help us do our song for the harvest celebration?”
 
“No. You kept saying you forgot how to play. That’s when we started calling you old old Prudy.” She closed her eyes and for the moment seemed sad. I didn’t remember the incident, although I remembered the children calling me old, old Prudy. Why would she want to tell him about something so sad?
 
“I wasn’t that old,” I said.
 
“You were twenty-seven. Not old for a man of the court I suppose. Old for the farmers and the knights and the politicians Aftertyson wanted me to marry.”
 
“You were just a child then, everyone must have appeared to be old to you.” I waited. I am sure she had no guile or shame or cunning. She would say it.
 
“I was thirteen,” she said and then bit her lip. I nodded my agreement letting her know I knew the truth.
 
“And that was three years ago, wasn’t it Lydia?”
 
“It could have been I suppose.” her gaze was half playful – half serious. What was I to do with a child bride. She would be sixteen in what? Twelve days. Sixteen. I was thirty and growing older minute by miserable minute.
 
“So what did you get me for a wedding present? I hear that in Dimbersmere it is customary for the groom to give his bride something special. A treasure.”
 
"I did give you a very valuable horse. He was certainly treasured"
 
“Oh that. I would not want to keep that poor man’s horse. No matter what you give him in return it would never be enough to make up for the loss of his dearest friend. Besides I chose that as a momentary prize. Surely you must have scoured your entire kingdom to acquire for me an everlasting treasure to cherish the rest of our days together. Something that would declare your undying devotion to me”
 
Whatever my feelings for Lydia before this moment, I began to know of her true worth in this precious moment before the fire. No matter what game, plot or political expediency drew her into this odd relationship with a strange man, she was a virtuous child, acting on behalf of a family she obviously was loyal too. Why else would she be here – so vulnerable? I smiled at the thought of giving her something special. It certainly would the first step in let her understand my appreciation for her.

14111121111232.content:
I had not prepared a gift for my bride, wrestling as I had with the whole notion of marrying Lydia. I had three days. I had in that time seventy hours of wresting with all the ideas around marriage to her and two hours to pick out a gift. I was not bound by tradition of course, but she was of an age when a gift was actually the perfect bridge between the two islands we were in this arranged marriage. I admired her calm with me. If I were her I would be terrified of what a marriage to a potential tyrant would be like.
 
“You don’t have a gift for me do you…Your Majesty…Ty,” she said. I felt she was teasing as much as feigning disappointment.
 
“I don’t think you should tease me about that, Lydia. But, I’m not going to lie to you and say that one of my Lords is holding it for you back at the celebration or that I have it in my…our chambers in Dimbersmere. I will always be honest with you. No I don’t have a wedding present for you that I scoured my kingdom for.” The image of Lydia wielding my sword as though it were a four foot long match stick flashed through my thoughts. “But I do have a present for you.”
 
Lydia’s eyes widened and danced and she took another step closer to me.
 
“Yes, now that I think about it, I have the perfect gift for you.” I carefully got up to avoid contact with my bride and slipped out the door.
 
After a quick trip to the stable I approached Lydia. The light seemed dimmer in the room. It cast a warm glow on her pale skin. She held her hands behind her back. She stood on her tiptoes trying to peek at the object I held behind me.
 
I quickened my step so that with one motion I knelt before her and lifted my sword, its hilt in one palm of my right hand and the razor edge cuffed carefully on the sleeve of my leather coat.
“This is my wedding gift to you my queen,” I said looking steadily into her velvet soft, violet colored eyes.
 
Her hand covered her mouth and helped to stifle her gasp.
 
“What does this mean, King Keravin?” she asked.
 
“I am giving you my sword; my grandfather’s sword actually. He was a great warrior and protector of the people of Dimbersmere. Today, you have sacrificed yourself and in some way that I don’t understand, have rescued the people of Dimbersmere. Your courage and self sacrifice alone would entitle you to my Grandfather’s sword, but I offer it to as a symbol of your power and authority as Queen of my humble nation.”
 
I bowed my head and raised the sword up to where her dainty hands could take hold of the ancient, deadly weapon.
 
Instead of taking the sword, her hands caressed my head. Her fingers threaded their way through the strands of my hair. I wanted to pull her to me and embrace her forever. I was glad and it was good that there was a merciless blade between us.
 
Her hands found my chin and raised my head and her warm lips kissed my forehead. She was tender and yielding but I dare not over ride my sensibilities as I was tempted by her budding charms.
 
“You do surprise me my King,” Lydia said, “You surprise me, but I now know that you are not at all that Prince Rudy anymore. You have always been a distant wish in my heart, I think, and I will cherish this gift and pray that we will never need to use it.”
 
Her right hand gripped the hilt of the sword. And again with the agility and strength she displayed at the wedding, the heavy elements of the weapon lightened and sailed upward at the command of her elegant hand, wrist and arms. I was in awe of her energy transfer into that deadly instrument and watched as she propelled it before her to the mantel piece. She masterfully found a home for it there. I was grateful for her acceptance of my gift and grateful that the sword was no longer mine or my responsibility.
 
I rose to join her as she stood admiring her handiwork. I rested my arm lightly around her waist wanting to infer nothing more than respect and honor to this beautiful child.
 
“Are you glad you married me?” she asked.
 
“Yes, of course Lydia,” I said. “The only question now is what to do with you until you are the proper age. I suppose you could live here with your father, and kind of be like the Lady of South Dimbersmere. Not that you wouldn’t be the Queen, it’s just you would still be a part of your father’s house until you are the proper age to really be married.”
 
Lydia slid gently away from me. A cloud of something from inside her darkened the pretty features of her face.
 
“Then you honestly don’t know?” she said, seating herself at the edge of the sofa. “They didn't tell you that my father is dead. I haven’t been a part of his house since I was eleven.”
 
“What?” Something had been odd about our earlier conversation and even her presence in Aftertyson’s villa seemed peculiar, but with these words I felt I was nearing something I didn’t want to examine. Especially not after pledging just a bit more of myself to her troth. “I don’t understand. Aftertyson left the wedding party just minutes before you did. We both were there, we…”
 
“Aftertyson is not my father,” she said with a nervous laugh. “For heaven’s sake, he didn’t tell you? No, of course he didn't tell you.”
 
I tried to control my shock and anger and confusion, but I was not good at such things. I was a poor politician and I would have been a horrendous ambassador. I went to the sofa and took a knee before her, worried that I was at last being drawn into the intrigue I was trying to avoid, the plots that would mean the ultimate destruction of Dimbersmere.
 
“Aftertyson is my adopted father. Well not even a father really. I am more of a ward to him. He was deeply in love with my mother and so when my father died, he attempted to win her love. And I think she did love him as well, but the issues surrounding my home were too complicated.”
 
“I’m deeply sorry for your loss, Lydia, I had no idea. I can't imagine why Aftertyson didn't tell me the truth.”
 
“Well that was nearly five years ago now. Perhaps he does think of me as his child. When you came to visit Aftertyson, I was still grieving. Not just my father, but also my mother. I didn't understand it all at the time and I’m still confused by what happened, but I was told that my mother had become gravely ill and that I was being sent away to a friend who would watch over me until my mother got better. As time went on I was aware that she was not getting better and that the people around her were concerned about things that…”
 
“You could never understand,” a familiar voice came from behind us, “at least not yesterday, but you will understand everything very soon.
 
I was appalled by the intruder's presence.
 
“What are you doing here!”

14111121111232.title: Lydia Is The Lady of South Dimbersmere

141111211112321.content:
Sir Cleven stood in the doorway to the villa’s parlor. His glare was that of a yellow eyed bird of prey. I had never noticed how old and crooked he had become until that moment standing next to my child bride.
 
“I’ve come milord to tell you and your wife a lovely tale, which as you may have guessed, Lydia, has already begun. You of course don’t know the whole truth or you probably would not have come…or would your Majesty? You seem to love your King Keravin. Well I don’t know, maybe in the end you would have had no other choice. Your Lord Aftertyson saw to that, driving off every decent offer from every other house.”
 
“I’m sure you’re mistaken about my benefactor’s intentions, sir. I’m sure all of his talk about suitors was just to make me feel better about losing my future in the House of Lassiter. There were no such prospects I am sure.”
 
Lydia’s words pierced me and I physically flinched and while I believe I didn’t make a sound, both Lydia and Cleven both stared at as though I had belched out some obscenity.
 
“Lassiter?” I turned enough to block out my view of my duplicitous counselor and faced Lydia, my hands shaking. “You are the daughter of King Mernel Lassiter?”
 
“Yes, but I thought you knew, your grace – honestly thought you knew.” The terror in her eyes communicated well the thoughts that she had lost me, and in a way she had. She was innocent of course. A prop or a dupe like me. Adornment for a future battlefield we would sit on the mound and watch the brutality from a far. But our fate was sealed.
 
I set Lydia free from my scrutiny and turned to my advisor, my confident, my soon to be council of war – “And the Queen, Cleven?”
 
“Perhaps not in front of the Queen, your grace,” Cleven said.
 
“I am not weak, sir,” my Queen said, “Quite the contrary, I think I know what you are about to say. It has been hinted at enough by Aftertyson, though he was too ashamed to name it. How about you? You seem to be as bold as you are fool hardy, care to talk about my mother?”
 
A laugh actually came bounding out of me as I saw Cleven both cringe and blush. His arrogance would be a barb that would make him an eternal enemy of my wife and I would have warned him but I was the one trapped and being goaded. I knew there were dank, nasty cells in my castle that would have suited his rodent nature.
 
“I am sorry your Majesties, I meant no offense,” he said with as much abasement he could muster. “I just meant to report as you have requested your Majesty that the Queen of Lassiter is in repose for a season while she recovers from some undetermined malady. While the house of Lassiter is anxious for her recovery, they are pragmatic. Simple people really, they just want a King and Queen who can rule and still be a symbol of vitality to the people.”
 
“What are you saying, Cleven?” I said.
 
“I am saying…”
 
“There is nothing wrong with my mother,” Lydia said, her tone was menacing and I was surprised how quickly she closed the distance between her and Cleven. I could see that it was hard for him to hold his ground.
 
“I remember some of what people around me were saying about her before I was sent away. But it was all lies then and it is all lies now. They have her locked up in some tower I suppose. They would dare dungeon a queen.”
 
“Perhaps you had better leave Cleven,” I said. I wasn’t sure what Lydia wanted, but I was certain of what was to come and I did not want to hear it.
 
“No,” Lydia said, “your knight has something to say, let him say…no, make him say it. Make him say the truth and then I never want to see his face again.
 
“Your mother aside your Majesty, and I assure you she is being attended to with the utmost kindness, the news I bring is not at all bad. In fact I believe news is wonderful in that what has been done has bestowed a great honor on you both and will be a tribute to your mother and father my Queen and to your grandfather my King.”
 
Sir Cleven appeared unable to go on and left his pending announcement dangling before us. It was Lydia’s retreat from him that softened his manner. She took the daintiest of steps to stand on the hearth, pressing in close to me. My arm naturally went around her waist. I felt more like a brother than a husband, though I had never had a sister, I knew that I would be her protector no matter what was to face us in the future.
 
“The Counsel of Lassiter sends you their greetings and their congratulations,” Sir Cleven said, opening a scroll. It was obviously new parchment and each end of the spindles had a carved head of a bird of prey attached to it. Cleven’s hands were steady as he loosened the ties that bound the rolls in place.
 
“Greetings, King and Queen Keravin,” he began.

“Please accept the congratulations of your humble servants, the High Counsel of Lassiter on your marriage. We declare today, King and Queen Keravin of Dimbersmere that we would be honored if you would take the throne of our House and rule as King and Queen forever. Queen Lydia is the only remaining heir to the throne as her mother is retiring. In marrying a long time ally of the House of Lassiter the throne should be hers by the rights of succession. Please take courage and know that the people of Lassiter will be gladdened by the news of your return and will celebrate the news that a Lassiter remains on the throne of our glorious house.”
 
Cleven looked up from the scroll and lifted it towards Lydia and I. “It is signed by every member of the High Council of Lassiter. It was delivered to me by messenger just a few moments before I came to see you.”
 
“You do know what this means, my King?”
 
“I think I do,” I said. ”Thank you for delivering the news so quickly. Odd, don’t you think? That the House of Lassiter could conjure up such a proclamation and send it over one eighty miles so quickly?”
 
“News does travel fast. I suppose they had some foreknowledge of this blissful union. And maybe they drafted the proclamation before your wedding. But just the same, it is good news and the people of Dimbersmere will at last have a protector that does not ransack their goods and consume all their food and drink.”
 
“Well they have certainly given me something to consider on my honeymoon with my Queen,” I said, waving my hand at my ex-counselor.
 
“I am sure that the High Counsel of Lassiter is anxious to hear your answer your Majesty.”
 
“Oh, I’m certain they are. And I am certain that you told them that they could expect a swift response with the King of Dimbersmere in full compliance with their wishes.” My grip on Lydia’s waist grew tighter as my furry began rising up into every muscle in my body. I would have gladly summoned an archer to pin Cleven’s treacherous heart to the door post, but no page was in hearing of my voice. Pitty.
 
“What do you think of your poor pitiful subjects my Queen? Have we been the ones to have disappointed you? Have I at last disappointed you?”
 
I felt her hand gently caress mine as she eased away from my embrace. I sensed her strength rising as though she were the eagle taking to the wind. The long dark tresses of hair bounced as her strongest hand gripped the hilt of the sword just above her head. She swung it to the front of her and she directed the tip in Cleven’s direction.
 
“On you knees, messenger!” she said.
 
Cleven clung to something wolflike that came out some primal instincts until he probably realized there was no one around him to back him up. At least that’s what I surmised from the wild look of panic that flashed across his face. He looked at me for some direction. Unfortunately for Cleven my fury had quickly turned to amusement as though I were watching a cat corner its prey.
 
“What…?” the old knight stammered. Again hoping for some direction from me.
 
“I’d take a knee, Cleven. If I were you I’d get on both knees and pray for mercy.”
 
He did as I directed as Lydia glided across the room, the point of her sword now aimed steadily at Claven’s throat.
 
As she began to speak her voice thrilled my ears with that sensous contralto tone that I had learned only seems to come when she is deeply wounded or anxious. She let the tip of the sword rest on the saggy skin under Cleven’s chin for a moment.
 
“I want you,” said Lydia, “to give this message to those nasty toads of Lassiter. I want my mother here now. And she had better be unharmed. I know she has to come by carriage or barge, but as fast as that proclamation was contrived and sent I expect my mother to be just as quickly released and on her way. Let them know that tomorrow will be soon enough.” Lydia looked back at me.
 
“When she has had a day to rest and recuperate here, then we’ll send out a messenger,” I said. “Only then, will we send a messenger to the house of Lassiter with our answer.”

14113.content:
Our old King was killed last evening. We collected at the beheading site, as everyone did, to observe the tragedy. Why we go and watch these dreadful sights, I know not. We are told if we are not there, there will be five years of hardship for our family - so we are there under duress. I do not want my children seeing such atrocities. I am in a forest at twilight. Gentle chirps of night birds waft through the trees. Insects join in, creating a rhythmic auditory pattern. I feel calm and breathe in the night smells as all of the forest creatures prepare for rest. I cannot remember a time of when I felt so at ease and so comfortable. The ground beneath my body hugs me in a gentle embrace.

I stare at the sky. Purples, blues and reds streak across the sky like a child's haphazard painting. I hear footfalls of some sort moving through the forest. I attempt to rise, but I am unable. The ground - the oh so comfortable ground- refuses to release its hold on me. I struggle. More footfalls are heard. And growling.

I realize a cloak is about my shoulders and around my neck. The cloak holds me to the ground. It pulls me to the earth. The more I struggle the tighter it wraps around my throat. A wolf howls. Many other answer in kind. I feel the warmth of my urine soaking my garments - soaking the cloak.

I feel the wolves breath on my skin, but they remain unseen. I scream. The cloak pulls tighter choking off my cries.

My urine soaks into the earth, becoming a part of the land. The dirt soaks into my flesh, becoming a part of me. The wolves, unseen, circle about me snapping and nipping at my exposed flesh. My breath is almost gone. I am losing myself to the land, to the cloak, and to the fear.

"I am King," I rasp.

"Only while you live," The wind whispers. "Kings become ash and dust as easily as peasants - especially unworthy Kings."

Tears flow, dripping in the earth. "I am worthy?" I cry to the trees and the sky, looking for affirmation. "Do not take over my body, dear earth."

"A true King must be bound to the earth - to land he rules - to truly be worthy of the crown," the crickets sing.

My eyes snap open. Candles flicker. I am resting on a bed. A figure sits beside me.

"You're going to die, my King..."

1421.title: The Royal Nightmare

14212.content:
"You're going to die, my King..."

I try to rise but strong hands shove me back to the pillow. “Where is Sir Gray?”

A figure points to the corner to the outline of a man sitting in a chair, motionless. “He is resting while I look after his charge . You mustn’t fret so much, as I was saying, or you’re going to die, my King.” The darkness hides his face but I swear I can sense a smile behind his words.

A chill of absolute fear circles my spine causing screams to form in my lungs. I clamp my mouth down with my hand. I must not make a fool of myself. This mysterious man could be exactly who he says he is, and I have no real reason, other than the madness of being named King and a potential assassin running about the castle. I am King. I cannot believe it.

The figure beside silent stares as I try to compose myself. “Who are you?”

The man shifts closer to me. “My name is Jonathon Verch. I am a King’s Guard.” His hand grips my shoulder. “Be calm, sire.”

A sigh like a kettle on my mother’s stove seeps between my lips. I let myself relax. “I cannot believe all that has happened today,” I say.

The hand tightens on my arm. “Yes, it was shocking to learn that one of the lesser nobles was named over more legitimate claims. Have you any idea why the King named you?”

I shrug away from the iron grip on my shoulder but the hand remains clasped like a bird of prey on a rodent’s broken neck. I shake my head at his question, but realize he probably cannot see me in this dimly lit room. “I have no idea. It was as much as a surprise to me as anyone. Have they located the King’s assassin?”

“Surely there must be some reason for the King to name one such as yourself as his successor. Were you and the King confidants in secret?”

The panic in my chest blossoms again. I notice he ignored my question. The insulting nature of his words should anger me but fear is my only response. I have never been a brave man. My mother always said I would do best finding a strong-willed woman to bolster my passive nature. My mother always said passive. I always heard coward. Cutting through the fear is a longing for my mother to know that her only son has been named King. The very thought makes a tiny chuckle roll through my lips.

“Did I say something amusing, sire?” Sir Jonothon growls.

“No, I was just thinking of -” I stop myself. I am King. I do not need to explain myself to a mere guard. As a mere noble, I would never have tolerate such insolence from a servant, so as King I surely do not need to take this from a guard. “I am tired. I wish to rest. Please leave.”

The guard makes no attempt to move. His hand remains locked upon my shoulder. His entire body tenses and I can feel his eyes on me, burning into me with malice. I suddenly have no doubt that this man means to harm me. “You are no King. You do not deserve to be King.”

“Sir Nigel!” I cry out to my Captain sleeping in the chair. “Help me!”

Sir Jonathon turns toward the still figure in the chair again. This time he chuckles before turning back to me. “Sir Nigel will not be helping you, Keravin. He died quietly and unspectacularly as he lower you into the bed.”

A knife point touches my chin.

“He was so determined to protect his new King that he forgot to check his back as he entered the room carrying your useless body. Why were you named King? I must know.”

Tears well up in my eyes. My thoughts go to my mother. I remember as a boy he used to call me a Prince. It was a term of endearment, or so I thought at the time. I never knew my father and my mother was a beautiful woman. Was it possible the King and my mother…

This was the thought that I died with. The assassin swiped across my thought and I could feel the warm blood pooling beneath my neck and head. The last words I heard were “You were never to be King. Whatever reason the King had for naming you does not matter. He may as well have cut your throat himself. I want you to know that…” The words faded and a lightness came over me.

I laughed out loud as I thought of my reign as King being a footnote in history. My only significance will be the shortness of my time on the throne. What throne? I never had the chance to even sit my ass in my new throne.

The world around blurs and swirls. I am swimming in air and feeling truly free of all worry and fear. I am never to be King - he said, but I was - I am King.

My mother is at my side, holding my hand, and behind him stands the King. I know instantly that he is my father. He gazes at me with eyes that speak of sadness and pride, and also anger. He pulls me in close and pats my back. My mother kisses my cheek and tells me how proud she is. I am happy. I never wanted to be King but I am glad I had the chance.

The King looks into my eyes with a steely expression. “This isn’t over my son. No. We have the means and the cause to carry on. You shall be King. You shall be avenged .”

142122.title: Return to Life

1421221.content:
Jack slept fitfully that night. The image of the slain man invaded his dreams, waking with a sinking guilt-filled pain in his gut. These Hunters were a nasty sort and Jack felt he should have done something more for the dead man. Sleep evaded Jack for the remainder of the night until finally he gave up all hope of rest and dressed for the day.

Jack wandered down to the public room of the Black Dragon Inn and tossed a log on the glowing embers in the hearth. The view from the street-facing window showed the night had brought a light fog with it. Jack hoped it also brought some cooler weather. He fetched a kettle from the kitchen and exited the rear door of the inn.

The water well was situated next to the Inn’s stable. Jack could hear the horses restlessly scuffing and shuffling, in particular, Graywash nickered and snorted nervously. Graywash was a beautiful Friesian who had arrived at the rear of the inn one morning and refused to leave. Taylor, the innkeeper, had asked around Col Ti'er and some of farmers in the outlying area but none could claim him as their horse, though some certainly tried.

Nardst, the stable manager and Taylor’s brother in law, adopted the magnificent animal. Many fights and arguments can be attributed to the ownership status of Graywash. Taylor wanted to sell him at the market but Nardst had said you don’t sell a fine gem at a brothel. Graywash, Nardst claimed, was the most intelligent, fierce and powerful horse he had ever encountered. He once, in a heated exchange with Taylor, claimed Graywash had the ancient soul of a noble knight and to sell such an animal would make them no better than the cursed slave-traders.

The horse’s whines seemed out of character so Jack passed the well and eased next to the closed stable doors. He had instinctively adopted a cat-like stealth, holding the kettle away from his body, and peered between the wooden slats that formed the stable walls. Graywash was in the back stall shifting from leg to leg and fluttered his ears. Jack’s hand was reaching for the door latch when he heard the man’s voice.

“What are we waiting on? That is the beast. Slice its throat and be done with it.”

Jack’s hand froze and he slowly lowered the kettle to the ground. He slid away from the door and around the corner of the stable, stopping at a wooden cask. He listened.

“Confirmation is required.” It was a different man’s voice. “The initial dat-patch indicated capture was the preferred recourse.”

A gruff huff sounded followed by a sound so strange to Jack his body jerked. It sounded almost like a bird chirp but was definitely not any bird that lived in these forests. Jack glided onto the cask then slid onto the stable’s roof, his movements fluid and absolutely soundless. He moved across the top support beam and noiselessly dropped to his stomach.

Below him Jack could make out three large men, obviously Hunters – the same Hunters he had encountered earlier. One of them had odd, tiny flames of red, green and yellow in his right hand, at least he thought they were flames, but they never flickered nor gave off smoke. The mystery bird chirped again and the colorful flames extinguished themselves with no indication of smoke.

“Order confirmed. Capture is the preferred recourse. Let’s remove the horse in the native fashion until clear of inhabitants. Hunter Onyx, grab a bridle and lead for the beast.”

Graywash neighed loudly and kicked the wall of the stable. Bridles, brushes and tools clattered to the floor. Jack watched from above as the horse reared up and smashed the weak stall door to bits of wood. The black, massive horse charged into the main aisle of the stable and bowled over all three Hunters.

Jack leapt to his feet and dropped to a crouch. He really wasn’t sure what he should do. He had no weapons and begrudgingly admitted to himself he was slightly terrified of both Hunters and horse. Jack decided getting off the roof was his best choice when a loud crack of a splitting timber erupted into the night. The support beam he was standing on listed toward the front of the stable. The Hunters cursed. Graywash whinnied furiously. Jack’s surefootedness failed him for only an instant as the support beam jerked from beneath his feet.

The cheap lumber of the stable roof gave way to even Jack’s thin form. Jack’s hands snatched a rope hanging from the dangling remains of the stable’s vertical support beam. He felt the slack in the rope tighten and wrapped his legs around the swaying beam to prevent the rope from jerking clean from his hands. Jack hugged the hanging, broken timber and looked down in amazement.

One of the Hunter’s head was a pulverized mess where it had shattered apart the bottom half of the beam Jack was desperately clutching. The second Hunter was scrambling across the floor feeling around piles of hay for what could only be a weapon. The last Hunter had a dirk in hand and was cautiously eyeing Graywash. The calm in the Hunter’s eyes was unnerving. Graywash kicked wildly tearing the stable apart. Jack couldn’t tell if the horse was trying to escape, attack or panicking.

As though in answer to Jack’s confusion, Graywash exploded into the stable doors. The force of the impact rocked the entire stable and Jack’s perch swayed and snapped loose from the cross beam. Jack and perch plummeted to the floor. His skill for being agile was well known in Col Ti'er, but it truly was a shame no one but the Hunters and horse were witness to Jack’s graceful landing. His slender, lithe form slid the beam beneath his feet, and the moment the wood struck the floor Jack leapt into the air, tucked into a flip and landed like a cat on all fours.

The dirk wielding Hunter turned to his partner, who had recovered a whip from the stable floor, and pointed at Jack. “Kill him. I will get the beast.” He dashed after the horse through the shattered door. Less than five seconds later, the Hunter was hurled back into the barn and an angry horse roared.

A crack of a whip startled Jack. The whip-toting Hunter was smiling. Jack pushed himself upward to get to his feet. But when he pushed off the stable floor, Jack was lifted completely from the ground and was then whipping in a half circle and literally flying through the now destroyed stable door. The ground was rushing past him as he flew through the night with the back of his belt securely clamped between the powerful jaws of Graywash.

1421221.title: Graywash

14212212.content:
Cobblestone roads blurred into dirt pathways as Jack swayed helplessly to the rhythm of Graywash’s gait. The hot breath of the black horse produced an uncomfortable, wetness on the small of Jack’s back. The Col Ti'er guards at the east facing gate remained motionless and stunned when the spectacle of a horse carrying a man in his mouth burst through the open gateway and disappeared into the darkness.

Graywash’s pace never slowed as they entered the prairies. Jack could only watch as the grassland’s many shades of green with an occasion speck of color raced past him. Discomfort was settling into his hips and the blurring landscape was unsettling his stomach. He closed his eyes, concentrating only on the wind roaring through his ear. The sway of the ride and the constant drone of the passing air suddenly lulled Jack into a dullness then sleep.

A wispy smoke invaded the darkness of Jack’s slumber and fine tendrils of gray fog weaved around him. Vague shapes and flickering tongues of orange and red formed within the haze while people-shaped movements faded in and out of the surrounding blackness. With shocking suddenness, his father slid through the murkiness and burst before him in stark clarity.

He was a thin man with a long, worn face and short brown hair. His green eyes narrowed with worry and concern. “Jack, get up, now!” The words were said rapidly, almost blending into one another. Thin hands pulled him from under the bed sheets. “Go to your sister’s room. She’s waiting for you.”

“Dad? What’s happening?” Over his father’s shoulder in the clouded background Jack could see the living quarters of his childhood home. The familiar sight filled him with happiness, sadness and longing all at once, each fighting for dominance. He looked down at his six-foot tall, fifteen year old body as his father shoved him toward the door of what he supposed was his sister’s room. Jack turned to his frantic father who stood at least four or five feet taller than him. How could this be? He could remember little of his father but he knew he was no giant.

“Go now, son. I’ll explain everything later. You and your sister need to get away from here.”

My sister? Smoke erupted from the darkness and his father blended into the fog until he vanished completely. Flames crawled up the walls of the living quarters. His mother shrieked from somewhere beyond the reaching fingers of the haze. He glanced over his shoulder toward the door that was supposedly his sister’s room.

The smoke vanished instantly. A gruff frightening voice, shouting indistinguishable words, could be heard from somewhere beyond the room he now mysteriously found himself standing. A girl, maybe twelve or thirteen, looked down at him. My sister! He knew instantly. Memories of her delicate hands bathing him, of their laughter blending into a joyful sound as her fingers tickled him, of her annoyance at Jack stealing candy from her special hiding place, and a hundred other images of their brief shared life flooded into his mind. Her name was Teresa.

“We have to go, Jacky. We will meet mom and dad later in a small village named Col Ti'er.” She smiled for his benefit alone, the true terror showing in her violet eyes. Her hands, so soft and warm, lifted him to her window and sat him on the sill.

The door to Teresa’s room split into two, flames erupting through the jagged opening. A large silhouetted figure with a huge war axe in one hand and a short sword in the other slid between the two halves. Teresa moved instantly in front of the looming figure, shielding Jack.

Then the ground seemed to rise up and smash Jack in the face. He opened his eyes to clumps of prairie grass and could feel prairie dirt on his lips. “I have a sister,” Jack whispered as he ran one hand through the thick prairie grass and wiped his lips with the other. He rolled onto his back and stared up at the huge, black horse staring back. He scurried backward moving away from the massive beast. Graywash charged slightly forward, snorting, then abruptly turned away, whipping the boy’s face with his long black tail. The horse nickered and trotted away.

The sun peeked over the horizon revealing the seemingly endless prairie in all directions. Jack stood, brushing off dirt and grass, and stretching to ease the cramping in his hips. Graywash neighed and snorted loudly moving his head up and down in the direction opposite of the sunrise. Jack felt suddenly naked without any weapons as he watched the expanding sunlight reveal the spectacular waves of grass, the colorful spattering of wildflowers and four figures riding hard out of the west toward him and his menacing four-legged companion.
