14212212.title: Dream Ride

142122123.content:
The sunlight spread like a gleaming blanket across the plains. Jack and Graywash watched the approaching riders and tried to determine if they were friend or foe. In his gut, Jack feared the riders were more Hunters seeking to cut short the lives of the brash horse and the inadvertent witness.

He searched about the plains looking for a viable weapon but only found dirt, flowers and grass. His eyes drifted to the massive black horse and the horse’s eye glared back at him. If he could ride the fearsome beast, he would be able flee from the pursuers, but would the horse allow it?

Jack stared at the approaching riders again, trying to determine their identities, and then slowly stepped toward Graywash. The horse snorted. Jack quickly stepped away from Graywash.

“Come on, horse! We’re going die!” Jack said, stomping his feet in the grass. Graywash stomped his hooves in response along with a high pitched neigh. Jack’s jaw clenched tight and his eyes narrowed at the horse.

“I may be afraid of you, Graywash, but you can’t scare me! I am going to ride you!” Jack walked to the horse, placed his hands in the thick mane and pulled himself toward the horse. Graywash stepped sideways and Jack crashed to the ground. The horse kicked up patches of grass with his hind legs and patches of dirt and grass showered Jack.
Jack punched the ground and bolted to his feet. A deep growl emitted from Jack’s throat as he leapt for the backside of the horse with intentions of using his hands to push himself forward onto Graywash’s back. The horse’s rear end bucked just as Jack pushed off and the young man sailed over the horse’s head. He landed in a heap amid a patch of dirt and wildflowers.

His face red and his eyes wild, Jack huffed and rolled onto his feet. He ran head-on at Graywash, his hands balling into fist. He drew his arm back and aimed for the horse’s nose. Graywash’s massive head swiveled to one side, missing the blow, and then slammed the side of his head into the side of Jack’s head. The boy rolled head over feet away from the horse, jumped back to his feet for only a moment before collapsing on his backside.

“I hate you, Graywash.” Jack grabbed a handful of dirt and slung it at the horse. “Let me ride you or we are going to die! Do you not see the riders?” He pointed and glanced at four riders sitting on their mounts staring at Jack.

“Are you fighting with a horse, Jack?” Aric asked.

“I think they are having a mud clot fight,” Taylor said, smiling.

“And I think the horse is winning!” Jasper added.

Nardst dismounted his horse and walked toward Graywash. “What in the good graces of Elving Gorge are you doing out here, Jacky?”

Jack stared at his friends. He could feel tears forming as relief flooded through him. “By the stars! I am so glad to see you all! I was getting- ”

Aric interrupted, “Jack, we need to move, now. Can you ride your horse?” He looked over his shoulder, back toward Col Ti'er.

The words came out before Jack could even think of stopping them. “No! I cannot ride that infernal beast!”

Jasper smiled at Jack and pointed with his thumb toward their home. “Why in the gods’ names not, Jack? You rode him out here. You see that cloud? That smoke back there?”

Jack stood and looked. At least ten riders moved across the plains, and behind them, where Col Ti'er should be, rose billowing columns of smoke that became more and more visible as the sun left the horizon.

“Hunters?” Jack asked.

“Definitely,” Taylor answered. “We, four, only escaped because we all came looking for you at the same time. We… I thought you were dead.”

“Jacky,” Nardst called, “ride my mount. Come on, lad.” Nardst had mounted Graywash and was turning the beast away from the approaching riders and his home.

Jack glared hatefully at Graywash and then mounted Nardst’s gray spotted Appaloosa named Wildy. Nardst and Graywash lead the way across the plains while the Hunters pursued and Col Ti’er burned.

Jack rode silently next to Aric. He wondered, even though his day was just beginning, if this day would ever end. An attack by Hunters, memories of a forgotten sister, and now flight from his burning home were quite enough events for one week much less one morning. He glanced back at the pursuers and became suddenly aware of his lack of leather armor and weapons. The Hunters were slowly closing the distance. It was only a matter of time before they would reach weapons range and that would prove deadly for himself and his band of friends, especially on the wide open plains.

“We need to- ” Jack shouted at Aric.

“I know. We can’t outrun them. I think we need to split up,” Aric said.

Jack and the others agreed.

“There is an abandoned winery about twenty-five miles to the east-south-east,” Aric explained as they rode. “It is called the Screeching Bean. Once you shake your pursuers we will meet up there. I’m going to head east. Jasper and Taylor head north. Jack and Nardst head south. Good luck, my friends.”

Jasper and Taylor shot off to the north, Arik continued east while Nardst and Jack turned south. This was the moment that counted. The hope was the Hunters would divide their forces but there was no guarantee this would be the case.

Jack peered over his shoulder, urging Wildy to ride harder, faster. The group of Hunters continued to follow Aric. Death was certain for Aric if all the Hunters stayed on him. Jack started concocting a plan to force some of the Hunters to break off when three of them broke from the main group and turned north. Moments later four more broke and headed directly for Jack and Nardst.

“Jacky, about three miles from here the plains slope drastically into the Rujel Marshes. It is there we can decide to make a stand or look for a hiding spot.” Nardst was gently urging Graywash to slow down slightly to avoid Jack and Wildy from falling too far behind.

“I’ve no weapons, Nard!”

“I’ve only a dagger, so it looks like we will be running to ground.”

For the next three miles they rode hard and silently. The horses’ breathing, the rushing wind and their pounding hearts filled their ears as the Hunters slowly closed the gap. The landscape changed slowly, giving rise to mushrooms and softer ground. The grass was less green and the wildflowers less beautiful.

The slope Nardst had mentioned was more like a jagged series of small cliffs. The horses never slowed as they leapt from each cliff and landed in increasingly mucky ground. When they reached the last cliff they leapt into waist high brackish water. Nardst and Jack urged the horses to continue deeper into the Rujel Marsh. Jack looked back as they began their trek across the marsh; the Hunters were just reaching the uppermost cliff.

“We will keep moving to the center of the marsh where the trees get thicker. I’m hoping we can lose them in there,” Nardst said.

Jack watched as the Hunter’s progress was slowed by the small cliffs and the soft earth. A gap had formed between Nardst and Jack as the soft bottom seemed to have no effect on the progress of the powerful Graywash. Wildy struggled and fought against the mud sucking at her hooves. A small current formed in the marsh water and Jack turned Wildy into it to increase their speed. The current gained strength and the water deepened.

Nardst shouted at Jack but the sound of the current drowned out his words. Graywash and Nardst turned and started moving toward Jack. The current had transformed into rapids as Graywash closed the distance between them.
“Jack, get out of the current!” Nardst shouted over the rushing water. “They lead to underground caverns-”

The ground beneath Jack and Wildy vanished. Horse and boy fell with water cascading all around them and the sunlight quickly vanishing. Jack looked desperately for anything to grab to stop his descent. Above him, an eight foot circular hole of sunlight with water pouring over the edges seemed to be getting smaller.

An ice cold wall of water hit Jack so suddenly he lost all sense of space and place. The watery pool chilled him to the bone. The weight of the falling horse drove Jack further beneath the water. Panic seized Jack as he realized his feet were still in the stirrups. As he attempted to free his feet, the heavy, unmoving horse pinned his leg against the underwater cavern floor. Jack gazed at a small, shimmering circle of sunlight far above him. Coldness stabbed his muscles and a sudden weariness stole over his entire body. He pushed against the horse but his strength was gone. Pinpricks of light danced around the edge of his vision and Jack just wanted to sleep. Jack couldn’t remember where he was and what he was supposed to be doing. The freezing water lulled him into a deadly peaceful sleep.

142122123.title: Allies Arrive

1421221232.content:
A beautiful, bright, shimmering light beckoned to Jack. His legs were free now and the stabbing cold had vanished, leaving only the comforting warmth radiating from the light. He swam to the light pushing and pulling his body through water.
CRACK! Cold pierced his flesh like a million needles and there was no air. The light had become a faraway glow which offered no warmth and did not beckon. He struggled to move but a heavy object prevented him.
CRACK! Air flooded into his lungs and warmth blanketed him soothingly. The welcoming light had returned and Jack glided toward it. Shadows moved beyond the light. Jack increased his efforts to reach it, kicking his legs and pulling with his arms.
CRACK! Frigid waters swallowed him again, shooting pain and bringing overwhelming exhaustion. Jack fumbled with the heavy object briefly and screamed.
CRACK! His fingertips touched the light, spreading heat up his arm. Jack threw himself at the light and splashed onto a cold, hard surface.
“Holy shit! Someone came through.” The voice boomed and echoed. Jack was blind, all he could see was whiteness. The voice was male.
“Oh my lord, it worked! It worked! Who is he? Where in the hell is his realm key?” This voice was female.
Jack scrambled around on the floor unable to speak or stand. His body would not obey his commands.
A new, deep, commanding voice echoed in Jack’s ears. “There is no key! My god, it is keyless crossing! It is unstable, he’s fading already! He looks like he is from the Carmek Realm.” Hands grabbed his shoulders as a faceless shadow appeared before him. “Listen man, tell Gregson that the Hunters are realm jumping freely now. Tell him Overton spoke to you and I said he has to-”
CRACK! Hands yanked Jack’s tunic. A cold breeze slapped his skin and delicious air rushed down his throat only to be met by a stream of water shooting up his throat. Jack coughed and water spewed from his mouth and nose. Strong arms supported him beneath his shoulders and dragged him from the icy liquid. The sound of falling water crashed all around him.
“Quiet, Jacky,” Nardst whispered in his ear. “The Hunters are close by, and even with the roaring waterfall, let’s not take any chances.”
Jack looked upward at the sunlit opening in the earth. Trickles of water ran over the corner of Jack’s mouth but wonderful air was filling his lungs. “Tell Gregson…”
“Shush.” Nardst dragged Jack across damp rocks into the shadows away from the cavern’s skylight opening and leaned him against an algae covered rock wall.
Jack sat silently as his eyes adjusted to the darkness. The cavern was roughly oval shaped with a waterfall and steep, dripping rock walls that contained dark, watery passageways. Jack closed his eyes and slept.


A rapid clicking interrupted Jack’s sleep, and it was several seconds after waking when he realized it was the chattering of his own teeth. The coldness from the rocks beneath him numbed his backside and legs. The waterfall sprayed cold mist across the cavern chilling the skin and preventing wet clothing from drying.

1421221232.title: A Strange Encounter

14212212321.content:
The giant orb of the sun spread its early morning warmth across the plains as grass and clumps of dirt flew from the hooves of Aric’s horse, Marglee. She wasn’t his horse of choice, but the pickings back in Col Ti’er had been slim when he was forced to flee his home. A glance over his shoulder told him two Hunters had stuck with him.

They had the better mounts and were closing in on him quickly. He figured it was best to pick a place for a confrontation rather than have circumstances pick it for him. Aric scanned the landscape looking for a place to make a stand, noticing to his right were more grasslands and a large rock, straight ahead were flat grasslands and dirt and to his left was a large solitary tree. Rock or tree, he thought.

Aric decided on the tree with the deciding factor being, if he died, he would rather rot beneath a tree than next to a rock. He veered Marglee left and encouraged her to dig deep and hard. Another peek at his pursuers told him they were big, armored men with each carrying a fearsome weapon. An axe dangled from the waist of the lead rider while the other had a war hammer strapped to his back. He spat in their direction before returning his eyes to the tree.

He looked down at himself to assess his own readiness for combat. Luck had favored him when the Hunters began laying waste to the village. He had been getting ready for his next shift and had already dressed in his chainmail and strapped on his broadsword when he heard the first scream. He had exited the guardhouse to clouds of smoke, and at the head of the road near the east gate were flames. He could still picture the flames in his mind, unnatural in its movement and origin.

The Hunters had formed a line across the head of the east road and slowly walked west as they cut down anyone who opposed or presented themselves to the advancing line. Aric had made a quick count and determined there were at least fifty attackers. How had so many Hunters arrived in the town without notice? On instinct, he drew his broadsword and moved toward them, but then he saw the flames. Some of the Hunters produced flames from their hands or from something in their hands; Aric couldn’t see well enough to determine its true source. The flames moved in a straight line from the source to wherever the Hunter pointed his arm, reminding Aric of pictures he had seen in storybooks of dragons breathing fire.

The flames hit buildings, people, and animals, igniting everything it touched. Aric sheathed his sword. He remembered his father, the greatest Town Guard Commander in Col Ti’er history, saying that to openly confront an impossible battle limits possibilities. His instinct and desire to battle the invaders urged him to defend the town, but his duty to the people of Col Ti’er and the words of his father overrode his raw impulse. Aric turned away from the Hunters to help evacuate the city.

He ran to the Black Dragon Inn and commanded anyone he met to flee from the city immediately. Door by door, Aric ordered people out of their rooms and out of the city. When he arrived at Jack’s room, Taylor and Jasper were exiting the boy’s quarters. They told Aric the boy was missing and nowhere on the premises. Taylor explained Nardst was checking the stable for Jack and getting horses for them, and she suggested he do the same if he hoped to escape from the onslaught.

The fear in the Innkeeper’s face had been terrifying to Aric and that was when he remembered a rumor of Taylor surviving a Hunter attack before she lived in Col Ti’er. Aric, Taylor and Jasper agreed to meet at the west gate and ride out together. He rushed from the inn and to the Town Guard stable where he immediately noticed his horse, Whisk, was missing. The only horse that had remained was Marglee, so Aric saddled her and headed toward the west gate.

Col Ti’er was an inferno when he crossed back to the main road. Smoke and ash filled the air and burned Aric’s eyes and throat. The line of Hunters was slowly and methodically marching, burning and murdering their way through the blazing city toward the west gate. Aric wound his way to the gates, stopping at homes and businesses to help citizens escape the oncoming carnage and flames. When he arrived at the gate, Taylor, Jasper and Nardst waited on their horses.

“Jack?” Aric had asked.

Tears moistened Taylor’s eyes as she shook her head and shrugged.

“Jacky can take care of himself, and if not, he’s already dead and there’s nothing to be done. Now, unless you want to be roasted like a goat, I suggest we ride the hell away from here.” Nardst said.

“Aric, look here,” Jasper called. “Horse tracks heading across the plains.”

“I recognize that beastly hoof mark. That is Graywash’s tracks, for sure. Let’s follow it. We could make use of that horse if we can catch him,” Nardst suggested.

Aric had agreed which lead to the discovery of Jack and to the current hope of reaching the tree before his pursuers reached him. As the tree came closer, Aric started to strategize his attack and his defense. He would stay close and keep his back to the tree to prevent either Hunter from getting behind him. He noted several low branches that could block a high cut and he also mentally positioned himself on the side of the tree which put the sun to his back.

As he closed on the tree, he glanced back once more estimating the time he had until his opponents arrived. He dismounted quickly and slapped the backside of Marglee to remove her from harm’s way. He moved into the ideal position and drew his sword. A knot of nervousness tensed his stomach. He swallowed hard and breathed calmly. His feet spread shoulder wide, Aric found his center of balance and breathed another deep intake of air. I am ready. I am focused for battle. I am courage and I am confident. The broadsword lifted and pointed at the approaching riders.

WC:1062
14212212321.title: Aric's Run: The Escape

142122123211.content:
The Hunters reined in their mounts about three yards from Aric and the tree. It appeared he had taken them by surprise with his confrontation. They hesitated.

“You care to dismount or should I cut you down while on your horse?” Aric asked.

The lead Hunter threw his leg over his horse and slid to the ground. He studied Aric seriously then spoke without taking his eyes from his intended target. “Stay on your mount. I will engage him. Once engaged, trample him with your horse.”

Aric didn’t know if he was surprised at the actual tactic or at the fact that he openly announced his intentions. Either way, Aric never moved. He would let the Hunter make the first strike.

The Hunter drew out his axe and walked toward Aric. “You’re a big one. We’ll make this quick.” In a flash of movement, the Hunter threw his axe at Aric. It was an unexpected move but Aric side slipped past the oncoming weapon and feigned a lunge at the Hunter’s midsection. The other Hunter charged with his horse, and Aric pulled back from the feint and pivoted away from the axe-throwing Hunter and spun his body against the side of the approaching horse. The horse passed between the two combatants. As Aric came out of his spin, he jammed the edge of his blade to the horse’s neck and sliced deeply into the flesh and then immediately turned his blade to an upward stroke striking the flat of his blade against the rider’s chest. The horse roared and reared back slightly as the clank of blade on armor sounded into the morning air. Aric dug his boots into the ground and stopped his movement along the horse’s body. His sword pushed against the rider’s chest, forcing him to the back of his horse.

The rider fought to stay astride but the rearing of the horse and the pressure from the pushing broadsword flipped the Hunter backward off the horse. Before the rider struck the ground, Aric had thrust his sword into the belly of the rearing horse. Blood gushed to the ground and savage, raw screams erupted from the dying horse.

Aric stepped away from the horse and located the lead Hunter. He had retrieved his axe and had taken up a defensive posture near the tree. The fallen Hunter rolled to his side and gained his feet. Aric noticed the fallen Hunter was off balance, possibly confused and disoriented. He knew if he didn’t press his advantage now, he would have two opponents of opposite sides of him. Against better judgment and training, Aric turned his back on the lead Hunter, stepped toward the staggering Hunter and cut upward with his sword toward his throat.

The lead Hunter shouted a warning, but his partner reacted too slowly and the blade cut into his throat, scraping against the bottom of his jawbone and cutting a wide, deep gash into his neck. His hands slapped at his face momentarily and then fell to his side as his body collapsed.

Aric swung around instantly in a defensive stance and his sword parried the axe blow aimed for his skull. The fighters stepped backward and studied each other. Aric was breathing heavily. The Hunter waited and glared.

Aric wondered what he waiting for. Why would he give me the opportunity to rest? Did he think I…

Flames erupted from the spot where the fallen Hunter lay. Aric turned instinctively, bringing up his sword for defense. The dead Hunter’s entire body was engulfed in flames, although it wasn’t actually flames, it was more like the body had transformed into lava and was burning itself into ash from the inside out.

An axe blow slammed into Aric’s ribcage. Pain seared through his side as the force of the blow knocked him toward the ground, but then something pulled him in the opposite direction. Intense pain rolled through his entire body as he was dragged in the direction of his attacker. Pain blinded and disoriented him.

“Give me my axe, you bastard!” the Hunter shouted.

A foot pressed against his hip and pushed the lower half of his body as the top portion was pulled in the opposite direction. Excruciating pain tore at him. Aric looked down and saw the axe lodged in his ribs and the Hunter’s foot was driving into his hip as his hands yanked to free the axe.

Aric didn’t know if it was the intervention of gods, the benefit of intense training, or the body’s natural way of protecting itself that granted him a moment of clarity, but his mind cleared. The pain ceased for only an instant, and Aric sliced deeply with his sword into groin of the Hunter.

The pulling stopped immediately and Aric crumpled to the ground away from the Hunter, the axe still wedged in his ribs. The Hunter cursed loudly, and he moaned, and then he repeated this pattern for a long time. Aric rested his face in the dirt, unable to move, too painful to even speak. He could see the writhing form of the Hunter and hear his vile curses and his pathetic moans.

Aric felt tears roll across his cheeks. He touched the axe handle gently, but an intense pain shot from his side and stabbed him in the brain. He thought of his father and how he had hoped to follow in his footsteps to become the Town Guard Commander. He knew death was coming for him.

The cursing stopped. The moaning ceased. The Hunter’s skin began to melt and then turned to lava. Aric watched the evil man disintegrate into nothing but black ash. He wondered briefly what kind of creatures were these Hunters and where did they come from, and then he closed his eyes.
#

Thirsty and cold, Aric was surrounded by darkness when he reopened his eyes. He thought he was dead and was saddened to know his side still hurt even in death, but something stirred behind him. He slowly and carefully dragged himself into a sitting position. The axe was still protruding from his ribs. Marglee stepped from the shadows and nuzzled his face.

“Whoa, girl, you’ll knock me over.” Aric reached up and gently stroked her face. “That’s a good girl.”

His side felt as though it were on fire, so much so that he was waiting for his own skin to become lava. Using Marglee for support Aric pulled himself to his feet as sweat rolled down his face and a sudden chill wracked his body. He needed a healer if he wanted to live. He placed one foot in the stirrup and pulled himself up and over the horse’s back. He screamed. Tears flowed from his eyes as he sobbed into the horse’s mane.

He guided Marglee over to the Hunter’s horse still standing near the tree and removed a rope attached to the saddle. Aric tied himself to the saddle while pain, chills, the protruding axe and fatigue wore down his body, but his spirit rebounded. I will not die today, maybe tomorrow, but today I shall live.

He pointed Marglee toward the abandoned winery and urged her forward as his head slumped forward and sleep claimed once again him.

WC: 1209
142122123211.title: Aric's Battle

1421221232111.content:
Jasper and Taylor sped to the north with three Hunters in pursuit. Unlike Aric or Nardst and Jack, their quarter horses had the speed advantage and quickly widened the gap between them and the Hunters.

“Suck on our dust,” Jasper shouted to the fading pursuers and then turned and smiled victoriously at Taylor.

“You truly are a simple bastard, Jasper.” Taylor noted with a smirk.

“The only kind of bastard my mother knew how to raise, you dirty harpy.” Jasper studied the landscape ahead of him as he pondered their next move.

“So, where to? The Monastery of the Unspoken, the town of Grimchak, or Englatain Mountains?” Taylor asked.

“Not the Monastery. I would hate to bring these animals to the monks’ doorstep,” Jasper stated. “I’m not very fond of what lives in those mountains either, so I’d prefer to avoid them, not to mention it is a good long run to the Englatains.”

“Grimchak, then?” Taylor grimaced.

Jasper smiled as he imagined her displeasure at the prospect of visiting Grimchak. “Yes, ma’am, Grimchak it is. But we need to make sure we lose our friends here.” He pointed over his shoulder to the trio of Hunters.

Taylor shielded her eyes and squinted into the distance. “There’s a small bluff up ahead. If we run hard and put enough distance between us and them, I know a sure-fire way to prevent further pursuit.”

Jasper never hesitated or doubted a word the innkeeper said. He nodded and they pushed their horses harder to gain the bluffs. He was amazed at the speed they managed to coax out their horses and at the resourcefulness of the woman riding alongside him. She had arrived in Col Ti’er about eight years ago with a worn out mule, an oak bow, and a purse filled with a modest amount of gold coins.

He had been a wet behind the ears recruit back then and had been on gate duty when she had wandered into the city. He had been instantly smitten by the new arrival. Her dark hair and gray blue eyes warmed his heart with romance and hope, but his efforts had been gently, and then directly, rebuffed. After that, Jasper had never bothered her with romantic notions, but he had offered his friendship which she had readily accepted. Now, with so many years of friendship behind them, it seemed laughable to Jasper that he had ever considered Taylor as a romantic interest.

She had bought the Black Dragon Inn a few weeks after arriving and turned it into a thriving inn and a popular choice for a meal or a drink. She had, over the years, Jasper recalled, mentioned her past but only rarely and guardedly. He remembered she once mentioned that she had ended up in Con Ti’er because of a Hunter raid on her village, but she offered few details. He knew that she had been married once, but never mentioned what had happened to her mystery spouse. The following year, her brother-in-law, Nardst, arrived at the Black Dragon Inn and began working for Taylor. Neither offered any information on their seemingly missing husband-brother to anyone in Col Ti’er.

“Cut left around the bluff and get to the top.” Taylor ordered, cutting through Jasper’s thoughts and scattering them like cockroaches at dawn.

The bluff was small but offered an advantage of height and a moderate amount of concealment. They rode around and up to the edge of the bluff, and then dismounted. Taylor moved swiftly. From her horse’s saddle pack and straps, she removed three arrows and her unstrung oak bow. She dropped to one knee behind a fallen, rotting tree and stabbed the three arrows into the ground beside her. In a matter of seconds, she had curved her bow, attached the string to the tip, and allowed the string to tense as the bow gained its familiar shape.

Jasper could see the Hunters approaching, riding side by side, as Taylor nocked an arrow and drew the bow. Her breathing became steady and even, and her eyes locked onto its target a moment before the arrow released. Jasper lost sight of the projectile the instant it left the bow, so he watched the approaching targets.

A spray of blood from the closest horse’s neck indicated a hit. Its front legs folded, its head collided with the packed earth, and its forward movement slid across the ground until it came to a dusty halt. The rider stayed astride during the entire descent then leapt from its back to examine the fallen horse.

Another arrow followed and pierced the farthest horse’s eye, causing the beast to whirl in the opposite direction before collapsing on its side in an unmoving heap. Jasper watched the Hunter roll away from his dead mount and come up on one knee looking for the source of the attack.

Taylor grabbed the third arrow from the ground, nocked it and let it fly at the final horse. Her aim was high and she missed her intended target and embedded the arrow deeply into the final Hunter’s shoulder. Jasper watched the injured rider slide from the back of his mount and use its body as cover from further attacks.

“Let’s move, Taylor,” Jasper commanded as he pulled her mount toward her.

She hesitated a second, staring at the three Hunters below, and then mounted her horse with the bow still in hand. Jasper followed suit and they raced down the bluff and toward the north.

“I missed one of the horses,” Taylor said.

“I noticed. So did its rider.” He smiled at her and pointed to the northeast. “To Grimchak we go.”

“Great,” she said unenthusiastically. “More fun on this gloriously fun day.”

1421221232111.title: Jasper & Taylor's Run

14212212321111.content:
The fires of Grimchak belched a greasy haze over of the circular corralled city. The smell of charred horseflesh hit Taylor in the face like jarring fingers jammed up her nostrils. The city, if city was the proper name, housed the best, worst and most notorious horse trainers, dealers and thieves. The entire city’s structure was designed for training, housing, selling, buying and slaughtering of horses. Taylor’s nose wrinkled in disgust as she and Jasper approached the city’s only entrance.

Grimchak’s entrance consisted of two platform towers and a strong, wooden, swing gate which controlled the exiting and entering of the city. The guards at entrance were more interested in those exiting than in those seeking admittance. Taylor noted the guards checking ownership documents of all who exited the city’s corralled walls. The Grimchakians frowned upon horse thieves as others would murderers and molesters. The phrase “Like a horse thief in Grimchak” was commonly heard and referred to someone who violated sacred laws of morality.

“I love that smell. Yum Yum,” Jasper stated as he rode up next to Taylor. “Horseflesh – the meat of champions, psychos, and Grimchakians.”

Taylor glared at her companion in her familiar mock contempt way. “I’ve heard stories of Grimchak, but the odious odor doesn’t do all the descriptions justice. This place is awful looking.”

“You ain’t seen nothing, yet. The inside of Grimchak is a horse lover’s nightmare. Steel your stomach… and your heart, my friend.”

Taylor sighed, trying to imagine the horrors held inside this circular horse hell. She knew some of the finest horses could be purchased, but she also had heard of the atrocities against horses this place had committed. She planned to be here only long enough to water and feed their horses, get a tiny bit of rest, and buy provisions before heading toward the Screeching Bean to meet Aric and the others.

Her stomach tensed at the thought of the others, particularly Jack. He was so young and she or one of her friends had always been nearby to protect the boy. She hoped Nardst was taking good care of him. She hoped both the boy and her brother-in-law would find their way safely to the abandoned winery.

“Why you here?”

The voice of the gatekeeper broke through her thoughts. The guard wore horse hide for clothing and brandished a weapon that appeared to be made of bone - horse bone if she had to guess. He smelled of horse and manure, and Taylor could see tiny nits leaping to and fro in his hair and on his horse hide garments.

“We’re here to resupply and rest before moving on,” Jasper explained.

The guard eyed Jasper with a hard stare before transferring his gaze to his horse. “You sell that horse?”

Jasper shook his head. “My horse is not for sale, but thank you for the compliment.”

Bowing his head, the guard swung open the corral gate. Taylor followed Jasper into Grimchak, wondering what compliment Jasper had spoke of. She hated being so unaccustomed to her surrounding, and on top of that she was nearly exhausted, physically and emotionally. She allowed her mind to think of the Hunters for the first time since the attack on Col Ti’er; it hurt her heart and made her bowels turn to liquid. The fear of the Hunters could rule her if she panicked or dwelt on her past. She shove the thought away with a physical shudder of her body. She hastened her horse’s pace to catch up with Jasper.

“What compliment did that… guard give you?” Taylor asked when she eased next to her companion.

“Anytime a Grimchakian offers to buy or expresses interest in purchasing your horse, it is considered a compliment.”

“He didn’t ask about my horse.”

“No. I wouldn’t think he would. Let’s find a hostel to get some sleep.”

Taylor crinkled her brow. Forget that horse-killing guard - her horse was perfectly fine - even if she didn’t know her name. She had taken the horse from Nardst at the gate and wasn’t familiar with her at all. Leaning over the horse's neck, she gently patted her on the head. When she leaned back into her saddle, the whole of Grimchak came into view as she cleared the corner of the guard structure.

Fires of varying size, intensity and color dotted the interior of the corral city while a potpourri of horse breeds in varying states of healthy were gathered in hundreds of small corrals. Taylor’s nose wrinkled at the overpowering smell of manure from the giant mountain sized pile of horse dung on the far city of the city. The smell of shit almost overpowered the scents of cooking meats, rotting flesh, human toil and oiled leathers but not completely. Men, dressed in horse hides and armored in horse skulls and skeletons, skulked all about the compound. In the center of the corral, a series of buildings had been constructed which Taylor guessed were hostels, eateries and merchant stalls.

“You okay?” Jasper had moved next to her, a look of concern and mild amusement on his face.

A man a few yards away sliced open the neck of a white, skinny mare. The blood fountained into a trough and leather straps and hoists caught the dying body as it fell. Taylor turned away, facing Jasper. “By Strakor’s Plight, what sort of hell is this place.”

The amusement washed away from his face. Jasper rested his hand of her knee. “Try not to think about it all. We get some shut eye and some supplies, and the we put this place at our backs. We’ll be gone in less than 10 hours. Come on, I’m bushed.” He rode away slowly with his eyes turned downward toward the horse trail.

Taylor followed locking her moist eyes on Jasper’s back. She bit her lip until she tasted blood. Her eyes grew heavy as they traversed the city. Several men and women spoke to hear with offers of bargains or promises of cheap goods. She ignored them all and concentrated on remaining awake. Her thoughts drifted back to days before - two days before the attack on Col Ti’er.

14212212321111.title: Enter Grimchak

1421223.content:
Although this is atypical in a story, let us take a hard look at the Hunters through the eyes of one of their kind. This story is a Hunter story and how one Hunter became a hero and a villain to an entire Galaxy. Our story begins on a different planet than Jack and Jasper; it begins on a planet millions of miles away - on planet named Freeloader.

A fist stormed into his lips, spewing blood. It gushed across his chin and down his throat, choking him. One of his torturers yanked his head forward and slapped him on the back.
"Now do you want to answer?"
It was the head interrogator, Major Redvins Treodon, speaking. He was a tiny man, a Ruddy Hunter, with dark black hair and a face like a rodent. His voice was high-pitched and harsh. The prisoner lifted his face toward him.
"My name is Sayer Ersk, aid to Governor Galen of Freeloader. As a civilian, I protest these proceedings," stated the prisoner, weariness hanging on each word.
"We know that already!" The Major's hands swept at the air. Sayer glanced about the large, brightly lit office, desperately hoping to wake from this nightmare. But the nightmare remained, as well as the five men surrounding him. To keep his mind alert and the tears of despair at bay, he tried to remember how many days of captivity he had endured.
He could not remember. The days and nights had blended into one another; all filled with nightmarish pain. Consciousness was slipping away. He dropped his chin to his chest and closed his swollen eyes, listening to the men around him.
"You are not getting anywhere, Major," stated Colonel Nyle, the Provisional Military Governor of Laldan. Sayer pictured the man in his mind. His head was completely devoid of hair, except for ugly, red eyebrows that resembled tiny bits of fire. Nyle's nose was long and curved downward, reminding Sayer of a hawk's bill. Like Sayer and everyone else in the room, he was a Ruddy Hunter.
"Now wait a minute, Governor," stated Captain Kirton, "that's not true. We know that his name is Sayer Ersk and he objects to everything. We also know that we are wasting time. We need that information soon." Sayer almost laughed. Kirton tried to keep the mood light, but Sayer could hear the frustration in his voice. He tried to picture the Captain as well, but could only remember an average face and blond hair.
"Don't worry, I'll break him and we'll have that information," hissed Major Treodon. Sayer felt the Major's hot breath in his ear. "Isn't that right, Sayer?"
Despair blended with anger. Anger blended with fear. Sayer wanted to weep and attack and beg, all at the same time. Swallowing the knot in his throat, he lifted his head and glared at the Major. "My name is Sayer Ersk, aid to Governor Galen of Freeloader. As a civilian - "
Topa, the enforcer of the group, smashed his fist against Sayer's jaw, cutting off his words. Of all his captors, Sayer hated Topa the most. He was a behemoth with a bushy black beard and seemed to revel in causing Sayer pain.
Sayer ignored the pain. "As a civilian, I - "
Topa struck again.
Sayer bit into his tongue. "I protest these - "
Growling like a beast in fury, Topa drove his fist into Sayer's eye.
Sayer heard himself cry out. Colors swirled in intricate patterns and his head throbbed with the beat of his heart. He attempted to speak but his mouth failed him. He hung his head and remained silent, hoping he would disappear.
"Let's call it a day, guys. He won't be able to tell us anything if he can't talk." The voice came from the back of the room. It was laced with genuine concern and with something else Sayer could not recognize. Pity, perhaps.
Sayer forced himself to lift his head and looked at the speaker. He was a handsome man with brown hair, a muscular body, and depthless gray eyes. His name was Noah DeMara, but mostly everyone called him Buck. Something about the man seemed familiar, but Sayer didn't know exactly what. Buck seemed uneasy with the interrogation, and had only spoken when Sayer needed rest or water.
When Sayer looked into Buck's eyes, a strange and inexplicable sense of hope swelled his chest. But that hope vanished quickly as Nyle's shadow fell over him.

Noah DeMara winced when Topa's fist slammed into Sayer's eye. It was not the violence or the blood that caused his discomfort, for he was no stranger to either, but it was guilt and shame. He quickly pushed the negative emotions aside and walked over to Nyle and the prisoner.
"We have gone to a lot of trouble to bring you here, Mister Ersk. Now please cooperate. We don't want to hurt you," stated Nyle to the prisoner.
Sayer glared at Nyle and spat blood in his face. Bad move, thought Buck.
Topa's massive fist smashed against the prisoner's jaw.
Buck quickly stepped in between Sayer and Topa, placing a steady hand on the prisoner's shoulder. "I think he's had enough," said Buck, speaking to Nyle but looking at Topa.
Topa glared down at him and slowly turned away.
Buck handed Nyle a handkerchief, amazed that the Colonel had stayed so calm.
Nyle wiped the bloody spit and glared at Sayer. "Get him out of here. We do this again tomorrow morning."
Buck escorted Sayer from the room to a large hallway
then into an elevator. Buck felt Sayer's eyes burning into him, renewing the feelings of guilt and shame. He hardened himself and stared at the blinking floor numbers above the door. "Thanks for getting me out of there," whispered Sayer.
Buck shifted uncomfortably. It was ironic that this man should be thanking him. Me of all people, thought Buck. He tried to keep his voice indifferent, almost harsh. "I don't know what you're talking about."
"You're different than those other guys. Are you a Network officer?" His words were laced with pain.
"No. I'm an ex-cop, who somehow got mixed up in this crazy war." He wished Sayer would be quiet. Each word the prisoner spoke only added to Buck's own inner pain.
Sayer faced Buck and looked directly into his eyes. "Let me go. Just let me walk out of here."
The request was so heartfelt and unexpected that Buck almost agreed. He wished he could, but things were beyond his control. "I don't think that will be happening."
"Please! Help me. I have a family, a wife and daughter! Let me go home to them." Tears filled Sayer's eyes. "It's obvious you don't want me tortured, and that you don't want to have anything to with this. Please let me go!"
Buck felt anger crawl up his spine. It was as if Sayer had looked into his soul and had read it like pages in a book. And for a brief moment, he wondered if he knew about - he cut the thought off quickly. No one knew, and he promised himself to keep it that way.
The doors opened. Buck and the prisoner exited, and entered a bathroom. He handed Sayer a towel and told him to clean himself.
"You won't help me will you?" asked the prisoner. "Are you too scared to stand up for what is right?"
The fuse had been lit; his temper flared. It was Buck's biggest weakness. Once ignited, it was like a raging fire, hard to quench, quick, and sometimes deadly. "Can I ask you something?"
Sayer nodded.
"How were you captured?" His voice hissed.
The prisoner wet the towel and dabbed at his wounds. "I was on my homeworld of Freeloader when three guys broke into my house, stuffed me in a bag, and beat me into unconsciousness. When I woke up, I was in a brig aboard a transport headed for Laldan. Now answer my question, are you too gutless to stand up for your beliefs?"
The flames of his temper erupted. Buck snatched the towel out of Sayer's hands and grasped the front of his shirt. "You have no idea what my beliefs are! So don't think you're talking to some bleeding heart who'll open the door and let you walk free. You are here because you have information we need. You are here because I brought you here." Buck released his shirt with a shove.
"You brought me?" Anger and astonishment laced Sayer's voice.
The fire raged and Buck's hands curled into tight fists. "That's right! I led the team that kidnapped you. So I suggest if you want to stay healthy, you answer the Colonel's questions. Let's go."
Buck brought his prisoner to the detention cells and left without a word.

1421223.title: Hunters

14212231.content:
"Can you break him, Major?" asked Nyle as Buck entered the office after delivering Sayer to his cell. The Governor's eyes were locked on Treodon.
Buck stood by the door and watched Treodon squirm. He had boasted about his prowess as an interrogator and now he had to answer for his failings.
"Yes, Governor. I'll break him. I just need to find a new strategy. Topa and I have some ideas." Treodon's rodent-like face glanced at the giant Lieutenant standing beside him.
Topa nodded at Nyle ignorantly.
Nyle leaned back in his chair, his fingers gently tapping the armrests, and stared arrogantly at the two interrogators.
The look of superiority smeared across Nyle's face turned Buck's stomach. Since Nyle had gained his governorship, Buck had noticed a significant change in the Colonel's behavior and mannerisms. He had become more demanding, less receptive, and increasingly condescending. The dark delusions of authority had snared Nyle in a web of self-importance.
Contempt flared in Treodon's eyes. "I'll admit, Colonel, Ersk is tougher than I had expected, but I will break him. Give me a few more days and he'll talk."
Nyle tore into Treodon, pointing out his failings as an interrogator and as a Network officer. The Governor's bald head turned crimson as he described the unpleasant details of the Major's next assignment if he was to fail in breaking the prisoner.
Kirton moved next to Buck and nudged him. "Things are getting a little tense."
Buck nodded. The tension in Fleet Captain Kirton's voice was evident as well. The prospect of upcoming battles on the untested commander seemed to be taking their toll.
"You think Treodon can get the information from Ersk?" whispered Kirton.
"He's good, but Sayer's tough. It's hard to say."
Kirton sighed. "Want to get a drink later?"
"No. I've got things to do." Buck patted the Captain on his shoulder and moved to the window.
Nyle had finished berating Major Treodon and had moved on to Lieutenant Topa. Buck watched the giant man tense at every vicious word.
"Are you some kind of mindless pet of Treodon's?" The veins in Nyle's neck bulged. "I can promise you a long tour of guard duty. No more of the luxuries you enjoy with Treodon, because if you fail, I'm going to break up this little partnership and you'll never work with him again."
Topa's massive hands curled into fists and his eyes stared at the floor. Buck knew Nyle had hit a nerve. Topa and Treodon had worked together for years and had developed a close friendship. The loyalty Topa displayed for the Major was almost perverse.
Treodon patted the Lieutenant on the back and stepped toward the desk. Suppressed rage seeped into his words. "If you're finished, we have work to do, Governor. Sayer Ersk will talk tomorrow. I promise you."
A chill shot down Buck's spine. He feared for Sayer's life. The look in the interrogators' eyes said it all - Sayer would talk or he would die.
Nyle dismissed them with a wave of his hand and the two interrogators barreled out the office. Nyle turned to Kirton. "Are my forces ready?"
"Yes. I have everything in hand."
"Are you ready?"
Kirton's eyes widened and the muscles in his neck tightened. "I'm ready. But the information would make things easier."
"You may not have that luxury, Captain." Nyle sounded like a parent scolding a child. "I suggest you prepare for that contingency, or should I find a replacement?"
"No, sir." The Captain sighed heavily. "I'll be prepared."
"I hope so. You are dismissed, Captain."
Buck watched Kirton leave. He looked as if he were on the verge of crying. "I'll talk to you later, Kirt." Buck smiled reassuringly. Kirton forced a smile and disappeared behind the office door.
"He's nervous. I'm worried," stated Nyle as he propped his feet on the corner of his desk.
Buck knew this was an invitation for an opinion. "He'll do fine, Nyle. I think it's just a case of pre-battle jitters."
Nyle smoothed his red eyebrows with his index finder. "Maybe. You have any problems, Buck?"
He thought of mentioning the overly severe beatings of Sayer, but quickly decided against it. "No, sir." Buck watched Nyle pluck his nose hairs. He suddenly wanted to leave.
"Good night, Buck. Have Ersk here by the fifth cycle of the morning and inform the others of the time change." Nyle flinched as he yanked a stubborn hair.
Buck turned away quickly. "Good night, Governor. See you in the morning."
As Buck left the office, Kirton confronted him. The Captain's lips quivered and his hands shook. "Is he going to replace me?"
Buck grasped the Fleet Captain's shoulder and squeezed it reassuringly. "Relax, Kirt. He was just kidding. You're not going to be replaced." Buck hoped not.
A sigh slipped from his lips. "You want to get a drink?"
"I told you I can't. Maybe Tomorrow. Oh, I almost forgot. We're starting at the fifth cycle tomorrow. Okay?"
Kirton nodded.
Buck took the elevator to the second floor and entered Treodon's office. The Major and the Lieutenant eyed him suspiciously.
"Nyle said we're starting a little earlier tomorrow - the fifth cycle," informed Buck, trying to sound casual.
"Why?" demanded Topa.
"Because he said so," snapped Buck.
"We'll be more than ready," stated Treodon, anticipating Topa's reply.
Buck locked eyes with Topa. "You'd better be." He turned and withdrew from the office. They were planning something. He saw it in their eyes.
Buck left Network Headquarters and headed home. As he rode in his glider, a car that rides on air, Buck wondered if Sayer would survive beyond tomorrow.

14212231.title: Hunter - Interrogators

142122311.content:
Desna tried to open the door for what seemed like the hundredth time. It was hopeless. The door was locked, making her its prisoner. Tears of despair formed in the corner of her eyes. She could not understand why this was happening to her.

Crawling back onto her cot, she looked sullenly about the room. It was virtually empty. A cot and a small table with two chairs were the only furnishings. She hated the room and hated being its prisoner.

The fading sunlight filtered through the only shuttered window, its faint rays spreading across her small, pale face and casting a faded glow on her long, red hair and reflecting off her icy blue eyes. Her petite features displayed a sense of wisdom that contradicted her age. Desna was only twelve years old, and she couldn't understand why anyone would want her as their prisoner.

She had been here several days. Her jailer visited twice a day, bringing her food and allowing her bathroom privileges. He was an Hunter just like her with handsome features and a soft voice. He always asked her if she needed anything or if she was all right. She ignored his questions and tried to look as pitiful as possible.

She missed her parents and wondered if they were looking for her. Desna wished she knew why she was here. Closing her eyes, she reenacted in her mind the events which had brought her to this prison.

She had been sleeping in her bed when the sound of voices woke her. Sleepy eyed and yawning, she went to investigate, and in her father's office found four men stuffing something into a large bag. Desna tried unsuccessfully to slip away. Her jailer noticed her and moving quicker than she had believed possible, grabbed her. His hand quickly covered her mouth, muffling her scream. Something jabbed her in the arm and blackness engulfed her. When she awoke, she was a prisoner in this cell.

The door slid open and her eyes did the same.

"Everything okay?"

It was her jailer. She stared at the ceiling and tried to force tears into her eyes.

"I got your food. It's Timrek with rice. I hope you like it." He placed the food on the table.

The thought of dashing out the door crossed her mind, but she knew he was too quick. She was tiring of playing this pity routine and chose a new strategy. It was time to get some information. "I'm not hungry."

He looked at her suspiciously. "You have to eat."

She stared into his gray eyes and feigned the saddest expression she could muster. "I hate eating alone. Will you eat with me?"
The jailer seemed to give it some thought and nodded. He smiled sincerely and offered his hand.

She was taken aback by his charming smile and instinctively reached out for his hand. "What's your name?" she asked as he guided her into the chair.

"Noah, but I think you can call me Buck." He eased into the other chair and smiled. "What's yours?"

She never hesitated. "Desna." She smiled back and began eating. She could feel herself starting to like this man, and
that was something should could not allow. She needed to stick to her plan. "Why did you bring me here?"

Buck shifted in his chair and she could see his eyes searching for an answer. "It was unintentional."

"What were you doing in my house?" She realized she had caught him off guard.
Buck sighed and slowly shook his head. "It's rather complicated."

"Buck, what do you want with me?" She could see him squirming. He was definitely not prepared for this. She decided to press even harder. "Buck, why won't you bring me home?"

"Well, Desna, it isn't that easy."

"Why?"

"Because it just isn't." A slight hint of frustration seeped into his words.

"Can I go home?" A tear rolled down her cheek. Nice effect, she thought as she casually brushed it away.

"Eventually. Just bear with me."

"When can I go home?"

Buck took a deep breath and smiled at Desna. "Do you need to go to the bathroom?"

"No." He's not getting out of this that easy, thought Desna. "Why don't you tell me what's going on?"

He glanced thoughtfully toward the window. "Okay, kid, maybe you do deserve to know what's going on." He looked directly into her eyes. "Let's set some ground rules, okay?"

She nodded and stared back, trying hard not to blink. She was surprised by his sudden cooperation and suspected some kind of trick.
"First off, there will be certain questions that I can't answer. If you hit on one of those questions, I'll say `Can't answer' and we move on. Understood?"

She nodded. The distrust faded. Feelings of fondness crept back in and she allowed them to stay. Just for a while, she thought.

"Second, I don't want any crying. Third and last, I end this anytime I feel like it. Got that?"

"And I can end it anytime I want to, too. You got that?" Desna tried her hardiest to look tough. She had to hate him. Buck is the enemy she reminded herself.

Buck smiled. "Agreed. First question."

Desna straightened and folded her hands in front of her. "Why did you kidnap me?"

Buck mocked her movements. "It was an accident. You stumbled onto us and left me no choice."

"Why were you in my house?"

"Can't answer."

She bit her lip and glared at him. "Where am I?"

"Laldan."

"Do you plan to let me go?"

"Yes. I promise."

"Are my parents all right?" Desna pictured them in her mind.

Buck hesitated. "Can't answer."

Panic gripped her heart. She fought back the tears.

Buck gently put his hand over hers. "I had hoped you wouldn't ask that, Desna. Your mother is fine."

"And my father?" Her voice quivered. She wanted to pull away from his touch, but she found it strangely reassuring.

Buck's jaw tightened, and for a moment Desna thought he was going to break rule two. "Your father has been taken prisoner by the Network."

"Why?" His touch was suddenly vile. She yanked her hands away and gripped the edge of the table.

"Can't answer."

"Why, Buck?" She spoke through clenched teeth as the first feelings of actual hatred shattered the fondness she had felt for Buck.

"Next question." His eyes bore into her.

"Because of the war?"

Buck nodded and slid his hands under the table.

Desna wanted to cry. She wished rule two never existed. "Why is there a war?"

"What?"

"Why is the Network and Confederate fighting?" She didn't know why she asked this, but she couldn't think of anything better.

"It is rather complicated."

She had some understanding of the war, but never fully understood why the two governments were fighting. It had never been all that important to her, until now. All of sudden, it was the most important thing in the galaxy. "Tell me anyway, Buck. Tell me about the war." Desna figured if she knew more about the war, then she may be able to figure out a way to help her father.

"Where do you want me to begin, Desna?"
