142122311.title: Desna

1421223111.content:
Buck could feel himself sinking in a mire of sympathy. His heart went out to Desna. The guilt he felt for bringing her here threatened to overwhelm him. He cursed himself for letting her get to him.

It wasn't just pity and guilt at work. Desna impressed Buck from the moment he saw her. She had a maturity and a directness that he found appealing. Her presence demanded respect and honesty, and Buck decided he would give her both.

"I want you to start at the beginning," commanded Desna.

"Okay, the beginning it is." Buck sank into his chair and collected his thoughts. "I guess we will start on Rigel IV, the Hunter homeworld. About a hundred years ago, the government on Rigel IV was weak and the Hunter people were in disorder. According to stories, crime, violence, and poverty were common sights on the city streets. The Hunter civilization was slowly tearing itself apart.

"Ten of the most powerful Ruddy Hunter families decided a change was in order. They created an organization called the Hunter Network. Don't ask me why they called it that. I don't think anyone knows. Anyway, in a matter of twenty years, the Network had removed the old government and had established themselves as the legitimate ruling body."

"I learned some of that in school," interrupted Desna, "and my teacher said the Network used murder and threats and bribes to gain power. Is that true?"

"Yes. Their methods were questionable, but they did manage to clean up the cities and unite the Hunter people on Rigel IV."
"What about the other Hunter planets? How did they get control of them?" asked Desna.

Buck leaned forward and rested his elbows on the table. "Well, according to history, many of the colonies that surrounded Rigel IV asked to join, but I suspect some asked and others were forced to join. Eventually, all the Hunter planets in Hunter space were under Network control."

"When did the Network takeover Laldan, Freeloader and Doo III? Those planets aren't in Hunter space. They're in the Triangle. What right did they have to take over worlds in Free Space?" asked Desna, her voice rising in anger.

Buck remained calmed and smiled. "They didn't exactly take over those worlds. The government of Laldan asked to join the Network and Freeloader was liberated from the IKS."

"You mean taken over?" Desna pointed an accusing finger at Buck.

A sigh escaped from his lips. "After all the planets in Hunter space were united, Laldan asked to join. The Network quickly accepted them and that was that. As for Freeloader, it gets kind of complicated. The IKS had taken advantage of an unexplained mass hysteria on Freeloader. They moved in quickly and claimed it as their own."

"Why did the IKS want Freeloader?"

"As you probably know, the IKS is a splinter group of the Empire. They broke off from the Empire and settled in the Triangle. Over the years they gained strength, but lacked resources. Freeloader was a perfect source for just about everything and it also served as a very strategic military base. But the IKS didn't hold Freeloader for long. The Network, in their first real military offensive, liberated the planet and sent the renegade IKS back to their own territory."

"You mean they chased out the IKS and took the world for themselves," stated Desna.

Buck started to object, but then thought better of it. He was not about to argue politics with a twelve year old girl, no matter how smart and insightful she seemed. "Have you ever heard of Zirkon Arc?"

She sighed and rolled her eyes. "Of course I've heard of Governor Arc. He was only the leader of the Confederate!"
Buck narrowed his eyes and fought to hold onto to his patience. "Before he was the Confederate leader, he was a strategists for the Network. He devised and executed the attack on the IKS, and as a reward for his success, the Network appointed him as planetary governor of Freeloader."

Desna shook her head. "I didn't know that, but what does all this have to do with the Network-Confederate War?"
"I'm getting to that now. After Arc was appointed, he convinced the council on Doo III to join the Network. Seven years passed. During these years two noteworthy things happened, the Network acquired the planet of New Era which is also located in the Triangle, and the Network's leaders, the Convocation, became very secretive and mysterious. They relocated to a secret base and only communicated with their most trusted officers.

"Then, without notice or cause, the Convocation issued a directive, that's a law of sorts, called Affirmative Action."

Desna's face hardened and her eyes narrowed. "That's when you guys started hurting the Green Hunters. Right?"

Buck raised his hands defensively. "Wait a minute, Desna. I don't know what this you guys stuff is all about, but I never had anything to do with the oppression of the Greens. When Affirmative Action was started, I was still a cop for the Triangle Police."

"But you are a Network officer."

Buck couldn't deny that. He also couldn't deny his dislike of Green Hunters. His aversion of the Greens could be attributed to his upbringing. All Ruddies were taught that Greens were different in their behavior, their intellect and their morals. He questioned those teachings now, but the feelings of distrust ran deep and were hard to shed. The mutual disunity between the Ruddies and Greens had existed since Hunter history began, but was always tempered by tolerance and laws. Buck remembered when the Affirmative Action was initiated it was like declaring war on the Greens.

"I wasn't a part of the Green oppression, Desna," stated Buck flatly. "I'll be honest with you though. When the directive was issued, I was in full support. Lots of people were."

"Why?"

Buck looked at the ceiling thoughtfully. He wasn't sure why the Affirmative Action received so much support. The Network did a fabulous job at keeping the issue vague and complex, supplementing it with propaganda. Ruddy Hunters seemed more than eager to seize the idea that Greens were the cause of any or all problems on Hunter worlds. The hate came easily. "I'm not really sure, Desna. For five years, the Action was carried out with very little objection or resistance. The Greens tried to revolt, but they lacked leadership."

"And this is where the war begins. You see, the Green oppression started on Rigel and was steadily extended to the other Network worlds. As on the homeworld, it was embraced by many of the Ruddies like a long lost child. But when the policy reached the Triangle worlds, the Network faced their first resistance"

Desna smiled. "Arc."

"Right. Arc and Governor Zardes of Doo III opposed the Affirmative Action directive and revolted against the Network itself. Arc and Zardes created their own government, calling it the Hunter Confederate, and as their first official action, they launched an unsuccessful attack against Laldan. The Network declared war, and that's how the war got started." Buck eased back into his chair and folded his arms across his chest.

"That's not the whole story!" Desna stared at him accusingly. "What about Galen and the IKS? What about the parasites? What about - "

Buck cut her off. "It's late, and I have to get going." He was tiring of the history lesson, but that was not the real reason he wanted to leave. Desna's eyes, her expressions and her voice cut through him with knives of guilt and shame. He felt an overwhelming urge to put distance between himself and his captive.

"Why did you kidnap my father?" demanded Desna as she walked around the table.

Buck headed for the door. "I'll be back tomorrow morning. Good night, Desna." He raced for the door, but a sharp pain erupted in his left knee.

WC: 1317
1421223111.title: Origin of War

14212231111.content:
"What right do you have to take my father and me from our home!" cried Desna, her leg rearing back for another assault.

The pain in his knee was mild compared to the aches raging through his heart and soul. He needed to escape, to get away before he fell prey to the girl's demands and to his guilt. He shoved all the pain aside and reached for the door's controls. Pain suddenly washed through his groin and slowly edged toward his stomach. He dropped to the floor and curled into a ball.

A blur of motion moved past him and out the door. Buck recovered quickly and stumbled after her. His temper boiled. His hand instinctively reached inside his jacket and grasped his holstered phaser. He pulled his hand away from the weapon as if it were fire. He shook his head vigorously, trying to clear his mind. What am I doing, he asked himself, I can't shoot her.

He quickly scanned the room. He was in the living room of his apartment. Desna's prison was a connecting storage room. He did not see her anywhere. "Computer, lock all exits. Code Noah two."

A shimmering blue light washed down the front door and sealed it shut. Buck stood in front of the storage room and listened. Silence.
He called out her name and stepped toward the sofa. He heard a rustling to his right and quickly turned. A metal figurine struck him just above his right eye. The pain was quick, but intense. He dropped to one knee and grabbed his head. A tender knot was already forming. He could not believe he was getting his ass kicked by a twelve year old.

"That's enough, Desna!" Buck moved toward her, but she was gone. "Damn it, you can't get out of here!"

"Why did you kidnap my father?"

The voice came from somewhere behind him. He turned and saw a glass object speeding for his face. He dropped and rolled behind a chair. The object smashed against the wall. He knew he had to get control of this situation quickly. The noise would attract attention, and that was the last thing he needed. Buck breathed in deeply and closed his eyes. He traveled into his mind, blocking out emotions, ignoring physical pain, and forgetting all concerns. He honed in on his one goal, capture and subdue the girl. Instincts, cold and penetrating, swept through his body, tensing muscles and keening the senses. His eyes snapped open, gray and hard.

He stood and examined his surroundings like seeing them for the first time. Another object, a small iron tray, raced toward his face. His hand snatched it from the air and dropped it noiselessly onto the chair. He heard the girl speak. The words muffled in his ears. He moved like an animal stalking prey, maneuvering between furniture. He paused and listened. Her breathing was heavy. She was very close.

He sprang over the sofa, glided behind the small bar, and snatched her by the back of her neck. The muscles in his neck tightened like cords of taut rope. His fingers tightened and slid around her tiny throat.

Desna struggled to free herself, but his grip was like a vise. She screamed.

Do not kill her, echoed in Buck's mind. Subdue the girl. Immediately, his hands relaxed and slipped over her mouth, deadening the intensity of the cry. Teeth sank into his hand, blood rolling down his palm. He felt no pain. He wrapped his arm around her waist and carried her to the storage room, his bleeding hand still covering her mouth. He shoved her inside, her teeth slipping free from his hand.

"I hate you!" screamed Desna as she spat his blood into his face.

Buck ignored her and pressed the door's controls. The door slid shut and locked. The bloody spit rolled freely down his face.

WC: 650
14212231111.title: Desna Escapes

142122311111.content:
The internal fire of his temper slowly died. The physical and emotional pain broke free of the mental barriers and washed over him like a tidal wave. Buck sat on his worn sofa and stared at the featureless wall as his muscles relaxed and his senses dimmed. A muffled sobbing from an adjoining room filled the silence of the small apartment.

He looked at the door of the storage room and thought about Desna. He could have killed her. Her innocent face haunted him, calling forth emotions that clawed at his soul. That he was responsible for her misery left him feeling confused and powerless.

He wondered how he had been transformed into this person, a stranger. A man no longer sure of his beliefs and his duties. A man who had kidnapped an innocent child, had participated in her father's torture, and had done nothing to right the situation. How had he lost control? The answer was as evasive as the night at daybreak.

Buck entered his bathroom and cleaned his wounds. He wiped the dried blood from his face and gazed into the mirror. How had he come to be in this situation? His past rose out of his mind and paraded before him.

He remembered how he, as a Triangle Police Agent, and several other agents had accompanied the Director of the Triangle Police to Freeloader for a diplomatic mission and how during this mission he had learned that the Network's leaders, the Convocation, and many Network officers had been taken over by a hostile and intelligent parasitic race. He remembered how he had quit the Triangle Police and joined the Confederate, and how he and several others had joined Arc's strike team and how they had traveled to Rigel IV and destroyed the parasites. He remembered how he had returned to Freeloader and had learned that Arc had mysteriously disappeared, and how Galen, the Assistant Governor, had taken over the Confederate. At the thought of Galen, anger stirred in Buck's chest. He quickly pushed it aside.

He recalled how Galen had put him and the others of Arc's team into prison and how he had claimed it was for the team's protection. He remembered how he had met Nyle, a Network officer being held prisoner by the Confederate, while he had been incarcerated, and how the renown IKS ambassador, Karstagg, had suddenly arrived on Freeloader to talk to Galen, and how he had persuaded Galen to free the strike team from jail. He also recalled how Governor Zardes of Doo III had been suddenly assassinated and how quickly Galen had declared himself Doo III's new leader. The anger he felt toward Galen stirred once more, and this time he let it linger as his recollections continued.

He recalled how he had decided to abandon the Confederate and support the Network, and how he had freed Nyle from prison and how they had escaped the planet in a stolen ship. He cringed as he remembered hearing the news about Galen and the IKS's alliance, and about how Karstagg had deserted the IKS Empire and joined the IKS. Galen had then given the traitorous Karstagg and his vile IKS forces Doo III in exchange for military support in the Network - Confederate War.

The feelings he had felt then renewed themselves in a sudden burst. He felt the anger toward Galen and the determination to defeat the Confederate and to reunite the Hunter race surge through him. He remembered how he had sworn to himself and to Nyle that he would do anything to ensure a Network victory.

Nyle and he had reached Laldan and Nyle had been appointed Governor. Buck recalled how Nyle had asked for an oath of loyalty when Nyle had appointed him as a governor's aid, and how quickly he had taken that oath.

Buck entered his bedroom and stripped off his clothing. Slipping into bed, he stared at the ceiling. Nyle had given Buck the order to kidnap Sayer Ersk, claiming it was necessary to insure a Network victory. Buck had objected, believing it wrong, criminal even, to kidnap a civilian administrator who happens to possess needed information. Nyle had insisted and had reminded Buck of his oath. If anything, Buck was a man of his word and he had reluctantly agreed. He had hired three civilians to help him, keeping their identities a secret from everyone, even Nyle.

Buck closed his eyes and wondered if he had made a mistake in taking Nyle's oath, or if he had made a mistake in taking Desna as a captive. Both seemed like the right thing to do at the time, but now he just didn't know. He had wanted to take the oath and to help his people, hoping to right the wrongs committed by the parasites and by Galen. He had had to abduct Desna. If he had left her, he and his team would have never escaped Freeloader before she had alerted someone.

And that left Sayer Ersk. His death would eventually be ordered, whether he gave the information or not, and Buck knew he would never let that happen. Buck felt he would ultimately have to choose between Nyle and Sayer and Desna Ersk, and no matter what his choice somebody was going to get hurt.

Sleep dimmed his thoughts and he wondered anew how he had lost control of his life. An answer never came and sleep plunged him into the world of dreams.

WC 914
142122311111.title: Sleepless Night

1421223111111.content:
The detention cells in the Network Headquarters were clean and brightly lit. The hum of a forcefield created a constant background noise that was only interrupted by the occasional scraping of a Network officer's boots. Day and night were meaningless within the prison, for windows and the sense of time were nonexistant.
Sayer Ersk sat on the edge of his bed and stared at the shiny white floor. His body was exhausted and battered, but his mind was strangely alert. He supposed it had to do with Buck's revelation, but he knew it was something else as well.
Buck had caught him off guard. He fumed at himself for falling into the oldest psychological pitfall faced by hostages. He had allowed himself to believe Buck would help him. The idea of Buck being his kidnapper still seemed incredible, but Sayer had to accept that Buck was the enemy. A vision of Buck being vaporized by a blaster flashed in his mind. He wanted to smile, but his swollen face wouldn't allow it.
He thrust Buck from his mind and decided to deal with him when the time came. Other things demanded his immediate attention, such as Galen. It was odd. With his captors questioning and beating him on a regular basis, he considered Galen, the Governor of Freeloader and leader of the Confederate, his biggest threat. He had the information the Network wanted, but he would never tell. His silence had nothing to do with loyalty or a sense of duty toward Galen or the Confederate, but rather fear. He was scared of Galen, or rather scared of what Galen might do to his family and the families of others.
Sayer closed his swollen and bruised eyes. A conference room appeared in his mind. A long table surrounded by chairs sat in its center. Galen was at the head of the table with two IKS soldiers standing at each shoulder. Ten other men sat around the table waiting for Galen to speak. Sayer was one of these men. The others were various aids to Galen and Confederate officers.
Galen cleared his throat, his green eyes studying each man carefully as if looking for any sign of treachery. Galen was a small Ruddy Hunter with jet black hair, yellowish skin, and pale thin lips. He did not look like a man of authority, and he reminded Sayer of a slick, fast-talking salesman.
"Seal the room and perform security sweep level ten." Galen's voice was overconfident and cocky. A forcefield shimmered around the perimeter of the room and scanning beams intensely probed each man present.
The computer approved all security measures and Galen leaned back in his chair, a smirk creasing his thin lips. "This meeting, gentlemen, and all issues discussed will be under security code fifty-seven red."
Sayer had never heard of security code fifty-seven red, but he knew it wasn't good by the gasps from several Confederate officers.
A civilian, like Sayer, raised his hand and waited for Galen to acknowledge him. Galen nodded curtly. "Governor Galen." His voice was uncertain. "I'm not familiar with that code."
Galen looked at the man disdainfully. "Someone tell him."
Sendoc, the Fleet Captain and a Green Hunter, stood. "It means that all information revealed here will not leave this room." Sendoc paused and glanced at Galen. "And if a leak from anyone in this room is discovered or suspected, all of our immediate family members will be terminated."
"All family members of the person suspected of the leak?" asked one of the officers.
Galen shook his head and frowned. "No. All family members of everyone present in this room, regardless of who is the leak. If one of you betrays us then I will be forced to terminate each and every one of your families." Galen sounded almost hopeful.
Each man at the table looked at the others like seeing them for the first time. Sayer wanted no part of this. He was not willing to put his family's lives on men he didn't even know. He raised his hand and waited to be acknowledged, for he knew the procedure well.
"Galen, I do not wish to be involved in this!" It was the civilian who had spoken earlier.
Everyone in the room tensed. Sayer's hand dropped to his side. No one could believe that someone had spoken without recognition from Galen, and had failed to call him by his proper title.
The man realized his mistake at once. He tried to apologize but it was too late. Galen's eyes narrowed and bore into the helpless man.
"Very well. You're dismissed." Galen's voice was cold and unfeeling.
No one breathed as the man walked to the door. Sayer was unsure as to what was going to happen, but he had a pretty good idea. His hands gripped the armrest until his knuckles turned white.
The man paused before the door and turned toward Galen slowly. "Governor, I can't get past the forcefield." His face was pale and his breathing ragged. "Can you lower it?"
Galen grinned wickedly, his back to the man. He bowed his head slightly and Sayer swallowed hard.
The IKS to Galen's right administered a brutal chop to the man's throat. Sayer closed his eyes. He could hear the victim coughing and gasping for air. Several more blows were delivered, each sounding more brutal than the last, and then silence. Sayer opened his eyes and watched as the IKS vaporized the man with his disruptor. The smell of charred flesh filled his nose. Sayer thought he was going to be sick.
"Let's get on with the meeting," stated Galen in an obviously casual voice. "Sayer, you had your hand up. What is it?"
Sayer stared at the tabletop, too scared to look into the Governor's eyes. "Nothing, Governor. It can wait. It wasn't important." Sayer thought his voice sounded very far away.
"Very well. As you know," declared Galen, "Nyle escaped recently with the help of one of Arc's men, Noah Demara, and we need to work on security - "
Sayer's eyes snapped open and gazed at the detention cell floor. That's where he had heard the name before - Noah Demara. Buck! He just remembered it. He was one of Arc's men. He used to support the Confederate. A sense of hope filled his chest, but he quickly crushed it.
He may be able to use this information, but he had to remember Buck was an enemy. He didn't know why Buck had changed his allegiance and that was what he had to find out. Then use it to his advantage. If he was going to play mind games with Buck, Sayer knew he would have to rely on his wits and not his emotions.
Sayer stretched himself across his bed and closed his eyes. He thought of his family and hoped they were safe. His absence may have caused Galen to issue the termination order, but Sayer didn't know Galen well enough to predict his actions. Hopefully, Galen wouldn't act rashly. Hopefully, his wife and daughter had enough sense to go into hiding for he had told his wife about security code fifty-seven red.
Sayer was on the verge of complete exhaustion. He hoped he had the strength to make it for another day. He had to escape soon. He would never tell the Network what they wanted to know - the consequences of that were too dreadful - but he didn't know how much longer he could survive the beatings. If he didn't get free, he knew he would soon be dead.
Sleep finally overcame him and plunged him into the world of nightmares.

WC 1278
1421223111111.title: Memory brings Hope

14212231111111.content:
The communications light flashed in the dark room like a beacon, intermittently bathing the large room with a red glow. Each flicker of red light was accompanied by a shrill high-pitched sound.
A large fleshy man stirred in the bed next to the comm terminal. He slowly rolled himself to the edge of the bed and ordered the computer to produce a dim light. The room brightened slightly. The large man wrapped a huge robe around him and settled into the overstuffed chair in front of the terminal. He violently jabbed a button on the comm panel and the lights and sounds died. A small screen in front of him came to life, illuminating the rotund man's features.
His face was round and flabby with a slightly paler hue than an average Ruddy Hunter. Layers of fat folded into each other where his neck and head connected. His hair was jet black, greasy and thin. Portions of his scalp were easily visible through the strands of hair that swept back from his forehead. Light green eyes, cold and glassy, swept over the screen. His bushy eyebrows raised as he poked at another button.
A figure cloaked in shadows appeared on the screen in front of him. The dark form shifted and squirmed in his chair. He cleared his voice before speaking. "Mister Fliss? Naylind Fliss?"
The obese man nodded.
The caller swallowed hard. "Sorry to disturb you. It's me, again."
The other nodded again. "I know who you are. What do you want?" His voice was soft and compelling, not at all compatible with his physical appearance.
"It looks like I'm going need you after all. We're getting nowhere. Can you be here tomorrow morning?" The caller folded his legs and seemed to tense.
Fliss leaned back, his chair moaning in protest. "That depends. We haven't discussed payment."
"I haven't much money. How much do you normally charge?"
An arrogant smiled creased Fliss' lips. "More than you could afford. Payment comes in other forms. A promised favor will do."
The dark figure was silent a moment. When he spoke, his voice lacked any semblance of confidence. "Sure. I promise you a favor." He hesitated. "What sort of favor?"
Fliss leaned forward, his eyes cold and lifeless looking. "Whatever I ask. Deal?"
"Just one favor?"
Fliss nodded.
"All right. We have a deal. Be at Network Headquarters tomorrow at the fifth cycle of the morning?"
"First, send me all your data on this Ersk character, and all actions done to him thus far. Second, will you have every thing prepared for my arrival, as we discussed earlier in the week?"
"Of course. Every thing is arranged, and I'll send you the files immediately."
Fliss nodded and terminated the call with a vicious jab of his plump finger. The screen blinked into blackness. Tapping his fingertips lightly together, he waited for the promised information.

WC: 482
14212231111111.title: A Late Night Request

142122311111111.content:
The sun rose over the southern hemisphere of Laldan, shooting tiny streamers of light into the cloudless sky. The greenish waters of the Deep Brint wore the sunlight like an overgarment. Seabirds screamed as if heralding the dawn.
A flittercraft skirted the water's surface, disturbing the serenity of nature. The seabirds scattered at its approached and sections of the Deep Brint's garment shattered into tiny pieces. The craft was small and circular with a transparent bubble encasing the small deck and its passengers.
The pilot worked the small control panel that was situated in the center of the vessel. He stared ahead at the large island as it drew near.
A short, stocky, Ruddy Hunter with greasy, gray hair and a thin mustache glanced over the pilot's shoulder. He wore a standard Hunter Network uniform, a black jacket with maroon trim, black pants, and long maroon gloves and boots. The yellow letters "HN" were emblazoned on his right breast, and on his left breast was a name badge that read Gramey Marect. On his collar was the insignia of a Lieutenant. His hands constantly tugged at the jacket's collar and readjusted his belt and holstered disruptor. After each readjustment, he would look to the rear of the craft at his companion for approval.
His companion, who also wore a Network uniform, nodded indifferently and stared across the Deep Brint. He wore the rank of Captain and his badge identified him as Paxton Dovic. His face and body looked as if it had been chiseled from stone, hard and unyielding. A long, thin, browned scar ran from his left eye across his protruding cheekbone and ended at his chin. His hair was shaved close to the scalp and had the color of a walnut. Dovic's brown eyes occasionally glanced at the large figure standing at the front of the craft.
The large man wore a Network uniform. A thin cigarette rested between his plump fingers as he stared at the horizon. The sun shone in his glassy green eyes. The uniform's collar was barely visible beneath the rolls of fat gathered at his neck, but the rank insignia was unmistakably that of a General's. The letters on his left breast spelled out the name Urish Rouchet. He sucked on his cigarette and exhaled slowly as Marect cautiously approached.
Marect cleared his throat and spoke, his voice raspy. "Fliss, I'm still not - "
A low growl sounded from somewhere beneath the General's layers of fat.
Marect flinched. "Sorry. General Roket."
Fliss eyed him without moving his head. When he spoke, the air seemed to chill. "Rouchet. Just call me General."
"Right, General. Got it. I'm still not sure about this."
Fliss never moved, his eyes returning to the horizon. He took another drag on his cigarette.
Marect glanced at the pilot then at Dovic and then back to Fliss. "We can get into a lot of trouble here. Why all the fake names and disguises?"
Fliss turned to the pilot. "Dock at pylon station seven." He turned back to the horizon without waiting for a response.
Marect bit his thumbnail. "I don't like this setup, Fliss." He bit into his lip, almost drawing blood. "I mean General."
Fliss dropped his cigarette and crushed it with his huge booted foot. Smoke curled out his nose. "Go away." His voice was barely audible over the craft's turbines.
Marect chewed on his upper lip and sighed. He stared at Fliss momentarily and scurried away.
The flittercraft glided around the western edge of the island and approached a small metal wharf built within a cove. The pilot guided the craft beneath the landing and the transparent bubble retracted into the sides of the craft. A circular door in the wharf's flooring slid open as the landing lowered around the round boat. Huge bolts slid out the craft's sides and locked into sockets within the wharf. The landing rose and lifted the flittercraft from the water.
Fliss stepped off first with his two companions following. A Network darter was parked at the edge of the wharf. The darter looked like a large, black and maroon sled. Inside the front of the vehicle were two seats facing a control panel, and in the back was a long, overstuffed seat that extended the width of the darter.
A beach of gray sand ran along the perimeter of the island and ended at a dense forest. An ironmetal road extended from the wharf's edge and cut through the forest. Fliss headed for the darter parked on the road and Marect and Dovic followed.
Halfway to the darter Dovic turned and faced the flittercraft. He pointed a small cylindrical object at the pilot. A cluster of tiny needles sprang from the cylinder and embedded in the pilot's throat. Dovic, his face inexpressive, turned and walked to the vehicle as the pilot instantly collapsed in a lifeless heap.
Marect and Dovic occupied the front seats while Fliss rested his massive frame in the back. Marect punched in the required security code to unlock the darter's controls and powered the engine. The darter smoothly lifted about a foot above the road's surface and glided forward. Marect navigated the vehicle up the road until he reached a small forcefield with a sign reading "Pylon Station Closed For Repairs". Dovic pushed a sequence of buttons on the darter's controls and the forcefield shimmered and vanished. The vehicle continued on and the forcefield was reestablished.
The darter glided into the city. Fliss' eyes stared forward, as did Dovic's. Marect took in the sights with the curiosity of a tourist. Network soldiers casually patrolled among the island's residents. The buildings, tall and sleek, were packed together tightly. Floater vehicles filled the ironmetal streets.
The island's newest arrivals wormed their way through the streets and eventually left the city and entered a decidedly residential area. The buildings were multi-storied and elongated with neatly arranged patches of plasti-grass surrounding it. The soldiers here were considerably less than in the city, but their presence was nonetheless evident.
The dwellings ended abruptly and a dense forest appeared. The trees and thorny undergrowth hedged the ironmetal road, casting shadows across the three men. The traffic had steadily lessened and was now nonexistent.
The road wound through the thick woodlands for several miles, leading to the center of the island. The darter followed a bend in the road and the forest suddenly ended. Several large structures enclosed by a domed forcefield lay ahead.
Fliss called the vehicle to a halt and nodded. Dovic exited the darter and disappeared without a word into the forest. The darter and its two occupants continued toward the structures.
The ironmetal road ended about forty feet from the forcefield where a small building was situated. Marect shifted nervously in his seat as a Network soldier exited the building and approached the darter.
"Welcome to Network Headquarters, gentleman," greeted the soldier indifferently, "Your names?"
Marect glanced back at Fliss's name badge and then down at his own. "Lieutenant Marect and General Rouchet," he quickly stated.
The soldier snapped to attention and managed a quick glimpse at the huge man in the back seat. "Good Morning, General."
Fliss' lips curled upward as he turned his glassy eyes on the solider. "Tell the Governor I wish to see him."
The soldier nodded and all but ran back to the guardhouse to contact Governor Nyle.
The General tapped his fingertips lightly together and waited.

WC: 1243
142122311111111.title: Ruse

1421223111111111.content:
"General who?" asked Nyle to the communications screen on his desk.
Buck and Sayer had just entered the Governor's office. Nyle motioned for Buck to place the prisoner in his usual chair.
"A General Rouchet, Governor, sir," answered the guard as Buck gently placed Sayer in his chair.
Buck noticed he was the first of the group to arrive. He had started his day earlier than usual. Desna had still been asleep when he had delivered her breakfast. Sayer had said nothing to him and Buck had done the same.
"Standby, soldier." Nyle waved Buck behind the desk and spoke in a hushed tone. "Buck, have you ever heard of General Rouchet?"
Buck shook his head and glanced at Sayer. He appeared to be asleep.
"Neither have I. He's here to see me. Check the computers," commanded Nyle.
Buck walked to a small worktable with a computer interface on top of it and accessed the Network personnel dossiers. Nyle glanced through his appointments on a small hand held computer.
"Here it is, Nyle," announced Buck, "General Urish Rouchet. Homeworld is New Era and his current assignment is labeled as classified."
Nyle furrowed his brow, tossed his small computer across the desktop and strode across the room. "Classified! Who's his superior?"
Buck scanned the screen. "Assistant Director Ehogan of New Era."
Nyle marched to the window and stared at the front gate.
Buck sensed the uneasiness in Nyle. It was obvious the Provisional Governor of Laldan was wondering just how provisional his governorship would be. An uneasy feeling settled into Buck's stomach as he joined Nyle at the window.
They could see the Network darter waiting outside the forcefield. Even from the window the General's huge mass was obvious.
"Why do you think he's here, Buck?" The anxiety in Nyle's voice was evident.
"I don't know. Maybe an inspection or maybe to provide some orders."
"Maybe. Maybe not." Nyle stared at the General as if he were trying to read his mind.
"What are you guys looking at?" asked Captain Kirton as he peered over the men's shoulders.
Buck and Nyle started at the sound of his voice. Neither had heard him enter the office.
"A General wants to see Nyle," answered Buck as he steadied himself.
"He looks awfully fat. What's he want." Kirton squeezed in between the two men for a better look.
"We don't know. Ever heard of General Rouchet?" asked Nyle.
Kirton seemed to think for a moment. "No, sir. Maybe he's your replacement."
The look Nyle shot the Captain was deadly. Kirton stepped away from the window and took another step away from Nyle.
"You'd better not keep him waiting, Colonel," advised Buck.
Nyle glanced back at the General, nodded and turned to the comm screen. Beads of sweat dotted the guard's forehead. "Send him through, soldier. Tell him I'll be glad to see him."
Major Treodon and Lieutenant Topa entered the office as Nyle terminated the communications. Treodon carried a large briefcase, and Topa cradled a roll of black plastic.
"Morning, gentlemen," greeted Treodon as he placed his case next to Nyle's desk.
Buck turned from the window. The General was being admitted into the headquarters via a secured underground passageway. Buck watched Topa toss Sayer's chair aside and spread the black plastic across the floor. This didn't look good. Topa replaced the chair directly in the center of the plastic. Not good at all.
Nyle ordered his secretary to prepare briefing room seven for the General's arrival. He asked Treodon if he had ever heard of the General.
Treodon shook his head, opened his case and removed a long, jagged, curved blade. He smiled wickedly.

Nyle ignored the Major and asked Topa the same question. The lieutenant also shook his head. "I want you to contact New Era, Buck. Demand to know the General's orders."
Buck stared at the vicious weapon in Treodon's hands. "I'll contact Assistant Director Ehogan. It will take two days to reach him and two more days for a response. You can't stall the General for that long." Buck faced Nyle. "It may be nothing at all, Colonel."
"Send the message anyway," ordered Nyle, "if he is my replacement, I want to be prepared."
Buck nodded and dispatched the message from the communications console. "We should have a response in about four days, Governor." He walked back to the window and watched the Network darter approach. How had the General gotten on the island? The question slipped into his mind with the suddenness of a tornado. The island's magnetic screen prevented beaming and the incoming and outgoing traffic of the island was closely regulated. An unscheduled craft approaching the island would be detected and halted. The General had to have made arrangements with someone to gain admittance on the island. Whoever that someone was should have informed Nyle. Buck leaned next to Nyle and was about to mention it when Topa caught his attention.
The Lieutenant was attaching straps to the prisoner's chair's armrests - he was attaching straps to an empty chair. Buck's heart shot into his throat and he bolted upright, his eyes furiously scanning the room.
Sayer Ersk was gone.

1421223111111111.title: Nyle's Unexpected Visitor

14212231111111111.content:
The Network soldier crashed to the floor as the broomstick snapped in two across the back of his neck. He attempted to stand, but a hand seized the back of his hair and smashed his face into the floor. His nose shattered and darkness engulfed him.
Sayer dragged the soldier by his feet into a supply locker. His hands shook as he removed the unconscious man's uniform. He had never struck another man in his life, and now that he had, he found the sensation both exhilarating and repulsive.
The stolen Network uniform fit well. Sayer bound the soldier with his discarded clothing and hid him at the back of the locker. Fatigue was closing in around him and he dropped to one knee to catch his breath.
His escape had surprised him. He couldn't even remember making a conscious decision to walk out the office. Buck and Nyle had forgotten him, their attentions absorbed with something out the window. Before Sayer knew what he was doing, he was hurrying down the hall outside Nyle's office. Kirton had passed him in the hallway, but the Captain appeared to be preoccupied with his own thoughts and Sayer went by unnoticed.
Sayer felt stronger and stepped back into the hall and quickly walked toward the stairwell doors.
A sign to his left caught his attention - "Environmental Control Room". He dashed into the room and a young soldier turned at his entrance.
"Activate fire suppression for the Governor's office!" shouted Sayer.
The young soldier's eyes widened. "There's a fire!"
"Hurry up! It's spreading!" Sayer bolted toward the controls. "You'd better activate the suppression system for all of the adjoining rooms, just to be safe. Hurry!"
The soldier's hands started pushing buttons and entering codes.
"Do you smell smoke?" asked Sayer as he exited the room and flew down the stairwell.



Buck moved away from Nyle and stared out the window. A smile creased his lips. Sayer escaped! He hoped he would never see him again.
"The interrogation will have wait until after I meet with General Rouchet," stated Nyle, looking at his chronometer. "Bring the prisoner back to his cell."
Buck winced.
"Sayer is not here!" Treodon anxiously surveyed the room.
"What? He was here!" Nyle joined the Major in his visual search.
Buck turned to Nyle, disgust filling his heart. "He must have walked out. I'll look for him."
"You have to alert the base, Governor! Ersk must not escape!" Kirton was frantic.
"No. Not with the General here. Topa, Buck, and Treodon, I want you find him. Kirton alert the guards in the front lobby," demanded Nyle.
Buck followed the Major and Topa out the office. The chances of Sayer escaping seemed hopeless. He would never make it out the building.
The foam injectors in the hall fired, spraying high pressured froth everywhere. The floor turned slick and Buck went down on his buttocks. The fall was painful but Buck couldn't help laughing. Sayer was indeed a man of surprises.
Topa and Treodon managed to stay on their feet as they rushed down the hall. Buck lifted himself to his feet as Captain Kirton barrelled out Nyle's office.
"The communications system is off-line! I have to contact the guards in the lobby! Sayer must not escape." Kirton sounded like a lunatic as he slid uncontrollably toward Buck.
Buck grabbed the blathering Captain by the front of his jacket and flung him down the hall. The Captain was airborne for several seconds, then landed hard on his back and skidded across the foam. He slid into the running Treodon and the Major toppled onto him.
Buck smiled as he watched the two men flounder over each other. Topa started to turn back to help, but Treodon waved him forward and shouted at him to find Ersk. The Lieutenant nodded and trudged around a corner.
Nyle slowly stepped from his office and stared at Buck. Globs of foam caked the Colonel's bald head. Buck shrugged and
followed Topa.

14212231111111111.title: The chase is on

142122311111111111.content:
The steps streaked past Sayer in an indistinguishable blur. He had eight floors to descend, and by the time he had reached the fourth floor his body protested with waves of pain. He stumbled to the third floor and collapsed on the stair's landing. The hard metal floor cooled his fiery skin, sending chills along the base of his neck.
The past two weeks of beatings had taken their toll on Sayer, leaving his body unresponsive and feeble. His breath came in small gasps and his lungs ached for oxygen. The wounds to his face cracked and oozed blood.
The sound of a door opening several floors above Sayer echoed down the stairwell. He violently forced himself to his feet and glanced upward as the sound of boots crashing down the stairs filled his ears. The footfalls approached rapidly and terror rose in Sayer's heart.
He raced toward the second floor's landing and felt his knees buckle from exhaustion halfway down the stairs. He tumbled down the stairs, bruising flesh and opening wounds, and plowed into the landing like a fallen meteor. He painfully rolled onto his back and gazed upward. His pursuer was one floor above and approaching at breakneck speed.
Sayer frantically crawled for the door leading into the second floor's hallway. He could feel the blood flowing across his shins as he lifted himself next to the door and grasped the handle.
The landing rocked as Topa's massive frame dropped into view. A sheen of sweat covered his forehead and his bushy beard had trapped globs of white foam. A smile of stained teeth appeared from beneath his beard.
Sayer dove at the huge man. Rage crushed all reason. The hatred for Topa filled his being and gave his body an unexpected surge of strength. The palm of Sayer's hand smashed against Topa's forehead, driving the big man's head into the wall. Sayer's knees slammed into Topa's chest and drove the big man downward, dragging his head along the wall. A howl escaped from Sayer's lips as he pushed the Lieutenant toward the floor.
Topa's head came to a jarring halt and his body went limp. Sayer's momentum hurled him over Topa and onto the ascending stairs. He twisted around quickly, anticipating a counterattack. There was none.
The blunt end of the handrail had driven itself into the back of Topa's skull. The huge man's stained teeth still smiled at Sayer from beneath a pair of lifeless eyes.
Sayer rose to his feet mechanically as he stared at the dead man's eyes. He heard himself laugh, a strange crazed laugh. An invidious coldness stole over his body and he fell into a void of darkness as tears replaced the laughter.


Nyle buttoned his jacket as he met Buck in the hallway outside of the Governor's quarters. He had changed his uniform and was rushing to the elevator.
Buck matched the Colonel's pace and tried to recoup his breath. The scene in the stairwell still had him shaken and he was not looking forward to breaking the news to Nyle. He remained silent until they had entered the elevator.
"Well, we found Sayer." It was best to start on a good note.
Nyle nodded. "Good. Where's the General?"
"I don't know." With all that had happened, Buck had forgotten about Rouchet. "Topa is dead."
The elevator rocked to a stop as Nyle jabbed the halt button. "He's dead? How?"
"I'm not sure. I found Topa and Sayer on the second floor stairwell. Topa's head had been impaled by the handrail."
"Sayer killed him? That's hard to believe."
"I know, but right now it's the only explanation. From the angle of the injury, there is no way he could have fallen."
Nyle chewed on his bottom lip. "Where's Sayer?"
"He's in the infirmary. I found him not far from Topa's body curled into a ball and weeping. He was totally incoherent. The doctor believes he's in shock." The thought of Sayer caused waves of guilt to wash over Buck. It was all his fault.
"Have you told Treodon?" asked Nyle as he restarted the elevator.
"No. He's going to want blood."
"He'll have it - after I get the information."
Buck pushed the halt button. "Nyle, we need to talk."
The Governor looked at his chronometer and sighed.
Buck ignored him. "I am very uncomfortable with this whole situation. Sayer is a civilian. Can't we get the information from him and then let him go?"
Nyle shook his head. "That is not procedure and you know it."
"I feel responsible for Sayer. I brought him here and I don't want his death on my conscience."
The veins in Nyle's neck bulged. "Then you can relieve yourself of this assignment any time you feel like it. I do not want to hear another word about this. If you can't do your job, I'll find someone else." Nyle jabbed the resume button and the elevator continued.
Buck's jaw tightened. The fires of his temper stirred. "I thought the objective of this whole war was to unite the Hunter race, not to exterminate them. Killing Sayer makes us no better than Galen."
"In every war, Mister DeMara, sacrifices have to be made and prices have to be paid. Sayer Ersk's death will be one of those sacrifices and your guilt will be one of those prices. I did not force you to take an oath of loyalty and no one forced you to kidnap Ersk. You chose to do both on your own. Now deal with it."
The elevator stopped and the doors opened. Nyle stepped into the hall and turned to face Buck. Every muscle in Buck's body was rigid and his temper was like an inferno.
"I wish I could let Sayer live, Buck," stated Nyle in a softer tone, "but I can't. Especially not after he killed Lieutenant Topa. I understand how you feel, but Sayer's path is unalterable."
Buck's temper fell away and he lowered his head. "I know. It just doesn't seem right. I feel as much a prisoner as Sayer. A prisoner to my oath to you and a prisoner to my decisions. I just wanted to let you know how I feel."
Nyle placed his hand on Buck's shoulder. "I owe you a lot and I'm sorry I can't help you." Nyle quickly lowered his hand to his side and stiffened. "But I do expect you to follow my orders and remain true to your oath. I know I can count on you."
"Yes, sir." Buck felt a strange emptiness in his chest.
"Go change your clothing, Buck, and meet me in briefing room seven. The General is waiting. I just hope Kirton and Treodon remember to change their uniforms." Nyle smiled and disappeared behind the closing elevator doors.
Confusion whirled like a cyclone in Buck's mind, scattering his thoughts like dry leaves. What was he to do? He was being pulled apart by his loyalty to Nyle and his responsibilty to Sayer. Walk away, he told himself, just walk away. He closed his eyes and wished he had never laid eyes on either Nyle or Sayer.
His thoughts drifted and faces flashed in his mind. Arc rallied his troops against the Green Oppression. Galen and Karstagg basked in the glory of their alliance. Nyle demanded an oath of loyalty. Treodon smiled wickedly behind a menancing knife. Kirton slid across a layer of foam. Topa grinned stupidly with a handrail digging into his brains. Sayer wept in a stairwell. Desna kicked him in the groin.
Desna!
The face of the red haired little girl froze in Buck's mind and the confusion shattered like a pane of glass. How could he ever tell Desna that her father was dead? He couldn't and he wouldn't. Somehow, he told himself, he would save Sayer Ersk.

The afterlife is real. I stand in a realm beyond all imagination with my royal father, the King and my sweet mother. I have been murdered by a cowardly assassin after being named as King. I am so pleased to see my mother after the many years on earth without her prescence and with my just discovered father.

My father had named me as King on his deathbed. I had never known I was his son and heir. I was King for less than a day before those who killed my father also killed me.

But now I stand in a place with no name and no limits. There are no parallels with the mundane and heavy earth I have come from. Here, in what I am calling Afterlife, existence is unique. There are no houses, cities or civilizations. I am at a loss for words to describe the joy and relaxed nature of Afterlife. I am happy.

But the happiness is tainted by the circumstances of my death and the anger of my father. According to him, we can still affect the world now lost to me. After our joyous discovery and reunion, my father explained to me that it was possible for us to regain the throne and... life.

"It is a wonder and pleasure to finally be able to acknowledge you, my son. I am saddened and overjoyed that we are finally together. I can not allow the villains who orchestrated, not only my death, but yours as well cannot be ignored. We must avenge our deaths.

"Your mother has informed me that their are mechanisms and rituals available to us allowing us to access to our former world. The throne is still in our reach and we shall reclaim it from those who usurped it with blood and deceit.

"I need your agreement, my son. Do you want to avenge and sit upon the throne you were denied?"

Despite my joy of the Afterlife, there is an pained emptiness in my soul at the manner I was dispatched from my former life. The thought of leaving this world hurts me almost physically but I know I must join my father in his quest for vengence. "Yes father. Let us regain our throne."

142123.title: Dead men deeds

1421232.content:
Like a God and his holy progeny, we prepare for our return to the place of physical lives to regain our throne. My father and I have come to a place surrounded by pink fluffy clouds and penguins with pointy sticks. I was told that the Being in charge of Return to the Earth request "lives" here and that our case must be made. When my my father had said rituals, I had assumed killing a goat or a duck in sacrifice and burning some candles bit I was wrong.

This ritual involves the meeting of the Being of Earthly Returns. I ask my father what is his name and my father only shrugs and repeats, “The Being of Earthly Returns.” To me it sounds like an administrator of the Iron Bank but who am I to judge the ways of the afterlife. I am a mere newly arrived soul looking to return to claim my throne.

I find it odd to think of the throne as mine. It is a seat I have never sat upon and a mantle I have never commanded. All the same I feel it is my right, no - my birthright. So I am claiming my birthright from the darkness of death so that I may rule and avenge all those who plotted against me and my father! So many will pay the price. If my power allows I may go as far as exacting revenge on the families of the usurpers. Kill them all and so none shall ever hurt me again.

I ask father if he would like me to talk to the Being of Earthly Returns.

“I am not certain, son. I have no idea what to expect of this proceeding. I only learned of it shortly before your death from a Being of Information and Orientation.”

I wrinkle my nose. “There certainly are a lot of “Beings” about with odd distinctions and realms of command.”

My father nods. “I agree, but it is the methodology provided.”

My father and I wait for some time in the area of the pink fluffy clouds with the penguin with the pointy sticks. I bend down in front of one of the penguins and smile. ‘Hello, sir.”

The penguin’s left eye twitches. “Oy Ho, fine being. Do you require something of me.”

“Yes,” I reply, “Do you know anything about this Being of Early Returns?”

“Yessir, I do.” The eye twitches violently. “The Being of Earthly Returns decides on who may or may not return to the realm know as Earth.”

“Oh my! So there are more realms than just Earth?” I look at my father. “How exciting!”

My father just harrumphs and delivers a look that says, “Leave the penguin with the pointy stick alone”

I ignore the look that says, “Leave the penguin with the pointy stick alone” and continue in the stimulating engagement. “What is your name?”

The penguin with the pointy stick twitches his eye some more. “I am known as The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick.”

I nod and raise an eyebrow. I pick another penguin with a pointy stick at random and ask him what the name of that penguin with a pointy stick might be.

The twitchy eye of The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick sends a twitchy glance at the penguin with the pointy stick that I have pointed out. “That would be The Dull Yellow Billed Penguin Being with a Slightly Dull Pointy Stick,” says The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick.

I point at another a penguin with a pointy stick in distant. “And him?”

The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick glances a hard twitchy stare and the nods. “That is The Blue-eyed, Buck-toothed Penguin Being with an Extremely Pointy Stick.”

I pick another penguin being but a strange summoning ding formed in my mind that beckoned me to a place beyoung the pink clouds. “Nice to meet you,Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick. I must be going now.”

“Very well,” says The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick.

My father and I leave the area and enter a new area made completely of golden clouds and sparkles. It is quite amazing and beautiful, and seated in a grand oaken chair laced with streaks of glowing blue illumination is The Being of Earthly Returns. It - for I cannot tell if it is male or female - glows a brilliant blue and is human-shaped. I can feel the warmth coming off of it. It reminds me the wonderful comfort of sitting in front of the hearth after coming in from the chill. I cannot see its eyes but I can feel the glare of them upon me. In my mind, I feel the beckoning again. I come forward.

My father, without a word, turns and leaves the area. I watch him go only for the briefest of moments and then I immediately return my attention to The Being of Earthly Returns. I walk forward and stop when the desire to do so overtakes me like a chill.

“YOU WISH TO RETURN TO YOUR EARTHLY ORIGINS. I SENSE IN YOU A DARKNESS AND EVIL INTENT. REQUEST DENIED.”

I scream in protest but then my mind is settled and I accept The Being of Earthly Returns decision. I realize instantly that my intent was impure and fueled by Earthly desires. I needed to see that my life was over on Earth and that this new life could not be directed by my past. I lost all interest in ever returning. I no longer wanted the throne. My new life - my new future - is what I need. Perhaps I be friends with the Penguin Beings with the pointy sticks. There is a whole realm here to explore and discover. I remember the excitement of my conversation with The Twitchy-Eyed Penguin Being with a Pointy Stick.

I return to my father and we never speak of Earth or thrones again. We live as Gods among Gods

1421232.title: The Hand of God

1422.content:
Sir Nigel Gray bore the weight of the newly crowned King and strode across the dark gray cobblestones of the palace. His mind was a jumble of thoughts and choices. The burden of protecting the new King was at conflict with his shame of failing to protect the former King. How long had he served only to have it all taken away - stripped like a slab of cut meat by a sneaky, ass-licking assassin. The life of the King he had protected had defined Nigel since the day he put on a King's Guard cloak, and now that was a steamy pile of donkey shit.

But he had to shove that down and face his new responsibility of this young man’s life. It was hard for Nigel to think of this man as King. The King was now dead. This man was named his successor but he had no idea who this man was. He had never heard of Tyrl Keravin. As far as he knew he had never visited the King nor had the King ever had any dealings with him. This was an utter shock to all and especially to those close to the King. But he had to protect this man whether he was worthy of the title or not. The worth of the man didn’t play into the duty of Nigel’s life. His only job now was to keep the new King alive and hope he was worth the effort.

Nigel chose the servant’s quarters as a temporary safe house for his new charge. He chose this simply as the least likely place anyone looking to do him harm would come looking. He gently laid laid the King into the rickety bed with the threadbare sheets and flat pillow and pulled a chair next to the bed. He gently covered the King with the thread bare blanket.

He stared into his new King’s face, searching for any sign of what kind of King he would be. Nigel liked the face that he saw: handsome, kind and innocent. He realized this man would need more than mere protection to be a good King - he was also going to need loyal counsel. Nigel gently patted the sleeping King’s shoulder - an act he knew was inappropriate for a Guard to do - but he felt an urge to connect with this man. He needed the King Tyrl Keravin to be a living breathing soul that Nigel would be willing to die for. He lowered himself into the chair beside the bed and rested his broadsword across his lap and held a dagger in his hand. Whoever came for the King had better be prepared to die.

A couple of hours passed before the King came awake. He jolted upright in the bed and vomited on the floor opposite of where Nigel kept his vigil. The King’s eyes met Nigel’s. Fear and uncertainty danced in his green eyes. Nigel raised his hand to calm the King when the door to the quarters opened.

A muscular figure in a castle guard’s uniform stepped into the room. Nigel immediately put himself between the stranger and his King. He smiled inside at the HIS King protectiveness that sprung to life. “This is no place for you, guard. Leave now.”

The muscular guard moved his head to the left and the right to see behind Nigel. “We are doing a room to room search for the King. Who do we have here?”

Nigel, dagger in one hand and the broadsword in the other, stared into the guard’s eyes. “How can you look for someone if you do not know what they look like?”

“Huh?” The guard stepped away from the closed door.

“Leave now. I will not ask again,” Nigel said.

“This is our new King?” the guard stated. “Our King is a nobody cowering in servant’s bed, hiding from his new crown. This is rich.”

The dagger left Nigel’s hand without warning or sound. It shot across the room aimed for the guard’s throat. Moments before impact, the guard’s sword arc upward and deflected the dagger. It clattered to the floor. Nigel dropped into a defensive stance while the King rose to his knees on the rickety bed. The attacking guard pointed his sword at Nigel.

“Surely you can see this King is a mistake,” the guard stated, moving sideways.

Nigel tracked the guard but didn’t move. “The only mistake I see is the one you have just made by threatening my King’s life.”

The sword swung in a vicious swipe for Nigel’s neck. He jerked out of its fatal arc and his own blade came up and deflected the strike toward the ground. He used this moment to close the distance with guard. Nigel struck for his opponent’s leg but he evaded. A crushing blow slammed into Nigel’s jaw. His face felt like it exploded and he dropped to one knee.

The guard was of a single intent as he body slammed into Nigel, knocking the King’s guard across the floor, and moving toward the King. The assassin’s blade swiped at the King’s head but the attack was interrupted. Nigel grabbed the guard from behind and crushed his arms and chest with all of his might. The air shot of the assassin’s mouth and he grunted and struggled.

KLONG!

The guard slumped into Nigels’ arms. A huge cook pot covered his head as the King stood upon the bed with his hands still holding the pot’s handle. Nigel released the attacked and man and pot crashed to the floor.

Nigel and the King’s eyes met. Nigel was filled with hope. This King would be very worthy. “Nicely done, majesty.”

The King nodded, breathing heavily. “Assassin? Majesty?”

Nigel smirked. “At least one of them. And you are my King, sire. The crown is yours.”

“Well, it looks like this filth got a crowning before I did, Captain,” the King replied.

“Yes, my King. It certainly appears that way. But I think it best if we get more guards and find a safe place for you to wear your new crown.” Nigel smiled and bowed to the King.

14221.title: A Safe Place

143.content:
Darkness offers too many places for those with ill intent to hide. Before I never thought much of them when I lived in my quiet home, but even though many men offer their hands to me in friendship, I can't readily accept them.

Maybe His Majesty knew about their plotting for his throne all along. It might have been what prompted him to choose a nobody like myself. I cast an uncomfortable glance about the candlelit room and pulled the cloak on tighter. Now that I am alone, or at least very nearly so, I don't know what to do with myself. The guards failed to protect the king before. It might happen again.

My musings are interrupted when a candle sputters and the lacy shadows dance along the pale cream walls around me and my back stiffens. I should be sleeping, but I can't. Every time the movements occur I remember all the whispers about the assassination, and just how deep a wound spelled His Majesty's demise.

A soft whisper drew my attention about again, this time over my shoulder where I thought it originated from. Nothing. I remember that the assassination took place at midnight, and I note that it cannot be far from that time now. Should I call my guards, or could one of them be responsible? I don't even know what an assassin looks like, but does anyone?

I stand and begin to pace the length of my room. I got this position whether I wanted it or not. I should do something about this mess. Hunt down the assassin so I could at least live without terror. As I move, a flicker passes in the black window and I hesitate. Part of me wants to rush over to the window to make sure the motion was only me, but my sensible side stops me.

Outside the guards' metal shod feet clank against the floor with monotonous rhythm as they walk a short distance away from my door. I tighten my fingers into fists until my nails pierce my palms.

That's when my candles sputtered and died, choking on the overflow of wax. I stumble in the middle of my strides and my heart throbs with awful strength against my ribs. My eyes struggle to adjust as I grope towards the candles. A breath of wind passes softly against my cheek and I jerk aside.

Something moves in the dark, I am sure of it. I reach for the dagger I use for eating. As a weapon it would do little good, but it has to be better than fighting a shadow with my fists.

Even if I cannot really see, movement still swishes nearby. Some of the patches of blackness stir unnaturally and I can feel the presence lingering nearby. My fingers clench over the warm wax of a candle and I jerk it towards myself with a rustle of my kingly robe. As I fumble with it, I manage to catch just enough of my breath to form words.

"Guards!" I call.

A soft brush of some cloth rushes alongside my face and an unknown object crinkles as the guards fumble with the handle of the door. Although I cannot be sure, I am sure that the assassin has left me even before the door opens. The raw orange torchlight sweeps across the room as the guard strides in, his unfriendly face cast in the copper glow.

"Your Majesty?" He asks, doubtful.

My claim as King is already under much scrutiny and I don't need any more trouble. "Please, relight these candles," I manage.

He complies with some care, sets the flickering objects back on my desk, and heads back out at my bidding. My whole body shakes and I brace myself on the desk before me. That is when I notice the note left behind.

1431.content:
I pick up the parchment, the paper dry in my hands. I notice then in the candlelight that they are shaking. I take a deep breath to steady my nerves. The immediate danger has passed and I know that. I just need to remind myself. After all, what sort of King would I be if the people could say I'm afraid of the dark?

I unroll the parchment in my hands and hold it close to the flickering flame on the desk. Shadows dance across it and my eyes are instantly flicking over the words. I have to force myself to slow down, to start from the beginning. I take another deep breath and start again.
         
Dear King,

It has come to the attention of others that your position of power has been gained by some contrivance of bribery. Note that this will come to light in the stark light of day and your power will be stripped, your limbs bound and your skin flogged until it peels from your very bones.

A shiver trickles down my spine and I read it again. The words are short, cold and calculated. Yet I do not know of the bribery which has been mentioned. I was as clueless to my promotion as the rest of the nobles in that room the day the bells tolled. How could this have happened? Somebody must resent me, loathe my uprising, hate the power I now hold.

I Tyrl Keravin, the king, who has been made king by the last will and testament of the last king who was slain, has been subject to slander, a frame-up, a downright lie. The more I thought about it, the more I felt the power of the manteau on my shoulders. How dare they!

My pride was hurt although I knew any pride to self-delusion. While I was a red fish passively observing life from the inside of a fishbowl, how ironic was that, the timid person, a mama's boy, to be exact, would crack the the glass and be lured out into the freedom of a wide, wild ocean, to be made a king to it. I felt like Poseidon now, and not the shabby-looking ineffectual character.

And Poseidon I was when I called for the guards. Forstrone, the chief of the guards, rushed in wirh two armor-clad knights following him. I held the note to his note. “Who put this on my table? Weren’t you around watching this room?” I roared.

“Only who was allowed, Your Majesty,” he replied. “You know we have a list of people drawn by the old king, May his soul rest in peace, and we only let them in here.”

“Bring me a copy of that list and alert the head investigator. I want this person, who wrote this note and put it here under my nose, brought to me so I can deal with him with the proper justice that he deserves.”

“Yes, Your Majesty,” Forstrone bowed and walked backwards to exit the throne room with the two knights at his heels.

After he left, I sunk to deep thought. This character who was out to get me through his lies and sneaky trappings evoked my curiosity. Why would anyone partake, through such a serious nature of lies, in such a personal intrusion to my welfare or rather the welfare of the kingdom?

It had to be someone close to the deceased king who had his very eyes on this throne on which I was sitting. The throne wasn’t even a comfortable one. With all the gilded fancy work adorning it, the workers had omitted the seat. No wonder the old king had a faulty gait. Once I would solve the puzzle of the note, I decided to do something about this seat. After all, no king should feel resentment against his throne.

“Your Majesty, Chief Guard Forstrone requests your counsel,” the guard at the door announced.

“Send him in!”

When Forstrone appeared I crooked my finger for him to approach.

Forstrone walked in front of me and bowed. Then he handed me a scroll.

“The list you asked for, Your Majesty,” he said.

“All right,” I said calmly. “You are entitled to five gold pieces for your promptness. Now, tell me, who do you think on this list wanted the throne after the old king?”

“Thank you, Your Majesty,” said Forstrone, with an embarrassed chuckle. “I think everyone on that list did. All of them are suspect.” And then with a note of appreciation in his voice, he added, “Only you, Your Majesty, were seen fit above and beyond those in the list. I have heard the deceased king refer to Your Majesty as a first-rate person, and I am always faithful to my kings, as I now pledge my loyalty to you, Sir, that I will do my utmost to bring the culprit to justice.”

Me? A first-rate person? Never underestimate the value of a few gold piece to buy loyalty, but I knew what I was doing.

“Thank you, Forstrone,” I said. “You may go, now, and do the best you can for this matter. Please!”

Forstrone backed up as he bowed. I barely heard him remark at the door, “A king who says please…”

Then I glanced at the list.

On the list was a huge circle branded in red wax. I scraped the wax edge with my nail and lifted it up. Staring at the names under that, I gasped. All the names of the members of the Council for the Realm, were glaring at me, the poor-boy king, who felt he had no business being where he is. All he had wanted to live a simple life and play his banjo.

Unfortunately, that wasn’t meant to be. I had to suffer through this ordeal, and my existence from this day on would be all about endurance. All my inner peace disturbed I sent for the chief investigator, Achenay.

He arrived without delay.

“Your Majesty?”

I handed him the list. “In this list are the names of people who are out to assassinate me just like the king before. Find out who, and I will see to it that he gets his just punishment.”

“But Sir,” he said, “I can’t do that. Our kingdom is a small kingdom like many. These people are working under the supervision of the Realm Master. We don’t even clearance to their files.”

“Then find a way. Any way,” I said, the future of our kingdom depends on it. Obviously, one of the Council members wants to incorporate us into his kingdom. This doesn’t concern my life anymore. If you don’t do this, our kingdom will be no more, and our people will be used a slaves by the larger kingdom. Do you want this, Achenay, for your family, your mother, your sisters, your sons, your neighbors?”

“Forgive me, Your Majesty, surely you’re right; however, I don’t know how to go about this as I said we have no clearance.”

“Achenay, this person must be absolutely, positively destroyed, brought to justice, whatever. We cannot put this kingdom at risk. For that end, I am willing to put my life on the line. But are you willing to put yours?”

Achenay bowed. “Definitely, Your Majesty,” he said. “If I am nothing else in my life, I’m loyal to my country and my friends.”

I stepped down the throne and stretched my hand to him. “Then, consider me your friend, Achenay. I will protect you if your efforts come to negative ends or if you are ever found out by the Council.”

“I’m truly honored, Your Majesty,” said Achenay, taking my hand and shaking it vigorously. “As long as we watch each other’s backs, we won’t be ruined.”

“And if nothing else works, we will have done the best for this kingdom, at least we will say we tried it.”

Now that I got Achenay on my side it was up to the history to write itself. The soldiers would fight, yes, but they would be protecting the kingdom, and those battles probably wouldn’t even be fought for years to come, again, if we established our power. It was a good decision I made to convince Achenay and he made a good decision to accept my proposal.

Our tiny decisions that could make or break us. Thousands and thousands of lives were always changed by tiny decision. And those changed lives would go onward to affect the rest of the realm and even the rest of the universe.

Pleased with myself, I climbed up to sit at the throne with that terribly hard seat. Now, who should I call for a pillow?

14312.content:
After a restless night of little sleep and vivid dreams of daggers and shadows, I awoke to a gray, misty day. I knew exactly the person to do my spying for me; someone I had used many times in the past with great results. My fool. No one would suspect my fool, because, rightly, most people thought she was an idiot.

She, you ask? Yes, she. The village idiot, they said, never amount for anything but milking cows or breeding other idiots with a shepherd. Her real name is Calliope Canters, but everyone at the castle calls her "Dum Dum" or "hey you" or "Fool". She and I prefer it that way. Callie is still young, but wise beyond her years. An unfortunate birthing accident with a pair of delivery tongs by a sodden butcher of a doctor, and Callie was born before her time with a misshapen head and as short as a five year old, although she is probably twenty by now.

Her mother was going to sell her for a new pig. I heard about it from my man about town and carriage driver, Donovan, an Irishman by birth, and the only person I really trusted in my castle besides my dogs. Donovan has a soft heart although he tends to cover it up with peppery language and a brusk manner. He was walking by the market square and saw poor ten year old Callie tied to a fence post with a misspelled sign announcing: Good for keeping house-mute girl-sold for a fine pig or best price. When Donovan saw her, his heart flipped. Despite her funny big head and tiny body, she had flaming red hair and eyes as green as Irish sod. She resembled his youngest sister, far away in the Emerald Isle. So he bought her, thinking she would be good help mate for his ailing wife.

What Callie was, though, was a sack of bones and skin, who didn't have enough energy to milk a cat, never mind a cow. Donovan's wife didn't have the heart to through the little mite out, even though she hadn't spoken a word. So, he made up a fine Irish yarn about how smart she was and how clever and told his best friend, the King.

When I met Callie, she had clean hair, shorn close to her head to get rid of the lice she had come with, a plain brown shift, good shoes on her feet, and hope in her eyes. I decided to make her my fool, since she was tiny and odd looking. But she couldn't make me laugh.

Instead, I found myself watching her go about the light chores I asked her to do. She reminded me a stray dog I once adopted, who ended up being the county champion sheep herder during the trials. She always did what I asked, and sometimes did what I asked before I opened my mouth. I think she was watching me as much as I was watching her.

After about a year of the two of us watching each other, Callie found her way into my study. I was trying to figure out what to do in the case of Widow Sandal, who had a mouth on her like a viper and a mean spirit. Widow Sandal was claiming the land next door as hers, because the new owners had never made proper use of the land, but let it go to meadow. She was insisting it was hers because the law of the land was such that all lands needed to be made useful for crops, or for recreation. Widow Sandal had beans she was waiting to grow.

Callie heard me muttering to myself. She wiggled up into the high chair next to me and adjusted her long green gown. Callie made all her own clothes from the fine fabrics I had picked out to match her coloring. This one managed to make her look older and taller than she really was.

"It's simple," she said, in a clear, crystalline voice.

I almost fell off my throne. "You can talk?" I asked.

"Of course I can speak. In fact, I know three languages. It is interesting what a girl can pick up in a bawdy house," she replied, a grin on her lips.

I blushed to think of my fool in a house of ill repute.

"Donovan didn't tell me that was your last employer. I thought,.."

"Sire, I am as virginal as the new snow outside. Why do you think the old bag was trying to sell me for a pig? No one would want to bed a girl as small as their daughter. Unless of course," she answered.

"Yes, yes, let's not think about such disgusting types of people. I didn't know you had an education. I thought you were just.."

"Sire, my father was a wandering teacher, a magician of sorts. He wanted to take me with him on his travels, but his horse came lame, and bandits waylaid him on the way to get me. He was killed in a sword fight. I hid his collection of books from my mother so she could not use them for firewood or to sell for more food or trinkets. I have knowledge of the stars, the medicinal herbs and the law. I even know what your courtiers are saying behind your royal back. Would you like to know?" Callie had a full grin now.

"Fool, you should have told your king as soon as you were comfortable here all this. I have wasted a year trying to figure out what that scoundrel Sir Lackjaw has been saying. Speak, girl!"

The fool, Callie, looked straight in my eyes and said:
