14313.content:
Although I know what I must do, I don't have a good enough idea of how to do it. I need someone's advice, and I don't know who I should dare trust or if I dare. But as the danger is already gone and only left me this threat, I take it to mean that they are not going to come back yet.

I can't understand why anyone would think I could bribe, but think it they do. I cast a longing glance at my bed and draw a deep breath into my lungs. Sleep would be nice, but now is not a good time. I fold the creased parchment in thirds and pull the unwanted mantle of my new status tighter around my shoulders. I head towards the door. The hinges let out a muted squeal and nearby armour clinks as the guards lean out to check what is going on.

"Sire?"

"I have urgent business to attend," I say as I ease the door closed.

The guards exchange curious glances, then nod. I grasp one of the torches and turn aside. Maybe this will inspire a touch more faith in me, though I am grateful for the darkness. It hides the fact that my knees still feel like water and my jaw clenches against my will. As long as they can't see it, I seem like I'm stronger than I am.

In my brief tour of the castle during daylight hours, I had observed the presence of a fantastic library. The man caring for it is elderly, and somehow doesn't seem like as much of a threat as the younger courtiers nearby. The Elder Scroller. Perhaps he will be willing to lend his counsel to me, or at least offer some insight on the letter.

The fingers that aren't curled around the splintery torch curl into such a tight fist I can feel my blunt fingernails digging into my palm. I would never bribe anyone, and I couldn't have. My very purpose for being at the castle was to ask for financial assistance. I hesitate. Did they think I had something else to bribe a king with, or perhaps the man that brought me the cloak in the first place?

I remind myself it doesn't matter, because they still think the same of me, and hurry onwards. The far side of the castle is still in eerie silence, save the soft clanks of armour and the murmured voices of guards somewhere down the hall. Two of these guards stand erect in front of the library door and bend their knees at the sight of me. I slip past them without pause. I don't have time to be stalled.

Even before I can begin my search of the Scroller, a whisper of sound catches my attention. I look back.

"Sire," the old, creaky voice makes me jump. "What brings you at such a late hour?"

I compose myself and loosen the death grip I have on the torch so the wood no longer set into my flesh. Though I promised myself I would try to be less obtrusive, I can't help but cast a surreptitious glance about the room. Just in case. In the feeble shadows I see nothing that stands out as dangerous, and return my gaze to the withered old man before me. His crouched posture, dull, ink stained jacket, and quizzical green eyes I take in with a quick look.

"Can I help you?" He asks more directly.

"I hope so," I say. "You are sure you don't know why His Majesty chose me to succeed him?"

I fancy his eyes narrow at the question. "Yes, Sire, quite sure."

"Perhaps," I somehow manage to keep my voice steady, "you could tell me more about this assassin's habits... and I'm in some need of suggestions. How can I show that I deserve this power?"

"King Tyrl," the old man says as he begins to make his way across the eerie, dark confines of the library, "there is a scroll with a legend here. Maybe I can't answer your question directly, but you might find what you're seeking in there."

My doubts are not so sure, but I follow him anyway. The mantle of royalty seems to weigh more than ever before on my shoulders, and I try to straighten my back. It does not help. The weight is still there. The message's burning warning still flashes through my mind in warning. I shudder.

For such a bent man, the Elder Scroller moves with surprising agility as he thumbs through parchments soft and wrinkled with age. I fancy some of them are older than he is, but it must be a close match if they are. At last he eases one scroll free of a pyramid of others. The stack trembles, but somehow contrives to stay upright. This rolled parchment he holds out to me in one claw-like hand. I take it with some misgivings.

"It might hold your answers, Your Majesty," he tells me. "How you can prove yourself, and why you were chosen."

The scroll in question is so wrinkled and yellowed with age that I find it difficult to comprehend how it could have anything to do with me. I'm a young man yet, though this job seems to age me by the minute and I haven't even survived a week. But he stares at me with such urgency that I sigh and unwind the parchments from their fastenings.

Even the delicate rustle sends a nervous spike down my back, but I shove it away. The fading ink is so pale on the parchment's surface that it appears more brown than black, and in some places ancient stains mar the otherwise undamaged scroll. I squint in the feeble torchlight, but I can only make out a few words. Tyrl. My name?

The light adjusts as the Scroller walks about behind me and holds it aloft. Thanks to this, I can make out the beginnings of a legend I have never heard of before, but too many words are blotted. A cold claw wants to rake through me. I take a deep breath and hold it higher so the orange luminescence brings them out.

It is a letter.

A new king was born in the wake of the old one's demise. The gods choose one who is below all the others, someone who was not born great, but learned how to be great instead. Tyrants are not respected, they are feared. Assassins are not loved, but hated...

The words are too rubbed out for me to make out more. It tells me nothing. I have no greatness.

"I don't understand," I say in frustration. "How can this help me?"

"There's more, King Tyrl," the Scroller reminded. "You just have to decipher it. Your coronation is today. Sleep well."

I listen as he shuffles away, but I know I won't sleep. The night is too old, and I am too tense. The only thing I can do is try and decipher a useless old scroll with my name on it, and try to avoid the gruesome threats in my letter. How could I do that?

I remember with a start that I came to see the man on his opinion of my threatening message. I roll the idea of showing it to him about in my mind, then turn as he disappears down one of the many aisles of scrolls.

"Wait!" I call. My voice is muffled in the closed space, and I wonder if he can even hear me.

Before I can repeat my cry or advance towards the shelf, his wrinkled face shows up around the corner once more, this time a scowl creases his brow and he clutches a particularly yellow scroll in one hand. I have to admit, he works very fast.

"I was - was given a letter," I say as I pull the crumpled note from my sleeve. "It seems odd that the assassin is able to write, so I assume it can't be a peasant. I wondered if you would recognize the handwriting?"

I doubt it will be so simple to locate the person responsible for the previous king's death, but cutting the assassin out of the picture would make my life infinitely easier. Easier to hang on to. I didn't have much time, and even if I clutched at the faintest lead possible I need all the help I can get.

The Elder Scroller's eyebrows arch in curiosity and he slides the burden he carries back in place with a rustle of old parchments. This out of his way, he approaches me with choppy, hobbling strides. I hold the letter out to him before I can stop myself and he snatches it from my hand with such speed I fear he might have torn it in half. But he holds the whole message aloft to the feeble light and squints.

He hemmed and hawed about the damaged evidence and turns it over in his hands several times. I shift my weight between my feet. What does he see that I missed earlier? Or is it nothing?

"Your Majesty, I do not know the writer of this message's handwriting," he admits at last. "It may or may not be one of the courtiers and noblemen here right now. I couldn't say."

A sudden desire to tear the parchment washes over me in waves, but I keep myself in check and content myself by biting the inside of my lower lip. It is a mild pain, but it helps keep my mind occupied on something besides my frustration and fear.

"But I can give you a few names of people that didn't write this."

It feels as though a cloud is swept from over my head. It might help narrow down the possibilities. That would make me somewhat safer, perhaps.

"You must remember, though, that it could be a forgery."

I catch myself before I groan, and incline my head to the man. "I understand."

He opens his mouth to speak when something taps to the ground somewhere in the recesses of the library's vast space. Movement shifts, and another scroll clinks down. I stiffen and silence shrouds the entire expanse of the room. Though I listen, I can make out no further sounds. An eavesdropper?

"I will write it for you," the Scroller says in a hushed tone. "You can make of it what you will then."

It seems to me that the scroll is my best chance to figure my role out and come up with a plan of action. It's too closely related to me, since it has my name on it. I don't think there is a hero or king with a name quite like mine. Call it conceit if you will, but I would have known if there was.

I turn from the room with a sweep of my unwanted mantle and let myself into the quiet hallway beyond. I still hear the clank of the guards' armour nearby, but it's small comfort. I rush to my chambers as the first light of dawn begins to turn the carpets gold before me and yank the door shut in my wake. Not that it would stop any determined assassin, but the note says I will be exposed as a sham. I find it hard to believe they would do so in the lonely confines of my room. Nobody would see the show.

The thought makes me grimace and I set the scroll down on my desk with a clack of the wooden rod that holds it shut. This is all I have to show for my efforts. My disappointment is stronger than my helplessness. That's saying a lot, because I feel like I am floating in place with no idea how to get out of the boat I am stuck in. Worse, it seems the king that appointed me his heir believed in legends and children's stories.

I set a heavy jar of bluish black ink on the corner of the scroll and unroll it as far as I can. It is then that I realize it will snap shut by itself if I don't find something else. The dagger I use for eating is at my hip, and I pull it from its sheath with a hiss. This I set on the bottom portion of the scroll so its weight holds it down. With this set in place, I grasp one of the spluttering candles so I can see. Soon the sun will be up anyway, but I want to get as much crammed into my head as possible before that crown rests on my brow.

Even with the helpful illumination the text makes no sense to me. My name is written in aged ink, and I am celebrated as some sort of hero born of an unusual relationship. My parents are kept in the records, but to me they are nothing more than names. I do not know them, and I never will as they passed away with the pox disease that spread through the kingdom many years ago.

This never bothered me before, but now I am restless and tired. Some instinct tells me that, although I only ever oversaw a small portion of land, I am not what I thought I was before. Even aside from the fact that I am now the king. I never wanted this position. I just need to prove myself. The scroll tells me fire is my best friend, but as I gaze into the candle's steady flame I am not so sure. Could it be suggesting I show a display of power through violence? How can I when there is nothing to be violent to other than a group of helpless, pathetic peasants?

I'm sure this will do me no good, but perhaps my real rivals are the nobles that eye me from beneath lowered lashes. They are my true danger because they know more of how the kingdom is run than I do. They are the ones I have to put in their place. But the scroll isn't helpful in that regard. It flings riddles at me, and tangles my thoughts so much that I, at long last, feel my head thump down to the desk.

That is when someone knocks on the door behind me. I jerk upright and twist in my seat so I can face the door. They must consider dawn a decent hour to disturb their king at. I set my mouth in a firm line and push myself upright. Even if I don't feel ready, I do my best to bring minor order to my appearance.

"Who is it and what do you want?" I ask.

1433.title: A King's Last Request

14331.content:
The Nobles gathered to select a jury of thirteen to hear the details known about the Assassin, Remundo and his henchmen. Lord Granahan was selected the leader of the jurors and he had the authority to decide the final vote in the matter of a 'tie' if an equal number of jurors decided if Remundo was guilty and was innocent. The same would be decided for Remundo's henchmen who helped him carry out the attempt on the King's life.

Lord Machiman, Earl of Cambria, served as judge.

The King, now safe without fear of another attempt on his life sat in the Golden Throne chair on which the mark of the dagger where his head could have been, was marked with a red circle. The circle was permanent and would be a reminder to him for the rest of his years just how fortunate he had been that one of the guards had intercepted the note which indicated the moment when the dagger would be thrown at the King's head.


The people chattered about the assassination attempt and worried that there might be another try at taking their new King from them. In the few short days of being King, they had already learned to respect him and liked his plans for the country after Justice was completed against the assassins.

Not everyone agreed about the King. Sir Landholm was whispering to three of his friends over in the corner as several people kept looking their way and wondering what they were discussing.

"There's no doubt they'll all be found guilty," grumbled Sir Landholm. "I can't believe young Peter Panship would have had anything to do that. Why, he's not got the sense of a goat so what could he have done to be arrested with the others."

Earl of Kindleford responded. "I heard he's been hanging around Lord Herdling lately so that may be why he was dragged in to the situation. Probably Kindleford had him carry a message or something simple enough for him to do well. We'll just have to wait and hear the charges against him."

"Well," said Earl of Straithorn, "I heard he was the one who put that note on the table. If he did, it's enough to make him lose his head. Poor little stupid fellow. He didn't know better and I'm sure nobody told him the trouble it could cause him."

Sir Landholm nodded. "You're right; he's too stupid to know any better. Poor kid. His mama's going to be in tears for some time after this day."

The Earl of Straithorn added, "Yes, I do feel sorry for her. She's tried to raise him good but it's hard with a boy like that. It's Gordo the Fisherman that led the whole affair, I feel sure. He's been trouble ever since the new channel was constructed across the southeast corner of his land even though it was nothing but swamp. He and Macademium Forestall both got more upset than they should have about losing some of their swampland. I say take both their heads off and save the boy." He laughed like a clown and his fat stomach shook like hell.

The Judge called, "Silence. Silence." He banged his wooden gavel on the table set in front of him. "This hour the jury of thirteen honorable men will listen to the charges and determine which of the prisoners will lose their heads when the sun rises in the morning." He looked at the Jury. "You have the power over life and death for the prisoners charged with attempted assissaciation of our new and beloved King. Now the Captain of the Guards will read the charges."

A hush fell over the crowd as the Captain of the Guards, Lord Byronkinson stood, unrolled his scroll and began reading, "Romundo, also known as Lord Panterion is charged with throwing the dagger which could easily have murdered our dear King. As you can see when you look at the golden Throne Chair of our beloved King, the dagger could have killed him instantly..." For the next hours he and others read their scrolls giving details showing how each prisoner participated in the dreadful attempt on the life of the new King. One thing the Jurors and the crowd noted was that there was a specific request in the presentation that the boy not be found guilty since he did not have the mentality to understand the significance of his placing the note where it had been found by a guard instead of the person it was intended for.

Eventually, the scrolls were completed and the Jury went to the side room to deliberate their decisions. When they returned, the decision was read by the judge, "All of the prisoners except the boy are guilty and this Jury recommends all should lose their heads at dawn."

The Judge turned to the King. "Your Majesty, do you agree with the Jury or do you wish to make any alterations to the decision?"

The King stood, "I agree with the decisions and the punishment and I abhor each prisoner who involved the boy whom they knew did not understand the gravity of doing what he did. I ask his mother to coach her son to avoid doing whatever is suggested to him in the future. The beheading will occur at dawn in the place provided."

The prisoners were taken to the dungeon to await their execution. The people left the castle murmuring about the day's activities and making plans to attend the beheading and join in the festivities which always followed such events in the Towne Square.

In the dungeon, the prisoners were served their last meal before dawn and were led to the place of execution. The crowd jeered as they were led, tied together in a long string of sad and mean men slogging along as slowly as they dared to walk. People in the crowd through wine, water, fruit, and chicken blood on them so they were soaked to the skin and covered with rotten fruit and flies by the time they stopped at the beheading station where three men covered in black from head to toe held large axes which would soon be bloody.

The King's musicians played mournful music until the first prisoner's head was on the block. The drums sounded as one man in black took his place, swung his axe and a head dropped into the wooden basket, leaving the headless body on the ground. Remundo was to be last so he had to watch as his henchmen's heads rolled.

Finally, with blood everywhere on the ground where Remundo knelt, all over the men in black and their axes, and the block which dripped with blood. Just as he was instructed to knell, Remundo shouted, "Let the King Die Today. Let others do what we could not do."

The people jeered and began to chant, "Off with his head; he'll soon be dead" over and over until the man in black raised his axe; then they cheered. "Long Live the King" "Long Live the King" until their King left the scene and those responsible too the bodies to be cremated and the heads placed on poles to line the roadway of the King's City.

14331.title: The King's Justice Pronounced

choices: A man hears Benile and offers his help.
Benile reaches for a plate of food and is grabbed by a guard.
143311.content:
Remundo's head hung over the block stained with his followers blood. The crowd's cheers, "Off with his head, he'll soon be dead," echoed through the square. Remundo's neck pressed tightly against the unyielding block of wood, but he raised his gaze and it settled on a young girl in the front of the cheering crowd.
"Off with his head, he'll soon..." her words trailed off as her gaze met Remundo's eyes.
"I hope the king dies today," Remundo mumbled as the axe glinted in the sunlight as it arced downward through the air, stopping suddenly with a loud thunk. Blood spurted from the clean cut neck of Remundo, and his head dropped, eyes open but no longer seeing, into the basket placed below the wooden block to accept it.
The crowd let out a loud cheer, the noise seemed to vibrate the ground in the square. People danced, laughed, and slapped each other on the back. Far in the rear of the crowd was Benile, a distant cousin of Remundo's, a man who wore a sober face. Turning to the man next to him, he smiled sadly and let his gaze move through the crowd.
"A bribe as simple as a meal, some music, and possibly a bit of debauchery," he said, "in exchange for the lives of so many good men."
The man standing next to Benile, who wore the dark wool robes of a monk, tightened the rope surrounding his ample stomach and replied.
"My son," for a starving people, the lives of many cannot compare to the satisfaction of a full belly." With that he patted the protuberance hidden beneath his stiff, stained robe.

The crowd moved to the edge of town and watched as the basket of heads were brought along the road by a horse drawn wagon. As its wheels creaked over the dirt ruts, people bowed their heads, refusing to see the blood dripping from the seams between the boards that make up the wagon's rear. But as soon as the wagon moved past, the conversations and laughter resumed.
"Did you see that man's body," said a peasant, his voice filled with awe.
"Which man," said a woman wearing dirty clothes, her hair grimy, her hands filthy.
"The one who's body flopped around the platform after his head was removed from his body."
"Oh, yes, I remember that one," she said. Her toothless smile widened with the memory.
"And so many," the same man said, "with so many heads rolling today, the feast should be bigger than usual. "I'm looking forward to a meal like one I haven't had in a long time."
"Look," a disembodied voice rose from the crowd gathered along the side of the road. "There is the first pole."
As the straight pole rose into the air, a head attached to its top, a great cheer went up from the crowd.
"Where is the celebration to be held?" a stranger asked no one in particular.
"I don't know," shouted someone.
"Does anyone know?" someone else shouted into the air.
A guard, his armor scratched from many battles, but still sparkling in the sunlight, stopped and banged the end of his spear against the ground.
"Silence!" He shouted. "I know where you must go."
A great hush fell over the crowd. A great dust cloud rose and moved over the crowd all the people suddenly came to a halt. A voice that sounded like it came from an elderly man rose up.
"Tell us, soldier," he paused as if catching his breath. When he continued his voice had weakened. "For we are hungry and we want to celebrate the King's victory.
"You must follow this road," the soldier pointed with his spear. "You are required to walk past each of the severed heads. Where the road ends--"
"We all know where the road ends," someone interrupted, "It's where the king's castle sits."
"Yes, and in the court yard of the castle a great feast has been laid."
Benile, who up to this point had been silent, finally spoke to the monk who had accompanied him from the bloody square.
"Look at them," he said. "They cheer for the death of their brethren, they cheer for food so that they may assuage their guilt."
The monk patted his thick hands against his stomach, and said, "I have a lot of guilt to be assuaged," he smiled at Benile, "so I had better hurry before there is not enough food left to make me whole again."

The castle court yard slowly filled with people as they passed under the gates at the castle entrance. Some gasped, some pushed others out of their way, some fell to their knees to thank the gods for so fine a feast.
There was a loud tapping that pulled everyone's attention to the balcony high on the southern wall. The king's colors were unfurled over the balcony raid to a great cheer.
"Silence!" A fat, bearded guard who stood on the balcony shouted. "There is food enough for everyone. The minstrels will soon be here for your entertainment, and there will be games of chance that anyone will be allowed to compete with. Another great cheer rose up from the crowd.
Benile stood just inside the open gate and peered up at the balcony displaying the bright red and gold flag of the king. Surely the king will make an appearance there, he told himself. But it will be when the king comes to join the crowd that I will act. Benile's hand disappeared inside his tunic, and his slender fingers stroked the ivory handle of his curved knife. As he stared at the balcony, Benile closed his fingers around the knife's handle.
"My time to act is near," he mumbled. "I will avenge Remundo."

144.content:
"But Bishop VanGrew, this is preposterous!" cried Lord Haversham. "You can't seriously expect us to believe that the King would name a... a lowly lord of some hovel as King, do you?"

The bishop's eyes narrowed. "You would accuse me? The Cardinal Bishop—a man of God—of lying?" Through gritted teeth he seethed, "You would dare?" Apparently, Lord Haversham was not as big of a pompous fool as I had first perceived.

His cheeks flushed an ugly red, his mammoth jowls flapping as he shook his head. “I… I would never—“

“I thought not.” The Bishop turned back to me. “Now, Sire, if you will come with me, we have much to discuss. We must prepare for your coronation.” He reached out and took my elbow, pulling me through the parting crowd. Several curtsied, while others sniffed in scorn. Perhaps I should have objected to being manhandled or even insisted that everyone give me due respect. However, shock had me stumbling along beside the Bishop.

He pushed through the door to the left and entered the King’s chambers. I stared in awe, taking in the red velvet curtains and cushions adorning the high-back chairs.

Shutting the door, he smirked and called, “It is done.”

From behind the door, stepped a regal man—a man, unwounded, and very much still breathing. I dropped to one knee and bowed my head, “Sire? You are alive, but…”

“Rise, Sir Keravin. I hope you will forgive the ruse, but I have need of someone I can trust.”

Rising, I trembled when I suddenly remembered the royal cloak wrapped around my shoulders. I snatched it off and held it out to him. “Why would you trust me, Sire? What have I done to merit such a boon?”

The king shook his head, “For now I would like for you to keep that and as for trust…. Well, let’s just say that I wanted a man who had no ambition, a man who would not want to be king.”

144.title: The Decoy

1442.content:
"Well, you got that right!" I blush at my loose tongue and bow again. "S-sire. As you said, I have never desired the throne. I'm actually quite bad at all these court affairs, in fact! What good could possibly come of making me king in your place?" My eyes go wide as a thought strikes me. "Please, Sire, don't let me get killed! The assassin...!"

The King chuckles. "Do not fear, Sir Keravin. There was no assassin." His voice grows momentarily pensive, the light going out of his eyes for a moment. "Not this time, at least."

"But... there could be an assassin?"

The King shook his head, gestured for me to take a seat, and began his explanation. "I have to go away for a time, without the nobles hounding my every step. Yes, you'll have to face the dangers that accompany being king --including the occasional assassin-- but you'll have my most loyal advisors to help and protect you. They've managed well enough with me so far. You have nothing to fear in their hands."

He waved Bishop VanGrew over. The old man came forward, handing the King a small folded piece of paper before moving to stand off to the side. The bishop still had a slight smile on his face.

The King unfolded the paper and, after reading it himself, handed it to me with a smile. "Read that, then tell me if you find this whole affair untenable."

So I read it.

Turns out, things were a lot worse than I thought.

Leaving his heir to take his place was something he could have second guessed, but it was his duty and at some point his son had with hold the Family name.

14421.title: One Way or Another

14422.content:
Under the cover of darkness, the former king left the city with nothing but a small pack slung over his shoulder, a set of simple but sturdy clothes on his back, and a long knife secured to his belt. No one looking at him would have recognized him as the King of only days ago, whom the people usually saw in the blinding guise of royal finery.

He felt only moderately hesitant to leave Keravin in charge of the kingdom. Though the man was largely considered an inept fool, there was a sincerity to him that would serve the kingdom well in the days to come.

At least until I come back, the former king thought. If I come back.

He kept to the back roads throughout the night, stopping in the predawn hours for a few hours' sleep before he would have to take his new guise to the public thoroughfares. At least, that was the plan. His mind had other concerns.

Like whether he had prepared Keravin enough for challenges ahead. I did as much for him as I could, and he has my most loyal advisors to help him find his way.

What about this quest of yours? There's no way this will end well! I know the dangers. Even if I die before the end, there will be others to finish what I started.

And what if all your efforts fail? I will succeed! I must, for the sake of my kingdom.

Yeah, I bet they'll completely understand you making that imbecile their king, since it's "for the sake of the kingdom." Since they could only have the opportunity to question my decision if I succeed in this quest and return, that point is irrelevant. Now shut up and let me sleep!

This back and forth went on for quite some time before the voices of doubt were finally silenced and the former king was able to rest.

A few short hours later, he woke up and continued on his way after a quick breakfast. It wasn't long before he reached the main road out of his capitol city. He couple just barely make out the grey towers of the castle in the distance.

He turned his back to his longtime home and began the long leg of his journey toward the distance mountains in the east, where the fate of his people was waiting to be decided.

1442211.title: Enter the village

144222.content:
He picked up his pace. The shadows concealed just within the outer edges of the forest kept pace with him easily, moving silently through clearings and underbrush with equal ease. The former king saw no way to lose them. Entering the forest would put him nearer their reach, and continuing to follow the road would keep him in their sight. If his stalkers decided to leave the woods and confront him, he would have no recourse but to fight, for fleeing would only delay his attackers and put him in a less ideal position for defending.

The road broke into a crossroads several miles further ahead, continuing straight toward the large town of Emindale after being bisected by a road that led to the predictably named River Crossing to the south and the border of the Averil Kingdom to the north. It was usually a well guarded place. Perhaps he could lose them there, assuming things remained unchanged that long.

That assumption could quickly be disregarded as inapplicable.

The shadows converged onto the road, revealing themselves to be a ragtag band of outlaws, armed with the reasonably expected bows and swords and dressed in patchwork green and brown clothing. The masked man who was clearly their leader took position a few paces in front of, and leveled his sword at, the former king.

"Now, this is quite simple," the masked man said. The mask muffled his voice, giving it a slight echo as he talked. "This is robbery. You give us this money, this moment, or this is your last of all this moments. This is your choice. Think this well."

The former king blinked. "So, you are saying that if I don't give you my money, you'll kill me?"

The masked man groaned. As he spoke, he waved his sword around, prompting some of the men around him to scramble out of the way. "Yes! This words are this meaning. You make this choice. Now!"

The former king took in the gathered brigands. They seemed inexperienced, and wary of their eccentric leader. It could be possible for him to turn them against each other, but their desperation for whatever riches he might have might well outweigh their doubts.

144222.title: Hunted

1442221.content:
After some consideration, during which the group's leader showed his impatience through further gesticulations of his sword, the king got an idea. It was questionable, but it might work to diffuse this situation. Well, as far as the King was concerned, at least.

"I have one question," the former king said as he slowly lowered the pack from his shoulder and began sifting through it, as though he was trying to retrieve some money. At least, that is what the on-looking brigands thought he was doing. But instead of pulling out a bag of coins, he pulled out a fairly small, black, ball-like object. "How many of you know what this is?"

His question was met with blank stares until the leader spoke up. "What is this? This is ball! Black ball, useless for this purpose. Give us this money, or this is this moment's end for you!" He waved his sword in a slightly less random motion, and his men brought their weapons up in even more hostile attitudes.

"Wait! Just wait a moment," the king said, holding the object up in a showman's gesture. "This may look like just a ball, but no! It is so much more than the naked eye can see. Give me a chance, and I can show you just how this incredible item can change your lives. Decide quickly, for this limited time offer won't last long!"

The looks on the faces of some of the brigands indicated that they were curious about his words, but the leader quickly countered. "Nonsense! This is nothing but this desperate plea for this life. This will not save you!"

The former king threw up his hands and sighed. "Well, I tried. If none of you want the chance of a lifetime, who am I to argue?"

One of the brigands in the back of the group shouted, "Come on, at least let him tell us what it is!"

A different man near the front of the group nodded his head vigorously. "Yeah. I wants to know how much we can sells it for."

Someone else piped up with, "Is it magic or something?"

"No! This is not this way! Cease this talk of this ball!" The mask on the leader's face didn't allow a view of his expression, but the former king was quite certain the man's face was probably becoming red and contorted.

The former king threw his arms wide, saying, "Well, what will it be, folks? Do I have to take this miracle product elsewhere? I can only give this limited time offer on a first-come basis, so act fast before it's gone!"

Chaos ensued. Several of the bandits desperately wanted the special offer, but since their leader wouldn't hear of it (he was quite tight with the purse-strings, at least as long it regarded his underlings), they decided to force the issue despite the forceful swinging of their leader's sword. The king took their momentary distraction as a chance to sneak away into the cover of the forest's canopy and continue in the direction of the crossroads.

It wasn't long before he was intercepted by yet another shadowy form in the forest. After a moment of breathless mutual observation, the newcomer spoke. "Call me Ivan."

Well, it was as good a name as any.

1442221.title: This is the Last Moment

14422212.content:
"Do you have it?"

The former king held out the black sphere which had caused so many problems for the brigands. "Yes, though I thought we weren't supposed to meet until nearer the mountains."

'Ivan' took the sphere and examined it a moment before slipping it into his pocket. "Something happened. We will need to tread carefully but quickly if we're to accomplish our mission."

"Are the others aware of these changes to the plan?"

"Not yet. You are the first I've had a chance to contact."

"Then we need to spread the word. Can you do that?"

Ivan nodded. "But in the meantime, I suggest you hurry with your next tasks."

"Of course."

Ivan disappeared into the shadows of the trees, yet another shadowy figure of many, and the former king turned his mind to these new circumstances. Whatever came next would decide the fate of his kingdom and, perhaps, the world.


If only he could find out what that was! The end comes too soon for those of us who fight the great battles which shape the course of our lives, and yet it is the struggle, not the victory, that makes us what we are. After all, the victories and losses would be meaningless without the memory of the struggles which led to them.

In time, this battle will be fought again, and again, and again, but each battle will be unique to its time. Bear the banners of the battle proudly, and when the call to arms returns, heed it with all honor.


And if that's not enough, keep writing!

14422212.title: Ivan Says...

14423.content:
“Whoa! Are you running from a marriage proposal?” I glanced wide-eyed at the king. Out of the corner of my eye, I could see Bishop VanGrew with a full-blown grin on his face. I was glad somebody was amused.

“Not running. More like dodging.” The King gestured for me to have a seat. “Let’s get comfortable while I explain. Bishop, could you manage to procure some ale for us? I suspect our friend here may need it.” The Bishop nodded and backed out of the room. The King eased down into the chair next to me.

“The marriage contract you have in your hand is a contract between Lady Myst of the House of Stark and the King of Targaryen. If fulfilled, the contract will ensure peace on our northern borders. Say, istn’t that where your hamlet lies? Hmmmm, I suppose that peace would benefit your small hamlet?”

“Well, yes. We would have no more troubles with the blood-thirsty raiders, but why do you want me to pretend to be king?”

“Not pretend. Be king.”

“Huh?” That queasy feeling in my stomach danced its way up my throat. I gulped, swallowing the bile.

“It’s simple really,” The king said. “I can’t marry Lady Myst because I am in love with her aunt, Queen Hannah of the House of Stark.” The king’s eyes glazed over and his voice grew wistful. “So beautiful…. raven hair, eyes the color of the sky, and her lips…. ahhhh, her lips….” He shook himself, rousting the image from his mind. “Unfortunately, her husband the King of Stark might object to that union, which, of course, would be very bad for your little hamlet.” The king raised an eyebrow as if to check that I was following him.

I nodded dumbly. “Very bad.”

“So that’s where you come in.” The king grinned. “The contract just says “The King of Targaryen.” If I am not King, then I am not the one who will marry Lady Myst. You will. After the deed is done, I will return from the dead and reclaim the throne. And if something were to happen to the King of Targaryen while I am away, well then…..”

So, with the real King safely tucked away in some hidden chamber within the palace, there I was about to be trussed up as pretty as a royal banquet goose. Oh, and I had no doubts that I'd soon be dead. Yes, dead, and plucked naked, my head adorning the ramparts!

Prince? I could have sworn that clodhopper was but a lowly Sir. "Send him away, and be quick about it," I whispered.

144232.title: The Royal Wedding

choices: The New Arrival Announces Queen Hannah has Just Entered the Castle
1442321.content:
I awakened to a cawing ruckus. Perched on the window's ledge was a pure white raven, the King's own personal messenger. At once I noticed the tiny scroll attached by a leather strap to its right foot.

"Blasterly, or whatever your name is, get in here!"

My man-servant arose from beside my bed, where apparently he'd slept on a portable bed. "Ye...yes," he coughed, his voice raspy with sleep. "What is it, Sire?"

"Don't call me that!"

"As you wish, Si...Sir."

"Go and find the real King, and tell him he's a raven returned, a white raven."

After he'd gone, a knock came upon on the door, and when I opened it, there stood a plump man so short he came only to my shoulder. He had pins stuck in his red velvet coat, a measuring tape slung about his wide neck, and he carried a small stool, which he set before me and hopped up on.

"Good day, Sire. I am here to measure you for your royal wedding garments, if you please." His breath reeked of garlic and some other foul substance.

"My...oh, yes. Well, get on with it, I've more to do than stand around all the day, you oaf."

After I'd rid my self of the chattering tailor, it was one intrusion after another: the caterers, not just one, mind you, but one for everything: the salads, the main courses, the deserts, what wines, and on and on. "Why isn't the queen seeing to all this?" I demanded of the winesman.

"I do believe the good queen's feeling rather poorly this morning, Sire."

"I see. Well, if there's nothing else, you may take your samples and leave."

Alone at last, I burped. All those small cups of wine had rather gone to my head. Really, being the King is rather tiresome work. I wonder if Jorkie and the boys are down at the local inn. I could do with a spot of Marlor's good ale.

I turned as the wall next to the massive marble fireplace swung outward and out stepped the real King. He was dressed most peculiar as though he were a huntsman, I guess, though it was not very convincing.

"Sire," he said to me with a sweeping bow and a grin that spread across his handsome face. He stood back up and twirled one of his hands in the air. "Ah, he said noticing all the small wooden bowls still partially filed with wine. I see my good lady wife has been slack as ever in her duties, hmm."

"Ah, yes, Sire."

"No. No, I am Huntley."

"Right." As stupid a name as that outfit. You'll be fooling no one.

I sighed as yet another disturbing knock came, but whoever it was barged right in...

14423213.content:
No sooner had Blasterly opened the door for this next visitor, than all heck broke loose! The man, dressed all in black, including a half-mask that prevented anyone from guessing his identity, burst into the room, a double-edged sword glinting in the early morning light.

"Eeee!" squealed Blasterly as he dove under the royal bed. Evidently, his duties did not include protecting me or the King!

The would be assassin lunged for the King, but at the same time, I tore a heavy, ornate torch holder from the wall, and struck him on the side of his head. He wobbled for a moment, looking from me to the King, then collapsed in a heap.

"Are you harmed, Sire?" I noticed a small red stain blossoming on the front of his light tan tunic.

"No. No, Tyrl. It's only a minor flesh wound." Still, he wore a pained expression on his face.

By this time, Basterly had managed to crawl out from under the bed, albeit red-faced, his head hanging in shame.

"Let me attend that for you, my King." He went into the adjoining room and returned with a rag and small bottle of clear liquid. Once the king had stripped off his tunic, he began cleaning the wound.

"Enough!" bellowed the King, grimacing. He pushed the man in black over with the toe of his deerskin boot, reached down, and stripped the mask from his face. "The Kingslayer! He let out a long whistle. How fitting is that!"

I sucked in my breath, eyebrows raised to the ceiling, and frozen in place. When I could breathe again I said, "Is he de...dead, Sire" What would that make me? The Kingslayer slayer?

"No. He's alive, now help me drag him through the secret entrance. I want no one to hear of this." And just as we got the last of him through, yes, you guessed it, another blasted knock!

Once again the King ducked into the secret room as Blasterly threw a blanket over the blood-stained rag and medicine bottle, and I went to berate whoever it was this time!

Does a king ever have any peace?

After a long walk form my chambers, in new shoes that pinched and caused my sore toe to throb anew, we at last approached steps leading up to the Grand Cathedral. I stretched my neck back to gaze up the many broad steps to see Bishop VanGrew gazing down at myself and Embrey who had accompanied me.

"Good morning, Sire," he said bowling not so low, I noticed. His blubbery-thick lips turned down in a frown. And sweat rolled down his gouty neck. "I trust you slept well," he offered.

Like you give a mule's rump if I did or did not. "Oh, quite," I said.

"Come! Come! We've been waiting for some time for you to arrive. The bride's all-a-jitter," he informed us in his nasally voice. We stepped into the cool recess of the cathedral, and I gaped at the elaborate trappings of the place: marble floors throughout, massive candelabras that seemed to float from its vaulted ceiling, flowers of every kind let off an overwhelming perfume, and a lengthy red carpet went on forever down the isle to the alter.

As we approached the alter, I mused that its contents could have fed my village for many a year: golden goblets, a diamond encrusted sword laid lengthwise along the white draped marble, gems galore were inlaid in the two six foot candle holders that stood either side of the alter, and a feminine delicate crown of shiny gold.

I wondered where the guest all were, when the doors whooshed open. In marched a parade that went on for quite some time. Lords, Ladies, the prince who'd knocked upon my door. Most were strange to me, but I did pick out one or two who were well-renowned. Witnesses tot his spectacle, this farce, not wedding guests!

Once they were all seated, Bishop VanGrew lifted a chubby arm, calling for silence. He nodded to an alter attendant, and he disappeared into a side door. Moments later, he ushered out a woman in a revealing white gown. It was cut low, and it reveal the swell of her ample breasts. Stop gaping, you fool! I felt like whistling! If this is the famed Myst , well, I could certainly do far worse; she's stunning!

I straightened myself up and gave a slight nod to my would be bride. She, in turn, smiled a smile to rival a thousand candelabras!

"Let us proceed," the bishop said, attempting to sound important, but failing.

Well, the vows that occur between a king and queen go on longer than winter in Winterfell. After what seemed like hours, the deed was done, and lucky me, I got to kiss the bride. And let me tell you, it was some kiss, and her lips, well...

Lady most dear,
with eyes so clear,
what should you fear?

when you shall live here
Enjoy comforts sheer

144232131321.title: The Great Battle

1442321313212.content:
I followed Sir Gavin out of the royal chamber and up the stairs. As I reached the parapet, I stopped and gasped in horror. The castle was surrounded by thousands of knights as far as the eye could see. I was rather glad I had taken care of business downstairs.

Suddenly someone below spotted me and a roar went up from the angry throng. A catapult pulled back and sent a mammoth rock careening toward the castle wall. On impact the rock splintered into a thousand pieces and the wall shook. I ducked and covered my head.

Sir Gavin reached down and grabbed me by my cloak. Hauling me up by the scruff of my neck, he held me two feet above the floor, which could not be seen from below. Dangling there, I realized I was actually eye level with the giant.

He roared with anger. “Do your best, you infidels! Our mighty King Keravin shall split your guts and roast your innards for the buzzards to devour!”

Who’s he calling mighty? I wondered as a roar went up from our own knights. Sir Gavin sat me down, and straightened my cloak. Behind him several ladders appeared along the outer side of the wall. Horrified, I realized that an attempt was being to scale it.

“Uh… uh….” I pointed and Sir Gavin whirled. He grabbed the nearest ladder and shoved with all of his might. A thunk silenced a scream below. Not breaking stride, Sir Gavin began screaming orders. Out of nowhere, several men appeared with boiling vats of oil and dumped the scalding contents over the wall. Screams of agony once again reached my ears. Clasping my hands over my ears, I turned and darted for the staircase.

I took no more than two strides before I found myself being lifted by the scruff of my neck again. My feet kept moving but my forward progress was halted. This was getting old. Sir Gavin turned me once again to the wall so I could face the hoard of enemies.

“Act like you are yelling, Sire,” he whispered. Having no other recourse, I complied and began moving my mouth in gyrations. For good measure I added some exaggerated arm movements, which apparently pleased my ventriloquist, Sir Gavin.

“See here, what befalls the enemies of our great kingdom. Curse those who dare to think I am weak for you shall see just how mighty I really am.” Sir Gavin laughed, and I threw back my head and mimicked a roaring sound. Sir Gavin cut off the laughter so I snapped my mouth shut. I could only hope that the cutthroats below could not see how out of sync we really were. Finally, Sir Gavin once again set me on my feet and dusted me off.

“Forgive me, Sire.” Sir Gavin nodded and almost smiled. “Now, you may return to your chambers if you wish. I will send for you later so that our enemies may see what a worthy adversary you are.” He turned and began marching down the parapet, shouting out orders to ready for the next round.

I started to sputter and then thought better of it. I turned and scurried down the staircase, right past my chambers.

1442321313212.title: Reluctant Hero

14423213132123.content:
I raced down the hall bent on seeking freedom from this nightmare. No way was I cut out to be king. What a joke, and everyone knew it. Even Sir Gavin knew he had to cover for me. I wasn’t kidding anyone. I broke out into the courtyard and ran for the stables.

“You there, stable boy!” I cried. “Get me a horse.”

“But, Sire—“

“No buts, get me my horse, now!” I was fairly sure a king had his own horse.

“Sire,” the boy’s eyes widened into saucers. “Are you going to ride out there and kick some butt?” That stopped me cold. The castle was surrounded by thousands of enemy knights. Suddenly, fleeing did not seem like such a good idea.

“Uh, no. Of course not. I just wanted to inspect my horse.” I glanced around searching for a plausible explanation. “Uh, I wanted to make sure he’s doing okay.”

“Inspect your horse, Sire?” The stable boy cocked his head and raised one eyebrow. Apparently, that sounded even lamer to a lad than it did to me.

“Never mind,” I said. “I’m sure you are doing a fantastic job. Carry on.” I waved him off toward where the horses were kept and turned to search out the sanctuary of the chapel. Could my own chapel grant me asylum? Where else could I hide?

I was half-way there when a hand reached out and snagged my neck, dragging me back into a hidden panel in the wall. In a split second, I found myself inside the wall of the castle. Wiping spider webs from my face, I froze as I realized Page Embrey stood in front of me, and we were alone in some kind of hidden passage. This was not good.

Page Embrey held up his finger to indicate silence. Since he appeared to have the upper hand, not to mention a rather lethal looking sword, I decided co-operation to be the more prudent move at the moment. Embrey motioned for me to follow him. We trudged the length of the dark tunnel, lit only by a torch that Embrey had picked off the wall. The shadows flickering along the wall sent shivers down my spine. I had heard stories of the castle being haunted but now they didn’t seem like just stories. It didn’t help that my companion, if he was indeed the King’s half-brother, probably wanted me dead.

At a fork in the tunnel, Embrey turned left, glancing behind him to make sure I followed. I briefly considered taking the right tunnel, but I suspected that he could chase me down if he wanted to. After several more turns, we stopped in front of a panel. Embrey reached up and pressed on a stone. With an eerie creak, the wall began to rotate, stopping only when a doorway had been created to the King’s bedchamber.

“What…” I struggled to find my voice. “What are we doing here?”

“If you want to run, Sire,” sarcasm laced Embrey’s voice, “you need to be prepared.” He raked his eyes over me in scorn. He grabbed a knapsack from under the bed and shoved it toward me. “Here, this is filled with food and water, enough for two days.” Striding over to the wall, he snatched a sword down and tossed it to me. Out of sheer reflex, I snagged it out of the air, narrowly missing the blade.

From the King’s bed table, Embrey pulled a dagger. Holding it in his right hand, he marched toward me with a menacing expression. Forgetting I held a sword, I back peddled until I felt the wall pressing into my back. Embrey smirked, flipped the handle of the knife over, and shoved it into my belt.

“Let’s go! I can get you out through a tunnel that opens into the woods. I’ve got a horse waiting for you there.”

“Wait!” I cried finally gaining my senses. “Don’t you want to kill me?” Okay, maybe I shouldn’t have reminded him.

“Kill you?” Embrey mouthed. “Why would I want to do that?”

“Because you are the King’s brother and want the throne.”

Embrey laughed. He actually had the gaul to laugh. “Yes, I’m the King’s brother, and yes, I want the throne, but you are an innocent pawn of my brother’s. Killing you would be one more crime for which our house would have to answer. Besides, if you turn up dead, the kingdom might go looking for the real king.” He shook his head. “No, I just need you out of the way where my dear brother’s minions can’t use you anymore.” With that he turned and walked back into the tunnel.

For a stunned moment, I stood there trying to sort it all out. However, Embrey interrupted my ruminations by poking his head back into the room. “Coming?”

I nodded and scurried after him.

144232131321231.title: The Great Escape

1442321313212311.content:
A cool cloth stroked my brow. Water trickled down by scalp and trickled behind my ear. The voice of an angel whispered in the same ear, “Come now, Sire. It’s time for you to be waking up.”

I fluttered my eyes and squinted as the light sent shards of pain streaking through my skull. I groaned.

“Hush, now. I’ll cover the light from the windows.” The cloth left its comforting march across my forehead, and I risked a peek to see if an angel had indeed rescued me. In the darkness that now engulfed the room, I could just make out the shadow of a woman with long hair. Not until she stepped up to stroke the fire, could I see she truly was an angel of mercy. Beautiful blond hair cascaded in curls to her waist, and blue eyes sparkled as she smiled at me. Her dainty nose set atop lush and full lips.

“Now, that’s better isn’t it, my Lord?” I nodded and was rewarded with another smile.

“My lady, where am I?” The last thing I remembered was Embrey tossing me over the lip of a well.

“You are in my home in Glen Eives.”

“Whoa!” I jack-knifed up as a sudden thought hit me. Pain throbbed but I kept my focus. “And you would be?”

“Why, I am the healer of Glen Eives, Sire. I’ve been caring for you for since yesterday.” I stared in horror. Standing before me was the most beautiful witch I had ever seen.

“But…..” I stammered, “but…. I thought you were….. well, old!”

The witch snickered. “I am old. Almost 300 years this coming spring. I tell ye, these old bones ache something fierce through the winter months. The cold is coming that’s for sure.”

“But you’re so beautiful.” I had never spoken so directly to a woman in my life. My angel turned witch shrugged her shoulders.

“Fountain of Youth spell—“ The door banged open and in stormed Embrey.

“Is he awake yet?”

“See for yourself, Embrey, my love.” All now that just sucked! Her beauty was so great, I had almost convinced myself that 270 years was really not the big of a gap for two people in a committed relationship.

Embrey marched over to the witch and gave her a swift kiss on those luscious lips. And I had thought this guy was annoying as my page.

“So,” I interrupted, “I guess she gave you a muscle-bound, handsome prince spell?” Embrey broke off the kiss and turned to glare at me.

“No, she gave me a wimpy, sniveling page spell so no one would suspect anything.”

“Ahhh,” I retorted. “It worked.”

“Can he travel?” Embrey asked, ignoring me.

“In the morning, perhaps.” The witch ran a finger over Embrey’s chest and purred, “Perhaps you can stay another night?”

“Sounds like a wonderful plan,” Embrey said as he dipped his head to feather kisses along her nape. I groaned aloud again. It was going to be a very long night.

14423213132123111.content:
At nightfall the next evening, Embrey ordered me to make myself ready for our journey. Though my head no longer ached, every bone and muscle in my body still screamed in protest as I pushed myself off the bed. Apparently, being thrown down a dry well was not something it had appreciated. However, since said well was enchanted by the witch, no amount of searching had allowed my enemies to find us. Thus we escaped to the witch’s cottage, and for that the pain seemed a small price to pay. Better to be sore than dead I always say. I chuckled aloud at my own humor.

The witch glanced at me and lifted one brow in question. However, she said nothing and just handed me a small sack of provisions and a small amulet.

“Here, put this over your head and wear it with you for the entire journey.” She rasped in an ancient voice. I stared at her suspiciously. I could have sworn her beauty had wavered for a moment to reveal an old crone. But no, her blue eyes sparkled back at me when she winked. I shook my head to clear my thoughts.

“What will the amulet do? Make me invisible?”

“No silly,” the witch cackled—okay that was definitely not her normal musical laugh, “It will protect you from evil spirits that lurk in the Woods of Hampshire. You will pass through them at midnight, and I would hate for your soul to be enslaved by the Demons of Hampshire. Embrey needs you alive.”

I shuddered, “Yea, me too. Thanks.”

“Let’s be on our way,” Embrey called from just beyond the door. I stepped outside to find him holding the reins to one of the most beautiful horses I had ever seen. The stallion stood at least 18 hands with a coat as silky and black as midnight. I stepped forward and reached for the reins.

“No, I don’t think so,” Embrey said pulling the reins back. “That one’s yours.” He pointed to a tree to the left of the door. There stood the oldest, ugliest nag I had ever seen. Not more than 15 hands tall, every rib and backbone shown through its mottled and scraggly coat. I groaned knowing that I’d feel every one of those protrusions.

“You expect your king to ride a nag?” I gave Embrey my best royal snooty look.

“I do if that’s all the horse I think he can handle,” he retorted. Okay, I probably deserved that. I was not exactly known for my horseman ship. “Besides,” he continued, “You are not my king; you are an imposter, and we both know it.” With that, he placed a foot in his stirrup and swung up onto the magnificent black. “And while we are on the subject of identity, I would appreciate it if you would address me as Sir Embrey.”

I shut my mouth at his audacity and turned back toward the nag. The horse swung around at me and showed me its teeth in what could only be described as a snarl.

“I could cast a beauty spell if it would be easier your sensibilities.” The witch cackled again. This time I was sure I saw a few more wrinkles in that previously porcelain skin.

“Would that make her run faster if our enemies should find us?”

“No, but it’s a wonder what a female is willing and able to do when she feels beautiful.” The witch batted her eyelashes and tossed a moldy gray hair behind her shoulder. I shuddered.

“Uh, no thanks.” She shrugged and stepped back to stand in her doorway, her skin once again glowing in the evening light. Perhaps her spell was only contained within the parameters of her home.

I stepped up to my waiting nag and grasped her reins to untie them from the tree limb. For my troubles, the grateful wretch snapped at me almost, I was sure, biting my hand in two.

The horse snickered.

I snatched the reins and jerked down to show her who was boss. From the glare, I doubted I had made my point, but since Embrey—Sir Embrey that is—was bellowing like a jackass that it was time to go, I decided to save this battle for another time.

I stepped up into the stirrup and swung my leg over the saddle. At that exact moment, my little nemesis sidestepped two steps toward me, which meant my momentum carried me right over the saddle. I landed with an umph and lay there staring at the underneath of the tree branch. The nag actually turned and laughed at me like only a horse can.

Sir Embrey, however, was not amused. “Is Princess too much for you to handle, Sire?”

“Princess?” I sputtered, setting up. “Her name is Princess? You’ve got to be kidding me.” I got to my feet and glared at Princess. Taking her reins in hand, I once again attempted to mount. This time I anticipated her side step toward me. Unfortunately, Princess moved in the other direction, which left me hanging in mid-air until gravity took over, and I once again found myself inspecting the undergrowth of the tree. “Spoiled Princess, more like it,” I muttered once I had regained my breath.

By this time, Embrey had dismounted and held the reins firmly in his grasp. “Allow me, Sire.” His voice practically dripped with sarcasm.

I stood and grabbed the saddle horn and practically jumped into the saddle. No way was I giving this little equine witch another chance to dump me. Embrey handed me the reins and stomped back to his horse. I watched with envy as he vaulted into the saddle and whirled his mount toward the trail. Digging in his heels, he and his stallion seemed to take flight.

I tapped my stirrups against Princess’s side.

Nothing.

I tapped a little harder.

Nothing.

Unable to stand it any longer, I let out a screech and slammed my heels into the nag’s side. She snorted and bobbed her head. Another hard dig, and she ambled forward at a leisurely pace. At this rate, it would take us a year to reach our destination.

“Hey, Embrey!” I yelled. “Where are we going?” I wasn’t sure if he heard me as he and his winged Pegasus had a considerable lead on us. Embrey pulled up and whirled his mount to wait for me. As we moseyed closer, I could see his fierce glower.

“It is Sir Embrey, if you please,” he ground out.

“Oh, sorry, Sir Embrey,” I emphasized, “would you mind telling me where exactly we are going?”

“To Night Haven,” he said. “Now try to be a little quieter and try to move a little faster will you? The night patrols could still find us.”

“You picked the stupid nag,” I muttered. Embrey rolled his eyes and turned back up the path, moving at a slower pace to accommodate the one speed Princess seemed to have—turtle class.

14423213132123111.title: Flight to Night Haven

144232131321231111.content:
Darkness encroached on all sides. Crickets chirped their symphony and bullfrogs croaked out an accompanying rhythm to create a sinister overture. Occasionally, an owl hooted in the distance, its lonesome echo sending shivers down my spine.

“Hey, Embrey,” I whispered and watched his back stiffen. I sighed “Okay, Sir Embrey?” Embrey pulled up his horse and turned in his saddle to face me.

“Yes? What do you want now?”

“Just wondering when we would reach Night Haven?”

“Another 15 minutes,” Embrey muttered and turned, urging his horse up the trail. Well, somebody’s a little testy.

“No, seriously. This place is creeping me out, Embrey.” I raised my voice hoping he would answer. It took me a second to realize that Embrey had frozen in his saddle. He snapped up a fist to indicate silence. I had a feeling it would be in my best interest to listen.

The woodland creatures continued their ominous music. I heard nothing, but Embrey’s back remained rigid. Without warning, my horse, Princess Nag, shied away from the right side of the trail. Her eyes rolled back, and she reared, turning to face the opposite way. I nearly lost my seat, but managed to yank back on the reins, keeping the nag from bolting—not a usual description applied to her I feared. Princess kept prancing as if she could hear something I could not. I managed to turn her back in the right direction.

Then over the shuffling hooves and nature’s big band music, I heard a low growl. I whipped around to see what Embrey was doing. Embrey chose that moment to leap into action; apparently he too had heard the growl. As he pulled his sword from his scabbard and lifted it high, his stallion reared. Like a statue I had once seen, the two hung there for several moments before coming to the ground with a jar that shook the ground.

The trees around us erupted in growls and snarls. A black beast with three inch fangs and glowing red eyes sprang at Embrey. With one swipe of his sword, he cleaved the beast in two. Another fiend leapt out of darkness only to meet with the same fate.

Embrey screamed, “Ride!” For once I was in total agreement. I dug in my heels and didn’t have to tell Princess Nag twice this time. She must have sprouted wings because we flew down the trail, snarling and nipping dogging our heels. From behind me, I heard the pounding hooves of Embrey’s steed. A sudden yelp let me know he had dispatched another demon, but I wasn’t looking to confirm that. My plan was to ride until Princess could go no further. Then, I would carry her if I had to. After all, she might have just saved my sorry hide; it was the least I could do for her. Funny how running for our lives could bond two creatures.

On my left, Embrey and his ride overtook us. He reached out and snatched the reins, pulling us to a stop.

“Whoa,” he said. Sweat had plastered his black hair to his forehead and dripped down his cheek. I whipped my head around to check for any more of the offensive creatures.

“Are we….” I gasped for breath. “Are we safe?” My eyes continued to scan the surroundings.

“Yes, Sire. We are safe. I’ve been trying to get you to stoop for at least two leagues.” He laughed. “I didn’t think Princess had it in her. Now that I mention it, I didn’t think you did either.”

This time I laughed. “Let’s just say we were motivated.” I reached down and rubbed Princess’s neck. She shook her head up and down as if to agree with me. “What were those things?”

“Why those were the Demons of Hampshire, of course.” I shuddered. I reached up and grabbed my amulet.

“I thought this was supposed to protect me.”

“You’re still alive, aren’t you?” Embrey raised an eyebrow.

I sucked in another deep breath and heard Princess do the same. She seemed calm, so I hoped all was well. “So the rest of the trip will be good?”

“Hardly, next are the Serpents of Stellerine.”

“Serpents?” I shook my head. “You mean snakes? Please tell me you did not just say snakes.”

“I didn’t say snakes; I said serpents.”

“Aren’t those the same thing?”

“No, I don’t mind snakes,” Embrey explained. “They eat rodents and other such creatures. The serpents are evil and can grow as large as twenty feet.”

“Twenty feet?” I gasped.

“Twenty feet,” Embrey agreed. “Now, let’s go.” He whirled his mount and urged it into a walk. I followed suit, my imagination taking over. Twenty feet serpents?

1442321313212311113.content:
“Pssst, Sir Embrey?” I stressed the sir to get his attention. “How much farther?” I watched as Embrey’s shoulders bunch up. The man was really going to have a terrible backache if he kept doing that.

“I told you another fifteen minutes.” Embrey never looked back.

“You said that an hour ago,” I accused.

“Sorry.” Embrey shrugged. “I’ve never been good at telling time in the dark.” I was about to remark he wasn’t very good at ever telling time when Princess Nag started bobbing her head and dancing in a half circle. This time I knew enough to trust my new friend. If she was nervous, I had better be nervous. As I listened I could hear the rustling in the woods. Embrey had already halted, but instead of his sword, he had pulled a torch and lit it.

I really wished he hadn’t. Hundred of snakes slithered through the branches overhead and on the ground. Though I didn’t see any twenty-foot snakes, there were several that measured at least eight to ten feet. Apparently, Princess wasn’t happy either and reared several times to emphasize her point. I finally got her to keep all four hooves on the ground but she snorted her displeasure.

Embrey dropped from his horse, and holding the reins, he began swooshing the torch in front of him. The snakes recoiled from the heat and light, clearing a path.

“Follow directly behind me,” Embrey whispered. “Keep an eye overhead. You don’t want one of them dropping on you.”

No kidding.

We had not progressed more than 50 yards before Embrey froze. In front of him, slithered a giant serpent of at least 30 feet. Embrey’s horse reared and nearly unhinged his arm. Some how, he managed to keep hold and toss me the torch. As he came down, he yanked his sword, prepared to do battle.

“S-s-s-ave your s-s-s-word, human. I mean you no harm.” Embrey froze.

“Did that snake just talk?” I whispered, but Embrey never uttered another word.

The serpent chuckled. “You’ve never heard a s-s-s-erpent talk before, King Keravin?”

“How…. How did….” I sat stunned. Of course, I wasn’t the only one. Embrey and both horses were in some kind of trance, not moving a single muscle. Even the other snakes had ceased slithering. The giant serpent and I were the only ones present in the truest sense of the word.

“How did I know your name?” asked the serpent. “I know many things-s-s. Now lis-s-ten clos-s-ely because-s-se your life may depend upon it. Before dawn breaks-s-s over the eas-s-tern s-s-sky, you will encounter three more perils-s-s, each wors-s-e than the las-s-t. The firs-s-t will be boiling mud traps-s-s. Watch the ground and trus-s-t your hors-s-e. S-S-She will guide you through s-s-s-afely to the other s-s-side. The s-s-second will be the giant s-s-spider of Archaidia. S-S-She is dec-c-eitful and once her web ens-snares-s-s you, s-s-she will never let you go. S-S-Stuff your ears-s-s and cover your nag’s-s-s eyes-s. That way s-s-s-she cannot s-s-s-ee. Then lead your hors-s-e through without looking to the left or right of the path. S-S-She cannot trick you then. The third is the deadlies-s-t. It comes-s-s in the form of a friend or foe. Trus-s-t no one.”

“Trust no one?” I asked. “That’s it?”

“Trus-s-t no one.” The serpent weaved his head in agreement.

“Why are you doing this?” Seemed a bit out of character to me for a serpent to be so helpful.

“Why becaus-se, S-S-Sire, you will be the next true king, and I like to have friends-s-s in high pla-c-ces-s-s-s.” With that the serpent turned and slithered into the forest.

Embrey and the horses sprang to life as the other snakes disappeared.

“What… What happened?” It was Embrey’s turn to stutter.

“Oh, just a chat with a new friend,” I muttered. “Let’s go.” I dug in my heals and Princess and I took the lead.

14423213132123111131.content:
Another hour perhaps had passed before a foul stench reached my sensitive olfactory. I wrinkled my nose in disgust and felt bile rise in my throat at the smell of rotten eggs. Princess shook her head from side-to-side, as if to shake the odor from her nostrils. I pulled up and turned to face Sir Embrey. I was a bit surprised that he had allowed me to remain in the lead. Come to think of it, I was a little unsure why I had taken the lead. A bit out of character you might say. Maybe the Kingship thing was going to my head.

“Sir Embrey, do you smell that?”

“Rotten eggs.”

“Uh, huh,” I agreed. “The Mud Pits of Arbrill.” Embrey’s eyes widened at my knowledge. I smothered a grin. He knew nothing of my conversation with the serpent.

“You may be right, Sire. I had forgotten about them.” Embrey looked past my shoulder, and I got the feeling he was hiding something. “Perhaps we should take a short cut through the woods that I know. There’s a small path just up ahead that should get us through.” Embrey tapped his horse to take the lead, but I held up a hand halting his progress.

“No,” I said, my gaze steely, “We cannot risk any further delay. Princess seems to have a nose for it. Stay directly behind me, and we shall be fine.”

“You expect me to trust you and the nag?” Embrey snorted in disgust. “I don’t think so.”

I shrugged. “Do what you want,” I said, determined to stay the course, “but I am taking the straight path.” I whipped Princess around and urged her forward, leaving Embrey sputtering. I knew he would follow because for some reason I seemed to be of value to him—at least for now.

The stench grew stronger and soon the moonlight revealed small patches of bubbling mud. Princess shied away from a particularly big one that must have measured two feet in diameter. I watched as a brown bubble expanded on the surface before exploding and showering us with hot bits of mud and ooze. One splotch struck my arm leaving a burn mark before I could wipe the offending mass away.

Poor Princess had no such ability to protect herself, and she would jump and squeal whenever the splatter hit its mark. However, she had turned into a real trooper, and she kept trudging along. A couple of times, she stopped and backed up before choosing another route. I gave her free rein.

Considering our rocky start, I found it amazing that I now trusted Princess so implicitly. What was even more amazing was that I somehow knew the serpent was telling the truth. Not necessarily that I could trust him, just that in this case, he was telling the truth.

I heard a curse and a shrill neigh from behind us as a particularly nasty bubble exploded. I shifted to look and almost fell out of the saddle laughing. Embrey looked like he had been indulging in a rather extended mud bath. I sobered when I realized that some of those mud splatters were probably going to leave a few nasty burn marks, and I probably didn’t look much better. Embrey’s eyes shot me daggers, so I decided discretion might be the better part of valor in this case.

I turned and urged Princess on. After several more minutes and a few more mud splats, one of which landed on my head singing off a bit of my hair, we reached the edge of the mud pits. I sighed. My father had been as bald as an egg; I did not need anything hurrying the process along.

“Sire Keravin?” Embrey called from behind. “Is that a waterfall I hear up ahead?” I paused, and I too heard the distant roar of a water cascading over rocks.

“Would you be thinking we might be in need of a bath, Sir Embrey?” I asked.

Embrey smirked, “Just thinking of your comfort, Sire.”

“Let’s go.” Princess must have read my mind because she picked up the pace and headed straight for the rushing sound. It wasn’t long before the path opened up to reveal a pool at the base of a small waterfall—maybe 25 feet. Moonlight shimmered on the water and lush vegetation surrounded the oasis.

Embrey and I jumped from our mounts and yanked their saddles from their backs. As soon as my horse had been cared for, I dove into the water and came up sputtering. The cold left me momentarily breathless, but oh so refreshed. I splashed about rubbing at my clothes and hair trying to remove the mud that had begun to cake on. I finally realized I was going to have to strip in order to get truly clean. Since I had never been terribly modest, this didn’t bother me too much.

As I pulled off my tunic, however, I noticed something a bit odd. I wasn’t sure if it was my imagination or not, but I could swear that my arms were bulging with muscles just a bit more than they had the day before. I felt like a young boy who had just discovered his muscles. I held up my arm and pumped my fist. Sure enough, there were real muscles there, the kind that might actually be able to lift something. What’s more, there was real hair on my chest, lots of dark curly hair. Now, I know that wasn’t there before.

I glanced over to see if Embrey had noticed these changes, but Princess caught my eye. She was splashing around in the other end of the pool and had managed to cleanse herself of most of the mud. Had she grown a couple of hands? Surely not, and her coat. What once had been a dingy mottled coat was now gleaming white, with a mane that would leave any woman to shame. I looked closer to see if I could see her ribs or backbone but only healthy horseflesh greeted my eyes. Princess met my eye, and I swear she winked at me.

“Hey, Embrey!” I shouted thinking to ask if he had noticed anything strange. However, I decided I didn’t want him to think I was anymore of a fool than he already did. “Are you coming in?” Embrey was still working on cleaning his armor and his saddle.

“In just a bit, Sire. A knight always takes care of his armor and horse first. It could mean his life someday, you know?”

I didn’t really know, but I wasn’t going to point out my ignorance. Then another strange thought occurred to me.

“Hey, Embrey? If you know I’m not really the king, why do you call me Sire?”

Embrey shrugged, “Because I don’t want to slip up if we meet others along the journey.”

Embrey wasn’t meeting my eyes. I wondered why?
