14423213132123111131.title: The Mud Pits of Arbrill

144232131321231111311.content:
We tarried at the waterfall for only a short time. We had many miles to cover and many obstacles to overcome before we could truly rest. However, the cool water had cleaned our bodies and refreshed our spirits. As we dressed, I noticed that my clothes fit a little tighter. I walked over to Princess, admiring her gleaming white coat. She nudged my shoulder and nickered her agreement. She was liking the way she looked too. Embrey though seemed not to have noticed our transformation.

“Sire, let’s mount up,” Embrey called. He was already in the saddle, his horse was dancing with impatience to be on the way. I grabbed the horn and swung up into the saddle.

“Giddyup,” I called to Princess. Acting like her namesake, Princess pranced down the trail after Embrey. “Now, don’t get all prissy on me,” I muttered.

We rode the next several miles in silence with only the occasional chirp of a cricket or the croak of a frog to keep us company. I had felt peaceful and relaxed back at the pool, but slowly a sense of unease came over me. I felt a thousand eyes peering at me, watching my every move.

I gripped the reins a little tighter and must have communicated my unease to Princess. She started side-stepping and fighting any forward movement. What had the serpent said? “The second will be the giant spider of Archaidia.” I really didn’t like spiders.

“Embrey,” I whispered, “hold up.” He too seemed to be struggling to control his horse. I dismounted and searched my saddlebag for a cloth I could use to bind Princess’s eyes. Finding nothing, I tore my sleeve from my left arm. The darn thing was ripping out anyway. Princess didn’t appreciate being blind and she snorted her displeasure. “Hey, cover your horse’s eyes,” I instructed Embrey.

“Why?” His face mirrored his confusion, and I recalled he had not been privy to my conversation with the serpent. I’m not sure he would have trusted him even if he had heard it.

“Just trust me on this one okay?”

“Trust you?” Embrey snorted much as Princess had which I found amusing. “I don’t think so.”

“Embrey, there is a giant spider up there, and if we don’t cover our horses’ eyes and our ears she will deceive us. If that happens, we are dead.” Embrey rolled his eyes and whirled his mount to head down the trail. “Embrey, please!” But it was no use. Beside me Princess danced and pulled on the reins.

“It’s okay, girl,” I murmured. “We’ll get through this.” In the next moment, I wasn’t so sure. A piercing scream silenced the sound of the woods and all grew quiet as death. I feared for Embrey but knew there was nothing I could do.

I was alone now.

A soft whisper reached my ears, “So Sire, you dare to enter my web? You can save your friend, you know—“ I snatched some remaining scraps from my sleeve and stuffed them into my ears. I could hear nothing.

Taking a deep breath, I stepped forward. Princess was blind and I was deaf. We had to rely on each other. My heart thumped in my chest and sweat dripped down my back. The smell of fear and sweat mingled in the air.

I inched down the trail, being careful not to trip on any roots or rocks. Princess strained at the reins, and I knew if I lost my hold she would bolt. She was my lifeline.

In my other hand I held my sword, but remembering the serpent’s instructions, I looked neither left nor right. Unfortunately, he had failed to tell me what to do if I met the Queen head on.

I froze as a rather hairy appendage blocked my path followed by the most monstrous spider I had ever seen. She must have been eight feet tall with the blackest thickest hair covering her entire body. I stepped back and looked up. Large beady black eyes transfixed mine. Her fangs clicked, and I could tell she was speaking.

Princess yanked back on the reins, but I held firm and lifted my sword preventing the creature from advancing on me any further. It reared on its hind legs and swatted at me. I sliced at the attacking appendage and watched in horror as I cleaved it in two, blood spurting from the wound. On the ground the amputated limb twitched and stilled. Judging on the movement of the monsters mouth, I was sure it was screeching in pain, but I could not hear.

Without warning the creature charged at me, and Princess reared, lifting me from the ground. Dangling from the reins, I swung the sword and plunged it up and under the monster’s mouth. It pierced its mouth, and deeper still. I knew the moment it reached the brain because the spider tumbled taking both Princess and me with it in a tangle of hairy legs.

In the melee, one of my earplugs fell out and the reins slipped from my grasp. I pawed at the prickly legs, desperate to find the reins. Black on black in the moonlight made them invisible. I heaved one large appendage off of me and struggled to free myself, thinking I could at least reach my horse. I could hear her neighing in frantic confusion. Before I could break free, Princess managed to gain her feet and bolted.

I tried whistling but my mouth was so dry nothing more than a squeak emerged. Even if I had been successful, I doubt Princess would have returned. So much for our imagined partnership; not that I blamed her much. I looked down at the hideous creature and shivered.

That’s when I heard it—the clicking and rustling sounds of thousands of spiders. I turned and glanced behind me, my blood turning to ice. Every inch of the trail from the ground to the tallest tree was covered in a web crawling with tiny spiders. I turned and watched as the web began to extend up the sides of the trail.

Realizing I would soon be trapped, I vaulted over the dead queen and sprinted down the trail after Princess. I had never been the fastest runner but the adrenaline fueling my blood gave me wings. I could hear the spiders behind me continuing to weave their deadly web but I wasn’t looking back to check their progress.

How far I could run I would never know because as I rounded the corner in the trail, there stood a miracle. Gleaming in the moonlight with her back to me, Princess waited, bobbing her head as if to urge me on. I needed no such encouragement.

Leaping, I landed in the saddle, snatched the reins, and dug in my heels. Princess needed no encouragement either and took off like a young filly determined to win her first race.

144232131321231111311.title: Queen of Archaidia

1442321313212311113112.content:
Princess ran for what seemed like an hour though it was probably only 20 or so minutes. She began to slow and her breathing became labored, taking deep heaving breathes. I knew that even with her renewed youth and vigor we would have to slow or I would risk losing her. Somehow being on foot in this wooded land of horrors didn’t appeal to me. Plus, I had become a might fond of my traveling companion.

As I slowed Princess to a walk, I checked behind us for any sign of the creepy crawlies but could detect nothing. I could only pray that they were not interested in capturing me and more interested in caring for their dead queen.

I wondered for the countless time, what had happened to my other companion and protector, Sir Embrey. I feared the Queen of Archadia had killed him or worse. I shuddered to think of being injected with a spider’s venom and then being devoured from within by its digestive juices. As a child I had studied a bug meeting its fate that way. I could only hope that Embrey had died first. Though he may have been a pompous, arrogant jerk at times, he did not deserve that fate.

Dawn’s fingers began creeping over the horizon as I rounded the next bend in the road. Though moonlight had lit most of our way, I hoped that the coming daylight would dispel the sinister shadows that seemed to haunt the trail.

But wait. Hadn’t the old serpent warned of a third peril more deadly than the last two. Now, that wasn’t a pleasant thought. What had he said? “It comes in the form of a friend or foe. Trust no one.” What exactly did that mean? I could see not trusting a foe but not a friend either?

Reminded me of an old wise man from my village from when I was but a scrawny young lad. I had been complaining about a friend cheating at a game, and he had simply said, “With friends like that, who needs enemies?” I did not understand until much later that he was questioning my choice of friends.

Could that apply to this riddle? And who was the friend and who was the foe? I was alone out here except for Princess. The serpent had said “Trust no one,” but I doubted that applied to my horse.

I wasn’t even real sure where I was, where I was going, or what I was supposed to do once I got there. That had been Embrey’s job and I had been too much of a sniveling coward to insist on knowing the details.

Princess snorted and pulled up. My head snapped up, and I focused on the trail ahead. What in the heavens? The trail divided in a fork, but that was not what held my rapt attention. To the left, sat Sir Embrey on his midnight stallion. He smiled and nodded as if nothing was amiss. To the right sat Sir Gavin on a sorrel steed. He was dressed from head to toe in armor, but I could tell it was him because of his eyes and a shock of red hair that shown through the open face shield. He was also scowling at me as he was often want to do.

“Well,” I said, trying to gather my wits, “fancy meeting you two here. Out for a morning jaunt are you?” Sir Gavin’s scowl deepened.

“Sire, this is no time for joking. We must get you back to the castle where you will be safe.”

Sir Embrey’s horse took a restless step forward. “Sire, if you return to the castle, you will be a dead man. Night Haven is this way.”

I sat back in my saddle, crossing my arms over the horn with the reins dangling between my hands. I was hoping to effect a rather casual pose, though I was feeling anything but relaxed. I studied the two men. Who could I trust?

“Sir Embrey, how did you escape the Queen of Archadia? Frankly, I thought you dead. I know I heard you scream.” The last I said to get a reaction out of him. Though but minutes ago, I had mourned his demise, I now found myself furious to find him very much alive.

Embrey sputtered, “I did no such thing. Knights do not scream—“

“But they do,” I interrupted, “leave their king behind to face such a hideous creature?” I raised an eyebrow in challenge. Which fault would he admit? Either way he was a coward and I would see him exposed.

“Of course not, Sire,” he argued. “The Queen had captured and bound me. I lay but a few feet from the trail, helpless to move or even, as you suggest, scream.”

“Then, pray thee, Sir. How did you escape?” The words of the serpent slid through my memory——Trust no one.

Sir Embrey shrugged, “The Witch of Glen Eives had cast a spell of protection on me. Though the Queen of Archadia was more powerful, her hold on me loosened once she was dead. It took some time for her poison to fade but once it did I awoke to find my horse nearby. I immediately raced to catch up with you.”

“Catch up?” I asked. “How did you arrive here before me? You didn’t pass me.”

Embrey shrugged, “A short cut, of course.” I turned to Sir Gavin.

“And how did you find me?”

“That was easy, Sire,” Sir Gavin replied, his deep voice rumbling. “Night Haven is where the king has sought sanctuary. It only made sense that you would seek him out and try to dissolve the agreement between the two of you.”

“And why would I be safer back at the castle instead of following the plan you surmise I have made?”

“Because Sir Embrey never planned for you to reach Night Haven.”

“What?” roared Embrey, pulling his sword from his sheath. “You shall pay for besmirching my honor. I have done nothing but serve and protect Sir Keravin, as ordered by my King.”

“Oh, shut your trap, Embrey! You know very well that if Sir Keravin reaches Night Haven, he will have proven himself in valor and wisdom, and as such, his brother intends to abdicate the throne to him in truth.”

I gasped, “Whoa!” Both men turned back to me. “What do you mean my brother? My brother the King?” My voice ended on a squeak.

Sir Gavin nodded, “Aye, and meet your twin brother, Sir Embrey, younger than you by five minutes, making you the heir to the throne.”

Sir Embrey smirked, “Hello, big brother.”

“So with me out of the way, you become king? Why didn’t you just do away with me somewhere along the trail?”

“I couldn’t,” sighed Sir Embrey, “The Witch of Glen Eives cast a spell on me at our birth that prevents me from being directly responsible for any harm coming to you.”

“Did she cast the same spell on me?” I ground out, and Embrey actually backed his horse up a pace or two. “And I still don’t understand,” I continued completely furious now, “how going anywhere with you, Sir Gavin, is in my best interest either.”

“Well, I guess there is no harm in revealing all now.” Sir Gavin pulled his sword from his own sheath and before either of us could move had detached Sir Embrey’s head from his neck. “No,” Sir Gavin continued, “It’s really not in your best interest as I am in truth a Prince of the House of Martell. The plan was simple really. Once the King went into hiding to escape his assassins, we would finish off both of his heirs. With no heirs, he would either have to return or we would hunt him down and finish the dog wherever he was hiding. In fact, as we speak, a force is on its way to Knight Haven to do exactly that.” An evil smile lit Sir Gavin’s eyes. He raised his sword and spurred his horse toward me.

I surprised Sir Gavin—and myself—by spurring Princess toward the fight instead of away from it. I had my sword between his chain mail and through him before he could even blink. The force swept him off of his horse, taking my sword with him. He lay there on the ground staring up at me in surprise. I dismounted and retrieved my weapon.

Sir Gavin gasped as if trying to say something.

“Somebody should have told you not to under estimate the House of Stark,” I said. With that parting comment, I turned back to my faithful steed and mounted. However, as I turned back toward the trail, I found it once again barred by my friend the serpent.

“Well done, S-Sire,” he hissed. “I s-see you have filled out s-some s-since I last s-saw you.”

“Yes, you wouldn’t know anything about that would you?”

“I might.” He bobbed his head, “I trus-st you will remember me when you are king?”

I stared for a moment unsure how far to trust. At last, I decided I would need all of the alliances I could gain, and I rather liked the new me. “If it be within my power and is honorable, I vow I shall remember you,” I said, hoping I had not just sold my soul to the devil.

The serpent nodded and said, “The king awaits you in Night Haven.”

Sometime around noon, I emerged from the wooded path. Before me lay a small keep nestled in the valley below. Conscious of Sir Gavin’s threats that a force was on its way to kill the King, I scanned the surrounding countryside. The peaceful scene belied any treachery. Only a few trees and a handful of sheep dotted the landscape. A lazy brook meandered through the rolling hills.

The scene would have made a beautiful scene, but as a defensive position it was a joke. The enemy would automatically have the high ground and no moat surrounded the small castle. I doubt the property housed 50 knights. What was the king thinking? And who named it Night Haven? Please, more like Invitation to Raid at Night.

I spurred Princess, and we quickly reached gate, which was wide open. As we galloped into the courtyard no one challenged our entry. I slid off Princess and tossed her reins to a stable boy who had hurried out to greet me.

“Here, see that she’s properly cared for and where might I find the King?”

“The King, Sir?” The boy scrunched up his little nose. “There’s no King here.” No King? A sense of foreboding settled over my shoulders.

“Then where is the Lord of the Manor?” I asked, hoping he might have some answers. The lad pointed to the stone building off to the right of the courtyard. “Thank ye.” I hurried over and knocked on the door. I cook answered the door.

“Yes? What kin I do fer ye?”

“I’d like to speak to the Lord of the Manor, if you please.”

“Lord Channing? What would ye be wantin with the like o’ him?” She eyed me with distrust.

“I’m looking for someone and I hope he can help me. The House of Stark would be very appreciative if you would please.”

Her eyes widened and then she cackled as if she knew some inside joke. “Oh, it would, would it?” she asked. Opening the door wider, she bid me enter and have a seat in the drawing room. Soon shuffling feet scraped the floor. I looked up and gasped, surging to my feet to take a knee.

“Oh, pish posh! Now, rise,” said the King. “I am Lord Channing here.” He gestured for me to take a seat. “I’ve been expecting you for some time.”

I eyed the King shocked by his countenance. His once tall and robust figure had shrunk into that of an old man. His once handsome complexion was now marred by wrinkles and a scraggly beard. Had it not been for his shocking blue eyes I might not have recognized him.

“Sire?” I managed. “Or should I say, brother?” The king smiled.

“You may call me, Orion, if you please. It is true you are my brother and Embrey was your twin brother.”

“Was? Then you know?”

“Of course, the witch of Glen Eives is here and we have been shall we say monitoring your progress. I saw Embrey fall. I loved him, but the world will be a better place without him.”

“Why?” I asked, puzzled by his matter of factness.

The King shrugged. “Embrey’s soul was dark and poisoned by envy. He discovered too early in life who he really was and that panted the seed of envy. He has been plotting to steal the throne since he was a young lad.”

“Wait, can you please explain to me how I am your brother? I was raised in Hampshire as a lowly Lord. I haven’t even been a very good one at that. And what happened to you? The last time I saw you, you were a robust warrior.”

The King shook his head sadly. “For many months now that robust look has been thanks to the Witch of Glen Eives. She has masked the ravages of this malady that racks my body. A few weeks ago, she warned me that she could not maintain the cover for much longer. She also could not hide your identity much longer.” He glanced at me fondly. “When our father discovered your birth, his wife the Queen was insanely jealous. She cursed your birth and proclaimed that Embrey would be responsible for your death. To prevent this, my father enlisted the Witch of Glen Eives’s help. She has always been loyal to the House of Stark.”

I shook my head, “I’m not sure I understand.”

“The Witch of Glen Eives was more powerful than the sorcerous the Queen used. She was able to undo much of the damage but not all. For your safety, it was decided both of you would be separated and hidden away. Embrey was sent to live with a close cousin, and you were sent to live with a dear friend Sir Keravin. Unfortunately, the Queen discovered the whereabouts of Embrey. She used her money and position to plant people near him who would poison him against you and the throne.”

“But,” I interjected, “Wasn’t the Queen your mother? You speak of her as if she were some evil hag.”

“Yes,” sighed the King, “She was both. When she passed from this world, I grieved for the mother I wish she had been. Just as I will grieve for the brother I wish Embrey had been. It is that way in families sometimes.”

“Okay, explain the muscle thing? Was that the serpent? The witch?”

“Again, the answer is both.” The king smiled. “The serpent is the Witch of Glen Eives in disguise. You were never quite as scrawny as you thought but that was necessary for your disguise. Your adoptive family was not the most brawny of creatures and you would have stood out. Questions would have been asked.” The King eyed me a bit. “Though I do think she might have been a bit excessive with the new you.” He chuckled. “That might not last, but no matter. A bit of training and you will beef up in no time.”

“And Princess?” I asked feeling a bit perturbed.

“Oh, she was disguised as a nag. Couldn’t have Embrey knowing you were riding a horse from the King’s stable, now could we?”

“Look, this is all good, but what now? Do you know that the House of Martell is on its way to kill you and steal our lands?” I stood up and began pacing back and forth. The King eyed me warily.

“Yes, and I shall let them do me the favor of ending my suffering. But by that time, you shall be crowned King and shall be long gone from here. By the time they figure out they have killed the former King, you will have returned to the Castle and will have marshalled our defenses. I have made alliances with the House of Targaryen, the House of Arryn, and the House of Nights Watch. Each have promised their finest knights to join us in battle. They have all agreed to follow you.”

“But,” I protested, “ I am no knight, no strategist.”

“You are more than you know, brother.” The King rang a bell near his chair. “There are several knights whom you can trust implicitly. I have written their names on a scroll for you. They will guide you and teach you everything you need to know.”

“Yes, Sire?” A maid had silently entered the room.

“Bring me my scrolls and summon the Bishop and the knights.”

“Yes, Sire. Right away.” She bowed and backed from the room. In almost time, Bishop VanGrew glided into the room. Behind him three page boys followed each carrying an assortment of items.

“You are ready, my liege?” He asked the King. The Bishop’s eyes, heavily lidded held great sorrow. The last time I had seen him he had been full of mischief, but not now. The carried on his shoulders a great cloak of sadness. When the King nodded, the Bishop turned to me and asked, “Are you ready, my prince?”

“Ready for what?” I said, feeling completely confused.

“Ready to become king, of course.”

I shook my head, “Uh, no. I can’t. He’s still capable.” I gave my head another shake. “I can never take his place.” I felt tears burn the back of my eyes. I felt overwhelmed, terrified…. And somehow like I was losing a brother I never knew I had.

“No, you will never take his place, but you will be King in your own right,” The Bishop said. “To refuse is to leave the House of Stark and this kingdom without a king.”

“Fine, then when he dies, but not until then.”

“Brother, you must,” the King coughed, and gasped for breath. “I will be dead in days of natural causes and in hours if the House of Martell has its way. For the Kingdom’s sake, you must take the crown.” His eyes pleaded with me. “Please?” I felt myself sink as I stared my destiny in the face. I glanced at the Bishop and nodded.

Before I knew it, I was kneeling before the Bishop vowing to protect and honor the House of Stark. I could hear him praying in Latin as he placed the heavy crown on my head, making me truly the King of Stark. Our only witnesses were a few page boys, a maid, a cook and a half-dozen knights who had seemingly materialized out of nowhere. I briefly wandered where the Witch of Glen Eives was but dismissed the thought. After all, it wouldn’t do I suppose to have a witch and a Bishop in the same room.

As I rose, my brother feebly pushed himself from the chair. He took me by both shoulders and stared me in the eyes.

“Thank you,” he whispered a tear in the corner of his eye. “Now, I can rest knowing that our kingdom is in good and noble hands.”

Before I could respond, one of the knights, a Sir Mardune, stepped up. “Sire?”

“Yes?” my brother responded but grinned sheepishly when he realized what he had done. He looked at me, nodding for me to respond.

Yes?” I asked, feeling like a fraud.

“Sire,” Sir Mardune answered, “We must make haste. Ours spies tell us that the House of Martell is but an hour away. We must leave now.” With that the house and knights erupted into a frenzy of activity. Within minutes, I, along with an accompaniment of six knights, headed out on horseback in the opposite direction that Martell would come. I looked back one last time. Despite the ravages of age and disease, a noble man stood there, his hand half-raised in a gesture of goodbye.

1442321313212311113112211.content:
After several hours of steady riding, Sir Mardune, rode up beside me. He seemed hesitant to speak so I decided to help him along.

“Sir Mardune, is there something on your mind?” I glanced sideways at him. “Speak, please. I’m counting on you and the others to guide me through this. I need your complete honesty and your frankness. Don’t worry about offending me. I promise you shall keep your head.”

Sir Mardune nodded and grinned. “Of course, Sire.”

“Well?” I prompted.

“The scouts say we are now being followed. I don’t believe your brother gave us much time before the Martell’s discovered our trail. We must pick up the pace if we wish to reach our reinforcements. I would also suggest that we send messengers ahead, asking those reinforcements to prepare for battle. We could lead them into a trap, if you will.”

“You give sound advice, Sir Mardune. Who is our quickest messenger?”

“Lars, Sire.” Sir Mardune motioned for a young scout to join us. The lad could not be more than 15 summers. He was fresh-faced and eager to please. Sir Mardune leaned over and spoke quietly. Lars nodded and then spurred his horse. The two shot off like a rabbit I had once seen flee from a fox. I just hoped the fox that chased us would not catch up.

Two hours later, we crested a hill and halted in awe. Thousands of knights lay in wait. They and their horses were decked out in full armor, their weapons at a ready. I grinned.

“Sir Mardune? How many men do you think the Martells have?”

He shrugged. “Scouts suggest half of the force in front of us. They think they are chasing a small contingency, protecting their king. They have no idea our allies have joined us.”

So we waited in the hot son. From a distance, the sound of a small army moving over the countryside reached our ears. The enemy was making no attempt to hide its progress. They probably thought we were on the run and they just had to catch us. Well, keep coming, Martell. We shall let you catch us.

One of our scouts burst over the hill and skidded his horse to a halt in front of us. Both he and his horse gasped for breath.

“Whoa, there young sir,” I said. “Take a breath and give your report.” The boy sucked in several breaths until he was calm enough to speak.

“Sire, 300 knights are about 10 minutes behind me. I think they saw me so they may be weary.”

I looked at Sir Mardune. “There goes our element of surprise,” I said. “Unless….” I drifted off thinking.

“Sire?”

“What if I take a small portion of our knights up to the crest and pretend to stand our ground and fight? Then when the battle turns against us, and it will, we will turn and pretend to run right over this hill.” I grinned. “And the Martells will chase us right over that hill and right into our laps.” Sir Mardune nodded in approval.

“That could work, except for one thing.”

“What?”

“No way will we allow our King to be at the front. We can’t risk losing you. We will need a decoy.”

“No,” I insisted. “I understand your concern, but they have to see me. There can be no doubt or they will be suspicious. Plus, my knights must know that I am willing to fight with them.”

“Sire, since you asked for frankness, you are no trained knight.” Sir Mardune’s expression revealed his angst.

“True, but Princess and I have gotten really good at running.” I smirked when Mardune raised an eyebrow.

He sighed, “All right, but only if I am by your side. I am much better at fighting than I am at running.”

“Agreed.” We turned in unison and gathered a small force. As we crested the hill, my heart stopped. Other than my skirmishes over the last 24 hours, I had no battle experience. “Merciful, Father,” I muttered. “Protect us.” I flipped my visor in place and waited for the Martells.

When they were within a few hundred yards, I raised my sword and sceamed, “For House of Stark!” I slashed my arm down and we lunged forward to meet the coming melee.

The two forces came together with a loud cacophony. Swords slashed and clanged. One nearly took my head off, but Mardune’s sword met the incoming with such force the attacker was unseated. I was really beginning to like that guy. After giving enough to make it look as if we had tried, I gave the retreat cry.

We spun around and raced over the hill with the Martells right on our tail. As they crested the hill, they tried to pull up when they saw the formidable force waiting for them. Unfortunately, their sheer numbers pushed the ones in front forward into our trap. In the meantime, a portion of our knights circled around the hill and flanked the Martell forces. They had nowhere to go.

We showed no mercy.

Persnillica! "what a stupid, stupid name," I grumbled to my Page, Embrey the Exact.

"I quite agree, Sire," he whispered to me, rolling his blue eyes and, giving his head the minutest shake.

"Persnickity Persnillica," I shot back at him, gafawing loudly, quite pleased with my alliteration.

She was neither tall nor short, a little plump, but what man doesn't like something to grab onto. She approached us with her head down as if inspecting the stone tiles. Before I could even signal for her to be escorted away, she turned, sniveling, and ran from the hall. "Calinda!"

Lightening struck so close as we exited the assembly hall, we were temporarily blinded. We stood beneath the arch that flanked the massive wooden door, now hanging askew. Like a twin brother answering his call, the thunder roared across the castle as though it would shake the very stones apart. Within seconds, our clothes lay plastered against our shivering bodies, for it was a cold rain. The maids, all twenty, huddled in the entrance, their faces pale with apprehension.

In between gusts of wind, I shouted, "Embrey, tell the girls we head for the lower levels of the castle after the next thunder!" It didn't take long before the lightning lit the heavens again in multiple flashes, and I saw the skies were a swirling mass of violet and black bruises. Thunder crashed, and I raised my voice above the cacophony of the wind, "Now! Get them moving!"

Embrey led the maids out of the hall, some holding hands with their sisters for comfort. Following the young man's lead, they dashed straight across the cobblestones to another archway that would lead them down to a lower level of the castle.

I hung back as another barrage of violence erupted overhead. I could see the last of the girls scampering in through the arch across the way, young Embrey ushering them in. When the last went through, he beckoned me to cross. I wave him off, motioning for him to go, and held up the pointer finger of my right hand. "I'll be there in a moment!" I shouted, but I knew the lad would not here with the pounding of the rain.

When I stood alone, drenched through and through, I bolted from the arch, but turned left, not toward the safety of the lower level. I ran on down a hill and through a cobblestone courtyard, through another massive arch, until I saw the object of my desire ahead. This was the Peddler's Gate, where deliveries were made day and night for the many needs of the lords, ladies and even commoners of the castle proper.

A few small kegs, most likely empty of ale or wine, were stacked against a closed shop. I snatched up one and hoisted it to my shoulder, then another I tucked under my arm.

As I drew closer to the gate, a guard stepped out from a small enclosure. Within I saw another guard, and a table strewn with playing cards and mugs.

"What is you business, sir?" he asked, flinging the rain from his mop of dripping, black hair.

"Wine keep wanted so many kegs, so I bring him so many kegs. Oh, no, he says to me, you bring too many. I should have shown him my fist, but Fagarro is too kind for such things," I told the guard. "Now I must return them to my uncle, and in this storm. Ah, the life of a poor merchant, eh?"

Just then it began to hail in earnest, and the man wishing to get back inside, or get back to his card game, or maybe both, turned a key and flung open the small door, shooing me through. "Try and stay dry, eh" he said, turning and giving a wild laugh. He stepped within and slammed the door against the gusting wind.

"Free at last!" I ran...

When I thought I could not take one more step, up ahead, I spied a small cave off to my left. It was man-made, tunneled out of a large hill, its entrance supported by a frame of oak beams. Scampering in, I could see nothing, not even my hand held aloft. I stood there, shivering from head to foot. Tryl, you'll have pneumonia for sure if you stand here doing nothing.

Certainly, I had not had time to prepare for this unexpected flight. I had no dry clothes. I had no dry kindling to attempt a fire to dry those I wore. Nor had I any provisions to sustain me. Well, at least there's plenty of water, eh. Tyrl?

As my eyes adjusted to the dimness of the cave, a faint light glowed further in. Could their be King's Guards holed up in here? I took a few tentative steps forward, the light growing brighter as I went. Tip-toeing the last few steps before a bend in the cave, I inched my head around the curve. One gray-haired old man in a tattered but dry cloak sat warming his hands over a small fire set in the middle of a tiny room. The smoke rose to a vent cut in the ceiling. I noticed a large wood-framed carrying pack lying off to the side. My stomach rumbled at the thought of food. Continuing to stare into the room, I tried to decide if this man would be a friend or a foe. {I]What, you couldn't take on one grandfather if need be, Tyrl?

While I still contemplated my options, the old man spoke in a leathery, cracked voice, "You may come in, young man. Come share my fire, and warm yourself. Are you hungry?"

"Thank you," I said, stepping in and sitting across from him on the hard-packed dirt floor. I noticed he sat upon a nice padding of fresh pine needles and envied the comfort.

"No need to thank me, son. This particular shelter has stood here for eons, certainly before my time, and I am quite ancient."

Taking a closer look at him, I knew this to be more than true. His face was not just lined, it was a road map of deep crevices, which, oddly, gave him a kind of handsomeness, in a wise sort of way. His full head of gray hair shone like silver in the firelight. A matching beard and mustache accompanied his beautiful locks. A vibrancy vibrated about this old-timer. I couldn't lay my finger on why he made me feel so at ease. It was as if I'd known him, always.

Pulling his pack closer, he opened the main portion and removed a second cloak. The outer layer had been sewn with supple light-tan leather, its inner lining a patchwork of winter-white fox fur. It must have cost a fortune!

"Go ahead and strip off those soggy clothes, and use this while they dry," he said, proffering me the magnificent cloak. "Keep it if you like, too."

"But, I..., I could never accept such generosity. That is the finest cloak I've ever seen! Are those real jewels on the golden clasp?"

"They are. And this cloak is more than it seems, young man, but I've no use for it after today," he informed me.

"What do you mean?" I said, rising and stripping off my uncomfortable clothing, while he began to explain.As he talked I used a few taller branches he had gathered and built several tripods, lashing them together with some leather cording the old man had in his large pack. I draped my soggy items over them, placing them near to the fire. Throwing the cloak around my shoulders, I plopped down by the fire, luxuriating in its soft warmth as the old man talked on.

"Yes, well, the cloak was a gift, from my own father many years ago. Are you familiar with the sir name of Galvarn?"

"Galvarn..," I mused. It had a very familiar ring to it. Then it hit me! I let out a long whistle. Surely, you don't mean Gregor the Great?! Wasn't his sir name Galvarn?"

"The very one," the old man said, a generous smile blooming on his face. That would be my father, and great he was. I fear I pale in his shadow, but I have tried, and that is all one can do. No? And, may I have your name?"

"Tyrl. Tyrl Keravin."

"Keravin..., hmm, I do seem to recall hearing that name, though, it was a long, long time ago. It might be you've a connection to him, and if you are related..., and here he paused and said, oh, but forgive an old man's wanderings. Where were we? Oh, yes, my father."

"I would guess it would be no small feat to match your famous father. How came he by this cloak, and do tell me what else is special about it, if you please, good sir."

His next simple statement rocked me back, and my jaw hung slack. "It is a magical cloak, imbued with the magical property of invisibility, young man, though, I must worn you, there are many who seek it to this day. So I will let you decide how much of a gift you consider it."

I sat there a few moments, absorbing all he'd said. He, in turn, stirred the fire, causing a shower of sparks to cascade up and out, like a firemaster's display.

"How many are seeking this cloak, and exactly who will be looking for it?" I asked him, a bit of apprehension creeping up my spine. Nothing's ever free, is it, Tyrl?

"For the time being, you are more than safe," He said, though I thought I saw a twinkle of mischief in still-clear green eyes. "Let us put that aside for now, and perhaps you'd enjoy a small feast?"

Feast? What could he possibly have in that bag that would constitute a feast? "I am quite famished, and I do thank you for your kind offer," I told him, my mouth beginning to water, my stomach to growl.

"Let me see," He spoke as if to himself. After much rummaging about in his pack, he proceeded to pull one item after another out. I sat there, dumbfounded. No way is this possible! Seeing the stunned expression on my face, he smiled again, and said. "Oh, yes, it's a magical bag, too, if you hadn't already guessed that, Tyrl." He gave a chuckle, and spread the silk table cloth he'd pulled out with a flourish.

At once, like an experienced house servant, he'd begun to dress our makeshift table. Feast was an inadequate word to describe it all: wines of two kinds, both white and red, and ale to boot, golden goblets to drink from, a fully cooked grouse, stuffed, he told me, with early onions, carrots and cabbage, there was fish, and curried lamb, and here he briefly described his visit to a far off island, where he'd procured the curry and other rare spices too, small finger bowls of varying sauces and dips to delight your taste buds he said, a variety of cheeses, nuts, fresh succulent berries, and on, and on, and on, finally ending with a selection of sweet treats, which had me salivating, having quite the sweet tooth as I did.

We set about devouring most all of it, and let me tell you, that old man could keep up with me, bite-for-bite! When we could eat not another morsel, we sighed in unison, "Ahh..!" I let out a loud belch, and we shared a laugh. Leaning back on my elbows, my gut far too extended, I waited patiently for the old man to renew his tale of the cape.

Some time later, after I'd dozed for a few moments without meaning to, I noticed he'd packed it all up neat-as-a-pin. Feeling rather guilty for not doing my share, I offered to go out and collect more firewood for the night, but he just gave me another of his twinkle-eyed smiles, and said, "Oh, there's no need for that. You catch my meaning, Tyrl" He said, patting the bag...

I jumped up and strode over to the, not green but orange with violet spots, frog. "And what manner of thing are you?" I asked it.

Though I've been stuck here in the condition you see me in for some years now. I could return home, but for one thing," he told me.

But that too was many, many years ago." As he went on, he rummaged in his large, bulky pack, at last producing an intricately carved silver cup, which he dipped into the pool. "Try it, Tyrl. You won't be disappointed."

I took the handsome cup from him and brought it to my lips. I closed my eyes, trying to decipher the intense flavor it had. Then it hit me. Once as a very young lad, I had traveled far south with my father and mother. A sad occasion it was, though, as we went to attend the burial of my father's father. But while we were there, my father's sister, Annala, her name was, gave me a fruit I had never tasted before, as it grew not north of there, and she called it a Tangerillo.

"What flavor did you get?" the old man said, startling me from my memories.

"Tangerillo," I said.

He took the cup from me and took a long draught, draining the full amount he had dipped out. "Coconut!" he exclaimed.

"Coco what?"

"Coconut. It grows on tall trees on islands many days to the southwest."

"Does a co-co-nut taste like a tangerillo, then?" I asked him.

"Good heavens, no!" he laughed. They taste nothing alike. I'm afraid I've had a bit of fun at your expense, young friend."

"Let me guess, I told him. That's a magic cup, right? And everyone who trys it, gets a different flavor. No?" We both laughed, and he clapped me on the back.

"You're learning," the old man said, delight pulling up the corners of his mouth. "And, now, I am afraid I must leave you. Don't look so sad for we shall meet again, but I cannot say exactly when."

Standing, we came together in an awkward embrace, then I stepped back, and he put his hand upon my shoulder. I felt it quiver beneath his hand.

You'll do well, Tryl. Everything in the pack has its purpose, which you'll soon discover along your journey. Try and remember all I've told you, and be a man your mother would be proud of. I can ask nothing more. Now I must go as the hour has grown late."

"Glimmer," Bralina said, gazing up at him with big doe eyes, I noticed. "I thought you'd never visit us again; it's been so long, too long, my wonderful friend." She took up his hand and practically drug the elf across the room, depositing him right smack in front of me.

Now I know I've gone on and on about the old man's and Bralina's twinkling smiles and how they can light up a room, well, when this elf smiled, the whole world could have been lit up. He had the most dazzling set of pearly-white teeth! To say his gem-like green eyes twinkled would not do them justice.

Jarode let out a small a cough from the high-backed chair near the fireplace. "Prince Glimervan," he said, standing and giving the elf a deep bow. "It is a great honor indeed to see you again, young friend."

"The honor is all mine, good, kind, and truthful Jarode." Did he know and take the oath I'd just taken? And who have we here?" he said turning to face me.

I...,I am Tryl," I said, my body slightly rigid from awe. Not only is he an elf, but a prince; it was a bit much to take in all at once, and I plopped back down on the couch, flushing red again.

All three of them chuckled, and I grew redder.

"Come now, you needn't be embarrassed. We laugh with you for we ourselves had a similar first encounter." Jarode said. "He's a friend, and a good friend at that. Soon, you'll grow accustomed to these little surprises, eh, Tryl?"

"How do you do, Tryl, friend of my friends?" he asked,

"Very well, and you, Gli...Prince Glimmervan." I choked out.

When he laughed, it filled the room, like a small waterfall tinkling. "Quite well. Thank you for asking."

"Well," Bralina cried out. "Looks like it's time for yet another feast! Are you hungry, glimmer? I sure am!" Everyone laughed at this as apparently we all knew that Bralina was always hungry, though slight she was. She bounced off to retrieve the ever-bountiful pack.

Jarode's face grew serous as he asked the elf prince, "What, aside from our good fortune, brings you to our Path this day?"

"I am afraid I have bad tidings, regarding the advancement of "Bad', he said. What the heck does he mean by, 'Bad?

"Ah! As I suspected," the old man said, nodding his head and fingering his beard in slow strokes. "It is good you have come then, Glimervan, and Bralina, Tryl and I are at your command," he said and gave another of his low bows.

14423213133111121111111222122121.title: The Elf Stays for Dinner

144232131331111211111112221221211.content:
As we sat around the dinner table, a sumptuous feast laid out in honor of Prince Glimervan's visit, our appetites grew less and less as he spoke on.

"Many noble families, I am sorry to tell you, are involved in the spreading of this foul mind set, this 'Bad' as the elves have come to call it. It involves the loosening of the morals of men. To be more technical, it comes down to spreading the philosophy of 'What's yours is mine' Oh, never mind if a man is slovenly and has not earned it. This is a sickness creeping over our lands. So far it has been contained to where men dwell, but it is threatening to engulf all."

"This is very bad, Glimerman," Jarode said, hanging his head, and closing his eyes as if contemplating all the solemn elf had said. All of a sudden the old man stood up, his chair falling back. I had never see him angry, and I gaped as he slammed his weathered fist on the old table, rattling our cutlery and cups and plates. "This can be the doings of none other than my half-brother, Drakar. Foul he has been and ever will be. Do not take lightly that men and elves alike name him 'Drakar the dark. For his soul is mired in darkness, his heart black as the deepest pit." He began to slump, and quicker than I could believe, the elf was at his side, holding him up. Bralina, too, sprang up and righted her gramp's chair, so that Glimerman could settle him on it.

"Forgive my outburst," Jarode said, lifting his face and giving us all a half smile. "Ever has that man tried my patience." He fiddled with his beard as he was like to do when thinking, and said, "We shall defeat him. Yes. And all of the rest of those who spread this 'Bad'."

"May I offer a saying my father once told me?" I asked, looking around at the three of them.

"We would be most pleased to hear it, Tyrl," Prince Glimervan said.

"Well, I was often complaining to my parents of my long list of chores, that they were to hard, that I did more than my younger siblings, and so one night as I prepared to sit down with the family at the dinner table, and this was a night after I had done my chores but very sloppily and in anger, too, I noticed there was no plate where I always sat. When I asked my mother where my plate was, she looked down, and my father spoke up," and he said,

"If a man, or in your case, Tyrl, a strapping boy, won't work, then he shall not eat. I think it best if you go to your room and contemplate that, whilst your belly complains," he told me.

All three of my friends nodded at this as though they thought it very wise.

"Of course I was none to pleased by this, but as I grew, the saying stuck with me, and I grew to appreciate the wisdom of my father's words more and more, and I knew as well the harsh lesson had been done for the love he bore me."

144232131331111211111112221221211.title: The Advancement of 'Bad'

1442321313311112111111122212212112.content:
I'd no sooner finished telling of my father's words of wisdom to me, than the elf snapped his head around, faster than a hummingbird's wings. He drew a finger to his lips as he made for the front window, pulling the lace curtain aside an inch.

"Draw your weapons, my friends, and take up positions around each window," he said, motioning me to the other side of his as there were only two windows in the small cabin. "It would seem the 'Bad' has found us."

My heart pounded as I flew across the room, planting myself to the left of our window. No sooner had I, than a black-feathered arrow crashed through the window, glass shattering into a myriad of pieces. It buried itself with a pronounced "Thunk," into the high-backed chair Jarode had occupied a mere moment before.

"Close one," the old man said, giving a small laugh. He didn't seem at all concerned that men—and they were men dressed in black, wearing mail and helms,—we're trying to kill us.

The elf banged a large shard of glass with his elbow from his side of the window and rapid-fired three arrows: "Thwack! Thwack! Thwack," was the sound I heard as each struck one of our attackers, and with every one a man lay dead or dying. Man, he is so fast! Puts you to shame, Tyrl.

I let loose with one of my own, but it sailed on by my target, the arrow embedding in an elm tree. I blushed, which seemed to be my new favorite pastime.

"Slow and steady," the elf said, in his musical tone, and I tried again. This time I hit the man who appeared to be in charge. I'd noticed him standing in the rear and directed the other men about. My arrow took him in the thigh, but he went down with blood streaming from his wound, and I inwardly cheered.

"That's three for me!" Bralina called out, giggling like a child at a circus shooting booth. "That last sneaky trickster had a torch, too! Do I get double points for that, Glimmer?" Her face flushed from excitement, rather than embarrassment as mine had.

"Tryl," Jarode called to me. "Get down and crawl to the pack, and sling it over to me."

The pack sat about seven feet from me by the front door, and I crouched down, and crab-crawled to Jarode, depositing it by his foot then scampered back to my window just as another arrow blasted through the last remaining shard of glass in our window. This one hit the cast iron stove in the corner, snapping the shaft in two.

As I attempted to fit another arrow in place, Glimmer's hand whipped at the side of my face, knocking an arrow away, but still it grazed my cheek. I felt a slow burn, and a wetness roll down my cheek.

"Now that was even closer," Jarode said with one of his twinkling smiles. "You okay, boy?"

"Ye...,yeah, I guess," I said, swiping at the blood with my sleeve.

A horn sounded, and all at once the men-in-arms began to retreat. I gaped as they were cut down to a man, and after the last had fallen, a flood of elves dropped from the surrounding trees.

"Looks like we won't be needing the pack after all," Jorode laughed, and we all joined in, tension draining from our faces.

The king set his elves to building a funeral pyre, and once it was roaring, they took up the task of burning the bodies. I stood in stunned silence. "Wowzers!" I said, turning to gaze at Glimmer and his father, the King. "Your people built this place?"

"Many, many years ago, my new, young friend," King Fabellious answered. "We have made improvements over the years, but our forefather's certainly deserve the bulk of the credit."

You had to let your eyes take in their fortress city for a few moments as it blended in so well to the surrounding trees and vegetation. It was as if they grew the place not built it! Rope ladders made from hemp ascended into the gigantic Redwood trees and spans of rope and wood crosswalks spider-webbed everywhere! You could go anywhere you needed to go without ever coming down. And the living quarters! Amazing in their construction! These were no mere tree huts but palaces with towers and ramparts, brightly colored banners fluttering atop them from what had to be at least a hundred different elven clans.

"Pretty impressive, eh, Tyrl," Bralina elbowed me and smiled."

"That's an understatement," I said, returning her smile, but not without another of those cursed blushes.

"Come, my friends, and we will have a bit of respite and talk over our plans to defeat 'The Bad', Glimmer said. We followed him through the dense and lush vegetation. Flowers of every color, every scent, wafted up and delighted the eye, bushes laden with ripe berries, carefully placed, paced us down a neat cobblestone path (I snatched a few every so often, stuffing the sweet and juicy fruit in my mouth), and pools of that same teal water as the lake I'd seen earlier could be seen dotting the grounds every so often.

"This is my father's humble house," Prince Glimmervan announced. I bent my head and neck back, trying to take in the colossalness of it! It had to be a hundred rungs up from where we stood, and it spread out in every direction! Humble, my #*$! Off to the side, Glimmer helped his father into a large wicker basket, gave a tug on a side rope, and the king and basket began to ascend.

"You may do the same, Jarode," Glimmer said to the old man, but I am sure my friends would rather take their time and go up by hand and foot. That way they will enjoy all the views our fortress affords.

Bralina and I followed the spry elf up, and, about halfway up, I made the mistake of looking down. Dizziness threatened to topple me from the ladder. I gripped the ropes, my hands white-knuckled as sweat ran down my back and brow.

Glimmer gazed down at me and said. "Tyrl, try not to look down as there is much to see out and up." He gave me an encouraging wink, and I gave him a weak nod and tried to relax. Placing one foot on the next rung, one hand up,..Stop being such a baby, Tryrl!

At last we made the summit and stood upon a veranda of sorts. The view! Stunning would be a poor choice of words to match the grandeur! From our almost cloud-like view, I could see the surrounding lands for many miles: sparkling rivers flowing off into the east and south, grassy meadows waving in the gentle breeze, valleys, and even far-distant mountains. Closer in I even spotted Jarode's cabin. And! What are those small, dark things moving all around it? Peering harder, it hit me. King's Guard's! King's Guard's! I cried, grabbing Bralina's arm and turning her to where I pointed. "There, by the cabin!" I told her, I fingering the now bloody scab on my cheek, remembering our recent skirmish with them.

"Glimmer, dispatch a segment of elves at once!" King Fabellious told his son.

"As you command, my King," and, with that, glimmer gave a low bow to his father, then ran down one of the many walkways, where he was soon lost to view.

144232131331111211111112221221211211.title: The Beauty of the Elves

1442321313311112111111122212212112111.content:
An hour had not passed when Glimmer came up the rope ladder to his father's veranda, where King Fabellious, Jorode, Bralina and I reclined, and I do mean reclined, on fabulous velvet-clad wicker couches and chairs, which his servants had carried out from a large storeroom for us. We sat sipping spiced, ice-cold tea of a most delectable flavor I could not name. Several servants bearing the king's emblem of a mighty-antlered elk on their tunics, served us what the king had called a light lunch—a delicious bread the elves called Cambrelle, scrumptious, creamy butter and spreading cheeses, more of the berries I had snatched on the way up with little saucers and pictures of heavy sweetened cream to douse them in, cold roast venison, slices of duck smothered in an orange sauce, and tiny tea cakes peppered with nuts.

Though Glimmer had run all the way back and climbed the ladder in haste, he was not winded in the least.

"Well, Father," he said as yet again he bowed in respect to him. It was a larger pack of Kings' Guards this time, but I chose a band of our finest archers, who quickly dispatched them to a man. Let us hope that is the last we shall see of them for awhile."

"As always, Glimmer, your old father is proud of his faithful son," the king said, dipping his head to the prince.

"Thank you, Sire," Glimmer said, using a more respectful title than he normally did.

"Now, we were just about to begin discussing our plans to eradicate 'The Bad', King Fabellious said. Let me tell you how the elves believe this 'Bad' came to be."

"There was a time long ago when the land was pure, and no evil walked upon it. But their came to be born a man named Baraba, a man of lowly birth, but one who aspired to greater heights. At two and twenty, he left his father's meager farm and set off to do so. Along his way he met a sorcerer. This man believed in using his powers for the good of all men, much like your oath, Jarode," Baraba, convinced him that he was such a man, and that he would be willing to see to the wizard's every need, if he would take him on as his apprentice.

"I recall this tale," Jarode interuppted. "Carry on Fabell," he told the king, using a more familiar name.

"Yes, where was I? Ah! So this good sorcerer taught Baraba all of his secrets of magic, and he was renowned in all the lands for his skill, so it was an extensive undertaking. Now, there came a day when apprentice matched master, and Baraba grew jealous of his fame—he wanted this for himself." The king paused to take a sip of his lemonade, gave a little cough, and began again.

"One fateful night, when many in the village they dwelt in were at a fair two towns march from there, Baraba, carried out the dark deed he had long harbored in his heart. Just as we sip our drinks together this day, so, too did they, but this evil apprentice had doctored his master's drink with the fatal Febba leaves, found only on the edges of Lackamoore Swamp to the north of here.

"A most horrible death, I am afraid," said Glimmer, shaking and hanging his head.

"And so it is," said the king. When his master's body lay cold and stiff, he rolled it in a carpet, tossed it into the back of a wagon, and set off to dispose of it and to hide what he'd done in the same swamp the poison had been fetched from."

"Many days later he arrived at his destination," the king went on. Now this was already a dank and foul water, fit for no man to drink from, nor beast to live in. And when he threw his master in, immediately a fouler stench arose.

"May I interrupt a moment, Father?" Glimmer asked.

"You may my good son."

"I love to tell this part, because Baraba, 'Black Baraba' as some have called him, got his for the cruel thing he had done. Apparently the clever master had had a talisman of sorts tucked into a secret pocket of his robes, and Baraba had missed it in his search of the body. This artifact would grant the old wizard a brief period of life after death, so it would seem. I will relinquish the tale back to you now, Father," the prince said.

"Well, to get to the point," the king said. "The old wizard now knew he had passed on, and he had watched as his body was roughly tossed on that cart, thrown into the stagnant waters of the swamp, and his anger grew. When it did, the swamp turned dark as ink, and it bubbled and tossed about, until it became a swirling tempest. Up it rose, and rose, and then, it was flung all across the lands. And that was the beginning of "Bad".

"Glimmer, you may tell the last bit."

"Yes, and this was the first time that neighbor rose up against neighbor, coveting what the other had, the first time men slayed men, and all the land grew darker."

"Jarode nodded in solemn agreement, his weathered face bearing a frown. "We have had this 'Bad" with us since then, but always there have been times when it was pushed back as though it slept, but I fear, it has reawakened and in some strength this time.

14423213133111121111111222122121121111.content:
I suffered a fitful night's sleep, tossing and turning as I dreamed about 'Baraba the Black', only this time it was me he'd tossed in that foul swamp. Me who'd risen in anger, and me who'd played a part in helping spread the 'Bad'.

"Tryl, wake up, you oaf," Bralina's voiced drifted through to me.

"Huh? Is it morning already?" I rolled over and groaned, stretching my aching, tired muscles. "Arrrg," I let out as my arms and legs protested. "That long, long rope ladder did me in, I'm afraid."

"Aw, I think you'll survive. Now get up, get dressed, and meet us on the veranda," Bralina said and flounced off, swinging her slim hips as she went. I saw her glance back over her shoulder to see if I'd been watching, but she only winked at me when she saw I had been, while I blushed, yet again.

"Get up, get dressed, and anything else, your highness?" I asked, doing my best to sound as bossy as she.

Once outside, the fresh air revived me a bit, and I drew in a few long breaths of the sweet-scented morning air. "Good day, King Fabellious, "I said with a low bow. I gave a nod to Jarode, and Glimmer, and they both smiled. Bralina I ignored, but I heard her giggle as if that didn't bother her in the least. She loved to get my dander up.

"Young Tyrl," the king said, dipping his head to me. "I trust you slept well?"

"Oh, yes, um..., well enough," I said. "I mean, well enough, thank you, King Fabbelious. He laughed at this.

"Come enjoy some of these fine sausages. Glimmer and I made them ourselves with rare spices brought in from the coastal cites. Very good, if I do say so, myself," he said smacking his lips.

A servant brought me a plate and silverware—Real silver there, Tyrl— as I sat down at the teak-wood table. Bowls of: scrambled eggs with globs of melted cheese, fried potatoes topped off with a mound of sour cream, and more of the fresh berries I'd come to love, rounded off the meal.

"Jarode and I spent half the night discussing our plans to calm this latest storm of 'Bad'," King Fabellious said, looking, in turn, at Bralina, Glimmer, and then me.

"Yes, Jarode broke in." We think you three clever young people will do nicely," he said, giving us all one of his famous twinkling smiles.

"Nicely for what, Gramps?" Bralina asked, stabbing another sausage from the steaming bowl with her fork.

"A quest," the king said. We've been calling it 'The Quest of Three', which has rather a nice ring to it, eh, Glimmer?"

"I do love a quest, Father," Glimmer said, showing off his brilliant white teeth.

"I've never been on a quest," I said, then blushed as they all stared at me. "I mean, what will we do on this quest?"

"In a lowered, serious voice, an almost threatening voice, the king said, "You three will cleanse the swamp of its foulness, and thereby restore the balance of the 'Good' and the 'Bad', he told me, then included the other two with a nod at each. The look on his face brokered no arguments.

I gulped, and looked around at Bralina and Glimmer. While my heart had sped up, they seemed as if he'd just asked them to eat everything sweet that their hearts desired.

144232131331111211111112221221211211112.content:
SBy noon we had all assembled in front of the king on his veranda. It would be a three day trek to the foul 'Lackamoor Swamp'. King Fabellious, looked us over as though we were his King's Guard, which I suppose we were in some ways.

"May the blessings of the elves be upon your journey, young ones," he said, rather too solemn for me.

"Thank you, Father," Glimmer said, reaching out and hugging him in a warm embrace. They held each other for a moment, then broke apart, the old King giving a small cough.

Bralina and Glimmer hoisted their smaller packs on their back, while I carried the larger, though weirdly lighter magic pack the old man, Jarode, had given me. How many supplies would we really need with everything we could possibly want coming out of mine?

We said no goodbyes, which I thought odd, but then these were elves, and surely they had their own customs. When we made our way down the long rope ladder, at last, we walked out few paces, gazed up, and Jarode gave a wave, which we returned.

The day was warm, and we were soon all sweating under the high-noon sun as we strode from the forest and across the flower-strewn meadow. A deer drank from one of the teal colored ponds, stopping and lifting her head to watch us, though seemingly unafraid.
We entered the other side of the forest after a few moments, and we were glad to be in the cooling shade of the trees.

"What say we sing a song to make the time pass quicker," Glimmer said, stooping to pluck a blade of thick, green grass. This he folded and brought to his mouth. I looked up in surprise when he played a recognizable tune.

"Wow! Can you teach me to do that?" I asked him, and he gave me another of his dazzling smiles.

"It's fairly easy, once you practice for a few years," he said, clapping me on the back and giving a small laugh. He began the tune anew, and Bralina chimed in, singing in a sweet, high voice.

Oh, the maids are lovely, lovely!
Oh, lovely in the springtime.
Oh, the boys do flirt and flirt,
flirt with the swish a skirt.


"Hey! Those are not the words I learned to that song," I said, giving her a raised eyebrow.

"Nope," she said. "But they are mine, and Glimmer never said we couldn't sing original lyrics, now did he?" She skipped and did little twirls ahead of us, singing it again, and pretending she had a skirt to swish.

"Well, don't plan on making a career out of being a poetess," I called out to her as she'd gotten far ahead by now.

A few moments later we heard her squeal, and Glimmer and I raced ahead to see what the trouble was. Let it not be more King's Guards, I prayed.

Out of breath, we pulled up next to he. I bent over with my hands on my knees, panting though Glimmer seemed hardly winded at all.

There stood Bralina, her pack on the ground, and stripped down to her underclothes.

"Look at that gorgeous waterfall," she squealed again and walked out into the teal water. Why I ought to spank her while her bottom's wet! Making me think some beast had got her.

Glimmer dropped his back as did I, and we spent an hour swimming, splashing, and cooling off our sweaty bodies.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
As Glimmer, Bralina, and I dressed on the bank of the shallow pool created by the waterfall, a boy stumbled from the dense wood off to our left. He took a few staggering steps, then he collapsed in a heap. His clothes were soiled, his bare arms and face covered in a criss-cross of scratches and bruises.

Lightning fast Glimmer stood beside the boy, who appeared to be in his mid-teens. "Are you okay?" he asked the youth, kneeling down and cupping his head in the cradle of one arm. He un-slung his deer skin water pouch, removed the wooden cap, and offered the gasping lad a few sips.

The boy tried to talk but failed. The elf gave him another small sip, and said, "Take your time. We won't let any further harm come to you."

Sighing, he tried again, and got out, "I..., I...," before he lost consciousness.

Bralina and I joined Glimmer, stooping down to gaze at our unexpected arrival.

"Where do you suppose he's come from?" I asked them. "He seems to be pretty beat up and a bit malnourished to boot."

"Poor thing," Braliina said as she stroked the boy's flushed cheek. She pushed a few strands of blond hair from his eyes. That was when she noticed the small dart embedded in his neck. Her hand went up...

"Don't!" Glimmer's hand shot out and knocked her hand back down. "It's a poison dart, and I know who has done this to this boy," he said as he stood up. He searched the forest a moment, shielding his eyes with a cupped hand from the glare of the setting sun, then he told Bralina and I to grab his feet, and he asked us to help him move the boy to a more secluded spot in the shelter of the trees.

Once we'd walked deep into the thick forest, the hardwoods gave way to tall pines with wide spreading branches, and here, we laid the battered and drugged boy down, under a canopy of one of the largest pines I'd ever seen. Glimmer set about snipping off low branches, and these he stacked up in a wide circle. With care, we picked the boy up once more, and he gave a soft moan as we laid him on the bows.

Glimmer stood up, a frown spread across his handsome face. "Watch over him, Bralina. and give him sips of water, if he will take them. Tyrl, stand lookout, for I fear he may be followed, yet. I know of a leaf that will save his life, but it is a far ways from here, and I must be quick, if he is to live." With that, Glimmer shot out of sight. One second he was there, the next gone. How does that elf move so quickly!

The normally petulant, teasing Bralina had grown quiet. She sat on the edge of the boy's make-shift bed, once again stroking his cheek. She murmured a lullaby of sorts to him under her breath. I could make out only a few of the unfamiliar lyrics:

Hush sweet child 'O mine
for I shall keep you safe...


"Snap!" Someone or something stalked the forest. "Ssh, Bralina," I whispered, pointing to where I thought the crunch of a broken branch at been, but she was already nodding in silent agreement. I gazed all around. I saw nor heard anything.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Two Day Trek

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
The night wore on, and, still, Glimmer did not return. I lay on another of the three pine bow beds Bralina and I had made, while waiting for the elf to return with the antidote for our new, young friend. I gazed up through a bald patch in the massive pine we lay under—the night sky a brilliant blue with a spread of diamond-like stars scattered across it. Where are you, Glimmer!

Though I was supposed to be on watch, I must have dozed of for a minute, because there was Glimmer—for once he looked tired. I didn't think the elf would ever show signs of wear.

"I am so sorry...," I began, but the elf cut me off, and he raised his finger to his lips, nodding off to the east. "Tyrl, you must kindle a fire, and Bralina is trained, and will be able to produce a tea made from these 'Bava Leaves'," he said. As soon as it is cool enough, get a large cup of it into him as fast as you can. He may vomit it up, but do not let up, he must have a full cup, so replenish it as needed.

"Surely this intruder will see and smell the fire," I said to him.


"Yes. That is so. I must go and search him out first. Remain vigilant." And with that he pulled his quick disappearing trick again.

I searched for kindling and small twigs. Bralina gather a few small logs, and together, we soon had a nice blaze going. She set a flat stone atop it, and I placed a cast iron pot on this, which I had filled with water from a small stream nearby. Soon the water began to boil, and she added in the correct amount of leaves to make it strong enough for the boy's antidote.

While we waited for the concoction to cool, we sat close together, and I noticed Bralinas hands were shaking. This was so unlike her—to let her guard down—to not be'Bralina the Brave'. I draped an arm around her, and she leaned in closer to me. "It will be okay," I said, trying to comfort her. I smelled her sweet lilac-scented hair, and being brave for once, I planted a light kiss atop it. Her hair was smooth as corn silk.

She sniveled, and remained quiet. A night owl gave a long series of eerie hoots, and when I looked up through the gap in our pine tree, I noticed the moon was full— An ominous sign with the owl hooting, too, eh, Tyrl?

Not two seconds later, a wailing scream echoed through the woods. Shivers ran down my back, and Bralina shook all the more. Let that not have been Glimmer!

After the tea had cooled sufficiently, I propped the ailing boy up in my lap. He was still dead-to-the-world, so I gave his cheek a small pinch and whispered in his ear. "Can you hear me? We are trying to help you, but we need you to drink this down." He didn't open his eyes but let out a little moan. I released the breath I'd been holding, for he was so still and pale, I thought he may have left us.

Bralina dipped her finger in the tepid tea, and brushed it across the boy's parched lips. His eyelids fluttered, then opened, though he had a faraway look in his eyes.

"Wha...,"

"Ssh," Bralina said. "Don't try to talk, now. Here," she said, bringing the cup up to his mouth. "This is what will make you all better," she coaxed him into drinking it as if he were a small by, not a half-grown man. "Our friend, the elf, Glimmervan, ran very far to fetch the leaves of the 'Bava' bush. It is said they will counteract most any poison, for that is what has happened to you."

"Pois...," the boy said, but he choked on the liquid and began to cough.

"There. There." Bralina said. "Lets not talk on it anymore, just now." She poured a small amount more into the half-full cup, to replace what he'd spat out, remembering Glimmers warning that he must have a full cup for it to be effective in counter-acting the poison.

As the boy sipped, the color began to return to his round, still-babyish face. After he'd finished the whole cup, he was able to sit up on his own, though still a bit shakily.

Twigs and leaves crackled under someone's feet, and then Glimmer emerged from the forest, his bow resting over one shoulder. He smiled when he saw how well our young arrival was doing. "Well, it would appear someone's taken their medicine," he said, giving the you a wide smile.

"I'm starving!" Bralina said, and both Glimmer and I burst out laughing, while the youth stared at us in bewildered silence. I grabbed the magic bag and produce the best feast yet!

As I pulled one item after another from the pack, the boy's eyes grew wider and wider. Soon I had everything arranged on a silk tablecloth, complete with a candle and a vase of brightly colored tulips (which were out of season, of course). The boy drank in the aroma of baked turkey, steaming rice pudding, creamed corn with lots of bacon bits thrown in, and apple pie to-die-for!

"How?" he said, his moth hanging slack. "How are you doing that? I mean, it shouldn't even all fit i there!"

We all laughed again, and Glimmer began telling of Jarode's magic pack...

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
After our late-night supper, we all sat around the dying fire. Glimmer suggested the boy be given only water or mint tea, until his system would be purged of the deadly poison. We kept the conversation light, so as not to over-tax the youth. We did learn his name was Stevan though.

"Ahhhhhhhh," Bralina stretched her arms over her head, and said,"I think we'd better hit the hay. Morning will be here bright and early." She got up and made her way to her pine bow bed, plopped down, and was making purring noises within minutes.

I looked over to where Stevan lay and noticed he was already out. Glimmer and I sat up for awhile, watching the dying embers of our small campfire.

"So, tell me about earlier," I said. "Who did you hunt down?"

"It was another of the King's Guard." he said. "I believe he got lost in the woods, and that he was alone. "He won't be sneaking up on us again." His face was pulled down in a slight frown, his brow wrinkled as if it pained him that he had to keep taking people out.

"You were protecting the boy, Bralina, and me, and I thank you, Glimmer," I said, rising. "I think I will call it a night as well, my friend."

"Good night, Tyrl," the young prince said as he doused the fire with the remnants of the tea kettle.

Morning dawned with a heavy fog surrounding our little camp. Glimmer, always the first to arise, sat drinking a cup of strong coffee, by it's smell.

"Wouldn't mind some of that," I said. "Good morning." I arched my back and intertwined my fingers, stretching my arms up high. He poured me a cup and handed the steaming mug to me.

"Thanks. Should we wake the others?"

"Soon, for I am anxious to complete this quest as soon as possible. It worries me to be away from our fortress so long, what with King's Guards crawling all around the region," Glimmer said.

"I'm up," came a groggy growl. Bralina threw her blanket aside and sat on the edge of her pine bows, stretching her legs out and kneading her thighs. Apparently, those elven rope ladders had gotten to her too, though she'd never say so in front of me.

"And I," came a croak," from our new fourth member. The boy sat up and coughed. "My throat is a bit sore," he said.

"It most likely will be for a day or so. That poison works all kinds of dark magic," Glimmer told him. That poison comes from a plant near where I went for the antidote, and the only people I know who use it are the 'Swampers' as they are called. We'll have to skirt their known haunts, too, on our way to the swamp. We'll make for the north side of it. They believe there is big evil there and avoid it at all costs. I believe they may be right," the prince said, raising an eyebrow in my direction.

We packed up and set a slow pace through the fog. It hung around until way after high-noon as though to prevent our progress. But soon the sun broke through, and a gentle wind scattered it, leaving a crystal clear sky. The day was cooler than yesterday, and we were glad of it, for we found no other pools to refresh ourselves in.
