1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Two Days to the Swamp

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
A day's march from our final destination, the 'Lackamoor Swamp', ground zero for the origination of the 'Bad', we made camp. Hopefully, it would be the last of two stops before we finally arrived and completed this quest King Fabellious had entrusted to us three, which now is four, with the addition of the boy we'd picked up along our way.

We'd marched all day and all were weary: sore muscles, sore feet and sunburns for fair-skinned Bralina and I. We were a dusty, tired bunch in need of a bath. Fortune chose to smile on us when we exited a thick wood of maple and oak, entering a wide valley with a deafening double waterfall!

So tumultuous were the falls that we could not hear each other speak. We followed the series of cascading rapids strewn with gigantic boulders as if some Giant had heaved them helter-skelter in a fit of rage.

It looked as though we'd be having salmon for lunch and maybe dinner as well. Hundreds of them could be seen leaping and swimming throughout the waters. We camped on the gravel shores of the river, parallel with a good-sized inlet, where one could snatch the fish right out by plunging our hands into the shallow water.

Bralina and I as our custom had become, gathered and started the fire for our noon meal. Glimmer, ever quick, provided the salmon, and our new friend cleaned and, surprisingly, cooked them. We sat enjoying our meal and listened while Stavin told us about more of his life on his father's small farm.

"As I was saying," the boy said, "it's just me and Pa, since Mum died giving birth to me. Pa had taken to the bottle for many a year, but right around the time I turned twelve, he swore off of the stuff. After that, our farm began to prosper for a time. But no sooner had we built things up, than raiders would come in and steal and/or destroy our crops, fences, and one time they burned down our barn."

"I always suspected it was them Waldor's that done most of it, but we never did catch them in the act. They liked to do it when they knew we was off to market or visiting a small fair, times like that," he told us, pausing to take a breath and a long swill of iced-tea.

"That is very commendable of you to stick with a drunken father, and so you were rewarded with his sobriety," Glimmer said. He gave the boy a pronounced nod of his head and one of his beautiful smiles.

"Thanks, Gli..., I mean M' Lord, your Grace, if you please," Staving said, a slow blush creeping up his neck and face.

"Oh, do call me Glimmer," the prince said. "We are friends, after all, and friends needn't be so formal when they are alone."

"How much further is the 'Lackamoor Swamp', Glimmer?" I asked him as I took a bite of the delicious salmon and licked my lips. I savored the taste. Stavin had dipped them in batter and fried them on a large flat stone placed on the coals of our fire. He'd found a variety of rare spices in the magic bag (which the boy had become fascinated with), and sprinkled them liberally over the fish. I don't think I'd ever tasted better salmon than them.

"I would guess just under a day to go," the prince said. If we can march well into dusk, and, if we rise early on the morn, and march a good day's march, too," and at this pronouncement, he looked at the boy. "You do seem to be growing stronger by the hour, Stavin. Are you up for that?"

"I feel almost back to my old self, and I think after a good night's rest, you'll all be hard-pressed to keep up with me!" We all shared a laugh at that, and I clapped the smiling youth on his slender back, giving him a thumbs up.

We gathered up the supplies we'd brought out for lunch, and packed it all into our packs, then once again set off, following the stream bed for a good long while, before veering off into another dense wood of pine.

The further in we went, the denser the trees, which at one point were so tightly packed, we had to negotiate with care, lest someone get a branch in the face. Here, too, were many thorn bushes, and loads of itch weed, and other poisonous plants so that when it finally began to thin out, all of us were covered in a myriad of scratches and small cuts, well, all but Glimmer, of course. Two of us had poison Ivy, so we took an early evening rest.

"I saw a leaf that will take the itch from your rashes. It's just back a ways," Glimmer said, looking at the boy and Bralina, who were squirming and trying not to itch and make it worse than it already was.

"Be right back, and once we've made a salve, we can go on for another hour or two, before we make night's camp. The elf strode off with his easy, long-legged gait, and we all plopped down, enjoying a much needed rest from our long journey this today.

Too much time had passed, we noticed, and, still, Glimmer did not return. The sun was setting, and it cast shadows across the rippling waters of the river, making ghostly images appear to be floating by.

"Should one of us go seek him?" Staving asked when we were all pulling long faces and looking all about for our friend.

"No," I said. "Then I fear we'd be looking for two of us. Glimmer can take care of himself, and better than an of us," I added.

Bralina, who'd been quieter than normal ever since we'd picked up the boy, said, "I have a whistle, and it was given to me by Glimmer's Father, King Fabellious. Shall I blow it?" she asked, cocking her head and looking at us. "He will recognize it particular call." So typical of her,she didn't wait for us to answer. Putting the long, thin, wooden whistle to her lips, she gave a pronounced and shrill blast. We waited. Nothing. She tried again. No answer was heard.

"Stop that!" Glimmer called out, emerging from the woods. "Do you wish to call the King's Guard down upon our heads, foolish Bralina?" he said, and that was the first time I'd ever heard the prince speak even slightly harsh to anyone.

Bralina blushed a deep crimson-red, and looked down. "It was foolish of me. Forgive me, Glimmer."

"I should not have spoken thus," the prince said, hanging his head so that his long, blond hair fell across his tired face, but this quest has taken a tole on even me," he said.

He walked over and gave Bralina a warm embrace and a peck on her pale cheek. Brushing her short, dark hair from her face, he tousled her hair, and then we all stood up, and we were off again, marching until well after dark.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Glimmer, having heard Bralina's whistle, had flown back to us before he could get the medicinal plants for her and the boy's poison ivy rashes. They marched in sullen and silent discomfort, wiggling and flinching as if that would make the itching go away. I walked ahead of them with the prince, and we shared a small laugh, but not so they could hear. No sense in rubbing salt into n open wound.

After a weary three hour trek, we came upon the perfect place for a night camp. A considerable hill sported a flat spot at its summit, roughly twenty by twenty feet of grassy turf, which would be almost as soft as the pine bow beds we'd become accustomed to. We trudged up, sighing as we ascended, for we were weary, indeed.

The boy dropped his pack and flopped to the soft green turf! He spread his arms and legs wide, stretching and giving a big, "ahhh," as only a teen-aged boy could.

Glimmer laughed, and set his pack aside as he sat down and stretched his long legs out in front of him. He absently plucked a blade of the sweet smelling grass, folding it and bringing it to his lips to play us another tune.

Bralina did the honors in her high, sweet voice:


In a meadow, in a meadow,
in a sweet clover meadow,
came a fellow, came a fellow,
to my sweet clover meadow.



"well," I said unrolling my sleeping blanket and lying on top of it, for the night was warm and mild, I'm about done for. And the morning will come as it always does."

"Good night, ya oaf," Bralina called making her own bed. I heard her soft giggles at this and smile. She's growing on ya, Tryl. Best watch that or your roaming days will soon be at and end!

The song had many more verses, but that was all she could remember.

In moments our little camp lay sleeping, soft purrs from Bralina, and larger snore from Stavin. I think he has some serious nasal blockage! I lay gazing at the myriad stars, strewn across a black velvet sky, they twinkled like the old mans eyes when he smile.

Morning stole in with a nasty, cold rain, which soon had us scampering to pack up our camp. We marched out, munching on cold biscuits and little else, seeking shelter has quick as we could. We didn't find it quick though. On and on we marched across open field of knee-high grasses that soon had all of our pants. My left shoe had a small hole, and I could feel the water oozing in and out with every step.

Glimmer came to a halt, pointing off to our right.

Is that a cave? Out here on the prairie? Impossible! None-the-less, when we drew closer we saw that it was, indeed, a cave, though it was man-made and dug into a small hillock. It reminded me of the one Jarode and I had stayed in, when we hid from the King's Guard though this one was much smaller. I doubted any of us could stand erect in it.

As we all stood there inspecting it, wondering if it could shelter all of us, wondering if we'd have to crawl into it, a crow landed on a nearby oak tree. From its perch it berated us, "Caw! Caw! Caw!"

The door to the cave banged open, slamming against the hill, and out stepped the smallest man I'd ever laid eyes on! He had a long white beard that swept the ground. How does he keep from tripping on it?

We gawked at the little fellow, most of our mouths hanging open, except for Prince Glimmer, of course. He had more manners than we.. He wore a bright blue vest with a ruffled long-sleeved shirt beneath it. His shoes! His black shoes were polished to a high gleam and sported golden buckles. These caught the morning's sunlight and thrust it in our eyes!

"And who be you?" Glimmer ask him, shading his eyes with a cupped hand.

"I be, Vandermiremire," he said, giving a sweeping bow. "You may call me Van as my friends do. They do."

To our shock, the crow called out, "They do! They do! They do!" Apparently, he likes to say things in triple! He flew from his branch and landed lightly on Van's shoulder. "Food! Food! Food!," he screamed, so I thought he'd break the little fellows ear drum, but Van never flinched.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: A Crow Watches!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Vandermiremire, or Van, as he'd so politely said we could call him, reached up and stroked the sleek black feathers of the crow's back. I would have sworn, right there and then, that that darn bird twisted its neck to the side and kissed him. And there was a total look of admiration gleaming in its dark, beady eyes. I am not joking. The bird seemed to calm at his touch, and instead of screaming, it said, "Van. Van. Van," with a kitten's purr of affection!

"Yes? Yes. Food we must have. Yes?" the little man said in his queer way of speaking, clapping his small hands and nodding all the while, and giving us a wide grin. "So, come. Yes?" And, with that, he turned, and, without having to duck at all, he retreated back into his earthen cave. A moment later, when we had not yet decided who should follow first, we heard a faint call asking from far off, "Yes?"

Glimmer flashed one of his pearl-white smiles and ducked low, answering Van as he went in, "Yes! Yes, we come."

Bralina, Stavin and I burst out laughing. This was probably the most fun we'd had on this quest.

Each of us remaining outside took a turn at stooping and entering the little fellow's home. Once inside, we descended down a long cobblestone path, which twisted and turned the further in we went. The walls brushed our shoulders at times, and other times we had to turn sideways and scoot along. Rounding a bend, we reached the apparent end of the tunnel, and and all three of us stopped and gaped!

Glimmer stood grinning like a court jester. I think that's the only time I'd ever seen the prince acting like a commoner, his mouth hanging open with a dazed look of amazement pasted on his handsome face. "Its..., it's quite something. Isn't it?" he asked, gazing about a wondrous woodworking workshop.

Too stunned to answer, I gave a long whistle instead. Everything, from supplies, tools, half-made and finished works, had been placed in the perfect position, so that your eye took them all in in a glance. Here stood a bench, with larger tools, saws and clamps longer than the little man, and above, row upon row, hanging on brackets, were hammers of all sizes, chisels, their sharp edges gleaming in the many over hanging candelabras, awls, hand drills and so many other bits and piece. Only two words could describe the owner of this fabulous workshop: organized and talented!

Van stood bobbing his head, which seemed slightly out of proportion to his small, compact body. "Like? Yes, like."

"Like's not the word, my friend," the prince said. "How long have you had this workshop, and who do you make all these marvelous things for?"

The little fellow did not answer, but merely smiled again.

There was no end to the variety of objects Van had created. It must have taken him years to accumulate it all, not-to-mention all the wood he would have needed to haul down here to make them. There were: dolls, who's faces were painted with such life-like qualities, you might not be shocked if they got up and walked, horses pulling carts laden with this and that, flowers carved in such intricate detail and painted so realistically that one would think they could actually smell them, shields with beautiful emblems emblazoned on their fronts, toy soldiers, and..., too many things to name all in one day.

We spent about an hour drinking in all the wonderful sights of his workshop, then the little fellow said, "Come? Yes, come." He motioned with one hand for us to follow him down yet another tunnel in his warren-like home.

The crow, still nestled on his shoulder called out,"Come! Come! Come!"

While the workshop was stunning, his living quarters were quaint; lace curtains on windows that had been painted so as though one would think they really were gazing outside. One window pictured a mountain scene with evergreens marching up its slopes, and yet another cast your eye on a meadow spread with a magnificent bouquet of wildflowers. I walked up to it, reaching out to be sure I couldn't feel the softness of their petals, smell their lavish perfumes.

"These are amazing, Van" I told him, turning around and grinning at him, for the windows inspired one to grin.

He returned mine with one of his own. He really was a pleasant little guy.

"Eat? Eat, yes," he said.

We watched him prepare our meal in his just-his-size kitchen, even the ceiling was lower there as if he had made it off limits to anyone else, well, to normal sized people. We sat in his miniature chairs, Glimmer reclining on a fairly nice sized sofa. The furniture though tiny felt as though it were very sturdy and would bear our weight.

After a time, the most delightful aromas began to fill the rooms. I breathed in, trying to distinguish the many smells wafting about. "Is that lemon pie," I asked Van, and he turned nodding his head up and down, more than was necessary to convey his affirmation.

"Lemon pie. Yes. Good."

"Good! Good! Good!", screeched his pet bird as it flew into the living room and landed on the arm of my finely-made wicker chair.

"Name! Name! Name!" it seemed to ask. "T...,Tyrl," I told it, scratching my head. I didn't know if I quite trusted the thing, if it would suddenly fly at me and try and pluck out my eye, but it remained perched there, staring at me.

"Eat," called Van, and he began bringing us out many dishes of steaming food, which we carried to his miniature, though long oak table. I saw now that he'd quickly put together quite the feast: roast duck, a very large bowl of mashed potatoes, and there were candied yams, and, of course, the lemon pie I had smelled earlier.

"Eat! Eat! Eat!," the crow called, and so we did. Van fed it bits of duck as it once again perched on his shoulder.

After we'd stuffed ourselves on Van's delicious meal, we took to the living room once more. All were content to sit and stare at Van's wonderful painted windows, where one could imagine this underground den set above ground in a beautiful meadow or at the foot of a wooded mountain slope. We sat in silence for some time, each lost in their owns thoughts.

Glimmer broke the silence saying, "As Tyrl is like to say, morning always comes, so I think it best we thank Van for that fine meal, once again, and get some shut eye."

We all murmured our assent, and thanked the little man, shaking his arm up and down, patting him on the back.

Van stood up, and hopped form foot to foot, then ran over to a wall with framed pictures. I had noticed them before, eight of them, hung neatly in a row. I'd thought they might be of his parents, siblings or passed on relatives, but when he motioned us over, I saw that each bore a striking resemblance to the little fellow; they shared his same short stature, and many were the spitting image of him, with some perhaps having different hair coloring or a longer nose, but much the same, still.

"Mine. Yes, All mine," Van said, puffing out his chest and rocking on his heels in obvious pride. "Mine! Mine! Mine!" screamed the crow, startling everyone but Van. {I I wish he'd stop that!

"Those are all your children?" Bralina asked him, and he nodded, smiling wide.

"Sandermotemote, Festerinerine,bailygormgorm, he went on, reciting and pointing to each picture as he went down the row. I wonder why they all have names that repea? Did their namer have a stutter?

We nodded, and Stavin said, "What a fine lot of children you have, Van. They must be a big help to you, no? Where are they all?"

At this the little man hung his head, his mouth pulled down slightly at the edges. "Gone. Yes, all gone." He spread his arms out wide and turned in a circle, pointing at the four directions. "Married. Gone. Babies. Yes."

"Do they ever come to see you,?" Bralina asked, she looked as if she would cry for him.

His face brightened at this though, and he darted across the room to a corner desk carved in intricate patterns and polished to a high shine. From this, he pulled out a calendar, bringing it over to us. He pointed at a big X placed on the 20th of this month, which would be in nine days. "Coming. Yes, Sandermotemote, come. Wife. Babies, many." He told us.

Bralina smiled, and a "Ah," escaped her parted lips. "I am so glad for you, Van!" He grabbed her hands and they both spun around in wild circles, then they fell apart, and he gave her a bow, and she a curtsy to him, and then they both laughed, their faces flushed.

He shook his head up and down, then said, "Sleep? Beds. Yes, many beds." At this he chuckled some more and marched off down another tunnel. We followed.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Just as always I always say, "morning came," and Glimmer roused everyone from their beds. Since there were no real windows in Vans warren-like home, we had no way of gauging the time.

"Morning. Yes? Good morning," Van said as we all stumbled into the living room, rumpled an bleary eyed. We all nodded to the little fellow, saying the same to him.

"Breakfast. Yes?" he asked, already moving towards his little low-ceiling kitchen. He hummed a merry tune as he went, and began slamming pots and pans onto the stove.

"I wonder what we'll be having this morning?" I asked the others, my stomach already rumbling and my mouth watering, for I knew whatever it was to be, it would be delicious.

Soon we sat about the old oak table, stuffing our mouths with a honey-sweetened porridge, crisp bacon, scrambled eggs smothered in three kinds of cheese, and a delicious pineapple-orange drink. I wonder where Van got those fruits this time of year and so far north of where they grow. Must be one of his many children delivered them to him.

"Delicious!" Stavin said then burped. "Excuse me," he blushed. "That was yet another fine meal, my little friend," he told Van.

"Fine! Fine! Fine!" the crow called out. It had chosen to sit right on the edge of the table next to Prince Glimmer, who like Van had at dinner last night, fed it bits of food.

After a time, we all pushed our plates back, our bellies more than satisfied.

"Van, my good friend, we have enjoyed your gracious hospitality, and for that we thank you." Glimmer said, pushing his chair back and rising. "But all good things must end, and now we must be on our way to complete our quest."

"Quest! Quest! Quest" I'll give ya a quest if you don't shut your beak, you annoying black-feathered beast!

"Crow go. Yes?" Van asked, looking around the table at each of us. "Yes. Crow go. Lead."

"Are you telling us the crow knows the exact way to 'Lackamoore Swamp?" I asked him.

"Lackamoore. Yes. Not far. Crow go."

"Okay, so now we are a party of five it would seem!" Glimmer laughed, and we all joined in, well, me just for show as I was none-to-happy to be having that loud mouth bird tagging along on our quest. And, just to rub it in, he screamed, "Five! Five! Five!" I covered my ears and sulked, stomping from the table to gather up my pack.

Bright sunlight struck our eyes. I blinked and looked at the ground, until my light-sensitive eyes adjusted. The rest of our group gathered around me as the little fellow emerged last. Big hugs were shared all around, and I saw tears slipping from Bralina's eyes.

Van wiped them from her cheeks with his small thumbs then planted a kiss on her forehead, which she had to bend over to receive.

"Goodbye! See you soon!" we all said and turned, heading down a well-trodden path, heading north.

"I'll miss that little guy," Bralina said, and we all agreed.

A whoosh of air ruffled my hair as the crow flew right over me. It looked back directly at me as if in challenge, as if it knew I didn't want it along. "Go! Go! Go!" it said, and I knew it was mocking me.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
We had an easy go of our morning trek, but as the day wore on, we moved into hilly terrain that forced our weary legs to march ever up and up. At times, the steepness had us slipping and sliding, for a light rain had fallen here over night, making our footing treacherous. We grabbed onto small saplings or roots to keep from plunging down.

No sooner had we crested one of these monumental hills, than we were sliding down its backside, loose gravel kicking out from under our boots, then up another—an endless row of teats rising.

"Can...,we...,stop a moment?" Bralina asked, bending over and breathing hard as sweat poured down her flushed forehead and cheeks. I was glad she had asked, for my legs trembled and felt as though they'd turned into bread dough.

We were on top of one of these teats, and we could see for many miles. "Look, there," Stavin said pointing down and to his right. A meandering path cut through a light wood, and skirted around the last of the four giant hills. "That's the way I'm going," he said as he tossed his pack down and himself too.

Glimmer flopped down, too, and gave the boy a head rub. "Smart boy," he said.

We rested for half an hour, then made the last descent, and all of us agreed that we'd find another way to return, if we could.

About two-thirds of the way down, Bralina's foot twisted on the root of a scrub bush, and she went head over heels, landing in a heap. She let out a yelp at the bottom, wincing and holding her ankle. "Ahhh, it hurts!" she said as her face scrunched up in pain.

"Let me see, Glimmer," said, being the first to reach her. Stavin and I slid down the rest of the way and went to see if we could help.

"It'll be okay," the boy said. He reached out and grabbed her free hand.

"Take you hand away, Bralina," Glimmer said. He gave her an encouraging smile, and said, "Let me see. It's probably only a sprain." I could see blue and purple spots rising around the back of her ankle though no bones protruded, thankfully.

After his careful examination, the prince assisted Bralina in sitting up. "It's not broken, but I don't think you should walk on it for today, maybe tomorrow as well.

"Stavin, and you, too, Tyrl, scout around for two sturdy young saplings to make a travoix," he told us. "Here, wait a moment." He walked over to me and rummaged in my pack I had set by my feet. He pulled out a very sharp ax and handed it to me. "This should make light work of cutting them down."

Glimmer picked up Bralina and carried her to rest in the shade of a large pine. He gathered bows from its lower branches, building them up to make a foot rest for the girl. "It will aid in reducing the swelling if we keep that foot of yours elevated." Bralina gave him a small smile though the pain was still writ across her wrinkled brow.

"Thank you, Glim," she said then closed her eyes, and soon she was purring softly, giving a little moan every now and then.

About twenty minutes later, Stavin and I returned with the saplings, which Glimmer stripped of the small branches with a sharp knife. "Tyrl, go get your pack, and search it to find a large piece of leather and some rawhide strips."

The pack, being magical, came in handy, and, in no time, I had procured the items Glimmer needed. Stavin and I helped lash the leather to the poles, and soon we had a sturdy frame on which to carry Bralina.

We ate a light lunch of cheese, grapes and fresh-baked bread with butter—thank you, pack. After ten minutes of letting our bellies rest, Glimmer and I gently placed her on her new ride, and we set of again.

"Aren't you lucky, getting to ride the rest of the way to the swamp?" Stavin teased her.

"Ride! Ride! Ride!,' screamed the crow. He'd been circling ahead of us the whole way, but now her landed on Bralina's good leg, making himself at home. "Ride. Ride. Ride," he said in a much softer voice. that is one smart bird. Annoying but smart none-the-less.{?i}

It was hard going with two of us pulling Bralina along on her travox. Glimmer and I went first with Stavin spelling us each for a shorter time. Bralina complained that she most likely could walk, that all this business really wasn't necessary, but we didn't pay her no mind. Her ankle—though not too swelled— had turned a vivid mixture of purple and blue and was still painful to the touch and/or any movement. There was no way she could bare weight on it yet.

The wind kicked up a notch, blasting our hair back from our faces, and we put our heads down and trudged along, slower than we had been before.

"What is that awful stench?" Stavin asked, waving his free hand about his face as he pulled his side of the travoix one handed. "It's enough to make me gag!"

"Lackamoore Swamp, my friends," the prince said. He knitted his brow, gazing ahead. "It won't be long now. I suggest we rest in the shade of that large maple tree up ahead. We need to discuss out plans to complete this quest."

None of us argued as we were more than wore out. Days of marching had done us in, and we all had the blisters, aches and a sprain as in Bralina's case to prove it.

We all flopped down, relishing the shade the elm provided. "How much further do you think, Glimmer?" I asked, stretching out on my back.

"I'd say less than two miles, Tyrl, at least from the strong smell coming off of it.

"I remember Jarode said we must toss in the talisman he gave us, but were there any words to say? I don't recall," Bralina said.

"I believe we toss it in, say a quick prayer to banish the 'Bad', restore the "Good', then we get out of there. Jarode seemed to think something violent could occur," Glimmer said. I think Tyrl and I should go alone the last two miles as there's no way Bralina could run if need be."

"Now just a dang minute! I didn't come all this way to be left behind," Bralina said. Her face scrunched up in a scowl, her lip protruding in a pout. "I won't stay behind! My ankles almost good as new, what with lying around all day on that contraption."

It has been decided. You would hinder our escape if it is needed. Glimmer stared her down, until she cast her eyes at the ground, still pouting but no longer protesting.

"Stavin, you okay to stay and watch over her?" I asked him.

"Sure. This were never my quest, and I've only come along to see a bit of the land. Ain't never been off Pa's farm much. He gave me a smile and sat down by Bralina, who'd grown very fond of the boy.

"Let us get this over with, Tyrl." And he and I stood, giving the two remaining behind friends a nod. As we'd gone on down the road, my knees took on a tremble. Just what lives in the Lackamoore Swamp? Will we come out if we go in? I had my doubts, that I did.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
We were close now! The stench filled our nostrils, and we had to stop frequently to bend over with our hands on our knees, and wretch. Never in our lives had we experienced such vile fumes! It burned our eyes and throats raw.

"Glimmer! I...I don't know if I can go any closer!" Not only were the vapors coming off of 'Lackamoor Swamp' making my stomach do massive convulsions, but my head began to pound and spin, so that my legs became unstable. I looked over at him, and he was pointing back the way we'd just come. I saw his lips saying, "Back! Back! and we turned and stumbled back for half a mile, finally collapsing beneath the cooling shelter of another massive pine.

"That was beyond gross, horrible, no..., I don't know what it was," I said, swiping at the tears streaming from my sore eyes.

I' ha...ehh, ahh!" Glimmer coughed and spat out a wad of black slimy goo. "Arg..! That is just nasty business!" he said. His face had gone pale, and I thought he might collapse, so I sprang to his side to support him. He breathed in a few more gulps of the, at least, fresher air here by the tree, though it still carried a pungent blast of foulness.

"I'll be alright", Glimmer said, a bit of color coming back into his cheeks.

"You scared me about as much as that awful wailing we heard, I said. I don't know if I want to find out what that was."

"I know, ahh! I wish it were not so. This quest is more than I bargained for."

We rested for a good half hour, then Glim sat up, and said,"Here's what we'll do, my good friend. There is pine sap leaking from many of the branches and the trunk of this tree. We will gather up as much as we can and spread it on small pine bows, placing another layer on top. It's fairly sticky stuff, so that should glue it together. Then we shall lash it across our faces, covering all of our noses and mouths. This should help somewhat with the horrendous odor, though I don't think there is much we can do for our eyes. At least we won't be retching every few minutes.

It took some time to accomplish this task, but once our pine bow masks were in place, we set of again, though we both seemed to want to drag our feet, in no hurry to get back. We looked to be two men walking to the gallows.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Something Lives in the Swamp

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Foot dragging or not we came back within sight of the cursed Lackamoor Swamp. The pine bows Glimmer had suggested worked well to diminish the foul stench but nothing could eliminate it completely. And, while our noses and stomachs were most grateful for the masks, our eyes suffered horrendously. I looked over at my friend and thought he must be crying, for great tears fell in abundance from his eyes. He swiped at them and shook his head, new ones forming before his face could dry. I, too, did the same, wishing this were over and done with.

As we wrestled with our blurred vision another problem arose, for a great gray cloud formed in the middle of the swamp, where the reeds grew thick and tall. It snaked out like ghostly fingers, its tendrils searching us out. Within minutes, we could see nothing, not he I, nor I him, nor even our own outstretched hands, so complete did it block out any light.

"Glimmer!" I said, panic rising up to form a bile in my throat.

"I'm here," he said, reaching out and poking me in my already sore eye.

"Ouch!"

"Sorry, Tyrl. I didn't realize you were standing so close to me now."

"What are we to do now, Glim?" I asked. Jarode said the talisman must be thrown into the very heart of the swamp, and we are only standing on it's edge."

"We must inch our way in. But be very careful where you place your feet, for there are sinkholes and much that can swallow a beast or man whole. Come," he said, gripping my wrist and trying to pull me forward a step."

I gulped. For a moment my legs remained locked as though they were between the jaws of a massive vice; trapped firmly in place.

"Tyrl? Are you okay?"

"No, but lead on." I hoped the quiver in my voice wasn't too noticeable.

We advanced three steps before we heard something, "Clickity-clack, clack, hisssss," it cried out, like some grotesque half reptilian, half insect thing. It was approaching fast. To make matters worse it now chomped its jaws together, or so I imagined. "Chomp! Chomp!" They had to be very large jaws, with very large teeth, to make such a loud racket. I gulped again, reaching out and grabbing Glimmer's shoulder. "Whaa...,oh, man, Glim, what is that?"

Such a fear rose up in me that I attempted to bolt, but the elf held firmly on to my wrist as if he had anticipated this.

I felt him lean into me, and whisper, "To the left. Go to your left." Now I was leading him, hoping I'd not guide us both into a mud hole or something worse.

The clacking noise became fainter, and we both stopped for a moment. Sweat rolled off my face, my heart fluttered like a cadged bird's wings hitting the bars of its prison. "I'm scared, Glim."

"And rightly so," the elf said. That helps! Thanks, Glimmer.

A light wind touched us for a moment, clearing away a bit of the putrid gray cloud that had surrounded us. We could see around in about a six foot diameter. No more. I spied a large stump from some long dead oak it looked to be, and both of us sat down, breathing hard. No sooner had we than the cloud engulfed us once again.

"I'm really not liking this swamp at all! I hope we find those reeds soon, toss that darn talisman in, and get the heck out of here! Without getting eaten, too, huh, Glim? No answer. Glim? Gim!"

I thought I'd upchuck right then and there, so frightened was I to think I was alone, alone with that thing out there. "GIMMER!" Nothing, not a peep, but then, far away, but growing louder, "Clickity-clack, clack, hsssssss! "NO!" I jumped up and bolted back off to my left.

The elf prince had been sitting to my left, so surely he went this way. But why did he leave me? Or did he? Maybe that thing stole up and took him, or maybe he stood up and paced about and fell into a whole. Stop it, Tyrl! Get a hold of yourself.

After slogging forward a good dozen paces, I heard him. Gurgling, the words hard to make out.

"Ty...,glug...,rl...,ahhgh!"

"Glim! Where are you?" The sound had came from lower than where I stood, so I got down on my knees, crawling about in a wide circle.

"He...,help...aagh!"

I reached out both hands swinging them in a wide circle. "Slap!" My left hand struck the soft flesh of what had to be my friend. My other hand shot in, and I reached down into a slimy substance, grasping the elf beneath his armpits. I tugged, but he would not budge. I gripped him tighter and strained back with all my might. I kept up the pressure, tugging even harder, until at last I heard a sucking, slurping noise as his body withdrew from the gross muck.

He lay half in, half out of it, while I sprawled on my back, thoroughly spent.

"Tha...,thank you, Tyrl, my..., my friend." He lay there panting for a time, then used his arms to drag himself the rest of the way out. "I thought..., I thought my goose was cooked for sure!" he gave a small laugh, but I knew he didn't think it a bit funny.

"Me too," was my only response.

We had not rested but a few precious moments before the beast could be heard, closer than ever. Now I could hear that its body must be cavernous. A loud slithering, slopping, thud, thud shook the ground, threatening to knock us from our feet. We scrabbled up, Glim taking the lead, and dragging me along again. "Run!" he said, and I swear I felt hot breath on my leg, and the hideous clacking right behind us. "Faster," Glimmer said. We bolted like two scared wet hares escaping a flooding warren.

We came to an abrupt halt as we crashed into something solid and unmoving. We fell apart, crumbling each to a side. "Ouch!" I said, grasping my right elbow. "Glim?" When he didn't answer immediately, I screamed at the top of my lungs, "GLIMMER!"

"Tryl! Stop that! I am here. I thought my neck was surely broke. It took me a moment to regain my breath," he said. But to be sure, I scooted close to the sound of his voice, and reached out and touched him with my shaking hands. I sighed.

"You must try to be quite. We will draw that thing to us otherwise."

"Yes. I am sorry, but I just want this over with, Glim. You know what I mean?"

"I hear you, my friend. Soon it will be." And he said it with such finality, I nearly believed it. Nearly.

"Come," he said, placing his shoulder next to mine. "Let us see what we crashed into. Perhaps it will lead to the center of the swamp."

We crawled back where I had sat and put our hands out, groping in the gray mist. Our hands touched smooth wood. "A door!" I said, standing, and searching. "I found the knob," I said. But, all of a sudden, I thought, Maybe we don't want to open it. Maybe something worse than clickty-clack thing lives within!

The elf prince stood alongside me and pushed my hand off of the knob. "Wait." he said, he reached inside the pack on my back and brought out two glowing swords. They emitted a bright blue light that drove back the gray mist, enough that we could see the dim outline of the door, its knob of brass highly polished.

"Why the heck didn't we get these out before?" I asked, my voice sounded quavery, and I gave a delighted little laugh.

"Fear has a way of driving sense from a man's mind," the elf said, and he too gave a nervous laugh of relief. We both felt more sure, so that he placed his hand back on the knob and turned it. A creaking sounded as if this door had not been opened in a long, long time. I thought the hinges would bust off, so loud was the complaint.

Inside it was black as pitch. I poked my sword in, and I could just make out a narrow tunnel. The walls seemed to be comprised of hard stone. Glimmer took a step in, his own sword leading out front.

I ran my hand over the smoothness of the wall. It was so sleek to my touch. It was as if water had flowed through this tunnel for many eons, polishing them. The tunnel went on and on, and we both noticed we seemed to be going in a spiral. I hoped it was spiraling toward the center where we needed to go. At last, we came to the end, and there stood an identical door to the one we had entered.

"What do you think, Glim?" I asked him, furrowing my brows, gulping back my mounting fear. "Do you think it is the middle of this swamp? Who would have placed these doors here? Do you think it could have been an ancient sorcerer?" Sweat rolled down my forehead and stung my sore eyes.

"If it was, Tyrl, let's pray he worked for the 'Good'," the prince said, placing his hand on the knob and giving it a twist. A blast of hot, putrid air caused him to pull back his hand, slamming the door shut again. "Arrgh!" he said, coughing out another wad of black crud.

"We're definitely going to need something stronger than pine sap to squelch that horrid smell," I said, shaking my head and trying to wave off the foulness that seemed to want to choke the life from us.

"Ah! I know exactly the thing that will do the trick, Tyrl," the elf said, his face lighting up like a bright blue candle from his hefted sword. Once again he reached into my magic pack, and extracted two clear vials with a pink substance half filling each. "Oil of the 'Sabbalac' flower. I wish I had thought of this before we approached this wretched place! he said," shaking his head in self scorn and handing me one. "Take off your mask, and place a single drop, for it is powerful, on yours. Surely this will block out even that foul odor."

He opened the door a second time, and to his credit, the foul blast of air that rushed out, seemed to be diluted by at least half with the aid of the sweet smelling flower nectar.

We stepped through together, for the door was tall and wide. What we saw, what we smelled, what we heard, made no sense. No sense at all! This could not be the middle of the swamp. Could it...?

There were no reeds. There was no stench. No clackity-clack, clack, either, so far. But what there was!.

"We are on a Quest, and sent by my Father, 'King Fabellious" and our friend Jarode.

"Ho! The old man gave a hearty laugh. A wizard of some renown. Then, my new friends, I would very much like to meet this wizard. Indeed, I would!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Narthargan stood, towering over both Glimmer and I by nearly a foot. His gray robes swirled about his long legs as he turned and faced the cavern lake. He extended his staff with the runes etched upon it, thrusting it toward the water...

"Fasama El Jarode!" the wizard's voice blasted through the cave, bouncing back at us with deafening reverberations. Glim and I covered our ears, wincing as our ear drums throbbed.

A cloud of pure white light exploded with another barbaric burst of sound, this more cacophonous than the first. Both Glim and I fell to the ground, moaning in pain. I saw a thin trickle of blood run down the side of the elf's face, even as I felt the wetness on my own face.

After images flashed before my eyes, and I scrunched them closed against the pain. When I opened them, spots of white danced before them, then slowly my vision began to clear. At first, I thought I'd gone mad, mad with this wizard's display of magical power, but I blinked, and blinked again. He still stood there by the lake, facing Narthargan, his white robes stark and brilliant compared to Narthargan's dingy gray. "Jarode! I called out. "But..., but, how?"

"Stay back, Tyrl, Jarode said. I saw his lips move, then panicked as I heard nothing. "What?!" I screamed.

Jarode must have magically enhanced his voice, for this time I heard him clear as a bell.

"Stay back, I said, Tyrl, for this does not concern you nor Prince Glimmervan. This is between my brother and I." he told us, placing one long leg behind and one in front, he took up a defensive pose, raising his own carved staff up.

"Bro..., brother? Did he say brother, Glim?" My voice was not enhanced, and Glim shrugged his shoulders, mouthing, Come!"

After a time, I began to hear the waterfall gurgling over from high above. At least we had not been permanently deafened. "Did he say brother?

"That he did," the elf said. "I suggest we retreat to the near to the door, lest we need to make a fast escape." We did, and stood watching the two wizards locked in a combative stare. Both of their staffs now crackled with energy; Jarodes sparkled like diamonds in a heavy mist, whereas Narthargan's seemed almost foul, like the putrid mist we saw rising from 'Glackamoor Swamp'. He is no good wizard. Is he, Tyrl? You were nearly tricked!

"Do you smell that?" the prince asked me. We gazed about for where the faint odor could be coming from. "There!" he called out, pointing beyond the two wizards, who were now shooting off flames of white and gray light at one another. Glim continued to point, and I followed his directing finger. The lake! Up out of the middle rose swamp-like clouds as if the swamp were invading the pristine waters of this beautiful lake.

"It would seem we were deceived, Tyrl," the elf said, hanging his golden crowned head in shame. "And, see, he pointed at the water again, even the teal beauty is vanishing, and it is nothing more than that blasphemous swamp! His eyes narrowed with anger, his fists knotting. My heart thudded, and I, too, grew angry.

"We must help Jarode," he said. "There, see those mid-size rocks? Grab one." We both ran over to snatch one from the side of the cavern, then I followed the prince as we dashed in close to the dueling wizards.

So focused on each other, and still blasting each other with even brighter bolts of light, they did not see us approaching. "On the count of three, Tyrl, aim for his chest, and if we hit his head, so much the better. One..., two..., thr...,ee! We both heaved our heavy stones, and Thwump! Thwump! Mine hit him smack in the chest, and I heard bones cracking like dried twigs. The prince's rock hit the left side of his face, taking off half the wizard's nose and scraping down his cheek to the bone. One of his eyes lay half out of it's socket, crimson blood oozing from all his many wounds.

"AAAArg!" Narthargan bellowed, thrusting his staff in our direction, even while he attempted to stuff his damaged eye back in place. Glim and I dove apart, me to the right, and him to the left. His bolt of light split between us and crashed into the wall near the door. A great chunk of rock flew from it, and a spiderweb of cracks began to form.

That was the break Jarode had needed, for he took careful aim, and with one last humongous blast, he blew his brother off his feet. I blinked from the brilliance. And when my eyes had adjusted, nothing remained of him but a smoldering pile of dusty gray cloth and a short length of his rope belt.

We heard the old man sigh and saw him lurch forward. Glimmer darted to his side and caught him before he slammed into the large boulder by the lake. He breathed heavily, leaning upon the elf for support.

After a few moments, wherein we had all remained silent, contemplating this last series of events, Jarode spoke...

"That was foolish! Foolish indeed to come between two wizards, you young fools." His voice, at first stern, had gradually softened near the last bit. "But, I am glad you are my young fools..,er..., friends." he said at the last. His old whit-tooth smile touch his eyes, setting them to twinkling, and Glim and I returned it.

Another long gap of silence ensued as we each rested, lost in our own thoughts. Then the young prince sat up, and asked, "Good Jarode, was that foul man really your brother as you called him?"

"I am afraid so, Glim," though I am not proud, or I should say, I was not proud to be his brother. No. From the time we were wee lads, he had a mean and dark streak in him as though the "Bad' had always been within him. He left our small village, where we had both trained as apprentices under a renowned wizard, named Agore. No one ever heard from him after that. Though I long suspected he had gone off to practice the dark side of our craft.

"What shall we do now?" I asked Jarode. If that lake is really part of 'Glackamoor Swamp', then perhaps we may toss the talisman in from here to banish the 'Bad'?"

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
"That may be may wise, young friend, " Jarode said to me. He still rested upon the flat-topped rock near the teal lake, 'The Hidden Lake' as the now dead Narthargan had called it. "I would urge caution, however, for I surmise this is the very place my brother practiced his darkness, and if that be so, he may have warded all within this cavern, even the lake, itself." Jarode said, his face pulled down in a slight frown of thought. He raised his bushy white eyebrows at Glim and I, waggling them and nodding his head.

"You are wise, good Jarode," the elf told the old man. "How may we aide you in searching for these magical wards, Jarode?"

"I'm afraid magic is best left to magic, good prince, however,' he grinned, I am famished after that fierce battle."

We all laughed at that, and Glim and I set about preparing the old man a feast deserving of a conqueror. While we did Jarode strode about the large cavern, around all sides of the teal lake, and he even contemplated the waterfall and ceiling for a good bit of time, I noticed.

"Look here," Glim said, pulling out a whole cooked turkey, brown and crisp and set upon a gorgeous platter he'd pulled from the magic pack Jarode had given me so long ago.

Not to be outdone, I rummaged in the pack for some time, then, smiled big as a Cheshire cat as I plucked a white and red checkered table cloth from it, complete with matching red napkins, real silverware that gleamed in the late afternoon light streaming in the sky hole above.

"Wait!" I cried out as Glim tried to reach around me into the pack. "I need these, too," I said bringing forth three crystal goblets of which I struck one with my thumb and fore finger, producing a lovely "Ping!"

"He tried to get in, yet again, and I snatched the pack closer to me and said, "If you please, my friend, I am not quite finished!" He gave a little huff, but sat back waiting for me to finish my display.

Lastly, I searched for my last contribution to our grand feast; "Aha! I have it! Out came a huge bottle of a very fine red wine. "All yours, Glim, I said, pushing the pack back to him." He ruffled my hair and smirked at me, then began digging deeper in the pack.

"Potatoes shall go nicely, mashed, of course, the elf told me, setting a big bowl on the center of the cloth next to his scrumptious turkey."Quite right," I agreed, smacking my lips. My stomach was beginning to rumble in protest of having to wait so long.

"What else? Oh, well, we certainly must have sweetened cranberries, and yams, and corn, and fresh baked hard rolls, butter, and what for desert?" he finished, puffing with that long winded spiel!

"I rather fancy some strawberry-rhubarb crisp, don't you?"

"Most excellent choice, Tyrl."

We sat patiently for a time, waiting for Jarode to finish his inspection of the cave when, at last, he strolled over. He eased his old bones down onto the soft mat of grass, spreading his long legs off to the side of the table cloth. "Well! It would seem my two young friends have not been idle. It smells wonderful, and I am hungry!"

Glim passed him a plate and a set of the expensive silverware. Jarode filled his plate to overflowing, like he was a starving lumberjack, who'd not eaten, ever! Glimmer and I roared in delight, heaping our own plates the same. We all stuffed ourselves to over-full as well, then lay back upon the light green grass and slept for a short time.

When I opened my bleary eyes, night had fallen and moonlight crept across the sky hole and the lake, sending shimmers of grey and white rippling across the water. I saw the two swans, still gliding on that placid water, and I thought it a very good sign, indeed!

"Jarode made a small fire from twigs and branches he'd pulled from the pack, and we soon had a nice little fire to vanquish the shadows that were rapidly filling our cavern. He set about making a delicious smelling coffee, and on this we sipped to clear the cobwebs that sometimes formed from afternoon naps.

"Wonderful coffee, Jarode," Glim said, setting his mug on a flat stone he had found for a makeshift table. "Where did the beans come from, for I've never tasted anything like them?" he asked Jarode.

"Oh, very far to the south, on yet another island I visited last spring," the old man answered. "Gabol, if I recall the name. It means 'The Island of Love', and the people there are quite friendly, if you catch my drift." I'd never heard the old man speak as such, and I blushed a deep shade of red, while he and Glimmer shared a laugh at my expense.

The elf, as he was wont to do, absently plucked a blade of thick grass, folding it in two and bringing it to his full lips. He played us a soft, sad melody, then a livelier tune, as the old man said we should be on alert and not napping more.

"Now," the old man said, pushing himself up straighter and leaning back against the big rock by the lake, "about this business with the talisman, and whether or not, to throw it into the lake. I believe that is the course we shall take, Tyrl, Glim," he said, looking over at us as we put away the remnants of our feast. It never ceased to amaze what all we could pull from and stuff back into the small pack! But that is, after all, magic, eh, Tyrl?

"Yes. Where was i? Oh, I have been thinking, and if we were to make our way to the top of the falls," he paused here, pointing and drawing our eyes to the now silvery water splashing down into the lake, from there we should be able to throw it the farthest. I think, too, it is critical that it land near mid-center, for surely that is where Nathargan would have set his evil to work, his awakening of the 'Bad', if you will."

"I think I know just the way to reach the top of the waterfall," Glimmer said. Of course he would. After all, his home is in the tree within the Secret Forest.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: The Teal Lake

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
We'd all had more than enough, after more lengthy discussion on reaching the waterfall's summit and much back and forth contemplating on just how the talisman would vanquish the 'Bad", hopefully for good, though even if it set it back a pace, we had all felt that would be a great success. "Let's get some shut eye, young friends, Jarode said.

Glim and I pulled sleeping mats, blankets, and even three goose down pillows from the pack, that we might rest comfortably and be refreshed come morning for our great task.

I lay upon my comfy bed, sleep eluding me for a time as I am sure it did the other two. I must have fallen into a deep sleep, for I dreamed the evil wizard, Nathargan, lived, once more, and he chased me through my slumber, shooting my backside with his foul bolts of gray light.

"Wake up, Tyrl," I heard Glimmer saying. I opened my sore eyes to one of his famous, bright white smiles.

"Ah! Thank you, Glim, my friend" I was being slowly roasted by Nathargan in my dream.

"Oh, he's quite dead, young Tyrl," the old man assured me, smiling too. Apparently, the old man and the elf prince had been up for some time, while I'd snored on. The old man handed me another of his cups of fine-brewed coffee. I wrapped my hands around it, relishing the warmth of the mug, for the cavern had grown cool over night.

"So, if everyone is wide-eyed-and-bushy-tailed?" Glimmer asked. I think it time to surmount that waterfall's top. He pulled the pack, my pack, closer to himself, and with a bit of effort, he tugged a small contraption from it. It was made of hard wood, maybe oak, with bits of gleaming brass holding its parts together.

"What the heck is it?" I asked him.

As he pulled a long length of rope from the pack, with a small grappling hook attached to one end, he answered me, "That, tyrl, is a miniature catapult, and it will fling this hook very far. Hopefully, all the way to the top of the waterfall. You see those large boulders to the left up there? That is where we want our hook to land. Behind them, so that when we ascend this knotted rope (I looked to see that it was indeed knotted), it will pull snug and bear our weight, and if not, well, we would tumble back down into the water, and there are no large stones, I noticed, to break our bones." He thought this uproariously funny, though I gulped back a bit of fear, seeing how high up we'd be if it did let loose.

"Perhaps we'd best forego breakfast, Glimmer said," looking straight at me. "I think Tyrl is afraid of heights." He rubbed my hair as he so liked to do and smiled again.

"Yes, well, I wasn't born in a tree!" I said, and he and Jarode, and then I, too, laughed, trying to scare off my jitters.

Glimmer strode out into the teal water, stopping when he reached the middle of the waterfall. He stood about twenty feet from the falls, so that he could see the rocks above. Setting the hook in his catapult, he then cranked it up tight, took aim, and fired it.

We soon realized that getting the hook up there would take a few tries, but Glimmer, as I knew from watching him shoot his arrows straight and true, many a time, managed to embed it behind the large boulders on his third attempt, just as he'd said he could. He gave the rope a couple of hard pulls, then climbed up about a third of the way, and with great ease I noted.

Once back down, he strode through the calm water of the lake, and flopped down on its grassy bank. "We'll be up top in no time," he said smiling at me and Jarode in turn.

"Yes," the old man nodded, and I wondered how he'd have the strength to propel himself up, what with him being quite ancient. But, he soon put my worryings to rest, when he lightly touched his own shoulder with the tip of his staff, then did likewise to mine.

I hadn't felt anything, but then, a tingling went through my muscles, and I felt very much alive. I grinned like a school boy out of class without a pass. "What is this?! It feels magnificent! I feel as though I could climb twenty of those ropes, keep right on a climbing up to the heavens!"

I was beyond elated, until Jarode placed a hand on my shoulder. Immediately I began to calm, my breathing slowed, and I let out a long sigh. I still quivered a bit, but it seemed to be ebbing.

'My fault, Jarode," said, giving a big guffaw, which Glimmer joined in with, but not I. "I'm afraid I gave you a little too much get-up-and-go, there, young friend. A small smiled tugged at my lips as I never could stay mad at either of them.

"I see," I said, acting as though still slightly miffed for being the butt of their little joke.

"I shall go first," Jarode said, and with that he waded out to the dangling rope and went up hand over hand with ease, his long white robe billowing around him in the gentle breeze drifting down from the sky hole. The higher he went, the more it billowed about, and one time it rose up to cover his face. His pale legs looking like two sun-starved saplings. I thought he might fall, but the robe resettled, and then he was up top. He stood looking down at us and gave us a wave.

"You're next, Tyrl. It will be easy, I promise. Just don't look down," the prince said, grabbing the rope and handing it to me. I grasped it in my sweaty hands, then looked up. "Okay,"I said, reaching one hand up to the knot above, I began to climb. Up. Up. And up some more, and then, I looked down. The cavern began to spin, and I gritted my teeth, squeezing my eyes shut. Breathe, Tryl. Breathe. After a moment of hanging there in mid-air, I looked back up. Placing one hand up, I began to ascend again, chanting, just one more, just one more, until Jarode was, thankfully, hauling me over the edge.

choices: A Party of Five Becomes Six
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Glimmer was the last to begin the long climb to the top of the waterfall. Both Jarode and I stood near the edge watching him come up. When my head began to spin and my legs to wobble, the old man gently pushed me back, and I plopped down on the soft grass that adorned the summit of the waterfall.

In no time at all, the swift and sure-handed elf hauled himself up and over the edge. We gazed about at the wondrous site. Here, on the top, grew a wild assortment of plants and flowers; giant ferns, bushes, trees, and so much more grew here. The bees buzzed and sipped nectar from, at least, a thousand blossoms spread about in a dizzying rainbow of color.

"Wowzers!" I said.

"What a beautiful spot! "Wouldn't it be grand to build a house here amongst all this..., this bounty of nature," Glimmer said.

"First things first, my young, impatient friends," the old man said. "Tyrl, have you the talisman I gave you?"

I opened the pack, scrabbling about until I felt its smooth wooden edges in my grasp. I pulled it out and examined it. It had runes all over it, in a language I couldn't hope to decipher. I handed it to Jarode.

"This," he told us, holding it up so that the gems embedded in the front of it shone in the early morning sunlight, "is very old, even older than I," he said, laughing at that. "And that would be older than dirt."

"Now, I shall place strength upon our elf friend, for his aim is to be envied," Jarode said as he handed the magical object to Glimmer. He touched both of Glim's thin but broad shoulders, tapping each lightly. Glimmer shuttered, then wiggled in amazement.

"You're right, Tyrl, it is delightful!" He did manage to contain it better than I had though, I noticed.

"Now, young prince, aim for the middle!"

Glimmer cocked his long arm back, squinted one eye, then plunged his arm forward. The talisman arched up high, tumbling as it went, then it began its descent. Down. Down. Down into the very center of the lake. It splashed in, making ripples that grew out in ever widening circles.

I saw the two white swans, then, and they had swam for the shore and were now flapping their wings up and out of the water. They waddled off a dozen yards or so, then turned as if anticipating something. But nothing happened. The water lay placid, not the tiniest movement on it.

We all stood staring at it from atop the falls. Then...,

The calmness shattered, and the teal waters of the lake shot up and out of the sky hole! More and more of the water was funneled up, and more. Half an hour later, we gaped at an empty hole where the lake had once been.

"What happened?!" I asked, shaking my head in utter disbelief.

Jarode looked at Glimmer and I, and he said, the 'Good', young friends! The 'Good' is what happened! And if I am right then we must descend, and we must go back out the way you two came when you entered the cavern.

"But..., but that way is dangerous," I protested.

"I think I begin to understand why," the elf prince said, turning to gaze at the old man.

"Ssh!," Jarode said to him. Let us keep it for a fine surprise for Tyrl." Both of them nodded in agreement then, and Glimmer deftly hopped over the edge, scuttling down the rope, like an experienced pirate from a crow's nest.

I needed a little encouragement to toss my leg over into open space, quite a lot, actually. My knuckles were white with fear, but I closed my eyes and made my way down, and Jarode soon followed.

Once we'd all assembled on the grass, we flopped down for a bit of rest. That was when Glimmer's jaw fell open, for across the way, stood a naked man and woman, well, naked except for the few white feathers they held in personal places. A large pile of feathers lay scattered about them and both of the swans were no where to be seen!

The old man looked as if he would faint, and he reached out and grasped my shoulder, digging in his nails. "It cannot be!" he cried out. He took a step forward, then another, then stood staring at the comely couple.

Both sported masses of shoulder-length golden ringlets. Their identical eyes a soft, robin's egg blue. They were young as well, not much into their teen years.

"Ah...," Jarode cleared his throat, then pointing at the girl he began again, "Alivina," he said, giving her a low bow, and you would be her twin brother, Alastin. Am I correct?" he asked them, giving the boy a sweeping bow and an extra flourish with his white robe.

His voice still shook slightly as he turned to me and Glim and said, "These two have been missing for many a year. They are the son and daughter of the King of the North, Valaspar. But..., how?!" He scratched his head, then tugged on his long white beard.

The boy, the prince, I would assume, spoke first, saying, "And who would you good rescuers be?" He gave each of us a nod, his royal curls bouncing.

"I am the Wizard, Jarode. This is Prince Glimmervan of the 'Secret Forest' and our young friend, Tyrl. I have known your good father for many a year. He has been beside himself with grief all these long years. "Oh! The joy that shall fall upon his face when you lovely children grace his castle once again!"

With that proclamation, the old man strode to the pair, and he swept them both up in a fierce embrace, knocking their modesty feathers to the ground. I averted my youthful eyes.

"Anyone for another feast?" Glim asked, his smile beaming and gleaming.

"You know me, Glim. I can eat any time," I said.

After we'd found some suitable clothing for the brother and sister in the pack, of course, Glim and I set about pulling food out and this and that.

choices: Glimmer and I Take a Side Trip
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
The brother and sister, gaped at the feast Glimmer and I had laid out, once again arranging it on Tyrl's checkered table cloth. I thought their wide eyes would burst from their sockets.

"Well, I imagine one grows tired of eating worms and bugs and plants, no?" Jarode joked with them, laughing a deep belly laugh.

When the two of them smiled their eyes lit up, much as Jarode's did, twinkling is what I liked to call it. And, with every bit they brought to their identical cherry-red lips, they, "ooohed, and ahhed."

"Oh, Alastin! Do you remember when we were very small and mother wood fetch us up warm cheery tarts from the kitchen? I do! And they tasted very much like these," the young princess squealed, stuffing another large bite into her half-full mouth.

"I don't remember that," Alastin told his sister, but I do remember how much I loved roast beef!" He, too, was cramming it in so fast, we all thought the pair of them would choke.

"Our friends await us outside," Glimmer told them, after everyone had had their fill of food. "We have left them for too long, and I fear for their safety as one of them is inured or was. If anything came upon them, I am afraid, she'd not been able to run.

I felt a wave of guilt over this, over leaving Bralina and Stavin to themselves and without the aide of the pack, too. But repelling the 'Bad' had been foremost in our minds as we'd separated that day.

"I'm sorry to say that the outside is not quite as lovely as this beautiful cavern that has served as your home all these years," I told Alivina and Alastin. I saw Glim sneak a look and share a smile with Jarode, and my mind began to wonder. hmm..., no, that could not be!

It seemed we were always gathering up feasts, but none-the-less, we packed up this one, and when everyone was ready, we walked to the tall and wide door that had brought us here. We wound our way out, round and round, just as we had the first time, only going in a different direction.

When we came to the last bend, I called out, "Here it is!" I remembered the straight section that had led us in, and now it took us out. I gulped, hoping, that everything would be okay. I prayed no harm had come to Bralina and Stavin."

"Wait up, Tyrl," Glim called out as he came forward."

"Yes," Jarode chimed in. I think I should be the first out, and having said that, he thrust his staff out in front of him and led us on.

The bright sunlight stung out eyes, so accustomed to the cavern's dimmer light had our eyes become. But that is not what had me gaping!

"Glim! Glim, do you see this?! "What has become of the foul swamp?"

"I think you know," Tyrl, he said, smiling one of his biggest smiles yet.

"Yes," Jarode said, going out and looking in a wide circle. "The wind must have carried all the waterfall to land all across this swamp. It has carried the 'Good' and cleansed this foul place at last!" Tears shone in the old wizard's tired eyes.

"I am so glad, and I thank you for your wisdom, and my father's in sending us on this quest and in your aiding us, good Jarode," the prince said to him. "However, I think we had best be going, for it is a good two miles from here where Tyrl and I left Stavin and Bralina."

"Yes, by all means, let us make haste to them, Gliimer. Lead on," the old man said.

An hour later, for we were as weary as when we'd been going in as we were in coming out of the once swamp land, we came upon the giant elm we had left the pair of friends under. I spied Bralina's travoix we had carried her on, but they were not to be see. It looked as though the waterfall had reached even here, for the ground was saturated with water.

"Look," Glimmer called out. "See, here, and here?" Two sets of prints led away to the left, one big, one much smaller. "They've gone somewhere. But it will be easy to track them, at least where it is damp," the elf said.

We'd gone down the left hand side of a game trail and exited into a small meadow, when we first heard their voices, well, voices and the splashing of water. Giggles and playful screams led us through a patch of blueberries, which I stopped to grab up a few, stuffing the delicious fruit in my mouth as I continued to walk, and just beyond, there they were! They had shucked down to their small clothes and were floating and splashing themselves in a wonderful, but small, teal-colored pond!

I gave a low whistle, and their heads whipped our way. "Hey, ya great big oaf," Bralina called out to me. "Took you guys long enough! We could have been long dead and buried all the while you two took. And! Jarode! How did you get here!"

Her and Stavin swam the short distance to the ponds edge and clamored out, shaking their hair so that it sprayed all of us. Bralina laughed," her face flushed and healthy with the glow of new tanned skin.

"Hey! Watch it!" I told her, brushing water from my face. "Hello to you, too!"

"Ah..., who are these two lovelies?" Bralina asked, eyeing the siblings.

"That would be a very long story, and one told best after a refreshing swim," Glimmer said, stripping down. I did likewise, and we both swam about in the beautiful teal pond, while Jarode and the twins walked in ankle-deep water, to cool themselves.

Afterwards, being both weary and hungry, we all decided to make camp and strike out in the morning for Glimmer's home in the forest. King Fabellious would no doubt be anxious to hear of our success or failure in this quest.

"Anyone up for a feast?" Bralina said, skipping on ahead of us and laughing. Both Glim and I smiled and shook our heads. "That's our Bralina," I said.

"That she is," replied the prince.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Where is the Swamp!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
The morning dawned sweet, with no foul smells, no putrid swamp to dampen our spirits! I had dreamed the foulness of the 'Bad' had crept back in, saturating the surrounding land with its stench of evil, but as I opened my bleary eyes, I saw it had only been a nightmare, after all.

"Good morning, sunshine," Bralina said, handing me a cup of Jarode's steaming, delicious brew.

"And to you, Bralina," I said. "How is your ankle today?"

"That? I haven't thought about it in two days, so I guess it is very good," she smiled and continued to fry sausages on a flat stone someone had found and laid across the white hot fire.

"What ya cooking, Glim?" I asked the elf.

"My own special scrambled eggs," he said, giving a large pan next to Baralina's makeshift one.

"Sure smells good around here," Stavin chimed in, sitting up from his bedroll near the fire and giving a big stretch and yawn.

"Very good," the wizard said. "Now that you two sleepyheads have finally awoken, we have urgent business to discuss."

Everyone, including the newest additions to our party, the Swan Twins as we were calling them, grabbed plates and helped themselves to the finished food. We talked as we ate, everyone in a rare good mood, what with the new blossoming of this land. We all counted our blessings that this quest had gone in our favor, in favor of the 'Good'.

"First of all," Jarode said, holding his hand up as he'd taken another huge spoonful of Glim's spiced eggs, "Ah..., yes..., he swallowed and went on. I believe we really should consider splitting this group into two groups. Glim, Tyrl, I would ask that you two escort the twins back to their father, the King of the North, KIng Valaspar. Wait, hear me out. The rest of us should continue on as planned, returning to the 'Secret Forest' to bring King Fabellious up to date on this quest's success Now, has anyone any objections to that, and, if so, please tell me now."

"I think that a splendid plan, good Jarode," the elf prince said. He chomped down a sausage in two bites. Who could blame the slender elf for being famished what with all the energy we'd all exerted over the last week. I, myself, felt as if I could eat an entire mountain of sausages!

Of course, Bralina would be the first to raise an objection saying, "Why can't I go with Glim and Tyrl?" she asked, one of her famous pouts pulling down her cherub-like mouth.

"The less in that party, the faster they will be able to travel," the old wizard said. "With so many different groups of King's Guards seeking our demise, I think that the wisest course of action to take."

"I suppose so, but I'm not very happy about it," Bralina said, one corner of her mouth pulled up, giving him a half-hearted smile, but it never reached her lovely blue eyes.

"Good, then, it is settled?" the old man asked, looking around at each of us. The twins nodded, silent as ever, but maybe they had much to contemplate, after being away from their home all these years. I wonder what it felt like to be turned into a swan?

After breakfast, everyone pitched in cleaning up and packing it all back in my magic pack, then we all enjoyed one last cup of Jarode's delicious coffee, except the twins, who had yet to grow to like it, they enjoyed fresh-squeezed orange-pineapple juice.

"Well," the old wizard said, standing up and stretching his long arms over his head, "It is time we were off."

For a time, the two parties traveled together, but we soon came upon a crossroads, and there is where we said our goodbyes.

"Stick to the forest paths, Glimmer, Tyrl, where you will be less likely to stumble upon or be set upon by any of the King's Gurads."

"That we shall, good Jarode," Glimmer said, taking the wizard in a strong embrace. I did likewise, and then we hugged the others as well. They took the fork to the east, with us going straight north.

"Goodbye! Be safe!" we faintly heard Bralina call out, after we'd gone down the road a ways.

Glimmer, the twins, and I all turned and waved, then they were out of sight.

"How far is it to our father's castle? Alastin asked. His voice still had that half-boy, half-man quality to it and broke in odd places.

"I have never been all the way to the castle but close to it," said Glim. From the 'Secret Forest' it would take two days, but I believe we are closer than that from here. I would guess about one and a half days, if we make good time.

"Too think we were that close all these years," the young princess said to her brother. I saw a sngle tear slide down her round face. Alastin put an arm around her thin shoulder and swiped the tear away with his thumb.

"We're going home, now, Sis, and that is all we need think about."

"Glim," I said, "Look. Here is a game path, heading due north. I suggest we get off this main road and take to the shelter of the forest as Jarode suggested." We did just that then, and we all appreciated the coolness of the overhead canopy of maple and oak leaves. Dappled sunlight filtered through, but not enough to overheat us as we marched steadily north.

The sun lay high in the sky when we stopped by a small meandering brook. We removed out boots and socks and went wading in the cool flowing water.

The twins offered to make a light lunch, and we heard them "Oohing" and "Ahhing" every time they plucked a new food from the bag. Of course, Alavina insisted on more cherry tarts!

In no time at all, they had spread out a substantial feast, all carefully positioned on Tyrl's red and white checkered table cloth again.

"Well!" Glim said, eyeing the bounty of it all. "We'll be lucky if any of us can even move, let alone hike, after consuming all of that!" We all roared with laughter and set to eating every last scrap of it.

"Snap!" Our heads all twisted to the left.

"Sssh!" the elf said, bringing a finger to his lips. He stood, and silent as a snake, he moved off in the direction of the noise, taking his bow from his shoulder and notching an arrow. He disappeared behind a large maple...
