1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Glimmer and I Take a Side Trip

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
The twins and I huddled behind a large bayberry bush, Alastin's slender arms holding the shaking princess. She gazed up at me with her big robin's-egg blue eyes. I noticed they were moist with unshed tears. First day free of being a swan, and she probably wishes she were back gliding on the peaceful lake.

My legs grew stiff with squatting so long, and I sat down and stretched them out. Where is Glimmer? Why hasn't he returned yet? Then I heard the slightest rustle of dried leaves. I craned my neck around the side of the large bush, but I saw no one.

"If he's not back soon, I told the other two, I must go and see if all is well," I said, pitching my voice low as I could.

"Please, good Tyrl," do not leaves us!" Alavina said, rather too loudly.

No sooner had she spoke than a large sword parted the bush we hid behind.

"You! Out!" a mans rough voice said.

I stood as did the brother and sister, and we came around the side of our hiding place. I nearly burst out laughing, but sighed instead, for there stood our little friend, none-other-than, Vadermiremire, or Van as he'd said his friends called him.

"Van!" I said, forgetting we might yet be in danger. "How did you disguise your voice so? And when did you start carrying a sword?" I eyed the sharp-edged beauty, thinking he must have honed it a very long time to be so razor sharp!

"Tyrl. Sword mine. Yes. Friend," the little guy said in his usual unusual way of speaking.

"Van, what are you doing out here in the forest, so far from your house?" I remembered the night we'd spent in his cozy, warren-like home with fondness.

"Van bored. Visit, yes. Visit King. My friend." he smiled at this, and I gaped at him.

"You mean you know King Valaspar?"

"Yes. Van know. Good friend. Yes," he gave me a smile and pointed at the twins. "Who?"

"Van, let me introduce you to two very special people who, your friend the king will be heartily glad to see! I began, first, with their back story of how the evil Nathargan had used the 'Bad' to turn both of them into swans, many years ago. Then went on to tell him of how the good king and all within the castle had wept over their loss, for all feared the pair dead. But as you see, Van, our quest has brought a bonus. Not only did we cleanse the 'Glackamoor Swamp' and all the surrounding area, but we have freed the twins."

"Good!" he bobbed his over-sized head up and down, then went and shook hands with the pair.

"Van!" came another shout. Glimmer strode from around the giant maple, a huge grin widening across his handsome face. He went to the little man, picking him up and twirling him about, until he grew dizzy. Van's smiled blossomed bigger, his plump cheeks rosy.

"Now where did you come from?" he asked him, but he just smiled and pointed at me.

"He grew bored, and he just so happens to be friends with their father, the king," I said, pointing at the brother and sister. "Did you find anyone about?

"No," the price said. "Perhaps it was Van, who snapped that twig."

"So, you know the king, eh, Van? Well, then we're going in the same direction, and now we be five! Seems like that's what I said when Stavin joined our party," the elf said.

"Yeppers! Five," said Van, and we all laughed.

"Five! Five! Five! his crow screeched. I turned and looked up. I had not noticed it sitting on a branch of the maple tree. Darn! Why'd he have to bring that annoying bird?

"We had best be off again", Glim said. "We've lost a bit of time, and if we're to make the castle by tomorrow, we'd better step lively." And with that, our five members marched single file down yet another north-heading game trail. The sunlight filtered though the trees overhead, keeping us all in the shade mostly.

Late in the afternoon, we stepped out of the light forest, into a wide grassy meadow. There was but one tree here, centered in the middle of this green area, and we made for the shade of its spreading branches. The crow alighting before we reached it.

"Tree! Tree! Tree!" came its annoying call. Yeah, it's a tree! We know that, you dumb bird brain! I wonder what crow pie would taste like.

"Who's up for a feast?" Glimmer asked, smiling and sounding very much like Bralina. I miss that girl, already!

All heads nodded as they murmured their ascent. Once again a grand feast magically appeared, and we all sat about with full bellies, regretting that we still had far to go before sunset would force us to camp for the night.

Afterward, we hiked another two hours, then found a lovely spot to spend the night. It was a secluded area with forest on three sides, and a small waterfall, spilling into a pond,and just perfect for an evening bath.

The twins were rather modest and only strode through the shallows, rolling up their travelling pants to avoid getting them wet. Glimmer and I stripped down to our skinny's and strode out to the deepest part. It came up to just under my neck, and the water was cool and invigorating.

"Hey, Van!," I called out to the little fellow. "Don't you want to cool off?" I asked him. He shook his head, and then pulled out a two-piece fishing rod from his small leather pack he'd brought along. he snapped the two together and had himself a fine pole.

"Fish. Yes? Eat!" he said. He set about digging up some of the turf near the bank, and he soon had a whole slug of wiggling worms, which he place in a cup. He attached one of the squirming things to a hook on his line, then expertly cast it into the lake. "Fish!" he said again. "Yum!" We all laughed.

"Yum! Yum! Yum!" said his sidekick.

Glim and I splashed around for a good half hour, then emerged from the water, shaking ourselves dry. By this time, the little guy was cleaning a pile of sunfish he'd caught, and the twins had the checkered table cloth out and side dishes ready. My mouth watered.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: What a Castle!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
I don't know what the little fellow put on that sunfish for spices, but I'd never tasted any fish so good in my life, and I don't normally eat much fish either.

"Van," glimmer said, reaching over and stabbing another piece of fish from the flat rock the little guy had cooked it on, "Umm, um! That fish is so good! You must share your secret with the castle cook, so that when the king is reunited with his beloved children, we can have it at the celebration feast."

"Fish, good. Yes." He told Glimmer and took another helping himself.

Sunset had come, before we finished the huge meal, and with all the walking we'd done in the last days, all of us were more than ready to roll out our beds for some much needed rest.

The stars were twinkling in mass as I lay staring at the night sky. What a journey it's been, eh, Tyrl. And you thought you'd never have any adventure! That was my last thought before my eyelids closed of their own accord, and I drifted off.

I awoke to the aroma of brewing coffee and a soft mellow tune I didn't recognize. I opened one eye to see Glim sitting on a fallen log near the morning fire. He'd plucked up another blade of wide grass from the meadow we'd slept in last night, and on this he played his song. Man, I wish that elf would teach me to do that!

"Morning," he said noticing my eyes had both opened. "It's about time you got up, lazy head. We saved you some breakfast and a spot of coffee. You'd best get to it, before noon's shining on our backs." He laughed, and then went on playing his leaf.

"Arg!" I groaned and rolled from my bed, making my way to the log and settling in next to the elf. He poured me a cup, and I accepted it with a nod, it being too early for me and manners.

"I'd say we might make the castle by supper time, maybe a bit later."

"That would be great as I've had about enough of this marching day and night. Where are the twins?" He pointed to the pond, and I saw Alastin sitting on a rock, his back to the pond. "And where's is his sister," I said putting my hand up to shade the sunrise coming up over the water.

"She's around that little curve, and the prince is guarding her, so none will disturb her bath."

"Ah, I said." I finished my coffee and helped pack the cups and the pot back into the pot and rolled up my bed and blanket. By that time, the twins had come back, Alavina's wet, curly locks shining like gold in the sun. They bounced to and fro as she set about gathering her things.

"I bet you two are anxious and a little nervous for the grand reunion you'll have, maybe this very day," I said to the pair.

Alastin looked over at me and Glim, a shy smile growing on his face, "Yes, I am a bit nervous about meeting my father. I hope he will approve of me." He blushed and looked down at the ground, scuffing his boot in a patch of dirt beneath the tree.

"You needn't worry about that, Prince Alastin, for any father would be proud to call you son, from what I have seen these past few days." Glimmer told him, one prince to another.

"Thank you," Alavin said, and he also gathered his things.

The rest of the trek took us down a narrow road, but we met no other travelers after many hours march. Here the hardwoods gave way to giant redwoods, and we soon felt like dwarfs in comparison.

"Halt, in the name of the King!" We all came to a sudden stop, gazing all around at the swords that circled our little group.

"Who be you? And what be your purpose on the 'King's Road'?" asked a burly man in a shining breast plate and helm. A fancy red plume swayed back and forth in the evening's light breeze.

"Glimmer took the lead and spoke for us, "Good Knight of the King's Guard, I assume?" he asked the swordsman. "We have come to pay our respect to King Valaspar, and to deliver..., a message, meant only for his ears. I am Prince Glimmervan of the 'Secret Forest', and these," he said spreading his arm in an arc toward us, are my travelling companions. A brother and sister, and my friend, Tyrl."

"Hrrmph!" The man seemed unimpressed with these introductions. He spoke with one of his men, who pulled a great stallion from the woods, where they must have tied them, and down the road he galloped as if something chased him.

"Where do you think he's off to in such a hurry?" I asked Glim under my breath. The burly knight coughed and looked straight at me as if he'd heard.

"We will escort you the rest of the way to the castle," he told us, and his men gathered their horses reins, climbed in their saddles and formed up, some behind and some in front of us. Do they think us prisoners? Do they think we might try and escape? Some welcome, eh, Tyrl?

These Men must have been out-reach guards, for we were a good ten miles from the castle, and our feet grew weary with the passing hours. It was, as Glim had predicted, well past sunset when at last the castle came into view. And a grand site it was! Spires and turrets and battlements, crisscrossed here and there and walkways from one place to another, even one that spiraled down to a waterfall and lake. Had the sun been shining, I had no doubt it would have been even more stunning, for in the full moon light, I saw it was made entirely of white marble!

"Oh! Alavina!" cried out even as she slid to the ground in a crumple heap. Prince Alastin ran to her, and lifted her head into his lap. "This march has been to much for my sister! Water, someone bring her a drink!"

"Ill be alright ,"she told her brother, after taking a few small sips from a canteen someone had offered.

We let her rest a few moments, then she said, "I have delayed you all long enough. I can make it the short way left." Her brother helped her up, and we made a slower pace to the castle.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: One More Day

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
As our weary band drew near the massive front gate of the castle of King Valaspar, we saw more guards lined up on either side of the road. I felt like a prisoner being escorted down a gauntlet. They peered out at us from the slits of their helms, stern faced all. Some welcome!

Their 'Captain of the Guard' rode up to the tall wooden and iron enforced gate, speaking to someone within the gatehouse. A black-bearded, rotund man popped his head out to inspect us, wrote something on a chart, then spoke to the captain again. A few moments passed, where we were made to stand on our aching legs, and then a creaking sounded as the door, finally, opened wide.

The captain drew his stallion to the side, where it pranced in irritation of having to wait also, I assumed, and he dipped his head to us to proceed in.

The twins eyes were wide with wonder as they crossed into their long lost home. "I'm shaking like a leaf, Alavin," Alavina told her brother. He grasped her hand in his moist one, and gave his sister a smile. "Soon we will feel as if we had never left," the prince said.

We entered into a very large courtyard with a massive statue of whom I thought to be King Valaspar, but I would later learn it had been modeled after his great, great grandfather. The statue sat on a wide base, made to look like a giant boulder, and this was placed in a round pool of sparkling clear water. It was fed by a small boy statue, standing beside the late king. The boy held a urn, and, from this the water continuously flowed down into the pool. Like the entire castle it was made of white marble. There must be a marble quarry nearby to have used so much in the construction of this marvelous place.

As we all stood admiring the fountain, a long and sustained horn sounded from somewhere within the castle proper. After a moment, six guards, dressed all in white, including white enameled armor exited a small door set in a stone wall to our left.

"That would be the king's personal castle guards," Glimmer said to us. They filed out and lined up, three to a side and stood at attention, eyes locked straight ahead, but I felt them on us none-the-less. The captain who'd led us in, gave a wave of his hand, letting us know we should enter, and so we did.

We were led down a long hallway, lined with beautiful tapestries in bright colors. Most of them depicted hunting scenes, and I noted the bold crimson splashes of a giant elk, killed in a hunt. Someone, who looked a great deal like the statue in the pond, stood over the great beast, his bow hanging loosely at his side, a short sword drawn, with which he had obviously put the animal our of its misery with.

After a long walk, we came to an intersection, and the three guards in front of us turned to the right and we followed like sheep. The three others, bringing up our rear, did likewise. We found ourselves in a cavernous reception hall. The room was filled with long wooden tables and benches, scarred from many a feast that may have been rather raucous. That would be typical of gathered knights and men-in-arms who celebrated, tipping their hands until they were well into their cups.

At the very front of the room, upon a dais set up above the other tables and benches, were more seats, and in the very center, lounged a man on an elaborately carved throne He was long-bearded in black, with matching hair, though it was sprinkled with lines of gray. All six of our guards went ahead of us, making their way up, splitting in two, and left and right, they reformed to either side of King Valaspar, standing very straight, very still.

The king raised his large hand and motioned for us to come forward.

The twins seemed frightened, for they refused to move, and Glim placed his hand upon Alastin's thin shoulder and gently glided him forward. I took the princesses elbow and did the same for her, though at times, I felt as if I were tugging her along. I looked over at her, and her young face which was normally rosy-cheeked, had grown ashen, her eyes doe like.

"It will be okay," I encouraged her, still tugging her forward.

When we came within ten feet of the dais, the guard to the king's left raised his hand and said, "Halt!"

The king looked down on us, his eyes somber and his lips in a stern line. "What business have you four travelers to discuss?" he asked us. His voice had a deep and resonate ring, exactly as one might think a king would sound.

Glimmer, still with his hand on the young prince's shoulder, took a step forward. The prince did not follow, and Glim gently nudged him forward. "Your Royal Grace," he said, giving the king a sweeping, low bow. "I think you had best prepare your royal self for a shocking surprise." Glim smiled his best smile, white teeth flashing, though the kind did not return it.

The king's busy eyebrows raised, his face grew sterner, if that were possible, and the guard who had told us to halt, withdrew his sword as if we meant the king harm. The king stayed his guard, and he replaced his sword in its sheath.

"I am quite prepared for anything you might have to tell me, elf," the king said. He motioned for Glimmer to go on.

"Yes, Your Grace," the elf prince went on. You see, we four have been on a quest, Your Grace, and it is a fine tale to tell, however, how should I present this?" Glim, never at a loss for words, seemed a bit tongue tied at the moment.

Feeling my friend struggling to find the words, I stepped forward as well, dragging the now shaking and very frightened, Alavina with me. "If you will, Your High..., I mean, if you will, Your Grace, we have brought you a gift. Actually two gifts."

It was at this point that the princess's knees went out from under her, and she spilled to the floor in a dead faint. At once, the young prince, Alastin, bent to her, cupping her head in his lap. He called softly to his sister, "Alavina," tapping her cheek with the fingers of his hand. I noticed a large purple bruise already forming on her forehead. She did not respond to her brother's call.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: A Grand Reunion!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Seeing the golden haired young girl lying upon the floor of his reception hall. King Valaspar's face softened, concern raised his bushy black eyebrows. He spoke to one of his personal guards, and the man ran off, out the way we had come.

"Is she okay?" the king asked, standing and leaning out toward the pitiful scene.

"I believe she'll be alright, Your Grace," Glimmer said. "Though she has a nasty bruise, I'm afraid, Your Grace."

Lifting a hand the king spoke. "I am sorry she has been injured, and I have sent one of my men for a healer. It is best not to move her, so he will come to her." He sat back down on his throne. He stroked his long dark beard with the fingers of his right hand, then said,"While we wait, I think it best you tell me exactly what your business here is this day, for my patience grows thin."

"At once, Your Grace," Glimmer said. "These two," and at this he pointed to the twins, "ah..., these two young ones are Alastin and Alavina," he finally said. The elf prince gazed up at the king, waiting for recognition to hit the king. I hoped he too wouldn't faint dead away.

It didn't just hit the king. It blasted him back into his chair. His face flushed with heat, and his whole body seemed to quiver. He tried to speak, even as he rose. He stood glued to the spot he stood up in, and I saw his legs begin to tremble. One of his guards reached out and grabbed his shoulder, steadying him.

After a moment, the king gathered himself, and he gave a nod to the guard, letting him know he was okay to proceed. He came around one side of the long table, descending the short staircase. With slow, exaggerated steps, he came to stand by us. I saw a single tear slip from his eye and roll slowly down his cheek, and tears formed in my eyes as well.

He reached out and touched the young princess's soft, pale cheek. "Ala..," he said so faintly I could barely make out the syllables. He pulled his hand from her cheek and placed both upon his weathered face. He wept.

After a moment or two, the king looked up, and his watery eyes found those of the prince, his son. His voice full of gravel, he stood and said, "And..., and, you must be Alastin." He choked up again, and said, "My son! My long lost son!" And with that he ran to the boy, gathered him in his long arms and hugged him like he would never let the lad go again.

"Father!" was all the lad kept saying, over and over as they cried in each others arms.

About this time, Alavina's eyes fluttered opened. Just as they did, the guard who had left came running in, another short balding man in tow. He wore a plain brown robe, belted with twine. and a large golden cross hung from a chain around his pudgy neck. He bent down and spoke softly to the girl, "At least I see you have rejoined us," he gave her a small smile of encouragement. His voice was low and fatherly, and kindness seemed to be all about him.

"Where am..., where am I?" she asked him, her eyes had a far away look to them, and perhaps she thought herself yet again a swan, swimming with her brother on the beautiful, teal, 'Hidden Lake' in the cavern.

Alastin broke away from his father, coming again to his sister's side. "Alavina," he said, staring down into her confused eyes. "There's someone you should meet. Remember?" Recognition of where she was and of what they had com to do, filled the young girl's eyes. She struggled to sit up, and the healer assisted her, keeping a steadying arm about her slender back.

The king moved to her, bent down, and cupped her round cherub-like face in his palms. "Oh! I have often prayed for, dreamed of this day, never imagining it would come, would be granted to this old man. But, here you are, my lovely little daughter! My heart is full, full and overflowing with joy!" They both wept for a time, and then he scooped her up in his strong arms, and carried her from the room, never looking back at us.

The king's personal guards escorted Glim and I and Van, of course, who had remained quiet as a church mouse during all of this, to quarters where we could freshen ourselves. He said they would call for us soon, but he took Prince Alastin along with him, and we were left to ourselves in a grand room.

A massive bed had been placed in the center of one wall of the room, which gave a view to a large terrace and the surrounding countryside. Ornate carved doors led out to this, and a servant had come and opened them wide to allow a fragrant breeze to fill our room. Thick red velvet drapes hung at the four corners of the stately bed, and the dark wood of it had been polished so that it shone in the rays of moonlight streaming in from the west-facing terrace.

The servant brought us spiced, chilled wine, and a light snack of fruit and cheeses. We ate sparingly, knowing the palace staff was surely preparing a welcome home feast for the long lost children. Our servant smiled and smiled as though his face were frozen in happiness.

The three of us, having had so much excitement, and after having marched such a long ways, retreated to the bed. It was more than able to hold the three of us lying abreast, and we were soon all sleeping soundly.

We awoke to the same servant calling to us softly, "Good Sirs, if you will. It is time to attend the feast. I have laid out a selection of fitting apparel in varying sizes. I do hope you will find something you like." With that, he bowed from the room.

We each splashed our faces from a pitcher of water poured into a basin in the corner of our room. It helped to chase our sluggishness away. Then we looked through the huge assortment of clothes, each choosing his own. At last we were presentable, or so we hoped. I have no idea what one would wear to this kind of reunion feast.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: The King's Tears of Joy!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
A knock came upon our chamber door, and little Vandermiremier, or Van, as he liked us to call him, scooted over to answer it, his stubby legs flying faster than a windmill spinning.

"Hello. Yes? Feast?"

A young lord in fashionable velvet clothes with ruffled soft linen rows upon his chest and cuffs, raised his eyebrows at our little friend's queer speech, but made no note of it, having courtly manners, no doubt. He'd given us a slight bow when Van had opened the door.

"Good evening," he said, politely smiling. He was a young man, though he'd gone prematurely gray at the temples. "I trust you have had ample time to refresh yourselves, and, too, that you are quite famished from your long journey?" He stepped back from the door, gave a half bow, and a with a flourish of his arm, he ushered us all out into the wide hallway.

As we all had adorned our feet with indoor footwear, soft slippers in three glaring shades of red (mine, embarrassingly, had little bells that tinkled at my slightest movement), which is what our servant had called proper dress for a feast, our footfalls fell silent upon the stone floor.

We were led down a series of steps that seemed to spiral around as we went down, so that we knew not where we had begun nor ended up, but we soon came upon a wide, grand staircase, which led down to a massive foyer. From there it was but a short jaunt through an arch to a beautifully carved set of very tall oak doors. Leaves, vines, and bunches of grapes had been expertly carved in high relief on each of them, and we stood admiring whomever's handiwork.

"This way, if you please, good sirs," the young lord told us, and he opened both doors, flinging them wide.

"Wowzers!" I said, staring at the lavish production within a grand ballroom. How had they had time to prepare all this!

I looked over at my two companions, and their faces were as stunned as I was sure my own looked. Glim gave a low whistle, then put on one of his twinkling smiles, that made his elf's eyes dance. "After you," he said with a flourish of his arm, and Van and I entered the room with Glim bringing up the rear.

At once the merrymaking grew quiet as a funeral. I blushed as all eyes fell upon us.

A herald sounded his horn, and all the guests rose at once, giving us a bow or a little curtsy. I blushed deeper, not being used to being bowed to, I mean.

The men all wore similar clothing to that of the lord who had fetched us from our chambers. But the ladies of the court! Oh! There were so many to look upon!, And a good many were more than comely to boot. Their gowns were low cut, showing swells of amble and small bosoms, and their lovely dresses fanned out or dropped, clinging to their slim, pleasingly plump, or just right bodies as if they'd all been splashed by a rainbow, in every color and combination of colors. Jewels sparkled from throats and hands in a dazzling display! Of course all the knights and King's Guards wore their finest battle gear, minus their helms.

"Announcing: Prince Glimmervan of the 'Secret Forest', son and 'Heir Apparent' to King Fabellious!" the man called out. Glim gave a deep bow to the king, and twins, Alastin and Alavina, seated to his left an right, high up on the raised dais at the back of the large room.

"Announcing: Tyrl, friend and travelling companion to Prince Glimmervan," he called out for me. I guess it was fitting, since I had no titles of my own. Might as well have said, Tyrl of nowhere and of nothing!

Announcing: Vandermiremire, 'King of the Gnomes', 'Keeper of the King's Forest', and long time friend of the King."

Both Glim's and my mouth fell open. "Did he just say King?" Glim shrugged his thin shoulders, giving me an arched eyebrow. Sheesh! That makes me the only one with no royal blood!

The king waved us toward his table, and we made the long walk. When we stood just before the dais, he called out in his big booming voice,"Good Knights, my loyal Lords and Lady's of the Royal Court, I give you the heroes who have returned my precious, long lost children, heroes and friends to all assembled here!" Gosh! That sounded like a royal command!

All stood and a thundering round of applause ensued. I blushed crimson when ladies began showering us with all manner of sweet-scented blossoms. When they were done, we stood knee deep in petals, and I blushed crimson this time. Glim, prince that he was, only smiled wide, eyes twinkling again as he turned in a slow circle and dipped his head now and then to the adoring crowd.

As I have told you all often enough, we were used to having lavish feasts, what with the magic pack Jarode had given me, that wasn't hard to do, but the fabulous feast the king had ordered on our behalf, and of his children's, too, was something to behold. It went on for half the night. We sampled food I had never seen nor tried in my life. Deep fried frog's legs that melted in my mouth, and, oddly, tasted like a young chicken, prepared perfectly. There were so many side dishes, the servants were kept running, and I was sure they were being exchanged for new ones every so often, for a fresh round of faces served us often. Wine flowed like a raging river, and soon the hall grew loud and laughter bounced from the walls and rafters.

Glim turned out to be a splendid dancer, and all the ladies wanted at least one turn round the floor with the good looking Prince. I, on the other hand, possessed two left feet, so I contented myself with watching him, and the unexpectedly spry and graceful Van, spin round and round. It made me dizzy to watch them.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Reunion Feast

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
The sun would not be far from rising as we were led back to our chamber. We were loud and laughing, bouncing down the long hallways. Van got a running start in one and slid nearly twenty feet, all very graceful as though he were riding a wave on the open seas, but as he came to a stop, he teetered left, then right, then spun about and landed in a heap. We gave it a try as well, Glim doing even better than the little fellow, but I lost my balance half way through and careened off one of the none-to-soft stone walls. They had a good laugh at my expense as I rubbed a lump now forming on my cheek. We tried to get our escort to give it a go, but he politely declined, though I did see him smile.

Once inside our lavish room, we stripped down to our small clothes, the many cups of wine I'd had began to make the room spin. Both Van and Glim looked as if they thought so too. It was all we could do to find the bed and crawl in. Soft snores were soon emanating from all three of our open mouths.

Come morning, I would have traded the drum beating in my skull for last night's spinning room. Our servant fetched us up some mint tea with a touch of willow bark brewed in for the pain and queasiness. "May I get you anything else, good King, Prince and Tyrl?"

"Breakfast. Yes? Eat?" Van said, and I ran for the extra pot next to the chamber pot in the corner. I had an extra cup of mint tea, before I felt ready to leave the room. We certainly were not sliding or riding waves this morning!

We entered a small receiving room, where the king could entertain smaller groups. It was cozy, laid with a small fire and conformable chairs scattered about. A small buffet had been laid out on oneside of the dark paneled room. Van hopped t it immediately, while Glim and I contented ourselves to sip on only strong black coffee. Both of the twins sat close to their father, probably afraid to let him out of their site. I was sure the king felt the same.

"We've come to say our farewells," Glimmer told them, his face pulled down in a sad frown. "You have been most gracious to receive us in such a splendid fashion, King Valaspar, and I shall tell my father of your wonderful hospitality and of your amazing marble castle, too." the prince said.

"The king smiled broadly, standing and shaking each of our hands in turn. Both Alavina and Alastin had tears in their eyes as they gave us big bear hugs and many thanks.

"We will see you again," I said. "And, hopefully, soon."

"Yes, soon!" Van chimed in.

A whoosh of air flew in a window as the crow landed on the arm of Glim's chair.

"Soon! Soon! Soon!" it cried out. The king and the others laughed, and even I had to join in. At least that annoying bird wasn't at last night's feast. That was something. I wonder where it had gone off to?

"Before you depart, young friends," the king said. I have gifts for each of you." Glim started to protest, but the king held up one of his large hands, saying, "No. I insist upon it."

"Gifts! Gifts! Gifts!" the crow screamed. No one laughed this time. Annoying bird!

"Alastin, would you bring the leather bag just there in the corner?" the king asked his son, pointing off to his right. The young prince jumped up and retrieved the rather large bag.

"Let me see", the king said, rummaging about in it. "Ah! Yes,"he said as he pulled out a magnificent emerald ring. The stone was set about with diamonds in an oval shape, the emerald huge and gleaming in the morning sunlight filtering in one of the room's many floor-to-ceiling windows. "For you, Tyrl," he said, extending his arm out to me.

"M..., m..., me?" I squeaked. "But I could not accept such a lavish gift, Your Grace." I said to the old king.

"You can. And you will," he said with finality ringing in his deep voice. Then he smiled at me. "It's not just any ring, my boy, it has been imbued with magic. Though exactly what sort of magic it will produce for you is hard to say. The wizard who gave it to me many years ago, said it deepened on the heart of the person wearing it. But he was a wizard who worked only for the 'Good' of the land and people, so that I've no doubt it will aid you in a time of need."

"Thank you," I said, giving him a bow from my chair and taking the ring from him. I slid it on the ring finger of my left hand, and I was amazed that it seemed to fit perfectly.

"Now! For you, my little king. What have I got in here for someone like you?" After much digging through the bag, King Valaspar pulled out a carved wooden box, about a foot in length and maybe ten inches wide. It was beautifully wrought with engravings of forest trees.

"Go on, then, Van, open it," he told him, rubbing his hands in delight to see what his reaction would be. Van pulled the box in close and opened the brass hinged lid.

"Oooh!," the little fellow squealed. "Pretty! Yes. Very pretty!"

"Pretty! Pretty! Pretty!" screamed the awful bird.

"Yes, Van, they are. They were given to my late queen by her grandfather, a master carver of some renown. These, chisels are touched with magic as well. For there came a time when the old man could no longer carve, his hands having grown weak with arthritis. He had carved a most beautiful chair for a passing good wizard as one of his last projects, and this wizard so loved his handiwork, he imbued these chisels with strength, that my wife's grandfather might yet carve with ease."

"Love! Van, love" he said, clutching the box to his little round chest.

"Don't even!" I screamed at the bird as I saw its beak begin to work. It glared at me form the window ledge where it had flown, then flew out the window.

"And, lastly, for you, good Prince of the 'Secret Forest', a place I must visit, yes. For you I have a very...," he struggled to pull an ungainly shaped form the confines of his bag, but, at last, it popped out with a flourish.

Glimmer whistled as his eyes took in the large ash bow, complete with a quiver of white and rare black swan feathered arrows. "Yes, I am sure you have guessed, for this bow is known of far and wide.

"The 'Bow of Truth'!" the stunned prince forgot his manners, his mouth hanging open. He quickly remembered and snapped his jaw shut. "But, how? How did you ever come across this famed bow? It is said than any arrow shot from it shall never miss! But one can only take aim at a man or woman whose heart does not ring true, ring with 'Good'."

"The very one!" the king said. I am not able to tell you, at this time, how I acquired it, but there may come a time when I may.

There was much sharing and passing around of our magical gifts, but soon it was time to say our goodbyes.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Going Home

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Once again we found ourselves travelling down a tunnel that the giant cedars formed on the King's Road, their bows reaching out and over us like cradling arms. We had been a band of five, though now we were but a sad party of three.

The day had dawned cool and crisp with a hint of smoke tinging the air. "I hope that is just campfires burning," Glimmer said, sticking his nose up high and taking several long whiffs.

"If it is a wildfire, it must be someways off, huh?" I asked, gazing over at the elf and Van. Van! 'The king of the Gnomes', King Valaspar had called the little fellow! And 'Keeper of the King's Forest'! Who would have thought that!

"Let us hope so. And the wind is blowing away from us, so that is good too." the prince said.

"Good! Good! Good!" screamed the crow as he flew above, and so close did he fly over me that he ruffled my curly brown locks. I shook my fist at the smarty-pants bird, but he was long gone, down the road and disappearing into the branches of tall cedar tree.

"When will your son arrive with his family for your family get together?" I asked Van. We still called him Van, for he had told us, "King. Yes. Van King. Call Van." An so we did.

"Soon. Yes. Soon."

After a time we came to a crossroads, and this would be where we departed east, and our little friend to the south. The sun sat high overhead, glaring down on us as we'd left the tall cedars behind and now strode through a lovely flowered meadow of bright green grass.

"Look," Glimmer said, pointing ahead at the tall elm. Remember? That is where we slept that last night before reaching the castle."

"Yes, and a perfect place for a feast!" I said. Van rubbed his round, little belly and smiled. Glim laughed and with a sudden burst of energy, he raced off to the tree. We caught up eventually, for the elf was lightening fast. We all plopped down in the umbrella of shade created by the tree's wide, spreading branches and lay there panting. Well, not Glim, of course, he could run forever and never tire.

Our feast laid out, we all munched and sipped in no hurry to be anywhere for once. "It is nice not to be rushed or have to think about cleansing swamps, or returning lost princess and princes unharmed," I said, rolling over to my stomach. I pushed myself up, then stood,
and went to lean against the rough bark of the elm.

"I will agree with that," Glimmer said. "Though we should keep a wary eye out for any of the other King's Guards," he said, scanning the meadow with his shimmering green eyes. I did so too. I hope we don't run into those nasty fellows anytime soon.

Just to make our hearts jump, the annoying crow screamed out,"Guards! Guards! Guards! Still, both Glim and I checked a second time.

After a fine rest, where we actually all slept soundly, we awoke and packed up everything. We drug our feet, talking of this and that, but soon we had to say goodbye to our little friend.

"I shall miss you, Vandermiremire," the elf told hi, reaching out and engulfing the little guy in his long arms.

"An I," I told Van. Big tears formed in his large blue eyes, and I fought back my own as did the elf. Sniffing, we both hugged.

"Van go. Van sad. You come soon?" he said, and fresh tears sprang into my already red eyes.

Glim and I shook our heads, said one last goodbye, and then we were off, heading east across the meadow. I looked back once, and Van still stood there watching us depart. The crow sat upon his shoulder, fluffing its black feathers out. Just before we rounded a bend in the meadow, I heard it scream, "Friends! Friends! Friends!" Then I felt ashamed for always calling it names.

After several hours of marching at a leisurely pace, we spotted the slow flowing brook we'd camped by one other time. Here we dropped our packs and removed our socks and boots, to stroll for a time in the cool clear water. Frogs spoke to us from the shallows, and one big fat fellow who, lounged on a rock in mid-stream, sat sunning his fat green body. We sat on the bank, our feet danging in, and watched him for a time. Every so often his long tongue would snap out and snag a brightly colored dragonfly, slurping it back in and gulping it down whole.

"What if he were really a prince turned into a frog by some evil wizard," I said. Glimmer raised his eyebrows as if I were mad. "What? We did just see a prince and princess changed from swans back to a boy and girl. It isn't so far fetched to think. Is it?"

"I suppose not, Tyrl," the elf said smiling. We headed back out after donning our socks and boots. A short stint across the rest of the meadow and we had entered back into the hardwood forest we'd been in before.

"It's is nice and cool here," I said. The forest had many game trails and the footing was very good. Squirrels and chipmunks chattered at our passing, our feet kicked up dry puffs of dust and leaves as we made our way. Somewhere far off, we heard the hammering of a giant woodpecker.

"They're shy birds," Glimmer said, speaking of the woodpecker. "You can spot them though if you sit quietly for a time. Up ahead is where we turn slightly north for my home," he said, and I watched a small smile bloom on his handsome face. He picked up the pace, too, as though the 'Secret Forest' were calling his name. I wouldn't doubt it if it was, either, eh' Tyrl

The game trail we now follow had been tread upon by many feet, for many years. It was hard packed, and wider than the others we had followed. Here, too, the trees thinned, and patches of bright blue sky peeked though with white puffy clouds floated high above. I saw a falcon shoot across one, obscuring a small cloud for just a second.

"Clavar!" the elf screamed, jolting me from my daydream and causing me to stumble forward, tripping on a the root of a massive oak tree.

"What are you yelling about," I said as I eyed the elf with furrowed brows. I dusted the knees of my pants off and licked at a small cut on the palm of one of my hands.

"My falcon, Clavar," he said, pointing to the giant bird, who now sat on a branch of the tree who's roots I'd just tripped over. It gave a solitary screech and flew to Glim's slim shoulder.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: To the Secret Forest

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Okay! That hawk is huge! And it makes the crow look like a baby bird still in its nest.

"Where ya been, girl," the elf said, stroking its sleek brownish-red feathers. "Tyrl, could you rummage in the pack for some raw meat?" he asked, never taking his adoring eyes from the creature, just cooing at the dang bird.

"Sure," I said, setting my pack down. Dang bird probably looks at me and sees raw meat! I gulped, looking over at it as I searched for some meat. Finally I pulled a chunk out, though why our magic pack didn't smell like coppery blood I couldn't say. Blood dripped from the large hunk and splattered into the dry dust, sending up little puffs and leaving small round pools of crimson stains. I tossed it to the elf, who took out his knife and actually cut strips off of it for his bird. Does he think its a baby bird? Does he think it couldn't tear that hunk to shreds or us? I fought back my lifetime fear of birds and said nothing.

"Clavar is trained to hunt." He smiled one of his twinkling smiles my way, then returned to ogling the bird. "My father gave it to me for my sixteenth birthday."

After too long of a time for me, he released the bird back into the air. Its giant wings flapped up a breeze, blowing back my hair. I stepped back as it rose higher and higher, until it was not but a speck against the light blue sky.

"Come on!" The elf said. "We're on the home stretch now. We picked up our packs, slinging them over our shoulders and began a quick march down the game trail.

We were came off of the trail into a huge apple orchard. There had to be a thousand trees here, all bright with cherry-red apples making the branches droop to the ground. Bees in mass swarmed about, and I slapped one off of my neck.

"So many trees," I said to the elf prince.

"Yes. We make the best jams and jellies, and, of course, not-to-mention the very best apple wines,' he said, one eyebrow shooting up as he smiled.

We had just about crossed the orchard when, "Thwack!" Something hit me in the back. I saw another incoming missile and spun. Too late! I now saw they were apples, overripe apples, and someone hidden was splattering us with them. The first one's sweet smelling juices had drenched my shirt, the second my hair, which was now sticky to touch.

I looked over at Glimmer who, of all things, was laughing his head off, pointing at my shirt. "It's an apple war!" he said, grabbing me and ducking under a big fruit laden branch. "Quick! Gather as many as you can in your shirt, Tyrl. I know of a hill right back there," he said, pointing behind us. We stuffed as many squishy ones as we could fit into the folds of our shirts, and then we were running, Glim laughing all the way, his cheeks rosy, white teeth gleaming.

I tried to keep up to the quick elf, but he was already on the top of the hill when I panted up to join him. He'd set his apples in a pile at his feet, so I did likewise. "There!" he said, pointing at a rather small apple tree ten yards away. With that, he took aim, cocked his long, slender arm back, and let loose.

I heard an "Ouch!" And then I recognized the mischievous voice that complained, "Not so hard Glim! That one hurt!"

"Bralina!" I called to her. "Is that you?"

"Who do you think smacked you up side your head with a rotten apple, you oaf?" She gave a great belly laugh at this.

"Oh! You won't like the pay back, young lady," I called out. Then Glim and I grabbed one soft apple in each hand and ran toward her tree, counting as we went: one..., two..., threeee!

A barrage of sounds filled the orchard with: "Twack! Thwack! Thawck! Thawck," and the apples went pummeling into the tree, followed by many screams of pain, though I doubted they hurt as much as she carried on.

"Give! I give!" Bralina called out, jumping out of the branches. Both Glim and I fell on the ground laughing, for she was covered in an overripe apple pulp and sticky juice. A bee landed on her nose, and she swiped it away.

"Oh! Laugh now, you two oafs," she said, stamping her small foot and crossing her sticky arms though I saw a small smile play at the corners of her rosebud mouth.

Glim, who was the cleanest of us, was the first to be stung, probably from standing to close to fragrant Barlina. We all dashed from the orchard, running as fast as our legs could go. Thankfully, the bees did not give chase so content were they with their bounty there.

The 'Secret Fores't came into view in all of its grandeur as we sped onto the road leading up to it. Several archers dropped from the surrounding hardwood trees, calling out to Glim.

"Prince, Glimmervan," one said to him, giving the elf a low bow. "We have been anxiously awaiting your return. I have orders from the king to present you, and your friend, of course, if you will? He swept his arm to the side, ushering us out front. I saw many more smiling elves drop from the tress to follow in our procession. "Glimmer, we missed you," said a pretty faced elf, short of stature but well endowed, with a pair of ruby lips made for kissing.

"As I have you," he said, looking back over his shoulder. I saw him blow her a kiss and smile.

"And just who is that?" I asked him.

His face turned a bright red, and he said,"Oh, that is just Caravellia, Cara for short."

Soon we were at the base of the rope we'd climbed the first time I had seen this marvelous place, but being so tired, both Glim and I used the basket, and someone pulled us up from up top. Ever the showoff, Bralina scaled the rope with ease and beat us. She stood looking over the veranda's rail and stuck her tongue out at us.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Home Sweet Forest

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Of course King Fabellious never saw Bralina throwing rotten apples at Glim and I in the orchard, nor did he hear her calls us both oafs, nor did he see her stick her tongue out at me as I rode up in the ingenious basket the elves had designed. Nope. She acted the perfect wizard's daughter, polite, courteous always when she needed to be. I shook my head at her as the prince and I exited onto the veranda, and she gave me a smug little smile, her eyes dancing with mischief.

"My son! At last you have returned to me!" the king said, rising from his throne-like chair his servants had carried out for him to enjoy a bit of sun. He had laid his heavy royal red and white robe over the arm of his chair. The day had grown warm over the last few hours, and sweat lay like morning dew across his wide handsome face. That big bushy beard's got to itch like a son of a gun! I'd shave it off, if I were him, at least in the warm months.

"Father," the prince said, giving his father a deep bow, then stepping over to embrace him. "It certainly is good to be home, though our adventures were grand, to-say-the-least. Glimmer smiled, a twinkle reaching his sparkling elf eyes.

"Yes. You were gone so long, my boy, your old father imagined all manner of things that could have befallen you." the king cleared his throat and swiped at a tear that threatened to spill from one of his bright blue eyes. "An old man's fate, I gather."

"But now you are home, and you as well, young Tyrl. And my heart is glad, indeed! Come. Sit and have some iced-cold lemonade, made with fresh squeezed lemons, no less. You must tell me and Jarode everything, leave nothing out, for it has been rather dull in the 'Secret Forest', I must say."

"Hello, Prince Glimmer and Tyrl, I see Bralina has brought you two boys in." She giggled at this, and when neither the king or Jarode were looking, I spat my own tongue out at her.

"A goo place to start, said the king, would be at the very beginning, and at this we all shared a laugh.

"Well Glim said, and slowly our story unfolded. He was telling them how we'd come across Vandermiremire's home in the hill, and how the little man had offered us shelter from the pouring rain.

"Hmm," said Jarode," at this part of Glim's tale. "It seems to me that I recall a gnome by that name."

"Why he was a gnome, Jarode!" I said, "and not just any gnome, either! Sorry, Glim. Go on."

"Well, he had the most marvelous workshop, and everything was beautifully wrought, and all so neatly placed that your eyes could not take it all in in one viewing. Oh, and he insisted that we cal him Van, and that we did. We soon became splendid friends. We already miss him."

"Yes. I sure do as well," I said, giving a long sigh. "The little fellow really grows on you. But, I said, "That is more than I can say for his annoying bird!" Glim laughed, but Jarode's head spun my way.

He snapped his gnarled fingers, and stood. "Yes! And not the first one he's trained to speak, no doubt. It's been nigh on twenty years since I came across Van, and he had another crow back then. "

"Oh, yes, I do remember it all now. It took my old brain a moment though. Now let me see," the old man said rubbing his snow white beard.

"Yes. Yes! He was more than just a gnome, you are right, young, Tyrl! King of the Gnomes! And..., and he knew the king in the north. King Valaspar. I was there when the little fellow arrived shortly after me. The king was quite pleased to see him."

"I remember one thing clearly, the little gnome worked his magic on the king's trees as some had contracted a disease and many were dying, their bark falling off and insects invading. Well that gnome, that kingly gnome, got to brewing a foul smelling pot of something. It carried on the wind something awful, and was like to make you wretch if you breathed it in too much."

"Well, he applied this to the bark of the trees, and I recall seeing those insects dropping straight off. Then he'd applied more of the gooey stuff and wrapped the tress in fine linen. They looked very odd, indeed, like a mummified forest. And it worked! Three days later when he unwrapped them, you could see new bark forming over the old naked scars."

"King Valaspar was so relieved, he bestowed a grand title on Van, 'Keeper of the King's Forest," if I recall right.

"You are absolutely right, good Jarode," Glimmer said, giving him a nod and smile. "Van is really something. And we must tell you of how we came across the little fellow, near same as you. But that would be getting ahead of our grand adventure, the prince said.

"I think that could hold off until we had a bit of feasting, don't you all?" Bralina had been so quite (I told you she minded her manners when need be), we'd all forgotten she was sitting off to the side.

"Why, that's a grand idea!" cried the king. he stood up, waving his servant over, then proceeded to describe in great detail just what we'd need for our feast. This went on for some time, and my stomach began to rumble form all the delicious items he mentioned.

The poor servants had to go up and own flights of stairs many times, setting it all up outside. No sooner had they, than dark clouds rolled in. Tiny drops began to fall, and everyone looked up. Soon, they became fat drops, that splashed in the mashed potatoes and gravy boat, then a down poor sudden and fierce. The rolls were a soggy mess. The servants scrambled to get it all back in side.

Glim, Bralina and I roared with laughter. After all we'd been through, what was a little, or a lot of rain? We hugged in a circle and danced barefoot on the veranda, having shucked our socks and boots. The king and Jarode stood in the doorway, looking out at us younglings as if we were quite mad.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: A Father's Pride

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
"I feel quite the forgetful one," Jarode said, shaking his head. "Here I was in the cavern with the little guy, and I never even thought I had known him all those years ago. I wonder if he knew me and just didn't say anything? I should hope not, what with me paying no respect to his position within the gnomes."

"I am sure Van will forgive you, Jarode," I told the old man. "We did have other things to keep our minds occupied, after all."

"Yes. Quite so, Tyrl. I still marvel at those two young ones spending all these long years as swans. Well, they're free now, and they seem none-the-worse for it.," Jarode said, helping himself to another portion of the delicious scrambled eggs and cheese the servants had set upon our heavily laden feast table.

"And, how fares the King of the North?" King Fabellious asked. He pushed back from the table, standing and reaching into his pocket, he pulled forth a handsome pipe. This he lit, then strode up and down the veranda to stretch his long muscular legs.

"He is well, Father, and I do need to mention what grand hospitality he showed us while we stayed there. He is a good and fair king," Glimmer said and also stood, having eaten all he could hold.

"I shall have to consider a trip to see him then," Fabellious said. "It would do my old bones good to have a bit of my own adventure. What say you, Jarode? Would you make the trip with me? We might have need of his aid, and soon."

"That I would, my royal friend. That I would. I have always favored the north. The air has a certain sweetness to it, and the giant redwoods make the trip worth it. What a fabulous site to behold."

"What news of the 'Bad' declining, I asked, looking at the king and the old man. Have you had any further attack from the other King's guard?"

"Yes. Shortly after you three left, we had a sizable force march upon the 'Secret Forest', however, they were, nor ever will be, a match for our archers. We dispatched them rather handily, and sent them scurrying away, but only after half their numbers lay dead or dying upon the meadow. We lost not a single elf, I am proud to say." The king smiled a broad, toothy smile, pride written across his face.

"We have several prisoners being held in our lower dungeons at this time. They have been questioned thoroughly. We have obtained some very useful information about their plans to take over the entire 'First Kingdom', which includes all the lands men have inhabited for a thousand years or more. Grandiose is their scheme, but not one that cannot be undone!" Here the king's face pulled down in a fierce scowl, such as would frighten even a battle hardened soldier. I bet he was something leading his troops into combat when he was my age!

"Yes," Jarode said, standing and joining the king at the rail of the veranda. He too lit a beautifully carved pipe, and, in fact, I noticed it was the exact twin of the king's. Fabellious must have gifted it to him for some past deed he'd done for the elves.

Jarode went on, "There is a land, uninhabited by men, north of the north by far. Few men have ever traveled there, for it is a cold and forbidding place. Through questioning these other king's men, we have come to know of a plan for them to go there, to search for a powerful artifact they hope to use against the "Good."

"Yes," the king interrupted Jarode. "And that is why we must ask you, my good son, and you too, Tyrl, to go on a second quest."

His statement hung in the air, and our eyes grew wide and thoughtful. After a long moment Bralina burst out with anger, "Wait a minute! I got sent home early last time, and I want to be included in this quest!" She stamped her little foot down hard.

I laughed as Jarode's and the king's eyebrows shot skyward. Ha! Now they see your true side, little girl! Forgot about that, didn't you?

"It will be a dangerous trek," Jarode said, eyeing his outspoken daughter. There are things..., things no man should ever have to look upon. Make no mistake," and here the old man stared into Bralina's eyes as he went on, "evil lives and breathes in this land! Foul beasts that live in snow caves or beneath the snow in great tunnels. Ancient things, created by ancient sorcerers, powerful men who worked only for the "Bad'." He shook his head, and his eyes took on a far away look as if remembering some great tragedy."

"I want to go," Bralina said, crossing her arms across her chest. I'm second best shot with a bow among all the fine elven archers even. I have been trained with a sword, and with the whip, she said as if this would change her father's mind.

'If I say no, I know you'd most likely run off and join them anyway. Isn't that so, my brave, little Bralina?"

"Yes, Father," she said, giving him a half smile that reached her pretty blue eyes. It was meant to win him over, and having practiced it her whole life, she knew it would succeed this time as well.

"Ah," Jarode sighed. You are a persistent little creature, but one I love, and one I can never seem to deny anything to. Very well...," but before he got the rest of his consent out, his daughter flung herself into his long, thin arms, kissing both his cheeks, and the old man beamed.

"Come," King Fabellious said, sweeping his arm toward the door of his rooms. Let us retreat to my war room as there I have fabulous maps of this land Jarode spoke of, and I have a few more gifts that will aide you in your quest." His eyes sparkled just like Glimmers.

Our bellies overstuffed, we followed the king down a long corridor that took many twists and turns before arriving at his war room. And, when I saw it for the first time, I was astounded! Not by the size of it, but by the marvelous table that was centered there. It was carved with a map of the entire First Kingdom. So large was this table, it filled most of the room, leaving only enough room for the chairs to be pushed out slightly when one wanted to rise. I counted, and it could seat forty at any given time!

We all hovered over the great war room map, carved handsomely into the massive oak table. It had been coated with many layers of clear varnish so that it shone in the light of the sconces along the walls.

"Here," King Fabellious said, placing one of his large fingers on a spot high on the center of the map. " This is simply called 'North of the North', for lack of a better name or because that is exactly where it is." We all chuckled at that.

"It looks to be a good deal north of King Vlaspar's Castle," the elf prince said, leaning in to get a better look.

"Yes," Jarode said, "and it will be an arduous journey to-say-the-least! See here? These are the foot hills of the 'Great Snowy Watcher' as the mountain is named. Who named it has been lost to our knowledge, but it is a fitting name, for it is said that a powerful wizard passed not through death's eternal gates, but remained, half-spirit, half-man, and it is he who guards the only pass through to where he protects the ancient artifact the 'Bad' now seeks. That is where you must go, where you must seek entrance form 'Chalin the Chaste', as he was/is known for he took a vow of chastity, which I have read, he kept!" Jarodes blue eyes twinkled, looking over at me and Glim. And both of our faces sported a growing blush or red.

At this Glim and I eyed each other, most likely both of us thinking but not saying, "The poor man!"

"Perhaps good King Valaspar will give us hospitality once again, that we might rest there for a day or two, before proceeding on further north." I said. "He may even offer a few of those burly guards of his that ushered us into the castle. I think even the snow monsters might cringe at the site of their fierce faces!"

Everyone shared a laugh at this. Although, we all knew we might not be laughing in the near future, if we did chance across some of these beasts.

"When do we leave?" Bralina chimed in, ever the one in a hurry.

"Soon enough," her father said.

We spent the night lounging on the veranda, making small talk of anything but monsters. The king and Jarode retired early, claiming their old bones needed a bit more rest than our young ones. But, the three of us soon grew tired, too, so it wasn't long before we each began to yawn.

"Come," Glim said, "as tomorrow will be quite the trek and back the long way we've just come from, huh, Tyrl?" He tousled my hair as he liked to do then we all went to our separate rooms, and I for one, passed out on the soft downy bed immediately, snores soon filling my chamber.

"Tyrl!" someone called.

"Arg! Go away, Glim," I said as I threw my pillow at him, but the spry elf deftly jumped to the side, so quick were his reflexes. He picked it up from the stone floor, and began beating me with it, until I rolled over and shook my fist at him, in mock anger.

"Come on lazy bones!" Bralina called from my door. I sat up and noticed both of them looked spry, fully dressed and each toting their packs.

"Don't either of you two ever sleep in?" I asked, my voice like a little girl complaining. They helped me pack, while I took care of my needs, dressing in hiking gear once again. We made our way back down to the king's veranda where Jarode and King Fabellious snacked on a light breakfast, which we three joined in.

"Now," said the king, "I have not forgotten about your gifts! He rubbed crumbs from his long bushy beard and stood. He walked over to a medium-sized trunk his servants had no doubt toted out for him, and opened it. Its hinges creaked in protest as if it had not been opened in many years.

We waited in anticipation as he rummaged in the trunk for several moments, then he finally extracted a large leather bag, which he hefted out. He undid a raw hide strap, and opened the bag wide. One-by-one he took out three exquisite fur lined leather coats, with large hoods that could be cinched tight to keep the wind from our necks.

He laid them out according to size, then handed Glimmer the largest, which he took and opened to reveal the white winter fox fur it had been lined with, the outside being made of beaver skin, which would repel the wetness of the strongest rains or melting snows.

"It is amazing!" Glim told his father.

The king handed me the next biggest and the smallest went to Bralina. We both admired and stroked the soft fur, our eyes full of appreciation for the fine gift.

"Now," said the king, his eyes twinkling, "These are no ordinary jackets. Oh! I should say they are not!" He rubbed his large hands together, and his eyes said they had a marvelous secret.

When he said nothing more, Bralina burst out, "Well! Aren't you going to share this marvelous secret with us?" Everyone roared with laughter at her impatience. And Bralina blushed crimson.

The king tortured her with another moment of silence then said, "These fine coats will imbue the wearers with the magic of invisibility!" He waited impatiently for our response, arching his great eyebrows up and down, smiling broadly.

"Wowzers!" I said, smiling myself. "When some great snow worm seeks to eat me whole, I think I may grow to love mine!" Another round of laughter ensued as we all slipped our jackets on to see how they felt and fit.

"We definitely won't need these warm coats until after we leave the marble castle," Glim said as beads of sweat were already forming on all three of our faces.

"Thank you so much!" each of told King Fabellius, and we each gave him and Jarode farewell hugs.

"Be safe, and may your quest be as successful as the last," both the King and Jarode said in turn.

"We will, Father," the young elf prince said, giving him one more last hug. Then we were off, taking the rope and going down to the ground far below. We set off across the meadow, elves dropping from trees to wish us well, smiles all around. Well, Tyrl, your life sure has been an adventure for the last few weeks, and now you're in for more!

We turned and gazed up at the old pair on the veranda, waving and then going on.

Bright sunlight spilled across the flowered meadow, and the leaves danced as though alive in the cool, crisp breeze. The three of us marched side by side, across the bright green grass as it swayed before us.

"Are you two as nervous as me about climbing up, dang..., ah, what was it cal..., oh, yes, the 'Great Snowy Watcher'?" I think that is what Jarode had called it.

"I believe we all should appreciate the danger we will be placing ourselves in," the elf prince said. He looked over at me and Bralina to be sure we agreed, and we both nodded.

"We can get many useful things from my magic pack, too, like snowshoes," I said. Boy! Sure glad the old man gave it to me.

The day grew hotter as we trekked on, but the game trail we'd been following for some time, had led us into a light wood, where we now found ourselves under the canopy of hardwoods. Here only dappled sunlight filtered down to us.

Soon we spied the little stream Glim and I had twice now rested by. We unslung our packs, which were heavier now with the large fur coats King Fabellious had given each of us, and dropped them, dashing to the brook..

All of us removed our boots and socks and sat on the low bank with our feet dangling in the cool water. The frog I'd imagined a prince was nowhere to be seen, but further down the narrow stream swam a mama goose, her little flock in tow in a neat little follow-the-leader bunch. If I didn't know I could pull a goose, and a cooked goose, at that, from the pack, I would have been eyeing the big fat mama for dinner. But probably not now, since she had her little ducklings, and Bralina would put up a large stink about it too. You never wanted to push it too far with that hot-tempered little wench. I laughed and they looked over at me.

"Private joke? Tyrl," Barlina asked, raising one of her perfectly sculpted eyebrows as though she'd read my mind. I wouldn't doubt if the king or her father, Jarode, had given her such a magical item. I'd best keep my thoughts simpler and not about her.

"Well," Glim said, swinging his long legs from the stream and standing up,"We've a good couple of hours left before sunset. You two up for making it a ways yet?"

We swung our legs out in answer, gathered up our packs and set off again. We probably wouldn't make it to the 'King's Road' this night, but it would be close.

Glim plucked up another thick blade of grass, and after he had it just as he liked it, he began to play a lively, little tune. Bralina hummed along in her high, sweet voice. It made the going nicer, and I soon lost track of time, for the shadows were now thrown out in front of us, like three additional members to our little band of adventurers. Ha! Tyrl, can you believe the wonders you've seen and heard? Of course not, I answered myself. I certainly cannot. Thought I'd never see anything more than five miles from Pa's farm.

"Look!" Glim called out, running ahead of us. "Here's our old campfire from when we were but a day from King Valaspar's castle," the elf said. "What say we call it night, build up a fire, and have ourselves a feast?" He waggled his light blond eyebrows at Bralina, and she gave him one of her prettiest smiles.

Bralina offered to set the feast out, and Glim and I gathered loose wood and kindling that lay within easy reach of our little campsite. Glim soon had a nice small fire going, and he went off in search of a flat stone to brew our coffee on in the morning.

Bralina gazed around the small clearing, and said, "Where's Glim gone off to?"

"He went to find a flat stone," I told her, "He's been gone for some time though. What do ya think? Should I go see what he's up to?"

"Naw, he's a big boy..., er, a big elf," she said grinning.

A flutter of wings landed in the elm near our fire, and my eyes shot up, staring at it with its beady eyes returning my stare. "Na, that ain't him is it?" I asked, squinting at the bird. My question was answered, soon enough, as here strode in Glimmer, and following along behind was, none other than, little Vandermiremire!

"Van!' I said, rising up from where I had been adding bits of branches to our little fire. "What good fortune is this to chance upon you, yet again. I smiled a big smile, my cheeks puffing out. I went to the little fellow, and he grabbed me in a fierce bear hug, though his head only came up to my chest.

"Yes. Van here. Very happy now," he told me and included Bralina with a warm hug.

Van!" I have missed you, my little friend," she said, squeezing him tight.

"Friend! Friend! Friend," screamed Van's crow. Arg! Here we go again.

He set his much smaller pack down a ways from the fire, then he opened it and said, "Gifts. Yes, make Gifts. Van's friends' gifts," he told us. His round blue eyes danced in pride.

"Aw, that so sweet of you, Van," Bralina said, plopping herself down next to the little fellow. "I hope we have something for you as well," she said nodding her head toward my magic pack.

"Ah..., yes. Of course we brought something along, just in case we ran across you, my friend," I told him, and Bralina finally let off giving me the evil eye.

Van removed a package wrapped in fine white linen, and unrolled the contents carefully. When I saw the three figurines carved to match our likenesses to eveyr detail, I gave a low whistle!

"Wowzers! How did you have time to make these so quick, Van. They are amazing likenesses's. I mean right down to Bralina's little mole on her upper lip. You are a master carver, Van! That's for sure!" I said as he handed me mine. I looked quite a bit handsomer than I saw myself though and said so.

"Van," the prince said as the gnome handed him his. It was Glim to a tee, long of limb, and how he'd gotten it to look as if sunlight played off the elf's hair was nothing short of astounding. So life like, we all gaped at it.

"Like? Friends like. Yes?" he said, but by our smiles and hugs, he knew we did, indeed.

Many a time we'd slept in worse places than this snug hollowed out oak tree. It was spacious inside, big enough for the four of us to lie down in, and with dry clothes on and a nice cozy fire burning down to hot coals, we were soon all sleeping soundly.

We must have been much more tired than we thought, for we awoke to the hooting of a large owl, somewhere very close by the sound of its hoots. Darkness had swallowed the forest. I gazed out into a deep blackness. The moonlight did not filter down, so the skies must still be laden with rain, though it had let up for the time being.

My companions still lay softly snoring, perhaps dreaming of snow monsters, for Glim and Bralina, both, kicked out or punched something in their sleep. I sat up and pulled my magic bag close, reaching inside and pulling out a few breakfast items, thinking to surprise them all with a lovely start to their day. Orange juice, and ham and eggs, with fluffy biscuits too.

They awoke to the tree smelling of fresh brewed coffee. They stretched and yawned, and smiled to, for who doesn't like to have someone else do the cooking.

"Wow," did you do all this, Tyrl?" Tyrl! I think that's the first time Bralina's ever used my name as it's always been ya oaf before!

"I did!" I said beaming her my best smile.

"I'm impressed," the elf prince said, sitting up and stretching his long arms over his head. "Sure smells grand, Tyrl! Thanks a lot."

I poured them each a cup of the steaming brew that Jarode had given us more of, since we'd all said how good it was.

"Guess were not going to make the castle in daylight, huh? Wow, we slept this long?" Bralina said, slurping on her coffee in a very un-lady-like-fashion. That's our little Braliina!
As we all sat around a new morning campfire, we heard the pitter-patter of more rain as it fell on the leaves of the surrounding trees. Then a whoosh of air caused sparks to flare up from our fire as Van's crow swooped in out of the rain, flapping it wings from his shoulder and spraying drops of water on us and our breakfast. A lone black feather floated down and landed smack dab in my scrambled eggs. Dang that bird! I plucked it out, cheese sticking to it and tossed it out into the dark.

"Rain! Rain! Rain!" it screamed as if we didn't know.

As I kicked back lounging against the inside of the oak, my legs off to the side, the three of them packed up our remains, stuffing it all into my pack, though this would not make it heavier, being magic and all.

"It is but a light rain," Glimmer said, packing the rest of the bowl of eggs away. "I think if good Tyrl would find four large umbrellas in that pack of his, we might yet make the 'Kings Road', and the castle by midnight. If you're all up for a considerable march, that is?" He cocked his head at us, awaiting an answer.

"Suits me fine," I said, standing and stretching my arms over my head. "I certainly wouldn't mind sleeping in that grand feather bed we enjoyed last time we visited good King Valaspar."

"Nor I. Van ready," the quiet little fellow said. He had been extra quiet this morning. Probably he had been thinking of the trees he cared for in the King's 'Forrest'. I remembered the tle Jarode had told us before we left, how the gnome had saved the trees from an infestation, wrapping them in a special potion and linen cloth, like mummified trees, the old man had said.

When they had completed their cleaning up tasks, we all slung our packs over a shoulder and headed out into the black, dripping forest, each under a brightly colored umbrella I had found in my pack. We were a site with oranges, yellows, blues, and even Van with a red and white poke-a-dot one I'd found special for the little guy. He'd smiled broadly and set off out front, stomping his small feet through the puddles on the game trail we took.

After not to long, the clouds were swept away by a strong southerly wind, and out popped the moon in all its full splendid glory. It made our footing that much sure. And, in no-time-at-all, we stepped out of the hardwood forest and onto the 'Kings Road', which was lined with the monumental redwood trees, forming a long tunnel a we marched toward the castle some ten miles from there. The crow flew off ahead, once again ruffling my hair, so close did he fly over me. You cut that out, you dang black monstrosity! Of course, I would never call the thing names in front of Van, for he loved it as though it were one of his kids.

"Not so far now," Prince Glimmer said, and set off at a brisker pace, the wind whipping his golden hair back from his handsome, young face.

Another two hour trek saw us standing before the unbelievably beautiful castle of King Valaspar. Wrought entirely of marble, it was a site to behold. No King's Guard had stopped us this time, though we'd all spotted them lurking within the redwood trees. The gatekeeper called out though.

"Who goes there, and what is your business so late this night?" he asked us. We saw the same rotund face peek out the door, with his lively gray beard and mustache.

"We are Prince Glimmervan, and a party of three others," the elf said. "The good king will be delighted to see us again so soon, for we are on another quest, and we require his assistance in it, and in the war with the 'Bad." Glim said, stone faced and in his most somber tone.

The door creaked open, as he said,"Then enter and be welcomed."
