Sunlight sparkled on the dewy grass of the courtyard below, and song birds sang from the myriad rooftops. I stood looking down at the inner court as it slowly awoke to the new day. Shopkeepers open their doors, setting our their many wares. Horses pulling carts laden with fruits, vegetables, grains and other things entered through the same gate we'd come in last night, though I notice a different gatekeeper for this early shift.

"You're up early," the elf prince said, stepping out onto the veranda. He handed me a steaming cup of coffee.

"Thanks, Glim," I said, taking the mug from him. "Are Van and Bralina up yet?"

"The little fellow is still sawing logs, and I've not see our little Bralina yet."

"I'm feeling anxious for the start of this quest. How about you?"

"Like I said before, Tyrl, we had all better be wary and watchful, for it is a dangerous task we have taken on. None of us have any experience in mountain terrain. We shall need a good dose of luck on our side, eh, my friend?" He gave me a gentle nudge in the ribs and flashed one of his famous twinkling smiles that lit up his emerald eyes.

"Yes. Make that a humongous dose of luck."

"Luck! Luck! Luck! screamed Van's crow as it alighted on the low wall of the veranda. Oh! Go away, you annoying bird!

"Morning. Yes. Good morning," Van said stepping from our chamber into the sunlit morning.

"Morning, yourself, sleepyhead," I said, ruffling his snowy-white hair. He smiled and his blue eyes squinted at the brightness of the day.

"We'd best find the king, and have another look at that map of his, so we know our exact route to find this 'Chalin the Chaste' who supposedly guards the object we seek up on the 'Snowy Watcher' mountain."

We dressed and went in search of Bralina.

"I believe this is her door," Glim said, giving a few light raps upon a massive oak door with fruit and vine engravings.

"A lady servant answered, giving us a low bow. "She is dressing in the other room, if you care to wait here, she said, sweeping her thin arm around at the many comfy chairs surrounding a fireplace already burning bright with logs flaming and crackling.

We each took a seat, but Bralina soon pooped her head around her dressing room door. She stepped out, dressing in good travelling boots and attire.

"Good morning," all three of us said.

"Morning," she said, stretching and giving a big yawn. "I could have slept all day!"

"I know what you mean," I said. Seems like we never get enough rest with all these marches and quests!"

"Quests! Quests! Quests! screamed the crow. Arg! do we have to bring that dang bird along again/

We found a servant to take us to the king as we knew not where he could be found. We were told to wait in his outer chamber of his sleeping quarters, and we all sat about sipping more coffee and a light breakfast of biscuits with butter and an assortment of fruits.

A good time later, after we'd all been pacing about the room, King Valaspar finally appeared. I felt sorry for him immediately and remembered last night that he's been well into his cups. He look as if a mountain had fallen on him, so downcast was his face.

'Oh! My aching head!" he said, falling into a wide, high-backed chair. "It is a good thing I do not turn fifty every day! Ah! but one must always pay the pipe, eh?" he asked us, giving a lopsided grin that never reached his blue eyes.

"We are sorry for Your Grace's suffering," Glim said. "Shall we have your servant fetch some mint tea?

"Yes. I think that would be most excellent," Valaspar said, giving a groan.

After, he'd had his tea, which had also been laced with willow bark, he went back to his private chamber and dressed for the day, saying he'd be not but a few moments, and he thanked us for our patience.

Soon he came out, and then he led us all down several flights of spiraling staircases, so, once again, we were all turned around as to where we were within the marble castle. think that is intentional.

The first time I'd laid eyes on that massive carved war table, my jaw had fell open, and it nearly did again. Whoever carved the relief of the whole of the North, including the North of the North, where we were headed, was to be commended. Every detail was included, from trees to valleys to each peak and pathway up the mountain.

One thing I had not noticed the first time I looked at it was the little red circles with a sword going through them.

"What are those red dots with the sword, Your Grace?" I asked the king.

'Ah, yes. Those , young Tyrl, ar something all of you need to study and study well!" He raised his bushy eyebrows at each of us in turn as if a father giving a son a lecture. "Those are where monsters have been sighted more than once!"

I gulped and Glim, Bralina, and Van's eyes grew wide, for the 'North of the North' was covered in red dots just about.

"But, Your Grace!" Bralina said, sitting hard on her chair. "So many!" Her face paled and her eyes took on a faraway look.

"I'm afraid so." the kind sounded a bit worried for us. "However! Fear not, for I am sending a full regiment of guards along with you. "Each will be chosen for having experience in this mountain terrain. This is my gift to you, and upon your return, your safe return, we will discuss in detail the aide I shall give to your Father, Prince Glimmervan, and to his Wizard, Jarode, for fighting the 'Bad' falls on the shoulders of all who profess to work for the 'Good." His face grew stern and we all had a moment of subdued silence. Boy! He's good at making proclamations, eh, Tyrl? Guess that's why he's the king.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: We're off!

choices: Up, Up, and Up We Go!
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
After looking the map over for a long period of time, trying to burn the red dots that represented the lairs' of known monsters, we finally made for the practice yard down below in the inner courtyard of the castle. Here the men-at-arms were practicing their sword fighting and other weapons such as cudgels and spears, archers, too, took aim at stuffed targets.

We watched the mock fighting for awhile. The mens' bodies gleaming with sweat in the early morning sun. One man had the poor luck, or stupidity, to glance over at the arrival of his king, only to be knocked up side his head with the blunt end of a practice sword. His fellows hooted and called him names, while he burned a crimson blush up his neck and ruddy face. He stalked of in embarrassment, them still jeering at him.

King Valaspar motioned for his Weapon's Master, and a man who stood well over six feet strode over. For such a large man, he walked with a sure-footed grace. He saluted his king, and gave him a slight bow. "How may I serve you, My Grace?" he asked, standing firmly at attention.

"Farok, this is Prince Glimmervan, heir to the throne of King Fabellious of the 'Secret Forest', and these three be his travelling companions. The four of them were sent on a quest by the prince's father and his Wizard, Jarode, and they have need of a regiment of well trained mountain soldiers. Put together twenty of your finest, and have them present themselves fully packed and ready to go within the hour." The kind nodded to his trainer, and the burly, dark haired man strode off to do his bidding.

"Shall we set your packs by the fountain there," the king said to us, and he pointed at the statue we'd been told was the likeness of his great, great grandfather, though it could have been of this king as well, so much did he resemble his ancestor.

We all lazed about the fountain wide circular border, dipping our hands in to have the pretty, multi-colored Koi fish nibble at our fingertips. I pulled some chicken from my magic packs and they flocked to mine, nipping gently as they gobbled it up as fast as I could give them more.

The hour flew by, and soon the Weapon's Master brought a detachment of twenty men, presenting them in two neat rows to his king. "As you bid, Your Grace."

King Valaspar strode up and down the ranks, speaking to some by name, nodding to others. Some were old and gray of beards, while others sported fresh, youthful faces. All wore chain mail and had both swords and bows slung over their shoulders, with full quivers on their backs. their helmets were open faced, and each had a red and white feather for the king's colors, sticking out the top. They wave back and forth in the morning's gentle breeze.

I also noticed that each soldier had a large pair of snow shoes tucked underneath their quivers. I remembered Glim's and my conversation about having the magic pack just for that purpose, though I was not looking forward to tromping through deep snow, especially, not deep snow with snow worms living in it! I began to sweat before we marched out the castle's back gate, heading straight north, north to our doom, I hoped not.

When we fist det out, ten of the men-at-arms, advanced out in front of our party of four, with ten bringing up our rear. The way was easy going through open meadows, but soon we began to see some hard woods, and then a smattering more, and more, yet, as we went.

Soon we were on another game trial, still heading due north, but we were now in a dense wood of ample and oak, with some spruce thrown in here and there. As we continue, until nearly high noon, we came out of this wood and into a lush valley of swaying, tall green grass. Here The Captain of the Guard, who was also Farok, the Weapons' Master, called everyone to a halt.

We dropped packs, swords and other equipment, and all shared a meal and some refreshments. The soldiers gaped when I pulled a fully cooked ham, bowls of steaming yams, and even a few trays of cherry tarts from my magic pack. Yes! Those last were for Bralina's sweet tooth and love of them, since the young swan princess had requested then on our way to taking the twins back to their home.

Perhaps we should not have eaten quite so well, for we were a slow, sluggish troop marching on well into the sunset. By then, the hardwoods had mostly vanished, except for a straggler here and there. They gave way to the tall pine and blue spruces which grew well in the foot hills of these snowy mountains. Flocks of crows sheltered in the blue-green branches of several large trees, and as we approached they took wing, cawing and flapping in protest of their solitude being broken. Surely they did not see men often, this far north.

Van's crow, riding on his little shoulder, cried out to his feathered friend, "Caw! Caw! Caw!" A myriad of answers followed, like a drunken orchestra of cawing drunkard crows! ARG! Shut up, already! As if one of you wasn't enough! Now I have to put up with a while flock of you nasty birds?

We rounded a bend in the trail we'd been following, and there we glimpsed our first sighting of the majestic 'Snowy Watcher Mountains'. As Jarode had said, they were named for 'Chalin the Chast', he who refrained from women, so that he might watch over the sacred artifact that the 'Bad' now sought. We were on a quest that would take us to his snowy doorstep!

That is, of course, if we did not fall to our deaths scaling this mountain range, or that we were not eaten, torn limb from limb by the many morbid monsters that dwelt both above and below these lands.

"Death! Death! Death!" Van's creepy crow called as if it had read my mind, or was it a premonition?

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: The Foot of the Mountain

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Soon even the great pines and spruces grew thin, and those we saw marching up the mountain that lay before us like some great behemoth, we much smaller, stunted from the mountain blocking the sun and or the harsh wind we'd begun to feel coming off the face of this monstrosity.

The entire troupe stopped beneath the shelter of one of the last great pines, and we all dropped our gear, digging out our warm coats, scarves, mittens: rabbit fur lined inside and beaver skin on the out side of the gloves to keep our hands dry. So, too, did we add extra liners to our boots that we had deliberately selected to be an extra size bigger. The soldiers took the snow shoes they had on their backs and, I dug out four pair for us in varying sizes, and we all sat in the six inch snow, lacing them on.

As soon as everyone took up their gear, the front ten soldiers, started picking a path up the gradual slope of the mountain. At the bottom the going was easy, but looking up to the higher elevations, I gulped at what lay ahead. We were no mountain men. And, though some of these soldiers the king had sent along in hopes of protecting us, in hopes of our quest to retrieve the artifact was successful, some had some experience, but certainly this was not their normal kind of terrain either.

When we were several hundred feet up, we encounter loose gravel in the areas where the snow had bee swept from the mountain, and with the winds increasing by the hour, our footing became treacherous, to say the least. One guard went tumbling down, though he received some small cuts and scratched on his hands and face, he was mostly unharmed. Little Van nearly slid down as well, but the sure footed and ever quick elf had grabbed him by his fur trimmed collar, yanking him to his side.

"Watch it there, little friend, we wouldn't want to lose you," Glim favored the gnome with one of his glittering smiles, his eyes bright green in the overhead light of the sun.

"Look over there," Glim said, as a trio of eagles flew off to our left. They glided with ease on the mountain's air currents. "Probably searching for snow hares or mountain rodents," the elf said.

The Captain of the Guard called for a rest once we'd all reached a wide shelf of granite. Weary, we all dropped our gear, sitting wit our backs along the ledge's wall, which offered some protection from the relentless winds. We had a lit lunch of bread, meat and cheese, and hot coco, which I served the men from my magic pack. They each smiled and offered thanks as Glim, Bralina and Van handed them a steaming mug. They took off their gloves and warmed their fingers round the steaming cups.

All too soon, the tough captain called an end to our rest, and we set off to picking our way carefully up. Up. up, and up some more. As we went up, the air became much colder, so that our hairs in our nose froze and itched. Thankfully the boots and gloves, and the wonderful coats King Valaspar had gifted us, kept us toasty warm, and, too, we each, I am sure, remembered their magical power of invisibility.

As we went up even higher, I could see that this mountain range was made up of many peaks, which rose and rose, until their tops were lost to the clouds. The main one we sought, was 'Snowy Watcher', and to reach it, we would have to go round a smaller, though still vary high peak. The captain had said a narrow ledge went round it, but that we would have to then traverse a snow bridge, made entirely of thick ice. I did not relish either task, and my heart had fluttered as he'd said many had slid off of the snow bridge from going across too fast, especially if the sun was out, because it made it very slick, indeed!

We'd been advancing all day, and our legs and arms, not to mention our backs laden with all our gear, were beginning to grow fatigued. When another man slipped, and was caught by one of his companions, thankfully, the captain said we'd make for another ledge about thirty feet up, and there we would make our first mountain camp, well, the first for many of us.

This ledge, also made of the same hard, gray granite, was much larger, and a wall of rock formed a near perfect shelter, with a slight overhang for a roof. Under this we all collapsed. We lay panting for some time before even removing our packs and gear. We'd long since taken our snow shoes off, because most of the way up had been swept clear, and they were far to cumbersome to try scaling a mountain in.

The men-in arms, took off their coasts to remove their heavy metal, and their captain suggested they leave it here, and pick it up on the descent. To this he got a round of applause from the normally stalwart men.

They also gave us a round of applause when to their surprise we pulled log after log and kindling, and even small stones to make several campfire rings from my pack. Soon we had two fires blazing to push back the chill, and with the protection of the curved walls and overhang, it stayed quite toasty.

As if we were not the apple of the men's eye already, Bralina and Van set about spreading out a huge buffet of hot food to further drive the chill from their weary bones. How they managed to pull a long table from my pack will probably remain a mystery, and the next people to scale this mountain, who happen to come this way, will, no doubt, see it and scratch their heads as to how it got high up on the mountain ledge!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Up, Up, and Up We Go!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Our bellies overfull as was always the case when on ate from a magical pack that could make anything appear, well, Jarode had said most anything, but when it came to food, your heart's desire was sure to receive what it craved. Hot, roasted turkey, not a problem, complete with large bowls of mashed potatoes and gravy, easy peasy, pretty much whatever, so as I said, we were stuffed, and soon everyone of us four and all the soldiers slept peacefully under the ledge, warmed by our fires, also courtesy of my pack.

That was until.., "What was that noise?!" someone called off to my left. I opened one bleary eye, thinking it could be that dang crow I was just dreaming about. We'd not seen beak nor feather of the nuisance, sine we'd began our climb, and that was fine by me.

"There!" the same scratchy voice called out. "What is it?!"

By this time everyone was awake, and many of the soldiers were up and pacing, swords drawn, though they were only half dressed. Some marched about stocking footed, but soon donned their boots.

Glim and I produce a dozen torches from my pack, and we passed them out among the men. The captain selected eight to go scout the surrounding area, four to a side. It wasn't long though before we heard a terrible scream of pain, and one of the soldiers limped back in, supporting another, who's arm was bleeding profusely. He laid him down near one of the fires we'd re-stoked with fresh logs. Te other two that had gone left, came running back in, shouting!

"I don't know what it was, Captain, but it was big. It was very big, and it got Lokey, bout near tore his arm off. It was big, Captain!"

The mans eyes were like saucers, wild and darting all about as if something would try and grab him too, and sweat ran down his wide face, going round a large scar on his one cheek to drip off of his square chin.

"Get a hold of yourself, Moss," The captain told the agitated and obviously frightened man. He motioned for another soldier to come over, and told him to sound his bugle to call the other four back. He took his instrument case he'd slung over his back off, removing it from the wooden case. He put it to his lips, and gave three long blasts.

For a time no one returned, and we all grew silent, watching, anxious that something had befallen them as it had the other four. But then, the four came running in. "What is it, Captain?" one of them asked, breathing in large draughts of the mountain air.

"Something attacked Lokey," the burly captain said. "Everyone stay within the firelight, and you, you...," and he continued to point out a dozen more guards, "are to stand watch until sunrise."

Well, after that, and listening to the man who'd nearly had his arm torn off, moan, no one got any more sleep. We finally gave the whole idea up, and Glim and I brewed pot after pot of steaming hot coffee, strong as they could drink it. For the man who'd been injured, Glim pulled a dark green leaf from my pack, and set about making him a very strong tea of it, and to it he added some willow bark. The man winced as he sipped it, finally taking the whole measure, he quieted then fell into a light and troubled sleep.

"I made it not too strong, lest we need to move," the elf told their captain.

"Very good," he said, and went off to see to his injured man.

The sun rose, finally, off to our left, and spread it warming rays in through the opening of our stone shelter. The wind seemed less brisk than last evenings, and we were all thankful for that. Scaling a trail around a slope, then traversing an ice bridge did not seem like a good idea in a strong wind, or even in any wind to me.

No one had much of an appetite, but the captained warned us it might be some time before we'd have a chance for a bite again, so we all choked down some biscuits with strawberry Jam and a bowl of mixed fruit, and loads more of the strong coffee. The injured man had come to, saying his arm hurt bad, and so Glim gave him more of the concoction he'd brewed, but only a small sip, promising more when next we slept. Lokey gave the elf prince a weak smile, and a nod of thanks, then two soldiers propped him up for the short assent to reach the trail above.

Several times they had to pass him up, as he was unable to use his arm at all. Then he would cry out, and we all feared infection may have set in his limb.

After a short climb more, we all stood with our backs against the granite wall, and, let me tell you, if the captain called this a trail, well, it wasn't. I leaned our the slightest bit and vertigo claimed me, there was a fathomless drop down into jagged snow crevasses, black and appearing to go straight down to hell or worse, The trail, as he called it, could not be more than two feet wide, and it wound steeply up, much of it covered in patches of slick ice. I gulped, locked ridged against the stone, not wanting to move at all. I saw the last of the front soldiers disappear round the first turn, and the rear guard was muttering and calling out for us to move, and so Glim said, "It's okay, Tyrl. I won't let you fall, my friend," and with that, he turned me toward where the men had gone, and keeping his hand on my shoulder, he gave me a nudge. I took a tentative step, and Glim said, "That's it. One foot, then the other." I kept the mantra going in my head. One foot, then the other, one foot, then the other...,

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: What Was That Sound?

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Round and round and round we went on that slippery trail as the captain had called it, extremely treacherous, and tiny, not much of a squirrel path, I called it. Since my bout of vertigo, I never once looked down again. I watched, staring straight ahead, one hand sliding along the face of the granite wall as one man up in front of me nearly slid off the side when his feet went out from under him on a patch of ice.

"Captain," Glimmer called up ahead. We all came to a halt, as the elf went sideways past five or six men, their backs to the cold granite wall. He'd taken my pack along, and he knelt down in front of the captain, reached in and began pulling cloth bags full of something, these he told the captain to hand out, one to each of his men, and he said he'd do the same for our rear guard. When the captain plunged his hand in his and pulled it out, sprinkles of crushed gravel fell from it. "Clever!" was all he said to the elf prince.

Glim sidled back, then passes bag after bag back to the soldiers behind us, then finally one for Bralina, Van and myself, saving the last for himself.

The going got much easier after that with all of us sprinkling our gravel ahead of our feet. Still, it seemed to on a long time before we finally turned a corner, and there was an very large meadow, filled with crusted snow so hard, we could walk across its surface with out our boots punching through,and there, across the way, was the famed ice bridge, glimmering in the full noon sunlight. If you though that ledge around the mountain was narrow, Tryrl, then what do you call this, a shoe string?

Once everyone had come off the ledge and gathered in the center of the meadow, we all flopped down, dropping packs and other thing we'd carried along. Captain said we'd spend the night here and attempt crossing the ice bridge in the early morning before the sun had a chance to melt the top layer and make it more slippery and dangerous. I gazed over at it, thinking it would be dangerous no matter what time one crossed it.

"Slip! Slip! Slip!" cried Van's crow as it flew into our group, and landed on Van's pack. "Food, food, food," it said to him in it's voice it used only for him. He took our more nuts ans spread them on top of the crusted snow, and the bird set to gobbling them as if it were half starved. How the heck did that bird find us way up here? I was hoping it would stay down on the ground. Well, maybe one of them snow worms will reach out of its snow hole and snatched the dang, annoying thing. After thinking that, I felt pretty guilty, what with the little fellow being such a nice friend and all, but dang that bird gets on my nerves for some reason.

We had a early dinner of roast beef and all the trimmings, the we all sat around. Someone had a deck of cards and another some dice, so we played games, since the captain gave the okay, but we kept the betting fun, and no one lost much. We were just putting out our bedrolls when the first tremor cause everyone to jump up. Was it an avalanche or had a section of the mountain collapsed. If it was the latter I hope our way down was still there.

But then a second one came in and the snow around the edge of the meadow spwed up in a great spray. It shot all the way over to us, burying us in huge drifts.

"What is it?" I hollered at Glim, as I un-buried myself. He was dusting himself off, when we heard a angry roar. That's when we both turned, an all the captain's men, and there on the edge was the most hideous creature, white and slimy, a huge gaping mouth full of rows of razor sharp teeth. When it roared, it spewed a slimy substance that melted the surrounding snow down to raw granite,

"Run!" the captain of the guard yelled. Every grabbed what they could, but much of our gear was left behind. I grabbed up the magic pack, and my boots which had been drying by the fire. They were wet from sweat rather than any moisture that had fallen. Glim had everything he came with as did Van, but Bralina lost her entire pack in the scramble. I was glad to notice we all had our fur jackets, and we all said the word Kin Valaspar had whispered to u, "Vasa," poof, one, two, three, four of the running pack simply disappeared into thin air. I saw shocked looks on the men's face's I'd been running next to.

Everyone dashed to the ice bridge not slowing a bit, and being the sun had mostly set, it had refrozen, so it wasn't quite as slippery, the captain went first and just as he got to it, he went into a deliberate slide, and slid three quarters of the way across in one smooth slide. "He shuffled his fee the rest of the way and was across.

Standing on the other side, he now screamed, run and slide! Run and slide!" And, by golly, one by one we did, and one by one we were across. The worm had made it slow crawling over to it, and howled in anger. Apparently it didn't trust it, or it didn't like ice as much as it did snow.

It kept trying to spew its slime across the ice, but it did not have the same effect as it did on snow, for the bridge remained solid with out even a hole or cracks.

"Boy! Bralina said, "I could have done without seeing the likes of that blasted creepy thing!" We all shook our heads, even some of the captains men.

We marched off a good ways, even going up the mountain more in the dark. Glim, with his great vision had spotted a cave up a hundred feet or so. We made the slow ascent as best we could with the falling shows all around us.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: The Ice Bridge

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
We were all huffing and puffing in the thin mountain air, by the time we made it all the way up to the cave Glim had spotted from the ice bridge. It was a large cave, and the captain sent half his men in to be sure none of them foul ice worms had made it home. They came back after a thorough search, saying the coast, or the cave was clear.

We all marched in, and the cave too a bend to the right, down a little descent, and we found ourselves in a second room, smaller but cozier too, and best of all, there was another path through a section of wall that led out to the mountain, and that meant we had a second escape route, if need be.

Dropping everything, we all sprawled on the smooth cave bottom, still breathing hard. Once we'd recovered from the arduous climb, we set about taking stock of all we'd lost in the mad dash across the ice bridge.

"Dang! I lost just about everything. I mean, my whole pack!"

"Not everything, Glimmer said. "You have your life. You were not eaten by that foul snow worm. Nor did you fall off the ice bridge or turn an ankle. So count your blessings, my friend. Besides we can get you a whole new pack, and replace every item you had, and all these men's items too, just by reaching in Tyrl's magic pack. And with that, he gave her one of his best Twinkling smiles. One of those heavenly smiles that made his green elf eyes shimmer. Then we all laughed, long and hard.

"You're right, Glim," she said, giving the elf a playful punch on his long, thin arm.

"Yes, I said, were all pretty lucky to have escaped with our lives. That was terrifying, and I hope we don't run across more."

"Lucky! Lucky! Lucky! screamed Van's crow, and for once I had to agree with that dang bird.

Glim and I took the magic pack around and built four small campfires, and everyone huddled about, talking in hushed tones, for fear of calling something upon us. Guards were appointed watch, and I offered to stand with the first. As everyone snuggled in for the night, We stood about the two entrances, watching for any signs of trouble.

From this high up, the stars seemed very close indeed. I watched them pop into being, one after another, until the whole sky was a twinkle of lights. It was a rare sight, and one I will always remember.

Two hours later, one of us went and woke the second watch, and it was our turn to catch as much shut eye as we could, for we still had high to climb in the morning. The captain thought we might make it to where 'Chalin the Chaste' kept watch over the artifact, and if not, then very close to it. I, for one, would be glad to find him, retrieve the thing, and then to get off of this blasted mountain with its snow worms, and who knew what else.

I saw Glimmer trot off for the second watch with another group of soldiers before my eyelids grew heavy as stones and I fell into a light sleep. More snow worms traversed my dream, and I know I kicked out several times as Van said, "Okay. Yes. Tyrk, okay." "Okay, okay, okay," I heard his crow whisper as if it knew men slept. Funny bird.

I woke to the smell of coffee brewing, and I sat up and threw off my wool blanket. It was very warm in the small cave as someone had kept all four fires burning. The smoke rose to a small natural smoke hole, which kept us from choking.

Most of the soldiers were up, sipping on their coffee, some honing their swords and knives. Others were helping fetch water from a small pool that had melted a large pile of ice in the corner, which had melted from our fire. We washed as best we could, then all enjoyed crisp bacon Bralina and Van made on two flat stone set in one of the fires. Glimm, I spotted across the room, flipping pancakes like a pro, and sending them sailing onto men's waiting plates. Every time one landed, a quite cheer or thumbs up would be made. Everyone was still leery of drawing any attention to our party.

I got up, and Van followed to go grab one or two of the elves fine smelling flap jacks. "About time you got up, " the elf prince said. He tossed one high in the air, and I only had to move my plate an inch, and it fell centered right on my plate. He smiled as did I.

One of the soldiers standing morning guard came in to report the sun was rising to the captain, and it was soon time to pack all our things up. I wasn't looking forward to another frigid climb. My legs were aching before we even set out the cave.

Once we got going, the soreness worked its way out, but it was not an easy climb this day. No, many a time we had to pound in spikes and use ropes to haul or gear and then us and the soldiers up. It was very slow going. At least, no morbid monster had approached us.

I was amazed that out of a group of twenty four, we had suffered no losses, and we only had the one injured man, whom Glimmer was tending. What ever the elf put in those concoctions he boiled and placed on the man, or had him drink, seemed to speeding healing to the long gashes he'd received on his arm from most likely a monster of some kind, though he never really could say exactly what had attacked him.

Just as soon as we hauled everyone up a rough stretch, and we walked a few paces around a bend in a field of snow, we knew instantly that we had stumbled upon the keep of 'Chalin the Chaste', and it was a marvelous site to see, perched their on the peak of the "Snowy Watcher Mountain',

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: A ways to go!

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
With all the excitement of the last month, with meeting so many new friend, with going on multiple quests, with having a magic bag given to me, with seeing a brother and sister turned from swans to a beautiful boy and girl, with so many wold and awesome adventures, why my mind was blown away at the site of 'Chalin the Chaste's mountain keep was beyond me!

But that's exactly how I, Glimmer, Brallina and Van felt upon gazing at it. When we rounded that last bend and it came into view, it stole our breath away. Our packs were carelessly discarded, our eyes big and round, mouths hanging askew, and not just us four, but the soldiers too. I saw more than one sword slide from burly hands to lie in the snow.

'Fairy Tale Castle n the Sky' would not do this place justice, no. 'Magnificent Monumental Marvel in the Sky'? Nope. Not even close to the wonder of it. Larger than any castle I had ever seen, had ever imagined anyone could think about building, let alone actually building it!

It rose and rose and rose to staggering heights. Whether or not it had battlements or rounded domes or even flags flying from its many towers I could not say, for they were lost to the fast swirling mists and clouds.

I craned my neck back, taking in the full splendor of the massive crystal blue ice! And not just one shade of blue, mind you, but a myriad of subtle shade changes, bedazzled one's eye.

"Wowzers!" Now that is a good description of Chalin's Palace, in one tiny word!

"Yes." was all Glim could get out.

"I would like to live here," Bralina chimed in.

"Van, no. Cold. Too cold!" the little gnome said, hugging himself and shaking in mock coldness.

"Cold! Cold! Cold! cried the crow.

"Yes! I bet it is ice cold," I said, looking right at the bird, and to my surprise, he said, in his voice he only used with van, mind you, "Yes. Yes. Yes, Tyrl." Well, my mouth fell open again as I stood staring at the smart bird.

I was totally unprepared for what it did next as well. He flew from Van's small shoulder to land on my broader one, then sat making little cooing noises. Makes me feel a little guity for all the times I wished it harm! Maybe it's not so bad after all.

Van smiled at me and said,"Friend. Tyrl's friend." I smiled back and nodded.

When we'd all had taken in the stunning beauty of the castle, the captain called four men out to go left, four to the right, to scout our the place. They took of a slow walk, approaching the massive buildings, but the had not gone twenty paces toward it when, "Crackle, ZZZZT!" and a blue light arch out and blasted all eight men back nearly ten feet. They landed with soft "THUD! THUD! THUDS! in the deep snow, but I saw tendrils of smoke rising from their hoods to a man. Some had black smudges on their hands and faces, and all bore a stunned look of surprise on their windburned faces.

"What the heck!" screamed their captain. "What in bloody hell was that?!"

As if that were not bad enough, a long resounding sustained blast of a horn began. It went on and on, until everyone to a man, and Bralina, had covered their ears to block out the deafening sound. The ground shook with the cacophony of it. It felt as if it were rattling my bones and my teeth.

I hear Van's crow screaming in anger at it, "Stop! Stop! Stop!" then I saw it arc out and away from our group, seeking to get away fro the awful horn.

Just as suddenly as it had begun, the horn was cut off, and to our surprise, the massive wooden and iron bound doors of the keep began to swing open, though no one was seen with in. No one move, but we all stood watching, anticipating the arrival of someone. Anyone? No one came though, and still we stood gawking at the open doors.

After a half hour of nothingness, many of us had plopped back down on the cold snow. It was eerily quiet up on 'Snowy Watcher Mountain', the only sound being the roaring winds, which whipped our hair about, and tried to tear our scarves and hoods from us.

Then, breaking the silence with such force, a voice cried out as those greatly magnified:

"Enter Prince Glimmervan of the 'Secret Forest', and all of your companions."

When we rose and the soldiers along with us four, the voice came again:

"No! Only the four on a quest for my sacred artifact may enter." That was all it said, then the silence once again swallowed any noise but the wind.

"How does he know you name, Glim? And how the heck does he know we're on a quest for crying out loud? An about the artifact we seek? I don't know if I like this." No. I don't like this one bit!

As Glim, Bralina, Van , and I approached the blue behemoth, the voice called out a final warning:

"Leave the magic pack where you stand!" It was said with such authority that I immediately obeyed, dropping it with a thunk to the snow. We walked four breast, slowly as though we walked to the gallows, to our sure death, for we knew not what we were walking into. What if this 'Chalin the Chaste were mad as a dog. I mean, he'd been living up here all a lone, supposedly for centuries.

"Do you think he's mad?? I mean mad as in loony?" Bralina asked, reading my exact thoughts.

"Mad! Mad! Mad! Van's crow had returned and alighted on the little fellow's shoulder. The voice did not complain, nor say the bird could not enter, so we proceeded toward the doors, slow as w could go without stopping completely. I gulped back my fear, staring straight ahead as did my companions.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,035

One step. Two. Then one more, and we stood just outside the massive open doors of the keep. We could feel the cool air swirling within. And the curved tunnel looked even longer now that we stood before it.

"Shall we?" Glimmer asked, ushering us inside, but at the last second, he put his arm back out, and stepped across the frozen threshold himself. He stood there, still as a statue, but nothing happened. No arc of blue light zapped him, and no voice cried out to halt. He turned back to us three and gave us all a smile that only pulled half his mouth up, but both eyebrows raised as if in questions. He took another step, motioning us to come, and we did, each stepping through and pausing, to see if maybe we would be the ones to be zapped back, but no.

Someone had ingeniously laid and anchored strips of some kind of thin wood slats across the ice of the floor for the entire length of the tunnel, and they had grit embedded in them, which made for a surefooted path. Only after we'd gone down this tunnel a long ways did it begin to curve, and when it did! Oh! Boy! If the outside had blown us away, well...

Around the bend we came to a slamming halt, one piling into the one ahead.

Glim gave a whistle, long and loud. "I never..., I never seen anything like this n my life!"

"Who do you suppose carved all these statues?" I said, looking at each of them in turn.

"I have no idea, but man, they're good!"

"Good! Good! Good! said the crow, flying from Van's shoulder to alight on a statue of a grim faced man-in-arms. Ever detail had been painstakingly carved on it, from shining breast plate to his powerful sword held aloft in a mighty fist. The look on his broad face both stern and brave.

"If I didn't know it was ice, I'd almost expect him to swipe at us with that blade," I said, giving a small laugh, then stepping back a pace from it.

"Hey!" The elf prince said, he sounded as if he'd been startled by something, and we all turned to where he pointed. Our faces grew white at the site, for their standing in a miniature sculpture of a tunnel stood the three of us, our expressions of wonder from a moment ago, captured on our faces. I gulped and goose flesh jumped across all of our arms and ran down my spine.

"How?" Bralina said, backing away from it.

"Magic! Magic! Magic!" cried the bird.

"He is exactly right," someone behind us said in a deep and powerful voice.

We all spun around.

It was Glim who recovered first, and the elf gave a low bow as he said, "Good 'Chalin the Chaste', may I presume?"

At this the giant of a man, for he stood well over six feet, gave a tremendous laugh, holding his sides and bending over, We stood silent, waiting for him to finish. He finally stood upright, wiping tears from both his eyes. His brad face was much more youthful than I would have thought, what with him supposedly being centuries old. He appeared as young as any of us. He had a rugged charm about him. Broad of shoulder, narrow of hip, and green eyes that would almost rival Glim's in their ability to shimmer.

"Forgive me, but I have not heard that particular nickname in half a century. I never was quite sure who pinned that one on me, though I'd like to know and have a few choice words with him. Yes. I would." he told us.

We continued to stare at him, silent as children scolded twice in church. Then I worked up my nerve to speak to the man, "You are Chalin though, right? Keeper of the ancient artifact we seek, one that will restore balance to the 'Good' and the 'Bad'?" I asked him.

At this, the smile slid from his handsome place and was replaced by a fierce scowl. He took a step toward us and boomed,"How know you of such an artifact or that it may be found here in my 'Crystal Palace'?" he asked.

For a moment I thought he might draw the long sword he had sheathed in his scabbard and lop of all of our heads, but he just stood there, feet spread wide, hands at his sides. Then he asked, "Who has sent you on this mighty quest?"

Glim took a step forward, giving him another nod of respect, and said, "We were sent on this noble task by my Father, King Fabellious', of the 'Secret Forest'. These are my travelling companions, Tyrl, Bralina, daughter of 'Jarode the Jolly' who is 'First Wizard' to my Father, and this is King Vandermiremire, 'King of the Gnomes', and 'Keeper of the King's' Forest' the forest of 'King Valaspar of the North'," Glim said, finally getting out all the titles, though once again, I noted my lack of even one. Tyrl of nothing? Tyrl of no name and no where, owner of nothing.

"Of all I have seen and watched for many years, and this know I, he said, "They are all good men, and men who seek to spread only the 'Good' wherever they go, and in all of their actions. I know, too, of the spreading of the 'Bad', and of the foulness of the swamp that you brave ones have cleansed.

"But, how? How could you know of these things?" Bralina was brave enough to ask for all of us. That's why her father nicknamed her 'Bralina the Brave',eh, Tyrl

"Brave little Bralina," he said, and she smiled and blushed, and I grew jealous. Jealous! What do you fancy her now, Tyrl?

"It is time," he told us. We waited for him to go on, but he stood there as if deep in his own memories.

"Time?" the elf prince asked. "Time for what, good Chalin?"

"It is high time I left this beautiful palace of ice, high time I came down off of this mountain."

"Down! Down! Down!" screamed Van's crow.
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Inside the Blue Ice

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,046

At the stunning news that Chalin would, after more than two centuries, leave his beloved ice palace and the mountain, we all stared at him.

"It will be with a heavy heart that I leave this place, but there is something you must understand about the ancient artifact they have sent you to retrieve. It will not work with out me. No. It is tied to me, and to me alone. The magic within it, that may keep the 'Bad' in check, is my burden, and mine alone. At this pronouncement he hung his head.

"Is there something else you are not telling us good sir?" Glimmer asked him. "We are at your service in anything your may require of us."

"No. No. It is just..., well, when I go down the mountain and finally enact the magic within the artifact, it will consume me. Oh, not instantly, I will have a year, maybe two, I was told, so long ago, by the mighty wizard who created it. I will age rapidly in that time, until my very bones turn to dust. But, I have lived longer than most, though much of it has been in solitude. After I have done what must be done, it would be my wish to have a bit of adventure, to see a bit of the world, perhaps dance, and laugh with others as I have so often dreamed of doing.

He had tears in his big green eyes, and so did all of us. What a good man to have given up his entire life, and all of it to protect us, to protect the world from the 'Bad'.

"You're a hero, Chalin," Bralina said, rushing to him, tears overflowing from her sad blue eyes. She hugged him in a fierce grip, and he did likewise. They stood there wrapped up like that for a long time, and finally we all joined in a group hug, Van, Glim and I.

Before I depart my home I have grown to love I would show all of you have few of its many wonders. I have poured my heart and soul into this place, and I think you will be surprised by much. "Come," he said, motioning for all of us to follow. Surprisingly we went to a small door, made entirely of ice, and one none of us had noticed, and with a word, it slid without a sound into a recess, and he stepped within as we did too.

We stood on an ice landing, before a massive winding staircase, yes, made of ice, but with the same gritted slats of wood, so that we need not fear tumbling down its myriad of steps. He took the lead and we began to descend. Down, down and down some more, until my knees began to ache. We came to another landing, and here he stopped, said another word, and an ice door slid open.

"That is a cool trick," I said to the big man" and he beamed at me with his brilliant white teeth in a wide, but handsome mouth.

"This is the way to my private quarters within this vast ice castle, but here you will find many more creature comforts," he told us.

"And where does the staircase continue down to?" asked the elf prince.

"That, my new friends," he said, raising his eyebrows, will take us from this mountain.

"What?! You mean we shall not have to go down the face of the mountain? Not across that horrible ice bridge, nor face those grotesque creatures who tried to tear off one of the soldiers arms..., the soldiers!" Bralina gasped.

"yes. What of our friends waiting out side?" I asked our big friend.

"Come, and I shall let you call them."

"Call them? From here? How would they hear me?"

"You shall see, oh, inquisitive one, oh 'Tyrl the Inquisitive One', "he said, laughing, and we all laughed, for now I finally had a title of my own!

As soon as we stepped through a tall wooden door, reinforced with heavy iron bands, we stood within a massive network of caves. Gone was the ice, and this place radiated with warmth.

He saw us smile and heard us make mention of how cozy the place felt, and said, "Hot springs. The whole of this place is heated by hot springs, deep under the mountain and piped up here, magically, of course."

"Wowzers! That would save on a lot of work chopping wood and hauling it from the foot of the mountain," I said.

"Indeed, the big guy said, laughing another of his rumbling belly laughs.

He led us down a corridor of granite, and came to a smaller room. it had a plush carpet and many fine pieces of carved furniture, which Van notice immediately. The little fellow and his crow, for once, had remained mostly silent thus far, but now he oohed and wed over it.

"Pretty! Yes, You make?" he asked Chalin.

'Yes. Thank you, Van. It was something to occupy my time, and something I really enjoyed doing."

"On your adventure, I said, "You will definitely want to include a trip to Van's wood shop, and home under the hill where he lives. It is quite something to see."

"I shall plan on it then."

Chalin stopped before a piece of furniture with a strange tube-like apparatus sticking out of it. It had a crank on the side of it, which he wound round and round, until we hear a click, then he motioned for me to step over.

"Speak into the tube, and tell your soldiers to approach the door in five minute, as that will give me time to turn of the bolts of magic they were hit with before."

"Captain? Can you hear me?" I asked, feeling rather silly.

"Yes! Loudly, Tyrl. Please speak softer, lest you break all of our eardrums," he said.

I whispered my next words. "We have met with Chalin, and all is well, and he is even now disengaging the blue bolt thingy, that had hit your men before. You may approach the double doors, and Glimmer or he will meet you at the end of the tunnel."

"Thank you, Tyrl. I shall gather the men."

choices: King's Guards at the Base Of Snowy Watcher
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,015

Chalin said he would go down to fetch the twenty soldiers up while we all enjoyed a bit of rest and some refreshment. He led us down another tunnel in the granite, and into a comfortable sitting room with cozy plush chairs and sofa in a matching calico pattern. Here, a fireplace crackled with burning logs, and the windows were painted to look real, one of a lake set deep in a wooded forest, and another of birds flying up from a marsh scene, and over these, little Van squealed in delight. It would seem the little fellow and Chalin shared many of the same passions.

We sipped on lemonade that had sprung up from the center of a round ornate table, complete with four crystal glasses, already filled with ice cubes! It had to be magic, of course. The whole ice palace had one wonder after another, though I doubted we'd even begun to see them all. He had lived here for two centuries, so what else did he have to do. Obviously, the blue bolts kept anyone from ever getting anywhere near the ancient object we had come to get, so he had nothing but time on his hands.

"It's sad to think that poor Chalin will age rapidly, and that in just two short years he will be nothing but dust." A tear slipped from Bralina's eyes as she went on, "I mean, the poor guy's been up here all alone for all these years. It's not fair!" she said, slamming her drink down and sloshing some onto the fine redwood of the magic table. "Oh!" she dabbed at the sticky liquid, before it could cause a water mark. Though who exactly would see it or care, after Chalin and all of us left, I didn't know.

We'd only been relaxing a few moments, when Chalin stuck his head in our little room. "Come," he said in his commanding way as if he'd always been in charge, but then he really was, or had been all these many years.

"I've left your soldier friends in a larger room, and I thought you'd like to join them there."

"Thanks you," Glimmer said as Chalin led us to it.

"Captain," I called out as we entered the room. "Did you bring my pack?"

"That I did," he said hoisting it up and waving it at me. "You certainly would not want to loose it, now, would you, Tyrl?"

"No, Captain, that I would not. And, how would I ever explain such a loss to Jarode!" We all laughed at this, except for Chain, who seemed preoccupied with his own thoughts. Who could blame the poor guy, having to leave here, and then knowing what he knew his fate to be.

"Good, Captain," Glim asid, striding over with his long legs. "We have the best of news for you and the men!"

"All the snow worms have been killed?" the captain joked.

"Even better," the elf prince said. Chalin has a way down this blasted mountain, and it can all be done within the mountain itself! We shall not have to scale the mountain, the passes, the ice bridge, nor fear any more monsters from the snows."

"My word!" the captain said, nearly choking on a bite of cheese. "I think that is the best news I've ever received in my life!" We all roared at this, but it was true. Had you ever in your life had to see and face one of those beasts, you'd be cheering too!

"The day grows late," Chalin said. Let us all get a good night's sleep, then proceed down the stairs, through a series of down ward sloping tunnels, then a short walk through a wide cavern, and we shall be at the very foot of the mountains.

With all the different bedroom he assigned to everyone, you would have thought this man hosted large parties all the time. I mean, I saw at least fifty bedrooms, and he let us all choose. Some chose to sleep on their own, while our party chose a two room suite, one side for Glim, Van and me, and a lovely room for Bralina.

We sat chatting in the sitting room attached to Bralina's quarters, which was connected our room via a wooden door with locks on both sides.

"What good luck, eh you guys?" Glimmer said. "I, for one, was so dreading another climb down this monstrous mountain. If I never set foot on it again, I will consider myself the luckiest elf on this planet. We all nodded, thinking how of that soldier had been injured, no doubt. I shuddered.

"I suppose we should all call it a night, huh?" Bralina said, giving a big yawn. We've a long march ahead tomorrow. When haven't we lately. We all said, yes, and then we three headed off to our separate room.

Soon all three of us were snoring loudly.

Being inside a cave, under a crystal ice palace, when we awoke, we had no way to gauge what time it was. The faux windows in our room were painted with both sunset and sunrise. When Bralina asked what time we thought it was, "Take your pick," was the elf prince's answer as he pointed at one scene and then the other.

A soft knock sounded upon Bralina's door and she sprang up to answer it. It ws our host, chipper for whatever time of day it was.

"Good morning, my friends. I trust you all slept very well?"

"Yes, and we thank you for your splendid hospitality," Prince Glimmer said. We all murmured our assent to this.

"Come," Chalin said in his usual demanding way. "I have laid out breakfast, and Then I want to show you just a few of my wonders before I leave this place forever.

I thought his eyes looked rather sad at this, but he soon enough gave us a smile to banish it.

"Wonders! Wonders! Wonders! screamed Van's crow. He and Van had both been so silent, sometimes we forgot they were about.
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Down the Inside

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,041

After we'd had a good breakfast of ham and eggs with thick slabs of bread, toasted and slathered in creamy butter, and loads of coffee and juice, Chalin said it was time to show us some of his many wonders. He smiled broadly and rubbed his large hands together in anticipation of reactions. "Oh! You're just going to love the first, and it's what I will miss most of all, once I have to go down and never return, he said,his face grew sad, but only for a moment.

He asked us to bring along everything we intended to take down the mountain as we would be descending and not returning to this level. Everyone gathered their things, and twenty four of us marched single filed down the now wooden staircase, for we had left the ice behind. Soon, we left the wooden stairs behind as well, for they became the granite of the walls and cavern, and here they were steeper and much narrower.

"How far down the mountain are we right now?" Glimmer asked Chalin.

"I'd say about one-third, maybe a little less," he said. "But, here," he said, pausing on a wide landing that had been carved out of the rock, "This is the room I am most proud of. When he opened a tall wooden door, a thunderous rushing of water met our ears. He stepped in, and the four of us followed, and then the soldiers. We were in another natural cavern, but by far the largest we'd been in yet. A humongous double waterfall roared down from somewhere very high up. The whole room from top to bottom was hung with climbing vines, sporting huge tropical flowers, normally only seen in the very far south, certainly never in the 'North of the North'! Bushes, ferns and many colored grasses were arranged to be pleasing to the eye. Cobbled paths led one down to a lake, where benches and may brightly lit lanterns were hung from the vines that criss-crossed everywhere.

"Wowzers! This is really something!" I told Chalin, and he smiled his biggest smile yet, his green yes glittering just like like the elf's always did when he smiled. "I can certainly see why you said this room was your favorite! It's the best room I've ever seen, anywhere!"

Sunlight filtered in and made the waters sparkle. They were teal, just a the water of the 'Hidden Lake had been in the middle of 'Lackamoor Swamp'! "Beautiful!" I told him.

"Look! See! Swans!" Van said, and sure enough a pair of rare black swans were floating in the middle of the beautiful teal lake. They were harder to spot than their white brothers and sisters.

"Lt's have a farewell feast on this little beach!" Bralina said,and with that she kicked off her boots and socks, and walked barefoot through the sand. She rolled up her breeches and strode through the teal water. "Ooh! It's just right! A touch cool! Oh, I would so love a swim!"

At this, Chalin smiled as he pointed to the far wall of the cavern, where tall narrow little multi-colored tents had been set up. They looked like traveling carnival tents, only much smaller. "Those are changing tents, and inside you will find an assortment of bathing suits. I always thought I might entertain a few guests, though it never happened until now. The red ten ts have male suits, the blue, girls.

Once Bralina had made her way to a blue one and disappeared inside, all twenty three of us decided to join in on her idea of a swim. We had a splendid time, playing with the brightly colored air balls Chalin provided, and even a disk that flew through the air, which he called an air slider. We must have been at it for hours when he called us out of the water. We all tromped out and stood dripping on the sand.

"I think it time you water babies dried off and changed back into your travelling gear, for we should have a light lunch, then be on our way. I've two more things to show you on our way down.

Bralina and Van, using my magic pack, soon had a feast fit for any king all spread out on two picnic table Chalin had placed off to the right of the beach. We had fresh bread sandwiches pile high with ham, roast beef, and thinly sliced turkey, cheeses, and chips and bowls of fresh berries with sweet cream on top, cherry tarts, of course, Balina's favorite, and loads of lemonade.

We ate so much food, that Chalin relented and said we should all rest for an hour. Which we gladly did. Then we all packed everything up, made sure we had all we wanted to bring down the mountain, then we once again followed our host down more spiraling stone steps.

This time w only went down a few steps before Chalin announced we were at the next of his wonders. He opened the door, and he told us all to place our hand on the shoulder of the one in front, and like that we all marched, single file into a pitch black room. Then! He must have done something magical for our eyes were hit with a barrage of colored lights! They danced up the walls and ceiling of the cavern in a spectacular light show. Some even spun free in whirling tornadoes of light. Bralina and Van both squealed and ran and jumped in one. They immediately burst apart, spreading dots of color everywhere. It was mind blowing to say the least! We stayed there for quite some time, thinking we'd never ever see such a grand explosion of color and light if we all lived to be a hundred. "Wowzers! I said as we exited that wonder of a room. Chalin's certainly got a fantastic imagination!

Everyone gathered on the large landing outside the room's door, congratulating Chalin on his awesome display. Never many said, had they seen anything to rival that! "Good. Very good," Van told him, giving him a bear hug.

His bird, of course, screamed, "Good! Good! Good!" And we all laughed, feeling giddy from the dancing lights.
1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.title: Chalin's Wonders

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,011

Well, I certainly didn't know what wonder Chalin would show us last, but between the jungle beach cave and that last dazzling display of lights, none of thought it could possibly top those. None-the-less, Chalin assured us all as we descended a long way down this time, "You will love and be very, very surprised at my next creation!" He seemed so pleased that we all enjoyed each one. I tried to think what the next wonder could be, but I could not think of a thing.

We must have went down a good hour's worth of the stone steps, before the large man stopped on another of the wide landings. Man, did Chalin carve all these steps by himself? Well, he certainly had time, so I guess he could have. Maybe.

"Okay, I am afraid this one is the last you will see," he sounded pitiful, and we all sighed, and told him how much we appreciated what all he's already let us see. He opened another of the same kind of doors all the rooms had had. "Now, it may seem a bit dangerous, but trust Chalin, it is not.

Well, I did not know if I though that could be true, for he led us all out onto a very long, very, very narrow walkway, with no railings! Below the ground was so far off, I could not tell exactly what was on the bottom, but I feared finding out.

All of a sudden the big man lept from the ledge, free falling from our site! Gasps of all kinds went up! We all looked over, me getting a big dose of my vertigo, and having to squeeze my eyes tight and wait for my heart to slow.

A mighty gust of wind blew up, ruffling our clothes and tossing our hair about our heads, and there..., and there was Chalin! Floating on the air! A big grin of self amusement strode across his wide, handsome face. Some of us said, what a dirty trick this was, but he just continued to smile, encouraging us to give it a try.

No way was I jumping off this high ledge, but then, I was free falling, my stomach somewhere up near my throat. I screamed like a little girl and scrunched my eyes closed again. Then, just as suddenly, I stopped, and I flt my body being pushed back up, strong currents of air buffeted all around me. When I opened one eye, there was Chalin and the ledge just to my right. He belly laughed, then did a summer salt in mid air. Then, to everyone's amazement , he swam. That's right! He swam right through the air, making exaggerated motions as if he were breast stroking through the water. He flipped on his wide back, kicking his legs like a frog, and stroking backwards, just as pretty as you please, as if people swam on air all the time.

"Try it, everyone! Come on! When will you ever have this chance again?" he asked as he made large circles around the huge cavern.

Soon every single one of us twenty four had joined in. Man what a sight it must have been had someone wandered in. People dong all kinds of stunts, pushing each other, laughing! OH! Man! it was a wild time, and one none of us will ever forget, no, not ever!

Van's crow was the only one with any sense left, and it sat perched on the edge of the narrow ledge and screamed at us, "Man! Man! Man!", and we all laughed at the smart bird.

All of, after about two hours of this silly behavior, followed Chalin back to the ledge by air swimming over. we grasped the edge of it and hauled ourselves on to solid ground. My legs felt rather odd at first, a bit wobbly and wanting to buckle. This made us all appear slightly well into our cups, and we all found this outrageously funny. We left the magical room, laughing like drunken sailors.

Of course, we pounded Chalin on his wide back, saying over and over how wonderful that experience had been. How we'd never expected anything like that. How none of us could choose which room had been our favorite, having liked each equally as much as the next.

"I can only wonder at the ones we did not get to see, Chalin," Glimmer said. His green elf eyes were really dancing now. "Oh, that we could stay and see them all."

"Yes, but we must all remember the urgency with which you all came here for. To halt the 'Bad'," he said, and a bit of his merriment left his eyes.

"Yes. Yes, you are right, good Chalin," the elf prince said. "Thank you for reminding us of our task. How far down the mountain do you estimate we are now?" Glim asked him.

"Well past the half way point by now," Chalin answered. "We will be out of it altogether before nightfall, and we should be able to set up a camp in the pines that are scattered about the base. There are many rock shelters to hide us from rain and wind too.'

"Yes," I said, "We made camp in one of those before we ascended the mountain that first day. It had a roof overhang that kept the rain from getting us all soaked.

"Rain! Rain ! Rain! screamed Van's crow. The noisy bird flew down the stairwell and was lost to our sight, as we continued to spiral down and down and down.

After two hours of going down, Chalin called another halt, and we all sat on one of the wide landings, sipping water and eating biscuits spread with jam. Van's crow reappeared and the little fellow spread an array of mixed nuts on the granite floor. The crow gobbled them up, swallowing them down his throat whole, shaking his feathers in obvious thanks. He made cooing noises at our friend. "Van Nan. Van." it said. I swear that bird loves him.

1442321313311112111111122212212112111121.content:
Word Count: 1,001

Just when I thought my legs would give out on me, that I might tumble down, taking those in front of me with, Chalin said, "Only a few more steps, and we will be in the large cane I mentioned, from their we go through a tunnel, and then we are out of the mountain. I saw a tear well up in the big man's eye for his beloved mountain that had been his home for these past two centuries.

Glim put a hand on his shoulder and said, "Chalin, never give up hope that there could be a way to return here."

"But I have told you, once is use the artifact," and at this he this he tapped a large pocket in his coat, "I will begin to lose the magic that has sustained me all these many years, my friend." He looked so very sad at this that all of us sighed, and many reached out to console him.

"Still," and here the elf's glittering green eyes narrowed, and he fixed them on Chalin, "Many times has my Father told me that there be a way in everything. I, Prince Glimmervan, pledge my whole heart in finding a way back for you, a way for you, good Chalin, to live one normal life span, if you will. Much have you served others, please allow me to serve you now in such a way as I can." Now the elf prince smiled, and gave the big man a low bow, sweeping his hand to the side with a flourish.

"My heart is filled to overflowing with your kind words an proclamations, my friend," and the big man bowed low in return to Prince Glimmervan.

We rested for over an hour in the large cavern. It was cool and I could smell pine sap, so I knew he was right in how far down we'd come inside the mountain. Up on a ledge, I saw the crow sitting, he stared down at me with his beady black eyes.

"Tyrl! Tyrl! Tyrl!" he called down to me. I nodded as if he were just another of our band of travelers. That bird is too smart by half!

Everyone was anxious to be out of the confines of the mountain, to breathe in fresh air, to see that sky, to be free. So it was with a much brisker pace that we made our way across that long cavern, down through the narrow tunnel, and then we ran from the exit, whooping an hollering!

We found ourselves in the same kind of terrain as when we'd first went into the mountains, only going up the outside, rather than down the inside. Thin pairings of mid-size pines marched up the gradual slopes, and that is where we'd come out. We made but a short descent to the level ground below.

Tired as heck, our one goal now was to find decent shelter for the night. It was Van who ended up finding the perfect spot, and that was due to his bird calling him there.

"Here! Here! Here! it had called, and Van went running, his little legs pumping fast. It was funny to see him running so fast, but not gaining all that much ground. The crow sat on an overhang of granite, much like the one we'd all camped under. Here, too, it had a natural wall that had formed in a circle, with one opening in front, and one in back. It would hold back the winds, and more importantly any rain, for we notice the dark clouds gathering overhead as we'd exited the mountain.

"Come. All come!" the little fellow had called to us, and the twenty four of us had marched over, dropping our gear in the enclosure. No one felt like eating much, so we munched on fruit and nuts, then everyone said they were tired. Bed rolls were spread out in the spacious space, and soon, all but the night guards were sleeping soundly. Van's bird perched on a ow ledge up near the roof, watching over all. He's probably the best guard of all.

Morning dawned, crisp and cool with a hint of smoke hanging in the air, though our own two small campfires had died out.

"Good morning, Tryl," both Glimmer and Chalin greeted me. Many of the soldiers were already up, enjoying coffee. Someone handed me a steaming mug, and I accepted it with thanks.

"Smell that?" I asked them, looking off to the southeast, where a column of smoke rose.

"Yes," Glim said. "I am concerned it is very close to where the 'Secret Forest' lies. He put his hand up to shield the bright morning sun, and said, "Father will know if it is. He has many scouts who watch for forest fires. They have an elaborate plan in place, and water can be pumped from one of the many streams that run through our forest.} Still, his face was pulled down with worry.

"I am sure it will be alright. Let us hope this wind will turn and move away from the fire. Perhaps we should break company with the soldiers and cut a path straight through to your home?"

"Would that we could, Tyrl, but by doing that, I am afraid we would lose even more time than going by the King's road, and the many game trails and meadows we crossed before. The wood grows very dense as the crow flies, and we would be marching up and down over those teats we found ourselves on that one time. Remember?"

"Oh yes," I told the elf prince, and my legs began to ache even thinking about that horrible trek we'd made.

We drank up our coffee, rolled up our bed rolls, and made sure every ember was out on our two fires. With all haste we marched briskly to exit the 'North of the North', making for the 'King's Road'.

"South! South! South!" screamed the too smart crow.

It was a good ten mile hike through pines that grew thicker as we marched south to the Castle of King Valaspar. King Valaspar's scouts must have reported us marching, for we had no sooner arrived than he was standing in the courtyard, congratulating his men and then coming over to us.

"Prince Glimmervan, I am so glad to see you, Tryl, Bralina and Van have all arrived back safely!" He gave us each a hug in turn. "You are a son a king may be proud of."

"Thank you good King," You and I both" he told the king.

"Come! You must all need a good rest, before you set out in the morning. You've no doubt seen the smoke, and you must be fearing for the 'Secret Forest', though I personally sent scouts that way, and they say they think it has skirted your home forest. Let us hope it is so."

"Yes, let us how, Your Grace."

We went in the small door n the wide stone wall of the inner keep, following the King down the long hall. At the intersection of two hall, he left us, and a servant took us along to our same old chambers, where we deposited our things and climbed into bed still wearing our hiking outfits. We didn't care,and we were snoring i minutes. The crow sitting on the bed post and watching over us. We never heard him say, "Sleep. Sleep. Sleep, young friends."

1442322.content:
That irritating do-gooder was back on my right shoulder again, he always returned, no matter how many petulant swats and swipes are sent his way! My conscience, I mean.

Y'know, the little guy in white flowing robes and that natty little glowing ring above his head, arms akimbo and an accusing glare in his eyes. I prefer the advice of the other little guy, the one in all red, two fetching horns that peep out from the black curls on his head and such an endearing gleam of mischief in his eyes! He does have a nasty habit of poking me with his trident to make a point but Virt (short for Virtue), the other guy I mentioned before - he makes the pain go away with a wave of his hand.

But, Vic (short for Vice, yeah, I know it's not very long in the first place, but that's what he prefers to be called, Vic.) plays hooky a lot, he's not always around to help me deal with Virt, and Virt can get so blah-repetitive sometimes, I need all the help I can get. When they're facing off, at least they're not lecturing me!

So, Virt, virtually unchecked, since Vic is still AWOL, starts off, "You know it, I don't need to tell you but ..."

Yeah, you don't need to, but you will give me at least 2000 words of opinion anyway.

He droned on about how I was conniving and colluding with someone who wanted to commit one of the seven (or was it ten)? I wasn't paying close attention) original sins, How I was being seduced by all sorts of sins myself, like Sloth and Greed, not to mention Power and Pelf. Funnily enough these last two were minor sins!

"Whose idea was this whole imrpesonation? Why are you doing this?"

But the guy was starting to make sense, it wasn't my aims that I was furthering, it was someone else's. Those were neither noble or something for the 'good of the people', it had been pure wicked lust that had driven the King to his action.

"And exactly what else does this ex-King desire from you, he surely did not intend you to loll around all say eating rich food and quaffing his precious mad?"

That scornful glare again, it was giving me a headache!

I was to be roped in for murder at the very least, of a man I had nothing against except that he did not much favour the area in which I lived. Who was to say that his successor would be any better?

"And of course, you have this Kingdom to rule for ever and ever, you and you heirs after you?" A sweeping glance at the room, my inability to go anywhere without a horde of minions watching my every move, brought home the truth of my miserable existence.

Nor was this Kingdom of mine to remain with me for long, the rightful owner would depose me on his return. Would I still have a head attached to my shoulders when he did that, with all the knowledge of his treachery in that head?

I turned to Virt with despair in my heart and pleading on my tongue, beseeching, perhaps for the first time, "Help me, Virt. I can't go through with this!"

"Very well. But you have to promise to ignore Vic when he does deign to appear, after he has slept off his revels, see what happens when one carouses ..."

He would have go on about Vic for ages, he tends to fly into a rage on this one point, but I reminded him, "Let's get back to how we get out of this sticky situation, hmmm?"

"Oh, that's simple, a disguise and henchman, you provide the latter and I shall give you the former."
