145.content:
Dawn was greeted with the sound of trumpets, the announcement of a new king. The people began to gather out in the square, and I wrapped Joshua in a blanket and brought him out to hear the announcement. Most were groggily finding their way through the streets, some of the old men still fighting off their drunkenness. I, however, had already been awake. A hush fell over the crowd as the vizier stepped out onto the royal balcony. He unrolled a scroll, an unnecessary but formal action.
"Ahem. Last night, whilst a storm covered the moon, a vile assassin snuck into our palace, disabling the king's guards. He managed to get into the king's bedroom and mortally wound him. The king is dead. In his final moments, King Tansigero named his replacement, and we have obliged. Bow before your new king, Tyrl Kevander. The king is dead; long live the king!"
A shy-looking gentleman with a thick brown mustache and the kingly garments stepped onto the balcony, at which point the entire square knelt.
"Long live the king!" echoed through the square a thousand times. I knelt with them, but this was not out of respect for King Kevander. Things had not gone according to plan, and there was going to be hell to pay. The shy new king raised his hands for the people to stop professing their love. As silence fell once again, he cleared his throat.
"Thank you for your love and respect. I am quite honored and, honestly, quite surprised at this turn of events. But, I vow to be a good king, to lead you through these troubling times, and bring our kingdom to victory against Bazallyn!"
The crowd erupted into cheers. I cheered with them, but I could feel panic growing in my chest. Joshua began to cry, giving me a wonderful excuse to leave the square. I walked trembling back to my cottage. Once inside, I hurriedly locked the door and bolted the shutters.
"Reesa, how good to see you!"
I yelped and swung around. I was too late. Midal Asafan sat lounging in my rocking chair. "My lord, you startled me."
Asafan let out a chuckle. "Apologies, I wouldn't want you to drop the baby. How old is he now?"
"Seven months."
"Ah," Asafan stood and walked over to me. "May I?"
I hesitated, but then quickly remembered that Asafan does not like to be denied. Reluctantly I relinquished Joshua to him. "Hello there," Asafan's voice took on a disgustingly sweet sound. He cooed at the baby, who giggled, having forgotten what had made him cry moments earlier.
"You seem like a very strong boy. Are you going to be an assassin like mother dearest? Here's a little something to get you started."
Asafan pulled out a tiny dagger, more of a dart than anything. He placed it in Joshua's hands, who gripped it and shook it like a rattle. He handed Joshua back to me. I wanted to pry the dagger from his hands but I knew Asafan would react negatively.
"You have made errors, Reesa."
"I am aware."
"The king was not to be left alive long enough to elect a successor. Then it would've gone to our benefactor. But he chose that no name Kevander, and it is entirely your fault."
"Yes, I'm sorry."
"Sorry doesn't change anything. Fix it."
"How?"
"I don't know. But one thing is certain. You will find a way to get Frago Anaximander on that throne, or we will be short a young assassin."
Asafan eyed the baby one final time and stepped out the door, leaving me with my thoughts and my child, who might not be alive much longer.

1451.content:
Reesa stood frozen for the moment. Her previous actions marched through her memory like Barack the Conqueror of old. No one could stop him. How was she to change fate? She was sure the King was dead when she slipped out of the castle. "Who had claimed Tryl to be the chosen? Who set this untrained boy to be king?"
Joshua began to squirm and fuss. She hummed a melody to quiet him and laid him in his bed.
Soft tapping at the door interrupted her thoughts and she stood to one side. "Who is it?"
"Tanya."
Reesa sighed and lifted the latch. The door flew open and the young girl flew into the room falling on the rough floor, tears streamed down her dirty face.
Two giant entered and slammed the door behind them.
"What were you doing at the castle yesterday?" One of the Kings Guards demanded.
"Castle? I was not at the castle yesterday. My son is ill and I need to keep him away from others as he is contagious."
"Whats wrong with him?" The smaller guard asked, moving closer to the door.
"Ignore her. I have a passel of children and they're always sick with something. Don't lie. My sources say you were in the castle near the time the King became ill and died."
"I wasn't there. You must have seen someone else. I had no reason to go the castle. The King has not called for me for over a month. I fear he had found some reason to be angry with me, but I have done nothing."
The younger man tried to reach the handle of the door blocked by his superior. "You are a liar!" The last words were followed by the man's backhand slap. Reese wasn't expecting this and caught off guard her head spun as she fell across Tanya's legs.
"Now you will tell me what poison you gave the king!"
"I tell you I wasn't there." Reesa's voice was muffled as she held her hand to her cheek.
The large guard jerked her to her feet. "You will come with me to the Captain of the Guard."
Reesa pulled against him. "Please believe me, I have been here with my sick child. I can't go with you. He'll be awake soon and want to feed."
"Let him go hungry for a little while. Its good for him. He won't be such a momma's boy." The guards laughed and pulled Reesa from the house.
"Tanya, get Getta, she will take Joshua."
The girl nodded.
The people stared at the two men marching a woman down the streets. When the women peeked out to see who it was there were some who laughed and others who just hid their face and turned away. No one stepped forward to help her.
At the castle, Reesa was thrust into the room where the Captain of the Guard held audience. He waved the men to leave them alone and fear began to slowly thicken her veins. She said nothing, but bowed her head so she could see where his feet took him.
"Welcome little Reesa. Since the King is dead, May he rest in peace, you are no longer under his care. In fact you are no longer needed around here. You did your job well. Not for our side, but we managed to make that mistake work for us."
She raised her head slightly and eyed him.
He saw her reaction. "Yes, sweetheart, we know what Asafan had you do. The king knew there was a plot also. He was so besotted with you he didn't care. I'm not so stupid. I can make things happen. I know Asafan visited you. What does he want?"
Reesa pressed her lips together and stared hard at the point where the Captain stood. His boots moved bringing the man so close her head touched his chest.
His gloved fist moved to her chest and up to her chin. His fist pushed against her
chin forcing it up and her gaze to meet his.
"You don't have a choice any more. You are now mine. I'm in charge now and you will do what I say. From now on I want to hear every word of every meeting you have with Asafan and Frago. I will feed you the information you are to give them. Do you understand?" His voice softened and his breath caressed her cheek. "Do I hear a yes, sir?" Fingers pinched her chin but she wouldn't open her mouth to speak.
"You want to play hard to get?" His free hand gripped her breast and she groaned aloud in pain, her mouth opening and his smashing hers filling it with his tongue.

She stumbled into her home immediately looking for Joshua. His crying brought her milk down and she held the globes searching for relief.
Gretta slipped through the hidden door and laid the boy against his mother. "He wouldn't take from me. Are you alright?"
Ressa shook her head.
"Someone is waiting to see you."

1453.content:
Once upon a time, there was a boy. He lived in the palace, and he played with the king's sons like his own brothers. Then, one day, the boy's father died. The boy was heartbroken. But, never fear, the king adopted him. As the boy became a man, he began to realize his potential. He was in a position to be in great power. The only thing standing in his way were his playmates.
That was an easy fix. One hunting accident and one poisoned goblet later, there was only one man waiting anxiously for the throne.
Frago Anaximander.
***
I was really trying to cry. I knew there was a part of me that loved the old king, even though I had ordered his assassination. But as I gazed into the casket on the dais, I could only feel one emotion.
Anger.
This man, who had adopted me at age eleven, loved me as his own son, had not declared me king! Of course, I knew this was coming. This was why I had ordered his assassination in the first place. But perhaps my secret meetings aroused too much suspicion, or perhaps the assassins had sold me out for higher pay.
The assassins. There was another group of people to blame for this. I had sent clear instructions: unfit to name a successor. And what did they do? Leave him alive long enough to declare that no name Tyrl as the king!
Speak of the devil, here approaches Tyrl now. He looks so unseemly in his kingly vestments.
"Frago, I am deeply sorry for your loss."
"Thank you. The pain of losing one father was enough, two fathers is too much to bear."
"Yes, well, you may live in the castle for as long as you need. I'm sure you have some inheritance somewhere, but I know transitions can be difficult whilst grieving a loss."
"Thank you, my liege."
I kissed his hand and walked away, barely containing my rage. I stalked out of the hall, done with my viewing of the king, although I'm sure everyone thought I could not bear the sight of my dead adopted father. I retreated to my room in the southern tower. Within moments, a knocking on my window came. I opened it.
"Asafan. You have failed me."
The assassin bowed before me. "I apologize, my lord. The assassin sent failed her job."
"Her?"
"One of our best, before she gave birth."
"An assassin as a mother? The poor child."
"What's more, no father to speak of."
"Oh," I let loose a devious grin, "Nasty, are we?"
"I have my suspicions on who it is but she will not say."
"And has she been punished?"
"I have told her to fix it. I don't know how she plans to do so, but her infant's life hangs in the balance so I imagine she'll work out something."
"Excellent," I smiled. "In the meantime."
I withdrew a dagger from my robe and stabbed the assassin in the stomach. He collapsed, clutching his belly.
"I do apologize, but there must be someone to distract the guard from this mother assassin. What was her name?"
Asafan refused to answer. I kicked him and he winced. "The name, or I kick again."
"R... Reesa Hav... Havensporth."
"Reesa Havensporth. I will have to send someone to pay her a visit. Until then... GUARDS!!!"

1453.title: The Tale of Frago Anaximander

14533.content:
“This, my friend, is the most important run of your life.”
I approached Lord Anaximander where he lounged on his couch.
“I take it we caught your father’s assassin?” I asked, nodding at the bloody stain on the floor.
“Perhaps, although I suspect something far deeper in the works.”
“A ring of assassins, then?”
“Not just a ring,” Anaximander stated, withdrawing a pendant. I leaned in for a closer look.
“I don’t recognize the symbol, my lord.”
“Nor would you, it is beyond your time.”
“You are not that much older than me, my lord.”
“Old enough…” he said, looking into an imaginary distance.
“What is it?”
“Have you ever heard of Lilyana Baroo?”
I drew back. “The witch?”
“A braja, actually. The last of her kind. You know, our people used to worship brajas, back in the day.”
“In the dark ages?”
“Yes, the dark ages. Brajas were slightly more than human, slightly less than angel. We feared their powers, and submitted to them. But brajas, by nature, are darker than pure humans.”
“Which is why they must be destroyed with fire or purified water. Any weapon not of pure light would not work.”
“Yes, and so when they became too oppressive, we turned on them, and hunted them down. Lilyana hid well for many years, but my stepfather ferreted her out.”
“I do not understand why this is pertinent.”
“Because, at the stake, Lilyana was defiant. She boasted. I was but a boy of five, but I remember. She calmly insisted that she had established a new organization of followers, a group of skilled assassins. And that she had entrusted something very important to these followers.”
“What would that be?”
“A daughter.”
I took a step back. “So, another braja lives?”
Lord Anaximander stood up and walked over to his bookshelf. “At the time, everyone believed this was the last desperate plea of a mad braja. But, I have seen this symbol before.” He picked a book of the shelf and opened it. He turned the painting towards me, and I squinted.

Her body twirled and jerked as she fell. She was going to kill that bitch, how dare she touch him, how dare she tried to lure him! If only Steven could see her real appearance, it wasn't his mother . . . but then this happened. The wind in her face made it impossible to breathe, she felt like she'd suffocate..Everything was black. She found herself falling in this darkness, hurtling to an invisible floor. A floor that would most likely kill her if she continued to fall at this speed.

The air pushed against her face, she closed her eyes, preparing for the inevitable. Steven was too far, he couldn't save her. So many things ran through her mind, she shouldn't have kept it a secret, she should have told him that she was a witch. Even after she had it, the magic, she wasn't perfected in it, it would go wrong if she used her magic to protect herself, it would have hurt Steven.

She braced herself and closed her eyes tightly, everything going numb around her. Just then, she felt strong grip on her waist, manly familiar hands, which pulled her closer to a body sharing the warmth, protection against the wind. It clicked in her mind, "Steven!". She couldn't believe it, she wanted to but she couldn't. She was afraid to open his eyes and find herself falling, it was her mind fooling her. She wasn't going to open her eyes but then she heard him chuckle,

"You know, you can open your eyes, Laura." Her eyes went wide and she opened them at once staring at the beautiful, familiar face, that looked into her blue eyes, it left her breathless, all she could manage to say was,

"H-how? Who are you?"

"Laura, what kind of questions are you asking me?! Well, I don't know the how too, but the who, I am Steven, silly! Let's get us down."

Laura held on tightly to Steven, her nails digging into the cloth of his shirt, no wait, it wasn't a shirt, it was flesh, bare skin.

"Where's your shirt?!" She had never held him this close, her heart was racing fast. Steven didn't reply, then she felt the wind stop, were they on ground?

"Um, Laura, we are . . . um, we are on the ground, you can leave me now."

Laura looked at his face and below, shit, they were on the ground, her cheeks were red as she blushed and fidgeted. She looked at him to apologise but then her mouth hung open, her words trapped inside her mouth, the sight was unbelievable incredible and magnificent! Wings, beautiful, blackest as the colour can get. They shone lightly, their texture like the one she saw in the angle movies and which she always yearned to touch. She instinctively, ran a hand over them, she loved the smooth, fluffy texture. They were wings. . . Steven's wings.

"HOW?!"

Steven grinned and winked at her expression, "You've got your secrets, I've got mine, love."

"B-but I don't understand . . . "

"Yes, let's run away from here, then we will tell each other everything, deal?"

There was nothing more she wanted than to run away from this place, without stopping to think, she spoke, "Yes, deal."

She considered that if it were not for Steven, the marble floor could very well have been colored in shades of ghastly blood red. If it were not Steven!

And Steven, what to say about the little trickster? To be honest, she had felt something was wrong – or, well right – with Steven right when they started their journey towards the magical realm. She remembered distinctly that on the first night when the darkness engulfed the forest, Steven “somehow” managed to capture hundreds of fireflies in a jar out of nowhere and used to light their path ahead. How could she have not guessed it; fireflies are known to be out in summers and not in these harsh wintery times, after all.

“This is no damn summer,” she whispered as a fresh gush of cold stream of air hit her.

She then also remembered his smile as he had said “This is to keep you safe from the forest beasts and the shape-shifters.”

How did he know that shape shifters dwelled in this place when he had never been to the forest before. Now she could connect the dots perfectly. He was the Guardian Angel who protected the passersby of the travelers through the forest. She smiled looking at him.

They were about to descend onto the outskirts of the maze when she caressed the silky wings of Steven. Steven with damn Wings! She could barely believe that this person who appeared as a coward at times to her was in fact a messenger of God, an Angel. She giggled to herself at how clumsily she had treated Steven sometimes. He deserved a sorry – a grand one; instead she threw a mock punch at him.

“So what is you secret, Madame Laura?” he said, raising his left eyebrow playfully.

“Mine, nothing,” she giggled like a school girl.

“Oh really? I too am a normal human being, then,” Steven said and his wings folded back into his back and disappeared.

Laura laughed and kept looking at Steven for sometime. It was time to tell her part of the story now.

“Would you be able to handle what I say, Steven?”

“Well, I handled you pretty well, didn’t I? Your secret wouldn’t be nearly as weighty, that is for sure,” Steven flashed another of those toothy smiles.

Laura drew a long breath and said – “I am a Witch, Steven. The Witch of the Silvery Circles.”
Laura didn’t look at Steven because she didn’t had it in her to look into his eyes. She knew that Steven had kept a secret from her too but that was something which couldn’t have harmed anybody. Her secret on the other hand had the potential to create havoc. She cringed a little as she prepared herself to a barrage of questions. She knew another deep breath. Sigh!

Steven looked at Laura for a moment, as if to consider whether to say something which was going on in his mind, but decided against it. He tilted his head again towards her for a moment but jerked it back straight, fluttered his golden wings and took a little hop in the air as if climbing a ladder and then set sail towards the sky. Laura was sure that there was something going on in Steven’s mind, something which he wanted to say but couldn’t. It pricked her because she believed that the revealing of her secret was what had given birth to this feeling of uneasiness between them. She winced a little and closed her eyes, to curse her ill judgment and jus then, she felt a gust of wind caress her face accompanied with sound of flapping. A little stunned, she opened her eyes and saw Steven with a smile on his face, flying some one arm away from her, hovering a feet above the ground. He had his hand outstretched.

“Now what is this about, Steven?” Laura said, still a bit stunned but she knew that it wasn’t bad for sure because of that reassuring smile on his face.

“Would you come with me to do a quick recce of this place?” Steven asked with those puppy eyes, head tilted to his right, possibly playfully. Laura’s eyes twinkled and she nodded as she took his hand, gently tugged at those velvety wings of his and climbed onto his back with a little effort.

“What took you so long to ask, huh? Grrr …” she kidded, mocking a growl. Steven’s wings were now flapping those huge wings at near full pace, and as they both started to rise above the ground he said, “I am scared of the witches, you know!” suppressing his smile, somehow. Laura gnashed her teeth as she pinched him in his ribs and an “ouch” escaped Steven’s lips. Soon, they both shared a moment of laughter which flooded away all the moments of uneasiness which had been building till then and washed away those doubts which were starting to burden Laura’s mind. She was at peace now, and she closed her eyes and felt the fluttering breeze against her face. A tear escaped her eyes and fell onto Steven’s wings.

“No spitting – no spitting bad girl, “Steven mocked her again, fully knowing that it was Laura’s tears. He also understood what must have been going through her mind all this while because more or less he was facing the same demons in his mind. But it didn’t matter what mattered was they had both slayed their dragons. They both continued with their naughty, playful ways under that bluest of skies as Steven went higher and higher till they were above the tallest trees of the forest.

“See, there,” Steven pointed at a river stream which looked like a waving blue ribbon tied to a girl’s pony from this height, “we should move by the side of the river stream till we reach that – oh, what is that? a building, yeah maybe – till we reach that structure we see there. Must have been a fort in older times, for sure,” Laura nodded. It was the eyes of Steven and Laura - blessed with their own special and some common powers – which were able to see that tiny structure from afar. No mortal would have been able to even contemplate the kind of clarity with which they were seeing the fort which lay at a distance of more than forty miles from the spot where they were. But they were no mortal, after all they were special.
Steven didn’t need to elaborate more and she understood the plan exactly,

“We will reach that abandoned fort structure and then, do a quick recce again, right Steven? But what makes you think that the fort is an important – ok, I get it,” she paused to complete herself, “In old times forts were built near rivers for two main purposes. The first one – the obvious one – was to get an unlimited water supply for all the soldiers and residents of the kingdom and second is to –“

“…Secure the fort, exactly, my thoughts” Steven completed Laura’s lines. She smiled. “And if there is fort, be sure that there must be some secret or some quicker way to get out from these thickest of forests,” said Steven smiling at the teamwork in the plan formation.

“Yeah, of course, else they wouldn’t have lasted long, you know, and would have been easily susceptible to warfare tactics which would take the advantage of this thick forest cover,” Laura said, nodding. She wished to reach that Fort as soon as she could; something about it intrigued her.

“But Laura, the fact that there seems to be nothing in that fort is jarring my senses a little, you know! Do you see what I see?” said Steven but Laura was so engrossed in the thought of reaching the fort and then getting out of this sickening forest that she moved her sideways and uttered “No” without even considering Steven’s question in her mind. Steven glanced at her and smiled.

“Don’t you see that this robust and magnificent structure would have been the most secure fortification in its time? It has the best of the nature’s protection all around it – a gurgling violent river blocking it from one side, thickest of forests protecting it from other and those mountain ranges offering the protection from East to West. But still it succumbed, didn’t it? I can’t think of one reason that it must have failed to prosper and grow as a kingdom. Can you, Laura?” Laura thought for a while but kept mum. Steven took it for a “no”. Such was the curiosity burning through his heart that he wanted to fly to that place, just now, but his wings were feeling heavier with every passing moment now.

His voice had a sense of disappointment in it as he said,
“We will have to go down, Laura. Can’t fly with a hippopotamus sitting on me,” he joked hoping to get Laura’s attention but no word came out of her.

“Laura?” Steven checked with Laura, as he stretched his right hand to pinch her leg which touched the sides of his right wing to startle her. Laura didn’t say a word but he did manage to get a heavy breathing out of her.

“What’s the matter, Laura?” Steven was now descending at a rapid speed because he wanted to check with Laura about what had happened. He didn’t had to wait that long as he heard laura say –

“Maybe, it was cursed by some Witch,” she paused,” a witch of Silvery circles.” Steven felt warm tears falling on his back which burnt his heart. His mind echoed with endless possibilities which hammered it and they neared the ground at an even rapid pace than before. Steven didn’t know what to say; his head threatened to explode.

Soon in a matter of seconds, they stood standing face to face under big Oak tree. The shadow of it fell on Laura in such a way that it covered half of her body. Steven moved towards her and placed his bony palm around her warm cheeks. He then, moved his right hand towards her hand, got hold of it and then squeezed her palm gently. Laura looked towards him, fighting a sad shade of red which threatened to float in her eyes. She was losing the battle against the tears, clearly. Steven wiped away a tear which was about to roll down her cheek. He said –

“Tell me Laura, what happened there, what is it?”

An even stronger sob enveloped her and shook her body like that bunch of leaves which are struck with a fierce gust of wind. She held his hand tight, as if preparing herself to say something to him, as she tried to suppress her sobs which were still overpowering her. Steven wiped away another torrent of tears flooding her cheeks, and then patted gently on her forehead before caressing it in a fatherly way.

“This Fort was of the great King Tusco,” she paused to look at Steven, “ever heard his name?” she barely managed to complete what he was saying.

Steven’s eyes narrowed at first unable to find any reference to the name in his mind but then they started to grow wider –
“Tusco Hunt?” his eyebrows curved upwards as he checked his guess with Laura, “King Tusco who ordered public execution of sixty-six practitioners of black magic some seven decades ago? That King Tusco Hunt aka ‘The Witch Hunter’?” he checked again, unable to relate this collection of facts in his mind with the current situation. Laura nodded her head and said –

“Yes, that King Tusco which history glorifies as “The Great Hunt”,” her eyes were swollen Red and they had a rage in them which Steven hadn’t seen ever before. It was if someone had wronged her and she was having trouble forgiving that person.
Steven was seemingly confused with this rage which seemed misplaced to him. He said,

“But those Black Magic practitioners were wreaking havoc all over the kingdom and the forest,” he nearly howled, “I remember getting to know about them from Goddess Lyria – the protector of Tree Souls. The trees were dying all around and so were the animals in the forest. Would you call that fair, Laura?”

When Steven turned to look towards Laura he saw her shaking with anger. She yelled –
“Forests of the Tree were a source of wood called as “chavara” – a kind of wood which turned blood red when sprinkled with the potion prepared by the black Magic Practitioners . Upon feeding it to patients who were infected with terminal diseases which had no cure back then, resulted in their magical recovery. Yes, the trees had to die but they were resulting in saved lives of people of that kingdom, Steven. Do you call that as unfair, Steven?”

Steven stood there not able to comprehend the fact that which of these stories were true – the one which he got to know from Goddess Lyria or the one which Laura had just told him. His heart said Laura but before that his mind wanted to clarify more –
“If that was the case, Laura, and the magic was saving people of the kingdom,” he took a deep breath to ensure he was not over agitated as he said it, “then why would he want something which would go against the welfare of his kingdom? He had always looked after his king- ”

“No, not his kingdom but just his back, Steven, this is all what he did,” Laura thundered as she cut his statement in half. ”He had plans to use the Black Magic for his own personal selfish gain. He had his eyes set on the realms –all Seven of them – and wanted to win over them. He knew of the might of the House’s forces but he also knew that those realms had never ever dealt with something which had the power of Satan with it, something which they couldn’t comprehend. He had plans to set three of the realms under the Black Magic’s spell and then make them fight with each other. He knew that the noble houses would stand nowhere when confronted with the blackest of magic from the Darkest of Worlds.”

Laura paused for a moment to wipe away a stray tear which had rolled down her eyes, “He always tried to push the Magicians in his kingdom, each and every noble soul of them, to meet his selfish demands. But this group of black magic practitioners had set their mind to rid this world of the taboo of Black Magic. They wanted to make their black magic the most silvery, most radiant form of magic the world had ever seen and what better way to use it for fellow humans, they thought. They worked day in day out to cure each and every person who fell ill to that incurable infectious disease but still people died with increasing frequency. It startled each and everybody person in that kingdom because there was nothing to suggest that the disease could be born in that purest of environment of the Kingdom,” she paused, as if living that time in her own mind. She continued -

“That is when leader of the Black Magicians in the kingdom insinuated King Hunto of spreading this disease himself – for hiw own selfish gains. Maddened by those accusations King Hunto ordered not only the executing the leader of the group but each and every member of that sixty-six magician clan. Next day, in front of a gathering of men and women of whom many had been treated by the sixty-six clan themselves, King Hunto executed all of them, one by one, laughing and enjoying every moment of it as he did it, ”

Laura’s voice had grown heavier as she fought back the lump building in her throat but it was proving to be near impossible now.
Steven listened intently to what all Laura had to say to him but one thing bothered him - “But why would the King do that to his own ki--“ But even before Steven could complete his question, his mind raced around to find an answer for him, ”That is because,” he said in a hushed tone, “he wanted to test the curse which he planned to inflict on the three realms. His large kingdom was his one big Guinea pig!” Steven felt little prickly hair on the back of his neck stand up upon this revelation.

He hugged Laura tightly as she sobbed against her chest. He now understood the whole plan and the glorious misjudgment historians had committed in respect to King Hunto’s credentials as a ruler. He wondered whether from now on he would be able to respect any kingdom, any person or any monument just because the history told so. As he considered the execution of the 66 Magicians who stood against the King he couldn’t help but applaud not only their bravado but also their unflinching resolve to remove the stigma related to their names and their professions. He kissed Laura on her forehead and asked her in the most hushed of voices,

“Who was that Grand Magician who stood against King Hunto and lifted the veil from his devilish plans?” Steven asked, with anticipation drenching his shaking voice. He looked at Laura whose lips quivered as she tried to gather strength to say those words -

“She was my Grand Mother,” she paused to regain breath, “She was who placed the curse on this kingdom just when the slaying sword spluttered her divine blood on the ill-deserving king and his devilish wishes.”

Steven’s heart sank and beads of liquid formed in his eyes. He didn’t know what to say. All he wanted was to hug Laura so tightly that their hearts may press and become one. And that is what he did as both of them shed tears sitting under the Grand Oak tree.

It was if this place was cursed by someone such was the eeriness it had in its spirits. The further he looked into the distance the more it he felt alone. In a way it was good because it made him forget his agony a little as he focused his mind to get out of here. And more importantly perhaps, he wanted to know what was the Wasp that almost killed him? Whose command was it following – if at all – or was it a land of monster wasps and that is why the place was barren? Could be, he considered the possibility. It was not a normal creature of course, because its every little feature right from those transparent wings to those little black eyes appeared as it had been carved by hand at first and then assemble haphazardly to resurrect a monster. Why would anybody do it and if they would do it then why would he be their target? There were so many things to consider and so many questions to answer but he had no answer yet, at this moment. All he knew was that he was alive.

“That should be good enough news, Steven, isn’t it?” he chuckled as he talked to himself, to encourage and take his mind away from it all. He stood now facing the forest as that was the only hope he had of meeting Laura. His eyes twinkled as he considered the possibility of this happening however improbable it looked.

“Would she be still waiting for me, there?” he murmured as he squinted to look towards the sun, in order to gauge the time of the day. It was half past six nearly and he had left Laura somewhere around four pm. That meant some two and a half hours had passed since he had left her. He thought whether if it was even a remote possibility of finding her there, still, because knowing Laura’s restlessness he knew that she had trouble being in the same place for long times even in normal scenarios and this was no normal scenario – not by far. She must have moved already and he was almost hundred percent sure about it but what remained to be answered was where to go searching for her and that too with this state of his wing.

“But is it that bad, anyway?” he thought to himself and hopped up towards the sky and let the fluttering of wings take over. Sadly, the wing simply couldn’t do it as his latest attempt tore up another artery of his wing and he landed to the ground with a thud. Still lying on the ground, he cursed himself for not being strong enough to take even the gentlest of loads. He knew he wasn’t right in doing it but this is all what he could do to use up the angst that had been building in him. The worst part of it was that he couldn’t use his own magic because angels are not allowed to use it for their own good. He reasoned with himself that this wasn’t for his own good and neither was he misusing it but for some reason his morals stood in between him and his magical cure. He looked around to see if he could find something which could stop the blood flow but what would he find in this land of King Barrenness.

“I will walk to you, Laura, nothing could stop me from coming to you,” he mumbled to himself as he started to walk towards the general direction of where the forest was. His legs were aching too and so was his body but he told himself that this was the time when the toughest of men survive. He would nose ahead and there were no ifs and buts regarding it. He walked with a limp towards the forest but his mind and will was still untouched. He knew that meeting Laura was not an option but a necessity. He imagined her rose like lips and those tender cheeks and was soon lost in her thoughts before he even knew. This helped him move with his mind not on pain for some distance but there was one more thing which was pulling his mind towards itself now and that was the smell of Jasmine.
His feet stopped as a fresh gust of jasmine hit him. He had sensed this smell – in fact too much of it and it almost made him go giddy - when he was flying towards the shadowy lands, too. The curious thing about the smell was for miles and miles away there was not a single speck of shrub on the ground, or in the sky for that matter, leave alone something as exquisite as Jasmine but still the smell which was filling his nostril was so strong that it felt to him that a garland of Jasmine was somewhere near him. He was looking all around with those suspicion laced eyes when out of nowhere something appeared and landed around his neck.
He jumped up in the air a little, stunned that the though in his mind had proved true – it was a garland of Jasmine which was sitting prettily around his neck. As sweet as its smell was, it appeared to Steven like a cobra and his hands jerked the garland out of his neck and threw it some distance away.

“Who is there?” Steven hollered, turning around his back searching for the one who had done this trick. “Who is it?” he exclaimed yet again when he couldn’t see a single soul in miles.

The garland lying at some distance disappeared into thin air as Steven grew even alert. But whatever alertness he had couldn’t prepare him for what happened next. The garland which had disappeared away just a while ago appeared on his neck but with one more Jasmine garland. Steven threw both of the garlands away in frustration –
“What the heck. What is this happ-“ he couldn’t say any further as he saw an outline taking form in thin air. He could tell via the large bun on the head and the curves in the body that it was a lady but what he couldn’t tell from that outline was that how beautiful she was. The lady stood there now in front of him, with the most beautiful of eyes he had ever seen – the almond shaped hazel eyes which never go wrong. As his eyes moved towards her nose and then to her lips he felt a sense of euphoria building up in his body as if it would explode him. Her chin had a little mole onto the right which accentuated her beauty even more – if that was possible. Steven stood there speechless, with petals of flower still in his hands. He was dumbstruck and didn’t know what to say apart from –

“W-who are y-you?” It didn’t feel right to say anything as it felt like disturbing the purity of the moment which was shared between them. The lady clothed in purple robe smiled – that slant smile which mystifies more than gladdens – and kept looking towards Steven. She moved even closer to Steven and only a few breaths separated them. She said –

“I am the Queen of Purple Haze,” she breathed inwards and her eyes looked at Steven intently, as if trying to say something to him.

1521112111211.title: Steven saves himself

choices: The revealing of the Blood stain
1521112111212.content:
Steven tried to flutter his wings to set sail but he couldn’t not because he was fatigued but it felt as if something had clutched them and was struggling to keep them at one place. He could see nothing but felt gentlest of hands touching his wings. He tried to break free of those hands which were trying to hold him but he was proving ineffective against those hands too. A hollowness in the soul had crept in him by now and no matter how hard he tried to shoo it away it kept coming back to him. He closed his eyes for the inevitable to happen seeing nothing but Laura’s face in his eyes. No way he could survive this fall, he thought, which was true but what was also true was that no part of his body touched the ground as he was whisked away, when he was just a feet away from the ground. The sudden jerk away from the ground led him to open his eyes as his eyes struggled to make sense of what was happening. He was dragged for some time, in a way which prevented his body to be in contact of the ground almost as if he was levitating and moving horizontally. He felt a fragrance enter his nostrils now, a perfume which reminded him of Laura.

“Is it you, Laura?” he exclaimed but instead saw a horse sized wasp taking form before him. His pace was slowing now and the wasp placed him with gentlest of motion down on the ground. Steven’s heart was still racing ahead and a shadow of darkness was enveloping his eyes. He knew that the fact that he had survived was no less than a miracle particularly with the kind of helplessness which had crept up in him during those last seconds. He looked at the wasp which was standing in front of him. The wasp’s eyes gleamed as it looked towards Steven, as if it was preening, and the wasp let out a little purr. Steven was startled by the purring sound from the wasp and obviously by the humongous size of a creature which looked something like a wasp but sized like a horse. What was this? Was it an animal sent from the heaven to look after him? He did not remember seeing an animal of this kind in heaven and neither had he heard of such a creature ever in his lifetime. It was as if somebody had made him, drawn him by hands. But who had the powers to do such a thing and more importantly what was the motive. He wasn’t even sure that wasp had saved him because he remembered the hand which had gripped him during the free fall was surely a human hand – a lady’s to be precise. He looked at the hooves of the wasp to double check his assumption. Wasp was fluttering its wing now, as if taking offense at the non-stop staring from Steven. Steven walked towards the wasp and said –

“Thank you friend,” and planted a kiss on its forehead, ”thank you for saving my life.” He caressed the wasp which reciprocated with a little neigh which almost startled Steven. The wasp had stopped its fluttering of the wings now but it sure looked intently in a direction diagonally opposite to where Steven was standing. Steven was a little surprised by wasp’s sudden head movement; it was almost as if the wasp had seen somebody standing there, it was that sudden.

“Somebody there, friend?” Steven asked only to see that Wasp was now rotating his head slowly as if it was tracing the movement of somebody. Steven grew a bit concerned and looked in the direction which wasp was staring at.

“What?” he asked again and now Wasp stood there looking not at Steven but in Steven’s direction – somebody standing behind him. Steven turned his head to find nobody.

“Well, I think you need a little break my dea-“

“Boo,” screamed a voice from behind and Steven almost fell to floor, stunned. He turned his head around to see a lady’s hand appearing out of thin air.

“You –“ and he ran towards the hands and clutched them like little kids do when they go out with their parents.

“Your observation skills are not that good for an angel, Mister,” giggled the voice.
“Hey, that’s not fair,” Steven waved his finger at the figure standing in front of him, “I asked if it was you, Laura, I guessed about you the first time I saw the –“ Steven paused , not knowing what name to call the wasp with.

“Waspey, her name is Waspey,” Laura told her smiling, as her whole body had appeared out of thin air now. She stood there with her
lovable naughty smile which made Steven go hug her.

“How did you do it, Laura?” he gasped still hugging Laura, “I could have died – No, I would have died,” he said correcting himself.

“Well,” she paused for an effect more than anything else, ”It is a long story, Steven. But first you tell me that what made you do that stupid trick you did up there in the sky?” Steven blushed a little but Laura kept rubbing it in, “You realized that I called out your name when I first saw you up there in the air but the next thing I knew was you were rushing head-wards to the beloved Mother Earth. You know that Mother Earth is not too gentle on things falling in her lap from a four hundred feet, right? What made you do it, silly?”

“Well,” Steven paused searching for words which would make him feel less stupid than he was,” let us say it was an error judgment on my part and - ”

“Of course it was, Steven,” Laura cut him through even before he could say the rest of it, “you know you would have died if Wasp had not put in the last dive towards you just some five feet away from you. We were hoping for some kind of action from you but no, Mister Steven lay still as if a dead man sleeping in his corpse,” Laura giggled. She clearly couldn’t have enough of the fun.
“Err- Hey did you see those shadows there up far when you were flying over me?” Steven tried his best to think of a topic to divert the attention from his mistake and thankfully he had plenty of topics to talk about.

“Flying over you?” Laura’s eyebrows curved downwards to question him.

“Now, come on Laura. Don’t fool me now. You have had enough fun, already, don’t you think so?” Steven smiled as he pinched

Laura’s cheeks, naughtily. Laura still stood there thinking, as if considering something.
Steven laughed – “So you are saying you were not there, Laura? Now, come on I saw the outline of the horse sized wasp – I mean Waspey – too,” he was a little embarrassed having said that but he continued when he saw no difference in reaction from Laura, ”I saw it across the fog, clearly, Laura don’t kid me anymore, now.” Steven said the last line more in hope than out of any real conviction.

“Steven,” Laura’s voice had a seriousness which wasn’t seen until that moment, ”we saw you when you were some forty feet away from the ground and not before that. In fact, we had just reached here, crossing the purplish haze which came in the path of ours. We tore through it, miles and miles of it and that is when we saw you, some forty feet away from the ground,” she kept looking at
Steven as he mind worked overtime to solve the mystery behind it.

“What?” Steven exclaimed, “so what was that thing which jumped towards me some four hundred feet up in the sky?” Laura shrugged her shoulder, kept silent for a while and asked –

“Are you sure that your mind didn’t imagine it all, Steven? Are you sure of that thing?” Laura’s ears wanted to hear unsure answer but she got none of it as Steven emphatically defended what he had seen floating in mid-air –

“Now come on Laura,” he exclaimed, “Do we see a wasp this big in size every day?” he said pointing towards Waspey, “That shadow was so clear, dear, I couldn’t forget it. Those hooves, those wings, that streak of blood,” he paused for a moment to search for the blood stain on Waspey and he couldn’t see it. He turned towards Laura –

“Wait, does she have a blood stain, somewhere on her body? Anywhere and – oh my, I remember that the figure I saw in the air had 12 horns too and Waspey sure doesn’t have it. What was that then?”
Laura looked more disturbed than confused to him. She looked a bit rattled.

“What’s the matter honey?” Steven asked as he placed an arm on her shoulder, “don’t worry we will find that thing, whatever it was and then –“

“I know what that “thing” was, Steven,” she looked towards Steven with a hint of fear floating in those eyes. Steven looked at her with his eyebrows curved upwards.

152111211123.content:
Steven had been away for little over 15 minutes but Laura felt years pass by her. She need not worry about him yet, and she knew that, but there was something in her mind which kept telling her that it wasn’t going to be that easy. Her legs were shaking from the nervousness which was gripping her body. A thin veil of sweat was starting to cover her face. She was getting restless and she was sensing it building since some 10 minutes ago. The rustle of the leaves wasn’t helping her either and she felt as if somebody was watching her; she literally could feel eyes on herself. She took a deep long breath to calm herself down and pushed back her head, as if to inhale the calmness from the sky. She felt a little better and she did it again. She thought that is she could be at this place for another half an hour or so then it was a reasonable chance that Steven would return by then. But what to do of her restlessness was her only question? She looked around a neat enough area, somewhere where grass covering was sprouting over the dust so that she could probably sit down and relax. Some ten steps away to her left she saw a lush covering of grass on a raised little mound. The mound was not unnatural and she had seen many of such throughout the forests. So there was nothing to think twice about resting there.

She walked towards it with thought of Steven still making a passing by in her mind and plopped down on the grass which didn’t feel any less than the leather sofas she had used in those homes of affluent people; only that it the current seat of hers was more cushy perhaps. She closed her eyes to feel the wind caressing her face, to hear what the wind sang in her ears and stretched her legs. There was a cocoon of calmness which she felt to be passing into with every passing second. It was so peaceful, full of bliss and not a single thought on her mind. She was now lying down on the ground, stretching out and yawned. Her eyes felt heavier and the breaths normal. She was now drifting into the dreams – not necessarily a bad thing considering the restlessness she was feeling a little while earlier. She had no thoughts yet but that was more because of her control over them; it wasn’t natural yet. But slowly as the subconscious mind of hers took over, she began to drift into the past. Thoughts were now sneaking into her serene mind as she slept peacefully. What a journey this had been, she reminisced in her sleep with images of the curious light fellows which lightened their path on the first night together! Then she thought about those Dragons she and Steven had encountered and the chase for the egg that had ensued. She had a smile on her face in her sleep. The next in line was this forest itself, thickest of them all by far which they almost stumbled into. She remembered Steven’s reaction when she had told him that they would have to go through this forest in order to reach their destination. Another smile sat on her lips as she relived it in her subconscious mind. Then, there was the turning point – hopefully the last of this trip – when they both revealed their darkest of secrets to each other; well, hers was way darker than his, at least. She relived the heart ache she felt at that moment and it almost broke her sleep. Surprises after surprises, revelation after revelation and nothing to prepare them for them! What more lay their way on their path to the ultimate glory, her mind was now taking full control. And what made her mind show her next in her deep sleep is what brought back the restlessness she had felt some thirty minutes before.

In her mind, she saw the scene when Steven flew to do a quick recce of the place. She saw those beautiful wings of his, his angel face, those daggers in her heart which she felt as he flew away. She then saw herself, looking skywards admiring his flight to the sky, exactly how she had done just minutes back. The mind didn’t stop at it though, it then showed her Steven’s path of flight. She saw what Steven saw- that tree cover all around him which he saw as he rose up, those expressions in his face when he saw the shadow for the first time – what was that? Her mind questioned itself in her sleep - and then she saw the fog which started to build out of nowhere, enveloping Steven and clouding his mind. She also felt the tiredness of Stevens as he tried to almost will his way through the forest – those droopy eyes of his, those aching muscles in his rib and the heaviness in his wings, she felt it all. And then, she experienced that free fall of Steven, falling towards the ground, almost conscious. Forty feet to ground, thirty feet to ground, twenty feet and then before she could see anything more, she heard a scream. It was a scream of her own and it sprang her up from her deep sleep, with her hand covering her face in pure horror. Her eyes searched for Steven all around but he was nowhere to be seen.

“He should have returned by now, shouldn’t he?” she murmured, “Could it be that this nightmare was true?” she was almost in tears as she said that, a lump already forming in her throat. A fresh nervousness was now taking her in its arms. She was sweating profusely, just like she was when she was feeling that panic attack sometime before she went to sleep. Her eyes were watery and her breath haphazard. Her stomach had so much churning going on it that she could feel it in her brain, buzzing and ringing like an alarm of some sort. She jerked her head, as if trying to push the thought away from her mind but it only made it come with even more vengeance. She saw Steven crashing to the ground and a beast sitting on top of him, just before Steven crashed.

“Nooo,” she wailed as she sprang to her feet, “I am coming Steven, I am coming for you.”

She wasn't to going stand there and do nothing. She wasn't going to lose anyone else. She had already lost so many people already in her life even though no one knew, not even Steven. He was the only closest person to her alive and safe and she didn't want to lost him at any condition. Especially not waiting for his death, she would have to do something, something that will save him.

The beast pounded on Steven's chest and continued to hit him as both of them fell down. the sight was dreading, Steven had bruises all over him and his shirt was torn, she watched his shirt fly away with the wind - it was bloody.

She yelled to the top of her lungs as a strong force caused her to fly into the hair with the speed of light and there she was, in the horizon watching everywhere where the two of them had. Her eyes turned a shade of red as her hair colour changed to golden and her appearance changed, her clothes warrior-like. She had two golden bracelets on her wrists which sparkled. She didn't care for anything, her eyes scanned the area as they landed on the beast and Steven, his Steven.

She ran towards Steven who was not moving, she held his head as she caressed his face with her other hand. She felt his pulse, thank God he was still alive.

"L-laura? I-is it you? Y-you look so different. . . " He spoke with a lot of difficulty. He couldn't believe if what he saw was correct, he recognised her by her sound, it was Laura, when he saw her, she was a beauty, she was already beautiful before but she looked even more exquisite, unique.

"Shh," She put a finger on his lips and held him tightly, "It's me, you will be fine. Just rest, okay?" And Steven surrounded himself to the darkness.

15211121112311.content:
Laura was particularly chuffed that she had protected Steven but was also concerned for his health. He had been displaying symptoms of Larara Disease, the disease in which the patient suffers from the post-trauma symptoms of black magic. When a mortal sees a black magic for the first time his or her senses are not strong enough to comprehend it , to make sense out of it or to make peace with it and all what happens then is a struggle of senses , of logic over feel which is not a pleasant feel for the inflicted. Steven didn’t say it, not one bit about the black magic, but it was his eyes which told his story, as with all patients of Larara. His one eye pupil had changed color to red while the other pupil was yellowish in color with some of part turned to red. She knew that as soon as those both pupil turned to red Steven was going to lose it and he would be nothing less than breathing corpse. The stress could last for hours sometimes weeks even and she didn’t want to lose Steven at this juncture of the trip.
She looked at the nearly unconscious Steven and stroked his hair. Steven had now closed his eyes, almost as if he had found peace with that first touch of Laura. He lay there in a world conjured by his mind, where black magic was wrecking havoc all over the kingdom. He would see flashes of the monstrous minotaur which Laura had just defeated, but the one in dream would just not be defeated. He was destroying buildings after buildings, killing people after people and destroying cities. Even as the minotaur did it, he would look into Steven’s mind’s eye and tell him that he was coming for him. And that thing was causing the constant shivering of Steven’s body. The worse part was that his mind was only accentuating the worst of things, the Minotaur, the destruction, the killing but it showed no traces of Laura to her. If it would have then maybe – just maybe – the brain would have co-related the dream with the real life events and caused a closure but that wasn’t happening – by a long distance no. And that was the one of the major symptoms of the Larara disease.

Laura looked at Steven who had sweat accumulated on his face, with his body shivering. He would also murmur something every now and then, something inaudible on the lines of “He is coming for me. He will kill us all.” A tear ran down Laura’s eyes. She stooped to Steven and planted a kiss on his cheek. Steven’s body shuddered as his mind had made out this kiss to be a kick to his face by Minotaur. The more you loved him, the more the patient went deeper into the disease and that was the problem which Laura was faced with. How could she not show love to him, or care for him when all she had was him. If had not been Laura and some other person who didn’t knew black magic then probably Steven would not have reacted negatively but since she herself was a source of the black magic which had inflicted this disease on him, the body kind of insulated itself from any further influence of the black magic practitioner. And this was body’s way for self-defense – to not react to any emotions from Black Magic Practitioner.

It was a good thing that Laura’s grandmother had taught her all of this – not so much as taught as in instilled in her. She remembered seeing this all as a kid when hordes of people would come to her house, in hope of the black magic to cure them of the diseases which had no cure. Her Granny never used magic for the benefit of herself but always for benefit of others. She knew that this was the only way to get rid of this stigma associated with Black Magic. After all, black magic was never meant to be used for ghastly purposes. It was always meant to do something which no other form of magic could and this was its specialty. A thing or person under the influence of black magic could never have an influence of any other kind of magic on him. Nothing erases the effect of black magic and this is what led some Magicians to explore the dark sides of the magic. They knew that since nobody practiced it and probably nobody would be able to gauge symptoms of it, they would be in good demand from the men in highest of authorities. Kings of Realms, Ministers in high hierarchy these were the kind of people who would avail their services and in return for their services they would ask for kingdoms or a part of it. The greed had gone into their heads and that is what gradually led to the stigmatization of Black magic.

Laura looked at Steven and thought in her mind,” I could do nothing else to save you, Steven,: she bowed her head
with a torrent of tears flooding her eyes,” I knew this was coming but in this circumstance there was nothing which I could have done differently to save you. I am sorry,” she sobbed, “I am so very sorry.” She raised her hand to put on Steven’s forehead but remembered that her love and affection would only make it worse. She placed her palms around her face and sobbed in them till her tear glands went barren. Steven was still lying still on the ground, nothing on his face to suggest whether he was alive or dead. She was on her knees now, bending even more to say something in Steven’s ears and she said -

“Nothing happened, Steven,” she said in a tone carefully devoid of any emotion or traces of love or care, ”it was just a bad bad dream,” she figured out that this way she might be able to trick his mind into believing what was good for him. She was trying to reverse what he had just seen. This seemed to be the only try which Laura had at treating him. Steven’s body showed no change because his Larara inflicted mind totally ignored the incoming words from Laura, not because it were from Laura, but because his senses were all engaged in eking out the most horrific scenes possible in his mind.

But Laura was no ordinary human as she knew how and when to place things. She closed her eyes to call in the powers of the other world for her help. At first all she could see was Minotaur and him charging towards her but soon, in a matter of seconds her mind was blank as a black canvas appeared in her mind’s eye. She told her mind to then find the most effective cure for Steven, something which didn’t involve anything exotic for she knew that she wont be able to find it in here in this place. Nothing was painted on the canvas for a little while, just the blackness of it – so black that it seemed to be staring at you with hundred eyes – but then slowly, something started to take form as a silvery streak illuminated the black canvas. At first, it appeared to be a random zigzag strokes of silver sprayed here and there for effect but then, slowly it started to make sense to her. She saw a water reservoir – a lake perhaps- with doves and ducks hovering around it. She saw some deer, hiding behind the trees as if in anticipation of something , something big to happen. The butterflies of hundreds of color circled the lake, played with the flowers and the animals alike.

In near distance – too near in fact – the rainbow stood there emerging right out of the Lake’s belly and going towards the Horizon. It was as beautiful a scene she had ever seen and her eyes couldn’t just have enough of it but the problem was that she didn’t know if such a place existed in this forest. She opened her eyes and tried to make sense of the direction. She remembered that in flashes of image she just saw, she didn’t see the sun and she needed the sun to find the direction. But hey, she saw the rainbow, didn’t she and if a rainbow is there this means that the Sun was right behind it. Her goosebumps moment was even more pronounced because at the same time as she made this revelation she also figured out a way to cure Steven, after all. The rainbow was in South west direction and she decided to move in that direction. She got hold of a wooden log lying some place near her, enchanted it with a mantra and then touched it to her body and lo – she was flying in the sky, through the thick forests as lightly as a soul would. She hadn’t brought Steven’s body because she knew his body wasn’t needed to be cured but it was his soul which must be. Steven’s soul said nothing but smiled as they glided up and over the forest cover. She knew that the lake would be soon upon them as she could hear the quacking of the ducks from afar and along with it she could see the beautiful white doves, flying with their wings wide open as if painted across the blue sky, crossing their paths.
She looked at Steven’s soul and smiled . As they gently lowered to the lake, she realized that the place which she was now seeing was even beautiful which the mind’s eye showed her.. The pleasant noise of the inhabitants of that lake intermingled with the nature and produced a sound so soothing that her little stressed soul was immediately at peace. As they stood towards the lake in all its wonder, she thought of what she would do next to cure Steven’s soul. She sat down on the grass by the lake and so did Steven’s soul as they looked towards the lake which gleamed. Emotion ran through her, wanting to hug him but she was careful to not do it since it could have affected the spirit adversely. 152112.content:
Laura knew Steve was gawping at her, probably wondering just who she really was. She swallowed, did her best to keep her gaze on the yawning entrance, seeing patterns in the moss and ivy that covered the walls. A memory was hidden around a dark corner in her mind; whenever she tried to grab it it slithered back into a darker corner. With all her being she knew the memory was going to split her and Steve up, but she also knew it would be the key to them getting through this monsterish-maze.

If only Steve wasn't staring at her like she was something to be wary about. Even if she was, maybe, possibly.... She drew in a deep breath and turned to Steve.

'We need to enter this maze, Steve,' Laura said, 'but I think our best option is to spend the night outside. You look exhausted and I'm sure I'll drop into a deep sleep the moment I close my eyes. We need to be on top form when we cross the threshold.'

Laura pointed at the ground and Steve noticed a huge piece of stone planted there, spanning at least ten foot. Grey, just like the of the walls, and clean but for one thing. Was that a footprint? He edged closer. 'Someone's been here,' he got out, surprised and wary. They hadn't been chased through the forest but... obviously someone was about.

'Steve, please... come back from there,' Laura said. 'I told you I sense something wrong, I told you the monster sucks souls. I know it does. Don't cross that threshold, don't even get close.'

'How do you know all this?' Steve asked. He did step back from the threshold and the footprint, spine tingling for a second as if he was being watched.

Laura hunched her shoulders, hugged herself. She shook her head.

''Whatever you know, you have to tell me!' Steve said. 'Whatever secret you're keeping, if it's about getting us through this maze, you have to reveal it. I have the most horrible feeling our lives are at stake!'

Of course they are, Laura thought. It's a monster's maze. She refrained from reminding Steve that. He was wound up. No need to make him worse. She was going to need him as much as he needed her. ‘Come,’ she said. ‘We might as well make ourselves comfortable. I’ll try to tell you things, Steve, but it’s all blocked in my mind. Maybe just sitting here will help.’ She moved a bit further from the entrance, where the pull to go inside wasn’t as strong.

Fortunately Steve came with her and sat down, leaning against the wall that prevented them from returning to the forest. ‘I know I’m nagging,’ he murmured, touching Laura’s hand briefly, ‘but… god Laura, I’m not the hero you think I am!’

At her brows shooting up, Steve felt a flush rise on his face. About the first warmth he’d felt all evening! ‘I don’t know what I’m doing half the time, I keep thinking about that darkness thing the man told me, and now this!’ He waved a hand down to the entrance. ‘And this.’ He tapped the wall behind him. He pulled a face and sighed. ‘You’re right, we should rest. We’ll both be better for it.’

Laura pecked his cheek. ‘You’re always a hero, Steve.’ Which was why she was a little worried about revealing her secrets. Heroes had certain morals and ethics, and she wasn’t sure her secret would stand in concert with them!! As much as she wanted to rest, she was going to have to dig for that memory, and reveal some of it – the bits that would still portray her as ‘normal’ to Steve. And, she thought, I need to take his mind off things for a while. As she shrugged off the knapsack, she said, ‘How about you try to get a fire started?’

There were bits of wood around, broken from the trees in the forest, somehow left this side of the wall. Wasn’t lighting fires something men loved doing?

‘Yeah, okay,’ Steve said, glancing around. ‘But I want to talk, Laura.’

Laura nodded. ‘When we’re warm and have full stomachs,’ she said. Well, maybe full stomachs… the knapsack was depressingly light in the food department. Pickled pork in greaseproof paper, some wizened mushrooms and a small block of cheese. Why had they not thought to stock up?

While Laura prepared the ‘meal’, Steve scavenged for wood and detritus and put together a decent pile. It wouldn’t burn through the night but it would help stave off the chill for a while.

The pair of them watched the flames, reds and oranges leaping about in the small breezes that would come and go. It provided some warmth and as twilight gave way to deep blue and then black, the fire became their little beacon of hope. Steve glanced up once, but the sky was without stars. Not cloudy… just without stars, as if the darkness had suffocated them.

Steve drew in a breath, tried to block what else the man had told him about the darkness. He turned to Laura, as she shifted slightly to lean her head on his shoulder, and opened his mouth.

Before he could speak, however, he heard an odd snuffling sound. A footfall? A rodent? The Monster????? ‘What’s that?’ he whispered.

‘What’s what?’

‘That noise, like something’s coming.’

‘I heard nothing,’ Laura said. ‘It’s just your imagination, Steve. Nothing’s here but us.’

‘What about what’s in the maze?’

‘It won’t come out here.’

‘How are you so sure?’

‘Well, why would it? Its power is in the maze, not outside it.’

Steve frowned. As good as that logic sounded, he didn’t like it. ‘Laura, what secret are you hiding from me?’

1521121.content:
Before Laura could answer ('I'm not hiding secrets' was her immediate gut reaction) a dragging, stepping sound came from their left. Loud enough that even she heard it, and couldn't deny that she had.

'See?' Steve hissed, rising onto his knees.

'It's probably just a rat,' Laura murmured, even if she didn't believe it. The sounds were definite steps and not hesitant, not like a rat who would be sniffing around, trying to decide if it should come closer or not. She looked at Steve; he knelt like stone in front of her as he listened. 'Steve?' she whispered.

When he turned to look at her the snapping flames made him seem mechanical and made his dark brown eyes black and glassy. She caught her breath but then he swallowed and blinked.

'Get behind me,' he said softly, rising and pulling the dagger from his boot. They were woefully under-armed for any sort of encounter, woefully unprepared in general. But then he'd never expected to come across a labyrinth with a monster and a wall springing up out of nowhere to prevent their retreat.

Steve shifted in front of the small fire, closed his eyes briefly so as to better get used to the dark that now stretched out in front of him. He didn't look to see if Laura had moved but then she said, 'should I put out the fire?'

'No,' he rasped with a shake of his head. 'If whatever it is has to look into the light, that's to our benefit. But, Laura, try not to stare into it yourself, alright?'

Laura mumbled an agreement to that, and shifted to the other side if the alley space so that the fire was more to her side than in front of her. She crouched to the ground; in her dark greens and browns she might be hard to see there and could act as an element of surprise to help Steve.

Once she'd fallen still, silence settled. Steve was standing, left foot slightly forward, dagger loose in his right fist. She'd seen him in this stance many times; he looked totally relaxed and uninterested but he could let that dagger go in an eye blink.

After maybe two minutes they heard the sound again, steps. Slow but unhesitating. Whatever was coming meant to come, whether it had heard them or not. Surely they had the advantage, having been round a slightly curve in the alley. The thing would not know there were two of them unless it had heard them talking earlier, and both Steve and Laura had kept their voices low.

Steve flexed his fingers around the dagger's hilt. His heart was leaping about and he drew in a steady breath to try and calm it. Despite his fears about the darkness and the monster in the labyrinth he felt mostly calm. He'd faced enemies before - human and otherwise. Better prepared, usually, but shortened odds did bring out the best in him.

The steps stopped just beyond the curve and then started forward again, and a large yet low shadow slid around the curve with a shuffle. Steve took a step sideways in an attempt to let the fire shed some light, and he blew out a breath at what he saw. 'It's a rat!'

Not ten feet from him, crouched now against the wall was a rat. A large one, maybe not even a rat but some other giant rodent, its fur hanging in dreds down to the ground. Steve shot a glance at Laura and prepared to laugh. Then the rat fixed him with its beady black eyes and said, 'don't insult me, I'm a mongoose.'

Steve choked on a swallow and Laura squeaked out a half-voiced scream. She scuttled back across the alley to the fire and their knapsack, now positioned behind Steve. She didn't mind rodents but talking ones were not something she was used to.

'And unless you give me some respect - such as putting away that knife - you're not going to make it out of this night alive.'

'Excuse me?' Steve demanded, raising the dagger.

'You don't act like a man who is deaf,' the mongoose grumbled. 'Oh blast it, if I must I must.'

Steve glanced back at Laura, totally bamboozled. She held one handover her mouth, pointed with the other. Steve turned back, and swore.

In front of him the mongoose was distorting with growth, sprouting longer limbs, while the dreds were shrinking and lengthening in random order. In a half minute, where the mongoose had crouched, a young man now crouched. 'You better give me some clothes.'

Steve probably would have just stared all night, even if he was used to weird stuff. A rodent-come-man wasn't something he'd seen a lot of!

'Come on,' the man said. 'I can't be of help if I freeze to death.'

'Here,' Laura said and Steve wasn't quick enough to stop her stepping passed and holding out a cloak. 'We don't have much,' she said.

The man took the cloak, mumbled a barely-there 'thank you' and slung the cloak around his shoulders. Once decent, he rose on two perfectly human feet and both Steve and Laura were somewhat surprised that the man was about Steve's height and only young. Maybe twenty?

'How about an explanation,' Steve said, 'before you take one step further.' He jabbed the dagger outward.

'How about you let me come closer to that pathetic excuse for a fire and warm my bones first?'

As Steve was opening his mouth to condemn the newcomer to his foulest words, Laura touched his arm. 'He's shivering,' she said, 'let him come closer.'

Steve grimaced. Laura was a soft touch often, but right now?? Then again, she had secrets... what if she and this mongoose man knew each other? Not that they'd shown any recognition. Steve rubbed his brow and shifted away from the fire, pulling Laura with him. He waved the man forward with his dagger wielding hand. 'Be our guest.'

The man didn't respond to the tone, just moved forward and then sank to his knees. He held his hands out to the flame and closed his eyes. Next thing, the fire was worthy of being called a fire - three times as large and giving off heat that Steve and Laura could feel even from their distance.

'What...' Steve began.

'Have you got any food?' the man asked. 'I wasn't able to find anything once the wall sprung up. I'm starving.'

'We're pretty low,' Laura admitted. 'Let me see though.'

'Laura...'

'Steve,' she responded in a tight tone. 'Just come and take a seat. Let our guest make himself comfortable before making him explain.'

The man smiled at Steve, which Steve read as she's got you whipped! and scowled. He did crouch at the fire side, though, and when he felt the warmth running through his body he even set the dagger on the ground by his knee. 'What's your name?' he asked.

'Darius,' the young man answered easily enough and thanked Laura for the pieces of meat and cheese she held out.

'Why do you sneak about as a rodent?' Steve asked.

'A mongoose is not a rodent,' Darius said stiffly around a mouthful of cheese.

'Then why do you sneak about as a mongoose?'

'I was hardly sneaking,' came another stiff answer. 'I was trying to find the end of this damn alley. The wall is too smooth for me to climb.' He pointed up at the stone at Laura and Steve's back.

'Why don't you move about in your human form?' Laura this time, curious.

'Because I can run faster the other way,' Darius responded wryly.

'Alright,' Steve growled, 'enough with the riddles. You look like a twenty-year-old kid in need of a bath and a barber, wearing just a cloak. Yet you reckon we won't survive the night without you. Start explaining before my patience wears out.'

'I said you wouldn't if you didn't show me respect,' Darius corrected mildly. 'But your interpretation is true too,' he added quickly, when Steve moved a hand toward the dagger. He took another bite of the cheese then rearranged the cloaked so it covered his crossed legs.
