'I was out hunting,' Darius said as an opening line of explanation.

Steve and Laura looked at each other, trying not to grimace. Mongooses were carnivorous animals.

'But I didn't find much; there's a darkness in the air tonight,' Darius said. 'Did you see there were no stars?' He looked upward, and the other two did the same.

Just the same expansive black that Steve had noted earlier. He wasn't sure if he liked the mongoose feeling the darkness like he did. 'What do you mean, a darkness?' he asked, to see what the young man would say.

'Evil,' Darius said, voice low. He leaned toward the fire, holding his hands out. 'Like life is being sucked out. I felt it more in my other state than this one but animals are more attuned. In any case,' he added after a short moment, 'there wasn't much to hunt. I came back to the labyrinth to check some of my traps, but nothing there either.'

'Traps?' Laura asked.

'Not for eating as a mongoose,' Darius said. 'But as a human. Rats, mostly, things I can roast.'

Steve squinted at the young man, unsure he was keeping up with this tale. 'Riddles,' he murmured just to put it out there.

'Yes, probably,' Darius agreed quite calmly. 'But that's how it was - I can think as a human even while I'm a mongoose. I was in fact human when I was checking the traps, but I changed when the wall sprung up. Easier to run, as I said. Easier to hide too, normally.'

Steve rubbed a hand over the blade still sitting on the ground, not in a threatening gesture, but for some sort of comfort for himself.

'Go on,' Laura said gently when the young man looked like he might stay silent.

'It's as I said,' he continued. 'I started along the wall in order to get out of this alley; it can't go forever.'

'Why not?'

'Why not?' the young man asked Steve.

Steve looked at Laura. 'How big did you say this maze was?'

She looked surprised a second. 'I don't... think I did,' she said. 'But... look at those walls; they're massive. Why are you asking?'

'If the maze is big, then the wall is probably just as big, surrounding the thing, don't you think?' Steve actually wasn't sure where he was going with this, was probably trying to make sense of it by thinking of the wall as finite.

He was aware of Laura and Darius looking at him, and shrugged. 'If you were trying to get out, I presume you're not from around here?'

'I'm not,' Darius said.

'But you hunt in the forest.'

'Yes,' Darius said, with a shrug. 'What of it?'

'You hunt around this labyrinth too.'

'Yes,' the young man replied again. 'So?'

'Isn't that dangerous?' Steve asked, picking up the knife. 'How do we know you're not from inside the labyrinth?'

'Well, I guess you don't,' Darius said. 'But if I lived in the labyrinth do you think I'd choose the form of a mongoose?'

'He makes a good point,' Laura murmured softly.

'How do I know what you'd choose?' Steve said. 'Monsters can take any form. You threatened us earlier, you came from the direction of the entrance.' He turned the blade over in his hand. He should have had the newcomer shoved against the wall the moment he'd turned human!!

Darius sighed. 'I don't come from the labyrinth, but I take this form because of it. Because of a curse.'

Laura sucked in her lips.

'My father and a raiding party went in one winter's day to try and learn the maze's secret. There's gold rumoured to be inside, did you know?' Darius cocked his head. 'My family wasn't rich, most of the town folk weren't. One night they'd had too much ale and went on a mission.' Darius swallowed hard. 'They lost three men and for the price of the rest of their lives they lost their sons.'

'Sons?' Laura asked.

Darius nodded. 'I don't mean dead. Well, not real dead, but this...' He waved a hand at himself. 'Turned us into various animals and because we could change at will we considered "touched" and cast out. We might as well have been dead to them.'

He drew in a breath. Laura sympathised but she could see Steve arching his brow and barely believing anything. The tale was odd, but she had heard of things like this happening.

'All that aside,' Steve said, 'you threatened us - that we wouldn't last the night. Why should we believe you won't try something?'

'That was nothing,' Darius mumbled. 'I've learned to go on the offence first. You didn't know what I might be able to do, I hoped to buy some time.'

'You still don't know what we might do,' Steve pointed out. 'And what was that whole "if I must I must" babble?'

'Well, once I'd spoken, would you have stayed calm if I'd stayed a mongoose?' Darius demanded. 'I doubt it. At times like this' - he waved around the alley - 'I prefer the other form. It feels safer.' He didn't need to say that he was better 'armed' and 'clothed' as a mongoose. He hadn't really been planning to turn human, not tonight with this darkness, not without preparation. He regretted leaving his little hut at all!

'So you won't try to kill us?' Steve said, skeptically.

'Not while you're the one with the knife,' Darius responded. 'Look, this is odd, yes. Say what you like, I've heard it all before. But I mean no harm now. I just want to get out of this place.'

Steve opened his mouth, and Laura squeezed his arm. 'You're welcome to stay here with us, make use of the fire to warm yourself,' she said. 'Thank you, by the way, for... increasing it.'

Darius gave a funny smile. 'One of my skills now,' he said. 'Fire. I'd rather I could conjour up clothes.' He tugged the cloak tighter around himself.

'Well, we're grateful for the fire,' Laura said. 'Hopefully it'll keep up through the night.'

Darius nodded. 'I won't harm you,' he said softly. 'I don't run with the monster in the labyrinth.'

'Is that what people thought when they first realised you could change?' Laura asked.

'No,' Darius said. 'They just thought we were cursed.'

'And there are more of you?'

He nodded but didn't say how many.

'Are they all mongooses?' Steve asked.

Laura frowned but he was curious.

'Some,' Darius said and again didn't explain.

Steve geared up to pester for proper answers but Laura was giving him a considered look that told him to stop upsetting the young man. She nodded at the fire and he realised that it had been bobbing high and low and low and high through the conversation as if he flared at the man's moods. It was low now and, to be honest, they couldn't afford to lose the fire (or the heat). 'Sorry,' Steve mumbled. 'It's just... I'm probably at my day's quota for strange things. If I'm being rude, I apologise.'

Darius shrugged. 'I've faced worse,' he said.

The fire dipped and then flared. Steve had plenty of questions and he wanted answers but he also just wanted to suck up the heat from the and pretend he was sitting near the hearth at home. Just for a few hours, anyway. God, this day had been WEIRD, and he realised suddenly Laura hadn't revealed her secret. Well, he was too tired now.

If the young man turned on them in the night, even after the promise that he wouldn't, well, dying would at least end the weirdness. Steve shook his head. He may not have been a hero as much as he wanted, but he wasn't a quitter. He'd fight. Now he just groaned. And then he said, 'Laura, I think I've an extra pair of pants in the bag. Give them to Darius, will you?'

Laura blinked, making him grimace, but scrabbled through the bag and did come up with a pair of pants. True surprise flashed across the youngster's face and they heard a stuttered 'thank you.' He rose and turned his back on them, quickly pulling on the pants.

Laura treated Steve to a brilliant smile. He just grimaced again. It wasn't all chivalry; he didn't want to catch any sight of nudity!

The young man returned to his place by the fire. 'I have good hearing,' he said, 'in this form and the other. If something approaches from either direction, I'll know.'

Steve gave a stiff nod, and wondered if the man had heard their conversation. That would be something they'd have a chat about in the morning.

15211211.title: The mongoose is good...

choices: Steve, Laura AND Darius go into the labyrinth
Steve, Laura AND Darius go down the alley
152112111.content:
The night passed without incident.

Steve knew this because he didn't really sleep a wink. There were several reasons for being awake:

1. He couldn't get comfortable no matter which way he lay, and he preferred to be on his side facing the odd-ball stranger. His stiff leather belt dug into his flesh, and the rough ground seemed to carry stones no matter much he moved about. The arm he was using for a pillow went numb very early, causing him to shift about to find a new position. (He was surprised he didn't wake Laura with all the maneuvering about.)

2. He did not really trust the stranger. Laura seemed to take the mongoose's story to heart and Steve had to admit it had sounded authentic, and the man could clearly transform. But.. to be able to sleep in the presence of a man who could transform and who remained mostly a stranger was not an ability Steve had. He didn't want it either. He had to remain wary.

3. He was worried about Laura. She'd managed to get away with not spilling what she knew about the monster and the labyrinth, or what was bothering her. She seemed to have calmed down quite a bit during the evening, but who knew what was going on in her head right now? Steve wasn't bothered so much about his safety around her but her own safety.

4. He didn't want to dream. For a couple of nights now he'd had at least one nightmare about an all-consuming darkness, and having no stars overhead unsettled him. Hearing Darius mention the darkness didn't ease his concerns at all. (Though he had to admit that he was kind of grateful the mongoose had spoken about it; it meant that he himself wasn't crazy.)


So, as dawn lightened the sky in the east from black to dark grey to light grey, and clouds were pinking up overhead with the as-yet-unseen sun, Steve rose on stiffened pins and shook himself out. God, if they were going to enter the labyrinth today he wasn't going to be in great heroic form. He rolled his shoulders, wincing at the creaking, cracking sounds. His stomach rumbled awake and he rubbed it, thinking that they might have used the remainder of their food last night. He narrowed his eyes at the sleeping (still human) form of the young stranger. He'd scoffed his fair share too!

Steve thought on the traps the man had mentioned, and took a couple of steps to put him on the turn of the alley. He couldn't see anything that looked like a trap and didn't remember anything from yesterday. Dawn had this area still cloaked in dim grey light so perhaps things were just not visible yet. In fact the only thing that stood out from the universal greyness was the entry to the labyrinth. It had a dark colour all of its own and Steve had the sudden thought that even in the pitch black of night, he'd have been able to see that entrance.

His skin crawled, and he back-stepped out of view.

As he returned to the makeshift campsite and the two sleeping forms, he kicked a stone at the wall. The ricochet was loud enough to make Laura and Darius start but not leap up.

Laura mumbled something, clearly not 100% awake, but Darius stretched an arm out from under the tightly wrapped cloak and suddenly the fire was pumping again.

As much as Steve didn't trust and didn't like the young man, he was grateful for the fire. He'd been cold in the night whenever the wind had shunted down the alley. He knelt down beside Laura, giving her a little bit of a shake, even though his gaze stayed on Darius.

The young man looked thin and pale, even with the golden flames flicking in front of his face.

'Does keeping this fire up sap strength?' Steve heard himself croak out. He swallowed back the frog, and rustled in the knapsack for one of the canteens. Finding it, he took a couple of swigs and then held it out to Darius.

Darius blinked, looked as if he wasn't sure what the thing was, but then he got himself up on an elbow and took the canteen. He swallowed deep, then recapped it and handed it back. 'Thank you,' he said quietly, 'and no, it doesn't sap my strength. Or at least it hasn't before.'

'You look pretty poorly.'

Darius grimaced. 'I've been out hunting three days,' he murmured. 'Barely found anything to eat, even in my other form. And when there's nothing for even a mongoose to eat then something is up.'

'Up?' Steve said carefully.

'I think you know what I mean,' Darius said, sitting himself cross-legged as close to the fire as he could. 'You know what I mean about the darkness, don't you?'

Steve nodded. 'I've heard stories. Thought they were legends.'

Darius shook his head, then inclined it. 'Well, legend maybe, but something real too.'

'Has it got anything to do with the monster?' Steve thumbed over his shoulder toward the labyrinth's entrance.

'I don't know.'

'But you know what the monster is?'

'No,' Darius said. 'I don't. I haven't seen it. And those who came back from that terrible mission would never say. They just looked haunted. When my friends and I turned we didn't have much warning; it wasn't until after it happened that we got told about the bargain.'

'Your fathers made a bargain?' Steve felt stunned.

'To save lives,' Darius said quietly, gaze on the orange flames.

Steve sucked at his teeth but before he could question any further, Laura squeezed his knee. She didn't speak but when he looked down at her he saw the stop grilling him expression. Steve pulled a face. 'How'd you sleep?'

'Like a log.'

'Really?' Steve blurted.

Laura managed a half shake and then rolled over and sat up. She smoothed down her hair, glancing at Darius and offering a quiet 'good morning.'

He answered back, smiled, then returned to his own thoughts.

Laura and Steve looked at each other, then Steve said, 'we have a choice to make.'

Laura arched a brow.

'Do we go into the labyrinth or do we continue down this alley to find the end, all the while hoping this wall somehow disappears.'

Laura sucked in her breath. Darius lifted his head, watching them.

152112111.title: The night passed without incident.

choices: They go into the labyrinth, Darius included
1521121113.content:
Laura held her breath a moment, fighting within herself about the best option to take. During the night memories had been teasing her, torn and tattered, like a puzzle she had to put together to reveal the whole. And what she'd managed to put together made her all the more sure that they needed to go into the labyrinth and that Steve needed her in order to survive it, but that she was also a danger to him.

How that worked, she didn't know. What the outcome would be, well, that was even more obscure. Except a fragment from the night, dark and misty, made her think that she wouldn't be leaving the labyrinth.

How was she going to explain what was going on in her head and have Steve not think she was totally insane? She glanced at the mong... Darius. His gaze was on her and for a moment she thought he was aware of the struggle within her, knew things that were going on inside. Well, he'd been transformed by the monster; maybe he did know?

But then he said, 'thank you for letting me stay her with you, for the food and clothing.' Maybe he'd been looking at her with gratitude.

'It's not a problem, Darius,' she murmured, glad for a second to be taken away from her own thoughts. 'I wish we had a top for you, but Steve's wearing the spare. The original is lying in tatters somewhere in the forest after a fight with a thorn bush.'

Darius looked startled a second and then he smiled. Steve scowled. 'If you hadn't wanted those berries,' he told Laura, and turned away so neither saw the flash of a grin/grimace on his face too. Ah, two days ago - back when life wasn't quite so terrifying and unknown.

Laura watched Steve sort out a morning meal - not much different from last night. A bit of the pork remained and some cheese, and a small flask of alcohol. As much as she longed to swallow it back, it probably wouldn't do to be impaired.

As they made the most of the meal, in silence, Laura contemplated how to start her tale. At the end of it, she still didn't know so she just blurted, 'I think I'm part of the labyrinth,' and shook her head because that wasn't quite it.

The two men stared at her, reflecting the same stunned expression. Then they glanced at each other and Laura felt a speck of wariness; such a tiny statement and the two men, previously not exactly friends, had formed some sort of alliance. She was going to have to tread carefully here.

'What do you mean, part of the labyrinth?' Steve asked slowly, trying to just sound curious, even if the hairs were up on his nape. He shifted onto his left hip, which gave better access to the knife he'd slid into his right boot. Not that he thought... He drew breath. Laura looked scared, he best not react before he got the details. Best not let his imagination get the better of him. He noticed that the mongoose had stiffened up slightly; probably reasonable given his unpleasant association with the labyrinth.

'I don't know,' Laura said. 'I didn't really mean part. I mean, I'm not...' She pressed her lips together. 'I sense the evil in that place,' she began after a short moment, 'and I think somehow I'm part of it. Not evil, but... god, I don't know! I've got all these fragments of things in my head, I think they're memories but I don't know. They feel like memories.' She looked at Steve, pleading for some sort of understanding but he looked blank.

His right, she did sound a bit crazy.

Darius, on the other hand, looked afraid. His right, too.

'I'm not evil,' she whispered, voice catching. 'I think... I think you need me to get through the labyrinth, Steve, but that I can't... leave it.'

Laura reached for the little flask, hands shaking. She flinched, bit back a cry, when a hand took hers, prevented her from picking up the flask. Steve froze a second too and then he let her go.

'I never thought you were evil,' he rasped out. Which was true, but maybe because he'd been hoping beyond hope that what he felt was wrong. 'Laura, I've known you for a long time now.' (Ten years, in fact.) 'I trust you.' He was aware he didn't sound quite convinced, and winced. 'Well, I'm doing my best.' He picked up the flask, unscrewed the cap and held the flask out.

Laura hesitated, then took it and drew in a deep swallow. Her throat and eyes burned. Steve took two mouthfuls of his own and then he surprised Laura by holding the small silver item out to Darius. 'Alcohol,' he said.

Darius stared at him in total surprise but took the flask. He eyed the neck and sniffed it, making Steve feel just a little insulted, but then took a small mouthful. Did well not to spit it out over the low fire. He swiped the back of his hand over his mouth and held the flask out. 'Thanks,' he croaked.

Steve gave a half smile, sat the flask between his knees, and then looked at Laura. She seemed a bit more calm but maybe the alcohol was reacting quickly on himself. 'What do you mean about fragments?'

'Exactly that,' she murmured. 'Bits and pieces of things, nothing complete. It's like a massive puzzle I have to put together but nothing fits and bits are missing.'

'So... how do you think you're...' Steve glanced backwards a second.

Laura sagged. 'I have this really weird feeling I belong with the labyrinth. I don't know if that means I belong to the monster. I don't even know what the monster is, really.' She held her hands out to the fire and it flared. She gave a tiny smile toward Darius whom she knew had made that happen. 'It's like I'm part of the labyrinth; that's how I think you need me in order to get through. Like I know the way. I don't remember ever being here, but I must have been at some point.' Another shrug. Still not making sense, she was sure, but it was helping calm her in an odd way. 'And... and if I go in there with you, to help, then I can't leave. It's like a trap and home or something all in one.'

Steve inclined his head. 'What if we don't go in?'

'I don't think you've got a choice,' Laura said quietly. 'The more I think on it, the more I feel you have to go through it.'

'I don't want to lose you,' Steve said before quite realising it.

The smile on Laura's face was beautiful for a moment.

'What if I go in on my own?'

'No,' Laura said immediately, reaching out as if to keep Steve still. 'You will not survive.'

'The monster will get you,' Darius said.

Steve scowled at him but Darius didn't back down. 'It killed six men in my father's mission party.' His voice cracked, and the fire dipped low.

Laura crawled around to him and wrapped him in her arms, murmuring to him while he dragged in choppy air. Steve sucked on his lips in order to keep quiet.

Laura glanced up. 'I have to go with you,' she said softly. 'I know the tricks of the maze. The monster knows things too but not as much as me.' She felt puzzled by that statement but also that it was true. The more she spoke, the more she had a feeling that she was the maze. And how did that make sense? The labyrinth had always existed, and she couldn't remember a moment when she wasn't human. Her head hurt. She focused for the moment on comforting Darius, was relieved that though he was wary he no longer seemed to be wary of her. As if he knew that the labyrinth and the monster were two separate things.

15211211132.content:
'I feel woefully under prepared for this,' Steve said softly as he tightened his grip on his knife.

Laura only managed a pale version of a smile. She had no weapon at all, bar memories feinting in and out. But she didn't think she'd be the focus of the labyrinth in any case, well, not of the monster. She glanced at Darius; he was pale and nervous, shifting on his feet. He had every right to stay behind but he'd refused. 'I want to see this monster dead,' he'd said and no one had balked him.

However... 'I don't mean to be insulting,' Laura said softly, 'but you might be better off in your other guise.'

Darius' brows rose, so did Steve's. Laura felt a flush heat her face. 'I just think you might be safer that way,' she mumbled. 'No so easy to catch but also, not so noticeable.'

Darius cocked his head now. 'I don't understand.'

Laura's lips pressed tight. 'Darius, you might be our only hope. I don't know how this is going to go, at all, but if there's trouble, you might be able to escape.' She looked over at Steve, then back at the young man. 'And perhaps bring aid.'

'From whom?' Steve asked. 'I doubt anyone's just going to leap up for the task.'

'Well, I don't know,' Laura returned, 'but if push comes to shove, lets not all three die!' And she stormed off a few feet, trembling, eyes filling.

Steve looked after her and then turned back to Darius. 'Is there help you could bring?'

Darius shook his head. 'Not from my village,' he said. 'I don't live there any more anyway, but they wouldn't come even if the King himself asked. Not now.' He rubbed a hand down his cloak-covered sleeve. 'I'm not a coward,' he said to his feet.

'Yeah, well, Laura's talking some sense,' Steve grumped. 'Maybe you should stay out here. It's not your...'

'Don't tell me it's not my fight!' Darius cried.

Steve stepped back, startled by the sudden fire in the young man. 'Alright, alright, nobody's saying nothing.' He turned away, managing to keep the rest of his thoughts to himself.

After a second he heard the same shuffling from last night and turned. The mongoose was glaring at him. 'Laura was talking some sense,' Darius parroted at him.

Steve frowned but nodded, then conceded that the mongoose guise was better than a half-dressed young man. He grabbed up the pants and cloak and stashed them in the pack. He caught sight of Laura returning, stopping for a second when she saw their companion's new form. Then she knelt down in front of the animal and thanked him for everything he'd done thus far. Which, Steve, thought, only went so far as keeping the fire up - though that had been a decent benefit.

If Darius replied, Steve didn't hear it as he swung the knapsack over his shoulder. Once it was secure, he stepped forward. 'Guess, the time's now?'

Laura nodded, rising. She gave Steve a quick kiss on the cheek. 'Keep close to me, but behind,' she said. 'Darius, you stay behind too.'

The mongoose chittered in reply, which made Steve frown.

Laura turned and took a breath, then started down the corridor towards the maze entrance. Chills were chasing up and down her spine now, but she was sure that was just nerves, not the precursor of something else. Behind her Steve and Darius followed, Darius keeping to Steve's side (but not within kicking distance).

At the entrance of the maze, that huge threshold stone still showing the footprint, the three of them stood for a moment. The mongoose held its head to one side, listening and Steve found himself doing the same thing. He could hear nothing. He turned to look at Laura; she was pale but seemed calm enough.

'When you're ready,' Steve whispered.

She glanced a tiny smile at him. She drew in a deep breath and started forward. The dirt over the threshold swirled slightly as she stepped over it (not on it) and Steve and Darius followed, the mongoose leaping the stone. Once in, they stood still again as they considered left or right. The corridor looked the same either way and in fact it didn't look too much different from the created corridor outside the maze!

Steve kept his silence, even when the mongoose sat right at his side. Actually, Steve thought, it might pay to keep the mongoose close. Animals were suppose to be able to sense things humans couldn't.

Laura turned to face them.

152112111321.content:
'They look the same,' Steve murmured.

'That's how this place works,' Laura said, her voice quiet too.

Same stone, same odd assortment of ivy, same length. In fact, left and right both looked like they just continued on and never ended. Laura knew that wasn't so. Along these inner walls there were gaps; they just couldn't see them.

Down at Steve's feet, the mongooses chittered.

'Look,' Steve said, 'we don't speak mongoose.'

'Steve,' Laura warned him.

'I wasn't speaking,' Darius said. 'That was my teeth chattering.'

Laura shook her head at Steve, forcing him to mutter out an apology. The mongoose moved further from him. How was it that a rodent cold make him feel so bad? Steve shook his head and looked at Laura. 'Which way should we go? I don't think standing here will do us much good.'

'Left,' Laura said, and made sure she sounded certain about it. As much as she wavered on which way to go, she wanted Steve and Darius to at least feel like she was backing herself. What a thin line!

Steve didn't query her choice and at their feet Darius remained silent. Steve snagged Laura to him and gave her a quick kiss on the cheek. 'Lead on,' he said softly.

He trusted her, he had to. She had experience within the labyrinth and he didn't. Laura managed a tiny smile and they started down the left corridor, her right hand trailing lightly over the wall.

'What are we looking for?' Steve asked quietly, eyeing the wall. He saw nothing but stone. A glance down found Darius trailing beside him (not behind him) eyeing the stone at that level; probably nothing different there either.

'Ambiguities,' Laura said. 'It looks like it goes forever, but it won't. At some point this wall will give way to another twist.'

Steve sucked on his teeth. 'That's why you're touching it?'

'Yes.'

'Should we... I?'

'It might help,' Laura said with a glance over her shoulder. 'This can change in an instance. I might miss something that you catch.'

'Okay,' Steve said, and moved closer to the wall.

He refrained from mentioning that Darius could find his human form and help out too, but he didn't really want to see a flash of nudity and have to scramble in the knapsack for clothes. Besides, he thought that Laura had been right; Darius might manage an escape if needed. Remained to be seen if he'd come back....

The mongoose shifted sides, so that he kept on Steve's outer side, always near his feet or in front, never behind though he often looked over his shoulder. Steve presumed he was listening for things. Since he didn't ever turn around Steve presumed that what he might be hearing wasn't a problem. But then again, what did the mongoose know about the monster? Nothing?

'Laura,' Steve called after a moment. 'This hazy thing you mentioned you saw with your sister. Is that what we are expecting at some time?'

'I don't really know,' Laura said. Then she stopped and turned, making her companions do the same. 'I don't really know if it's the monster.'

Steve cocked a brow.

Laura shrugged. 'If it was then how am I still here? Why didn't it suck my soul too?'

Steve felt at a loss and ended up saying the very stupid, 'maybe it has a limit?'

He was pretty sure the chittering from the rodent meant stupid ass. He shifted a foot, which made the animal turn to him, baring his teeth.

'Gentlemen,' Laura admonished, though right now neither of her companions warranted that title.

The mongoose came to her side, and said, 'it killed six men in my father's party, and would have kept going.'

'Do you know how they died, Darius?' Laura asked, crouching.

The mongoose shook its head. 'All we were ever told was that men had died and the rest had made the bargain.' His voice dropped at the end. 'They never said how.'

'And they didn't say by what?' Steve asked, crouching now too.

'No,' Darius said, and shifted a little closer to Laura.

'I wasn't going to kick you,' Steve mumbled.

That only made the creature stiffen, and earn him a frown from Laura.

'I'm sorry,' Steve said, 'but I'm really on my wit's edge here!' I'm in a dangerous maze with my girlfriend who thinks she might be the maze, I'm waiting for a monster to jump out at me and I'm talking with a giant rat! Fortunately for all involved, that was all in his head. He grimaced; the day was only going to get worse.

'We're all on edge, Steve,' Laura said but she gave a smile too lessen the blow of her words. Then she said, 'I don't know if it was the soul-sucker or something else, but if it should appear then try your best not to look at it directly.' Which felt a bit odd out loud since Laura was pretty sure she had looked at the thing directly. But it hadn't even moved toward her, just laughed. She shivered. She so didn't want to hear that sound again.

Just as she was thinking that she noted the hair raise along Darius' spine and he stiffened. She opened her mouth but Steve pressed a finger to her lips. 'Quiet,' he mouthed.

He hadn't heard what Darius had but the animal was rigid; that meant there was something coming from somewhere. And as much as he might be uncomfortable with the shape changer, he had to acknowledge Darius had skills. He and Laura held their breath, watched as Darius tilted his head slightly behind them. Or, rather, behind Laura; so, to the left in the direction they'd been travelling.

Steve strained his ears but he could hear nothing that might indicate something approached. And when he lifted his gaze at least he didn't see smoke!

'The wall,' Darius whispered in a very faint voice.

Steve nearly yelped out 'what wall?' but more in shock than annoyance. They were surrounded by walls and as far as he could see nothing had changed.

'That one,' Darius said and his nose poked to the left. 'Just behind Laura. It's... moved, I think.'

'You think?'

'Steve,' Laura admonished quietly.

'I heard a grating sound,' Darius said, 'but I can't see any different. I didn't see it move.'

'You don't hear anything else, Darius?' Laura whispered.

'No.'

They crouched like they were for another half minute before Steve and Laura caught each other's gaze. We can't stay here, Laura seemed to say. I know, Steve offered. Laura nodded and rose, keeping a hand on the wall. Behind her, Steve shifted his knife from one hand to the other so he could wipe the sudden sweat from his palm. Steve looked down at the mongoose. The hair wasn't so stiff along his spine any more and he appeared to have relaxed a little.

'Oh wow,' Laura breathed and got his attention. 'Darius was right, the wall has moved.'

Steve watched her hand slide around an edge, while the rest of her body stayed back. She glanced over her shoulder. 'We need to follow this.'

He nodded, swallowing. He came up beside her and still had to look hard to see that there was indeed a gap. God, if not for the mongoose's hearing they would have missed this. Maybe it wouldn't have even happened. Steve shook his head; not the time to think about that. 'Let me look first,' he murmured, clutching the knife.

'No,' Darius said, moving up. 'Let me. If... if something's there it won't expect me.' At least, something so low to the ground.

'Okay,' Steve said, 'but don't go out of sight.'

The animal blinked and Steve might have felt embarrassed just a second for saying that to a rodent! Then he watched Darius take slow, cautious steps through the gap, hesitate a long time (ten seconds!) before continuing until he stood mostly within the next section of the labyrinth. He glanced left and took a longer look right.

'What is it?' Laura whispered, heart crashing against her ribs with concern and fear.

'A garden,' came the answer.

Before Steve could prevent her, she had stepped forward and was soon staring too, her mouth open in a perfect O. That didn't leave Steve much choice! But he took his move slowly, sliding around the edge of the gap, keeping his eye on Darius and Laura for any change in their stance or gaze. But they didn't look transfixed, just surprised. And surprise on a mongoose's face was odd.

Then Steve felt his own mouth drop.

A garden, the mongoose had said. But that didn't really cover what they were seeing.

A click made them all jump and Steve flung a hand out, met solid stone. 'Well,' he croaked. 'No going back that way.' And he realised Darius had taken a short look left because there was a solid wall that way. They could only go down the corridor toward the garden.

Steve swallowed, then took Laura's hand a moment. Darius crouched between them.

choices: They carry on, free from the monster
152112111322.content:
Laura seemed amused, which was totally out of place right here, right now.

'What are you thinking?' Steve asked, voice low.

'Something I remember from my childhood,' she responded. 'Left is right, but right is wrong.'

Great, Steve thought, more riddles to mark the occasion.

'So, we go right?' he heard from his feet.

He glanced down, gaze narrowing at the mongoose who had its beady little eyes on Laura. Laura was nodding. 'Wait,' Steve said. 'You're going to go right just because of a riddle?'

'If you have better reasoning, Steve, now's the time to spill it.' Laura's tone tried to be light, but failed.

Now Steve was aware of the mongoose looking at him. 'I'm just saying,' Steve said stiffly. 'If "right is wrong" why are we going right?'

'Because if "left is right, but right is wrong" then left is wrong,' Laura said.

The mongoose chittered, and Steve stepped away before he could react with a boot. He regarded Laura. She seemed calm, even if she was spouting riddles, and to be honest, he had absolutely nothing to tell him left or right so what right did he have to quibble. He was probably going to die either way. Right at least sounded a bit more positive.

'Okay then,' he said, 'right it is.' He took a step.

Laura pegged him back. 'Me first,' she said. 'And, Steve, please, if I tell you to do something don't question it. You either, Darius,' she added, pointing at the mongoose.

'Alright.' Steve frowned and the mongoose glared. They'd said that in unison, and now Laura had a tiny smile on her face.

Steve sucked in a breath, tightened his hold on his knife. 'Lead on,' he said softly.

Laura squeezed his arm, realised this would be hard for him. He was the "man" after all, needed to be a hero. Well, he'd probably get that chance sooner rather than later anyway, but Laura would do her best to keep them safe until then. If she was part of the labyrinth like she thought, she wasn't sure how long it would be before she'd really start to become it. Physically. She ran a hand over the smooth grey stone with her left hand. Majestic and cold all in one. I'd have used limestone, she thought, if I'd built this.

Laura shook her head of that stupid thought. A labyrinth was never designed to be warm and welcoming! And she had to keep her mind clear, in any case, so she could cope when those memories came clean in her head. She could feel them pushing at the edges of her mind, like a tentative finger poking at something unknown. Like when she and her sister had poked the jelly puddings. Laura hesitated mid stride, but continued before Steve could notice and speak. Sister. Oh my god, I have a sister.

How had she forgotten that?

Laura frowned to herself, straining through the mist of memories. There she was, emerald-eyed Rena. Good heavens, how had that memory been hidden? Her sister!

And with it came a flood of other memories, including the day she and Sam had come home from their date to find Rena had taken up a dare and entered the labyrinth. And had had her mind sucked dry by... Laura drew in a long, long breath, trying to calm herself down. She remembered now - a hazy, smokey thing with distorted limbs, a vague human shape but not all in one.

'If you see smoke, try not to look directly at it.'

Steve yelped out 'what?' in startlement at the sudden noise and at what he'd heard. A squeak had him shift sideways and he realised he'd stepped back and trod on the mongoose's foot. The mongoose was giving him a look he didn't really appreciate. 'Hey, I didn't mean that!' he got out quickly, annoyed, and hoping like heck the rodent wouldn't bite him.

Laura took his arm to hush him, waggled a finger at Darius who had crouched low to the ground as if to protect himself. She apologised herself, and then crouched down too, drawing Steve with her. He didn't look at all comfortable and she probably wasn't about to make him any less uncomfortable. 'I've remembered something,' she said quietly and revealed what she'd recalled about her sister. 'The monster was there - at least what I thought was the monster. No one had really seen it before and survived to describe it. But it was hazy, a smokey sort of form. Vaguely human but with distorted limbs. Not solid anyway.' She swallowed and looked at Darius. 'Did you father or the others ever describe what they'd seen?'

'No,' Darius said. 'They refused to say anything about it.'

'Did the men who died,' Laura began. 'Were they left in the maze?'

The mongoose seemed to freeze for a second, eyes glassy. Then its tail curved around its body is what looked like a defensive gesture. Steve felt himself stiffen but he heard nothing but their own breathing.

'Yes,' Darius said. 'They were left there.' He looked left and right as if he might suddenly be faced with them. 'I hadn't thought about them still being here. Surely they...'

'The monster sucks souls,' Laura said quietly. 'I don't think he needs the bodies. My sister was put back into the maze.' She screwed her eyes closed at that memory. 'She might still be here, for all I know; the men of your village too.'

The mongoose looked like it might be sick, which was a fascinating sight. Before Steve knew what he was doing, he'd reached out and stroked down the animal's back. Darius flinched but his teeth didn't show, perhaps because Steve said, 'it'll be okay,' at the same time he'd touched the mongoose. Honestly, he didn't know what was wrong with him. He got out a wry smile, but felt a little okay at Laura's smile.

Laura apologised quietly. 'I didn't mean to hurt you, Darius, I just wanted to warn you it might happen.' She was worried about it herself, remembered she'd worried about it long ago when her sister had been left there 'I can't...' She shushed herself. She'd been going to say that she couldn't sense them, but even if she was part of the labyrinth, without a soul a person didn't really exist. She wouldn't be able to sense them like that. And, really, she wasn't sure if she could sense anyone else in the maze anyway. She didn't now.

'Anyway,' she said after a moment of silence. 'If you see a hazy thing, look away.'

Steve and Darius both assured her they would.

Laura didn't tell them she'd looked the thing in the face because she couldn't explain why she was still here. And sane. At least, I think I'm sane.

'Okay,' she said. 'Let's carry on.'

She rose, rubbed a knee free of dust.

152112111322.title: Right?

choices: While Laura sleeps, Steve does some sleuthing.
Steve sleeps too, and they pass a decent night.
1521122.content:
'I'm not hiding secrets, Steve,' Laura said. 'I just sense danger in the labyrinth. You must too'

Steve considered her, and Laura said softly, 'you've got that feeling about the darkness and I don't.'

'I'm not sure we should be playing a tit or tat game here,' Steve commented, and then sighed. Laura was right on a certain level. She didn't know half about the darkness that he did and he certainly hadn't revealed everything to her. If she pushed, and found that out then she'd have even more reason to keep quiet herself. And... 'Yeah, I feel something evil in there.' He nodded at the stone wall in front of them, moss creeping up the mortar. A daisy-like flower sprouted out about half way up, and he stared at it like it was a total oddity. Well, it seemed like one. Something so pretty in a place like this.

Steve sighed, and then he caught sight of a mouse rounding the corner and tracking toward them. It huddled close to the wall. 'There's the monster,' he mumbled.

Laura gave a soft giggle into his neck, and they watched the mouse scuttle passed.

'Probably should have caught it,' Steve said. 'Could have eaten it.'

'Steve!' Laura slapped his chest.

Steve had only been half kidding, though it probably wouldn't have done them much good. He changed the subject. 'Have you seen the monster in the labyrinth?'

'No,' Laura said. 'Have you?'

'Of course not.'

'Then why do you think I have? Just because I know that it sucks souls?' Laura straightened off Steve's shoulder.

'No,' he said, even if it was true.

Laura eyed him a moment before shifting closer to the pathetic excuse for a fire. It didn't provide much warmth but the brightness at least gave a tiny bit of cheer. Laura frowned, stupid memories just out of reach again. Except for the one that let her know the monster's soul-sucking punishments. 'I had a sister,' she began and then stopped, shook her head.

Behind her, Steve was silent. Laura bowed her head, drew in a breath. 'I had a sister,' she said again, 'until she strayed into the maze one day.'

Steve drew in a sharp breath, and Laura turned. He reached for her and she readily moved back to his side, let him put his arms around her. 'I'm so sorry,' he murmured.

'It was years ago,' Laura said. 'I was no more than fifteen, Rena twelve. Always a sprite, she was, getting into trouble. Getting me into trouble too.' Laura felt a smile try to pull her lips up. These memories were unhindered by blocks and corners and dark spaces. Sometimes she wished that wasn't so.

Steve waited, finally realising that to get Laura to talk required silence on his part and patience.

'There are very many entrances to this labyrinth,' Laura began again, after a while, stating a fact Steve knew. 'There was one just a couple of miles from our village. The best pasture lay beside the maze, and we grazed sheep there. They never wandered in; animals have a sixth sense about danger, you know. I was never particularly bothered about the place either though I knew not to go near the entrance. Our parents had always told us stories about young people being forced inside by some magical pull of power, how roars of things unknown could be heard. Well, you know how it goes,' Laura said, twining hands with Steve. 'On the one hand we all stayed away, on the other we secretly egged each other on, though no one was ever brave enough to test theory. Not until my sister.'

Laura closed her eyes. She'd been on a date with a handsome young man and what a perfect day it had been, until they'd come home to find the place in an uproar. Rena and a couple of her friends had been playing jacks with stupid dares. Someone had dared Rena to step over the threshold of the maze. Rena being Rena, and without Laura there to act as her common sense, had taken up the dare. Especially since one of the rewards was a kiss from the boy she liked.

Steve maintained his silence, couldn't say the sister was silly because he'd done stupid dares at that age for much the same reason.

'When Rena stepped over the threshold, nothing happened,' Laura began again. 'So they egged her to go further and she did. Apparently she stepped out of sight and didn't come back. No one dared go in after her. When Samuel and I returned, she'd been gone about a half hour and no one had dared even get our parents.' Laura realised she had tightened her grip on Steve's hand, and let go.

Though he didn't speak she watched him flex his crunched fingers. Then he curved his hand around hers. 'You went in, didn't you?' he asked softly.

Laura nodded. 'She was my only sister, I couldn't not.' She drew in a deep breath. 'She wasn't far from the entrance, just a couple of feet down a corridor. Out of sight but they'd have found her if they'd looked. Just kneeling on the ground, eyes wide open.'

She wasn't dead. She'd blinked when Laura had called her name but there was no recognition in her gaze. A grey haze of smoke seemed to waft around her and as Laura had drawn closer, the haze coalesced into a shape. Horribly human, but distorted in the limbs so that the arms were massive. It seemed to take on solidity and then reverted to haziness, held its ground when Laura screamed at it to back off.

'It laughed,' Laura said in an odd voice. 'When I told it to back off, to leave Rena alone it laughed, and said it was too late. She'd paid the price. I didn't know quite what it meant then. We still thought the soul-sucking was part of a myth. But once I got Rena outside of the maze and lay her on the ground, I realised. Her gaze was blank, nothing...' Laura shrugged, not quite able to explain what she'd seen. 'The colour was gone too. Rena had gorgeous green eyes but they were milky grey. The village doctors could do nothing and no form of magical charm they knew helped. Rena was a husked, somehow living still but soulless.'

Laura drew in a deep breath and let it out.

'Did she die?' Steve asked quietly.

'I don't know,' Laura said.

Before Steve could question that answer, Laura revealed the final piece of that puzzle.

'The doctors said she was cursed and recommended that our parents put her back into the labyrinth. She could not harm us there - as long as we stayed away.' Laura swallowed a lump. 'They did it, they believed the doctors and dad and another man put her back in the maze. They said she never said a word or moved or anything. She... she might still b-be there. My s-sister...' Laura broke down into tears.

Steve tightened his arms around her, horrified at the images invading his mind. He was sorry he'd asked, but he also felt a little more calm. These memories were what was making Laura nervous and uncomfortable around the labyrinth.

'A couple of days after they left her there,' Laura broke into his thoughts, 'I left the village. I couldn't stay there and think of Rena so close to me and yet so far away, just lying on the ground. For all I know, she's still there and I... it's my fault.'

'What? How?'

'I should have been watching her,' Laura cried softly. 'Sam and I were only supposed to be away for a couple of hours, but we were way half the day. If I'd...'

'No!' Steve cut her off. 'It's not your fault, Laura. Don't think it is. Your sister sounds very strong willed; you wouldn't have been able to stop her from that dare. I'm sure of it!'

Laura sniffed. Probably, that was right, but it didn't stop the guilt. God, she'd done so well burying that memory and those feelings they now sliced at her as if just yesterday, as if the fifteen years of guilt she had buried was giving her a one-day hit. And yet those other memories, the ones that made her feel like she was connected to the maze somehow stayed just blurs in her mind. Rather like that smokey haze that had hovered over her sister.

Laura cried herself to sleep on Steve's shoulder.

1521122.title: Laura refuses to answer....

15211221.content:
Wish I could sleep.

Though Steve was in fact glad he wasn't actually tired just now. It was so much worse when you were tired but couldn't sleep.

He sat for a moment, hearing Laura's soft even breathing near his ear, feeling the rise and fall of her breathing within his embrace. God, what a horrible memory she'd just revealed. And he hadn't had any inkling of her close attachment to the labyrinth, outside what she'd already revealed. They'd been together three years at least and she'd never said.

Then again... they'd never had any need to discus the labyrinth!

Steve ran his tongue over his teeth and recalled what Laura had said. Mostly that she hadn't seen the monster, but then had said she'd seen the hazy thing with her sister. Well, that didn't mean they were one and the same and by the time Laura had reached her sister her soul was already gone. Perhaps the hazy beast had been there for another reason?

A shiver shunted down Steve's spine. Laura hadn't mentioned that her father and the others had seen the creature when they'd put Rena back into the labyrinth. God... what a harsh thing to have done. And to have done it while kids looked on! Steve brushed hair back off Laura's forehead and sighed in her sleep.

He shifted slowly, until she was curled on her side, had on the knapsack. He settled his cloak over her, tucked it around for warmth, then slowly rose. While she was sleeping he was going to check out a bit of the corridor they now found themselves in. He felt almost certain the wall had sprung up to force them into the labyrinth but if so, why hadn't it closed off the ends? They could still wander along either way, perhaps come to an end.

He tried to recall what he knew of the labyrinth. It was immense, yes, had several entrances (and therefore exits) and seemed to always be this grey stone. Smooth as if it was just one large block, though Steve was certain he'd seen it at times looking like ashlar masonry put together. Man made? Legend always said there was a Creator, but a magic sort rather than human. That was how the place distorted, shifted, changed depending on who was looking at it. Damn it, it was how a stonking great stone wall had slid up blocking their retreat into the forest!

The stone was, unsurprisingly, cool to Steve's touch as he trailed it along the wall. A light layer of dust on parts of it where dirt had stuck and become rather like stone, letting dust pile up. Ivy plants climbed from the ground but as far as Steve could see it never reached the top of the wall. Thought there'd been ivy at the entrance, Steve was also pretty sure none of the ivy that might be growing on the inside of the labyrinth had climbed over the wall. Once they were in the maze they wouldn't be climbing the walls to escape!

Steve swapped sides to get a closer look at the new wall but frankly it didn't look or feel any different to that of the maze. And for a moment Steve wasn't sure which wall he was focusing on. He bent over his knees for a moment. Then he heard Laura calling for him, and he hurried back to her.

She was sitting up, looking around. The remnants of the fire showed the panic on her face.

'I'm here, I'm here,' Steve called as he came up.

'Don't leave me like that,' Laura cried, reaching out for him. 'I heard noises and you weren't here!'

'Sorry,' Steve said, kneeling and holding her tight. 'I just wanted to do a bit of sleuthing, checking the walls. Did you have a nightmare?'

'No,' she said, 'not until I woke and didn't see you.'

Steve apologised again, said he'd stay beside her this time. As he settled more comfortably he asked the question on his mind. 'Laura, you said you'd not seen the monster.'

'I haven't.'

'Then what was the hazy thing you described?'

'Not the monster,' Laura said. 'It can't have been. Surely I wouldn't be here if it was? Why would it let me take Rena?'

The tremble in her voice told Steve she was hurt at the accusation, but he'd had to ask, to get it clear in his mind. 'I don't know,' he murmured. 'Maybe it didn't need you? Or maybe it wanted you to take her, to show the others?'

'That's... horrible,' Laura said.

Yes, it was, and it gave the monster some sort of brain activity that Steve wasn't comfortable with, a cunning. And a little tiny part of his brain wondered if Laura hadn't been affected somehow. The sensible part of his brain told him that of course she had been affected. She'd seen her sister vacant! She'd seen her father heed "warnings" and put her sister back into the maze. Who wouldn't be affected by that.

'God, Steve,' Laura sniffed.

Steve apologised again, and wrapped her tighter in his arms. 'Honey, try to sleep again. I'll be right here. Tomorrow's another day. Things will be better in the dawn.' Wished he could sound a little more confident about it.

Laura was still a moment, then she wiggled more into his space and let out a sigh. 'I love you.'

'I love you,' he said and hoped it be enough to get them through tomorrow.

Tomorrow when things were supposed to be better, but also when they were going to go into the labyrinth.

It was the voice of an angel, no one could doubt that. It came from nowhere, and it also came from everywhere. There were no words, just the sound of an organ, but it was a human voice. Laura looked at Steven in surprise as he slowly sank down onto his knees and sat back against his heels. Laura did the same.
"Can you hear that?" Steven asked, his voice filled with awe.
"Of course I can hear it," Laura replied. "My God, it's beautiful, whatever it is."
"It sounds like a voice, but it also sounds like an organ." Steven began to slowly sway with the soft, slowly changing rhythm of the sound. "It's an angel, and she's singing," he said.
Laura and Steve fell silent as they listened to the singing. They closed their eyes, no longer afraid that someone, or something, might sneak up on them in the dark. The beautiful sound lulled them and made them both feel safe.
"I can't make out where it's coming from, Laura," Steven asked. "Can you?"
Laura tilted her head and listened intently for a moment, then she turned and looked at Steven, her eyes focused on something far away. "It's coming from everywhere, Steven," she said, her voice dreamy.
"I think you're right," Steven replied.
The singing grew louder, but the softness in the voice remained, nudging Laura and Steven further into the trance that had overtaken them. The voice rose to a crescendo, its high pitch never wavering, and then it softened further as the volume of the voice lowered.
"I have never heard anything like it before," Laura said.
"Me either," Steven replied.
"You are safe with me."
Steven opened his ears and looked at Laura. "What did you say?"
Laura's eyes opened slowly. "I didn't say anything."
"Yes, you did," Steven said, but his eyes were narrowed with uncertainty. "Didn't you?"
"What are you talking about, Steven," Laura said. "I'm just listening to that angelic voice. It's the most beautiful thing I have ever heard."
"I know," Steven said as his gaze slowly scanned the dark clearing where they knelt. "But I heard something."
"Yes, the voice, the beautiful voice that is singing."
"No," Steven said too quickly. "No, I mean yes, I can hear the singing. But I heard another voice. Just as soft and soothing. But it said something."
"What did it say?" Laura asked.
"It said, 'you are safe with me.'" Steven combed his fingers through his hair. "Didn't your hear it?"
"No," Laura said. "Are you sure you heard something? Couldn't you just be mistaken? I mean it has been one heck of a long day." Laura's gaze lingered on Steven.
After a short minute, Steven replied. "Maybe it was my imagination after all."
"Yes, maybe," Laura said.
Laura and Steven remained silent as the singing continued. There were no words, only the sweet tones of what had to be an angel.
"You are safe with me."
"There it is again," Steven said as his eye shot open. "You must have heard it that time, Laura." Steven turned and looked at Laura and he felt a sudden fear grip his stomach. Laura's eyes were so wide Steven was afraid her eyes would pop right out of her head.
"What is it, Laura?" When Laura didn't respond, Steven followed her gaze off into the dark. There was nothing there for him to see. "Laura?" Steven reached out and touched Laura's upper arm. Her skin felt warm, very warm, and it felt like her entire body was vibrating. "Laura, are you okay?"
A slow smile began to work its way across Laura's lips. Her eyes softened and she tilted her head. Steven had never seen her so relaxed. She had never looked so at peace, and that made him feel strange when he asked if she was okay. She was obviously okay, more than okay from what Steven could see.
"You look like one of those paintings," he said. Laura slowly turned her soft gaze on Steven.
"What paintings are you talking about?" Her voice was soft, just above a whisper, and seemed to come from far away.
"The ones we see in churches, you know, the ones painted hundreds of years ago. The sky opening up in a rapture, winged angels coming down from the heavens, and the people looking up with an adoring gaze at the whole scene. That's what you look like now." Steven leaned in closer to Laura and looked into her eyes. "Are you sure you feel okay?"
"I have never felt better, Steven." Laura kept her gaze on Steven, the soft, adoring smile remained unchanged, her eyes sparkled like ice.
"You are safe with me," the soft voice said again. But this time, Laura turned her gaze to the place where she believed the voice had come from.
"So, you did hear it that time," Steven said.
"Yes, Steven," Laura said softly. "It's the angel."
"How can you tell?" Steven asked. "How do you know?"
"I just can," Laura replied. "I can't explain it, but I feel so peaceful, as if nothing can harm me." She looked around the clearing where they knelt and a smile stretched her lips. "I'm not even afraid of being here anymore." Laura put her hand on Steven's shoulder and pushed herself up. "I think the voice is coming from over there," she pointed into the darkness.
"Wait," Steven called after her, as Laura began walking away. "Where are you going?"
"I want to see her," Laura said. "I want to talk to her."
"Laura, you don't know what you're doing." Steven grasped Laura's arm, but she tugged it away and kept walking. "This could be a trick," Steven said. "With all the strange things that have been happening around here today, this could be anything."
"I don't think so, Steven," Laura said in a soft voice Steven had never heard her use before. "It's okay, I just know it is. It's safe."
Steven jogged a couple of steps to catch up with Laura, but stayed one step behind her just in case something wasn't as it seemed. He felt the same things Laura obviously felt. There had been an unmistakable peace that settled in his mind when the singing began. He felt no fear, felt no reason to be afraid. The only unsettling thing about him now was that little sliver of caution that he seemed to have been born with. While the rest of him let go, allowed the peace and tranquility to envelope him, that one sliver, call it an instinct to stay alive, whatever, but there was that one little thing that kept him vigilant.
"You are safe with me," the voice said again.
But this time the angelic voice sounded as if it was coming from further away. Was it leading them? Was it getting them to follow it? If so, why? And where was it taking them?
"Wait, Laura," Steven called after her. "We don't know what's happening here. Let's go slow until we understand what's going on."
Laura stopped walking and turned her body around to face Steven head on. An eerie smile played on her lips, and her eyes seemed to be completely unfocused. Her lips began moving, but no sound came out. Steven rushed to Laura and grasped her by the shoulders. Shaking her gently, Steven said, "Laura, snap out of it. Please. You're scaring me."
"You are safe with me."

"You heard her, Steven," Laura said, trancelike. "We're safe with her." She shrugged Steven's hands away he stood still as he watched her slowly walk into the darkness.
The darkness swallowed Laura as she walked away. Steven wasn't sure what to do. Should he follow her? Should he remain where he was in case something went wrong.

But as soon as the distance opened, the lights moved forward, creating a long line of glowing green light like an emerald necklace.
"Steven," Laura turned around to say something to Steven, but suddenly stopped, her eyes locked on the deep darkness of the forest. "There!" she shouted and pointed. Steven turned around and stared.
The lights blinked out, but not before Steven and Laura had seen them.

"I may be wrong," Steven said slowly, "but they may actually be something that will help us."
"Help us? Have you lost your mind, Steven?" Laura tucked her head behind Steven again so that she was completely hidden from the view of the lights. "They are definitely not human."
"If I'm right," Steven said, "and I think I am, they used to be human."
"Now I'm really worried about your state of mind, Steven," Laura said, her voice shaky. "I knew I should have just turned back even if Steve didn't want to," Laura mumbled to herself.
"Wait, one is coming over," Steven said. He could feel Laura's hands grasp his upper arms and yelped when her nails dug into his flesh. "Ouch," Steven said, his voice whiney. "That hurts, Laura. Ease up."

"Shh," Steven admonished. "Let me do the talking, okay sis?"
"I won't argue that, Steven," Laura said. "I'm finding it hard to talk to you, I probably couldn't talk to the light even if I wanted to."
The glow cast a sickly green glow over Steven's face as it came to within a few inches of Steven's face. There was a low hum emitting from the small light that changed in volume in a definite rhythm. Louder, quieter, quieter still, then lower, quieter, and then low again, but moving louder and holding the volume for a moment before going quiet. It was a tune that Steven recognized, but he couldn't place it. It must be my nerves, he told himself. But he definitely knew the tune, and given time he would remember it.
His eyes locked on the glowing light, and he tried to stop his body from shaking. The light hovered in front of Steven for a moment later, and then moved back away.

Laura's head slowly rose above Steven's shoulders until her eyes were not only visible, but also reflecting the green glow of whatever it was hovering in front of her. As she gazed at it, the hum began to form into a rhythm again, and it's volume rose and fell.

His finger began to glow green as it neared the light, and Steven could feel the skin of his finger warm. Steven turned around again and raised his finger until it was nearly touching the light. He took a quick glance over his shoulder as if to say something to Laura, but instead of speaking, her turned back to the light.

Steven paused as if trying to find the right words, but when he raised his arm straight out from his side and opened his palm, it was obvious that he had something else in mind.
"Um, um, um, ummm," Steven hummed as he opened and closed his fist with the rhythm of his humming. But there was no response from the light. Steven did it again, but using a different tune this time.
"Ummmm, um, ummm. um. um. um. ummmm," and again with each hum, Steven's fist opened and closed. Steven let his arm fall to his side as he gazed silently into the light. Suddenly, the light grew brighter.
The light's vibration of sound repeated the same tune Steven had just hummed. Steven's mouth fell open as he watched the light's glow become brighter and duller, brighter and duller, with each different tone it emitted.

"You are asking me to be intelligent, logical, and fearless as we find ourselves in a dangerous, stupid, and illogical situation.
But Steven wasn't listening. Instead, he raised his arm out to his side again and held his hand flat, his palm facing the light.
"I'm going to ask him another question, Laura. Let's see what we can find out."
As he began to hum like he had done before, the light grew intense, brighter than it had been before. Steven assumed the light had suddenly become afraid of something, because is back away a couple of feet and it was joined by a number of other lights that had been hovering in the near distance. As they merged together, it was as if a large light had suddenly appeared out of the darkness.
"Oh, sh....." Steven's voice trailed off as the group of lights began humming and vibrating.

1523231.content:
"I can't stand this any more," Laura shouted and ran into the darkness of the woods.
Steven watched as the nigh swallowed Laura. He wasn't sure what he should do. The lights that had coalesced from many points of light into one large beacon was now undulating and shimmering. Steven wasn't sure if he should be afraid and run like Laura had, or just stand there and keep whatever it was from pursuing Laura. A moment later his mind was made up for him, as two small orbs of light broke away from the beacon and flew in the direction Laura had fled. Steven turned and took two quick steps to follow the lights, but suddenly a loud voice stopped him in mid-stride.
"Every thing will be alright,"
Steven slowly turned expecting to see the bright beacon of light, but instead, what he saw made his jaw drop open and his eyes bulge.
She stood before him, her dark eyes clouded by something Steven believed had to be drug related. Her long, curly dark hair fell down past her shoulders to the middle of her back in a riot of bouncing tendrils. Her thick lips formed a wide smile that revealed two rows of large, white teeth. Steven's eyes moved down from her face, as he continued to take in her form. The woman was a bit on the heavy side, and a long, loose-fitting, multi-colored dress hid her round hips and ample thighs. Her feet were clad in flat sandals that exposed her crimson-tipped toes, and a leather strap wound its way around her ankles and up her calves. She wore multiple gold hoops around both wrists that jingled when she moved her arms.
"Hi, baby," she said. "Where did you come from?"
"Where did I come fr...?" Steven blinked, swallowed, then blinked again. "This can't be. No, this is not possible."
"What's not possible, baby," the woman said in her sweet, smooth voice.
"Janis Joplin?" Steven ran both of his hands through his hair, pulling at the strands behind his head. "No, no, I'm seeing things. I'm hallucinating."
"Hallucinating?" the woman said. "Now you're talking my language. She smiled and looked around conspiratorially. "Just between you and me, baby," she turned and gazed at Steven, her eyes brightened by anticipation. "You got anything to share?"
Steven stared at the woman for a long second. His lips moved as if he was saying something, but no words came out of his mouth. He wiped his palm over his mouth, swallowed, blinked several times, then ran his tongue over his dry lips.
"Something..." he blinked. "Something to share?" He shook his head vigorously as if he could clear the image of the woman standing not three feet away. A woman who had been famous during the 60's. A woman who had captivated millions of people with her voice and with her crazy, unpredictable antics. A woman who had lived a wild life of abandonment of drugs and casual sex.
A woman who had died many years ago.
Steven looked back over his shoulder trying to find Laura, but the woman pulled his attention back to her with her words.
"Don't worry about her, baby," the Janis Joplin look alike said. "Just say, Bye, Bye, Baby, and then let my friends find your girl."
"She's not my girl," Steven said a little too quickly." He looked over his shoulder again. "And who are your friends who have gone looking for Laura?"
One is name Bobby McGee," she said. Her gaze, still unfocused, searched the darkness where Laura had disappeared. "The other one is my Big Brother. He owns a Holding Company, somewhere in Port Arthur in Texas."
Steven just stared at the woman, his mind racing in all directions. This woman, no, this visage, could not be a real person, and certainly not the dead Janis Joplin, he told himself.
When Steven didn't say anything, the woman's shoulders sagged as if she had become suddenly sad.
"You don't believe me, do you/" she asked.
"Don't believe you about what?" Steven asked. "You mean about you being Janis Joplin?"
"No," she said and smiled. "You didn't believe me when I told you that my brother owns a holding company in Texas." Her smile faded. "You think I'm lying to you, don'tcha?"
Steven's lips moved rapidly, but the only sounds coming out of his mouth were unintelligible animalistic grunts.
"What are you on, baby?" A wide smile returned to her face. "And do you have any left to share?"
"Any what?" Steven was finally able to put words together. "What am I on? Do I have any to share?" Steven shook his head again. "What the hell is going on here?"
"You seem to be having some kind of nervous breakdown, baby," the woman calling herself Janis Joplin said. She reached out and took a hunk of his cheek between her thumb and forefinger and pinched. "But I'll look after you. You'll be fine."
Steven touched his cheek where he had just been pinched. A red mark was beginning to take shape. "I'm not having a nervous breakdown," Steven said, his voice rising in volume, "I'll have you to know that--"
"Look!" The woman said. "Here comes you girl." She jutted her chin out. "I told you that you didn't have anything to worry about."
A sweaty Laura emerged from the darkness and walked slowly, tentatively, toward Steven. Behind her, two men followed.
When Laura reached Steven, she tucked herself behind him, her hands grasping his arms from behind.
"Why did you run off like that?" Steven asked Laura.
Laura's voice was edgy, nervous. "I just couldn't handle any more setbacks." She looked at the woman who had just been joined by the two men who had found her in the woods and convinced her to come back. "These people are weird."
"Do you know who they are, Laura?" Steven waited several seconds before adding, "Did they tell you their names?"
Laura pointed to the taller one, and said, "That one is Bobby McGee. At least that's who he says he is." She swung her arm to the other man standing there, and said, "And he has something to do with some kind of holding company in a place called Port Arthur in Texas." Laura let her arm drop to her side. "But to tell you the truth, Steven. I think they're all crazy."
"I heard that," said the woman who had introduced herself as Janis Joplin.
"Me too," said the guy so-called Bobby McGee. The other man, the one who owned the holding company stood there quietly, his eyes taking in Laura brazenly.
"What are you looking at?" Laura said when she felt his withering gaze moving over her body. "What are you, some kind of freak?"
"Yeah," the holding company guy said. "I am a freak. Want to freak out together sometime?"
"Groovy," Bobby McGee said. "We've only been here a short time and already we're putting a party together."
"Slow down, you guys," Joplin said. "It sounds like you got Trouble in Mind. And this guy," she pointed to Steven, "he looks like he's got Trouble in Mind. But I'm gonna try Just a Little Bit Harder to not be a Cry Baby. You know how I am, I Need a Man to Love. So Move Over while I search for my Mercedes Benz." The woman let out a long breath and said. "Somebody should name some songs after what I just said."
"Will everyone please stop this nonsense?" Steven said, his voice strong and authoritative. "We're still lost, Laura and I, and we need to get out of here."
"That's no problem, baby," the Joplin lady said. "I already have a plan to do just that. After all," she waved her hand indicating her and the two guys with her, "we came her to help you guys."
"So what's the plan?" Steven asked. "How do we get out of here?"
"Well, baby," Joplin said, "it's like this."

Probably calf skin, Steven thought. As his eyes continued upward, he took in a pair of old, ripped, faded blue jeans. Further up and he saw a wide waist circled by a wide, black belt ending in a huge silver belt buckle. That's so big if can be used as a picnic table, Steven told himself. But he couldn't stop his gaze from moving higher. He had to know who this person was. As his eyes rose he took in a faded, multi-colored shirt. There were reds, blues, greens and yellows running as thin straight lines across each other making small square patterns that were filled with a color Steven couldn't identify. Again he felt his attention being drawn upward until he saw a great, dark, matted beard that hung to the creatures chest. Moving further Steven saw a wide, crooked nose that looked like it had been broken, twice, and above that he saw the bluest eyes he had ever seen. The form was topped by long, curly, brown hair that disappeared behind the creatures massive shoulders. The thing must have been six feet sex inches tall, and he looked powerful. He held an axe casually, it's wooden handle resting on his left shoulder.
"Get up," the big thing said. "You must not bow down to me," a smile broke out on his face and his face reddened. "It would be embarrassing if someone saw you down there like that."

The giant lowered his gaze and pushed out his lower lip. "Sorrrryyy." he said. "I didn't mean to scare you. I was just having a little fun."

Before she could protest, her eyes were even with the giants and there was at least two feet of space between the soles of her feet and the ground.

Steven pushed himself up from the ground and shouted up at the giant. "You'd better put her down if you know what's good for you. She's tougher than she looks."
The giant looked from Laura down to Steven, then back to Laura. His lips, half hidden behind his beard, slowly stretched into a wide smile. "Sorrrryyy," he said shyly. "I was just having fun again. I didn't mean any harm."
Laura drew her right hand back behind her head, balled her fingers into a tight fist just like Steven had taught her, and then exploded a right cross that connected with the giant's nose.
"Take that you brute," she said. She watched a huge tear gather in the corner of the giant's eye. "Who do you think you are coming around here and scaring people. Why I ought, I ought, why I ought to give you another right cross."

The giant slowly lowered Laura to the ground. He rubbed his nose with his thumb and forefinger, and the tear that had been sparkling in the corner of his eye finally spilled out and ran down his cheek. The tear fell from his cheek and landed on Steven, soaking him.
"Oh, now look at what you've done," Steven said as he tried to brush the water from him.

"Wow, are you ever fickle," Steven said. "A minute ago you gave this guy a right cross, threatened him with a right uppercut, and now, a minute later, you're giving me heck for yelling at him. Some women, I swear!"
"And just what do you mean by that, Steven?" Laura asked.
"Yeah," the giant said. "What do you mean by that?"
Steven stared at Laura for a long second, then he raised his gaze to the giant's eye, then he looked back down to Laura. "So that's how it's going to be now? Two against one? Okay, then, maybe I should just leave."
"Sure, Steven, you could just leave," Laura said. "But you're lost. You have no idea which way you should go to get out of here."
"I know, I know," Steven said as he looked around the small clearing where they stood. "But I can find my way, don't you worry."

Steven looked at the giant and watched his chest rise and fall with each breath. "How can he sleep so soundly with everything that's going on?" Steven asked with a frown.

"You are always complaining about him," Laura said. "He's not doing this, he is doing that. We have no idea how much energy was sapped from him when that light spewed him out. Maybe it's you who needs a nap!" Laura crossed her arms over her chest and huffed.

"Yes you do," Steven countered.
"No I don't, either," Laura said.
"Sure you do," Steven replied.
"Don't," Laura said.
"Do," Steven countered again.
"Don't either," Laura said and stuck her tongue out at Steven.
"Do so," Steven said. "As a matter of fact--"
One of the giant's big, grey-blue eyes was open and staring up at Steven, then it moved to Laura. "Can't I even take a nap without you two acting like a couple of spoiled kids?"
"She started it," Steven said.
"I did not!" Laura said, her anger turning her face red.
"You did, too," Steven said, matching her anger.
"Did not!" Laura said again.
"Did!" Steven said, and this time it was he who stuck his tongue out.
"Paaaleeese," the giant shouted. "I can't take any more of this." The giant sat up and scooted back against the tree trunk. He glared at Steven, and said, "You are behaving like a child."
"See?" Laura said. "It is your fault--"
"And you, little miss," the giant said turning to Laura. "You're not acting much older than he is!"
Laura started to say something , but the giant put his hand out to silence her. "Don't even start, little miss," he said. "Both of your are behaving badly."

"Good," the giant said. "Now you two shake hands and say you're sorry to each other."
"What?!" Steven said. "But I really didn't do anything."
"Yes you did," Laura said.
"No I didn't," Steven countered.
"Did," Laura said and crossed her arms over her chest again.
"Did not!" Steven said. "It was --."
"I can't take this anymore," the giant said, his voice betraying his exasperation. "I think I'll just leave."

The giant looked at Steven. "What about you? Do you care if I leave?"
Steven tried to look like he was considering his answer, but in reality he didn't want the giant to leave, but he didn't want the giant to know that. He didn't want the giant to think he could take over. After considering his answer for a short minute, he said, "Okay, I'll say it. Please don't go. You're probably our best chance to find out way out of here."
The giant took a long time to answer, but he said, "Yes, I am your best chance to find your way home. So let's just stop the nonsense and concentrate on me finishing the story so we can get started."
"Why do we have to waste time with the story?" Steven asked. "Why can't we just go?"
The giant took a deep breath, and then looked at Laura. "You were right when you said he picks on me."
"You heard that?" Laura said. "I thought you were asleep."
The giant wiggled his eyebrows at Laura, and said, "I can always hear your sweet voice, even when I'm sleeping."
Laura blushed. "You're just making that up to make me feel good."
"No, I'm not," the giant said and smiled.
"Yes, you are," Laura said as her face reddened.
"I'm not," the giant said.

"Did not!" the giant said.
"There you two go again!" Steven rubbed his eyes with the knuckles of his hands. "I can't take this." He turned to the giant. "Look, if you have to tell this story before we can leave, which I think is weird, then let's get the story started so we can get it over with."
"Well," the giant said. "You don't have to get all huffy about it, Steven."
