Steven opened his mouth to complain about what Laura had just said, but realizing that would only waste even more time, he decided to swallow the words that were on their way to his mouth. Instead, he smiled and nodded.
"Okay," the giant said. "Where was I when all the foolishness started?"

All three of them fell silent for a moment, then the giant said, "Now that everyone is done, where did I leave the story?"
"Jack has just traded his cow for a handful of supposedly magic beans."
"They were magic!" the giant glared at Steven. A second later, the giant exhaled slowly. "Okay, anyway, Jack put the beans in his pocket and started home." The giant smiled at Laura, and she smiled back. Jack wondered what was going on between them. "Needless to say, when Jack arrived home his mother was very upset when she saw what Jack had received in trade for their prized possession.
"Is that what you got for old Nellie?" Jack's mother said.

"Oh, Jack," his mother said. "You've always had your head in the clouds." She clucked. "Go ahead, plant the beans, you might as well. They're not worth cooking."
Jack lowered his head in sadness. "I'm sorry, ma," a tear fell from his eye. "I thought I was doing the right thing."
"No need to apologize, Jack," his mother said. "Just go outside and plant the magic beans. We'll see what happens."
Jack stepped out into the yard, the beans held tightly in his grasp. He walked to a sunny spot near the barn and knelt down. Using his fingers, he dug a hole about six inches deep in the ground.
He opened his hand and stared at the beans, then spat on them. He tipped his palm sideways and watched the beans drop into the hole he had dug in the ground. Using his other hand, he covered the beans and then said a prayer. Afterward, he stood and as he walked back to the house, he mumbled. "I hope those beans really are magic."
The giant paused and Steven said, "Okay, go on, go on. Let's get this story out."
The giant's eyes widened as he glared at Steven. "I'm not going on until you apologize to me." He crossed his massive arms over his barrel chest and harrumphed.
"Well," Steven said. "I have nothing to apologize for. So I'm not going to."
Laura's gaze traveled from the giant to Steven, then back to the giant. Neither man looked as though he was going to give in.
Taking a deep breath and letting it out slowly, Laura sat back against the tree and waited.

Steven inhales deeply, and then his cheeks puff out as he exhales.
"Okay," he says finally. "Feel better?"
The giant allowed a smile to slip onto his lips. "Yes," he said, "I do feel better."
"Now can we get on with it?" Steven asked. Laura sat next to the two men, nodding.
"Okay, but if you interrupt me again," the giant said, "the deal is off. Understood?"
"Yes," Steven said, reluctantly.
"I'm so glad you boys are getting along again." Laura gazed at the giant. "I think your story, at least so far, is sooo interesting. I can't wait to hear the rest."
Steven watched Laura and wondered if she meant what she said, or was she just trying to get things moving forward again. He felt foolish for arguing with her, but more foolish for arguing with the giant. Sure, Steven told himself, the story the giant was telling was stupid. Who would ever believe that there was such a thing as magic beans. But letting the giant get through the story he was telling was the only way they could get him to guide them out of these God-forsaken woods.
"I'm all ears," Steven said and smiled at the giant. "I'm looking forward to hearing the rest of the story."
"I'm glad you've finally come around," Laura said. "I think the giant's story is fun, and filled with mystery. I mean, think about it. Magic beans. That's an amazing thought."
"Magic beans?" Steven said. "The only magic I've ever gotten out of beans is the tooting it created after I ate them." He smiled sheepishly. "I remember one time I was actually able to play Give Peace a Chance, by the Beatles."
"That's gross," Laura said.
"That is not the kind of magic I'm talking about here, Steven," the giant said. "I hope you are taking my story seriously. Otherwise I might change my mind."
"Why is telling this story so important to you, anyway?" Steven asked. "I mean, it's just a story, right?"
"Yes, that's true," the giant said. "But it explains how I got here," he swung his hand in a wide arc. "It's how I found you and Laura." He smiled at Laura. "And I am so very glad I found you... and you too, Steven."
Laura returned the giant's smile. "I'm glad you found me... ah, us, too."
Steven stared at Laura and burned inside. She was so obviously flirting with this guy, this giant. After all he and Laura had been through, Steven resented the way she was treating him. Who was it that took care of her and kept her safe since their ordeal in the woods began. He was, he told himself. Who was it that put himself between Laura and all the danger they encountered since their ordeal in the woods began. Him, he told himself. And who was it that would continue to keep her safe and care for her after the ordeal in the woods had ended. He would, he thought to himself as anger welled up inside of him.
But Steven knew that unless they were able to get out of these woods, unless their ordeal ended in a good way, there was nothing he could do to garner Laura's respect. He had to relent, he had to do whatever the giant wanted. He had to do whatever it took to get him and Laura home.
Swallowing his pride, Steven said, "I have to admit that I'm also interested in what happened that brought you to us." Steven tried to put as much sincerity into the tone of his voice. It was not an easy thing to do, because he was making this up as he went.
"I'm asking you to go ahead and tell us the story." Steven winced inside, because the last thing he wanted was to listen to this gibberish coming from a man way too tall to be normal.
"I'm glad you finally came around, Steven," the giant said.
"Me too, Steven," Laura said. "I'm glad to see that you have come to your senses"
Steven wanted to get up and scream as he ran head long into the woods. These two were driving him crazy. He took a deep breath, forced a smile onto his face, and nodded at the giant. "I'm ready," he said, "start whenever you're ready. There is no rush."
A wide smile opened on the giant's face, revealing two rows of large teeth that looked like crooked tomb stones. "That's very nice of you, Steven."
Laura was all smiles as she gazed lovingly at the giant.
"Okay, now I remember where I was." He inhaled and let it out slow.
"Jack went to sleep that night and had no idea what to expect in the morning. If the beans were just that, beans, then he knew there would be nothing outside in the morning except the disturbed dirt where he had planted the beans. But what kept him awake most of the night was the thought that if the beans were really magic, what would he find in the morning. He couldn't wait to see the result of all of this.
"Jack." Jack heard his name being called but thought it was part of the dream he was having. He pulled the blanket up to his chin and rolled over.
"Jack!"
The tone of voice told him that the voice was not in his dream. It was the voice of his mother. He knew better than to turn over and ignore her, even though he hadn't slept much last night.
"Jack!!"
"Yes, ma," he said, pushing the word through his sleepiness. "What's wrong, ma?"
"Get up," she replied, her voice hoarse and tired. "Get out side and look at the mess you created."
That got Jack's interest. What mess had he created except for the planting of those beans. Magic or otherwise.
"I'm on my way, ma," he said. Jack threw his legs over the side of the bed and sat up. The smell of last night's dinner wafted into the bedroom; onion, beets, and chicken broth. His stomach gave a shift at the thought of the gruel he had eaten last night.
Jack pushed himself up onto his feet. He quickly got dressed and walked out into the kitchen. He could tell that something was wrong. The kitchen was also bright with sunshine this early in the morning. But this morning the kitchen was bathed in shadow.
"What is happening, ma," Jack asked his mother.
"So, you've noticed, have you?" she asked.
"Yeah, ma, I noticed," Jack said. "Something isn't right."
"You're darn right something ain't right." She stepped to the kitchen window and pulled it open. She leaned her hands on the window sill and stuck her head out through the opening. Jack noticed that his mother turned her head and looked almost straight up into the sky. When she pulled herself back into the kitchen, she stared at Jack with wide, red-rimmed eyes.
"Well, you've really done it this time." she said.
"Ma," Jack said, impatience coloring his words. "Can't you just tell me what I have done? Admonishing me isn't helping me to understand anything." He went to the closet and pulled out a box of Frosted Flakes, then stopping, he changed his mind and put the cereal box back into the closet. Reaching deeper into the closet, Jack pulled out a box of Lucky Charms.
"I can't believe you eat that stuff," his mother said. "Don't you know it's loaded with high fructose corn syrup?"
"Ma," Jack said as he poured the sugary cereal into a large bowl he had placed on the table. "If I worried about everything I ate, I wouldn't eat anything." He looked at his mother from head to toe. "Besides, you're one to talk about eating badly. You could stand to lose about fifty pounds yourself."
His mother came at him with a polenta stick. a wooden paddle used to make polenta in the special copper pot she owned. "You can't talk to your mother like that, you little brat. Why, if you father, God rest his old bones, was around he'd whoop you to within an inch of your life."
Jack saw the wooden weapon coming his way and thought, discretion is the better part of valor. Quickly putting his shoes on, Jack ran for the door. Turning back he saw his mother still coming for him. Jack jerked the door open and ran outside. He took no more than ten steps and suddenly stopped. His eyes widened as he looked at the stalk sticking out of the ground exactly where he had planted the beans yesterday.
His eyes settled on the spot where the green stalk came out of the ground. His gaze rose, and rose, and rose even higher until the green stalk disappeared into the clouds drifting by in the sky.
Jack felt a shock go through his spine. "What the hel.....?"
Jack couldn't believe his eyes. But his reverie was interrupted when his mother walked up behind him.
"See what you've done, Jack?" she said.
"But ma, those beans were magic, just like the guy said.
"Magic, smadgic," she said, and handed her son the axe she had been hiding behind her back. "Get rid of it Jack." she dropped the axe on the ground at his feet and turned and walked away.

They had no permanent spouses, they just all lived together, sleeping in large dormitory tents, eating in cafeteria style areas. They even had a slogan, well, a couple slogans."
"Slogans?" Laura asked. "Why would they need slogans?"
"I don't think they felt like they needed slogans, but just like things like that usually happen, the slogans just appeared."
"What did the slogans say?" Laura asked.
"Things like 'make love not war.' 'Drugs, sex, and rock and roll.' I'm sure there were others, too."
"Umm," Laura said. "Those slogans don't sound like they would belong to dangerous people." Laura slowly peeked around Steven's shoulder and gazed at the single light hovering in front of her and Steven. "He looks friendly, doesn't he? I mean, he's green, not red."
"Good point, Laura," Steven said, his voice growing in volume as if he was suddenly beginning to laugh. "Do you want to hear the rest of the story?"
"Yes, by all means," Laura said. "Go on."
"Okay," Steven said and gazed at his sister to see if she meant it, or if she was being sarcastic again. When she remained silent, Steven continued.
"They came from all over America, all over the world actually. People said they didn't bath regularly, but they did. The people in town saw them after they had walked many miles and hadn't had a bath is several days, several months for some of them. But they were clean. They kept the bug population down as best they could--"
"But population?" Laura said. "What does that mean?"
"I'm not sure," Steven said. "I'm just telling you about the things I heard. I remember someone saying that they had a whole bucket of what they called 'roaches' and that they burned them at night."
"uggghhhh," Laura said, then placed her palm over her mouth, and spoke through her fingers. "Sorry."
"It's okay," Steven said. "I think it's gross too." Steven took in a deep breath and let it out slowly. "So they congregated here, in these woods, and set up their living situation. It wasn't all bad, either. They kept the area free of debris by gathering fire wood, and scrub bushes to burn. They kept their trash in one place. They swam in the stream that's supposed to be nearby. It's also where they washed their clothes. They used no soap, they didn't want to contaminate nature."
"If they were that concerned, then they couldn't have been all bad," Laura said.
"Oh, some people thought very highly of them. Some people brought them food, old clothes, and even blankets and cooking utensils. They cooked over open fires, slept out under the stars, and in general respected nature."
Laura gazed at the light that still hovered just out of her reach, but she noticed the light had softened. It was almost as if, she thought, the light had become thoughtful as it listened to Steven's words. Could it be, she asked herself. Could those kind, unassuming, nature loving people have somehow become the lights that hovered in the darkness of the woods? It was a question she hoped she would one day find the answer for. But for now she wanted Steven to continue his story.
"Go on, Steven," Laura said as she stepped closer to the small, hovering light.
"Sure," he replied. "But I don't know too much more about them." He closed his eyes as if he might be able to see the memory of his hearing the tale about the people who had come to live here. It came back to him slowly.
"They weren't welcomed by everyone. Some of the village people resented them. They called the forest people bums, crazy, dirty, pigs, but eventually they came to be called by a name that stuck with them. No one knows where the name came from, how originated it, or why it stuck. But soon everyone was calling them by that name. Hippies. Do you have any idea, Laura, what that means?"
Laura tapped her finger against her lips as she thought, then she said, "No, I can't say that I know what that means. But I have heard the word before."
"Hippies," Steven said slowly. "I wonder what it means."
"Does it really matter, Steven," Laura asked. Her gaze slid through the darkness until it settled on the hovering soft green glow. "Do you really think those lights are, um, hippies?"
"Um, could be," Steven said thoughtfully. "After the forest people had been here for about a year or so, one day they just disappeared."
"What do you mean, disappeared?" Laura asked.
"Just what I said. "One morning a group of the village people strolled up here and entered the woods, expecting to speak with some of the hippies. But it quickly became apparent that the hippies had simply disappeared. There was no trace of them."
"No trace at all?" asked Laura.
"That's right." Steven turned his attention to the glowing light. "I wonder," he said thoughtfully.

choices: Laura goes screaming into the darkness holding her hands over her ears.
Moonbeam suddenly feels threatened and stops talking.
15232331.content:
Steven paused and fell silent for a few minutes and turned his gaze to the black sky. He seemed lost in thought, but after a few moments, he took in a long inhale, held it, then ballooned his cheeks as he exhaled slowly. He turned to the light that still hovered just out of his reach.
"I'm going to try something that might be helpful," Steven said. "I want to try to communicate with them."
Laura said nothing, she just watched Steven move so that he was standing in front of the light, but just to the right a bit. Steven's arm rose until it was straight out from his shoulder, and then he opened his hand so that his flat palm was facing the light.
"Hmm, hmm, hmm hmmm." The hum sound a lot like the song they played when communicating with the aliens in Contact. Close Encounters of the Third Kind. Laura giggled. "What are you doing?"
"I'm trying to communicate with the light," Steven replied. "I figured this was worth a try."
"Why don't you just talk to us?" the voice said. Steven turned around and stared at Laura. "What did you say?"
"I, I, ah, I didn't say anything," Laura said as she took a step back, her eyes locked on the light.
"I thought you didn't," he said. "But then who did?" Steven began slowly turning his head until he was face to face with the light.
"Was that you who spoke," he asked nervously.
"So you can talk to me as if I'm actually here," the light said. "I hate it when people talk about me as if I'm not present."
"Sorry," said Steven. "If I had known you had the capability to speak I would have talked to you."
"Well, now you know," said the light, it's voice thin, and he gave a short squeak at the end of each word.
"I can see that," Steven said.
"I assume you want to know what's happening," the light said and lowered its intensity.
"Yes, of course I do," Steven replied. "But let's start with you name." Steven touched his chest. "I'm Steven. What's your name?"
The light seemed to stretch itself into what appeared to be a smile. "That's cool, man," he said. "My name, well, my name after I left the world of materialism, is Moonbeam."
"Moonbeam?"
"Yeah man, groovy, right?"
"I guess," Steven said. "So how long have you been here?"
"A long time, man." Moonbeam said. "I mean, if you count before I was this beacon and after I became a beacon."
"So you consider yourself to be a beacon? Is that it?"
"What else would you call us?" The light continued after a moment's pause. "Is it that hard to believe that there are several planes to living? You live in a plane that keeps you here on earth. But there are two more planes, the one I occupy. Here, in this plane, we are small lights, or beacons, as I prefer to call us."
"How many of you are there?"
"That's easy, dude," Moonbeam said. "There's only one like me. And that's me!" Moonbeam smirked at Steven.
"No, I didn't mean how many are there like you as in like you," Steven said but he sounded confused. "What I mean is how many are there like you... No, I'm saying the same thing again." Steven paused and looked like he was trying to think of way to phrase the question to eliminate the confusion. Recognition slowly seeped into his eyes.
"Moonbeam, I was asking how many small lights, beacons, are there?"
"I'm not sure how many of us exist," Moonbeam said. "But in this little group here?" he turned and shot a beam at the group of lights hovering near a tall oak tree, "There are twenty-five of us."
"Twenty five," Steven said, drawing out each word slowly. "How did you guys become light?"
Moonbeam leaned over Steven's shoulder and peered down at Laura. He smiled.
"Well, dude, I can say for sure that we were not captured by space aliens and examined." He laughed. "No, there are no space aliens around here." He glanced down at Laura and looked into her nervous eyes. "At least none that I know of."
"I was only speculating," Laura said defensively. "I didn't say for sure."
"Well, that's good, starlight. Do you might if I call you Starlight?"
Laura slowly rose up so that she could see over Steven's shoulder. "My name is Laura. L a u r a. So no, I mean yes, I do mind if you call me Starlight."
"Okay, okay," Moonbeam said. He turned to Steven and said, "Did someone pee in her post toasties this morning?"
"No, she's always this..." Steven's words trailed off when he saw Laura glaring at him. "I mean," Steven could see the smirk on what passed as Moonbeam's face. "We've been out in these woods all day. We've been out in the woods all day. Then we got lost. Then when it got dark out we got even loster."
"Loster?" Moonbeam's face pinched in distaste. "There is no such word as loster. You might have gotten more lost as night fell, but there is no such word as loster. But you won't need to use that word again anyway."
Steven felt threatened, but the feeling didn't last long. As soon as Moonbeam put his hand on Steven's shoulder, all concerns melted away. He wasn't worried that he had stained his clothes earlier, he even didn't care that he and Laura were lost. He just seem to be in a perpetual good mood. It has to be due to these little, greenish lights, Steven told himself.
"Sorry, I'm just nervous," Steven said.
"Understandable, under the circumstances," Moonbeam said. "Now, what is it you want to know?" Moonbeam paused, then continued. "About us, I mean."
"Well, for starters you can tell us how you went from human beings to this," Steven waved his hand toward the group of lights that hovered nearby. "How did you guys become these little points of light?"
"Ahh," Moonbeam said. "Little points of light. I remember there was someone who used that during a campaign speech."
"You guys have a government? You run for office?" Steven asked.
The light looked at Steven as if it was him that looked strange. "Dude, are you partaking of the herb?"
"The herb?" Steven asked.
"Never mind," Moonbeam said. "I guess I was just thinking out loud." The light seemed to lower its glow. "Okay, so you want to hear how we ended up like this? You want to know what happened""
"Yes, I do." Steven pointed back over his shoulder with his thumb. "And so does she."
The light moved forward until it was peeking over Steven's shoulder too. "Hi there, little moon flake."
"Moon flake," Laura said as she rose slowly. "There is no such thing as a moon flake."
"There are many things in our world that you don't know about," Moonbeam said. "So keep an open mind."
"Open mind my as--"
"Laura!" Steven interrupted. Pasting a big smile on his face, Steven turned to Moonbeam and said, "My sister is very excitable. And she's scared--"
"And hungry, too," Laura interrupted.
"And hungry," Steven said and smiled. "We're listening. Go ahead, tell us what happened.
Moonbeam made a sound that sounded like he was clearing his throat. A moment later he began speaking.
"Well, dude, as you know not everyone in the village liked us. Oh, there were a lot of village people that liked us, but as usual, there is always a few haters.
"One night we were all sitting around the camp fire. We were singing kumbaya. Do you know the song?"
"I think I've heard of it," Steven said.
"Would you like me to hum a few bars?" Moonbeam said.
"No, no," Steven held his hands up, palms out. "That's okay, I get it."
"So anyway, we were all sitting around the campfire," he glared at Steven, "singing kumbaya, when suddenly a bunch of car headlights were coming up the road toward us. With the headlights blazing in the dark it looked like a diamond necklace." Moonbeam shook his head. "But it wasn't a necklace, instead it was the cops and a bunch of village people coming up here to turn us out. Make us leave, man!
"Why is it that when all people want to do is live closely with our brethren," he paused to smile, "and our sisters as well. Why do people have to feel threatened by that."
"I think it's because people--"
"The question was rhetorical, Steven," Moonbeam said. "Should I continued?"
"Yes, by all means," Steven said.

15232331.title: The glowing light comes forward and begins tell...

choices: A loud boom is heard, interrupting the conversation.
152323312.content:
Moonbeam's gaze, which was more a beam of light than anything else, moved from Steven to Laura, then back to Steven. Moonbeam exhaled. "So we were just sitting around the fire. We had finished dinner and were just hanging out. And then we saw all those car headlights coming our way. Needless to say we were all a bit nervous. We had never been visited at night, well, we did have some girls show up one night and they stayed for a few days." Moonbeam smiled with a memory Steven could only guess at. But a moment later the smile evaporated and Moonbeam continued.
"As I watched the headlights come closer, I just knew there was trouble brewing. I mean, that many people coming up to the hill where our camp was, at night? No, something was wrong and I knew it."
The light began to elongate and then it began taking on the shape of a man. Laura quickly jumped behind Steven for protection, and Steve put his hands in front of his face, just in case the light became too bright he didn't want to harm his eyes.
But then the light began to undulate, picking up speed, until the shape of a man became crystal clear. He was a good looking young man of about twenty, not tall, about five-feet-eight, and very slender. He had long, curly hair that flowed down his back and framed a face that looked more innocent that anything. Half his face was hidden beneath an unruly beard and mustache. As the light's glow dimmed, the man stepped forward. His tie-dyed shirt showed all the colors of the rainbow and his bell bottom pants had stripes going horizontally and vertically, creating small boxes in the material.
The man who had just emerged from the light reached out to shake hands with Steven. Steven, his mind still racing over what he had just witnessed didn't initially reach out and take the hand offered to him. But Moonbeam kept his hand out, waiting. He seemed to understand that Steven would need a few minutes to get ahold of himself. Over Steven's shoulder, Laura's eyes peered at the image in front of Steven.
"It's okay, man," Moonbeam said through a bearded smile. "I understand that you are having trouble understanding what you just saw. It freaked me out the first time I saw it too." He looked from Laura to Steven, watching their eyes, a smile wavering on his lips.
Steven was the first to come around. His shoulders relaxed and his fists unclenched. He tilted his head from side to side trying to loosen the muscles of his neck. Steven turned around to see if Laura was okay, and when his eyes met hers he could see the fear residing there.
"It's okay, Laura," Steven said. "He's obviously harmless. We're going to be fine." He turned to Moonbeam and said, "Right?"
"We're cool, man," Moonbeam said. He waved his hand, palm open, toward the other lights that hovered in the near distance. "We're all non violent. We wouldn't hurt anyone. Never could. That's why we never understood why the village people did what they did."
Steven felt his body come back to the moment. "What did they do?" Steven asked. "The village people, I mean?"
"We were all apprehensive about what was happening when we watched the cars coming closer. Some of the people who had been with us for weeks ran and hid, obviously too afraid to wait and see what was happening."
Moonbeam turned back to the hovering lights that had appeared with him. "But most of us didn't have any fear. I don't know if that made us stupid or just too trusting. But anyway, there we stood while the cars pulled up at the edge of the woods. I knew there was going to be trouble as the people began piling out of the cars." Moonbeam seemed to be lost in the memory.
"What happened?" Steven asked. "Did the village people cause trouble?"
"Man, did they ever," Moonbeam said. "We were willing to give the village people the benefit of doubt. We waited for them to reach us where we stood. But our eyes never left the weapons the village people carried."
"Guns?" Steven asked, shocked.
"No, something worse than guns."
"What could be worse than guns," Laura said. It was the first time she spoke since the light had become the man standing in front of her and Steven.
"Well, welcome my lady," Moonbeam said and reached out a hand. When Laura took Moonbeam's hand they shook for a long time, much longer than usual. Moonbeam couldn't take his eyes off Laura.
"Why are you staring at me?" Laura asked and moved back behind Steven.
"Groovy, Moonbeam said, a wide smile that revealed his teeth, some crooked, some broken, some missing. "You look exactly like a girl who was with us that night. The night the village people came to see us. She was beautiful, just like you. Her and I spent a lot of time together. Man, she and I had so much fun--"
"Okay, okay, I get it," Laura interrupted. "You don't need to go into detail."
Moonbeam smiled, his eyes moving from Laura's eyes to her lips, then back to her eyes. "I'm sorry," Moonbeam said. "I get carried away sometimes when I think about her," he whispered. Leaning in closer to Laura, he said, "Don't tell my girl over there, she wouldn't understand. She's very jealous." Moonbeam took a quick look over his shoulder and smiled. Laura gazed at the lights hovering in the distance and wondered which one was Moonbeam's girlfriend.
"Can we get on with this, please?" Laura said. She looked in the direction they had been traveling, and said, "We still need to get out of here." She turned back to Moonbeam, and said, "The sooner the better."
"Yes, yes," Moonbeam said. "Where was I?"
"You were about to tell us what the village people did. They were walking up the hill to your camp."
"Oh, God," Moonbeam said. "We're you there?"
"No..." Steven answered.
"Then how did you know that?"
"Because you just told me," Steven said.
"Yes, I did," Moonbeam said. He seemed to be a bit confused, but then the cloudiness in his eyes cleared. He shook his head and resumed his story.
"They really put us off guard, the village people, I mean," Moonbeam said. "As they approached they were smiling and waving at us. It took our attention away from the things they carried." Moonbeam paused, and then shivered. "Baseball bats, axe handles, home made clubs, braided ropes, chains." He sighed long and noisily. "You name it and they had it with them."
"No guns?" Steven asked.
"They were smart enough to know that they could hit us with a bat and the pigs.... um, the cops would not be able to match up a bruise with a particular bat. It could never be proven who had hit whom. But a gun? Now that's a different story. A gun has ballistics. If they shot one of us the... ah, cops would be able to know who did the shooting. They were smart, those village people."
"How many people were hurt?" Laura asked.
Moonbeam smiled widely at Laura. "A lot of people were hurt. Those village people waded into the camp and began swinging those bats and clubs. There was a lot of screaming. A lot of shouting. My people were dropping into the dirt one after another. It was brutal. It was awful." Moonbeam fell silent and his gaze dropped to the dirt below him.
"I'm sorry," Steven said.
"Me too," Laura said.
Moonbeam slowly raised his head and looked at Steven and Laura in turn.
"That's nice of you guys, man," Moonbeam said. "But as it turned out, it wasn't so bad."
"How could that be?" Steven said.
"After the village people left, we all sat around nursing each other's injuries. It was late, and I remember it was very dark that night. But we took care of each other, bandaging each other, finding wood to make splints for broken arms. Everyone found something to do." He paused, sighed, then continued. "Luckily enough we still had some, ah, some medication left from the previous night's party. We all partook of the medication and found a place to sleep."
Moonbeam looked back over his shoulders and then turned back to Steven. "It happened at around three o'clock in the morning." He paused.
"What happened at three?"
"I was never really quite sure, actually," Moonbeam said. "I remember I woke up and there was an eerie silence. I mean, it was a silence that was different. There was no wind, not even a soft breeze. It was just silent and still. No one said anything even though everyone was walking around in a trance. The next thing I knew I was buzzing around inside a great big ship. All my friends were doing the same. It was amazing."
"What happened next?" Steven asked.
"I found myself standing in front of you, trying to communicate."

"But you must remember something," Laura said. "I mean, that was years ago when you were living here with your friends."
"Yeah," Moonbeam scratches his head of long, curly hair. "But can we sit down, my back is killing me."
"Sure, I'm sorry," Laura said. She pointed to a spot beneath a horse chestnut tree. "Over there," she said. "There's no roots sticking up above the ground." She put her hands behind her and rubbed her back side. "I can still feel the last time we sat under a tree. You should see what it did to my--"

"Damn, dude," Moonbeam said. "You need to loosen up." He reached into his back pocket and pulled out a bent cigarette and held it out. "This will calm you down," he said through his smile. "Come on, let's sit down and talk this through."
As they walked to the tree, Steven noticed that Moonbeam walked slow and was walking behind Laura. Steven turned and could see where Moonbeams eyes were focused and a pang of anger rose through him. He had heard about the old rumors about the hippies. They practiced what they called free love. Well, Steven told himself. Maybe that worked for them back then, but today that would not work. He would have to keep a close watch on Moonbeam to make sure he didn't get out of hand.
Steven turned his gaze on Laura and he could tell that she was enjoying the attention being shown by Moonbeam. He didn't think that it was Moonbeam's looks that she liked, he had a rough looking face what with that scraggly, matted beard and drooping mustache. But Steven thought he knew what it was about Moonbeam that Laura liked; it was all that kindness she felt when she was around him. Kindness! Steven thought. Well, I think kindness is overrated.
When they arrived at the tree, Steven, Laura and Moonbeam sat down. Moonbeam waited to see where Laura was going to sit before he took his seat, right next to her. Steven had no choice but to sit across from them. Now I'm going to need to watch what he's up to, Steven told himself. And I'm sure he'll be up to something.
Moonbeam lit his cigarette and took a long inhale, and then he did something Steven had never seen anyone do. Moonbeam passed the cigarette to Laura. Steven knew that Laura didn't smoke, so he wasn't surprised when she passed it to him without taking a drag. This elicited a frown from Moonbeam.
"Hey, Moonspeck," Moonbeam said. "Why don't you partake? It will make you feel better.

"Yeah, why not dude?" Moonbeam said. "I mean, just look at Laura. She's a fine babe. Her blond hair is so silky smooth." Moonbeam reached up and touched Laura's hair gently. "And it's so soft." Moonbeam shivered. "And look at that angelic face. The high cheekbones, the smooth forehead," Moonbeam's eyes began to glow. "And look at those beautiful, pouty lips." He reached out and ran a finger along Laura's cheek, across her lips, then along the line of her chin. "And there's something else, Steven," Moonbeam continued. "Look at that slender body, the gentle feminine curve of her hips, those long legs." Moonbeam's gaze moved upward. "And look at those..." his words trailed off as his hand began moving toward Laura.
"Okaaay," Steven said loud enough to wake every animal living in the woods, as well as all the other things that seemed to be thriving in the woods as well. Steven grabbed Moonbeam's arm and tugged it back. "I think we get your gist, Moonbeam. But we were talking about the name you seem to have given to Laura...Moonspeck.
"Yeah, man, Moonspeck." A wide smile opened on his face when I passed the cigarette back to him without taking a drag. "She's smaller than me and I'm Moonbeam, so since she's small, and the light in her eyes reminds me of the moon, I decided to call her Moonbeam." He turned and smiled at Laura. "If that's alright with you... Moonspeck."
Laura seemed to be completely taken by Moonbeam, and Steven couldn't figure out why.
"Moonspeck," Laura said slowly as if she was turning it over on her tongue, in her mind. "Moonspeck. Yes, I like it. I do."
"Woo. woo," Moonbeam said. "Let's not get any strange ideas."
"Ideas?" Laura asked. "What are you talking about?"
"All I did was give you a name, Moonspeck, nothing more." Moonbeam frowned. 'But already you're talking, I do. I don't want to get married." His gaze dropped to Laura's body. "I mean, I wouldn't mind playing married, but for real. No thanks."
A light of recognition entered Laura's eyes, as she listened to Moonbeam. "Oh, no, I said I do... like the name Moonspeck. I don't want to get married either."
"Okay, Moonspeck," Moonbeam said, "What about playing married. Do you like that too."
"Well," Laura turned to Steven and gave him a nervous look. "Let's just wait and see."
Moonbeam took another drag and held it in. "Okay, her said, his voice strained.
"So you were going to tell us what happened after the fight in the woods," Steven said, his voice filled with annoyance.
"Oh, yeah, oh yeah, Moonbeam said. "Well, like I told you, them village people came up here and beat us all senseless. But it wasn't until much later that the thing happened."
"The thing?" Asked Steven.
"Well, I don't know what else to call it," Moonbeam said. "I can't really call if a happening, because there was no music. And you need music if you're going to have a happening." Moonbeam took another drag from his cigarette. "You guys must know that." When neither Laura or Steven answered, Moonbeam continued. "Don't you see? A happening is where everyone dances, there's lots of music, you know, sitars, guitars, things like that. It's fun, man. All the girls dress up in their best tye dyed dresses and blouses. The men wear the jeans that have the least amount of holes in them. You know, stuff like that." When no one answered Moonbeam, he continued. "But a thing, well, that's something else. A thing in not usually a good thing. I mean, people get hurt sometimes. People don't dance, and it doesn't matter what you wear. As a matter of fact, during a thing you should wear clothes that let you run, as in escape."
Moonbeam fell silent for a minute. Steven looked at Laura and shrugged. He tipped his head toward Moonbeam and raised his eyebrows as if to say, what's with him?
Laura shrugged in return.
Moonbeam's body jerked as if he had been startled. "Where are we man," he said, and looked around slowly. Eventually his gaze found Steven and he smiled. When he found Laura a smile opened on his lips.
"Hi moonspeck," he said. "Did, ah, um, did we?"
"Did we what?" Laura asked.
"You know, did we?" Moonbeam said.
"If you mean did we as in did we," Laura said as she glared at Moonbeaam, " as in did we? Then, no we most definitely did not."
"Oh, too bad," Moonbeam said. "I guess it was only a dream."
"Okay, okay, everybody," Steven said. "What about telling us what happened?"
Moonbeam stopped talking and put his fingers to his temples. He began to hum. Slowly he opened his eyes, and in a voice that sounded far away, he said.
"Yes, I see it now," he said. "Bright lights, little funny looking people with long, long arms all around me. They had shaved heads, too. They were there and they were..." Moonbeam's voice trailed off.

15232333.content:
Laura stared at a silent Steven for a long second, then she asked, "You wonder what?"
Steven slowly turned his head toward Laura, his eyes told her he was deep in thought. He blinked his eyes and said, "I wonder if those lights could have anything to do with the people who lived here in the woods."
"You mea, the hippies?" Laura smiled. "That's the right word, hippies, isn't it."
"Yes, it is," Steven said slowly, his mind obviously stuck on some other thought. "I don't know why I feel that it is, but for some reason I just think those lights have some kind of significance. Something to do with either our safety, or in our danger."
"Our danger?" Laura said and backed up a step. "Then maybe we should get away from those lights."
"Are you kidding?" Steven said. "Those things could catch us no matter how fast we ran." He looked past Laura and watched the small lights buzzing around each other like bees. "And we both know there's no way we can hide from them."
"So what do we do?" Laura asked.
"That's what I'm trying to decide." Steven took a step toward the lights, and instead of backing away, the lights all stopped moving and formed a circle as if they were all facing him. "Look at that, Laura," Steven said. "See how they seem to be watching us?"
Laura turned and gazed at the lights for a moment, then without turning her gaze away from them, she said. "Yes, Steven, I see what you mean." She turned to Steven, and said. "If I didn't know better, I would think they are trying to communicate with us."
"That's my impression too," Steven said. "I mean, they formed a circle that looks just like a face staring back at us."
"What should we do?" Laura asked.
"I don't know if we should do anything," Steven replied. "We definitely don't want to scare them off."
"No, that wouldn't be good," Laura said. "Maybe we should just wait and let them make the first move."

"Let's talk about something other than pee," Steven said.
"Good idea." Laura sat down on the ground and patted the packed dirt next to her. "Sit, Steven," she said. "Let's just sit here quietly and see how the lights react."
"Sounds like a plan," Steven said. He let out a soft groan as he lowered himself to the ground. He wriggled his back against the tree trunk trying to find a comfortable way to put his back against the bark without causing too much pain. After several attempts, he was still not comfortable.

Steven backed away and propped himself up on the palms of his hands that he placed flat against the ground. "Now why would I want to start a fight with you?" he asked. "I mean, you don't seem to be bothered by the rough tree bark pressing into your back, and you seem to be able to stand the pain in your skin. You don't seem as worried about those lights over there," he pointed. "Which by the way seem to be coming closer every time I look at them. So pardon me if I think you're much tougher than I thought you were before this whole ordeal began." Steven lowered his gaze to the ground as if he was afraid of what Laura might say in reply.
A smile slowly crept across Laura's lips. "Do you really think I'm tough...tougher than you thought before all this?"
"You just want to hear me say it again," Steven said. Laura's gaze remained on Steven, to the point where Steven began to feel uncomfortable. He raised his eyes without moving his head. "What?" he said, and picked a blade of grass and put it between his lips. "Why are you looking at me like that?"
"Like what?" Laura replied.
"You know," Steven said. "You're looking at me like I'm some sort of a baby that can't take care of himself."
"Not at all," Laura said. "It's just that I feel almost like I'm seeing you for the first time." She smiled and her eyes lit up. "It's like you're someone I'm meeting for the first time."
"You're losing it, Laura," Steven said. "You know that? You are losing your mind."
"No, I'm fine, Steven," Laura said. "It's you who is changing."
"I am not," Steven said and pushed out his lower lip.
"Oh, yes it is," Laura replied.
"Is not," Steven said.
"Is too," Laura replied.
"Is not," Steven said again, more forcefully this time.
"Is too," Laura said showing no signs of backing down.
"Not!" Steven said.
"Is!" Laura countered.
"Not!" Steven said again.
The strong voice shocked both Laura and Steven into silence.
"Will you two please stop acting like little children?"
Laura put her hand over her eyes to protect them from the strong sunlight. Whoever it was standing in front of her was only a silhouette because the sun shone behind him. Or was it a her? Steven could see the black form, a shadow silhouette, as the sun's rays radiated out from behind him. He nearly looked as it a halo beamed above his head.
"Who...who..." Laura didn't seem to be able to form a complete sentence. Steven tried.
"Look mister, what ever your name is," Steven was trying to act tough. "I don't know who you think you are, but you can't just pop up here in front of me and Laura and not expect one of us," Steven's gaze turned to Laura," by one of us. Maybe you should just back down and move on. We are having enough trouble finding our way around without putting up with someone like you who just shows up and tries to scare us and doesn't think we're capable of, of, of, well, you just don't know what we're capable of."
The voice of the stranger was calm, serene, and dripped understanding when he spoke. "You don't have anything to worry about from me," he said. Then in a voice just above a whisper, he said, "I've been sent here to help you two," his gaze moved from Steven to Laura, then back to Steven, then back to Laura. Then, one final time, his gaze moved to Steven where it stopped.
"Sent by who!" It was more a demand than a question.
"Actually, Steven, Laura said, "it's not who, it's whom." She stared at Steven and then raised her eyebrows. "Sent by who is not correct." She turned to the stranger and smiled. "It's sent by whom?" She held up a finger of admonishment. "And you could stop this tough guy shtick and just be yourself. No one believes you're tough. I read somewhere that when someone tries to act tough but everyone around him can see right through him, it means the person trying to act tough is actually trying to mask his own fear."
"Is that right?" Steven asked.
"Yes, that's right," Laura replied.
"But it's not," Steven said and stuck his tongue out.
"Yes, it is," Laura said and stuck her tongue out too. If Steven was going to play that game, so would she.
"Is not," Steven said, his voice edgy.
"Is too," Laura replied.
The stranger's face move back and forth from Laura to Steven and back again as each one spoke. To someone passing by who didn't know what was going on, it looked like the stranger was watching a tennis match.
"Is not!" Steven said forcefully.
"Is too!" Laura said just as forcibly.
"Paleeese," the stranger said and place both of his hands against the side of his head. "You two are like small children."
"We are not!" Steven said.
"Yes you are," the stranger said.
"Are not!" Steven said.
"Are too," the stranger said.
"Stop!" Laura shouted. "Both of you, just stop."
"I can't believe he has me doing it now," the stranger said.
"You started it," Steven said.
"I did not," the stranger said.
"Did too," Steven said.
"Please, both of you stop, please!" Laura stood and looked at the stranger. As she took in his warm eyes, the curls that fell across his high forehead, the slope of his nose and the full lips just below the planes of his high cheeks, a sudden feeling of calm came over Laura. She reached out and touched his face and felt a warm flood into her as if warm water was filling her. She looked down at Steven and didn't feel the usual exasperation she always did during times like this. She felt as if she was standing in the presence of greatness, of someone special, a spirit.
"Who are you?" she asked in a whisper.
"I'm a spirit," he replied.

"I'm not," Steven said.

"Can we stop this, please?" Steven said exasperated.

"Did too," Laura said.
"Did not!" Steven countered.
"Did," Laura said forcefully.
"Whatever!" Steven said and fell silent.

"Okay, like I said, it was one night at her house," Steven said, his voice growing softer. "The lights went out and we were pitched into total darkness. Granny began laughing and then told me not to worry. She said the Haraara would watch over us."

”Steven-n-n-n-n-n,” – Laura’s voice bounced off the rocky area surrounding the caves. She thought Steven was gone, roasted off by that big Red Dragon who was seething with anger. She couldn’t forget those eyes of the beast – those enormous hellish Black hole eyes which swallow the power to think of anything, apart from escaping, perhaps.

“Laura,” echoes another voice, “are you okay, dear?” Laura looked around herself but couldn’t see a soul. She was standing on a narrow trail near the cave and the ground was still some good thirty minutes of trekking away – and that is if she would climb down like a crazy maniac. At her current pace it might well have taken beyond an hour. Climbing down the hill was their only hope as the thickest of forest surrounded the rocky region. Such seemed the thickness of the trees from up where she was standing that it appeared like nothing but green foliage for acres and acres of land. But the point was where was Steven?

“”Steven,” she whispered as she heard a rustle near her. It surely couldn’t be the dragon, or could it be. Her heart skipped several beats and she started to sweat.

“Steven,” she whispered again, ”are you around?”

“Hey, anybody in there? Laura, is that you?” Daniel yelled back.

Laura whispered a “yes”

“Why the hell are you whispering? Didn’t you see that that stupid red monster went to the right just after I sneaked through?””

“Sneaked through is fine but where are you now , Daniel?” said Laura, still searching for Daniel who was nowhere to be seen.

“I can see from where I am. From where you are standing, come some ten to twelve steps to further right and then look up,” Daniel hollered,” and please make it quick. I can’t hold out any longer.“

Laura rushed through the narrow trail and there she saw him, managing somehow, clinging to the walls. “Did you climb up the rocks, Daniel,” squeaked Laura in joy, as she saw Daniel hanging there, somehow.

“Didn’t know my that my hobby would save my life one day,” he smirked, “now come quick, stand there with your face to the stones. I will put my feet on your shoulders and then jump off, okay?”

“I am a superwoman, alright, ain’t I?” Laura giggled. These two sure had a sense of humor in toughest of times.
Daniel put his left foot on Laura’s left shoulder and then right on her right shoulder. Laura balanced her against the stone. And there, he jumped off her shoulder to land carefully on his feet. He sat there stooping for some time. Laura knew he was recollecting what had happened over the past few minutes. She knew he needed a hug. She walked towards him and wrapped her arms around Steve who had just risen to stand upright. He was not accustomed to this closeness from Laura and nor was he comfortable with such display of affections, ordinarily. But today was no ordinary day, after all. He too held her close and squished her gently, playfully.

“Why are you breathing so heavily?” he asked Laura who was still had her arms around him. She let her a little loose.

“Hey, I thought that it was you, nervous and all and possibly the fact that you had never ever h-,” but her eyes widened and her mouth got shut when she saw what surrounded them.

“Watch out Daniel,” she pushed Daniel’s head down, just in nick of time as. Even stooped, Daniel felt a magnitude of heat on his body that he had never felt before. It was if he was walking inside a volcano. He jerked his head upwards to notice the stone set on fire. The Dragon was back and she was not alone. She had four other dragons with her and each of them was at least twice as big as the Red Dragon. Daniel could only say “Let’s run –“ before all four of the dragon’s let out there wraith at him, setting the path ahead of him on fire.

Laura was nowhere to be seen. Thoughts of varying emotions started to enter his head and he yelled out, “Laura,” more in hope than anything else. He was very surprised when he heard a voice in return. Not a human voice but voice of tapping of feet against the hard rocks. It was coming from the directions where the dragon were hovering over. He quickly stooped under a stone formation which formed a kind of a cave in which little dragons would play. He thought long and hard, searching for an opportune moment to go for Laura’s safety. He knew she was out there somewhere and what he needed now was a chance.

The flapping of the dragon’s wings could still be heard by him. Possibly they were still around, searching for them.

“Dragons are not supposed to be this smart?” he murmured,” they are the dumbest of animals which have inhabited this earth. All they know is spitting fire but nothing more than that. I bet someone is control -” Before Daniel could finish what he was saying, he saw something he never thought he would. Four Dragon’s came zeroing in on him as he got his head out of the little cave, but that is not what surprised him. What surprised him was – “

153211121212.content:
A shining thing was hanging through the teeth of the largest dragon of them all the blue spotted one. He managed to see it from afar since the brightness from that bling was noticeable or miles. The Dragons’ increased the pace with which they glided towards Steven which had him rushing for cover; He felt as if they were going to crush against his human body but of course that wasn’t to happen for Dragons were not here to kill him; they were here to deliver a message to someone. Just nearby to where Steven stood, all the four dragons hovered over as if trying to ascertain whether it was for whom the message scroll was. Steven looked stealthily at them and then jumped to hide behind a tiny crevice in which his body could somehow managed to squeeze in. He peeped from behind the stone structure, now looking at the Dragons with a mixture of awe and reverence. There was something magical in the flight of a dragon, a grace which can’t be comprehended until you see it from up close, like the place from where Steven was fortunate to be.
The Dragons still hovered around that place and opened their tiny narrow mouth every now and then to let out a noise which was more soothing than shrill. When Steven saw the incessant flying and hovering as if waiting for something, he straightaway knew that something was different because if they were here to kill him they would have destroyed the whole place by now, turning the whole place into a Lava reservoir in no time. He had also managed to steal a look in the dragon’s eyes, especially the Blue one. It was something which was totally different to what it was when he manhandled their eggs, a little while back. Unlike the narrow, black hole of eyes which they possessed before, now they were whiter and wider, as if a different saintly soul inhabited those body than the monster soul which resided in it before. The intermittent noise which escaped their mouth was also no longer like those war cries before but bore the softness of a hymn, or a prayer. It appeared as if they were calling out somebody; it had a hint of softness in it. One of the Dragon slowly descended and landed to nearby the place Steven was hiding. It made a different noise from its horse sized throat which brought others to the same place, too. Now, all four dragons stood on the tiny rocks surrounding the stone structure where Steven was hiding. Strangely, Steven was not worried. It was as if he knew that they were here for something good, something noble. And anyway, even if he hid behind the structure he knew he couldn’t do it for long because sometime of the day he had to come out.

“Why not, now?” he murmured. Just then, he had a noise from all the dragons as if they understood what he said and they welcomed it. Steven smiled and slowly crawled out, with his eyes still fixed on the Blue dragon which was the biggest of them all.

Steven dusted off his clothes and stood tall, trying to show to the dragons that he wasn’t afraid. The Blue Dragon then moved towards him, as if trying to test his resolve. Steven’s heartbeat went a notch higher. He hadn’t seen Dragon from up close. The Blue plume shined in a mysterious gold color as did the scroll which hung from his teeth. The dragon crooked its neck towards Steven, sniffed him and then flapped its giant wings twice. To Steven it felt as if a mini gust of airwave had hit him. All the dragons flapped their wings twice and made a noise similar to the merry noise they had made just a while ago. The place was bustling with their noises in no time. For no reason that he knew or understood, Steven raised his arms in the mid-air, as if trying to calm them down. Strangely, the commotion stopped and the Dragons looked intently in Steven’s direction for some time.

“What are you here for?” he asked, hoping that the dragons may understand it. Steven didn’t believe if it was him talking to the Dragon. It was if he was in a trance, sleepwalking through the events and the conversations but yet he felt so alive and in a zone of elevated consciousness.

The Blue Dragon looked towards the other dragons and then moved further towards Steven. He bent his neck and placed the scroll at Steven’s feet and then stepped back to where he was standing before. Steven looked till the blue Dragon went back to its original place and then and picked up the scroll. The scroll red in color shone in a radiant brilliance as he looked at it. A silvery white string hung from its right side. Steven pulled it and the Scroll flung open in his hands. On it, there were symbols painted in Golden color.

They were not alphabets but those symbols were something similar to what Steven had remembered from those prehistoric cave arts. Hundreds of lines zigzagged in the scroll with no apparent meaning which Steven could glean out from it. Steven downed the scroll from the front of his eyes and looked towards the Blue Dragon standing in front of him.

“I do not understand it,” he said to Blue Dragon. The Dragon grunted and looked towards the other dragons as if reproaching the other dragons for some act of theirs. Slowly, it moved forward towards Steven and gently tugged the scroll which was in Steven’s hands and took the scroll in its teeth. Then, it took out its blue wiry tongue and wiped it all over the scroll. With a gentlest of fire forced through his nostrils, he set the scroll on fire for a second or so and then exhaled to put it off. Steven stood there wondering about the activities of the dragon.

“Is it some kind of a secret message which comes to life when put against fire?” he wondered. He had heard of such scrolls and messages in folklore. But this guess of his nosedived, when the other Dragon standing nearby the Blue one, clasped the scroll in its teeth and did the same thing which was done by the Blue dragon. It then tossed it to the third dragon which did the same thing as the previous two dragons had. Finally, it reached the fourth Dragon which clasped in its teeth and let out fire from its open mouth.

The scroll was on fire for good few minutes this time instead of seconds. All the Dragons as well as Steven looked intently onto the scene. A minute later the whole scroll was gone and what remained instead were ashes of the most dazzling golden color he had ever seen. The fourth dragon which had turned the scroll into ashes looked up at Steven and then moved towards him.

“Now what?” Steven asked but there was no change in the Dragon’s behavior or its walk. It simply kept on moving towards Steven as the rest of the three dragons stood where they were. When it reached Steven it bowed its head in Steven’s feet for a while.

Steven didn’t know what to do or say and instinctively reached for the dragon’s head to caress it. The Dragon purred with the most satisfaction laced purr and then looked into Steven’s eyes. Steven too looked into those pink pupils and then patted the Dragon its head, one more time. From then on till the time the Dragon didn’t blink, Steven saw a human figure floating in those wondrous eyes of the Dragon.

1532111212121.content:
“Who was that?” the words escaped Steven’s mouth. Just then, the dragon blinked. Steven could distinctly remember that the human form floating in those eyes was of a child with a bush of golden hair. By the looks of the dress the kid was dressed in, it seemed to be a girl why else would it wear flowery dresses and pink bow on his tiny hair?
“What was a figure doing in those Dragon eyes and that too a kid?” he murmured to himself, ”What did he want to show me?” Steven went towards the Dragon again and patted his head gently and then caressed it. He then looked into its eyes, hoping to see that human form again but instead what he saw was a whole lot of other images - a secluded cottage by the river, a tornado gradually building up to stand as tall as the mountains and that of a cottage being ravaged and plundered by that vicious tornado. He kept looking the dragon’s eyes, scanning and searching for those human forms in those eyes again but he couldn’t find any. What he saw was more images of tornados plundering forest, the rivers the cities. The two set of images he saw one after another had no connection whatsoever to his fuzzy brain. He let out an exasperated sigh. The Dragon blinked and poof went the images in those eyes.

“A cottage, a tornado, plundering of the cottage by that tornado - what does all that mean?” he muttered under his breath and looked towards the blue Dragon, more in hope than for answer.
“Can you help me?” he said but when the blue Dragon didn’t answer Steven turned his back on it in frustration and hopelessness.
“What is that they are trying to show me?” he wondered.

Just then, the Blue Dragon let out a noise which caught attention of the other dragons and they looked towards it. The sudden noise got Steven jerking his head in their direction, too. As if energized by Steven’s act, they flapped their wings together vigorously once more and dust around the place started to rise along with the ashes. In no time, the air around them turned more golden than brown because of those ashes scattered on the ground which mixed with the dust. The Dragons kept on flapping their wings, letting out shrill cries till the gold dust interweaved with each and every dust particle surrounding the place they stood. If somebody would have looked that scene from afar, it would have looked as if the gold dust from the heaven was falling upon Steven. It was a beautiful, surreal and spectacular scene and something which would have been enjoyed by even those who were at peace in their heart which clearly Steven wasn’t. As his mind was still trying to connect the dots of the human figure which he saw in the Dragon’s eyes, he was brain was just simply registering the fact that there was dust all around him – not gold laced just plain old dust.
Thinking about the mystery surrounding the human forms in those dragon eyes had numbed his capacity to notice, it seemed. As if realizing this fact, the Blue Dragon looked towards the other Dragon and they all stopped waving their wings at the same instant. The sudden vacuum after the incessant fluttering did the trick and caught Steven’s attention. After being ensured of Steven’s attention, the Blue Dragon waved its wings in a curious haphazard motion which for some reason didn’t appear all that haphazard to Steven’s eyes.

“I have seen this before somewhere! Where?” thought Steven as he kept looking at all the Dragons doing the same thing with their wings. Apart from the pleasant harmony which tied their act together there was something which struck him. He saw these figures and lines in that scroll! And then, the Dragons stopped with their act. Not a single Dragon moved for some more time and curiously neither did the gold dust remained suspended in mid-air. Steven yelled out aloud,
”What are you trying to say?”

This time it was not the Dragons which replied to him but the gold dust which arranged itself neatly into a kind of pattern. There was a magical feel all around the place as the falling gold dust arranged itself into a set of recognizable symbols, closely resembling the alphabets which clustered together to form words. A smile spread across Steven’s face as he saw the beautiful scene unravel in front of his eyes.

Till now, the words were,
“The Dragon Lord seeks your help.”
Steven could surely read what was written but couldn’t comprehend it. How could a normal person like him supposedly help the Lord of the Dragons, itself. Was he mistaken for someone he was not? Was he ready for it? Who was the Dragon Lord? Many questions swam through Steven’s mind.

Steven wondered what he could lose by undertaking such an adventure – his life? What else has he got to lose, anyway but if he lets go of this task he might lose two most important things to him – the self-esteem and then Laura. What would he without either of them? He had his answer and now all he could see the clarity of the situation in front of him. This was his chance perhaps to be the savior which he always craved for when he was a child. A faint smile flickered across his face as his mind went briefly to childhood days when he would fight with paper swords and against paper dragons. He took a deep, long breath as he prepared himself to use his palm sized dagger against Dragon’s
Lord. What Irony!

He looked into the eyes of the Blue dragon standing in front of him, nodded and said,

“I am ready, friend.”

All the four dragons let out a roar, as if celebrating the homecoming of a great warrior. Steven moved towards the dragons as all four of them hopped towards him. He gave a hug to all of them and heard back a gurgling purr in return.
Blue put his head down to the ground and curved his back too to enable Steven climb onto him. Steven had never rode a horse leave alone a dragon and his nerves showed as he nearly stumbled in his first attempt to ride on top of him only to be saved by a friendly shove by the little black dragon who stood there, as if waiting for this to happen. Steven hung onto the zig zag fleshy thorn like structure on the Dragon’s neck and pulled his body against it. Blue stooped further and gave his body a little jerk to the right and upwards to balance Steven upon him.

“Phew,” Steven’s feeling of relief came out of his mouth as he balanced himself on top of Blue. Blue craned his neck back to see Steven and he nodded back to him. Steven gently patted Blue’s neck andc caressed the scaly structure on Blue’s neck. Blue was now slowly and steadily rising up on his legs, trying his best to keep this act of his as slow as possible but such was the enormous height of this fifteen foot creature that a jerk or two were inevitable. Steven kept on clinging hard to Blue’s rock like body and the jerks didn’t harm him much apart from one or two leap of the heart. He was now preparing to ready himself for the flight of his life and he slowly closed his eyes in anticipation of it.

With Blue’s ravishing mane as the only thing to hold by Steven heard his stomach churn when Blue flapped its silvery wings which almost brushed Steven’s legs. The flutter of the wings caused so much noise that the neighing of the dragon’s as they took off from the elevated rock was subdued in it. All which remained now was a quick repetition of the sound made by the enormous wings of Blue and all the other dragons - “Phat..Phick…Phat..Phick..Phat” Blue looked towards the other three dragons and revved up the wings even more and lo, Steven perched atop the most beautiful of dragons of the world began rising into the warm air which surrounded that place. Steven wrapped his legs around the Dragon’s back as much as he could and away they went higher and higher into the ocean blue sky. Steven felt like he would vomit when he looked down to the ground amidst the jerky up and down motions of the dragon. It was as if a roller-coaster was set free to roam in the higher environs but Steven was not yet ready to enjoy it. They went yet higher into the sky and Steven closed his eyes hoping to cure the feeling of doom encircling his head. He was feeling like he could slip any moment from his far from safe seat especially because the he had not much to hold to. Just then, Blue tucked Steven’s legs between his hind toes as if securing him before unleashing more adventures on him. Steven suddenly realized that he felt far more snug and comfortable on Blue now. Did Blue feel his insecurity and agony?, he wondered. But how could their be this connect between them when Steven had apparently no connection to Dragon or had never ever seen one dragon in his whole life.

Before Steven could pain his head more with thinking about the non-existent connect, Blue raised his nose skywards and accelerated his ascent to the sky even further. At first Steven was stunned but now, he was feeling increasingly more secure with every passing second of ascent. In fact, he felt so secure that he freed his hand and let go the hair of Blue which he had held tight until then.

He used them to pat Blue, as if egging him on to go even higher and even swifter into the air. Steven was now completely in the moment – no fear, no undue thoughts was now near him and his mind was now a complete blank living in the present moment in all its glory. He let out a “yoohooo” as Blue chased the other dragons who were apparently racing with Blue now. Blue did a little somersault to cut through the arrow formation of the little black dragons and positioned itself to the head of the arrow shape. Together they tore through the air as Steven spread his arms wide, as if he was flying. If this wasn’t flying then he didn’t know what flying was! With his arms still spread out and his eyes open he looked down to see how far above he was and all he could see was little blue spots on the mother earth sprinkled between vast expanses of green. To top it all, the earth’s curvature was visible from the height which they were flying. What a scene this was! He felt alive alright; alive and kicking the air some five hundred feet above the Earth!

Such was the calmness which surrounded Steven in that moment, that it took some time for him to realize that the Dragons were no longer rising higher into the sky. They had decreased their velocity considerably too and all five of them – including Steven – were like gliding through the air more than anything else. Steven had now registered the fact that the time of the testing hour was to begin. Some fifty feet away, he saw a beautiful rainbow sparkling away in all its glory but it wasn’t the rainbow alone which caught his attention; it was the fact that the rainbow had a silvery dab smack right in the center of the bend and the dragons were now lining up, one behind the another, as if to enter the rainbow one by one. Blue was the one leading them now as the rest three lined them up courteously behind him.

The sparkle of the Rainbow was now falling on the Blue’s body and in the next five seconds it hit Steven’s body too. He felt a definite shiver run through his body, as if somebody sagely had placed his palms on his forehead, and slowly all the seven colors bathed his body in the glory of the colors. A new sense of consciousness had pervaded his body and in that stream of consciousness he saw the figure of an Old man who was infinitely old if one went by the ripe whiteness which colored his hair and beard. His eyes too spoke of the years of wisdom he had accumulated in himself but the aura on his face and forehead betrayed the years – a youth, in the best of his health would have been exceedingly proud of the freshness his face possessed.

Though Steven knew nothing about this old man, but such was the grace and calm in the old man’s aura that Steven’s head bowed almost by himself to the Godly figure in front of him.

“The Keeper of the Dragon welcomes you,” he said, in a baritone which hit the deepest oceans of Steven’s soul.
Steven felt a surge of emotions running through him and he exclaimed,

“Father!” with stream of warm water running down his cheeks.

Steven needn’t know what all questions he needed to answer since what was appearing before him next was the mother of all questions he had answered in his life. A sinuous dragon, red in color with green veins running through his body, appeared from behind where the four dragons stood. A ghastly stench filled the place as the dragon rose up higher and higher in the air till he hovered over them all. The Dragons looked around to see the curious figure rising above them all. It was unlike anything they had ever heard or seen in their lifetime. It was as if the Red Dragon was afflicted with wounds which sat all over his body, waiting to be burst open. Steven was the most stressed of them all as he knew that whatever be the case he wouldn’t sit and fly on this dragon, if that was the reason he was here. He knew that he had to go to the Dragon Lord but if he had to go search for the Dragon Lord seated on this beast then Lord save him. Or was he the Dragon Lord himself? This question stressed him even more. If this monster was the Dragon Lord then he was surely not a role model in terms of hygiene which other Dragons seemed very particular about.
For instance, look at that Blue Dragon standing there. Now, although he is petrified of the Red Monster there is something of a class about him as he stoops down with that carefully combed mane flowing backwards, those white polished teeth as if he brushed thrice an hour and those super clean nostrils which were devoid of mucus or any stupid hair growth. Steven’s hand quickly went to his nose to pluck the stray nose hairs which were hanging their tiny heads out from it. Then he looked at the little Black dragon whose feet looked more pedicured than Kim Kardarshian of the modern world and his wings – wow look at those spick-a-span wings – which danced ever so slightly every time the little one tried to block his eyes using it. He was afraid not only for himself but for his self-image too; think what would Laura think of him when she sees him with this ghastly Red Monster.

“Off all the Dragons of the world, what did he do to deserve this rotten piece of Meat?” he wondered but another train of thought which went something like “What have you done in your life to deserve a dragon, Monsieur?” quickly derailed the first train of thought. Of course he felt at peace now because he knew in his heart that he was a worthless piece of crap who deserved a limping rat to sit on at the very best and the fact that he was getting a dragon, however unsanitary, would do him more good than bad, anyway. The Red Dragon came down to sit between all of them, resulting in a stench equivalent to hundred tonne of rotten hen. Steven looked at the other Dragons and cursed them as they had big, long wings to cover their tiny nostrils whereas all he had was his shirt sleeve and that too let through some of the stench. He Red Dragon looked all around and opened his mouth to say something. But before he could say anything there was a large thud heard resulting from the little dragons going unconscious. Steven wondered what kind of magic was it but before he could consider more about it, the gust of rotten smell from the Red Dragon’s mouth hit him and he vomited, instantaneously. He bent over to let out what all he had consumed which was primarily water and Dragon eggs. As Steven wiped of his last remnants of vile, he thanked the stomach for digestion which essentially hid the fact that he had sneakily feasted upon Dragon’s egg while they were hiding in the cave.

Steven heard a curious noise as if somebody complaining and he looked at the Red Dragon, who was wrapping around his torn wings around his own nose and glaring towards Steven with a look of disdain in it.

“What is the matter with you?” it said in a squeaky voice which hardly justified his ultra-sized personality. It was more like a horse was given a sparrow’s voice – not even duck’s!

“Excuse me!” said Steven who was offended by the stupid question. It was also a true fact that he managed to utter these words because had gained confidence having heard the squeaking little voice of the Red Beast. He felt his empty stomach could gurgle
way more loudly than the sound uttered by the stupid Dragon.

“This is plain disgusting,” the Red Dragon squeaked again, “don’t you have any regards for cleanliness or what?”
Steven tried to search for traces of a practical joke in the Red Dragon’s mannerisms but nothing felt comic about him – well, apart from his voice – and the dragon stared right back at him with the most serious of death stares. It is funny how a small little thing can change perspective about anybody and Steven was experiencing it to the hilt as he imagined himself pounding the Red Dragon on top of his head. How would he reach the top of the head was somebody else’s problem at the moment.

Steven looked at Blue and to find what he thought of this Red beast. TO be fair, Blue was never intimidated by the Red Dragon and all what he bothered was for the safety of his own respiratory mechanism. He had held his breath for some five minutes now and he knew that he couldn’t do it any longer. He held onto the last signs of breathlessness and prepared himself to inhale the putrid air all around that place. But before that Blue had to exhale the most he could so that he could inhale the most he could to be secure from the agony for as long as possible. Three- Two – One and lo, Blue exhaled with all his might and a Blue streak of flame shot across the smelly air, probably cursing its luck, and landed right on the foot of the Red.

“Whoa – whoa, brother,” Red Dragon exclaimed, “don’t be too excited,” he said as he hopped back five steps. “And anyways, I am not here to fight.”

What the Red Dragon didn’t say was that he was a yellow blooded mammal who didn’t had it in him to fight – he never could. All he ever did was to attend the Live Portrait sessions by Chinese Artists who used him to create magnificent art. However, considering the enormous size of the Red he could never finish their portrait; that was the precise reason one of the frustrated Chinese painter had tried to set him on fire because seeing him reminded him of unfinished work, every single minute of his life.
“Blue, do you know why is he here for?” Steven asked Blue mistaking his fire throwing act as a sign of attacking. Blue wanted to shrug his shoulders but sadly evolution hadn’t given him that option.

“You little mess,” Red jumped into the conversation, “can’t you talk to me directly?”

As he did this, the Red Dragon lost all control on his lungs and the result was that he was exhaling fireballs all around him. It was quite a sight seeing a dragon about to be killed in his own fire and exotic photographers, if there would have been any, would have lined up for the front row seats of such a scene.

Steven stood their viewing that scene for some time; he wanted to clap and whistle and call all his friends to see the irony of the situation but some grey matter in the upper compartment of the head told him that this was his moment to run away to hide from the Red Beast.
