He also knew that once he would survive he would return to be the tall pain in the neck he was slowly but surely building into. He had to run and that moment was now. With his still fixed at the raging fire, he turned towards the tree to run away from the spot. Then, just when he had turned his back on the Red Beast, the human in Steven came to the fore; it made him feel that it was his duty to help the Dragon out. Or maybe, it was the little ego which craved for a Dragon sized boost. Whatever it was it made him stop and walk towards the Dragon, who was still hunched over his knees.

Steven ran to his side, ignoring the giggling sound he was hearing from somewhere. Of course it was Dragon Blue who was overtly amused by something or the other. Steven gave Blue the most cursory of sideways glance and raised an eyebrow in recognition of the fact that Blue was seen rolling in the dusty ground. Strange, he thought to himself but kept rushing to be Red’s side. When he was some three steps away from him, he took a long breath, preparing himself for the breathless experience which awaited him. Soon, he reached there to stand shoulder to shoulder (or shoulder to knee) with Red in his time of crisis. He tapped him on his knees (which certainly felt odd and yes, squishy) and said-

“Any issues, friend?” What happened next was what Steven never expected.

“Gotcha,” Red said with the widest of smiles as he hugged his new friend Steven. All sixty ton of Red Dragon squeezed Steven to fill his heart with utmost glee.

Steven didn’t know what hit him. So Red was faking the panting et al all this while so that he could trick Steven into his scrubby wings! Now he understood why Blue was seen rolling on the floor laughing. So he knew about it all; Or was it that he was just guessing that this was to happen. He marked it as a to-do thing in his head which was getting increasingly clouded by the smell of the beast wrapping him. The stench of the Red Dragon was now rapidly drenching every pore of his being and he tried to push back Red; but it felt like an ant pushing against a combo package of whale and a dinosaur. What was most strange about it all though was the reek didn’t make him vomit, this time out. Maybe he was growing immune to it. Steven noted this point in his mind so that he could quote it when his mother would nag him about being stubborn and all. When Steven caught himself thinking about his mother while he was hugging Red it gave him a strange feeling, as if he was comparing his mother to a beast. Well however apt that description might have been, it didn’t sound right in his head and he let out a cry of frustration.

“What…what. w-what? H-hey are you, okay?” Red said as he saw Steven’s face had turned ghostly white because of the mixture of several emotions – anger, frustration, suffocation being the top three at this time.

“Can you care to leave me out of your crab clutch?”

“Crab, where is the crab?” Red jumped with horror and looked around to search for the crab.

“I said crab clutch, beast. Idiom. Heard it?” Steven gnashed his teeth as he said it, standing tall on his own feet as Red still jumped around searching for the non-existent crab.

“I am not idiot, Steven. How mean of you?” Red Dragon replied, with a look of hurt in his eyes.

“Hey, I said Idiom not idiot,” Steven said, in reply to that insinuation.

“Oh,” was all Red could manage to say as a look of embarrassment flashed in the Dragon’s eye as he realized that it was his old malfunctioning ears which had felt him down yet again. It was too bad that that there was no hearing machine in production those days because if someone needed it then it was the Dragon clan, and mostly the older one of them – which they all were in fact.

“Crab?” said Steven and raised his eyebrow in order to ask him what was up with the crab thing he saw.

“No, no. I knew there was a crab, somewhere. Where is it?” the Dragon dance had begun yet again and Red hopped all over the place, shook every single muscle to drop off the crab which he thought was perched somewhere on his body. Steven wanted to stop him from doing it but this was a scene which was not an everyday slice of life. A Dragon hopping and jumping as if running around to catch its own tail was a tale for the ages.

“This is why I hate my size,” Red yelled as he shook those large wings but nothing dropped off from them.

This could have gone on quite a few more minutes if not hours, if that human in Steve had not made another of those guest appearances. That human in Steve was a bloody party pooper but it knew how to choose its moments and it only arrived once the entertaining joke ran the risk of being run thin to its bare skin. This worked was doubly beneficial for Steve – firstly, Steve could enjoy the fun to the maximum and secondly, it made him feel good at the end, after all.
This is what the human is about after all.

“There is NO crab, stupid beast?” he yelled at Red Dragon. Red Dragon stopped in its step and looked back towards Steven, as if he would cry any second.

“I am not stupid, Steven, I am j-just,” a lump equivalent to three normal sized human formed in the Dragon’s throat as he tried to complete his sentence, “I a-am j-just Bloody old. Boooohooohoohoooo” he couldn’t control himself any further as buckets of tear ran down his flat face and thudded the ground.

Steven knew he had to stop this crying soon – not because of the human thing – but because if he let Red cry, the place could be soon flooded with them. And maybe, there was a bit of the human thing, too.

Snark! Snark, wake up.” she tugged the little tail of the tiny dragon. He opened one eye and groaned,

“What’s that? Ouch!” Rhea awoke abruptly, swatting her hand at nothing until Snark appeared. “What? Snark? You little beast, what are you up to? Must you cause such a commotion when you show up?” she ranted.

Snark flitted up to the mantel and dropped the note, which sailed down to the floor like a dead leaf. Rhea reached down, almost tripping over a table to get it. She read it quickly. “Oh great specks of fibremeal! it can’t be.” Her face goes pale as she assumed the worst scenario. A note from Seer was usually vital and they were rare recently, but this call for the One Kin--that meant big trouble.

Rhea looked at the time--three hours ‘til dawn. Just time enough she thought to rouse them. She grabbed her over cloak and rammed her feet into her boots.

“Oh Snark! Tell her we’ll be there. Regular spot. Soon.”

Snark, however, had already disappeared.

“Drat that creature!” Rhea muttered and slammed out of the hut.

It took her three hours to rouse everyone, thanks to Topaz, the blind. He offered to climb the path up to the forest to find Orin while she raced around the village. She was utterly exhausted by the time she reached Silvertwine Arrow, the grove of sacred trees, the favourite meeting place of seers from all realms. Already, Topaz, Orin and the Twins had assembled, the younger two wide eyed with excitement and curiosity. It was their first call as heirs of Laddenstrike, their grandfather’s estate. The younger twin had also received his gift-and so the tradition continued.

“Calm down , you two.” she said as they ran to meet her. “This is serious business if I’m any judge.”

By the 8th hour of the morning the gathering was complete, except for the Seer. Snark had delivered the message a little late, as he had popped in for breakfast and forgot the time. She had been watching their arrival and waiting to see Orin, and timed her own entry with his. She rode on Tak and dismounted just outside the sacred grounds.

“Friends.” she spoke as she walked into their midst, “thank you for coming so promptly. I wish it was for better tidings, but unfortunately...I need your help. The whole village does, maybe even the far reaches. A great destruction approaches us and we must warn the people, plan for defense. The mayor will not hear me so it is up to you, the people of the Right. The council must be pressed to hear me--prepare so disaster, as in times past, can perhaps be avoided. I must leave you to do what you can here while I meet with others afar--to get better sight of the situation. I do not want to leave. My place is here--but we are small, I, yet young in power, only trust my vision in spite of my youth.

Orin, you ,who knew my parentage, my journey. vouch for me, old tutor. I seek most of all your wisdom in this though I am most certain of myself.” She bowed briefly in her plea.

“Yes , daughter, I do thee vouch. My old bones tuned to earth’s shatter, have felt the wind of shadow , too. It reeks of old evil. Memory fails not for hours of near death. I fear,-
friends, we must heed, before too late.”

Many nodded.

“But what if it doesn’t work? How can we possibly influence the council and will Melnon listen? He has taken much power over them--more I think than you realize.”

“I think he may be part of the problem to come, knowing or not.” Topaz the blind said cryptically.


“Then we will alert the village ourselves, prepare as best we can while Seer raises some help.”

“ And we will offer our assistance here and now,” piped up a small unfamiliar voice.
Seer looked down. Sitting in the crook of an aged alder were two elves. The speaker jumped up and bows, slinging his bow. The elder white-haired elf scrunched his eyes and

“Elves!” an astonished shout form the twins.

“Well, I’ll be,” said Rhea, “I never.”

“Welcome,” Deidre spoke. “thank you for the offer.”

“We could do no less. We are the protectors of this grove.”

“We?” Rhea said.

“Yes, our people. Oh, we stay out of sight mostly.”

“But worse danger than your human foolishness is afoot,” interjected the elder, “Danger for us all.” he looked straight at Seer.

“You’re a seer too!” she said, “Then you’ve seen--? It’s true!” Her worried tone almost got the better of her.

“Lass, we’d best counsel and then you be off to the great Mountain and I’ll to Lower Cavern. Fear not, for I will be here in your absence. Orin will bespeak me. And Snark, he is still in your service not doubt?

“Yes, how did you know?”

“Oh, Snark and I go way back. A story for another time,” he sounded wistful unlike his earlier tone. “Uhem,” he brought himself back to the present. “Well come , Seer. Lad, you stay. Listen. Help.”

She turned to Orin. “Take care and thank you.”

The group turned to discuss procedures as the two seers walked toward the glade. The elf escorted Seer to a quiet spot by the river Esplan where they sat on Mute Rock. It was peaceful there and quiet in a strange way as if not a part of the real world.

“Sit here,” he motions to a particularly grey yet mottled rock. She sat on its cool form and in a moment it was warm. Noticeably so. Her face showed her expression of puzzlement and he explained, “ This is Mute rock. We have permission to meet here and he can be quite the host when he wants to be.”

“ Thank you , Mute rock,” she acknowledged, feeling a little silly. She herself talked to trees, so she was not really surprised.
Serious again, she asked, “How bad is it?”

He looked at her and said gravely, “He has destroyed Oberla, Mylanda and holds Caprica. The trolls in Foreland have moved north, hoping not to have to engage him and that not finding them there, he might spare their homes. I have reports all over elfdom, on the edges of your world, of disastrous effects already on the mists of Forever Unseeing and Time Beyond. It seems he has a deeper power than Ringman of Old and no one yet knows how to defeat him. There are old prophecies. I study them now. No avail. The trolls say nothing. Gnomes do not have much written lore. Giants are reluctant to deal with anyone. It may lie with your people--the answer--you must meet with the others, the magics of the crystal, dragon lore-or even pure human lore. I have spoken with Tiara Main. She , like you, has had visions and seeks the Record Books of Tair Cask. You would be best to travel to Cair Daval and the Mountain Masters, though there are rumours from our flyers that Eban has left this world--he long held the key to the tomb of Mysteries Long Buried. Who his successor is I know not. That is all I can tell you, except that it has befallen you Young One, to discover the ebb and flow to this dread.

“Yes, so it seems. What you say burdens my heart. yet more determined I am to stop this. Surely more than I are to fight. Already , you have given me strength, and faith. I will do as you suggest and head to Cair Daval first, as fast as Tak can fly.” she decided as she got up from the rock.

“Yes, well, I can perhaps help that. “Your dragon-- a fine ally. Here,” he held out a small bag of granules. “Rope this around Tak’s neck. It will give him further strength and power in time of need.”

“Thank you for all your help,” she shook his hand and turned to go.

“And Seer,”

Yes,”

“Take Snark with you. I imagine he is rather a bother at times, as befits his name. But he knows more than you may think, forgets more than he remembers---but invaluable insight and information he possesses. He will come through in the end.”

“Yes, I am learning that.” she smiled, thinking about the lazy little thing who liked to sleep on her shoulder. She’d never seen him do that with Teriel.

She mounted Tak, whom she found Orin and in her mind she called for Snark.

“Yes, yes, I’m here already.” Snark appeared, his mood not having altered. “Where are we going?”

“To Cair Daval.” she replied. “Know the way?”

“Know the way!” he sputtered, totally insulted. “Why I’d know the way to that forsaken barren with my eyes closed- just so I’d always avoid it. Why of all the earth’s shelters would you want to go there?” he ranted. “Ok ,Tak, now head west to the Aura Sea but follow the shore south.” he ordered as if born to lead, before getting an answer to his question.

He sat up on Seer’s shoulder like a little captain, nose pointed into the wind. She shoved her crystal into her sack and began to explain.

“We have to meet other seers to find out how to stop this. No one knows, according to Elf Eidderin.”

“Eidderin!” Is he still around? hiding out, no doubt. They all do, now. Like some dragons I could mention. Cowards.”

“Oh now, Snark. That’s not it!”

“I know. He’d know, old Eidderin. You are blessed if he let you into his confidence. I guess you told him about me, uh?”

“Well, he brought it up actually.”

“No! Well, what do you say to that, hiding out and spying as well. Not a seer for nothing! So did he say how we, uh, met?”

“No, we didn’t have time.”

“Ah, no matter. Better to be on with the task at hand. On there now Tak.” he attended to directions and stood a little higher on her shoulder.

Well, it has been ages. I was very young when I came once before. But I will try to remember. Let me think.” The little dragon closed his eyes, then opened them to gaze around obliquely. “Move toward that centre peak, Tak, the one that is rounded and smaller than the rest.”

Tak obliged and brought them in close. Snark continued, ”now circle around slowly and let me get my bearings. If I remember rightly there should be a..yes, there it is, see that dark shadowy spot on the side of the mount? Head there. That should tell us further what we want to know.”

“Runes,” she guessed.

“ Yes, this is the code for entry. You must interpret then and go to the very top of this mount, chant them three times as you walk in a circle. Then stand in the centre and wait.”Snark went on.” Funny, I’d forgotten all of this . Useless, ‘til now.”

“ You are a wonder, Snark,” Deidre praised. “Thank you. Now what do the runes say?”

Elanis touradis ladicai! over and over even though the master only did it twice, the echoes were thousands to my sensitive hearing. I just flapped about crazily,” he went on.

153231.content:
“Relax, Laura,” said Steven. “Beth isn’t here and I’m not making eyes at anyone. We’re here to find our way out.”

“Our way out of this forbidden hell? The very place where wars of long ago has left the ghosts of silent warriors, with experiences so gruesome that their minds have been tortured…And you pick on me for walking the wrong way. Everyway is the wrong way, Steven. Until you make it the right way.”

Steven stopped walking and folded his arms. “Hey, I didn’t pick on you, silly! You picked on me.”

“Sure,” Laura said mockingly. “I picked on you, but only after you complained like a crybaby. You act like Mr. Macho man near the girls, but you fall apart near me, your sister, when we’re in trouble.”

“Let’s just walk,” Steven said nonchalantly. “Arguing will get me nowhere. Especially with you! You could take us to our deaths.”

“Oh, really!” Laura raised her eyebrows and rolled her eyes. “We aren’t dead yet, although we are being watched by something or someone.”

Steven grunted a negative. “You and your imagination…”

They arrived at a small clearing between mighty tall trees and wished they hadn’t. “Ouch,” said Steven skipping on one foot. “Ooh, ouch, this really, really hurts.” He lowered his hands to rub the shin that he had hit against a tree trunk just before they had stepped into the clearing. But losing his balance he fell onto the slippery, slimy, green-leafed ground. As his senses had started spinning, he lay with eyes screwed shut, and once this most uncomfortable sensation passed, he realized Laura was saying something to him repeatedly. “Steven, please, are you all right? Please be all right, Steven!”

He pulled himself together enough to sit up. The effort made him whimper, but he poked into his body to make sure it was all in one place.

“Good meat! And he’s down on the ground,” a voice said.

“Oh, no!” Laura groaned, alarmed.

“Just joking,” A knight in full armor with the insignia of a fox on his chest appeared, making his way through the trees. “I didn’t mean to scare you guys, but we’re at war, and two lost people from God knows where are always suspect.”

“We’re from earth,” Steven said. “Although I don’t know how we’re here, how we found ourselves here.”

“I know how,” Laura said. “It is the weird contraption you were showing me, and we fell through something.”

“Time door,” smirked the knight. “Or maybe a worm hole. Earth you said? I never heard of it. It must be some Godforsaken place, out there.” He made a circle with his hand to indicate a probable place. “Or a blackhole of some kind, I’m not much learned about these things. I only know how to fight wars.”

Steven staggered to his feet, but grasped his knees, making a few pathetic sounds. “Let me,” the knight said, and without waiting for consent, he touched Steven’s knees and stroked down his shins all the way to his feet.

Feeling much better, Steven looked at the knight, surprised. “How did you do that? I thought I’d never walk again.”

“No problem,” the knight said. “I know a bit of the magic of healing. All my friends who are warring with me can do some magic, but not like His Majesty. He is the tops. He can even read minds.”

“That must be so inconvenient for you,” Laura said. “I certainly don’t want anyone reading my mind.”

“If you ever met his majesty, you wouldn’t say that. He is the most kind, most understanding, most forgiving master of all the masters, but if you approach him from his negative side, beware!”

“Well, maybe I keep away from him,” Laura said. “Thank you kindly, sir, for helping my stu… stupi…, my brother.”

Steven crinkled his nose at her.

The knight grinned. “If my master wants to meet you, he will find you,” he said. “There is no escaping him once he puts something in his mind.”

“Well, at least not at the moment, sir knight,” Steven said. “Can you show us a way to get out of the forest?”

“If that’s what you want. But the war is everywhere. Wherever you go you’ll meet beasts, beast masters, dragons, giants and even nice folks if you are lucky.”

“As long as we get out of this forest,” Laura said.

“Just beware of knights in black and giant women and lizard beasts that can become invisible,” the knight said, pointing toward a direction. There is a town there that is quieter than the others. Once you get there, you can figure out what to do.”

“Thank you, Sir,” Steven and Laura said in unison. Laura added, “I’m sure we’ll make it.”

The knight bowed at them in greeting and turned his back to go into the dense part of the woods. As he left, Laura thought she heard him mutter to himself, “If you can ever make it…”

They sat at the clearing on a log for a few minutes, then Laura got up to pick a few berries from the brush. I hope they are not poisonous, she thought, as she tasted one. It was exactly the kind of blackberry her grandmother used to make a jam out of. Recalling her brought tears to her eyes, but at least, they had something to quiet the pangs of hunger they were feeling.

Once the berries were eaten, Laura stood up and looked around. Miraculously the forest around them had taken the same shape and size all of a sudden.

“Which way did the knight say we should go?” Steven asked.

“This way! Oh, it looks the same in all directions. This way…No, this way…”

“You’re wrong, Laura, as usual. That way! Geez, I can’t even tell toward which direction the knight went.”

“This way!”

“That way!”

“This isn’t home and we’re not hitching a ride Steven. Use your head.”

“What about your head? Is it of any use? As it never is…”

Another argument, the consequences of which could separate the brother and sister forever…

Laura's eyes fluttered and she opened them to sunlight streaming in across her face. It took her a moment to cross the void between sleep and wake. Once she did, she sat up and looked around. This room was unfamiliar. How did they get here? When? And where was Steven?

"Steven?" she called out, turning her head left and right. She smiled when she saw him asleep in a rocking chair near the hearth. It looked like the most uncomfortable position to sleep in. She studied him. He looked so young while he slept, much younger than his five and twenty years. Laura recalled their childhood and the friend of her brother on whom she had an incredible crush. And though she was seven years younger than the boys, they never once complained about her tagging along. After Daniel died, Steven stepped into the big brother role seamlessly, as if he knew his place would forever be as Laura's protector.

Laura watched Steven's face scrunch and he shifted in the chair, pulling himself into a tight ball. His features looked pained and agonizing. 'I wonder what he's dreaming.' She thought. She considered waking him to ask, and then thought better of it. They were supposed to be travelling to beg the king to call off her wedding to the Earl. She recalled their decision to enter the forest, and then getting lost in the forest, but little else came to mind about the events after they'd decided to turn around.

She glanced around the deceptive cottage. At first glance, the room seemed tiny; just enough space for a table, a few chairs and the rocker. But each sweep she made with her eyes provided something else to look at; another door, a hallway, or another piece of furniture.

Steven mumbled "have to keep Laura safe. I promised." And she turned her attention back to him. He was still sound asleep and still curled in the fetal position as best he could in that too small chair. His body looked enormous in the rocker and Laura again studied the lines on his face. She had done so covertly so many times, but this morning she relished in her opportunity to do so freely. Truth be told, it was Steven that she wanted to marry, not some smelly Earl who was twice her age.

But Steven had no title and her father needed the alliance. Laura was convinced that there had to be another way to make a pact with the earl. She loved her family, but this sacrifice was too great to ask her to make. If the rumors were true, she wouldn't last very long as the wife of the earl. Each of his three wives had died mysteriously within a year of their marriage. Surely that could be reason enough to call off the whole wedding.

It took Laura a moment to realize that she was looking directly into Steven's hazel eyes. She wasn't sure when he had opened them or how long she had been staring into them. What she did know was that a warmth had spread over her entire body. Her mouth opened and her breathing came in quick gasps. Something flickered in Steven's eyes causing her heart to flutter.

"You're awake!" He blurted, righting himself in the chair. "I was so worried when your fever came on as quickly as it did." And with that, the moment had passed and the caregiver, older brother figure was back.

Laura smiled and sighed. "I don't recall what happened at all. Where are we and how did we get here?"

"You remember nothing?" Steven sounded shocked.

Laura shook her head and nibbled her lip. "I remember the cliff and then deciding to turn around and that is the last of it."

"Oh dear," Steven looked worried. He stood and walked over to Laura and placed his hand on her forehead. He sighed in relief when he touched her cool skin.

"What? Steven, what is it?"

"Well, we saw one of them." He began, sitting on the bed next to her, and Laura noticed the tremble in his voice. "The cursed, we saw it and we ran. We found this cottage and came inside. There's a woman who lives here, a witch of the southern sun. She gave us shelter. And then you got so sick, so fast. I wasn't sure if you were going to wake up. She had me give you something to drink and you slept. I stayed up half the night watching..."

"Oh Steven," she threw her arms around him and for the first time in their lives, he put his around her.

154131211.content:
Although both Laura and Steven had agreed to do “it”, neither of them knew what “it” was. They had a decision to make in terms of direction to take but more importantly, they had to decide the path from thereon; what to do next once they reached the top of the hill where they had tumbled down, or what next if they reached to the end of the slide. The fact that the slode downwards had a bit of an unknown to it scared Steven a bit. Laura, despite all what she had seen was in a comparatively much better state of mind than Steven. She for some reason still longed to go to the pit she had seen when they were moving through the forest. It made the decision easier for her. She said,

“Let’s climb back to the top of the hills, shall we?”

“And would that be because there is the pit you fancy for some reason?” Steven let out a nervous smile, “Do you think a treasure or some jewels of Tuten Khaamen kingdom awaits you there? What is up with the pit, huh?” Steven lips curved into a big smile and it released some of the tension that had been building up in him.

Laura smiled back and said, “No, hon, its not because of that Pit,” she made sure to cross her fingers as she told this lie, “It is because at least we know what awaits us there on the top of the hill while if we go rolling towards the bottom- going by the events our eyes have seen today – I would not be very surprised to see an army of Ghouls dancing as we reach there.”
The mention of the “ghoul” did the trick as Steven didn’t want to run into anything unsavory, anymore. His mind too took comfort in the fact that a known valley is better than an unknown pond. He nodded his head and said,

“Let’s move quickly, dear. Sun won’t last long,” he looked up to see the position of the orange ball of the sky, “some two hours tops I believe before the darkness is all around us. That couldn’t be pretty, can it be?” he flashed another of those nervous smiles.
Laura moved forward and clasped her hand. She said nothing in words but her eyes gave him all the support he needed. Laura was an indeed a brave woman, much like her mother who was rumored to have fought witchcraft and Ghouls.

Together, hand in hand, they started to trek their journey upwards. Laura had already started to imagine the kind of thrill she would get as she would descend into that hellish pit. She was an adventurer in the truest sense of word and this was one adventure she couldn’t let go. She was going giddy with excitement but the worst part was that she couldn’t share it with Steven for he might have takena backward step. She remembered his pale face when they saw the pit for the first time. It was if someone had ordered Steven to go down the pit all by himself. She giggled a little, thinking about it and Steven caught her smiling.

“What is that for, mam?”

“Nah – nothing,” she couldn’t think of a quick enough lie so thought it safe to just avoid it altogether.

Laura kept herself shushed as she covered the rest of the journey. Steven was too exhausted and too scared to let out a word too and essentially they kept walking in total silence – if heavy breathing of them both as they trekked up could be discounted for. From where they were now, Laura could see the edge of the hill which meant they were now some ten minutes away from the top.
At that moment itself, Laura’s eyes went towards a tree which stood some five feet away from their path. She kept looking at it for some time before moving towards it.

“Hey, hey!” exclaimed Steven, “what is up with you, now?”

She looked back at him, smiled but didn’t answer him and now ran towards the tree. For some reason, the tree had arm length cloths of different colors tied to it long branches. It was not a peculiar sight in this part of the region and they had met several similar “clothed” trees in their path, before too.

“What are you doing, Laura? Stop fooling around,” Steven yelled, not out of frustration but out of mere panic.

Laura untied one piece of red cloth tied to the low hanging branch of the tree and then another and then another. Within a minute she had nine to ten piece of cloth with her. Steven stood where he was trying to make sense of it all. He thought long and hard but nothing hit him. Just when he was about to ask Laura, Laura herself said,

“Do you know what these are, Steven?” Laura finally spoke, “These are little pieces of blessings. The passersby of the forest, tie it to the branches of the tree if their long held wishes are fulfilled. That is their way to acknowledge and thanks the Lord of the Trees which dot the path through the forest. “

What she had just said was the absolute truth. Many travelers through this Ry-Ry forest have their different reasons and motives to do so but for most of them, the reason is to be blessed by the energy of the Lord of the Trees. Hence, right near the end of their journey they take out a piece of cloth they had carried with themselves, and tie it to the branches as a token of respect and thanks for the protection they got from the Tree Lords.

“And why exactly are you taking it, Laura?”

Now came the lie from Laura, “See we were stupid enough to not bring the clothes with us. We have nothing so I am taking some of these with me so that we can do something which all the travelers do for the Lords of the place.”

Steven nodded more readily than a gullible kid could have. He was not dense in the head it was just that he was too scared to think straight, so as to say. But then, out of nowhere it hit him. He said,

“But why are you taking so many of them with you?”

Laura was surely not ready for it and she just kept moving on, without answering him, hoping against hope that somehow Steven could just let it pass. When Steven kept silent for some minutes Laura thought she had succeeded and just when she was getting comfortable with the feeling, Steven said –

“You are going to tie them together and jump into that dammit, Pit, right?”

Laura stopped where she was; not purely because Steven’s word hit her but because the pit was now six feet away from them. She turned to look back at Steven who had a look of a defeated man in his eyes. He sighed.

1541312112.content:
“Are you sure we should do this, Laura,” Steven asked, although he knew the answer to this question anyways. She had been preparing for it all the time ever since she decided to take the uphill path. Steven wasn’t mad at him – by far no – because he knew that Laura had streak of an adventurer about him. He had seen too much of it lately to ignore or hate it. Better way to cope with it was to embrace it and embracing is what he did. He walked towards Laura and hugged her, which caught Laura by surprise because she stood there, looking away from Steven hoping for a barrage of angry words; this wasn’t even the last thing on her mind.
“D-Daniel, so you are not mad at me?” she exclaimed, with joy overflowing in his eyes. She hugged him tightly and playfully swung him a little.
“Hey careful,” said Steven stepping away from the Pit a bit, “we don’t want to fall into it hugging each other. The pit aint that wide, Miss,” he smiled, a mischief floating in those black eyes. Laura playfully kicked his shins.
Steven said,
“So you must have a plan for going in, right?”
Laura gave her the blankest of look and shrugged her shoulders.
“Come on now, Laura. You mean to say that we just jump into this pit, enjoy the environment and come back? Now, there is got to be a motive, man,” Steven sighed.

Laura kept quiet for a while, as if calculating something in her head. She looked into the nothingness, counted something on her fingers and then said,
“Steven, we have precisely forty five minutes before the sunrays become too weak to illuminate the mouth of the pit. We don’t want to be in that pit with darkness surrounding her. RIght?”

Steven smirked and said, “Well if you ask me, I won’t like to be in that pit on the brightest of days either, hon,” and they both shared a big laugh. Laura looked towards the pit as he talked to Steven,
“I have a feeling – not a passing one but a real gut feeling – that in that pit we would find something which would help us to defend ourselves for the rest of the journey. I am attracted to it like –“

“Like to me?” Steven winked and they beamed a smile.
Laura moved towards Steven in an exaggerated romantic way. She placed her right hand on Steven’s left shoulder and said,
“Nothing compares to you, darling,” and flashed a pout at him. They both shared another of those hearty laughs which gave them tears.
“Enough fooling around, let’s do it,” said Steven almost catching Laura by surprise. She didn’t expect to hear it from Steven ever. She gently squeezed his palm and said,

“Thanks for doing this for me, dear. It means so much to me,” and Laura smiled at him. Steven too gave her the warmest of smiles and said,
“Let’s go,” and Laura nodded.

She quickly tied together the many clothes she had untied from the sacred tree to form something which could serve the purpose of a rope. One by one as clothes got tied together, the piece of the tied up cloth in their hands must have been some forty feet now.

“I think this should be long enough to reach the bottom of the pit. What do you say?” Laura asked Steven.

“Well, I really hope that the pit is not deeper than the near forty feet which this makeshift rope would take us,” said Steven, trying to gauge the length of the rope, “I am concerned about two things though – the strength of this,” he said shaking the long cloth structure, “ and the time we have on our hands.”

“That time part we can manage, Steven, we will not climb down for than forty five minutes, okay?”

Steven’s eyebrows went up in mild surprise - “Hey, but aren’t the Sunrays supposed to die in another half an hour or so and – “

“-and we have to get back to, correct?” Laura finished Steven’s statement and Steven nodded. “My point is that the fear of unknown is only when we climb into the pit not while climbing back up. We would have seen whatever secrets lay in the pit during that descent into the pit and thus, coming back up would be a total breeze, hon.”

Steven wasn’t really sure about it though the conviction in Laura’s voice made him agree to her point. Anyway, he knew Laura would do it so it was better that he agreed to her.

Steven searched for something he could tie one end of the cloth to and fortunately he found a tree stump some three hands away from the pit. He knew the Palomar knot – or fisherman’s knot – from his childhood visits to his fisherman grandfather. He tested the strength of the tree stump by trying to shake it with his foot.

“You aint no Superman, Mister,” Laura giggled and Steven too. He tied the cloth to the tree stump and gave it a jerk so as to do the final rehearsal and checks before descending into the unknown. She gave it to Laura who checked the strength too and then they both held it, with Laura standing nearer to the cave of mouth than Steven. That way Laura would descend first into the pit and could alert Steven of any danger or abnormal occurrence. Steven tried to reason with her to be the leading man in the expedition but had to give into the will of Laura, as usual.
“Deep breaths, everyone,” she said jokingly as he saw Steven closing his eyes, as if to pray. Steven opened his eyes and mock punched her. Together, they moved right on rim of the Pit and looked into it. A blank nothingness stared right back at them. Laura checked the tautness of the makeshift rope one last time and then threw it into the mouth of the darkness.

“Come after me,” said Laura as she hunched to his knees and then with a clean jerk slid into the Pit leaving Steven behind, wondering how could he even start to do it. He closed his eyes and his heart pounded against his chest.
“It’s wonderful here, Steven, we should live here, I think, ” said Laura, playfully, as her voice echoed in the pit and reached Steven’s ear. It made him smile – the best antidote to stress.
“Yeah, that would be the best. No Rent, no taxes. No mosquitoes,” pat came Steven’s reply as he was now stooping over the pit and climbing down into it. He heard Laura giggle right back. His complete body was now inside the pit and he felt the coldness of the pit hitting him mildly.

“Should have got our sweaters, don’t you think?” Steven’s nervousness was going away now and he again heard Laura giggling. But what he also heard was a distinct hissing sound, as if tens of snakes were ready to dig their fangs into their bodies.

“What was that, now?” Laura asked and Steven shrugged his shoulders.
“Why don’t you speak, Stevie?” that’s when Steven realized that of course Laura couldn’t see his gestures.
“I don’t know Laura. Maybe there are snakes down there in the pit. I just don’t know,” a little nervousness was now dripping into Steven’s voice, “Do you see anything in there,” he asked looking between his legs to see Laura but all he could see was an outline of her head, moving sideways, and wiggling of her body as she slid down the cloth.

“Keep going, shall we?” asked Steven.
“What is this?” asked Laura, more to herself than Steven, as she kicked a structure which looked like a door to her.

“What are you doing?” Steven held on to the wildly swinging rope because of the free kicks delivered by Laura. She didn’t reply but slid further down and so as to inspect the door like structure from up close. Steven too slid down and reached where Laura previously was and saw that curious structure on the walls of the pit, too.

“Is it a box?” asked he.

“Shall we knock?” asked Laura, as her hands scanned the wooden structure. Steven considered it for a second and nodded.

“Come on, Steven, catch hold of something,” she yelled. Steven who was just below Laura, tried the same technique as he had seen Laura do and slid his fingers into a crevice like structure just below the door level. He pushed his fingers harder into the crevice until he had a strong grip.
“You okay,” Laura asked before one final climb and Steven let out a “yeah”.
“Great,” Laura pulled her weight up to the door and held onto the handle of the door. The door flung open, dragging her with it, bruising her knees in the act. Laura didn’t even flinch because she knew if she said even a word then Steven would lose whatever confidence he had. Once she had reached the level ground, she quickly stretched her arms out for Steven who was struggling a bit with his grip.
“Come on, Steven,” she egged him on, “pull yourself up just a little bit more.”
Steven was trying his mighty hard but it was only so much he could do with those muscles of his which were not accustomed this level of physical activity. Laura hung her arm even lower but not before tying her leg to a stone which looked strong enough to support her wait. She hung even lower and now, could manage to touch the Steven’s fingers somehow. Steven looked up at Laura,.
“Laura, go back. Push back I say,” he was particularly worried about her since he could see that more than half of her body was hanging down the mouth of the pit. But Laura kept pushing on, until she could clasp Steven’s wrist.
“When I say, push yourself up, okay?”

“But Laura you can’t be doing this. You would end hurting yourself, I am –“
“Now, Steven, push,” screamed Laura and Steven gave almost jerked himself upwards to catch hold of Laura’s wrists. He used his legs to get even more thrust and gave another upward jerk to his body. Laura was pulling herself back to the top using her legs which she had wrapped around the rope to slide herself up. Slowly but surely, they were rising up towards the mouth of the door. Steven and Laura were getting the hang of it now and the climbing motion had become much smoother as it fell in sync. Some five minutes later they were lying on the floor near the door, panting, gasping for breath but giggling like little kids.

"Stop it, will you, Steven?" Impatience filled Laura's voice.
"I'm just trying to lighten things up, Laura," Steven said. "You are becoming so tense."
"I need for you to take me seriously, Steven," Laura said. "Stop with the shtick, will you. It's getting dark, and if we don't get out of here soon who knows what will happen."
Steven looked at his sister with a softened gaze. "Okay, sis," he said. "I'm sorry." He put his hand on her shoulder. "Now tell me, what's this strange feeling you have?"
"I can't explain it," she said as her gaze scanned the darkening woods. "It's like there are a million unseen eyes watching us. Do you know what I mean?"
"A million, really?"
"Steven!"
"Sorry, sis." Steven swiveled his head side to side trying to see into the darkness. "It sure does get dark fast around here, doesn't it." Turning to Laura, Steven said, "Once it's totally dark we should be able to see if there are any eyes following us. Won't eyes reflect in the darkness?"
"I kind of hope they do, and I kind of hope they won't." Laura knelt down and rested her back against a tree. "Let's wait until it completely dark and our eyes are accustomed to the darkness. Then we can move forward. We have to find our way out of here Steven."
"Steven knelt next to his sister but did not rest against a tree trunk. Instead, he scanned the area constantly, his eyes searching the deepening darkness, for what he couldn't say. A moment later, hearing Laura's rythmic breathing, Steve turned and saw that Laura was fast asleep. "How can you sleep at a time like this?" he asked. Laura didn't stir.
"Laura! Laura!" Steven nearly shouted but got no response from his sister. He grabbed her shoulders and shook her. "Laura! Are you okay?" Laura still did not stir.
Steven slowly stood and looked into the darkness. He began to shout. "Help! Anybody. Can anybody hear--"
"Shhhh." The breath of the voice stirred the hair above Steven's ear. "Be quiet or they'll hear you."
Steven's skin prickled as if stung by a thousand bees. The hair on the back of his neck rose. He slowly turned to see who it was that has whispered into his ear. But after he had made a complete circle he saw no one.
"Who's there?" he croaked, his mouth dry. "Who is it?" Still no response. He could feel a presence, like there was someone standing right next to him. He could even feel the heat of someone's body. He looked down and saw that Laura was still asleep. Maybe she's not sleeping, he told himself. Maybe she's in a trance or something.
"No, she's fine," the disembodied voice said. "She'll wake up once you and I have agreed upon what to do."
Who, w wh who are you?" he stammered. "And where are you?"
"Right here, Steven." Slowly a light formed straight out from Steven's face. It was as if someone held a flashlight five feet above the ground and when it was turned on the light fell very slowly to the ground. Inside the shimmering light, Steven could see what looked like a small woman.
"Who's side are you on?" he asked as he backed away into the darkness.
"You would leave your sister here? What if I am evil?" The light grew brighter. "Come back, Steven. Come back."

Steven tured to the right. Laura and Husky dog, Yapo, followed him.
"Wait, don't leave me alone," the goblin called loudly, you need me."

Steven and the goblin faced off head to head. "Boo!,"shouted Steven.
The goblin shivered and shook. "You're a disgrace to your race," Steven said. "You lie and you shiver and shake when someone says, "Boo!"
He turned away from the others. "I know your friend has gone for reinforcements. Get out of here."

"No," barked Yap, "Not those,they're poisonous. Here, try these blueberries over here."

Steven and Laura picked as they walked, slowing them down more. "Look," cried Laura. "Look at that tree. All of the branches are rocking."

"It's a rockabye tree," Yapo barked. "This is a good place for me to take a side trip because I'll see the rockabye tree from a distance.
You must be tired. You sleep here under the tree. I'll wake you when I return.

With that, Yapo, the Husky, took off at a run. "Yap, yap, yap," Laura and Steven could hear him barking in the distance. Then all went still.

Yapo came to a halt when he reached the ridge above a narrow valley. Looking down he saw their old pal, the goblin standing amidst a large horde of goblins carrying spears and bows and arrows. Yapo, being a manifestation of the Spirit of Winter, blew frost from his breath, and watched it spreading out in front of him. "Fin and Feather, Change the Weather," he yapped.

Snow started to fall,everything turned white. Yapo luxuriated in the cold breezes that blew his way as he watched everything in the narrow valley turn to ice. The last to freeze were the shivering goblins. All movement stopped, they were like statues.

Then Yapo barked another incantation. "Shiver and shake, change my shape. No more be a dog, Now be a horse. Instantly the furry husky
turned into a big white horse with a long mane for holding onto.

"Neigh, neigh," he tried out his voice and galloped off to find the rockabye tree with the sleeping children.
"Neigh, neigh," he stomped around on the ground until they woke."Get up, climb upon my back and I will carry you through the forest.

"It's a talking horse," Steven said. "He sounds like Yapo."

"It is Yapo," said Laura, who had an instinct about animals.

"Please, call me Relampago," said the horse, kneeling down on all four legs. "Up you go. If you hurry, we'll reach the castle by nightfall."

Steven tugged at his beard in thought. "The men in the village--they have said this forest is cursed. Could the beast be that which stalks it, hunting for our souls."

Steven smiled. "I suppose I should be listening to you, Laura. You've gotten us through this far. I see no reason to stop going." He took her hand in his and the two began slopping through the mud on their way south.

It was the third day when Steven questioned the decision. They had been traveling in a straight direction, being certain to hug one ravine wall as they headed south. Still, Steven was fairly certain he'd passed a particularly thorny looking vine at least twice. How could they possibly be going in circles? Still, he wondered.

They had subsisted by eating moss from the few trees that managed to still stand at the edges of the ravine's bottom or by munching on beetles as they passed. Steven had caught a snake on the second day, but Laura had only scolded him from leaving her side.

"Steven, don't be foolish. You could have been killed, wandering away like that. You KNOW time passes strangely here. You might have been lost for weeks, but I would not have noticed your departure until you'd returned five minutes later. Besides, we have no way of COOKING such meat, with the ravine's bottom as wet and muddy as it is. Just like a man who has spent not a day in his life in the kitchen. You leave all the cooking to me. I'm the one who will get us out of here."

Steven only stared at her. He was absolutely flabbergasted. He knew the past several days had been hard for both of them. He knew she worried for their son, for their village, even for him. But this pride, this hubris, it would keep them from finding their way out. He'd suggested they turn North ages ago.

"Laura," Steven spoke softly, as if afraid of setting her temper ablaze, "I feel as if we've been traveling in circles. Don't ask me why, I just feel it in my bones. Maybe we should have gone north? We are no closer to finding the cure for our son than we were three days ago. Maybe we have gone the wrong way."




Laura narrowed her eyes at her wayward companion. She had gotten them this far, hadn't she? It was Steven's fault they had come to this accursed forest in the first place. He had ignored her suggestions that they find another way, and when he refused and she had foolishly followed him. He leapt into this cursed ravine in the first place, got himself turned into a direwolf, and almost got them both killed! It was only her patience and quick thinking that had saved them thus far. "Steven!" she called, but he was not listening. He instead seemed to be glassy eyed, staring at a row of brightly colored flowers, daffodils, and roses, each open and shining, as if the dew that kissed the petals were diamonds rather than plain water.

Laura frowned and looked at the rocky cliff that stood between her and Steven. She had climbed down the ravine, hadn't she? Certainly she could find a vine, a foothold, SOMETHING that would bring her closer to her companion.

She paced the edges of the cliff for most of an hour, periodically calling to her partner, who seemed completely oblivious to her presence. At one point, she noticed Steven lifting something to his lips, his face glowing in pure bliss, as if he was drinking a heavenly nectar.

Laura felt her skin growing hot the longer she stood at the bottom and tried to gain his attention. She was thirsty, was she not? She deserved to feel the liquid wonderment of such nectar sliding down her parched throat, did she not? She had gotten the two of them this far, while Steven did NOTHING. Did she not deserve a rest?

A flash of light, and Laura knew what came next. That stupid beast, with its stupid diamond claws and its stupid golden scales. She rolled her eyes as it floated next to her. After her multiple encounters with it, she was fairly certain she could read its reptilian face. And right now, it was definitely smirking.

Stupid beast.

"Laura," it whispered in her ear as it gently stroked her ear with one diamond claw. "Laura, what has happened? Why has Steven find himself in such a place? We both know you are the one who has been keeping the journey steady. You are the one who does not give into temptation, who does not fade in the face of harsh choices. Why should you be down here while he enjoys himself above? While your son still lays ill? Why? Indeed, what if that garden is nothing more than a distraction meant to keep you away from the cure you ultimately seek?"

And though Laura knew by now the beast and its craftiness, she also could not deny that what it said was undoubtedly true. There was no reason to believe that Steven's current circumstances were anything other than a distraction. And so evil a distraction. Neither of them should possibly have anything so beautiful, not now, not when their son still lay so ill.

"What shall you do then, Laura?" the beast growled as it faded back into nothingness. Laura looked into her hands and saw a hardy rope, tied into a lasso. Somehow she knew, that if she aimed, she could land that lasso around Steven's limbs, drag him back away from the enchantment she must surely be under. It would be so simple. He should be here, with her, not there, not in such a disgusting mirage that would certainly only lead them to both to heartache in the end.

But then again, the beast rarely encouraged her to take the true direction. What she wanted now, more than to bring Steven now, was to be in Steven's place, enjoying beauty and sustenance and a wide-eyed ignorance of the darkness around her.

Laura could not imagine grass could be so soft, yet as Steven lay her down on the grass beneath them she might as well have been enveloped in feather down. Her blood was on fire, her skin electric, and it was as if they were teenagers again, before the trials and tribulations of the village, of famine, of parenthood.

Their lips caressed in such sweet surrender then that hours might have passed, days, and she could do nothing but gasp in his strong embrace.

Until that damnable voice purred in satisfaction in her ear.

"It would be wonderful to stay here, wouldn't it?"

She couldn't see the beast, but she could feel it, its sickeningly sweet breath upon her face, its diamond claws gently tugging her hair even as Steven did the same. She was electrified, but she was annoyed, and she didn't know what it might say next.

"You could stay here in the arms of your lover, Laura. Time in this valley passes much as it did in the ravine. You could be here weeks, months, and not a moment passes in the real world. Surely your son could wait? And when you arrive, you could bring with you news of a new family member, more children to love. You would like that, wouldn't you?

And oh, how Laura would. To fill a house with Steven's children, to love them and care for them as each day went by.

But Andrew. Her son. The child that already had filled their tiny cottage. He would die. The beast might still lie.

But the comfort here, the amazing scent of her lover around her, within her. How could she stay away?

Steven must have sensed her hesitation, for he pulled away to stare into her eyes.

"Laura," he whispered. "Where are you? What are you thinking?"

155111.content:
Laura stood, fear and frustration roiling in her stomach, as the dark woods absorbed Steven and Freya. For a time, Laura could hear Freya and Steven's movements; the rustling of tree branches, the snapping of twigs, the sound of their footsteps growing more faint with each passing second. When Laura could no longer see or hear Steven and Freya, she inhaled deeply and turned in a slow circle, taking in her surroundings.
I hope I did the right thing, she thought. But now that she was all alone in the darkness, every sound that reached her caused a new spike of fear to stab into her.
"Did I do the right thing?" she mumbled into the darkness.
"That depends on what you are trying to accomplish."
The disembodied voice seemed to fill the darkness around Laura. When it grew quiet again, Laura understood that she was imagining things. "The dark woods can do that to you," she said.
"Do what to you?" The same voice caused Laura to stumble backwards, nearly falling onto her bottom. She wind milled her arms to keep her balance, and didn't fall.
Cautiously, almost hoping she wouldn't see who the voice belonged to, Laura said in a low voice. "Hello?" She scanned the darkness. "Is anyone there? Hello?"
"Hello, yourself," the voice answered back.
Laura gasped. "Who's there?" she said quickly as she back away from where she thought the voice came from. But if she was thinking correctly, she would have admitted that the sound came from everywhere around her. But admitting that would cause Laura to think she was losing her mind. She continued stepping backward until her heel caught a tree root running along the surface of the ground. She yelped and fell backwards and prepared herself for the pain she knew would come when her bottom smacked against the ground. But instead of hitting the ground, Laura felt two arms under her own arms, which kept her from falling. Without thinking, and from force of habit, she said, "Thank you," but immediately realized there was really no one there.
"You're welcome," the voice said. "Or would you prefer what young people say today instead? "No problem?"
"What?" Laura asked, suddenly no longer fearful. "Are you some kind of English teacher or miss manners or something?"
"I can't believe you just referred to me a miss manners. I pride myself on my masculine voice.
"Who are you?" Laura asked the darkness. "And could you please take your hands off of me?" She felt the arms move away from under hers and began falling backwards again. But the hands caught her under her arms.
"Are you sure you want me to let you go?" the voice asked.
"Yes, but this time I'll know to keep my balance." When the hands withdrew from under her arms, Laura stood straight. She used her hands to slap the dust out of her jeans.
"What?" the voice asked. "You're not going to say thank you?"
"Oh, yeah," Laura said. "Thank you."
"No problem," the voice said and chuckled.
Laura suddenly felt fear again. She had almost fallen which would certainly have caused her some pain, even if not a little injury. But feeling herself being lifted and prevented from falling and receiving a painful blow to her backside, Laura had forgotten that there was not supposed to be anyone with her. She had watched Steven and Freya leave, she had been alone. So where did the voice come from? And who did it belong to?
"I suppose you're wondering who I am?" the voice said. This time it seemed to emanate from behind her.
"Yes, actually I am wondering who you are." Laura sighed. "You see," she continued, "I am alone here. My friends," she turned her eyes in the direction that she had last seen Steven and Freya before they were gobbled up by the darkness, "my friends have gone, they left me alone. So if I'm supposed to be alone...." her words trailed off as she scanned the dark woods, "then who the devil are you?"
"It's funny that you would ask that question, actually," the voice replied.
"That's not funny at all," Laura said. "Look at it logically. I'm supposed to be here alone. That means there should be no one for me to carry on a conversation with. There should be no other voices. And before? when I fell? I should have fallen all the way to the ground. But I didn't. And why didn't I, you may ask. Well, I'll tell you even though you didn't/i} ask. I didn't fall because you caught me in mid-fall. You caught me before I lost my balance and travelled all the way to the ground where my butt hitting the ground would have caused a sudden stop in my momentum which would have cause me great pain." Laura jutted out her chin. "So you see? It's not funny at all that I'm asking the question, who the devil are you?"
"Wow," the voice said. "In the future I'm going to have to be careful about the questions I ask you."
"Do you plan to ask me more questions?" Laura asked. "Because as far as I am concerned, you don't even exist."
There was a loud chuckle that seemed to come from every where. When the laughter died down, the voice said, "I have many, many, many questions I want to ask you. But if your answers are going to be as long as the answer to my first question, then maybe I'll hold off on the more complicated questions."
Laura harrumphed. "My answer to your first question was not overly long," Laura said. "I don't know what made you say a thing like that."
"I don't even remember what my question was," the voice said. "It seemed so long ago that I asked it."
Laura's face reddened with anger. "If I could see you," she said, "why, I would...I would...I just don't know what I would do." She scanned the woods again but saw no one. "And for your information, your first question was this; It's funny you should ask that question."
The voice grew louder. "You see?" the voice said. "It wasn't even a question. It was more a rhetorical statement, not really a question."
Laura stamped her foot on the ground. "Oh, I see," she said. "So now you're the question police? Now it's you who decides what is a question and what is not?" She raised her fist into the air and shook it. "I'll have you to know that I am not abrogating my rights to consider what is or is not a question. Do I make myself clear?"
When the voice grew softer, Laura thought whoever the voice had belonged to must have back away. But when he spoke, it was apparent that the owner of the voice had no, in fact, moved away or backed down.
"I wasn't questioning your authority to make your own decisions about what is and what is not a question," the voice said. "I was merely pointing out that some questions are, in fact, questions. While other statements that some people might consider a question is really not a question at all, but it is merely a rhetorical question, or a rhetorical statement." The voice grew soft again. "Am I making myself clear?"
Laura considered what the voice had just said, but she found it confusing. After all, either a question was a question, or it was not a question. She didn't believe for one minute that it was up to the questionee as to whether the words spoken by the questioner was a question or not. But Laura knew this was no time to split hairs about such mundane matters. Here she was, lost, the woods as dark as night... wait, it was night. I'm losing my mind, she told herself. But she had to get back to the pressing matter at hand.
"Look, Mr. Voice, whoever you are," Laura said with a voice dripping with sarcasm. "Let's not quibble over such dumb things as whether a question is a question or not."
"So," the voice said. "You think we're quibbling?"
"Maybe that was a bad choice of words," Laura said.
"Oh, no," the voice said, growing more insistent. "I am not going to let you off the hook as easily as that."
"Can't we just move on?" Laura asked. impatience edging her voice.
"Oh, I see," the voice countered. "When the going gets tough, the weak get going? Is that it? Well, let me tell you something, Little Miss.-- ."
"Wait!" Laura interrupted. "Did you just call me Little Miss?"
"Um, well, ahhh, no, I don't think I did." The voice stammered.
"No, I think you did," Laura said, her eyes narrowed. "I distinctly heard you say, Little Miss." Laura paused as her gaze scanned the small area where she stood. "I know that voice," Laura said slowly. "I recognize it as just well as if I had heard it yesterday. In fact, it was yesterday when I heard it."
"You are imagining things," the voice said nervously. "You and I have never spoken."
"You're following me," Laura said. "Is that it? You're following me? Stalking me?"
"No you just wait a dad-blamed minute here Little Miss." The voice raised in volume. "I have never stalked anyone, ever."
"But you have followed people before," Laura said through squinting eyes. "Haven't you?"
A heavy silence fell between Laura and the voice. Laura thought back to yesterday when she had heard this same voice. It had to be him. Who else could it be? Laura smiled with the memory of how he had tried to come on to her. Had flirted with her. And Laura had enjoyed that nearly as much as she enjoyed seeing how jealous it made Steven. Steven! Laura thought. He's probably chasing Freya around in the woods right now. Laura's reverie was interrupted by the voice.
"Okay," the voice said. "I'll own up to it," it's me."
"So you are him," Laura said. "I thought so."
"Can you give me a minute to explain?"

He rubbed his palms along his thighs to wipe away the sweat, but when he looked down he saw that where he had wiped his hands on his thighs there was a greenish glow. His eyes widened. "What the hell?" he said, astonished.
"Hehehehehe," the pixie laughed. "You see?" she said. "I have all kinds of magical powers--"
"Magical powers?" Laura said, the nervousness in her voice was unmistakable. "Steven, are you sure we should have come here at all?"
"It's too late now, missy," the pixie said, it's voice becoming louder. "You should have thought about that long before you bothered us by coming here. Don't forget that the wood is filled with trolls, and they aren't nearly as nice as I am."
"Nice?" Laura said and stamped her foot. "You call yourself nice when you demand that we follow you?"
"I have demanded nothing!" The pixie's voice had turned thunderous. "I told you that you have a choice. Follow me to safety or go it alone and find certain death."
"Steven, I'm scared."
"You're scared?" Steven stammered. "Don't you think that I'm just a little scared too?"
Suddenly, the pixie's light grew warmer, fainter, nearly translucent. She shimmered softly. "I don't mean to scare anyone," she said with a voice that was both soothing and low. "I am not here to do anything like that. I simply want you humans to understand that I am here to help you."
"Can I have a few minutes alone with my sister? Please? I won't say anything bad."
"It will be better if you don't," the pixie said. "Remember my magical powers."
Steven stared up at the pixie, and said, "Right, right," he turned to his sister and rolled his eyes. "Magical powers, let's remember that sis."
"Don't mock me, human," the pixie's thunderous voice shook the trees around them. Then it suddenly turned soft again. If you looked closely you could just about see a shape resembling a smile deep inside the light. "I mean, you shouldn't mock someone who is only trying to help you, sorry."
"Right," Steven said slowly. "So is it alright if I discuss this with my sister now?"
The shaped smile widened inside pixie's light. "Certainly. Go ahead. I was only reminding you that I can hear everything you say."
"Okay," Steven said and turned to face his sister. "Let's remember that, sis."
Laura shook her head vigorously, but there was no mistaking the fear emanating from her once beautiful eyes. Her lower lip trembled, further announcing her fear.
Steven put a reassuring hand on her shoulder. "It's okay, sis. Let's talk about what we should do." He glanced back over his shoulder and saw that the pixie had sat on the ground, her back against the broad truck of a huge tree. Steven shot pixie a smile, then turned back to his sister again.
"Okay sis, you go first," he said in a voice that was not much more than a whisper. "I want to hear what you have to say about all of this. He stared across the darkness at Laura, waiting for her to reply. But instead of replying, she just stood there trembling.
"Laura, Laura?" Steven grasped both of his sister's shoulder and gently shook her. "Laura! Come on, snap out of it or we'll never find our way out of here."
Finally, after what seemed like an eternity to Steven, Laura's body shivered and she seemed to awaken from whatever had held her captive.
"Well," she said slowly, and looked around as if seeing the dark wood for the first time. "We're still here?" she said with a tremor in her voice.
"Are you okay, Laura?" Steven asked, concern rippling his forehead. "Let me look into your eyes." He stepped closer to his sister and stared into her eyes. "Everything looks okay to me sis," he said. "Just take a minute to gather yourself--"
"We have wasted so much time already," Pixie said. "Let's get a move on, giddy up, saddle up, get along little doggy." Pixie smiled and then laughed. "I have always wanted to say that." Hehehehe.
I don't think I'm the only one losing his mind around here, Steven thought. He turned back to his sister.
"Are you okay now?" he asked.
"Yeah, yeah, I am," Laura said, but her voice spoke more of disorientation than clarity.
"So what do you say?" Steven felt more than saw the pixie's light move. He turned fearful eyes toward the light and watched it move up to the top of a tree, then higher, then higher again, then way up past the top of the tree top.
"Watch this humans," Pixie shouted.
Suddenly Pixie fell down into the tree. Steven and Laura watched pixie fall through the tree. She bounced off the branches ricocheting from one branch to the next like the small metal ball inside a pinball machine.
"Wheee!" Pixie shouted as she bounced from tree limb to tree limb. "Wheee."
Steven turned to Laura and his eyebrows rose high into his forehead.
I think that pixie is crazier than either one of us."
"I think you're right," Steven. Her eyes moved around in their sockets as her gaze followed the crazy pixie bouncing inside the tree's leaves.
"Anyway, Laura," Steven said bring her back to their conversation. "What do you think? Do we follow," he turned and glared at the pixie, "her? Or do we go it alone?"
Laura hesitated before answering, but when she did her voice was filled with uncertainty. "I think we should. I THINK, I said, remember that!"

"Yes, I suppose I am," Laura said, her eyes still glued to the pixie bouncing around the tree shouting whee, whee.
"Okay, then don't complain when I make a decision if it turns out wrong."
"Sure, sure, Steven," Laura said. But Steven wasn't convinced she had agreed.

This fog stabilizes temperature and humidity in this forest, creating a perfect environment to nurture Asia's precious primal cypress forest. The minute Laura leaned on Chilan, she lost consciousness. She didn't recognize what was happening to her. It was as if she was walking in a dream world.

When she came to lying on her back with sunbeams pouring down into her face and the soft sweet murmur of running water close by. She felt a steady throbbing at the base of her skull and a stubborn ache in her optic nerve.

She rolled onto her side, then pushed up into a sitting position.

"Tuck your head between your knees before opening your eyes," Chilan ordered. "This is an unstable world you'll need to get used to."

She did as she was told but her breaths felt like steel wedges driven in between her ribs. She groaned and forced her eyes open.

She saw that she was on now a greenest grass with thick but long and soft blades. There were pine trees in clusters along the ledges and the air was filled with the fragrance of pine.

Chilan helped her to her feet and without saying anything signaled to the point where the grass blades ended. Laura nodded and started walking with wobbly steps even though she still felt pain in her ribs. It was a river, down the bank. The water was clear and swift as it flowed between the boulders whose edges jutted out. Across the river, a cliff rose to about a thousand feet.

Now they stood at the edge of an open field. There was not another soul around. But far away at the end of the field sat an amphitheater of stone, enclosed by high cliff walls. Behind it were the mountains in whose nooks pockets of snow lingered.

Chilan said, "They are waiting for us at the amphitheater. Are you ready to get up on stage and act?"

With one snap of her middle finger and thumb, Chilan produced a long black cloak, wore it herself, and inside its flap hid laura, shadowing her face in the depths of the stiff cloth. Despite the warmth of the weather, the cloak was light enough and didn't cling tightly.

"Now, there is nothing about us to attract attention or any notice," Chilan said. "We were fine up to here, but we'll have to pass through town to reach to my place. And anything can happen on the way."

"Am I really in great danger?" Laura asked, thinking of the lizard massoids. They had to be a kind of the beasts her brother had mentioned. Thinking of her brother brought tears to her eyes.

"I'll protect you," Chilan said. "Control your emotions. The worst part will be when we pass through the black tower. Some of the lizard massoids there are invisible. The cloak is covering you well, and if you lean on my leg, I will be able to sense you and also will manage to aid your steps."

"How will I be able to walk if I don't see where we are going?"

"You'll be able to see through the flap of the cloak in front of your face. The flab is transparent on your side, but not when someone from outside looks at it."

"Like an interrogation room window," Laura said.

"I don't know what that is, but whatever happens, whatever you see, don't make a sound, and don't talk to me. If you hear me talking, don't answer, but do as I say. Hang on to me and just don't do anything foolish."

"I'll be very quiet."

Together, they walked for a while first over a bridge and on a dirt road. At the end of the road they reached to a clearing where a gated tower stood, as black and bright as polished onyx with stairs on the outside. The stairs were steep and Laura mounted them with difficulty.

"Chilan, what's wrong with you?" A screechy voice shrieked from somewhere. "Did you hurt your leg?"

Laura's stomach fluttered, when she saw the large lizard that had taken form by the gate. The beast was colossal in size covered in green scales, and looked as if it were a bloated, mutated mass of indiscernable parts. It opened its powerful jaws sideways to show toothless gums as if it were laughing.

"No time for joking. Open the gate, Talavic. I had a long day and I'm tired," Chilan said in a calm voice.

"Your desire my command, pretty Chilan," Talavic said, taking an awkward bow.

Inside the tower, archways surrounded the entry. The stone floors were rough in some places and worn-out in other places. They walked for a while, climbed up a few more stairs, then climbed down again.

"It is because of the prison under these stairs we have to walk up and down," Chilan said, as if talking to herself. "No one considers the pedestrians."

Laura opened her mouth to answer but closed it again, remembering Chilan's warning. They were now out of the tower and walking on a stone-paved road. Ahead of them, two huge lizards walked clutching each other's claws. Their scales were bright red and shone under the blazing light from the two suns.

Young love Laura thought. This had to be two young lizard massoids in love. Suddenly one lizard jumped on the other and devoured it. In the terror of the moment, an unintended sound escaped from Laura's mouth.

Chilan coughed to cover up for Laura but the lizard had turned around and was now eyeing her.

"What's the matter with you?" the lizard massoid yowled.

"A bit under the weather, I am," said Chilan. "Better stay away."

"Yech!" said the lizard-massoid and scurried to the far side of the road.

"Germaphobics, these are!" Chilan commented as if talking to herself again.

More lizard massoids showed up on their way, one minute friendly with each other the next minute devouring, but whoever they devoured reappeared unharmed from their tail. If Steven could only see them, Laura thought. Steven's image in her mind brought tears in her eyes again.

"No emotions!" Chilan whispered holding the collar of the cloak to her face. "Lizards can detect emotion."

Someone swooshed past by Laura's side a trifle briskly, and a melodious voice called Chilan's name.

Laura saw that the someone who had brushed by them was not one but three giant women, as tall as Chilan. Laura noticed images and auras flaring and then disappearing about them like a hologram.

"Good day, Chilan," said the youngest one with shiny black hair falling to her waist.

"Good day, Sedhaj, Vorolie, Aejol," answered Chilan. "Excuse me, but I am in a hurry to get ready for the next show. Maybe we can get together, sometimes."

As they walked away, Laura heard one of them comment, "Stuck-up. She's always so stuck up!"

One thing is sure, Laura thought. Giant or dwarf people never change.

"Only a short distance left," Chilan muttered and they continued walking.

"You see, you and I we have been together in many lives. Both of us took many shapes and forms, but we always found each other."

A crowd of three-dimensional shapes stood outside Marzendra’s castle.

“See, they are all ready and waiting for us,“ said Marzendra. “But I couldn’t let you go until you ate something. Earthly bodies need nourishment to exist. You must be very careful with what you put in your mouth, Laura.”
