“Your Majesty, is Miss Laura ready to come with me?” Ausout asked, his luminous black form acting like a star under the gloomy morning sky.

Marzendra turned to Laura. “Go with him,” he said. Then noticing her hesitation, he rubbed her arm gently. “It is going to be all right Laura.”

During the moments when Ausaut led Laura into his chariot, or at least the tacky, outsized globe-like thing that he called a chariot, Laura inspected him carefully. His was a strong, captivating face with sharp-angled bones, a scarred left brow, a square jaw and a cleft chin. His eyes were startling, a deep-ocean blue, the eyes of a teller of tales. His lips quirked in a half-smile when he noticed her staring at him.

Then the hatch opened, and he thrust out his hand to help her up the three steps into the enclosed part of the ugly dark green cab. Laura took it and his big, warm hand engulfed hers like a mitten filled with the softest cotton balls.

“Remember the feel of my hand, Miss Laura,” Ausout said. “Who knows, we may be cast in the dark, and if someone else holds your hand, without you seeing him or her, you’ll know it isn’t me.”

“What if it’s Marzendra?” She’d rather be holding Marzendra’s hand, she thought.

“You already know Marzendra’s, but if it’s him, he has many other ways of making himself known.”

“I don’t really know him very well,” Laura said.

“But, Miss Laura…”

“Please, just call me Laura.”

“Yes, if you so wish. I was just saying that Marzendra insists you two knew each other for a very long time, centuries in earth-time. Now, if you permit me, I must take my helmet off to adjust to the inside of this chariot.”

As soon as Laura sat down, a belt that looked like a serpent bucked her down on its own volition. She squirmed and looked at Ausout who was unlatching the helmet from the armor. His hair was short and shiny black at the top, closely curled, but at the back much longer hair in several braided portions fell out of the helmet. Immediately a hand that came out of the side of the vehicle reached to the helmet and held it as if it were a hook.

“Not bad, my chariot, don’t you think? I got the outer shell from an antique place packed with old-fashioned robots and two dimensional screen sets. I designed the insides myself. Most of it is underwater equipment, but after a few adjustments, it fits my needs in all dimensions. I value old things. When I look in the ways of the ancients, I find hope for the future.”

“Truth be told,” Laura said. “Everything is new to me, here. I vaguely recall how we ended up in the forest, my brother and I, I mean. One minute my brother was showing me his new invention. The next, we ended up in the forest where all kinds of weird things were happening.”

“I see…I think your brother must have unknowingly touched into an area of knowledge alien to both of you. The Realm is infinite in its own way, but I’m afraid, your planet is forever unreachable.”

“How so?” Laura rubbed her hands together in distress. Not returning to earth ever? The idea stabbed her right in her middle, but she only let out a tiny sigh.

“Too difficult to explain. Although we have a little time at the moment, it might not be enough. When we return, I’ll ask his Majesty Marzendra to talk to you about it. He had more earthly lives than any one of us. He says he asked for that asylum because of you.”

Each word that came out of Ausout’s mouth, generated at least ten questions in Laura’s mind, but she decided to shut her trap and let Ausout tell her things in his own way, but where was Marzendra?

“I am here,” came Marzendra’s voice. “I’m in the vehicle behind you, but I’ll always be with you, Laura. Just think of me, and you’ll hear from me.” Laura looked about her, bewildered, but also felt a certain kind of happiness reach to her face; she turned her head away from Ausout to hide her vestige of a smile.

“Your Majesty, Miss Laura is very happy to hear from you,” Ausout said. “You should see her now.”

Laura felt her face redden. Was there a way to hide her thoughts and feelings from these people?

“Yes, there is,” came Marzendra’s chuckling voice. “But you’ll have to work at it. Now I have to attend business, Laura. Talk to Ausout.”

“It seems I’ll have to work at a lot of things,” Laura said to Ausout. “How do you think I can adjust to, or if not, get out of this place?”

“Laura, please I implore you, don’t talk of getting out of here. You’ll hurt his Majesty and make him delirious with rage.”

“Do you mean I should be afraid of him?”

“Oh, no. He won’t show it to you, but he’ll take it on the rest of us, and what ends up happening won’t be pretty.”

“He doesn’t seem to be a harsh one. Is he cruel to you?”

Ausout shook his head. “He won’t hurt the tiniest insect. But especially us, the diviners of his castle, we’ll feel his hurt and it is a most painful thing to feel.”

“You mean you like him so much that his pain becomes yours.”

“More than that. His pain multiplies in us.”

“Oh, I see,” Laura said, although what she thought she understood overwhelmed her.

“Not seeing me doesn’t mean I am not with you, Laura." Marzendra’s voice said. Was he in her head again? She opened her mouth to say something, but before she could talk, the dwarf’s voice warned her again. “Don’t talk out loud and be very quiet, both of you. A mist blanketed the lake. and she noticed mountainous islands peeking at her through it. Could Steven be somewhere around here?

She retraced her steps back where she found Ausout lying in between a clumps of trees and brush with an arrow at his back.

“Ausout!”

She knelt by him and tried to undo his helmet, but she could only open it a quarter of the way, enough to see his face. He wasn’t dead.

“Shall I take the arrow out, at least?” she asked hesitantly.

Finally, she was in the deep forest again, but everywhere she looked, she couldn’t see Marzendra and no matter how often and how long she called him, she didn’t get an answer.

Then she noticed something, something different, something she hadn’t seen in the forest before. The color of the leaves on the trees.

The leaves were all purple and crimson. The forest she had come from, the forest where, on the screen, she and Marzendra had seen Steven, where the ruins were, had dark green leaves. Had she climbed down the wrong side of the mountain? Now she was really lost, and she longed for home, for her brother, and now for Marzendra, too. But she was lost, hopelessly, desperately lost.

Now, she was all alone and had to find Steven, and Marzendra, too. She had warmed up to him. She recalled how Marzendra had changed his shape just to please her, and as if something in her broke, she felt pain in the middle of her chest area. His shape of the dwarf had never bothered Laura, but why would Marzendra feel that way, when he was the one so knowledgeable and so powerful in so many ways?

As she lowered her hand from her mouth, Laura accidentally touched the star that was stuck on her chest under her light jacket. She felt a zapping sensation at the tips of her fingers.

The star thing! The star Marzendra gave me…how could I forget? Maybe I can use it in some way. But how?

She tried rubbing the star again. Yes, it was zapping all right but the zapping was much lighter than the time when she had felt herself spin around together with Marzendra when she and he were lifted into the reddish cloud. That had been more than a zapping sensation. She had felt extremely dizzy then, as their velocity had forced her down, and feeling sick, she had fallen into her bed in Marzendra’s castle, with Marzendra's sweet voice in her ears. "You are not used to speeds, are you? We have to fix that, Dear One."

But there had been no time to fix anything. Except the fact that she had found a friend in Marzendra. Well, maybe more than a friend, but who could tell so early in a relationship! At least she had been given the information that she and Marzendra had had a past together, a past the universe had erased from her mind, a fact that she had believed only half-heartedly.

Laura rubbed the star again, then looked up at the multicolored leaves on the trees. She had stopped treading about a few minutes ago, as her tears had been clouding the places where she was walking on. She certainly didn’t want to step on a serpent’s tail in this alien forest with no Ausout or Marzendra protecting her. She wiped her nose and tears on her sleeve and looked once more around her to see where her feet her taken her.

Then, it was as if the forest rose up around her, with a bright sunbeam turning every branch to purple and crimson and setting everything into a blaze of holographic prisms display while glass leaves and reeds moved and jingled against one another like sleigh bells. A little blue bird darted toward Laura and perched on a glassy branch nearby, its beady eyes staring at her. It lifted its tiny head and trilled “Odd lost girl in the fairyland, odd lost girl in the fairyland! Pull the star’s tail. pull its tail. Odd lost girl! Odd lost girl!”

Was the bird giving her a message? Should she listen? Maybe she should be polite.

“Thank you,” Laura said, and the next moment she felt astounded at her own voice zipping through the air as a stroke of bright red paint.

The bird reached out to her and touched her head with a rainbow-like claw. Just then, Laura noticed something peculiar. Her voice that had been a stroke of bright red paint had come back at her, and was swirling and creating a bird cage around her.

“No,” she screamed in terror. She certainly didn’t want to be captured.

Through the trees a tall woman all in a flowing white gown, with white hair and huge hazel eyes appeared; in her hand was a wand. “Are you here to hunt our birds?” she asked. Her words turned into light blue streaks, which the woman captured with her wand. The wand seemed to absorb all the streaks.

“No, I’m just lost,” Laura said, but as she talked her voice, still in bright red swirled on the cage making it even stronger. Laura grasped the bars of the cage and shook it to make it break.

“You see, girl,” the woman said. “Let this be a lesson to you. Don’t let your own words capture you.”

The bird on the tree chirped again. “Pull the star’s tail.”

“Hush, hush, hush!” The woman stretched her wand to the bird and the bird fell on the ground in pieces.

Laura took a step back in horror and let go of the bars of the cage. She realized she should be quiet, as this multicolored forest was a fairyland. Hadn’t the bird said so?

If so, then this woman had to be a fairy or possibly a witch in fairy form. Another thing the poor little bird had said was for Laura to pull the star’s tail, but the star had no tails. Laura put her right hand inside her jacket and pulled the points on the star one by one.

“Do you have an ailment of the heart?” The woman, fairy or witch, asked. “You are holding your heart.”

Because Marzendra is inside my heart! The thought hit her so hard that her knees buckled and she sat on the ground inside the cage. At that instant, she realized that she was holding the star and grabbing it with her whole hand instead of gently touching it or pulling on its points. As she did that she thought of everyone she ever loved, but especially Marzendra. If she ever found him again, she would ask him about the other lives they had been together, and would apologize for not remembering them, if there would ever be a waking from this nightmare.

“Marzendra,” she moaned as she shook the star that had so attached itself to her.

In the next instant, the forest with the multicolored leaves, the fairy woman, the glass pieces of the tiny bird started swirling around her and a darkness engulfed her, choking her, as if furiously alive. She struggled to breathe while a thunderous noise shook the earth on which she had been sitting, but the bars of the cage shattered and flew about her like pieces of broken glass and Laura felt herself being lifted up into a fluffy white cloud that moved so swiftly that its motion multiplied her dizziness in million folds.

When she came to, she found herself in the middle of the forest, the very forest where she and Steven had first gotten lost in, the very forest where she had gone with Marzendra to find her brother. The very forest inside where she had been frightened and terrified before felt like her motherland, her home now, in comparison with that other forest of the multicolored leaves.

She rose to her feet, her legs shaking and everything blurring about her. Her dizziness took a while to subside. When it was somewhat gone, she started walking, then stopped and put her hand inside her jacket to rub the star again. Marzendra, find me, please! Marzendra! Each sound of his name became a polished diamond, shining with no equal to its brilliance, inside her head.

She took a few more steps first to her right, then to her left, but stopped, not knowing which direction to go. That was when she heard high-pitched bells chiming steadily, and she felt the breeze warm and moist.

She walked toward the sound of the bells, but froze in place when a short form appeared through the trees with three knights behind him.

Marzendra!

She stumbled toward him.

Holding both her hands in his, he sighed. “At last, you made it.” His was a deep, heavy sigh, as if he had more to say, and he had used the sigh to keep him from saying it.

“The bird. Did you send the bird? She killed him.”

“An illusion,” said Marzendra, gazing into her face with his huge eyes. “It wasn’t a live bird. I can only send illusions into the fairyland. I was very concerned about you.”

Just the image of him, his wide curving mouth, was such a relief. Trying to pull herself together, “Ausout needs help. He’s hurt,” Laura said. “Up on a mountain where there’s a lake on top.”

Marzendra talked swiftly, as his eyes drifted to his entourage. “I know and don’t worry about him. I sent several knights after him.” He squeezed her hands in his as a comforting gesture. “Your brother we’ll find still, but you need rest, Laura. This speed sickness of yours, we have to take care of that.”

“Marzendra,” said Laura abruptly, not quite being able to hold back her words anymore, “I think, with you…I’m falling in…I’m falling in…big trouble.” This loss of control was something different, something unrehearsed. She felt the heat rising to her face.

Marzendra grinned smugly, his cheeks shaking like jell-o.

Following Marzendra’s vehicle, other vehicles had gathered and piled so tight together that their forms stacking up and sideways had taken the form of a huge fox that had just come out of the undergrowth where it was hidden, ready for action like a gathering body of a small army preparing for war.

“Are you sure you can let her in there?” Jarchial had asked.

By the way, Miss Laura, your brother is fine. We are certain about that, and we are certain to reach him in a few days or so. Ausout is found, too. His majesty told me to give you the news, so you wouldn’t worry.”

Then Marzendra had come in and sat next to her. Then slowly he had reached for her hand, which he still kept holding.

Now they were floating in the air in what seemed like a still night with three bright silver moons shining down on them and on the large stretch of water below them. The brilliance of the moon penetrated the vehicle, and shone on Marzendra’s face. What if he’s a dwarf? thought Laura. He has the most handsome and noble face, and I love it when he looks at me with those huge, magnificent eyes of his.

“Why, thank you, Laura,” Marzendra said with the softest, most loving expression on his face, and he pulled her hand to his lips. “You just made it so that this is the holiest night of my existence...so far.”

“We’ll work on that, too,” Marzendra said. “My grandmother will teach you. She is eager to meet you..”

Now that they were together, she was calling him Marz with his name, rolling it in her mouth like candy.

“Sometimes, I recall bits and pieces of other lives, at other times nothing happens, even with the chant you taught me.”

It was true; she did suddenly see scenes from other lives where she and Marz were together, sometimes dancing, sometimes fighting, but never agreeing to stay together, but she never recalled those scenes in their full sequences. Or else, she thought she was catching on to an idea or a scene as if hearing a rustle, hurried footsteps, things not quite comprehensible, or things always screened by shadows.

“We could try something else, a potion,” Corie said, hesitatingly. “I didn’t bring it up before because Marzie asked me not to. He said you’d feel bad, and he doesn’t want you to feel bad.”

“I don’t mind. I wish to get this over with, so we can go ahead with our life together without a hitch.”

“What shall I say to him, then?”

“I’ll tell him I asked for it, which I am now doing, anyway.”

“All right then, but you may not feel all that well for a little bit.”

“I don’t care,” said Laura. “May I have that potion, please?”

“I just hope Marzie doesn’t come back too soon,” Corie sighed.

The potion tasted just like chocolate milk, which was perfectly fine with Laura. Yet, later, as the pressure waves washed through her, a strange light shone in front of her eyes through the translucent walls of the castle. For some reason, Laura found herself resisting and the light began to fade gradually.

Then everything abruptly became clear to her. It was during the Victorian times when her then-father was a Lord and he was ordering her to marry someone, Duke Conte Briswald, for the convenience of some business or alliance he had in mind.

Laura, however, was in love with another nobleman, Lord Whestall, his brother’s best friend, who was Marzendra now but only a baron then. For his lower rank, Marzendra hesitated to declare his intentions, and Laura, Alexandra then, wasn’t sure that Lord Whestall returned her feelings. Although Laura made a few vague attempts toward Lord Whestall, the Lord didn’t catch on or didn’t follow through, and Alexandra had married Briswald, only to be abused by him. On his last day of life, Lord Whestall had stabbed Briswald to save Laura but was killed by him. Just like in Laura’s dream. Briswald had also died a few months later, from his wounds not healing well.

Startled and with frayed nerves and her thoughts filling with self-reproach, Laura looked at Corie. “I caused his death. He was the most selfless man I had ever known, always helping the poor, always kind to everyone.”

Corie’s eyes misted. “He still is. That life made this one possible for him. The powers-that-be granted him this eternal life, and your love for him made you two find each other for eternity.”

“I am so…so sorry,” Laura sobbed. “Not only for the last one but other lives, too. We wasted lifetimes through misunderstandings, usually all my fault. I was so selfish, so proud. I must have been plumb crazy.” As her tears ran down her cheeks, she felt a grey cloud being lifted from over her, but the cloud now had erupted and spattered in every direction.

“It wasn’t all your fault, Laura. It belonged to the family you had, especially in the last one. They had raised you like themselves. Class and control ruled them. They were slaves to the rules of class.”

“Yes, we all had exaggerated opinions of ourselves in those times,” Laura gasped, attacking her tears with her hands. “And I felt betrayed by him, too, when Whestall began devoting his attentions to my cousin.”

“As did Marzie, Whesthall then. He was timid, unable to follow through. He approached your cousin because he thought he could get closer to you through her. He also felt betrayed by you. I should have known better, too. I should have interfered since I was his mother in that lifetime.”

“I remember you, Corie. You were the kindest, warmest lady, so unlike the people around me…then.”
She blinked, her tears nearly blinding her, but she added, “Funny, I recall another thing. A poet who recited to me a few lines. I still remember that.
~Yet each man kills the thing he loves
By each let this be heard
Some do it with a bitter look
Some with a flattering word
The coward does it with a kiss
The brave man with a sword~”

“Oscar Wilde,” Corrie said. “He was prophetic, wasn’t he?”

“Yes, I think he sensed it; he sensed Whesthall’s story and mine.”

She began sobbing again, and finally she blacked out unable to handle this much emotional tsunami. When, she couldn’t tel,l but she felt the strong touch of Marz’s hand. When she opened her eyes, she saw the care and panic in his eyes.

“Gran, you gave her the potion, didn’t you!” He swiped up Laura and drew him to her. “It doesn’t matter. Laura. That stuff is dead and gone. We are alive and together now, forever.”

“I’ll make it up to you,” Laura sobbed, as a fierce pleasure filled her with just being held by him. “And it isn’t Corie’s fault. I asked her for the potion.”

“Now, wipe your tears, Laura,” said Marzendra. “And I don’t want you trying to make up for anything to anyone, let alone me.”

“But…but…but…” Laura sobbed.

“No buts here, my dear.” Marzendra hugged her. “Our lifetimes are our teachers, sometimes strict for our own good. The good thing is neither of us will return to earth, as much as we appreciate its teachings. Now is our chance together to make this realm as beautiful and as spiritual as we can. Don’t you agree?”

Laura nodded. Marzendra continued. “I have some good news for you. Your brother is found. My knights rescued him from Chilan’s people. They were holding him hostage and were planning to exchange him.

“Exchange him? For what?”

“You. They wanted you. They could do so much with your purity. Why, with what they could pump into you, Chilan alone could become the heiress to the throne after her supervisor.”

“Supervisor? She had a supervisor?”

“Yes, the great lizard-knight. He was a friend of mine at one point, but then he followed his lizard brain and he turned ugly.”

“My brother, where is he? I must go, rescue him.”

“Happy to say that, my love, Steven is on his way to here. When I was away from you for a while, I was casting a spell on the place where he was being held, so my knights could penetrate through and find him. It was quite difficult as his quarters were underground and impenetrable, but we managed it, somehow, without hurting him or anyone, even his most powerful guards. Something I did put them all to sleep, and sleep they will for a very long time.”

“What if when they wake up and find Steven gone and they come after us? Oh, Marz, I don’t want you or Corie hurt or anyone else.”

“That won’t happen easily as I left a dummy who looks just like Steven in his place, a moving, talking dummy. The only way they could find out if Chilan were to go see him, and that too, is highly unlikely, because Chilan hates underground anything.”

“You said, you left a dummy. You went in there, for Steven?”

“Yes, but it’s fine. Everyone was snoring and as the invisible dwarf I turned myself into again, even the ones among them who dabble in magic could not see me. If they did, they might have thought they dreamt it.” He threw his head back and laughed heartily.

When he stopped, Laura gave him a speck on the cheek with appreciation. Then she looked at him, looked through him, beyond him, her face intense with joy as if she were under his spell for good.

“Oh, now this is something I like, Laura,” Marzendra cooed. “Your love will lead us into new worlds, irresistible and intoxicating, all the way to the throne.”

Laura leaned against his chest. “I’ll go anywhere you take me, Marz,” she said. “But I’d like to see my brother, first. By the way, isn’t he a pure one, too? He doesn’t know any magic that I know of.”

“Oh, but he does. How do you think you and him suddenly found yourselves off of the earth and in this realm?”

“It was an accident!”

“It was no accident, Laura. Although he didn't know about it either, he had been thought in another lifetime, not on earth, but in a nearby galaxy, Alpha Centauri to be exact. I had to find his records in order to help him.”

“He had a lifetime in another place other than the earth?”

“He wasn’t the only one. We all did. But he and I were taught magic. You refused it.”

“Stupid me!”

“No, it wasn’t stupid. One can always learn magic, but reaching success without magic shows a higher calling, Laura. When one learns to do things without the hocus pocus magic, that person has purity. Then magic is divinely given to that person, as I believe will be given to you. When that happens you’ll be stronger than me.”

“But you are very strong. How did that happen, Marz?”

Marzendra remained silent for a moment. Then he replied. “I’ve never used my magic for negative things and never just to hurt another being. This made what I knew more powerful.”

“And because you also believe that everyone should be encouraged to find happiness. I noticed it in your interactions with your knights. Even the way you treat your enemies is gentle, Marz. No, I could never be as strong as you.”

“We’ll see what our existence brings,” replied Marzendra with a patient smile. “The thing is, we are together and for eternity. This is the greatest gift of the universe to me, Laura, and the end to all my sorrows.”

As she watched Marzendra’s face, Laura began to understand the complexity of this man, of everything he did with passion. There was a dramatic flair in his words, actions, and conquests. Each had a perfect sense of rhythm and timing. Thus, she was reassured that what seemed to be separate interests were, in fact, one and the same. This must have been the miracle of eternal life she thought.

While she was thinking, she didn’t notice the sudden appearance of a knight.

“Your majesty, your awaited party has arrived!”

“Let them in, Lieros, what are you waiting for!”

When Laura turned toward the entrance and sighted Ausout and Steven together, she let out a surprised scream and staggered back. Marzendra held her and walked with her toward the two men. Ausout was still in armor, but Steven had stars and ribbons on the chest of the jacket he was wearing.

“Welcome home, my two most favorite people,” Marzendra said with a satisfied look on his face. “I’m glad you made it through the realm safely.” Then, he turned to Laura. “I have another news, my love. Your brother has agreed to become one of my knights. We’ll all be together, now.”

Laura ran to Steven and hugged him, then stretched her hand to Ausout and said, “Thank you, knight Ausout for guarding me and putting yourself in such danger. I’m forever in your debt.”

Ausout bent in deference. “Your desire is my command, my princess,” he said.

“Princess? Just when did you turn princess?” asked Steven.

Laura smiled and held her hand to him to show the ring on her finger. Marzendra’s ring.

The End

"Then what are you?"

"I am rock. I was weaned at the breast of mother earth, raised in the upheaval of earthquakes. I am as old as time has been measured. I am the spirit of the mountain, Chilan."

Laura dropped the broken limb she was moving from the front of the door. "A mountain?"

"Not a mountain - the spirit of the mountain. My outer core still exists in the mountain range between my sisters, but my spirit has come to help solve the turmoils of war."

"But how - I don't understand."

"Throughout history, there have been upheavals. Some physical which gave birth to the mountains, the rivers, the valleys. These, while sometimes destructive were also constructive. Since the creatures of the land became sentient - man, trolls, goblins, elves - there have been other upheavals. Social upheavals, political upheavals, intellectual upheavals. All of these, up until now, have also contained the seeds of destruction and construction. Great things have been created in the shadows of these upheavals."

"You said 'until now'."

"Ah yes, I am glad you caught that. I knew you were astute. No wonder you are the chosen one."

"Chosen?"

"More about that later."

"Forces are coming together to create an alliance. They will cause the ultimate upheaval. It is they who call me monster, for as I have told you, they see what they are. When pure evil forces an upheaval, no good can come off it, unless, of course, good triumphs."

"But surely good will triumph. Is there not leaders, troops to meet this foe?"

"That is our dilemma, and why I have come to aid you."

"This is the second time you have referred to me as if I am some great hope, but I am nothing, a nobody. Why would I have a role?"

Chilan laughed. "Oh child, you are far from a nobody. You are the one that the oracles have foretold for centuries. Songs and poems have been written in your honor. Stories have been crafted about the bravery you will someday show. You, yourself, and all your friends and family have sung of the promises you bring."

"Yes, we do, but this is not fiction, and I will tell you more when we rest this evening." Chilan continued to reweave the hut's roof.

"I care not for this type of story. I think when we are done, I would like to sleep."

"Very well, little one, great revelations take time to sink in. Soon, you will need and want to ask me more. But if there is one thing a mountain spirit learns to do, it is to bide our time and mind our tongue until the moment is right."

With that, the two women continued their tasks in silence. Just as the moon was rising, Chilan proclaimed her work finished and helped Laura remove the last of the debris from the front of the door. After entering the hut, Chilan dusted off the top of a trunk in the middle of the room, opened it and pulled out stuffed mattresses.

"How did that fit in there?"

"Remember not all is as it seems, Laura." Chilan brought out two pillows, blankets, and when she set these up on the ground, she returned to the trunk and brought out two bowls filled with steaming liquid, and two tankards frosty and filled with ale.

"I must be dreaming."

"Hush, child. Eat well. You have many things to learn about this world and what is possible. This is a mere trifling. Then sleep. Tomorrow, we will begin your training."

155333.content:
Chilan watched as Laura, surrounded by a mob of trolls disappeared into the dark mosaic of foliage. She turned to the four trolls who had been assigned to stay back with her to keep an eye on her.
"How long will we have to stay here," she asked the troll who seemed to be in charge.
Mateus wore a bright red shirt over a loose fitting pair of pants made out of sail cloth. The soles of his sandals had been cut from an old tire and the tire treads could still be seen under the sole. The sandals were kept on his feet by strips of leather wound over his ankles and calves. His blond hair was combed back and curled over the collar of his shirt.
"Until we're told to do something else," Mateus said. Mateus had been silent up until this point, but his voice was filled with authority. "We have our orders and we intend to obey them." The three other trolls who stood next to him nodded their agreement.
"What if I told you that you are making a mistake?" Chilan said as she looked from one troll to another, stopping her gaze on Mateus. "What if I convinced you that Laura is in more danger without me than she is with me?" Chilan paused and stared into the dark confines of the forest. "Will you at least listen to what I have to say?"
The four trolls bumped their heads against each other, as they leaned in to discuss the matter. As they whispered, Mateus looked up over his shoulder to make sure Chilan didn't try to get away. After several minutes of whispered murmurs, Mateus stood and, staring at each of his comrades, said, "Okay, let's take a vote." He paused and held up his hand with his fingers outstretched, ready to take a count. "Who says yes?"
Two of the trolls held their hands up high. "Me, me," they said in unison.
"Okay," Mateus said. "Who votes no?" He waited.
One small, white gloved hand slowly rose into the air above the head of a troll wearing a green shirt with a torn sleeve, a pair of red pants, and a haggard looking pair or Nike sneakers that were once white. The troll looked around, and when he noticed his was the only hand raised, he began to cry and whine.
"Oh, man," he whined. "I never win at this game of voting. If I had known that you guys were going to vote no, I would have voted no as well." He wiped at his eyes as the other two troll gathered around him. They patted his back and offered him kind words about not being disappointed.
A troll wearing a bright yellow shirt and green pants jumped up and down and grunted. "I want to change my vote, I want to change my vote," he kept calling out."
Mateus looked at him and frowned. "Why on earth would you want to change your vote?"
"Because I don't want my friend, Angus, to lose, that's why," the troll with the yellow shirt said. "He's my friend, and if I change my vote from yes to no, then he won't feel so bad."
"That is so nice of you," Angus said to the yellow shirted troll. "But I want you to vote the way you think you should, not the way you think will make me feel better."
"Okay, okay," said the troll with the red shirt. "I want to change my vote too." He gazed at Angus with a soft stare. "See, Angus, you're not a loser. You have friends that care about you."
Angus wiped at the tears flowing over his round cheeks. "Thanks, guys. You're all true friends. I think--"
"Enough!" Mateus shouted and held his hand out to quiet the trio of talking trolls. "You're all losers if you ask me," he said. Troll grumbles filled the air around Mateus as he scanned the area around him.
"That's a terrible thing to say," the troll in red trousers said.
"You should be ashamed," another troll said as he wiped his sweaty palms on his green pants.
"Would you all please stop," Mateus shouted. "I have something important to say here."

The voices of the other three trolls faded away, and three pairs of eyes fell on Mateus.
"Okay, Mateus," the trolls said in unison. "It's your turn to talk."
Before Mateus could say anything, the troll in the yellow shirt said, "Where's Chilan?"
"Where's Chilan, indeed?" said the troll in the green shirt.
"Hey, she's missing," said the troll wearing the red shirt.
"I have finally gotten your attention," Mateus said to the trio of trolls taking their time looking around. "I've been trying to tell you that Chilan has hidden herself from us."
"But why would she do that?" Angus said. "Didn't she know we meant her no harm?"
"Yeah, didn't she know that?" red shirt said.
"Didn't she?" Yellow shirt said.
Mateus sighed long and loudly as he looked at each troll in sequence. His gaze stopped on Angus.
"I don't know what she thought," Mateus said. "But if she escapes that could put Laura, and maybe even Steven in danger." He took a deep breath, and continued. "It could be dangerous for the trolls that took Laura to look for her brother, too."
"What should we do?" asked Angus.
"Should we do something?" yellow shirt asked.
"We can't do nothing," red shirt said.
Mateus, impatience filling his voice when she spoke, said, "Let's not quibble about the details. We all agree that we have to find Chilan, right?"
"Right," Angus said.
"Correct," red shirt replied.
"Can we take another vote?" yellow shirt asked.
"NO!" Mateus shouted. Then more quietly, he added, "No, no more voting. We have to break up into groups."
"But there are only three of us...well, four if you count yourself."
"Of course I count myself," Mateus said. "Why wouldn't I?"
"Well, you're the boss, the man in charge, the big honcho, the man of the hour, the person what is in charge, the big--"
"Okay, okay, I get it, Angus." Mateus's voice was getting testy. It was becoming apparent that he had been left with three of the lousiest, laziest, loneliest, lamentable trolls in the group. But he refused to allow that to keep them from their appointed rounds.
"Here's what we'll do." He put his forefinger to his lips as he spoke. "We'll break up into four groups and search for the ghost, Chilan."
Angus held his hand up tentatively.
"Yes, Angus," Mateus said.
"Ah, well, you see, boss," Angus smiled shyly. "A group is made up of more than one person." Angus forced himself not to laugh. "And if we break up into four groups, than each group will consist of only one person."
"So?" Mateus asked as he eyed each troll for a second.
"Well, it's simple really," Angus said. "If a group has only one person, then it's not a group."
The other two trolls nodded their heads vigorously as they agreed with Angus's statement.
Mateus shook his head back and forth slowly. What am I getting myself into, he asked himself.
Mateus's shoulders sagged as he let out a long exhale and forced a smile onto his circular face.
"Okay, you guys win." He looked around the small clearing where they stood. "We will all go separately..." he waited to see if anyone had something to say about his plan so far. A moment later, when no one seemed to object, he continued. "That means we can go east, west, south, and north, each one of us taking a different direction, and look for Chilan."
"I want to go east," red shirt shouted and jumped up and down.
"No, I want east," yellow shirt said and pushed red shirt.
"Hey, watch your hands," red shirt said and pushed his red clad chest against yellow shirt.
"STOP!" and exasperated Mateus shouted. "I will assign a direction for each of you to follow." He glared at the trolls as they began to grumble amongst themselves. Slowly, ever so slowly, the grumbling stopped when Mateus said. "If anything happens to our friends because we couldn't put a search together, we will be drummed from the troll village. Everyone fell silent, giving Mateus the idea that he could finally organize a search for Chilan.

"You," Mateus pointed to Angus, "You will go east." He turned to red shirt. "And you will go west." Red shirt began to complain, but Mateus's glared shut him up. When quiet resumed, Mateus looked at yellow shirt and said, "You go south, and I will go north." His gaze locked onto each troll for a moment in turn. "Okay, then, let's get going."
As the trolls worked their way in the direction they had been assigned, Chilan looked down from high up in the locust pine where she hid among the prickly branches.
Fools, she thought. They couldn't find their heads if I placed a paper bag over them.
As the clearing below her emptied of trolls, Chilan slowly drifted down to the ground. As her feet felt the ground under her toes, Chilan looked around. Why wouldn't they believe her, she asked herself. She meant no harm to Laura, and especially not to Steven. She felt butterflies take flight in her stomach when she thought his name. Steven. There they were again, the butterflies fluttering inside of her.
Chilan had kept her feelings for Steven secret, but she knew that at some point she would be unable to control her emotions. Steven, with his grey eyes flecked with gold, his high brow suggesting superior intelligence, and the narrow chin she thought of often. But it was his wide mouth that had caught her attention. "And those pearly white teeth that showed when he smiled," she mumbled.
She realized that hiding her feelings meant the trolls had no idea how she felt about Steven, so why wouldn't they think she meant him harm? If only they knew, she told herself.
Chilan could hear the trolls thrashing around in the forest. "They're not a quiet bunch," she mumbled to herself. "If they were really looking for someone they'd never find them because they so easily give their position away."
Chilan took a deep breath and it looked like someone had shook out a bed sheet and let it billow into the air. She didn't like being a ghost, but she also knew that there was hope for her yet. She had heard that if she were to save the life of a troll she might be considered to be allowed to live on earth again. As a living, breathing person. She knew that would be the only way she and Steven could ever be together.

Chilan had not felt this free in as long as she could remember. She loved the feel of the air currents under her body as she soared through the clear sky. The wind in her face pushed her long black hair back against her head and caressed her face.
Why have I not done this more often? she asked herself as she glided over the tree top shimmering in the sun. She banked left and felt herself go weightless in the breeze. A moment later, she banked right and flew out of the forest and watched the ground beneath her change from the leafy green of the forest to the white sand beaches, their jagged lines ending where the blue water began.
Chelan loved the freedom of being up here. Up here in the clouds and the wind and the air currents she was alone, a solitary figure that was invisible to anyone who might look up. Oh, she knew she was making the normal swishing sounds, how could she not? After all, the law of physics still worked for ghosts, didn't it? She was sure of it.
Chilan was enjoying herself so much that she nearly forgot why she was up here. But slowly her reverie was replaced by the reminder that she needed to find a troll. It was the only way to save herself and Steven. As her thoughts returned to Steven, Chilan felt the butterflies in her stomach take flight.
"Love," Chilan mumbled. "Where would the world be without it."
She shook the image of Steven out of her head and concentrated on finding a troll. She reminded herself of her plan.
She had to find a troll, lure him into a dangerous situation, and then swoop in and save him. Easy, peesy, extra cheesy, she told herself and giggled. "Yes," she mumbled into the warm air. "Love can make us behave in a silly way."
She turned away from the ocean, reluctantly, and swooped back toward the forest, it's soft, power puffs of green slid by below her before long. She banked left and flew for a while, her eyes searching below for any movement. Not seeing any, Chilan banked right and soared just above the tree tops. She was beginning to think she wouldn't find a troll, but just then she saw one.
It was his red checkered shirt that gave him away. Chilan watched him scurrying across the ground, his short legs churning as fast as they would go. As she watched him, Chilan had a thought. I wonder what he's running from? Is he being chased, or is he just doing wind sprints?
Chilan decided to make a three hundred and sixty degree turn and come up behind the little fellow. Just as she completed her maneuver and was coming out of her turn, she saw it. She nearly missed it, its brown color blended in with the surrounding trees. He wasn't as fast as the troll was, but his pace was fast, more direct, and relentless. It took a moment before Chilan could identify what it was, but eventually she determined what it was that was following the little troll.
"I haven't seen one of those in years," Chilan said through a gasp. "Why, it's a double-breasted, brown-legged, horny-toad, roadrunner. Not the traditional road runner, oh no, this was a special species, one that was bred to be a killer. These roadrunners were called, dangerousity non-ambiguosity, headstronganous, roadrunners. They were smart, they were crafty, and they could track a man, or a troll, without any trouble. As Chilan watched the actions taking place below her, an idea blossomed in her mind.
The danger she saved the troll from didn't have to be made up, fictitious, or fake. The danger could be real. As a matter of fact, it would probably be better if the danger were real. Certainly the troll would react more naturally to a real threat.
"This might just work out better than I thought," Chilan mumbled. She took a deep breath that seemed to immediately leach out of her body, and then she banked left and made for the upper branches of a tall horse chestnut tree.
Chilan's speed dropped quickly as she alighted on a strong upper branch where she could see both the troll and the roadrunner, it's stout beak pressing into the wind ahead of it. She tracked forward of the roadrunner and found the troll. Little red shirt was rally making tracks, his little feet were just barely touching the earth as he scurried along. Chilan knew she only had a few minutes to come up with a plan that would save the troll. But she didn't want to hurt the roadrunner. This genus were nearly extinct, and she didn't want to add to the problem of a dwindling herd of roadrunners. Especially this breed.
It was the sound of the water falls that gave her the plan she would use.
"Yes," Chilan pumped her fist into the air. "It will work, I know it will." She gave one final pump of her nearly transparent fist and flew into the sunlight, disappearing in its rays.
Down below, running along the forest floor, the red shirted troll continued to scamper. He ran along fallen logs, hoping to hide his scene by not touching the ground. Jumping down from the logs, he ran through sage brush, wild roses, and onion plants that had been growing untouched for years. But he was beginning to tire. He could feel the energy in his legs beginning to give out. His breaths were beginning to come in gasps. His forehead was slick with sweat. He wanted to stop and rest, just for a minute, just to catch his breath, but the sounds coming from behind him gave his the energy to keep going.
Red-shirt was a hunter troll, and he knew all about the species of roadrunner pursuing him. He knew, for instance, that the dangerousity, ambiguousity, roadrunner could run for days. He also knew that if that genus of roadrunner were to catch him, it would mean his end. These roadrunners, while nearly extinct, would run until they dropped once they had gotten the scent of a troll. Red shirt felt fearful by the knowledge of what would transpire if he were caught. But that knowledge was also the impetus for his pushing himself to the limit.
"If'n I coulda just a minute take for a breaff," red shirt said. "that's a mean i'm a good fur to run mooa." A dead log lay on the ground ahead of old red shirt, and it would suspend him above the ground for forty feet. Red shirt made a dash for the log jumped up on one end, and then scampered along the rotting bark, his feet and legs a blur as he sped along. When red shirt jumped down from the other end of the rotting log, he dared a glance back over his shoulder, and he could see the roadrunner's head bobbing up and down as he tore after him.
Chilan knew she had to hurry if her plan was to work. She formed herself into a narrow line, like an arrow, so that she became more aerodynamic. With less wind resistance she was able to pick up speed and zoomed along quickly. She couldn't remember the last time she had gone so fast.
Zoooommmmmm, she went, flying soundlessly through the air. She had to make a slight course correction but once she did she found herself right behind old red shirt. "One final adjustment, Chilan," she mumbled. "And then you've got him."
As Chilan flew over the ground at break neck speed, she opened her mouth and waited until the last possible moment, and then she struck. Grasping red shirt by his suspenders, Chilan closed her mouth around the little guy. She heard his scream as she soared up into the sky. She wanted to tell him that he was safe, at least for the time being, but if she opened her mouth the troll would fall to earth. Chilan didn't even want to think about what old red shirt would look like when he splattered against the ground. She had no choice but to allow him to believe that he was in mortal danger. And in away, Chilan told herself, he is in mortal danger.
Chilan swooped high into the sky with a screaming red shirt dangling from her closed and locked jaw. She thought that if she tracked back over the dangerous roadrunner, old red shirt would be able to see that Chilan was only trying to help. She banked hard left and drifted into a one hundred and eighty degree turn, and was soon gliding past the roadrunner. The roadrunner had stopped his pursuit and was staring up at Chilan.
"I'll bet you're hoping I drop him," Chilan mumbled, careful not to open her mouth and drop old red shirt. From his position directly in front of Chilan's eyes, old red shirt stared at Chilan. He blinked, and his Adams Apple bobbed in his throat when he swallowed. He blinked again and a smile slowly stretched across his lips. Chilan was sure he understood that she was only trying to help him. But old red shirt put that thought to rest when he reached back behind his head and then drove his finger into Chilan's eyes.
Chilan couldn't believe what was happening. Her screech must have been heard all over the forest.
Dang, that hurt, she told herself needlessly, after all, she had felt it so she knew it hurt without her having to tell herself that it did.
Chilan, now looking through only one eye, soared high to the top of the horse chestnut tree where she had sat earlier. She gently released old red shirt and waited while he found his balance.
Red shirt looked down at the ground so far away. "You,me a gotta me outa here," he said, his voice soft and earnest. "I cnat live so uppity her. too uppity forme to stay."
Chilan shook her head, and said, "Do you have a better plan?"
Old red shirt nodded his head vigorously, and said, "youza betcha."

1553332.title: Chilan searches for the trolls.

choices: A loud noise pulls Chilan from her reverie.
It isn't Tilly and the guys when Chilan opens the door.
Chilan senses something flying above her.
1553333.content:
Chilan soared high above the tree tops looking for a troll she could lead to danger, so that she could save him and return to a living, breathing, flesh and blood human again. It was the only way she could be with Steven again, and she was willing to try anything.
As his name passed through her thoughts, Chilan felt the butterflies in her stomach take flight. Her skin warmed and it felt like a thousand bees were stinging her. "If this is what love feels like," she mumbled into the cool air around her, "maybe I should just leave it alone."
But Chilan knew she wouldn't leave it alone. She wanted to experience love again, the feelings of having someone care about you, knowing that you mattered, knowing that you were important to someone.
As she let herself drift with the air currents, Chilan thought back to when she was in love; with him. Oh, how wonderful it was to feel that most sacred of emotions.
Sure, you had to put the other person first, always their wants and desires put before yours. It was a feeling she craved more than anything.
She thought about how, when you were in love, you thought of the other person first. Some people called it sacrifice, but she never felt like it was a sacrifice when she made sure he was happy. She didn't think of it as a chore when he came home from work and his back and neck hurt and she'd spend an hour massaging his sore muscles. No, letting her hands slide across his warm skin was never a chore.
As she drifted along with the clouds, Chilan rummaged back through her memories. The lane surrounding the lake of her memories was gauzy, as if a fine mist of rain, or maybe fog, had obscured her older memories. But she finally broke through and there they were, clear as a bell or a summer afternoon sky.
She remembered the night they met, and how they nearly didn't.
It had been a long day, and all she could think about as she made her way home was how much she wanted to crawl into a tub of hot sudsy water and sip a cool glass of the red wine her Italian neighbor made in his basement. Sure, it was strong, and it didn't take much for her to get a buzz from drinking it. But tonight a buzz was exactly what she thought she needed.
An hour later, Chilan lay in a tub full of hot, sudsy water. The tub was long, but shallow and her knees poked up out of the water like two small volcanic islands. Two scented candles filled the bathroom with their sweet smell. She had one arm draped over the curved edge of the tub, the other held the stem of a wine glass that was half full. As she lay there she felt the days troubles evaporate.
She nearly shot straight out of the tub when the phone rang/
"Chilan," Tilly's excited voice filled the phone's receiver. "You have to help me, you just have to."
Chilan took a long, deep breath and said, "Tilly, how are you?" Her attempt at calming her friend down were wasted. Something important was going on in Tilly's world, and it had all of her attention. Chilan knew it would be best to just go along and let her friend follow the script she had probably been practicing all day.
"What's so important that I have to help you with?" Chilan said.
"Oh. My. God." Tilly said each word distinctly. "He is so beautiful. I can't wait for you to meet him."
"But why do you need me for that?" Chilan asked. "I mean, if he wants to go out with you he'll ask. If he doesn't ask you, then you ask him. It's the 2000's, my girl friend, it's okay for a girl to ask a guy out."
"Oh, I know, Chilan," Tilly said, disappointment filling her words. "It's just that he won't go out with anyone because his cousin is in town and he doesn't want to leave him on his own. He doesn't know anyone around here."
"So what exactly do you want me to do?" Chilan asked. She knew the answer to her question. She had only asked it so that she'd have time to think of an excuse.
"Well, it 's simple, actually, Chilan." Tilly's voice had suddenly slowed down. Intrepid was the word that came to Chilan's thoughts. "I can get my guy to ask me out, but you would have to be with his cousin."
Chilan could picture Tilly's fingers tightly wrapped around her phone, her knuckles white.
"Not a blind date?" Chilan said. "You know I hate blind dates."
"Oh, but my guy is so beautiful. And I just know you'll like his cousin."
Chilan had let out a long, loud exhale, hoping Tilly would get the subtle hint that Chilan wasn't interested. But Tilly missed the cue.
"Do these guys have names?" Chilan asked.
"Of course they have names, silly," Tilly said. "Everybody has a name. Why would you think I would date someone who doesn't have a name?"
Chilan wanted to interrupt Tilly to tell her that yes, she knew the guys had names. But interrupting Tilly meant that when Tilly resumed the story she would have to begin all over again at the beginning. So Chilan just went with it.
"Okay, Tilly, I'm glad they have names." Chilan rested her head against the curved edge of the tub. "Can you tell me what their names are?"
"Of course I can," Tilly said and paused. When Chilan said nothing, Tilly finally said. "Oh, you want to know their names, right?"
"That would be nice, Tilly," Chilan said. "It might be easier to talk to my date if I know his name."
"So you'll do it?" Tilly's voice squealed so loud Chilan had to hold the phone away from her ear. "Oh, goodie, goodie, gum drops."
"The names, Tilly," Chilan said, "What are their names.?"
"Oh, that," Tilly said in her sing song voice. "Your guy's name is Freddie. My guy's name if Steven."
Chilan hated the name Freddie. As she felt the warm water swirl around her, she took another sip of the velvety wine. The last thing she wanted to do was get out of the tub and go meet some guy who said his name was Freddie. But Tilly was a good friend and it has been a long time since her break up with Greg. Greg was an abuser, a loser, and a hoser. The guy had broken Tilly's heart and it had taken he a long time before she was willing to go out with anyone. Was it really too much to ask from a friend? Go out with a guy named Freddie so Tilly could go out with a guy named Steven.
Chilan pressed the phone to her ear. "Okay, what time and where will we meet?"
"You are the bestest of friends, Chilan," Tilly squealed into the phone. "We can meet at your place at eight. Is that okay?"
Chilan looked one more time at her glass of wine, dipped her fingers into the warm water, and sighed. "Sure, Tilly, eight o'clock at my place. I'll be with Freddie. But you owe me, big time."
"I can't wait," Tilly shouted into the phone. "I love you. I love you. I love you."
Chilan put down the phone and let her body ease back into water that was quickly becoming cold. "Yes, you certainly do owe me," she mumbled.
Of course, Chilan had no way of knowing that Tilly would repay her favor, and soon. And she had no way of knowing right then that the favor Tilly returned would cost her and Chilan their friendship.
Chilan sighed loudly and stood in the tub and lines of water ran down her warm skin and into the tub. Stepping out, she wrapped a towel around herself and left the bathroom.
"Sure," she mumbled as she pulled the towel tighter around herself. "Tilly gets the guy name Steven, and I get the Freddie. Sometimes life just isn't fair."
An hour later there was a knock at Chilan's door.
